(Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Hezbollah and Israel Trade Fire, Further Testing Cease-Fire
abstract: Both sides have accused each other of violating the deal; Hezbollah fired into Israel for the first time since the truce took effect, and Israel responded with airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah fired at Israeli-controlled territory on Monday for the first time since a cease-fire was reached last week, prompting Israel to launch a wave of airstrikes in Lebanon, as each side blamed the other for violating the tenuous truce.

headline: Kendrick Lamar’s ‘GNX’ Rockets to No. 1 on the Charts
abstract: The rapper’s surprise LP tops Billboard’s album and singles charts, where “Squabble Up” blocked Shaboozey’s “A Bar Song (Tipsy)” from a historic 20th week of dominance.
lead_paragraph: You never know when Kendrick Lamar will put out a new album, but when he does, it’s big news. His latest, “GNX,” is no exception, dominating rap’s fandom discourse and immediately taking over Billboard’s album and singles charts.

headline: More Arctic Air and Snow Are on the Way
abstract: Snow has been piling up for days around the Great Lakes as temperatures remain bitterly cold in the eastern United States. Another storm system brings the threat of more.
lead_paragraph: A blast of cold air is settling into the East Coast of the United States this week, even as people across the Great Lakes region continue digging out from a dayslong round of lake-effect snow that snarled Thanksgiving travel.

headline: How You Can Help People Get Good Jobs
abstract: Market forces aren’t enough. These three organizations help get more people into good jobs.
lead_paragraph: This newsletter is part of Times Opinion’s Giving Guide 2024. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: New York Philharmonic Looks to Philadelphia for Its Next Leader
abstract: Matías Tarnopolsky, who manages the Philadelphia Orchestra, will come to New York as the Philharmonic works to recover from a trying period.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic announced on Monday that it had chosen a new president and chief executive: Matías Tarnopolsky, who currently leads the Philadelphia Orchestra.

headline: Protesters Clash With Police Outside Georgia’s Parliament
abstract: Thousands protested outside of the Georgian parliament in Tbilisi for a fifth straight night after the government suspended plans to join the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Thousands protested outside of the Georgian parliament in Tbilisi for a fifth straight night after the government suspended plans to join the European Union.

headline: What’s Behind the Protests in the Country of Georgia?
abstract: For days, pro-Western Georgians have clashed with police over the government’s plan to suspend plans for European Union membership.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Georgians demonstrated in front of their country’s parliament for the fifth night in a row on Monday, widening a political crisis that has set the country’s pro-Russian government against those who want closer ties with the West.

headline: Maternity Leave and Ongoing Consent: New Rights for Belgium’s Sex Workers
abstract: A groundbreaking law, which gives some sex workers greater labor protections and social benefits than similar legislation elsewhere in the world, is now in effect in the European country.
lead_paragraph: A new law gives some sex workers in Belgium more protection from exploitation and violence and more social benefits than any other similar legislation in the world, rights researchers and advocates say.

headline: Trump Threatens ‘Hell to Pay’ Unless Gaza Hostages Are Freed Before Inauguration
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump said in a social media post on Monday that the hostages must be released before his inauguration in January.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday demanded that the hostages taken in the Hamas-led attack on Israel be released from Gaza before his inauguration in January, or there will be “hell to pay” in the Middle East for those responsible.

headline: 5 Women Win Reparations From Belgium for Crimes Under Colonial Rule
abstract: In a landmark case, a court ruled that the women, now in their 70s and 80s, who were taken from their parents in Belgian Congo, were victims of a crime against humanity.
lead_paragraph: A court in Brussels ruled on Monday that five mixed-race women, now in their 70s and 80s, were owed reparations from Belgium for crimes the state had committed against them under colonial rule in Belgian Congo.

headline: Biden’s Pardon for His Son Dishonors the Office
abstract: With the pardon of his son, President Biden added his name to the roll call of presidents who dishonored their office by misusing the pardon power.
lead_paragraph: Pardons are the consummate discretionary acts; presidents are never required to issue even a single one, nor are they limited in the number they issue or to whom. In this way, they reveal their roots in the royal prerogative of mercy. There is only one reason presidents, or kings, issue pardons: because they want to.

headline: Judge Steps Aside in ‘Shaken Baby’ Death Penalty Case in Texas
abstract: The judge who issued a death warrant for Robert Roberson voluntarily recused herself, adding the latest legal complication to a case that has drawn national scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The Texas judge overseeing the case of Robert Roberson, convicted of killing his 2-year-old daughter, has voluntarily recused herself from further proceedings, adding a new complication to a death penalty case that has drawn national scrutiny for its reliance on questionable evidence of “shaken baby” syndrome.

headline: Democrats Sharply Criticize Biden’s Pardon of His Son
abstract: Lawmakers in the president’s own party, many of them moderates, said his decision to pardon his son was selfish and would further damage Americans’ waning faith in democracy and the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Several Democrats in Congress spoke out on Monday against President Biden’s decision to issue a broad pardon of his son Hunter Biden, criticizing the action as one that would further erode Americans’ already waning faith in democracy and the rule of law.

headline: G.M. Will Sell Stake in E.V. Battery Plant to Its Partner LG
abstract: LG Energy Solution will now solely own a factory in Michigan that it had planned to operate through a joint venture with General Motors.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Monday that it was selling its stake in a nearly complete battery factory in Michigan to its partner LG Energy Solution, reducing to three the number of battery plants the carmaker will operate in the United States.

headline: Lake-Effect Storm Buries Great Lakes Region in Snow
abstract: More snow is expected across the region throughout the rest of the week as quick-moving storms move through the area.
lead_paragraph: More snow is expected across the region throughout the rest of the week as quick-moving storms move through the area.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: A Presidential Pardon
abstract: Plus, Free North Korea Radio.
lead_paragraph: President Biden issued a full and unconditional pardon of his son Hunter on Sunday night after repeatedly insisting he would not do so. He said he made the decision because the tax and gun charges against Hunter were politically motivated.

headline: Wisconsin Judge Strikes Down Limits on Public Sector Unions
abstract: The 2011 law stripped most government workers in the state of collective bargaining rights and set off protests that lasted weeks.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin judge on Monday struck down portions of a 2011 law that stripped most government workers in the state of collective bargaining rights and set off fierce demonstrations.

headline: Puzzle Mania 2024 Variety Puzzle Answers
abstract: Check your puzzle answers.
lead_paragraph: Check your puzzle answers.

headline: Were Hunter Biden’s Prosecutions a Result of Political Pressure? A Look at the Facts.
abstract: The gun case federal prosecutors brought against Hunter Biden was relatively rare, but the tax charges he pleaded guilty to may have been less unusual.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s fiery statement on Sunday announcing his son’s pardon included an eye-opening assertion: that Hunter Biden’s prosecutions on gun and tax charges were the product of political pressure, not the evenhanded administration of justice.

headline: A Question No One Was Asking: What if Elon Musk Was on the Bulls?
abstract: Scottie Pippen, a basketball star turned crypto fanatic, posted about how many championships Chicago would have won with Mr. Musk. The answers weren’t kind.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Bulls of the 1990s were one of the greatest franchises in sports history. Led by Michael Jordan, the team won six N.B.A. championships between 1991 and 1998. But what if the Bulls had one more multi-tool superstar on the roster? What if Elon Musk had been on the team?

headline: The Super Mega Support Group
abstract: A crossword so large you might need to talk about it in therapy.
lead_paragraph: Puzzle Mania, our annual special section, was published on Sunday. The section, a collaboration with T Magazine, is loaded with more than 50 puzzles, including twists on our daily games and new offerings such as logic and photo puzzles. The centerpiece, however, is the Super Mega, a 50x50 crossword, and its corresponding contest. The Super Mega is larger than most crossword software can handle, so constructors have to make the puzzle in sections and assemble them. This year, Sid Sivakumar did the honors.

headline: Elon Musk’s $50 Billion Tesla Pay Can’t Be Reinstated, Delaware Judge Rules
abstract: The judge said she would not reverse her decision to strike down the package after Tesla shareholders approved it a second time.
lead_paragraph: A Delaware judge on Monday affirmed an earlier ruling that rescinded a giant pay package that Tesla had awarded its chief executive, Elon Musk.

headline: ‘A Wonderful Wit’: Woody Allen on Working With Marshall Brickman
abstract: In an interview, Mr. Allen describes the years he spent collaborating with Mr. Brickman, a friend, on beloved movies. Mr. Brickman died on Friday.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1970s, the writer and director Woody Allen was known for farcical movies about subjects like the search for the world’s best egg salad, but by then he felt he was done “just clowning around,” as he later told the film critic Stig Björkman.

headline: Ex-Kansas Police Detective Found Dead on First Day of His Trial
abstract: Roger Golubski, who had been accused of raping and terrorizing Black women, was found dead on his back porch on Monday as his federal trial was set to begin.
lead_paragraph: A former Kansas police detective who had been accused of repeatedly sexually assaulting two women over several years while on duty was found dead on Monday, the first day of his trial on federal civil rights charges.

headline: Backlash to Biden’s Pardon
abstract: Also, Russian strikes in Syria. Here's the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Several Democrats in Congress spoke out today against President Biden’s decision to pardon his son Hunter Biden, who was convicted of gun charges and pleaded guilty to tax charges. The Democrats said it would erode Americans’ faith in democracy and the rule of law.

headline: Biden the Father vs. Biden the Institutionalist
abstract: A tension between parenthood and politics has defined the Biden presidency.
lead_paragraph: On the day President Biden’s career in national politics began in 1973, he walked up to a lectern set up in a Delaware hospital room while holding his 3-year-old son, Hunter, in his arms. Both Hunter and his older brother Beau, who was lying in a hospital bed nearby, were recovering after being in a car accident that had killed their sister and mother weeks earlier.

headline: Kash Patel Has Plan to Remake the F.B.I. Into a Tool of Trump
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump’s pick to lead the F.B.I. has called for firing the agency’s top officials, shutting down its Washington headquarters and prosecuting journalists.
lead_paragraph: “Fire the top ranks of the F.B.I.” Encourage Congress to demand testimony exposing “every single bit of filth and corruption” at the agency, and withhold its funding “until the documents come in.” Prosecute leakers and journalists. Replace the national security work force with “people who won’t undermine the president’s agenda.”

headline: Broad Pardon for Hunter Biden Troubles Experts
abstract: President Biden granted blanket clemency to stop his son from being prosecuted by the Trump administration for his foreign business. Experts reached for historical parallels.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s pardon for his son not only allowed him to escape consequences from his current convictions, but likely for any crimes he might have committed in the past 11 years.

headline: A Move
abstract: Inspired by the movement for women’s rights in Iran, Elahe Esmaili returns to her hometown to start her own resistance.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the movement for women’s rights in Iran, Elahe Esmaili returns to her hometown to start her own resistance.

headline: For Iranian Women, Can a Revolution Take Place at Home?
abstract: Inspired by the movement for women’s rights in Iran, Elahe Esmaili returns to her hometown to start her own resistance.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the Women, Life, Freedom movement, one of the most significant political uprisings in Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution, Iranian society experienced a period of upheaval. The movement began in 2022 when Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old Kurdish woman accused of disobeying the hijab law, died after being arrested by the morality police. Many Iranians supported the protesters, who called for greater freedom for women and the end of compulsory veiling; the regime responded with brutal crackdowns.

headline: If Anyone Can Save the Democrats, It’s Ben Wikler
abstract: This Wisconsinite is the obvious choice for D.N.C. chair.
lead_paragraph: Over coffee with Ben Wikler, chair of the Wisconsin Democratic Party, this summer, I was talking about my own unproductive tendency toward political despair, and my recurrent fantasies of moving abroad to give my kids a start in a less cruel country. Such thinking was completely foreign to him. I remember him saying that when he sees a crisis, his instinct is always to find the way through, no matter how narrow or convoluted the path. He seems to relish the opportunity to rise to a challenge.

headline: How Biden Changed His Mind on Pardoning Hunter: ‘Time to End All of This’
abstract: The threat of a retribution-focused Trump administration and his son’s looming sentencings prompted the president to abandon a promise not to get involved in Hunter Biden’s legal problems.
lead_paragraph: A dark sky had fallen over Nantucket, Mass., on Saturday evening when President Biden left church alongside his family after his final Thanksgiving as president.

headline: For U.K. Ambassador, Trump Picks Billionaire Who Supported His Rivals
abstract: Warren Stephens, an investment banker, gave $2 million in 2016 to a group aiming to block Donald J. Trump’s political rise. More recently, he backed Asa Hutchinson, Chris Christie, Mike Pence and Nikki Haley before donating to the Trump campaign.
lead_paragraph: Warren Stephens, an investment banker and billionaire who donated to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s rivals before eventually supporting him in the 2024 race, was tapped as Mr. Trump’s ambassador to Britain on Monday.

headline: Pardoning Hunter Complicates the Legacy That Biden Envisioned
abstract: President Biden is facing criticism for absolving his son after insisting he would not and, according to some critics in his own party, paving the way for Donald Trump’s return to office.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, not that long ago, when President Biden imagined he would etch his place in history as the leader who ended the chaotic reign of Donald J. Trump, passed a raft of “Build Back Better” laws to transform the country and reestablished America’s place in the world.

headline: U.S. Sending $725 Million in Arms to Ukraine, Including More Land Mines
abstract: The package, the largest since April, comes amid deep concerns in Ukraine that the Trump administration may cut off aid. The president-elect has vowed to end the war quickly, but has not said how.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon will send Ukraine an additional $725 million in military assistance from its stockpiles, including anti-personnel land mines, drones, portable antiaircraft missiles and anti-tank missiles.

headline: U.S. Coast Guard Suspends Search for 5 People Missing in Alaska Waters
abstract: The Coast Guard received a mayday call from a fishing boat on Sunday just after midnight. Search crews looked for its passengers for almost 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard said on Monday that it had suspended a search for five people who made a mayday call from a fishing boat off Alaska just after midnight on Sunday.

headline: Trump to Attend Notre-Dame Cathedral Reopening in Paris
abstract: The trip will be Donald J. Trump’s first foreign trip since last month’s election and offers a sign that global leaders are turning the page on the Biden presidency.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Notre-Dame Cathedral reopening in Paris.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 3, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Nov. 22 about whether the Trump administration and Europe will provide security guarantees to prevent Russia from taking more Ukraine territory paraphrased imprecisely comments made by officials about options Ukraine might have for future deterrence against Russia. The officials suggested that the Biden administration could allow Ukraine to re-establish its nuclear arsenal, which Ukraine had agreed to surrender after the fall of the Soviet Union in exchange for security guarantees. They did not suggest that the Biden administration could return those weapons to Ukraine. The error was repeated in an article on Friday about Russia’s recent attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure sites with missiles and drones.

headline: After Biden Pardons His Son, Prison Inmates Hope They’re Next
abstract: President Biden has pardoned people convicted of some marijuana offenses, but advocates for prisoners say he has been slow to grant other requests.
lead_paragraph: On Thanksgiving, Hunter Biden got the word from his father, President Biden, that he would be pardoned for tax and gun law violations, saving him from potentially spending a few years in federal prison.

headline: Frame Job
abstract: Henry Lin-David makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Trump Says He Will Block Acquisition of U.S. Steel by Japanese Firm
abstract: The announcement reiterated sentiments the president-elect expressed on the campaign trail, and further imperiled a deal that had already run into widespread political opposition.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Monday night that he would block a Japanese company’s proposed acquisition of U.S. Steel upon taking office, declaring that he would not allow the iconic American business to be owned by a foreign firm.

headline: Quote of the Day: Russia’s Elites Feeling Pinched By Slow Growth
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It is clear that if you’re an entrepreneur in Russia who doesn’t make, say, ballistic missiles, then you’re having a tough time.”

headline: Where You Should Donate This Holiday Season
abstract: The return of Times Opinion’s annual giving guide.
lead_paragraph: Adapted from the Opinion Today newsletter, originally published on Nov. 23.

headline: Macron to Pick New Prime Minister in Coming Days. What Comes Next?
abstract: After Prime Minister Michel Barnier lost a no-confidence vote in Parliament, President Emmanuel Macron castigated his political opposition for “choosing disorder” and said he would not resign.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France said on Thursday that he would appoint a new prime minister in the coming days, after the government lost a no-confidence vote in Parliament.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Russian and Iranian support for Syria.
lead_paragraph: Russia and Iran, the staunchest allies of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, pledged to stand behind his government yesterday, sending warplanes and voicing diplomatic support, as his forces attempted to repel a startling rebel advance.

headline: ‘This Is the Land of Wolves Now’: Two Columnists Get to the Heart of Biden’s Pardon
abstract: While the pardon is legal, the rule of law isn’t maintained by merely keeping to the letter of the law.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat and David French about President Biden’s decision to issue a broad pardon to his son Hunter Biden.

headline: Word of the Day: chutzpah
abstract: This word has appeared in 53 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word chutzpah has appeared in 53 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 2 in “Would You Wear 200 Stuffed Animals?” by Jacob Gallagher:

headline: Jon Stewart Thinks Biden Could Have Timed That Pardon Better
abstract: “Normally, you drop a controversial pardon like the way you buy porn at a gas station: in a flurry of other distracting purchases,” the “Late Night” host said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: 3 Climbers Missing After Attempt to Scale New Zealand’s Tallest Mountain
abstract: Two Americans and a Canadian were climbing Aoraki/Mount Cook before failing to show up to a prearranged flight on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Three mountaineers from the United States and Canada were reported missing on Monday after they did not return from an attempt to summit Aoraki/Mount Cook, New Zealand’s highest mountain, the local police said. Severe weather conditions were obstructing the search.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Earn $800,000? You Might Get Financial Aid at an Elite N.Y.C. School.
abstract: The average tuition of $65,000 a year at private schools has separated New York’s truly rich, who can afford to pay full tuition, from its merely wealthy.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to be rich in New York City these days. It’s quite another to be able to afford private school.

headline: What’s Next for Google’s Search Monopoly
abstract: The federal judge who ruled Google was a monopolist in search is weighing the U.S. government’s proposal to force the company to sell its Chrome browser. Here’s what happens now.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government asked a federal judge last month to force Google to sell Chrome, the world’s most popular web browser.

headline: Holiday Cookies
abstract: What are your favorites, whether to make or to receive? Why?
lead_paragraph: It’s Cookie Week at The New York Times because, at least according to the Food section, “cookies are the holidays’ greatest gift.”

headline: Jurors Set to Weigh Penny’s Fate in Choking Case That Divided New York
abstract: Prosecutors in Daniel Penny’s manslaughter trial finished closing arguments Tuesday. The trial has touched on fears about crime and the city’s failure to help its most troubled residents.
lead_paragraph: After a seven-week trial and the testimony of more than 40 witnesses, a Manhattan jury will settle a debate that for more than a year has divided New Yorkers: whether Daniel Penny, a former Marine who fatally choked a homeless man in a subway car last year, is guilty of manslaughter.

headline: One City’s Attempt to Change How Domestic Violence Is Tackled
abstract: San Antonio has long had a high rate of family violence. An unusual court is trying to intervene before the violence turns deadly.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering July night, Jesse Falcon was so high on cocaine, marijuana and alcohol that he would later say that he barely remembered the explosion of violence that happened.

headline: Google Worried Israeli Contract Could Enable Human Rights Violations
abstract: The tech giant, which has defended the deal to employees who oppose supplying Israel’s military with technology, feared the project might damage its reputation.
lead_paragraph: In May 2021, Google announced it had agreed to participate in a $1.2 billion cloud computing contract with the Israeli government and military, saying it was “delighted to have been chosen to help digitally transform” the country.

headline: A Home Library Can Tell Your Life Story
abstract: These interior designers have strategies for creating personal spaces for reading, whether it is in a dedicated room or a welcoming corner in your house.
lead_paragraph: If you own a lot of books, it’s great to have a place to celebrate and enjoy them. That’s why a home library can be so appealing: It’s a welcoming retreat where you can appreciate and be inspired by volumes you’ve collected over the years.

headline: Why Aging Experts Are Obsessed With ‘Health Span’
abstract: Trying to stay healthy into old age is a better goal than attempting to live as long as possible.
lead_paragraph: Americans, on average, can expect to live to about age 76. But their health will start to decline much earlier than that, around age 64.

headline: Edna Ferber Wrote ‘Giant.’ James Dean, Rock Hudson and Elizabeth Taylor Made It Immortal.
abstract: In “Giant Love,” the novelist’s great-niece chronicles the Texas saga’s divisive reception and the epic film adaptation that’s now better known than the book.
lead_paragraph: As if to defy her adult height of 5-foot-1, the writer Edna Ferber lived large, traveled widely and typed long and often.

headline: A Lebanese Exile Builds a Haven for Those in Need — or So the Legend Goes
abstract: The first English translation of Charif Majdalani’s 2005 novel “A History of the Big House” charts one family’s — and country’s — cycles of prosperity and ruin.
lead_paragraph: It’s a shame the first descriptor that comes to mind when many people think about the Lebanese is “resilient.” We are also stubborn, prone to aggrandizement, benevolently delusional, enterprising, petty and inclined toward generosity no matter how personally ruinous.

headline: Chris Brown’s Johannesburg Shows Draw Protest
abstract: Women’s rights activists have petitioned for the singer to be denied a visa for two shows in South Africa, where gender-based violence is high.
lead_paragraph: After Chris Brown announced that he would be performing in Johannesburg, tickets for the city’s 94,000-capacity FNB Stadium sold out in under two hours. A second show was swiftly added.

headline: A Throwback to 1960s Spy Novels and Cads Who Knew Too Much
abstract: In “Gabriel’s Moon,” William Boyd follows a writer who is drawn into an espionage plot and a global crisis.
lead_paragraph: What compels us to love an antihero? This question hounded me as I read “Gabriel’s Moon,” the new spy novel by William Boyd. I contemplated two curmudgeons from the espionage genre: Thomas Fowler of “The Quiet American” and Rick Blaine of “Casablanca.” In these stories, Fowler and Blaine undergo transformative character change. Their dormant hearts are awakened; they realize they cannot be idle bystanders to injustice. We cheer for the redemption of the dapper grouch.

headline: Can a Marriage Survive a Summer Holiday With the In-Laws?
abstract: In Weike Wang’s novel “Rental House,” a couple invite their families to visit them on vacation.
lead_paragraph: “Every happy family is unhappy in its own way” — is that the quote? Or maybe it’s, “Every unhappy family is happy to stay that way,” or even, “You only learn the ways in which a family is unhappy when they come to stay.” With or without Tolstoy’s wisdom, most couples know that extended visits from their in-laws reveal new edges to old dynamics between parents and children. Over the course of a friendly visit, tried-and-true ways of keeping the peace fail to function and new ways struggle to be born. It’s in this strange clash of familiarity and friction that Weike Wang’s third novel, “Rental House,” makes its home.

headline: Inside the Supreme Court Ethics Debate: Who Judges the Justices?
abstract: In private meetings and memos, the justices made new rules for themselves — then split on whether they could, or should, be enforced.
lead_paragraph: As the summer of 2023 ended, the justices of the U.S. Supreme Court began trading even-more-confidential-than-usual memos, avoiding their standard email list and instead passing paper documents in envelopes to each other’s chambers. Faced with ethics controversies and a plunge in public trust, they were debating rules for their own conduct, according to people familiar with the process.

headline: ‘How Did I Get Here?’: 7 Days in the Life of a Busy Arts Programmer
abstract: Jay Wegman runs from rehearsals to lunches to shows for his job at N.Y.U. Skirball, then home for a “What We Do in the Shadows” episode or two.
lead_paragraph: Jay Wegman, the artistic director of the N.Y.U. Skirball performing-arts center, likes to say that he lives in three time zones: “the present, a year from now and two years from now.”

headline: How Did New York Become the Freakiest Place on Earth?
abstract: The city has always been a haven for iconoclasts, but contemporary talents in virtually every field are making the metropolis more unique than ever before.
lead_paragraph: LET’S START WITH an acknowledgment: We are aware that, to some people, the word “freak” may not sound entirely complimentary. It connotes the unusual, the peculiar, the weird, the marginal. To those of you who feel that way, we say, exactly. The margins are where all the fun happens. Welcome to our celebration of those who’ve proudly populated, redefined and expanded the shadowlands of New York City — a metropolis that, for a century or more, has in turn reshaped and reimagined itself to accommodate them. Here, we showcase the long history, and the current flowering, of those who have let their one-size-doesn’t-fit-all flag fly in their lives, in their art … or in lives that they have turned into their art. People who came to New York not because they were hoping to find people just like them but because they knew they would somehow feel at home on the edges of a city full of people who weren’t like anybody else.

headline: How to Be a Freak
abstract: The writer and performer Julia Fox gives a tutorial on being yourself and finding your fellow freaks.
lead_paragraph: The writer and performer Julia Fox gives a tutorial on being yourself and finding your fellow freaks.

headline: Julia Fox’s Guide to Being a Freak
abstract: The writer and performer shares her tips and explains why it’s never worth pretending to be normal.
lead_paragraph: I remember being in fifth grade [on New York’s Upper East Side] and being exhausted from trying to pretend to be normal all the time. Once I went to middle school, that’s when the freak was unleashed: I’d go to St. Marks Place [in the East Village] and be enamored of the punk kids, with their spiky hair. Eventually they became my friends.

headline: My Favorite Song | Cole Escola
abstract: The actor’s favorite song is “Happy Birthday” — but they sing a country classic instead.
lead_paragraph: The actor’s favorite song is “Happy Birthday” — but they sing a country classic instead.

headline: Tell T a Joke | Julio Torres
abstract: The comedian tells a joke borrowed from Good Housekeeping magazine.
lead_paragraph: The comedian tells a joke borrowed from Good Housekeeping magazine.

headline: Tell T a Joke | Jackie Hoffman
abstract: The actress tells a joke about a wildlife photographer — and does a convincing impression of a lion.
lead_paragraph: The actress tells a joke about a wildlife photographer — and does a convincing impression of a lion.

headline: The Freaks Who Rule New York
abstract: From a masked artist to a Broadway pioneer, these are the one-of-a-kind creative forces shaping the culture today.
lead_paragraph: Artist, interior designer and writer, 71; Gramercy Park, Manhattan

headline: From Chinese Patriot to American Spy: The Unusual Life of John Leung
abstract: He had been hailed by Chinese state media as a model for his efforts to promote Beijing’s interests in the United States. He was in fact an F.B.I. informant.
lead_paragraph: John Leung was an unlikely spy. In the small Oklahoma town where he lived, people knew him as a former restaurant owner and a father. In Houston, where he often traveled, they knew him as a political organizer in the city’s vibrant Chinese community.

headline: 12 Freaks on the Items That Help Them Be Themselves
abstract: Cole Escola, Princess Nokia, Tabboo! and more share the tools they rely on, from glitter to great hats.
lead_paragraph: “LIP GLOSS is important. You need your lips to be sparkling if you’re about to read [someone]. Because one thing they’re not going to do is judge me on this face and this mouth.” — Richie Shazam, photographer and model

headline: Why Am I So Tired All the Time?
abstract: Chronic exhaustion is pretty common, but it’s also treatable.
lead_paragraph: Q: I get plenty of sleep, but I’m always tired. What’s going on?

headline: May It Please the Court: Trans Health Saved My Life
abstract: Tennessee’s ban on gender-affirming care for transgender adolescents has personal implications.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday I will present oral argument before the Supreme Court in United States v. Skrmetti, a challenge to Tennessee’s ban on gender-affirming care for transgender adolescents.

headline: ‘Everybody Is Drinking Guinness.’ We Know Why.
abstract: Guinness, the beer of Irish pubs and Irish men, has endeared itself to chug-happy Americans eager to “split the ‘G.’”
lead_paragraph: When Maxwell Quinn stepped out of the November chill into Clandestino, a bar in Manhattan’s Chinatown favored by a young, fashionable crowd, he quickly passed over the sparkling wines, dirty martinis and Lagunitas I.P.A.

headline: What Are the Freakiest Works of Art?
abstract: The creative people featured in T’s “Freak City” project share their favorite outlandish artworks.
lead_paragraph: In T’s latest feature, we celebrate the singularly strange talents and iconoclastic veterans who define New York’s avant-garde. It’s no surprise that, when asked about their favorite freaky art, many of the subjects cited pieces that were born or first shown in the city. The interior designer Ricky Clifton brought up his friend Jean-Michel Basquiat’s roughly circular work “Now’s the Time” (1985), while the performance artist Narcissister mentioned Annie Sprinkle’s “Public Cervix Announcement,” which premiered in 1989 at Manhattan’s Harmony Theater burlesque club before going on a world tour. Below, more of their genre-spanning suggestions.

headline: What Are the Freakiest Corners of New York?
abstract: The clubs, clothing stores and other places that attract — and repel — the freaks featured in T’s latest issue.
lead_paragraph: The people we gathered for T’s freak extravaganza first arrived in New York from places as varied as Austin, Texas, and Chengdu, China, but all are deeply connected to the city. It’s where they established their careers and continue to showcase their work, whether on fashion runways or gallery walls. As Mark Harris writes in the feature’s introduction, freaks have long “proudly populated, redefined and expanded the shadowlands of New York City — a metropolis that, for a century or more, has in turn reshaped and reimagined itself to accommodate them.” Still, that begs a question: What’s the freakiest place in all of the city? When asked, our interviewees (unsurprisingly) had their own singular ideas.

headline: The Classical Music Our Critics Can’t Stop Thinking About
abstract: Watch and listen to five recent highlights, including performances by Davóne Tines and Lise Davidsen, and a new album by Ethan Iverson.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s classical music and opera critics see and hear much more than they review. Here is what hooked them during the past month. Leave your own favorites in the comments.

headline: The Wildest Looks at New York Fashion Week Are Often in the Audience
abstract: Milan and Paris may be the biggest runway capitals, but it’s New York where attendees truly dress for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: Here, a parade of stylish individualists in their standout looks.

headline: Do You Want to Have Children When You Are Older?
abstract: A recent study breaks down the reasons more U.S. adults say they are unlikely to have children. What’s your reaction?
lead_paragraph: Do you hope to have children when you are older? Do you think that having kids is important to live a fulfilling life?

headline: Gladiator for a Night at the Colosseum? Some Romans Are Up in Arms.
abstract: An initiative by officials at the monument in a partnership with Airbnb has prompted an outcry among those who feel it will demean a cultural treasure.
lead_paragraph: It has probably been centuries since Romans have been so feverish about happenings at the Colosseum, and it is not because of the recent release of the Ridley Scott “Gladiator” sequel.

headline: Tycoon or Tradwife? The Woman Behind Ballerina Farm Makes Her Own Path.
abstract: Her picture-perfect life as a Mormon farm wife has made Hannah Neeleman a social media star and a cultural lightning rod.
lead_paragraph: Like many a frazzled home cook, Hannah Neeleman suddenly realized she’d forgotten the final step of her recipe just as she was about to serve it. It was a sunny November afternoon in Kamas, Utah, and she was simmering a potful of stroganoff, made with beef and yogurt from the cattle ruminating in the barn next door.

headline: Take the Middle Seat on an Airplane and Be Purified
abstract: It’s exposure therapy to the full spectrum of mistreatment modern life inflicts on us.
lead_paragraph: A disorganized mass will soon gather into a disordered queue and file onto the aircraft. I dawdle in the mass, reviewing the boarding pass on my phone and checking for my seat number, which, lately, has tended to indicate one of the least desirable seats, in the middle of a row at the back of a plane. “Why me?” I ask, or pretend to ask, knowing the answer: I have purchased the cheapest possible ticket and entrusted my placement to the inscrutable designs of my carrier.

headline: America’s Hidden Racial Divide: A Mysterious Gap in Psychosis Rates
abstract: Black Americans experience schizophrenia and related disorders at twice the rate of white Americans. It’s a disparity that has parallels in other cultures.
lead_paragraph: Earl Miller’s favorite book is “The Old Man and the Sea.” Growing up, whenever he moved, he made sure to pack a copy of Hemingway’s novella in one of his two black plastic trash bags. One bag held the books he had stolen along the way; the other, his few clothes. His homes, from the time he was 12, were psychiatric wards, residential programs and the foster homes of white parents who quickly decided they couldn’t handle a heavyset, badly troubled Black kid.

headline: What’s a Landmark? It Could Be a Playground.
abstract: A foundation argues that sites of famous protests against Robert Moses are worthy of preservation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at what makes a landmark. We’ll also find out about an office tower in Lower Manhattan that has become a place for artists, designers and boutique creative agencies by day — and for attention-getting parties by night.

headline: An Indigenous Group in Quebec Tries to Keep the Caribou Alive
abstract: The Canadian government is threatening to use emergency measures to protect three caribou herds at risk of dying out in Quebec.
lead_paragraph: The caribou emerged from the spruce trees in the distance, unmistakable with its creamy white neck and huge antlers. Behind it, the autumn sun was setting on a low mountain range and faintly illuminating a forest lake in a picturesque Canadian moment.

headline: How Private Funds Could Hurt Americans Under Trump
abstract: The fund managers who backed Donald Trump’s candidacy have welcomed his victory with calls for new directions in policy.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, financiers who manage almost $30 trillion in private equity, hedge and venture capital funds have shed their reluctance to exert political influence. Steven Mnuchin brought hedge fund experience to his role as the head of the Treasury during Donald Trump’s first term. More recently, Glenn Youngkin moved from private equity to the governor’s mansion in Virginia. But no presidency has been as thoroughly surrounded and supported by the private fund industry as America’s incoming administration.

headline: 6 Warm Getaways That Will Lift Your Spirits
abstract: Looking to take a break from the cold without traveling too far or spending too much? Here are some sunny, easy-to-reach places to beat the winter blahs.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’re a big fan of snowy mornings and cozy nights, winter can sometimes bring on the blues.

headline: The Revolutionary Sound at the Heart of a Holiday Classic
abstract: Listen to how Tchaikovsky uses the celesta in “The Nutcracker,” unleashing the potential of the instrument to signal playfulness and fantasy.
lead_paragraph: There comes a moment in “The Nutcracker,” a ballet full of fantasy and fantastical music, when the Sugar Plum Fairy dances to a tune you’ve probably heard before.

headline: Supreme Court Returns to a Culture War Battleground: Transgender Rights
abstract: On Wednesday, the justices will hear the marquee case of the term, a challenge to a Tennessee law banning several forms of medical care for transgender youths.
lead_paragraph: A little more than four years ago, the Supreme Court delivered a surprise victory to L.G.B.T.Q. communities. Rejecting the position of the Trump administration, the court ruled by a lopsided margin that a federal civil rights law protected transgender people from workplace discrimination.

headline: The Art of Decorating Holiday Mantels
abstract: The interior designer Bunny Williams shares tips on how she styles the five fireplaces in her Connecticut home.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season is an opportunity to let loose with festive decorations, bringing cheer to a home in a way that might seem too extravagant the rest of the year. And in a home with a fireplace, whether functional or not, the mantel should be a focal point.

headline: Five Opinion Writers on What Biden Should Do in His Final Days as President
abstract: Protecting land and appointing judges could go a long way toward bolstering Biden’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has about six weeks left in office, and with Republicans set to control both houses of Congress and the presidency next year, his final acts may be more important than ever.

headline: It Can’t Be Assumed That Higher Turnout Would Have Helped Harris
abstract: Voting records suggest Democrats who stayed home were less likely to support her, with no equivalent drop-off in Trump support among Republicans.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been reading post-election coverage, you’ve probably seen one of the big takeaways from the returns so far: In counties across the country, Kamala Harris won many fewer votes than Joe Biden did four years ago.

headline: It’s the Corruption, Stupid
abstract: The politician discusses what lessons he thinks Democrats have forgotten.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: ‘Politics Failed’: Top U.N. Envoy Says Gaza War Followed Years of Weak Diplomacy
abstract: World leaders failed to focus on a permanent solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and risk making the same mistake again, the departing United Nations’ envoy in the region says.
lead_paragraph: In September last year, the top United Nations envoy for the Middle East peace process left a meeting with Hamas leaders in Gaza thinking that he had helped avert a major escalation.

headline: Project 2025, Mar-a-Lago and Fox News: What Connects Trump’s New Staff Picks
abstract: See the links between more than 60 figures the president-elect wants for cabinet and other senior positions: billionaires, lobbyists, Fox personalities and more.
lead_paragraph: See the links between more than 60 figures the president-elect wants for cabinet and other senior positions: billionaires, lobbyists, Fox personalities and more.

headline: What Kash Patel Could Do to the F.B.I.
abstract: The true danger is almost less about the pick and more about what it says of Trump’s approach to his second term.
lead_paragraph: It goes almost without saying that Kash Patel, whom Donald Trump picked over the weekend to lead the F.B.I., is supremely unqualified to direct the nation’s premier federal law enforcement agency.

headline: A Worthy Cause (Actually, Many of Them) This Giving Tuesday
abstract: Highlighting nonprofits doing good work in New York and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Encourage literacy. Feed hungry families. Ensure girls in Africa have access to education. Teach young adults career skills. Support free speech. Fight inequality. Help immigrants gain access to health care.

headline: Why Israel and Hezbollah Are Still Firing Amid a Cease-Fire
abstract: Some violations of the truce, and some amount of violence, are to be expected, analysts say, and do not necessarily mean the deal will collapse and war will resume anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: A deal to end the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon went into effect last Wednesday, but already there have been multiple claims of cease-fire violations by either side.

headline: China Bans Rare Mineral Exports to the U.S.
abstract: The move escalates supply chain warfare and comes a day after the Biden administration expanded curbs on the sale of advanced American technology to China.
lead_paragraph: China said on Tuesday that it would begin banning the export of several rare minerals to the United States, an escalation of the tech war between the world’s two biggest powers. The move comes a day after the Biden administration tightened Chinese access to advanced American technology.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,264
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: When the President Pardons His Son
abstract: It has never happened before.
lead_paragraph: President Biden went back on his word by pardoning his son Hunter Biden. His stated rationale for granting the pardon will inevitably muddy the political waters as President-elect Donald J. Trump prepares to take office with plans to use the Justice Department and the F.B.I. to pursue “retribution” against his political adversaries.Peter Baker, chief White House correspondent, discusses where Mr. Biden’s decision leaves the U.S. justice system.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 542
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The White House Goes on the Defense, and Israel and Hezbollah Trade Fire
abstract: Plus, mail trucks get a “goofy” upgrade.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Why Turnout Wasn’t the Democrats’ Problem
abstract: We explore the data behind that assumption.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been reading post-election coverage, you’ve probably seen one of the big takeaways from the returns so far: In counties across the country, Kamala Harris won many fewer votes than President Biden did four years ago.

headline: Seniors Need Our Help to Stay in the Homes They Love
abstract: Habitat for Humanity helps older people who can’t afford to make their homes safe and workable as they age.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Holiday Giving Guide 2024. Read more about the guide in a note from Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: Investigation Into Forced Adoptions From Ukraine Points Finger at Putin
abstract: Yale researchers traced hundreds of children taken to Russia in the war, finding what they described as “a higher level of crime than first understood.”
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and senior Kremlin officials “intentionally and directly” authorized a program of coerced fostering and adoption of Ukrainian children during the war in Ukraine, according to a Yale University report that was released on Tuesday.

headline: Will Elon Musk Ever Collect His Full Tesla Pay Package?
abstract: The electric vehicle maker vowed to appeal after a Delaware judge rejected the tech mogul’s massive compensation deal for a second time.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has been on a winning streak since the election. But a Delaware judge just dealt the Tesla C.E.O. a blow, refusing to reinstate his huge pay package despite investors approving the compensation by a wide margin in June.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Cease-Fire, Trump Transition, Presidential Pardon
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: The Top 10 Books of The Year
abstract: The New York Times Book Review’s editor, Gilbert Cruz, shares three highlights from the 10 best books of 2024.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Book Review’s editor, Gilbert Cruz, shares three highlights from the 10 best books of 2024.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2024
abstract: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s top fiction and nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: Here they are — the 10 Best Books of 2024.

headline: Fighting Worsens Already Dire Conditions in Northwestern Syria
abstract: Years of war and a powerful earthquake had led to crushing poverty, displacement and breakdowns in services. But over the last several days, the region’s misery deepened.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals have been ripped apart by airstrikes. Nearly 50,000 people have fled their homes, and tens of thousands lack running water. Civilians are being laid out in body bags on hospital floors after shells struck their neighborhoods.

headline: ‘A Different Man’ and ‘Sing Sing’ Rule the Gotham Awards
abstract: The kickoff to awards season has a mixed record but can help lift small films like the two surprise winners.
lead_paragraph: “A Different Man,” a dark indie comedy starring Sebastian Stan, was the surprise best-feature winner at the 34th annual Gotham Awards, which took place Monday night at Cipriani Wall Street in New York.

headline: Netanyahu Welcomes Trump’s Demand to Free Hostages Before Inauguration
abstract: The Israeli leader’s comments came after President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened to take unspecified action unless the hostages held in Gaza are released by Jan. 20.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday welcomed President-elect Donald J. Trump’s demand that hostages taken in the Hamas-led attack on Israel be released from Gaza before his inauguration in January.

headline: Bloomberg Says Kennedy Would Be ‘Beyond Dangerous’ as Health Secretary
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor and a public health advocate, is asking Senate Republicans to persuade President-elect Donald J. Trump to “rethink” Kennedy’s nomination.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor, launched a lengthy broadside on Tuesday against Robert F. Kennedy Jr., using his opening remarks at a public health conference to warn that installing Mr. Kennedy as health secretary would be “beyond dangerous,” and tantamount to “medical malpractice on a mass scale.”

headline: Rihanna Steals the Fashion Awards
abstract: And a dozen other looks that made news at Britain’s Met Gala of style.
lead_paragraph: She wasn’t even nominated, and Rihanna still stole the show Monday night at the Fashion Awards in London.

headline: Developing Countries Face Record Debt Costs Amid Interest Rate Surge
abstract: The World Bank warned in a new report that poor countries will be stuck in economic “purgatory” without debt relief.
lead_paragraph: Soaring inflation saddled developing countries with a record $1.4 trillion in debt servicing costs last year, the World Bank said in a report published on Tuesday, detailing the precarious state faced by the world’s most vulnerable economies since the pandemic.

headline: Why Republicans Might Oppose Trump’s Push to Undo Biden’s Triumphs
abstract: President Biden wants to make it more difficult for President-elect Donald J. Trump to repeal his signature legislation, which sent money flowing to Republican districts nationwide.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has promised to unravel President Biden’s major legislation when he takes office next month, but Mr. Biden is hoping to salvage his most prized policies with help from an unlikely source: Republicans.

headline: The Climate Crisis Is Bigger Than Any News Cycle
abstract: Companies continue to invest in sustainability, though many are no longer broadcasting it.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: President Yoon’s Speech Declaring Martial Law
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol made the extraordinary declaration in an unannounced speech to the nation on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea delivered the following address on Tuesday night.

headline: Entrenched Arctic Air Sets the Stage for More Early Season Snow
abstract: Here’s a day-by-day look at the winter weather forecast this week.
lead_paragraph: The sudden freeze that has chilled many who had experienced a somewhat toasty autumn in the Eastern United States is set to continue this week as far south as Florida, while heavy lake-effect snow will return near the Great Lakes and widespread snow is likely to blanket the interior Northeast through Friday.

headline: U.S. Moves to End a Minimum Wage Waiver for Disabled Workers
abstract: A plan by the Biden administration would phase out a provision that allows employers to pay workers with disabilities less than the federal minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Tuesday moved to end a program that has for decades allowed companies to pay workers with disabilities less than the minimum wage.

headline: Maple-Miso Salmon, Lemony Chicken Breasts and Broccoli Pesto
abstract: Light-but-satisfying dinners to fuel you for all that cookie-making.
lead_paragraph: Is it OK to have just cookies for dinner? Asking for a friend.

headline: Arts Galas Show That Extravagance Never Goes Out of Style
abstract: They are costly, labor-intensive and seemingly dated, but cultural organizations say black-tie dinners remain essential to pleasing donors and paying the bills.
lead_paragraph: They drank salted maple espresso martinis and ate snow crab, Wagyu short rib and passion fruit bonbons.

headline: Final Defendants in YSL Trial Are Acquitted of Murder and Gang Charges
abstract: The winding, yearslong case against the star Atlanta rapper Young Thug, who recently pleaded guilty to gang charges, and five others concluded on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The two remaining defendants in the gang conspiracy and racketeering case against YSL, the Atlanta rap label that prosecutors said doubled as a violent street crew led by Young Thug, were found not guilty on Tuesday of murder and conspiracy to violate the RICO act.

headline: Chaos Plays Out at South Korea’s Legislature Building
abstract: Soldiers wearing helmets and carrying long guns pushed back against people who tried to enter the National Assembly, after President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law.
lead_paragraph: A chaotic scene was playing out early Wednesday at South Korea’s legislative building in Seoul, where thousands of people gathered to protest President Yoon Suk Yeol’s declaration of martial law, and police and soldiers tried to prevent people from entering the building.

headline: With Million-Dollar Paintings at Stake, What Does the Art Doctor Say?
abstract: The conservator Suzanne Siano analyzes the health of artworks. She frequents art fairs from Paris to Miami Beach providing advice to both buyers and sellers.
lead_paragraph: When Suzanne Siano walks around an art fair, she does not just see still lifes, portraits and colorful abstractions. She sees cracks in paint, staple holes, varnish layers and discolored canvases, any of which could be totally fine — or highly problematic.

headline: You Want That Gift to Arrive Today? This Is What It Takes.
abstract: Retailers like Amazon, Walmart and Target have figured out that if they get you your online order today, you will probably spend more tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: One day in early November, I ordered an emotional support pickle. The image on Amazon showed a green crocheted prolate vegetable, with a pink bow fixed on top and two black button eyes. It held a sign that read, “Emotional Support Pickle: I will always be around to let you know that you are a BIG DILL.”

headline: A Geopolitical Cauldron Simmers in Syria After Rebel Attacks
abstract: Iran and Russia, both stretched by conflicts of their own, have experienced setbacks in Syria after a rebel offensive in the northwest of the country.
lead_paragraph: The timing appeared to be both calculated and opportunistic.

headline: Pro-Government Airstrikes Damage Hospitals in Rebel-Held Syrian City
abstract: The director of Idlib University Hospital said his facility was one of two knocked out of service by Monday’s strikes.
lead_paragraph: The director of Idlib University Hospital said his facility was one of two knocked out of service by Monday’s strikes.

headline: What to Know About the Surprise Martial Law in South Korea
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol faces public fury and calls to resign after he imposed martial law, then backed down after Parliament voted to repeal it.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on South Korea and President Yoon Suk Yeol.

headline: She Met Hunter Biden One Night at a Club. Then She Fell in Love.
abstract: A chance meeting in December 2017 plunged Zoë Kestan, a downtown “it” girl and social media star, headlong into an unpredictable affair.
lead_paragraph: When Zoë Kestan first met Hunter Biden she didn’t know who he was. His father, Joseph R. Biden Jr., was no longer in office, and she didn’t read the news much anyway.

headline: The Furious Contest to Unseat Nvidia as King of A.I. Chips
abstract: Amazon, Advanced Micro Devices and several start-ups are beginning to offer credible alternatives to Nvidia’s chips, especially for a phase of A.I. development known as “inferencing.”
lead_paragraph: On the south side of Austin, Texas, engineers at the semiconductor maker Advanced Micro Devices designed an artificial intelligence chip called MI300 that was released a year ago and is expected to generate more than $5 billion in sales in its first year of release.

headline: Brooklyn Museum Shows Off All the Glitter, Glam and Greed
abstract: The new “Solid Gold” exhibition is a celebration of bling through the ages and around the world. But is eye candy enough?
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum aims to show how “gold has served as a powerful form of communication and self-expression for millennia.” Big ambitions deserve a big show: The 500 objects in “Solid Gold,” around half drawn from across the museum’s collections, include ancient Greek jewelry, Egyptian funerary objects, amulets made by Indigenous artisans in pre-conquest Latin America, 14th-century Italian altarpieces, gold-toned photography, illuminated manuscripts, Japanese folding screens, Hollywood film, a Peruvian gilded bed frame, technology and industrial design, and gold and diamond grills (or grillz).

headline: Stephen King to Shut Down His 3 Radio Stations in Maine
abstract: The author, who owns the small independent stations in Bangor, said that the decision was prompted by a desire to get his business affairs in order.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King, the horror author whose books have sold hundreds of millions of copies, inspired classic films and disturbed untold nights of sleep, has long played another role closer to his home in Maine: local media magnate.

headline: Senate Confirms General’s Promotion After Republican Senator Lifts Hold
abstract: Lt. Gen. Christopher T. Donahue commanded U.S. troops in the final days of the withdrawal from Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: It ended as quietly as it began: A Republican senator has dropped his hold on the promotion of Lt. Gen. Christopher T. Donahue, the commander of U.S. troops in the final days of the withdrawal from Afghanistan.

headline: The French Fare at Zimmi’s Is Anything but Routine
abstract: Plus Sal Tang’s brings Cantonese American to Cobble Hill, Dilli Dilli serves Old and New Delhi cuisine, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Like Third Falcon in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, this French bistro also veers refreshingly from routine escargots and beef Bourguignon. It’s from Jenni Guizio, who was the wine and beverage director for Union Square Hospitality, and the chef Maxime Pradié, a partner in the restaurant. They’re showcasing dishes like pissaladière, barbajuan fritters, vegetable terrine with anchovy emulsion, lamb stew with olives, and a Chartreuse souffle. Hand-blown light fixtures embellish a simple room that Ms.Guizio designed. The name refers to Marie Zimmermann, an artist whose Pennsylvania estate, Zimmermann Farm, Ms. Guizio now owns and runs for cultural events. (Opens Friday)

headline: Discounts and Deals Led to a Holiday Weekend That ‘Exceeded Expectations’
abstract: An estimated 197 million people shopped from Black Friday to Cyber Monday, the National Retail Federation said, fewer than last year but surpassing the group’s expectations.
lead_paragraph: Slightly fewer people shopped during this year’s Thanksgiving weekend compared with 2023, when a record 200 million people shelled out for the holidays, according to a survey released on Tuesday by the National Retail Federation.

headline: Who Is Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea’s Leader?
abstract: A conservative, Mr. Yoon won the presidency in 2022 by a slim margin, promising a more confrontational stance against North Korea. He quickly became unpopular and divisive at home.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea, who declared martial law on Tuesday night, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.

headline: War Doesn’t Work Anymore
abstract: In a nuclear conflict, total victory is not an option. We might as well stop pretending it is.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: A Wave of Galleries Will Debut at Art Basel Miami Beach This Year
abstract: Thirty-four galleries are joining the fray, bringing glass tongues, giant paintings and deceptively pink assemblages.
lead_paragraph: This year, Art Basel Miami Beach, held from Friday through Sunday, will bring together more than 286 galleries hailing from every continent, save Antarctica. Of this number, 34 galleries are participating in the show for the first time, the largest cohort of new exhibitors since 2008. Some have participated in Art Basel’s other editions in locations such as Hong Kong and Paris.

headline: Talking About the Best Books of 2024
abstract: A group of editors on the year’s most extraordinary novels and nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: Don’t let anyone tell you differently — end-of-year list time is a wonderful time, indeed. And, as we do every December, we are ready to discuss the 10 best books of the year.

headline: 5 Art Fairs to See in 2025
abstract: From San Francisco to Tokyo and beyond, these art fairs offer something for everyone.
lead_paragraph: The art market rises and falls, but art fairs are forever — or at least they seem so sometimes, given that they are more plentiful than ever.

headline: Keeping a Dance Alive, Even After the Show Ends
abstract: At Art Basel Miami Beach, the Mexican choreographer Diego Vega Solorza explores masculinity in a new work and his gallery sells objects from performances.
lead_paragraph: Diego Vega Solorza does not want people to think of him as a visual artist. He is certainly not a sculptor, he insists, nor a photographer or videographer — even though he will exhibit that kind of work in a showcase for emerging talent at this year’s Art Basel Miami Beach, the visual arts mega-fair running Friday through Sunday.

headline: Beyond the Art Basel Miami Beach Fair
abstract: Although the fair is a huge attraction, there are many other exhibitions to visit nearby.
lead_paragraph: During Miami Art Week the deal-making, socializing and celebrity gawking at Art Basel and satellite art fairs can vie for attention with the dizzying floor plans of gallery booths. But there’s a wealth of other options around town that serve up art viewing at a different tempo. Here’s a sample of the offerings.

headline: Martial Law in South Korea Tests Biden and a Key U.S. Alliance
abstract: The Biden administration has hailed South Korea as a model democracy and bolstered military ties as it relies on the country as a bulwark against North Korea, China and Russia.
lead_paragraph: For decades, South Korea has been one of the most important U.S. allies in Asia — not only because nearly 30,000 American troops are stationed there, but also because it stands as a beacon of democracy in a region where powerful authoritarian nations vie with democratic ones.

headline: Trump Will Have Enormous Power Over Climate Action. Here’s Why.
abstract: Presidents have extraordinary control over climate policy, in part, because it’s been decades since Congress has passed a comprehensive environmental bill.
lead_paragraph: Walking away from treaties. Redrawing the boundaries of national monuments. Repealing pollution regulations.

headline: Koyo Kouoh Is Named 1st African Woman to Curate Venice Biennale
abstract: Kouoh, who was born in Cameroon and currently leads one of Africa’s most important art museums, will organize the 61st edition, in 2026.
lead_paragraph: Koyo Kouoh, one of Africa’s pre-eminent curators, will oversee the 61st edition of the Venice Biennale, the organizers of the world’s longest-running contemporary art exhibition announced on Tuesday.

headline: Frieze Fair Further Cements Los Angeles as an International Art Capital
abstract: The sixth edition of the fair in February will have considerably more attendees from Latin America, Europe and Asia.
lead_paragraph: When Frieze Los Angeles first opened in 2019, one might have dismissed it as just another art fair. But for gallerists, collectors and artists, the fair’s arrival has signaled an important development in the West Coast art world.

headline: In Angola, Biden Warns That Slavery’s History Should Not Be Erased
abstract: In becoming the first American leader to visit Angola, President Biden said it was important not to forget the ugly legacy of the human trade that originally defined relations with Africa.
lead_paragraph: When American presidents visit another country, they typically like to highlight the positive history they share. But as the first leader of the United States to visit Angola, President Biden opted instead to focus on the most bitter chapter that connects the United States and this giant southern African nation.

headline: A Los Angeles Gallery Brings Bold Art, and Vision, to Miami Beach
abstract: In 2012, Esther Kim Varet founded the gallery Various Small Fires out of her home. It has since gone multinational, and Kim Varet is still pushing the envelope.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve been asking myself, ‘What’s the point of art?’” said Esther Kim Varet in a video interview, the day after the United States presidential election.

headline: A West Palm Beach Show Spotlights the Beauty and Tragedy of Boxing
abstract: Through paintings, photographs, sculptures, and even bejeweled boxing gloves, the show examines prizefighting as a metaphor for human struggle.
lead_paragraph: Muhammed Ali is crouching with his bare fists up, looking like he’s ready to explode. Andy Warhol, the Pop Art specialist, is wearing boxing shorts and heavy gloves and clowning around with his art buddy Jean-Michel Basquiat. There’s Mike Tyson and Joe Louis, two heavyweight stars, and some newly made photographs of young women boxers in Cuba.

headline: Drought in the Northeast: The Causes and Consequences
abstract: Readers discuss what one calls a “boom-or-bust precipitation cycle.” Also: Pete Hegseth’s mother’s accusation; what opera needs; Elon Musk and Mars.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Ultimate Yacht Rock Playlist
abstract: Gain a deeper appreciation of music from Michael McDonald, Toto and Christopher Cross.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, I watched an entertaining new documentary — or, as it’s billed, a “dockumentary” — about the genre of music that’s retroactively come to be known as “yacht rock.”

headline: NATO Chief Urges More Weapons for Ukraine Ahead of Any Peace Talks
abstract: Mark Rutte said it was up to Ukraine to decide when it was ready to begin negotiations with Russia — and that the West should help strengthen Kyiv’s position beforehand.
lead_paragraph: NATO’s new top diplomat suggested on Tuesday that Ukraine should put off any peace talks with Russia until Western allies can send enough military aid to help Kyiv push ahead on the battlefield and garner a stronger negotiating position.

headline: The Electric Dreams of a More Analog Age
abstract: An ambitious show at Tate Modern looks at how artists used technology from the postwar tech boom until the dawn of the internet age.
lead_paragraph: “We’ll always be together, together in electric dreams,” promises the soaring chorus of the infectious 1984 synth-pop banger by Giorgio Moroder and Phil Oakey. You might have it running through your head (I did) while walking through “Electric Dreams,” an exhibition at Tate Modern in London through June 1, as lights flash and dazzle, machines whir and hum, and the air around you pulses with sound.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Surrendered and Played Along’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I was 16 years old and gay. Alone. Except for depression, my constant companion, joining me in bed, waiting for the day’s end. The light was on. I raised my fist to shield my eyes, but light slipped through and found me. So I surrendered and played along. My hand contracting and releasing, light dispersing through my fist like a kaleidoscope. A decade later, I met Lucy. My soon-to-be girlfriend’s sole tattoo was of a fist inside a lightbulb. I like to think it was her light that had slipped through time to comfort me on my longest day. — Lena Munzer

headline: Turner Prize Goes to Jasleen Kaur Amid Pro-Palestinian Protests
abstract: The artist, who has supported the protests against the Tate group of museums, won the prestigious British award for an installation that includes a car covered by a giant doily.
lead_paragraph: Jasleen Kaur, an artist whose recent installation work focuses on her childhood growing up in a Sikh community in Scotland, on Tuesday won the Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award.

headline: Antidoping Agency Froze Out Investigators Who Warned About China
abstract: The World Anti-Doping Agency’s investigative unit highlighted intelligence about Chinese athletes possibly using a banned medication, but was kept out of the loop when 23 swimmers tested positive for it.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of 2020, the World Anti-Doping Agency’s investigative unit sent the agency’s top officials a report containing a stark warning based on an interview it had conducted with a doctor who had worked in China’s sports ministry.

headline: South Korea’s Obstacles to Parenthood
abstract: Korean women have always been resilient, but they alone cannot overcome a culture of misogyny and a lack of economic security.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: In a First, Transgender Woman Wins Model of the Year
abstract: Alex Consani is a star, on TikTok and on the runway. In her speech at the Fashion Awards in London, she acknowledged the struggles of other pioneers.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally ideological light does manage to shine through the murk of what is sometimes termed the ugly business of beautiful women. Take Alex Consani, who was named Model of the Year at the annual Fashion Awards in London on Monday night.

headline: Debbie Nelson, Eminem’s Mother, Dies at 69
abstract: The two had a fraught relationship that was immortalized in many of Eminem’s earliest hits.
lead_paragraph: Debbie Nelson, a single mother from Missouri whose tumultuous relationship with her eldest son, the rapper Eminem, provided fodder for some of his early hits, died on Monday. She was 69.

headline: Italian Man Given Life Sentence for Brutal Murder of Ex-Girlfriend
abstract: The killing ignited national outrage and provoked calls for stronger measures to protect women.
lead_paragraph: Giulia Cecchettin was just days away from graduating with a degree in biomedical engineering at the University of Padua, in Italy, when her disgruntled ex-boyfriend confronted her, demanding that she take him back. Her body was found a week later, wrapped in plastic bags and thrown in a ditch. She had been stabbed more than 70 times.

headline: An Imaginative Treat for ‘Adventure Time’ Fans
abstract: From the creator of that series comes “Mystery Cuddlers,” on Adult Swim, about a retired couple who have taken up private investigating.
lead_paragraph: Today for your viewing pleasure: two Adult Swim one-offs, one newly birthed, the other sadly dead but still glorious. To be a TV fan is to know that sometimes 22 minutes is all you get.

headline: Justice Dept.’s Apolitical Tradition Is Challenged by 2 Presidents
abstract: The post-Watergate norm that political leaders should steer clear of criminal cases is being tested from opposite ends of the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: The special counsel appointed to investigate President-elect Donald J. Trump is wrapping up his work without the charges he brought in two cases ever going in front of a jury.

headline: Indiana Man Looks Out of His Window and Finds 2 Babies Left in a Ditch
abstract: Robert Deane was waiting for a package when he discovered 4- and 5-month-old girls in car seats abandoned in the cold across the street from his house.
lead_paragraph: Robert Deane was waiting for a package at his home in Indianapolis when he looked out the window on a chilly, 27-degree afternoon on Monday. He noticed something unusual across the street.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: A Brief Martial Law in South Korea
abstract: Plus, become a gladiator for a day.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea promised to convene his cabinet and lift the emergency declaration of martial law that he imposed yesterday. His decision came hours after the National Assembly voted to end the order. Here’s the latest.

headline: Trump Team Signs Agreement to Allow F.B.I. Background Checks for Nominees
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump let weeks pass before signing the agreement as his team considered using private investigators instead.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition operation announced on Tuesday that it had belatedly signed an agreement with the Justice Department that will allow the F.B.I. to conduct background checks on people Mr. Trump intends to appoint as senior officials in his new administration.

headline: Namibia Elects First Woman as President as Ruling Party Keeps Power
abstract: Across southern Africa, political parties that have led their countries since the end of colonialism have ceded power to the opposition in recent months. Namibia bucked the trend.
lead_paragraph: In a year when election upsets have changed southern Africa’s political landscape, Namibia’s governing party has bucked the trend, winning the mineral-rich country’s general election, the electoral commission there said on Tuesday.

headline: The Best Wine Books of 2024
abstract: A tome on the totality of wine from a New York sommelier, a tale of six months in a French village and more books for the wine lovers in your life.
lead_paragraph: Many good wine books were published this year, but these five stood out. There’s something for every wine aficionado, including a work of rare scholarship, wonderful storytelling, an excellent guide for beginners and two collections of essays.

headline: What Holiday Tradition Do You Cherish Most?
abstract: Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, the holidays are full of traditions. There are the classics, like ice skating, and the more modern, like a holiday-movie binge session with family members.

headline: What Was Your Most Successful New Year’s Resolution?
abstract: Tell us about how you were able to keep it.
lead_paragraph: As we approach 2025, many of us will use the new year as a starting point to make positive changes in our lives. But by February — despite our best intentions — more than a few of us will have given up on our goals.

headline: Who is Lee Jae-myung, the South Korean opposition leader?
abstract: The opposition leader rallied lawmakers to vote down President Yoon Suk Yeol’s martial law decree.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after South Korea’s president, Yoon Suk Yeol, declared martial law on Tuesday night through a decree, Lee Jae-myung, the main opposition leader, called on his supporters and members of his party to gather at the National Assembly.

headline: Thirman Milner, Hartford Mayor Who Broke Race Barrier, Dies at 91
abstract: He grudgingly transitioned from civil rights to politics and became the first popularly elected Black mayor in New England.
