lead_paragraph: Thirman Milner, who in 1981 became the first popularly elected Black mayor in New England, in Hartford, Conn., and went on to serve three terms, died on Nov. 29 at his home there. He was 91.

headline: Woman Who May Have Fallen Into Sinkhole Is Likely Dead, Authorities Say
abstract: The state police in Pennsylvania said there were no signs of life, as they searched for the 64-year-old woman, who went missing while looking for her cat.
lead_paragraph: Update: The authorities said on Friday that Elizabeth Pollard had been found dead in the sinkhole.

headline: Eric Adams Suggests the Biden Pardon Proves He Was Also Targeted
abstract: The mayor has argued that he was indicted because he criticized border policies. He also said that he has rights that migrants do not because “the Constitution is for Americans.”
lead_paragraph: Eric Adams, the indicted mayor of New York City, on Tuesday presented what might be deemed his closing arguments in the court of public opinion.

headline: How Polarized Politics Led South Korea to a Plunge Into Martial Law
abstract: Yoon Suk Yeol’s decree, and his reversal under pressure from lawmakers, were the culmination of years of feuding between the country’s two main political camps.
lead_paragraph: Yoon Suk Yeol won South Korea’s highest office in 2022 by a threadbare margin, the closest since his country abandoned military rule in the 1980s and began holding free presidential elections.

headline: Morton I. Abramowitz, Diplomat Who Made Refugees a Priority, Dies at 91
abstract: As ambassador to Thailand and Turkey, and later as president of the Carnegie Endowment, he pushed for making human rights central to foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Morton I. Abramowitz, a longtime U.S. diplomat who made refugee and humanitarian concerns a focal point of American foreign policy during his tenure, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 91.

headline: South Korea’s President Imposed Martial Law, Then Lifted It
abstract: Also, China banned rare mineral exports to the U.S. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea declared emergency martial law today in an unscheduled address to the nation. He accused his political opponents of plotting an “insurgency” and “trying to overthrow the free democracy.” But six hours later, after the country’s legislature unanimously voted to end it, Yoon rescinded the order.

headline: McDonald’s E. Coli Outbreak Declared Over
abstract: Federal health agencies closed their investigations into the bacterial outbreak that sickened 104 people and was linked to onions on the fast-food chain’s signature Quarter Pounders.
lead_paragraph: Health officials have closed their investigations into an E. coli outbreak linked to raw onions on McDonald’s Quarter Pounder hamburgers that sickened more than a hundred people, the Food and Drug Administration announced Tuesday.

headline: South Korea’s President Lifts Martial Law After Order Sparked Protests
abstract: Protests broke out in Seoul after President Yoon Suk Yeol temporarily declared an emergency martial law on Tuesday. Hours later, the National Assembly swiftly rebuked the order and voted to lift it.
lead_paragraph: Protests broke out in Seoul after President Yoon Suk Yeol temporarily declared an emergency martial law on Tuesday. Hours later, the National Assembly swiftly rebuked the order and voted to lift it.

headline: Republican Lawmakers in Georgia Press Case for Fani Willis Testimony
abstract: Ms. Willis, who charged Mr. Trump in connection with his efforts to cling to power after the 2020 election, came under scrutiny over her relationship with a lawyer she hired to lead the case.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, and the Georgia legislature clashed in court on Tuesday as Republican lawmakers seek to force Ms. Willis to testify and turn over records as part of their review of her prosecution of President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies for 2020 election interference.

headline: Trump’s Pick to Lead D.E.A. Withdraws, Citing ‘Gravity’ of Job
abstract: The announcement by Chad Chronister, a Florida sheriff with virtually no experience in the kinds of complex international investigations the agency handles, comes just three days after his selection.
lead_paragraph: Sheriff Chad Chronister, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Drug Enforcement Administration, withdrew his name from consideration for the office on Tuesday, only three days after he was nominated.

headline: Retired Louisiana Priest Pleads Guilty to Rape and Kidnapping Charges
abstract: Lawrence Hecker, who was indicted last year on charges related to a sexual assault in the 1970s, pleaded guilty on Tuesday just before jury selection for his trial was set to begin.
lead_paragraph: A retired Roman Catholic priest who was indicted last year in Louisiana on charges related to the sexual assault of a teenage boy in the 1970s pleaded guilty to the crimes on Tuesday, his lawyer said, just before jury selection for the trial was set to begin.

headline: South Korea President Declares Martial Law, Then Backs Down
abstract: Soon after President Yoon Suk Yeol’s declaration on Tuesday, lawmakers voted to defy him, prompting the president to say he was lifting his order.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea declared emergency martial law on Tuesday night, then reversed himself hours later as thousands of protesters flooded the streets, capping an extraordinary night of tumult in the deeply divided country.

headline: BlackRock Jumps Deeper Into the Private Markets
abstract: The world’s largest investor is buying HPS, a major provider of private credit, for $12 billion.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, is known for its heft in the public markets, particularly through its iShares exchange-traded funds.

headline: Can Rahm Emanuel Flip the Script Again?
abstract: The former Clinton and Obama aide has a gift for constructing winning coalitions.
lead_paragraph: There’s a buzz around Rahm Emanuel — the former Bill Clinton adviser, former Illinois congressman, former chief of staff to President Barack Obama, former mayor of Chicago — possibly becoming the next head of the Democratic National Committee. The progressive left despises his pragmatism and liberal centrism. He has a reputation for abrasiveness. And his current job, as ambassador to Japan, has traditionally served as a posting for high-level political has-beens like Walter Mondale and Howard Baker.

headline: Children Worked Dangerous Shifts at Iowa Slaughterhouse, Inquiry Finds
abstract: Qvest Sanitation was ordered to pay nearly $172,000 after the Labor Department found it had employed 11 children to clean equipment on overnight shifts at a pork processing plant in Sioux City, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma-based cleaning company has been fined nearly $172,000 after federal investigators found that it had hired nearly a dozen children to work dangerous overnight shifts at an Iowa slaughterhouse.

headline: Montana Lawmakers Reject Bid to Restrict Bathroom Use for Trans Legislators
abstract: The proposal would have effectively barred transgender women from using the State Capitol restroom for female lawmakers. Some Republicans joined Democrats in voting it down.
lead_paragraph: State lawmakers in Montana on Tuesday rejected a proposal that could have restricted bathroom access for transgender lawmakers at the State Capitol in Helena.

headline: Trump Donors Who Give at Least $1 Million or Raise $2 Million Get Inaugural Access
abstract: Perks being offered to the top donors to the president-elect’s inaugural committee include dinners with Melania Trump and the next vice president, JD Vance.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is raising money for his inauguration in increments as high as $2 million, according to materials from fund-raisers for the inauguration.

headline: South Korean History Is Scarred by Martial Law
abstract: The president’s short-lived declaration of a military emergency late Tuesday was young South Koreans’ first exposure to a state of affairs their elders remember well.
lead_paragraph: For many younger South Koreans, President Yoon Suk Yeol’s short-lived declaration of martial law late Tuesday night was their first exposure to a kind of turbulence that older generations remember all too well.

headline: How Pardoning Hunter Complicates Biden’s Legacy
abstract: President Biden is facing criticism for pardoning his son Hunter after insisting he would not. Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains how the decision will shape the outgoing president’s place in history.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is facing criticism for pardoning his son Hunter after insisting he would not. Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains how the decision will shape the outgoing president’s place in history.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 4, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about transgender students’ participation in sports in a Manhattan school district misstated the content of a letter that the city comptroller, Brad Lander, sent to the Department of Education. Mr. Lander asked for a review of the department’s handling of community education council elections; he did not make a formal complaint against PLACE, a parents’ group.

headline: South Korea’s Already Shaky Markets Further Rattled by Political Turmoil
abstract: Officials pledged “unlimited” support to markets as traders digested the implications of South Korea’s brief declaration of martial law.
lead_paragraph: South Korean stocks and the country’s currency were rattled on Wednesday, prompting officials to pledge “unlimited” support to markets after a tense night during which President Yoon Suk Yeol declared and then lifted martial law.

headline: Tickled Pink
abstract: Daniel Raymon’s puzzle earns top marks.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Nearly 300 Troops Stormed South Korean Legislature, Official Says
abstract: The National Assembly’s secretary general, Kim Min-ki, condemned what he called the “illegal, unconstitutional actions of the military.”
lead_paragraph: The secretary general of South Korea’s National Assembly, Kim Min-ki, condemned the military on Wednesday morning for breaking into the legislature during President Yoon Suk Yeol’s brief imposition of martial law, saying that nearly 300 troops had stormed the compound.

headline: Quote of the Day: In Angola, Biden Warns That Slavery’s History Should Not Be Erased
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s even more important because we have to keep the history and the story going wherever there are opportunities to tell the story.”

headline: The Art of the Gift: Samin Nosrat
abstract: One of the chef and author’s favorite gifts is homemade apricot jam, which she makes “specifically to be able to share it with people.”
lead_paragraph: Samin Nosrat, 45, is an Oakland-based chef and food writer. Her first cookbook, “Salt Fat Acid Heat,” won a James Beard Award and was adapted into a Netflix documentary series. Nosrat is currently at work on her next cookbook, “Good Things,” which is expected in the fall of 2025. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

headline: How a Country’s Economy Was Siphoned Dry
abstract: Bangladesh’s currency was battered by what the new head of the central bank says was the looting of the banks under the deposed prime minister.
lead_paragraph: The new governor of Bangladesh’s central bank, Ahsan Mansur, calculates that about $17 billion was siphoned from the country’s financial system in the 15 years before the government of Sheikh Hasina collapsed in August.

headline: California Democrat Flips Seat in the Last House Race to Be Called
abstract: Adam Gray, a former state lawmaker, defeated Representative John Duarte, a Republican, in a reversal of their 2022 race.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic former state lawmaker defeated the Republican incumbent on Tuesday to flip a seat in California’s Central Valley that was the last 2024 House race to be called, according to The Associated Press.

headline: South Korean Troops Enter Parliament Building
abstract: Soldiers stormed South Korea’s National Assembly as legislative aides put up barricades to give lawmakers time to vote on nullifying President Yoon Suk Yeol’s martial law declaration.
lead_paragraph: Soldiers stormed South Korea’s National Assembly as legislative aides put up barricades to give lawmakers time to vote on nullifying President Yoon Suk Yeol’s martial law declaration.

headline: For Some Koreans, Martial Law Brought Back Frightening Memories
abstract: “I immediately thought of 1980, and the fear and desperation we felt,” said a 60-year-old lawmaker who lived through the massacre of protesters in Gwangju.
lead_paragraph: The last time South Korea was under martial law, Chung Chin-ook was in his first year of high school, more than 40 years ago. His home city of Gwangju rose up to protest oppressive measures by the military junta, only to face a brutal, bloody crackdown.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A political crisis in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea this morning lifted an emergency martial law declaration hours after imposing it, bowing to pressure by lawmakers and protesters who resisted his audacious attempt to overcome a political deadlock that has hobbled his tenure.

headline: Prime Minister to Lead South Korea After President’s Impeachment
abstract: Prime Minister Han Duck-soo will be the acting president after the National Assembly ousted President Yoon Suk Yeol.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s National Assembly has voted to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol, suspending him from office, after his ill-fated decision to impose martial law early this month.

headline: Word of the Day: umber
abstract: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word umber has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 6 in “Rafting a Western River With the Next Generation” by Reif Larsen:

headline: Late Night Razzes Trump Over His Upcoming Visit to Notre-Dame
abstract: “If all goes according to plan, he would like to buy it and turn it into a casino,” Jimmy Kimmel said of the Paris cathedral on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Giving
abstract: To what causes and organizations would you most like to donate? Why?
lead_paragraph: December 3 was Giving Tuesday this year, a day when you are invited to take a break from buying things, and, instead, show generosity to others.

headline: Martial Law Didn’t Silence South Korea’s Media. It Empowered Them.
abstract: Journalists criticized the president’s attempt to place the press under military control, hardened by years of challenges to press freedoms by the country’s political leaders.
lead_paragraph: When President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea shocked the nation by declaring martial law, he placed news organizations under the rule of military command and outlawed “fake news.” It was a striking escalation of his long-running feud with media critical of his administration.

headline: Tapped by Trudeau to Steer Foreign Affairs, She’s Now His Possible Successor
abstract: Mélanie Joly, Canada’s top diplomat, has already faced off against India and China, with Donald Trump up next. She’s also considered a top contender to replace Justin Trudeau.
lead_paragraph: The offer was as enticing as it was unexpected for a relative political newcomer. Three years ago, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau asked Mélanie Joly to become foreign affairs minister, among the most prestigious and highest profile portfolios in Canada’s cabinet.

headline: Stalin Silenced These Ukrainian Writers. The War Made Them Famous Again.
abstract: The Soviet regime killed a generation of literary artists in the 1930s. Their legacy is being reclaimed as Ukraine fights to preserve its cultural heritage.
lead_paragraph: In Ukraine, they are known as the “Executed Renaissance,” pioneering literary artists whose lives were snuffed out by Stalin’s brutal purges in the 1930s.

headline: The Best Crime Novels of 2024
abstract: Our columnist on the year’s most outstanding crime novels.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long believed that crime fiction runs along a spectrum between order and chaos, where the two seemingly disparate states are always intertwined, ever-changing, never settled. It makes sense that a genre offering a window into the way we really function in society and behave with one another would embrace constraints while also constantly subverting them. This year’s standout authors understood the assignment: to push boundaries, to reflect the world in its messy glory rather than in tidy narratives.

headline: The Best Thrillers of 2024
abstract: Our columnist on the books that wowed her this year.
lead_paragraph: This deliciously nasty tale of resentment and revenge is set in a hotel in Egypt, where an elderly woman who enjoys secretly meddling in the lives of others has set up residence during Covid. The arrival of another guest — a boy of 8 who can match her, diabolical deed for diabolical deed — threatens to destroy her carefully constructed spider web of intrigue. Bollen writes with wit and style about an increasingly unhinged battle of wills between two unlikely opponents.

headline: When Life Becomes a Performance
abstract: From movie stars to the singularly strange creative talents who rule New York, the freest people are the ones who chart their own course.
lead_paragraph: What’s the difference between an actor and a movie star? Both are giving a performance. But for the latter, the performing never ends.

headline: How Did Lesbian Pulp Fiction Thrive in the 1950s and ’60s?
abstract: These lurid paperbacks offer today’s readers a portal to an early, furtive era of queer expression.
lead_paragraph: THE COVERS ARE what draw you in first, just as they were designed to do. They promise sex but, more strikingly, they promise shock — the jolt of the taboo, the sinful. They’re illustrations of women, usually two, sometimes more, often half-dressed or undressing, in slips and bras, a strap provocatively sliding down the curve of a shoulder. A knee is raised as a nylon stocking is tugged off. They generally seem to show dusky rooms; if a window is visible, it’s curtained because what has been happening inside is not for decent eyes to witness.

headline: Is Robert Pattinson the Last True Movie Star?
abstract: He may have wanted to be an actor without being a celebrity. But then he turned his fame into its own kind of performance.
lead_paragraph: IT WAS ROBERT Pattinson’s idea to take a pottery class. Since becoming a father this past March, the 38-year-old English actor has been searching for what he calls “healthy” hobbies. He’s considered bonsai (“they just start rotting”), trapeze (“can’t do that in public”), tennis (“not enough spatial awareness”) and dance (“my spinal cord freezes”). Two decades into his film career, he seems restless for new ways to express himself that don’t require a crew of hundreds or any of the baggage that comes with being one of the world’s most famous men. In recent years, he invented the recipe for a bastardized arancini-like dish called piccolini cuscino, or “little pillow” (“I got quite deep into it with a frozen-food manufacturer”); a nine-foot-long sofa with armrests as wide as the seat (“It weighs a ton — that’s probably one of the reasons it’s difficult to sell”); and pants with vertical pockets (“Why do they always have to be sticking out like weird little ears?”). He’s also been designing a straight-back chair with a slit running down the center of the cushion that “opens up for you like you’re in a kind of cocoon,” he says. To illustrate the idea, he built a maquette with a Fleshlight sex toy and an empty toilet paper roll.

headline: Kieran Culkin Could Rule Oscar Season. He’d Rather Be at Home.
abstract: The “Succession” actor is an awards front-runner for “A Real Pain,” but his actual priority is being a dad: “That’s the whole point of life.”
lead_paragraph: One of the many eccentricities of a modern-day awards campaign is that it can last much longer than the film shoot that put you in contention in the first place. In 2010, I spoke with Mark Ruffalo partway through a monthslong awards campaign for “The Kids Are All Right” and he said, with some astonishment, “Kyle, I spent six days on this movie.”

headline: Three Powerful Lessons About Love (Encore)
abstract: It’s been 20 years since Daniel Jones started Modern Love as a weekly column in The New York Times. Today, he shares what the job has taught him about love.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Jones started the Modern Love column in 2004, he called for submissions and hoped the idea would catch on. Twenty years and over a thousand published essays later, Modern Love is a trove of real-life love stories.

headline: Serving the Innocent Children of Incarcerated Parents
abstract: Foreverfamily helps families stay connected.
lead_paragraph: This column is part of Times Opinion’s 2024 Giving Guide. Read more about the guide in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: Pete Buttigieg on Passenger Protections and Flying Coach
abstract: The outgoing transportation secretary talks about his record of holding airlines accountable, what might come next and whether to check a bag. (No.)
lead_paragraph: Secretary of Transportation Pete Buttigieg has been at the helm of the nation’s transportation infrastructure — including its aviation system — during a tumultuous four years.

headline: Books, Lost or Imaginary, Come to Life at the Grolier Club
abstract: An exhibition of what-ifs, designed to be seen, not read, will be on display through February.
lead_paragraph: At the Grolier Club on the Upper East Side is an object never before displayed in public: an edition of one of Hemingway’s first novels, which was stolen when his first wife left a bag unattended on a train in 1922. The manuscript was never recovered, and the novel lost to history.

headline: Meet Lamb Chop, America’s Hottest Dog Toy
abstract: Beloved by generations of children as a famous TV puppet, the plush lamb has now earned elite status among an unlikely fan base: dogs.
lead_paragraph: Most toys that cross Foxie’s path rarely last. Rope toys are torn to shreds. Squeaky ones fall silent in her paws. Stuffies lose their eyes and ears once Foxie’s 12-pound frame gets hold of them.

headline: What Trump’s Cabinet Picks and Advisers Say About Climate Change
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump’s chief advisers would include one person who calls global warming an “existential” threat and some who don’t accept it as a problem at all.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s cabinet choices and key advisers run the gamut from people who acknowledge the threat of climate change to those who deny the scientific consensus that emissions from the burning of fossil fuels are dangerously heating the planet.

headline: Best Jazz Albums of 2024
abstract: Musicians both established and up-and-coming stretched themselves in fresh ways over the last year, creating poignant moments of collaboration and challenge.
lead_paragraph: In 2024, jazz continued to spiral out, looking both forward and backward and expanding to mingle with adjacent styles. The year’s most memorable releases in the genre are diverse, but they all share one key trait: a delight in intimate, real-time musical conversation.

headline: For Families of Transgender Children, Tennessee’s Ban Forces Hard Choices
abstract: The Supreme Court is hearing a legal challenge on Wednesday to the state’s ban on several forms of medical care for transgender youth.
lead_paragraph: The first families left as soon as they could, emptying homes and pulling out of school after Tennessee banned gender-transition care for their children. Others chose to remain, cutting back on vacations and Christmas spending to make it to doctor appointments out of state.

headline: Never Underestimate the Power of a Good Cookie
abstract: Biscochitos might not seem to have anything fancy about them until you take a bite. That’s when they revive and restore.
lead_paragraph: The charms of the Western desert are so overwhelming that even a girl like me can forget to eat.

headline: Stripping Down for a Night at a French Museum
abstract: To report on an unclothed visit to an exhibition about social nudism, a Times journalist chose to join the party. Her mother did, too.
lead_paragraph: Usually, when reporting where French is spoken, I worry most about my grammar. But in Marseille last month, the plus-que-parfait was far from the front of my mind.

headline: $800,000 Homes in Oklahoma, Florida and Iowa
abstract: A four-bedroom Tudor Revival in Oklahoma City, a Spanish-style bungalow in West Palm Beach, Fla., and a Dutch Colonial from 1930 in Sioux City, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom house is in Crown Heights, a neighborhood around 10 minutes north of downtown Oklahoma City. Crown Heights Park, which has a playground and a picnic lawn, is two blocks away, and along nearby NW 36th Street are a barbecue restaurant, a record store and a used bookstore. A Vietnamese supermarket is five minutes away, as is a shopping mall with a movie theater.

headline: Best Albums of 2024
abstract: Charli XCX, Mk.gee and MJ Lenderman top our pop music critics’ lists this year.
lead_paragraph: The agendas for 21st-century musicians keep getting more complicated. They can try to out-game streaming and social media algorithms, stoking the celebrity-industrial complex or steadfastly ignoring it. They can lean into idiosyncratic artistic instincts and intuitions. They can channel the zeitgeist or defy it. Of course, listeners have choices as well. For me, there was no definitive musical statement for 2024, no obvious pathbreaker. But there were plenty of purposeful, heartfelt, exacting and inspired individual statements. I gave the top slot to a project that strove mightily to unite a glossy sonic (and online) presence with surprising confessions. But song for song, the rest of the list can easily stand alongside it. And if there’s more than a little apocalyptic gloom in these choices, well, that’s 2024.

headline: I Should Never Have Picked Up That Gun
abstract: I am surrounded by men who live with regret. And that regret is an incarceration every bit as real as the towering walls around us.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of How to Live With Regret, a series exploring the nature of regret and the role it plays in all our lives. Read more about this project here.

headline: Is the Awkward ‘Diversity Era’ of Hollywood Behind Us?
abstract: The past decade’s clumsiest attempts to cram new faces into old stories now feel like a moment, and a genre, of their own.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood has its eras, often apparent only in retrospect. Think back several years: Do you remember packed theaters giving Black-power salutes at screenings of “Black Panther”? Do you remember when an all-female version of “Ghostbusters” was treated as a pioneering development? Do you remember when the writer of a “Star Wars” film described the Empire as a “white supremacist (human) organization” after Donald Trump’s 2016 election? Has enough time now passed to say that was all a bit strange?

headline: Will Trump Be the President of Vice?
abstract: Moderation on pot and other vices appears to have been part of a calculated effort to turn out young men for the G.O.P. — but it may come with consequences.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Brazilian Jazz
abstract: It’s bossa nova and samba, but so much more — funky, soulful and esoteric. Listen to these songs chosen by Joyce Moreno, Marcos Valle, Amaro Freitas and more lovers of Brazilian rhythms.
lead_paragraph: When the term “Brazilian jazz” arises, one might think of bossa nova, or Sergio Mendes (its most popular purveyor), and stop there. But there’s a world beyond those sunny instrumentals and bright vocals, where artists like Hermeto Pascoal, João Donato and Leny Andrade show that Brazilian jazz can be funky, soulful and esoteric. This type of jazz had deeper resonance beyond the oceanfront views it conjured.

headline: ‘Let’s Make a Dance.’ At Nature Theater, the Body Rules.
abstract: In “No President,” Nature Theater of Oklahoma creates its version of a story ballet, one burpee at a time.
lead_paragraph: It started with a dance. For Nature Theater of Oklahoma, that’s not unusual. Pavol Liska, who directs the company with his wife, Kelly Copper, said, “Dance becomes a kind of cell that contains the full DNA of everything.”

headline: The Anarchist With Big Ideas and a Silver Tongue
abstract: A posthumous collection of essays by the anthropologist and activist David Graeber shows a bold thinker whose original arguments could strain credibility.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after the November election, encountering the energetic optimism contained in the new essay collection by the activist and anthropologist David Graeber is something of a surreal experience. Graeber died suddenly in September 2020, at the tail end of the first Trump presidency — before the QAnon Shaman and the attack on the Capitol; before four years of President Biden; before tech billionaires like Elon Musk joined the Trump team; before Musk pledged to take a wrecking ball to the government bureaucracy that Graeber, a self-described anarchist, spent decades critiquing.

headline: Spy Dramas Are Getting in Touch With Their Feelings
abstract: ‘The Agency’ and ‘Black Doves’ are part of a new crop of espionage series whose biggest battles take place within the hearts and minds of their agents.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and Russia are at war. Political instability and civil war rage in Sudan. Iran is ramping up its nuclear capabilities. The world is basically a mess in “The Agency,” the new espionage series that inundates the viewer with rapidly intersecting story lines set on an increasingly complicated geopolitical playing field.

headline: We Wish You a Streaming Christmas
abstract: From “Our Little Secret” to “The Merry Gentlemen,” a roundup of several holiday movies to stream this season.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the most wonderful time of the year,” the song goes. “There’ll be parties for hosting/Billions of movies for bingeing.”

headline: The Midwestern Roots, and Woods, of N.B.A. Courts
abstract: Connor Sports, in the tiny mill town of Amasa, Mich., is one of the leading makers of hardwood floors for top professional and college teams.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles Clippers fans are being wowed this season by the bells and whistles in the team’s new $2 billion home, the Intuit Dome. They can watch replays on the world’s largest double-sided scoreboard, sit in a 51-row section reserved for die-hard supporters and buy a jersey in the 5,000-square-foot team store.

headline: A Brazilian Artist Movement That Uses Paintings to Save Indigenous Culture
abstract: After the Venice Biennale, the members of MAHKU are taking their social mission to Miami Art Basel.
lead_paragraph: As Cleiber Bane began to sing, he looked up at the purple, red and yellow fish painted along the wooden slats of his home in the Brazilian Amazon. Colorful crabs and birds, as well as an Indigenous man wearing a blue and red feathered headdress, flanked the aquatic creatures, while geometric shapes outlined in black covered the shutters.

headline: New Year’s Eve Fireworks in the Parks Are Canceled
abstract: Because of the drought, the traditional celebration in Prospect and Central Parks won’t happen. Prospect Park plans a light show with drones.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why you won’t see fireworks over two New York City parks on New Year’s Eve. We’ll also get details on how Dunkin’ — the chain famous for coffee and doughnuts — will be onboard the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: Should All Children Under 16 Be Barred From Social Media?
abstract: Australia recently passed a law that does just that. Should other countries do the same?
lead_paragraph: Imagine that your country passed a law barring all children under 16 from social media platforms like TikTok, Instagram and X. Would you welcome this change or be outraged by it?

headline: Steamy Nights Preserved on Film
abstract: Polaroid photos capturing the fugitive spirit and some famous faces of New York’s 1980s club scene are the focus of a new book, “Camera Girl.”
lead_paragraph: Outfitted with a Polaroid SX-70 camera and often dressed like a moll out of noir films, Sharon Smith spent the years between 1980 and 1988 photographing people at storied New York City dance clubs like Area, Roseland Ballroom, the Roxy and the Palladium. Along the way she also snapped stars like Iggy Pop, Madonna, David Bowie and Prince when they were still young.

headline: Supreme Court Inclined to Uphold Tennessee Law on Transgender Care
abstract: The justices heard arguments on Wednesday over whether Tennessee can ban some medical treatments for transgender youth. More than 20 other states have similar laws.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed ready on Wednesday to uphold a Tennessee law denying transition care to transgender youth, with some of them saying that judgments about contested scientific evidence should be made by legislatures rather than judges.

headline: University of Michigan Weighs Changes to Its Diversity Program
abstract: The school is one of higher education’s biggest supporters of D.E.I. Now it’s considering a new approach as critics question the program’s success and impact on campus life.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan, one of higher education’s staunchest proponents of diversity, equity and inclusion plans, is weighing changes to its own program as colleges across the country brace for the second presidency of Donald J. Trump and a Republican assault on such initiatives in government and academia.

headline: Will ‘Constitutional Republicans’ Save the Senate?
abstract: Only a handful of Republicans are needed to stand up for the Senate’s right to advise and consent on nominations.
lead_paragraph: Robert Byrd, the longtime Democratic senator from West Virginia, was steeped in the classics and in the history of the Senate. “Julius Caesar did not seize power in Rome,” Byrd declaimed on the Senate floor in 1993. “The Roman Senate thrust power on Caesar deliberately, with forethought, with surrender, with intent to escape from responsibility.”

headline: Human Interaction Is Now a Luxury Good
abstract: We’re increasingly becoming a society in which very wealthy people get human care, like concierge medicine and private schools with tiny class sizes.
lead_paragraph: In part of her new book, “The Last Human Job,” the sociologist Allison Pugh shadowed an apprentice hospital chaplain as she went through her day. The chaplain ministered to a family that had lost a young woman to a Tylenol overdose. She went from room to room, praying, offering hugs, even singing with bereaved and anxious patients and family members. “There is nothing like being in the worst moment of your life and being met with comfort by someone you don’t even know,” she recounted a patient telling her.

headline: Trump’s Project 2025 May Not Be What It Seemed. It’s Worse.
abstract: The early coercive pressures applied by Trump loyalists are a taste of what is to come.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 19, two weeks after Election Day, Elon Musk demonstrated perhaps the most brutal, if not sadistic, technique for making life in the federal civil service intolerable.

headline: David and Sybil Yurman on Art and Amagansett
abstract: Step into the Hamptons house that the artists and jewelers have renovated through the years.
lead_paragraph: Step into the Hamptons house that the artists and jewelers have renovated through the years.

headline: With Assad Challenged, a Push to Cut Syria’s Ties to Iran Grows More Unlikely
abstract: Even as Israel bombarded Syria, officials say the U.S. and Gulf countries were working to weaken its president’s alliance with Tehran. Rebels’ shock advance has dampened those hopes.
lead_paragraph: For months, his country was battered by escalating Israeli bombardment, while behind the scenes, the United States and Gulf countries courted him diplomatically. It was a secretive, two-pronged approach meant to pressure President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to abandon his most important regional alliance with Hezbollah and Iran.

headline: What to Expect at Today’s DealBook Summit
abstract: Sam Altman, Jerome Powell, Jeff Bezos, Bill Clinton, the podcaster Alex Cooper, Ken Griffin, Prince Harry, and Serena Williams are among the big names speaking.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, DealBook will be live and in person at our annual summit in New York.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,265
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Two Billionaires’ Big Plan to Shrink Government
abstract: What Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy aim to do to the federal government — and what it would look like if their ideas were carried out.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy have called the federal bureaucracy an “existential threat to our republic.” Now, President-elect Donald J. Trump is empowering them to drastically shrink it, by whatever means necessary.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 543
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: What to Know About the Chaos in South Korea, and a Major Trans Rights Case
abstract: Plus, how money to protect pandas is really spent.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Coming Up This Morning: Ken Griffin, founder of Citadel; Sam Altman, co-founder of OpenAI; Serena Williams; and former President Bill Clinton
abstract: Who will be speaking at the DealBook Summit
lead_paragraph: This year’s DealBook Summit will include interviews with some of the most powerful figures from Wall Street, Silicon Valley and Washington. Each has been at the heart of the news cycle this year, and they are likely to be at the center of some of the biggest events of 2025, too.

headline: Syrian Forces Battle Rebels Outside Government Stronghold
abstract: The rebels have set their sights on the city of Hama, where President Bashar al-Assad’s government has long maintained strength.
lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels battled pro-government forces on Wednesday on the outskirts of Hama, a major city in western Syria that has become the latest target of the surprise offensive launched by opposition fighters last week, according to both sides.

headline: How South Korea Plunged Into Political Crisis
abstract: After President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law, protesters gathered in front of the National Assembly and lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to rescind the order. John Yoon, a reporter for The New York Times in Seoul, explains how the extraordinary events were a culmination of years of political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: After President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law, protesters gathered in front of the National Assembly and lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to rescind the order. John Yoon, a reporter for The New York Times in Seoul, explains how the extraordinary events were a culmination of years of political turmoil.

headline: G.M.’s Ailing China Business Will Deal It a $5 Billion Blow
abstract: General Motors and other foreign automakers are selling fewer cars and losing lots of money in China, where domestic electric and hybrid cars have taken off.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Wednesday that it would take a more than $5 billion hit to its profit as it restructured its ailing operations in China, which have been losing money as its car sales there have dropped sharply.

headline: Bird Flu, Explained
abstract: We explore whether you should be worried.
lead_paragraph: By now, you’ve probably seen some alarming headlines about bird flu, and you may be wondering how worried you should be. I understand the uncertainty.

headline: Why South Korea’s Leader, Desperate and Frustrated, Made a Fateful Decision
abstract: ​A day after he declared — and then withdrew — martial law, President Yoon Suk Yeol was politically isolated as observers pondered his future in leadership.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on South Korea and President Yoon Suk Yeol.

headline: As Hegseth Vows to Fight, Trump Considers DeSantis for Defense Secretary
abstract: The president-elect appeared to be having serious conversations about picking Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida as Pete Hegseth, the current selection, dismissed the allegations against him.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: Iran Releases Narges Mohammadi, Nobel Laureate, From Prison for 21 Days
abstract: The activist, whose health has deteriorated, had bone surgery last month. She was just 19 when Iran’s morality police detained her.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Iran have agreed to allow Narges Mohammadi, the jailed activist and Nobel laureate, to leave prison for 21 days to recover from surgery, her foundation said on Wednesday.

headline: Handing Out Grants, Zelensky Tries to Win Over War-Weary Ukrainians
abstract: Citizens will be entitled to a $24 one-off payment this winter, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced, in a move apparently intended to soften the blow of a tax rise to help fund the war effort.
lead_paragraph: After nearly three years of a grueling war with Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine faces a difficult balancing act: extracting more financial resources to sustain the fight without overwhelming a population already straining under the conflict’s economic toll.

headline: Last Year’s DealBook Summit Was Headlined by a Memorable Elon Musk Discussion
abstract: Mr. Musk caught even Andrew Ross Sorkin off guard, as the Tesla and SpaceX leader accused advertisers that had pulled their money from X of trying to “blackmail” him.
lead_paragraph: The 2023 DealBook Summit concluded with an interview of Elon Musk that caught even Andrew Ross Sorkin off guard. In a 90-minute conversation, the divisive billionaire didn’t hold back.

headline: Amazon Sued Over Slow Deliveries to Low-Income Areas
abstract: The District of Columbia’s attorney general said the company deliberately outsourced Prime member deliveries in certain ZIP codes.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general of the District of Columbia sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of violating consumer protection laws by making slower deliveries to Prime members in historically lower-income neighborhoods.

headline: What is ‘heightened scrutiny,’ and why does it matter?
abstract: The question before the justices is whether the challenged Tennessee law, which bans some kinds of medical treatments for transgender minors, violates the Constitution’s equal protection clause.
lead_paragraph: The question before the justices is whether the challenged Tennessee law, which bans some kinds of medical treatments for transgender minors, violates the Constitution’s equal protection clause.

headline: Chanel’s Answer to the China Question
abstract: The house goes all out for its V.I.C.s.
lead_paragraph: What do you do if you are a fashion house possessed of the most coveted open designer job in the business, the subject of manic rumors and speculation, with the world watching every move you make for a hint of announcements to come?

headline: How Can I Show My Boyfriend My Parents’ Filthy Home?
abstract: A reader dreads the thought of her partner seeing her squalid childhood home, but being honest with her parents about her embarrassment is a nonstarter.
lead_paragraph: I am in my late 30s and in a great relationship. We’ve decided to move in together when our separate apartment leases end. We are both very tidy. But I am a clean freak because I grew up in a chaotic, dirty home. It took me years of therapy and self-help to deal with this. My boyfriend is just the opposite: I’ve visited his parents in the beautiful home where he grew up. Now, I am panicked about taking him to visit my childhood home. My parents are dirty and messy. Think: grime and roaches and leaving open cans of cat food on the kitchen counter for days. Telling my parents that I don’t want to bring my boyfriend to visit because I’m embarrassed to bring anyone there would hurt their feelings — which I can’t do. And when I’ve gone home by myself to clean, it causes arguments with them. What should I do?

headline: These 26 States Have Restricted Gender-Transition Treatments for Minors Since 2021
abstract: Transgender minors and their parents, guardians and doctors have challenged bans in 18 states, with mixed results.
lead_paragraph: The challenge to a Tennessee law before the Supreme Court this week traces its roots to the spring of 2021, when Arkansas became the first state to pass a law prohibiting gender-transition treatments for minors. Alabama followed in 2022. Tennessee’s was part of a coordinated deluge: Of 28 states where Republicans control the legislature, 24 now restrict doctors from providing puberty blockers, hormone therapies or surgery to transgender minors. Two more, New Hampshire and Arizona, ban only surgeries.

headline: How the Impeachment of South Korea’s President Will Continue
abstract: A detailed look at each stage of the impeachment process against President Yoon.
lead_paragraph: A detailed look at each stage of the impeachment process against President Yoon.

headline: Here Is What Led to Tennessee’s Ban on Gender-Affirming Care
abstract: Vanderbilt University Medical Center announced the opening of a new transgender care clinic in 2018. Years later, conservatives called for an investigation.
lead_paragraph: Vanderbilt University Medical Center’s announcement of a new transgender clinic in 2018 did little to draw attention to its practice. The four-paragraph news release amounted to a location, hours and the names of two senior staff members.

headline: Guardian Journalists Strike Over Planned Sale of Sister Publication
abstract: Workers have begun a 48-hour walkout, the first in 50 years for the outlet, over a proposal to sell The Observer to Tortoise Media, a digital media start-up.
lead_paragraph: Journalists at the Guardian and the Observer newspapers in Britain began a 48-hour strike on Wednesday over plans to sell The Observer, the country’s oldest-running Sunday publication, to a digital media start-up.

headline: A Year Among My Fellow Banned Writers
abstract: Removing books from schools robs us of important opportunities to understand each other, and ourselves.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: North Carolina Town Sues Duke Energy Over Climate Change
abstract: Carrboro accused Duke, one the nation’s largest utility companies, of ignoring data about climate change while increasing use of fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina town filed a lawsuit on Wednesday accusing Duke Energy, one of the nation’s largest utility companies, of deceiving the public about climate change and contributing to the warming of the planet.

headline: A 2020 decision protecting transgender workers is a major precedent.
abstract: The Supreme Court has rendered only one major decision on transgender rights: Bostock v. Clayton County.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has rendered only one major decision on transgender rights: Bostock v. Clayton County.

headline: Ken Griffin Says America Is Open for Business Following Elections
abstract: Mr. Griffin, who had previously derided Donald J. Trump as a “three-time loser,” said he voted for the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Griffin, the billionaire founder of the hedge fund Citadel and one of the top donors to the Republican Party, said “America is open for business again,” following the results of the United States elections.

headline: Pete Hegseth’s Mother Defends Her Son’s Character on Fox Show
abstract: The mother of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to be defense secretary appeared on the network where her son worked to say that he was a changed man.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Hegseth, Pete Hegseth’s mother, said Wednesday morning that her son was not the same man he was in 2018 when she fired off an email accusing him of routinely abusing women and lacking decency and character.

headline: This Year’s Hottest Holiday Movies
abstract: Want a holiday movie? Elisabeth Vincentelli of The New York Times has some favorites of 2024.
lead_paragraph: Want a holiday movie? Elisabeth Vincentelli of The New York Times has some favorites of 2024.

headline: Google Introduces A.I. Agent That Aces 15-Day Weather Forecasts
abstract: GenCast, from the company’s DeepMind division, outperformed the world’s best predictions of deadly storms as well as everyday weather.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, weather scientists found that the chaotic nature of Earth’s atmosphere would put a limit on how far into the future their forecasts might peer. Two weeks seemed to be the limit. Still, by the early 2000s, the great difficulty of the undertaking kept reliable forecasts restricted to about a week.

headline: Most Rural Hospitals Have Closed Their Maternity Wards, Study Finds
abstract: Labor and delivery units are losing money and struggling to find staff, in rural areas and large cities alike.
lead_paragraph: Over 500 hospitals have closed their labor and delivery departments since 2010, according to a large new study, leaving most rural hospitals and more than a third of urban hospitals without obstetric care.

headline: These Lemon Bars Are a Little Luxe
abstract: My lemon bars with olive oil and sea salt are softer in texture and more bracing in flavor than the usual citrus treat.
lead_paragraph: Have I mentioned I’m a sucker for lemon desserts? (Yes, I expect I have.) The first thing I grab when the treats come out is anything tart, tangy and sunshine yellow. This is true yearlong, but especially in winter, when icy weather and gray skies have me seeking brightness wherever I can find it. A batch of glossy lemon bars with olive oil and sea salt with their sweet-sour-salty curd is my SAD lamp — Seasonal Acidic Delight, that is.

headline: On the Border, Texas Shows Trump the Way
abstract: The incoming Trump administration’s new border czar said that Texas provided a “model” for border enforcement. State officials have offered to be a staging ground for mass deportations.
lead_paragraph: Tom Homan, an immigration hard-liner selected by President-elect Donald J. Trump to be his “border czar,” squeezed into a helicopter last week, as Gov. Greg Abbott gave an aerial tour of all that Texas had done to stop people from crossing illegally from Mexico.

headline: Is It Fair to Judge a Friend by the Way She Voted?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on friendship, suspicion and character assessment.
lead_paragraph: My best friend and I grew up in moderate-conservative households. While I became more progressive as I aged, she grew more conservative. In the past, we were able to have heated conversations and remain on good terms. Now I fear asking whom she voted for, suspecting that it was Trump. While I respect traditional Republican values, I believe Trump supporters are bad and selfish. My questions are: 1) Is it ethical to automatically characterize my friend as a bad and selfish person for potentially voting for him? And 2) Is it ethical to investigate whom my friend voted for just so I can get her to change her mind? — Name Withheld

headline: Police Search for Suspect in Killing of UnitedHealthcare C.E.O.
abstract: Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, was fatally shot outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan as he arrived for a company investor conference.
lead_paragraph: Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, was fatally shot outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan as he arrived for a company investor conference.

headline: Elite Sumo Wrestlers Will Compete in London, a Rarity Outside Japan
abstract: A five-day event in October will be the Japan Sumo Association’s first competition in Britain in more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: Sumo wrestling is coming back to London.

headline: Georgia Tumbles Deeper Into Crisis as Government Detains Opposition Figures
abstract: In a sign of a widening crackdown, security agents have searched the offices and homes of prominent activists and opposition leaders who are furious about the government’s position on Europe.
lead_paragraph: Security agents arrested and roughly dragged away a leading member of Georgia’s political opposition in front of a scrum of journalists on Wednesday as the country plunged deeper into political crisis.

headline: Rebels Push Toward Hama, a Syrian Government Stronghold
abstract: The map of battle in Syria’s civil war, long static, is rapidly changing.
lead_paragraph: The map of battle in Syria’s civil war, long static, is rapidly changing.

headline: Citadel’s Ken Griffin Said He Voted for Trump
abstract: Ken Griffin, the founder and chief executive of Citadel, celebrated President-elect Donald Trump’s win and said, “America is open for business again.”
lead_paragraph: Ken Griffin, the founder and chief executive of Citadel, celebrated President-elect Donald Trump’s win and said, “America is open for business again.”

headline: China Just Showed Washington How It Plans to Fight the Next Trade War
abstract: Faltering U.S. industrial leadership has allowed China to take a harder trade stance as President-elect Donald Trump prepares to take office.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump fired the opening shots in a trade war during his first term, Chinese officials often took days to respond and Chinese businesses followed every threat with alarm.

headline: Brian Thompson Was a Veteran Executive at UnitedHealthcare
abstract: Mr. Thompson managed a division that employs about 140,000 people and offers insurance plans to employers and individuals.
lead_paragraph: Brian Thompson spent more than 20 years climbing through the ranks at UnitedHealthcare, one of the nation’s largest health insurers and a main division of the conglomerate UnitedHealth Group, and there were no signs that his ascent was slowing.

headline: 1 Dead and Over 70 Displaced After Senior Center Fire
abstract: More than 95 firefighters responded on Tuesday night to a four-alarm fire at a senior housing facility in Edison, N.J., according to officials.
lead_paragraph: A fire Tuesday night at a senior center in Edison, N.J., left a 101-year-old man dead and more than 70 displaced during the holiday season, according to local officials.

headline: Sam Altman Says Artificial General Intelligence Is on the Horizon
abstract: Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, said that the arrival of artificial general intelligence would “matter much less” to the average person than currently thought.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, said that the arrival of artificial general intelligence would “matter much less” to the average person than currently thought.

headline: Review: Feeling Frazzled? This Dance Reacts to an Age of Anxiety
abstract: In “Dear Lord, Make Me Beautiful,” the choreographer Kyle Abraham experiments with expressing his emotions about the current moment.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Kyle Abraham is full of anxiety and fear, he has said, feelings that have landed him in a place of fragility. While this hardly sets him apart in this day and age, his latest work, “Dear Lord, Make Me Beautiful,” attempts to thread those feelings into a dance. Abraham, a MacArthur Fellow, is capable of much, but this would be hard for anyone to pull off.

headline: The Debate Over the Hunter Biden Pardon
abstract: Readers discuss the ongoing political and legal debate over whether the pardon was justified. Also: South Korea’s crisis; tariffs; crosswords.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Picks Jared Isaacman, an Entrepreneur and Private Astronaut, to Lead NASA
abstract: Mr. Isaacman’s company Shift4 Payments made him a billionaire, and he has financed two trips to orbit on SpaceX vehicles, including a daring spacewalk in September.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump will nominate Jared Isaacman, a billionaire entrepreneur who led two private missions to orbit on SpaceX rockets, as the next NASA administrator.

headline: Sam Altman Downplays the Dangers of A.I. and Musk
abstract: The chief executive of OpenAI said the technology would boost productivity and rejected worries that his rival mogul could use his political influence to harm competitors.
lead_paragraph: Sam Altman has played down the threat posed by artificial intelligence, saying the technology would be able to mirror the capability of humans sooner than the average person realizes but would “matter much less” than many predicted.

headline: E.P.A. Again Seeks Limits on a Harmful Pesticide
abstract: After a court overturned a ban, the agency has proposed restricting chlorpyrifos to 11 food crops, illustrating the limits of federal regulation.
lead_paragraph: Almost 25 years after federal regulators curbed household use of a pesticide linked to learning disorders in children, and three years after a total ban on its use on food crops, the chemical is again being applied to everything from bananas to turnips in most states.

headline: Lawmakers Move to Impeach South Korean Leader After Failed Martial Law Bid
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s attempt to break a political deadlock by imposing military rule collapsed within hours, leaving him with few defenders. A vote to impeach him could come as soon as Friday.
lead_paragraph: Emboldened by their forceful rejection of military rule, members of South Korea’s political opposition moved on Wednesday to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol, after his abrupt declaration of martial law failed spectacularly.

headline: Trump’s Trade Adviser Pick, a China Hawk, Was Jailed Over Jan. 6.
abstract: Mr. Navarro was a thorn in the side of Wall Street and a loyalist in Mr. Trump’s first term.
lead_paragraph: The cast of people that President-elect Donald J. Trump selected to fill out his economic team in recent weeks was viewed by many as a surprisingly conventional group, raising hope on Wall Street and beyond that Mr. Trump might not actually bludgeon allies and adversaries alike with tariffs.

headline: FIFA Secures $1 Billion Broadcast Deal for Its Club World Cup
abstract: An agreement with the London-based streaming company DAZN came just a day before the draw for the inaugural event and after other networks balked at FIFA’s demands.
lead_paragraph: With time running out, and most broadcasters running away, FIFA said on Wednesday that it had finally managed to secure a broadcast partner for its inaugural 32-team Club World Cup in the United States next year.

headline: Map: Where Rebels Have Advanced in Syria
abstract: Syrian opposition fighters have rapidly expanded the territory under their control in northwestern Syria.
lead_paragraph: Syrian opposition fighters have pushed back government forces around Aleppo in a surprise offensive, rapidly expanded the territory under their control in northwestern Syria. On Wednesday, they battled pro-government forces on the outskirts of Hama.

headline: South Korea’s Turmoil Is the Latest Threat to a Three-Way Pacific Alliance
abstract: Donald J. Trump had been seen as the main risk factor for the partnership between Tokyo, Seoul and Washington. Then came martial law in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: When President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea visited the White House last year, he charmed the Washington establishment by singing Don McLean’s “American Pie.” When he flew to Tokyo to usher in a new era of conciliation with Japan, it was a genial visit, with the prime minister treating Mr. Yoon to “omurice,” a Japanese dish that the South Korean leader likes.

headline: Trump Picks Paul Atkins to Run the S.E.C.
abstract: Mr. Atkins, a pro-business conservative, would likely take a lighter regulatory approach than the current chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump picked Paul Atkins to serve as chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, turning to a pro-business conservative and former regulator to run the agency that is in charge of protecting investors from fraud and malfeasance on Wall Street.

headline: To Save Refugees and Migrants Is to Save Ourselves
abstract: The psychology of fear, blame and scarcity keeps us from solving the crisis of displaced people.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: How Many Clubs Does One Jet Set Need?
abstract: Jeff Klein, the hotelier who turned Tower Bar into a Los Angeles institution, has opened a $40 million private club at the beach.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Crawford, in most situations as cool and collected as they come, sounded like an exploding firework when I asked her about it. “If you live in L.A., this is a big deal,” she said. “We’ve been waiting for something like this for so long.”

headline: Elon Musk Is on a Lot of Billionaires’ Minds
abstract: At the DealBook summit, some billionaires and political leaders marveled at the tech mogul’s reach, access to the levers of power, and staggering wealth.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is not in the DealBook Summit speaker lineup, but his presence is unmistakable.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends the Hunter Biden Pardon, but Suggests It Was Mishandled
abstract: The former president, speaking at the DealBook Summit, suggested that he understood the move but that he wished President Biden “hadn’t said he wasn’t going to do it.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton on Wednesday issued a modest defense of President Biden’s decision to pardon his son Hunter but suggested that Mr. Biden’s handling of the issue amounted to a self-inflicted wound.

headline: What Happens to the Case if the Trump Administration Switches Sides?
abstract: Since the federal government brought the challenge, the change in administration could affect its future before the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: The trans rights case before the justices on Wednesday is called United States v. Skrmetti, meaning that it is a challenge brought by the federal government.

headline: Trump Replaces His White House Counsel Before He Even Started the Job
abstract: The change reflects a renewed focus on who fills key legal posts with direct access to the incoming president, and particularly on a role that was crucial in the first Trump term.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday replaced his choice for White House counsel before he even got a chance to start the job, a sign of the shifting power dynamics in Mr. Trump’s inner circle in the weeks before he takes office.

headline: The Last Time Alcohol Poisoned a Defense Nomination
abstract: Pete Hegseth would not be the first.
lead_paragraph: The nominee for defense secretary was in trouble for carousing, transgressing with women and liquor.

headline: Trump to Nominate Gail Slater to Lead Justice Department’s Antitrust Efforts
abstract: If confirmed as assistant attorney general for the antitrust division, she would inherit lawsuits to break up Google’s search monopoly and ad tech dominance, as well as a case accusing Apple of making it hard for consumers to switch software and hardware.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: Supreme Court Decision Could Affect Other Trans Rights Cases
abstract: The ruling could set a precedent for several challenges to state laws regarding sports participation, bathroom use and health care for adults.
lead_paragraph: The Tennessee law at issue in the case argued before the Supreme Court on Wednesday is known as United States v. Skrmetti, and governs gender transition treatments for minors.

headline: They Were the Last of Their Kind, in Captivity. Can 5 Survive the Wild?
abstract: Researchers are trying a new strategy to reintroduce Hawaiian crows, which have been extinct in the wild for two decades.
lead_paragraph: When the aviary door swung open, offering the five young birds their first taste of freedom, they took note but stayed put at first, watchful.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Joe Biden’s Decision to Pardon His Son Hunter
abstract: Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, former President Bill Clinton argued that President Biden had reason to issue the pardon, but wished Mr. Biden had not repeatedly said he would not do so.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, former President Bill Clinton argued that President Biden had reason to issue the pardon, but wished Mr. Biden had not repeatedly said he would not do so.

headline: Donald Trump and Pete Hegseth See the Same Enemies
abstract: Hegseth, too, wants to fight the “enemy within.”
lead_paragraph: I can never decide whether “embattled” or “beleaguered” is the preferred adjective to describe a cabinet secretary pick whose confirmation chances appear to be vanishing. But with Donald Trump reportedly shopping around for backup candidates to run the Pentagon in his new administration, let’s just say that Pete Hegseth, Trump’s original choice for defense secretary, is clearly embattled, as well as beleaguered. And we can throw in “besieged,” too.

headline: Israel’s Military Says Hostages Were Likely Killed by Hamas as Airstrike Hit
abstract: The six hostages, whose bodies were found in Gaza over the summer, were probably shot in February by their captors as an Israeli strike hit close to the tunnel where they were held, the military said.
lead_paragraph: Six Israeli hostages whose bodies were found in Gaza over the summer were probably shot dead by their Hamas captors in February, around the same time that an Israeli airstrike hit near the underground tunnel where they were being held, the Israeli military said on Wednesday.

headline: A Storied New York Hilton Adds a Grim Chapter to Its History
abstract: The hotel, on West 54th Street, was where journalists examined the Pentagon Papers and where Donald Trump delivered a 2016 victory speech.
lead_paragraph: It’s the quintessential Manhattan hotel, somehow both drab and sleek, an emblem of the gray and glass aesthetic of the city that appears in thousands of beloved Hollywood films and series. The Midtown Hilton — or technically, the New York Hilton Midtown — is one of the city’s largest hotels, and the largest Hilton in the continental United States, with nearly 2,000 rooms.

headline: Serena Williams Said She Learned From Every Loss
abstract: Serena Williams said every tennis match loss helped her “become Serena,” and that she’s applied the mindset of learning from losses to her investment decisions.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams said every tennis match loss helped her “become Serena,” and that she’s applied the mindset of learning from losses to her investment decisions.

headline: In Global Finale, Biden Hopes Rail Project Defines Africa Legacy
abstract: In his last announced trip abroad as president, Mr. Biden relished touring a U.S.-financed train line in Angola intended to transport goods and critical minerals to port.
lead_paragraph: On the final day of perhaps his final trip overseas as commander in chief, President Biden celebrated his foreign policy agenda by turning to a piece of infrastructure at the heart of his identity: a train.

headline: Mammoth: It’s What Was for Dinner
abstract: A study of a 12,800-year-old skull of a toddler offers a glimpse at how early Americans found food, and how their hunts may have led to a mass extinction.
lead_paragraph: For millions of years, North America was home to a zoo of giants: mammoths and mastodons, camels and dire wolves, sloths the size of elephants and beavers as big as bears. And then, at the end of the Pleistocene Epoch about 12,000 years ago, most of them vanished.

headline: Trump Tax Cuts Won’t Help the Economy Grow, Budget Office Finds
abstract: A larger debt and higher interest rates would cancel out the boost from keeping individual taxes lower, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office found.
lead_paragraph: Ending the individual tax cuts President Donald J. Trump signed into law in 2017 would have a negligible effect on the American economy over the next decade, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office found Wednesday in a projection that could deflate Republican promises to supercharge the economy with tax cuts next year.

headline: U.S. Students Posted Dire Math Declines on an International Test
abstract: On the test, American fourth and eighth graders posted results similar to scores from 1995. It was a sign of notable stagnation, even as other countries saw improvements.
lead_paragraph: American students turned in grim results on the latest international test of math skills — adding to a large body of research showing significant academic declines since the Covid-19 pandemic began.

headline: Pardon Backlash Reflects Fraught Breakup Between Democrats and Biden
abstract: The criticism of the president’s pardon of his son from within his own party underscores how far gone his relationship with Democrats in Congress already was.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, the typically chatty New York Democrat and majority leader, often resorts to repeating a single terse phrase when he doesn’t want to answer a question.

headline: Detroit’s Mayor, a Democrat, Will Run for Michigan Governor as an Independent
abstract: Mike Duggan is shedding the label of his longtime party to seek the state’s highest office, as the term-limited Gretchen Whitmer departs in early 2027.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Mike Duggan of Detroit, who has identified as a Democrat for his nearly 40 years in public office, announced on Wednesday that he would run for governor in 2026 as an independent, a development that could roil the politics of his narrowly divided state.

headline: France’s Prime Minister Loses No-Confidence Vote and Is Expected to Resign
abstract: Prime Minister Michel Barnier will most likely remain as a caretaker until a replacement is named. But the vote could create a wider opening for the far right.
lead_paragraph: French lawmakers passed a no-confidence measure against Prime Minister Michel Barnier and his cabinet on Wednesday, sending the country into a fresh spasm of political turmoil that leaves it without a clear path to a new budget and threatens to further jolt financial markets.

headline: Collapse of France’s Government Further Burdens Its Weak Economy
abstract: Already struggling with flat growth and a large debt and deficit, the country faces a new period of instability without a functioning government or a budget.
lead_paragraph: As France prepared for deepening political turmoil after a parliamentary vote on Wednesday that toppled the government, one thing was clear: The paralysis risked unleashing a fresh wave of distress across one of Europe’s biggest economies.

headline: Fed Chair Powell Acknowledges Inflation Is a ‘Little Higher’ Than Expected
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said it was too early for the central bank to start reacting to the tariffs that President-elect Trump had been promising.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bank could be “more cautious” as it cuts interest rates at a moment when the economy was growing strongly and price increases had been slightly sticky.

headline: Citi Bikes Leave ‘Digital Exhaust’ That Could Help Track a Killer
abstract: The police said the gunman who shot an insurance executive pedaled away after the crime.
lead_paragraph: An electric Citi Bike like the one reportedly used as a getaway vehicle after the murder of United HealthCare C.E.O. Brian Thompson creates “digital exhaust,” streams of data that can be used to track the rider, said David Shmoys, a computer scientist at Cornell University who helped design the system.

headline: Eric Adams Proposes Tax Cut for New York City’s Lowest Earners
abstract: Under indictment and facing re-election, Mr. Adams has turned his attention to the city’s affordability crisis.
lead_paragraph: Amid voter concerns over the cost of rent, food and child care, Mayor Eric Adams announced a plan on Wednesday to eliminate New York City income taxes for more than 400,000 of the lowest wage earners.

headline: Rockefeller Christmas Tree Lighting in Midtown to Go On as Planned
abstract: An official with the N.Y.P.D. said there would be a “massive police presence” for the event on Wednesday night, including aviation and canine units.
lead_paragraph: The popular Christmas tree lighting ceremony at Rockefeller Center, about four blocks from where the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, Brian Thompson, was fatally shot on Wednesday morning, will go on as planned on Wednesday night.

headline: Finding a Sense of Purpose and Harmony Onstage
abstract: In a world frequently defined by polarization and isolation, music offers an opportunity to bridge divides and find common ground.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: Mary McGee, Motorcycle Racing Pioneer, Is Dead at 87
abstract: Her most remarkable achievement came in 1975, when she became the first person, man or woman, to complete the Baja 500 race solo.
lead_paragraph: Mary McGee, a risk-loving motorcycle rider who was often the only woman on the tracks she raced on — and certainly the only one wearing a pink polka-dot helmet — died on Nov. 27 at her home in Gardnerville, Nev. She was 87.

headline: Nadler to Relinquish Democrats’ Top Judiciary Post, Bowing to Calls for Change
abstract: Democrats’ longtime leader on the panel faced a challenge from Representative Jamie Raskin, and pressure from colleagues who wanted a younger, more strategic figure at the helm.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jerrold Nadler plans to step down as the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee next term, succumbing to calls for generational change as his party prepares to confront a second Trump administration.

headline: Read Representative Jerrold Nadler’s Letter
abstract: Mr. Nadler told his Democratic colleagues that he planned to step down as the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee next term.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Nadler told his Democratic colleagues that he planned to step down as the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee next term.

headline: Russian General Calls U.S. Chairman of Joint Chiefs
abstract: In a highly unusual call, the two men “discussed a number of global and regional security issues, to include the ongoing conflict in Ukraine,” a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Valery V. Gerasimov, the architect of President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, called President Biden’s top military adviser last week and talked about how to manage escalation concerns between the two countries, according to defense and military officials.

headline: Powell Not Concerned About the Fed’s Independence Under Trump
abstract: Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, the chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, said there was strong bipartisan support on Capitol Hill for the central bank’s independence.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, the chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, said there was strong bipartisan support on Capitol Hill for the central bank’s independence.

headline: Alex Cooper Says She’s Not the ‘Next Howard Stern’
abstract: “I don’t care if people consider me a journalist or a podcaster, or just a girl that talks online every week,” Ms. Cooper said at the DealBook Summit.
lead_paragraph: Alex Cooper of “Call Her Daddy” is the most successful woman in podcasting. This year, she signed a reported $125 million deal with SiriusXM — breaking with Spotify, where she has 4.4 million followers.

headline: Thursday Briefing: An Impeachment Motion in South Korea
abstract: Plus, what’s your favorite holiday tradition?
lead_paragraph: Members of South Korea’s political opposition yesterday moved to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol. The motion could be put to a vote as early as tomorrow, and comes after his declaration of martial law on Tuesday ended in spectacular failure.

headline: Durbin Urges Settlement for Accused 9/11 Plotters
abstract: Senator Richard J. Durbin wants Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III to accept a plea deal with the man accused of planning the attacks, a deal that Mr. Austin had revoked.
lead_paragraph: The departing chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee asked Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Wednesday to support a settlement with the man accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks, a move that would allow guilty pleas to go forward in the last days of the Biden administration.

headline: The Dangerous Precedent of Biden’s Pardon
abstract: It sends a signal that Trump’s abuse of the pardon system was not an aberration.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has issued pardons to just 26 people during his term, and granted the commutation of 132 prison sentences. Though he has been criticized for his reluctance to extend clemency, his choices mostly represented the best form of it, wiping away the criminal stains of everyday people who had been unjustly convicted or reducing prison time for those whose sentences were excessive. And his modest record spoke to Mr. Biden’s attempt to project an admirable restraint in using his absolute, easily abused power to overrule the judgment of the justice system.

headline: Eli Lilly Chief Says He Will Fight for the F.D.A., Challenging Kennedy’s Stance
abstract: The health care giant’s David Ricks defended the agency’s role in reviewing data and ensuring drug safety.
