lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a longtime vaccine skeptic with no medical or public health training, to be the next health secretary has sent a chill through the American public health sphere.

headline: Mike Johnson’s Newest Headache: The Smallest House Majority in History
abstract: The Republican speaker held on to control of the House, but will preside over an even smaller majority at a time when President-elect Donald J. Trump will need his help to achieve major agenda items.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson’s small majority just got even smaller.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in December
abstract: This month has a ton of new titles arriving for U.S. subscribers, including a Nate Bargatze special and the return of “Squid Game.”
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of December’s most promising new titles for U.S. subscribers. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Alex Cooper Said Her Team Spoke With Trump’s About an Interview
abstract: Alex Cooper, the host of “Call Her Daddy” and founder of the Unwell Network, said her team had a Zoom call that she did not attend with Donald Trump’s campaign about a potential interview.
lead_paragraph: Alex Cooper, the host of “Call Her Daddy” and founder of the Unwell Network, said her team had a Zoom call that she did not attend with Donald Trump’s campaign about a potential interview.

headline: Manhunt Enters Second Day After Health Executive Is Gunned Down in Manhattan
abstract: Brian Thompson, the chief executive at UnitedHealthcare, was shot in the back in Midtown Manhattan by a killer who then walked coolly away.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson.

headline: Hannah Kobayashi Is ‘Found Safe,’ Weeks After She Was Reported Missing
abstract: The search drew national attention after she flew from Maui to Los Angeles and did not board a connecting flight to New York last month. Her family said that she had been found safe.
lead_paragraph: A Hawaii woman who was reported missing by her family has been “found safe,” her family said in a statement this month, less than two weeks after the authorities said she had traveled alone into Mexico.

headline: Mexican Authorities Seize 20 Million Doses of Fentanyl in Record Haul
abstract: The operation comes after President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened tariffs on Mexico if the country did not crack down on fentanyl.
lead_paragraph: Mexican security forces captured more than a ton of fentanyl this week, marking the country’s largest synthetic opioid seizure, which officials on Wednesday said was equivalent to 20 million doses of the drug.

headline: Prince Harry Vows to Maintain Fight Against Murdoch Tabloids
abstract: The British royal says his legal battle against parts of the media is about “accountability” and defending legitimate journalism.
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry said his lawsuit against Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloids for hacking his phone was about “accountability,” but he acknowledged that any settlement he might be awarded would likely be dwarfed by his legal costs.

headline: Brian Thompson, Chief Executive of UnitedHealthcare, Dies at 50
abstract: Mr. Thompson, who was fatally shot in Midtown Manhattan, rose to the top of one of the world’s biggest insurance companies.
lead_paragraph: Brian R. Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, who was fatally shot in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday in what police called a brazen, targeted killing, spent more than 20 years ascending the ranks at one of the nation’s leading insurance businesses while raising a family in suburban Minneapolis.

headline: Trump Has ‘Lost Faith’ in N.R.A., Says Gun Group Official
abstract: In a new letter, an N.R.A. vice president said the troubled group needed to rebuild trust with Donald J. Trump and his inner circle.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has “lost faith” in the National Rifle Association, according to a top official at the gun organization, who argued in a recent letter to fellow board members that the N.R.A. needed to regroup so that it could help protect the Republican Party’s new edge in Congress in the midterm elections in 2026.

headline: Kelly Powers, 45, Dies; Fox Health Commentator Told of Her Cancer
abstract: A podiatric surgeon and a regular presence on Fox News, she used her television platform to talk about her brain cancer and treatment as well as cancer research.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Powers, a Fox News commentator and a podiatric surgeon who offered health tips and discussed medical news with viewers, as well as telling them of her own experiences with cancer, died on Sunday at her home in Colts Neck, N.J. She was 45.

headline: U.S. Defends Climate Accord as Nations Call for Stronger Global Action
abstract: In a landmark international hearing on climate change, a U.S. representative backed the Paris Agreement, but left unanswered questions about U.S. commitments in a Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: A representative of the United States took the podium on Wednesday at a landmark hearing before the International Court of Justice and declared that the climate crisis is one of the greatest challenges humanity has ever faced.

headline: A Health Insurance C.E.O. Was Gunned Down in Manhattan
abstract: Also, the Supreme Court appeared inclined to uphold a Tennessee law on trans care. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A police manhunt is underway in New York City after the head of one of the nation’s largest health insurers was fatally shot this morning in Midtown Manhattan. The police described the killing as a targeted attack. Here’s what we know.

headline: Prince Harry Says Murdoch Tabloid Lawsuit Is About Accountability
abstract: Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, vowed to continue his legal battle against Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloids for hacking his phone, in part because he believed that the misconduct of some journalists was calling into question trust in all.
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, vowed to continue his legal battle against Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloids for hacking his phone, in part because he believed that the misconduct of some journalists was calling into question trust in all.

headline: ‘Junk Fees’ or ‘Unbundling’? Airlines and Senators Battle Over Added Costs.
abstract: At a congressional hearing on Wednesday, senators framed the tacked-on fees for passenger seats or bags as akin to extortion. Airline executives pushed back, saying they gave customers options.
lead_paragraph: Is paying to check a bag on a flight a choice, or tantamount to extortion?

headline: How Kash Patel, Trump’s F.B.I. Pick, Plans to Reshape the Bureau
abstract: Donald Trump’s pick to lead the F.B.I. has called for firing the agency’s top officials, shutting down its Washington headquarters and has vowed to investigate the president-elect’s political adversaries.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s pick to lead the F.B.I. has called for firing the agency’s top officials, shutting down its Washington headquarters and has vowed to investigate the president-elect’s political adversaries.

headline: Google C.E.O. Comments On Landmark Monopoly Ruling
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin, the DealBook editor-at-large, asked the C.E.O. of Google, Sundar Pichai, about the August antitrust ruling that labeled Google as an illegal monopoly.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Ross Sorkin, the DealBook editor-at-large, asked the C.E.O. of Google, Sundar Pichai, about the August antitrust ruling that labeled Google as an illegal monopoly.

headline: Experts Say GLP-1 Drugs Have Potential Use Beyond Weight Loss
abstract: Speaking at The New York Times’s DealBook Summit, Eli Lilly’s chief executive and an obesity medicine specialist discussed the potential for wildly popular weight-loss drugs to be used to treat many other conditions.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at The New York Times’s DealBook Summit, Eli Lilly’s chief executive and an obesity medicine specialist discussed the potential for wildly popular weight-loss drugs to be used to treat many other conditions.

headline: UnitedHealthcare C.E.O. Killed in ‘Brazen, Targeted Attack,’ Police Say
abstract: The killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, near a Midtown Manhattan hotel on Wednesday morning set off a vast manhunt.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, near a Midtown Manhattan hotel on Wednesday morning set off a vast manhunt.

headline: Gunman Shoots 2 Kindergartners at Rural Christian School in Targeted Attack
abstract: The gunman at the Feather River Adventist School in Oroville, Calif., later died of what appeared to have been a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A gunman shot two kindergarten students, ages 5 and 6, at a small parochial school in rural California on Wednesday afternoon and then died from what the authorities believe was a self-inflicted gunshot wound, a spokesman for the Butte County Sheriff’s Office said.

headline: Could Dark Chocolate Reduce Your Risk of Diabetes?
abstract: A new study suggests that it might. We asked experts if that’s too good to be true.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve long assumed that you must deprive yourself of delicious foods in order to be healthy, a new study published today in The BMJ offers encouraging news: Eating dark chocolate has been associated with a reduced risk of developing Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Richard Hamilton, Who Helped Solve a Mathematical Mystery, Dies at 81
abstract: He came up with an innovative equation called the Ricci flow that helped mathematicians explore fundamental questions that were once out of reach.
lead_paragraph: Richard Hamilton, an inventive mathematician who devised the Ricci flow, a groundbreaking equation that helped advance understanding of the fundamental nature of three-dimensional space, died on Sept. 29 in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: Trump Picks Ex-Congressman Who Hawked Tax Credits to Lead I.R.S.
abstract: Billy Long served six terms as a representative from Missouri. Since then, he has helped businesses claim a pandemic-era tax credit that has been riddled with fraud and cost the government billions more than anticipated.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that he would nominate Billy Long, a former Missouri congressman, to lead the Internal Revenue Service, effectively pledging to fire the tax collector’s current leader, a Biden appointee.

headline: Sundar Pichai Hits Back at Criticism of Company’s A.I. Leadership
abstract: Google’s chief executive rejected the idea that rivals were set to eat into the company’s dominance in search, despite antitrust fights that could force it to break up.
lead_paragraph: Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, projected a rosy image of his company’s leadership in artificial intelligence, rejecting criticism from rivals and downplaying antitrust fights that could force the technology giant to split itself up.

headline: What We Know About the UnitedHealthcare C.E.O.’s Killing and the Suspect
abstract: A man captured in Altoona, Pa., was charged with murder in connection with the killing of Brian Thompson outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A 26-year-old man was arrested in Altoona, Pa., and charged with murder in the fatal shooting on Dec. 4 of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, in Manhattan.

headline: Rohit Bal, Exuberant Star of Indian Fashion, Dies at 63
abstract: Known as “the bad boy of fashion,” he was among a wave of designers who created modern Indian couture by updating traditional garments.
lead_paragraph: When Mira Nair was making “Monsoon Wedding,” her 2001 film about generational conflict, an over-the-top wedding and the family it nearly unhinges, one of the experts she turned to for sartorial help was Rohit Bal, an exuberant star of the Indian fashion world.

headline: Jeff Bezos, a Past Trump Foe, Is Optimistic About a Second Term
abstract: The Amazon founder said he saw signs of a “calmer” Donald J. Trump on the eve of his return to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Does Jeff Bezos fear President-elect Donald J. Trump? Quite the contrary.

headline: Pete Hegseth’s Troubles at Work Raise Questions About Leadership
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for defense secretary led two nonprofits into debt, and episodes of drinking continued into his days as a Fox News personality.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment he first went on air at Fox News as a contributor, Pete Hegseth’s star on the nation’s most powerful conservative media outlet was on the rise. A decorated combat veteran, Mr. Hegseth became the weekend anchor of the popular “Fox & Friends” show and a familiar presence to viewers across the country, including President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Memphis Police Used Excessive Force and Discriminated Against Black Residents, Justice Dept. Finds
abstract: The Police Department has been under scrutiny since Tyre Nichols’s death last year. The report noted that children in particular had experienced “aggressive and frightening encounters with officers.”
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department released the results of its investigation into the Memphis Police Department on Wednesday, finding that it had used excessive force, treated Black people more harshly than white people and mistreated those with mental health issues. The report said that the civil rights violations had a “corrosive effect.”

headline: A Harris Ally Says Biden Broke a Promise
abstract: An interview with Senator Laphonza Butler, Democrat of California, during her final week in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Laphonza Butler will have served as a senator from California for only about 15 months. But she has been a close ally of Vice President Kamala Harris for 15 years.

headline: Trump Selects Kelly Loeffler, a Top Donor, to Head the Small Business Administration
abstract: During a brief stint as a senator from Georgia, she became a fervent supporter of the president-elect’s agenda near the end of his first term.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: Read the Justice Department’s Report
abstract: The agency released the results of its investigation into the Memphis Police Department, finding that the department used excessive force, treated Black people more harshly than white people, and mistreated people with mental health issues.
lead_paragraph: The agency released the results of its investigation into the Memphis Police Department, finding that the department used excessive force, treated Black people more harshly than white people, and mistreated people with mental health issues.

headline: Bezos Is ‘Very Optimistic’ About a Second Trump Term
abstract: During an interview at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, Jeff Bezos, the Amazon and Blue Origin founder, said President-elect Donald J. Trump was calmer and more confident now.
lead_paragraph: During an interview at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, Jeff Bezos, the Amazon and Blue Origin founder, said President-elect Donald J. Trump was calmer and more confident now.

headline: South Korea’s Defense Minister Steps Down Over Martial Law Decree
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol accepted the resignation of Kim Yong-hyun, who said he took responsibility for the crisis caused by the brief imposition of military rule.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s president, Yoon Suk Yeol, announced on Thursday that he had accepted the resignation of his defense minister, the first member of Mr. Yoon’s cabinet to lose his job since the president’s short-lived declaration of martial law on Tuesday night stunned the country.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the 2024 DealBook Summit
abstract: Trumponomics, inflation, artificial intelligence, the changing media landscape, and the Elon Musk effect — these were the big themes covered at the annual event.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams, Jerome H. Powell, Jeff Bezos and other leaders across business and technology discussed artificial intelligence, inflation, the media and what the world would look like under a second Donald J. Trump presidency.

headline: A City of Cameras: How New York Police Are Hunting a Killer
abstract: The prelude, the crime and the aftermath were all caught on video. But investigators will need to use human intelligence to find the person who gunned down an insurance company’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: The cameras caught the gunman standing alone for five minutes on West 54th Street, ignoring the early-morning rush of people streaming by.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the erosion of the post-Watergate norm that criminal investigations should remain largely outside the reach of political leaders misstated the surname of a former Justice Department official who is now a law professor at the University of Maryland. He is Michael Greenberger, not Greenberg.

headline: Bitcoin Hits a Milestone: $100,000
abstract: The price of a single Bitcoin rose to six figures for the first time, an extraordinary level for a 16-year-old cryptocurrency once dismissed as a sideshow.
lead_paragraph: In May 2010, Laszlo Hanyecz, an early cryptocurrency enthusiast, used Bitcoin to buy two pizzas from Papa John’s. He spent 10,000 Bitcoins, or roughly $40 at the time, in one of the first purchases ever made with the digital currency.

headline: Like Something a Rabbit Might Say
abstract: Garrett Chalfin turns us every which way and teaches us an important lesson.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Trump Picks Banking Executive to Lead Social Security Administration
abstract: Frank Bisignano has spent his career at major Wall Street banks. He has a long history of political giving, mainly to Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: Quote of the Day: Jolted by War, Ukrainians Are Reclaiming Their Literary Heritage
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “If they were alive today, what kind of culture would we have? How different we would be? It chills me to the bone.”

headline: Listen to Jennifer Hudson’s Festive Holiday Playlist
abstract: The singer, actress and TV host shares songs from her new holiday album, as well as favorites by other artists.
lead_paragraph: Like most people, Jennifer Hudson has found a seasonal celebration schedule that works for her. “Normally, I start listening to holiday music right after Halloween, and the lights go up on Thanksgiving night,” said the singer, actress and television host, who in 2022 became the youngest woman to earn an EGOT (an Emmy, Grammy, Oscar and Tony; the entertainment industry’s ultimate achievement).

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: French lawmakers passed a no-confidence measure against Prime Minister Michel Barnier and his cabinet yesterday, deepening the political turmoil that has left the country without a clear path to a new budget and that threatens to further jolt financial markets. He is expected to resign.

headline: The Warning
abstract: No shockwave. No mushroom cloud. But a space nuke would change life on Earth forever.
lead_paragraph: No shockwave. No mushroom cloud. But a space nuke would change life on Earth forever.

headline: The Far Right Just Toppled France’s Government, and Nobody Knows What Happens Next
abstract: The government’s fall shows the strength of the far right.
lead_paragraph: France’s government has fallen.

headline: Word of the Day: incapacitated
abstract: This word has appeared in 62 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word incapacitated has appeared in 62 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 18 in “In Rare Move, Judge Changes Mind After 27 Years and Frees Brooklyn Man” by Corey Kilgannon:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: New York City Approves a Plan to Create 80,000 New Homes
abstract: The City Council passed a major housing plan known as “City of Yes.” Experts and elected officials say it is only a first step to address the housing crisis.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council on Thursday approved an ambitious plan that could make way for 80,000 new homes over the next 15 years, the most significant effort to address the city’s housing crisis in decades.

headline: A Coach Complained About a Dangerous Intersection. Then He Was Killed There.
abstract: A high school football coach was fatally struck by a driver in the Bronx. He was one of three pedestrians killed in traffic over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, after a crash at a Bronx intersection injured five people, a witness, Dwight Downer, complained about speeding drivers.

headline: Penguin on a Beach
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Old Photos Evoke the Chaos of South Korea’s 1980 Unrest
abstract: Clashes during President Yoon Suk Yeol’s brief imposition of martial law echoed the military’s actions during an earlier political crisis that lasted longer and turned deadly.
lead_paragraph: When South Koreans saw footage of troops clashing with civilians while breaking into the country’s National Assembly this week, many recalled the military’s actions during a political crisis in 1980.

headline: Late Night Weighs In on Pete Hegseth’s ‘Teetering’ Nomination Prospects
abstract: Hosts riff on Trump’s possible swap of his secretary of defense nominee amid excessive-drinking claims against Hegseth.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: When a Baby Killer Isn’t a Straightforward Villain
abstract: The real-life murderer who inspired “The Girl With the Needle” was “a monster,” said the actress who plays her, “but the movie is also about showing you her struggles.”
lead_paragraph: In 1920s Copenhagen, a woman named Dagmar Overbye was convicted of murdering multiple infants whose mothers had paid her to find adoptive families for them. She confessed to killing 16 babies, though the true number of victims was likely higher.

headline: Can You Copyright a Vibe?
abstract: One influencer is suing another, accusing her of copying her minimalist aesthetic on social media. It turns out there is a lot of gray area in shades of beige.
lead_paragraph: The oversize beige cable-knit sweater. The center-parted hair. The right knee pointed out, creating a curve at her left hip.

headline: Whatever You Do, Don’t Review This
abstract: Dentists, doctors, professors, dry cleaners. Everybody is asking for a rating these days.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, Ed Koch, then New York’s mayor, often grabbed bemused commuters emerging from the subway, asking them a simple, surprising question: “How am I doin’?”

headline: How the Messy Process of Milking Cows Can Spread Bird Flu
abstract: On America’s large dairy farms, milking is a vast operation, and the potential for disease transmission is worrying, health experts say.
lead_paragraph: After bird flu hit the nation’s dairy farms, it spread with alarming speed. Since March, the virus has infected more than 850 herds in 16 states. It has also infected at least 60 people, nearly all of them farm workers. In recent months, cases in cows and humans have mounted especially rapidly in California, now the epicenter of the outbreak.

headline: The Best Audiobooks of 2024
abstract: Voices, cadence, pacing: These 8 sublime audiobooks do everything right.
lead_paragraph: From vertiginous, ensemble-cast excursions through the dark web and French Polynesia to searing inner monologues of the antebellum South, the Brooklyn rave scene and American music royalty: The year’s best audiobooks are exceptional not just for their writing, but for the vocal performances that make these narratives particularly absorbing in your ear.

headline: The 63 Most Stylish People of 2024
abstract: It was an election year. An Olympic year. A year of brats and cowboys, witches and swans. Amid it all, these people, characters and things stood out.
lead_paragraph: Style manifested in many forms over the last 12 months, as well as in many places: on the campaign trail and red carpets, at stadiums and zoos. The 63 names on this list, which are arranged in no particular order, emerged as those that may come to mind when asked to picture 2024.

headline: Robin Wall Kimmerer Is Learning From ‘Rest as Resistance’
abstract: “It is an important idea and a serious challenge for me, at which I consistently fail,” says the author of the best-selling “Braiding Sweetgrass.” Her new book is “The Serviceberry.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: ‘You Can Never Look Back’: How ’70s Rockers Rebooted for the ’80s
abstract: The year 1984 was a watershed in pop music. The stars who’d made it big the previous decade had to embrace new instruments and MTV or risk being left behind.
lead_paragraph: Don Henley was stuck.

headline: How One of the World’s Richest Men Is Avoiding $8 Billion in Taxes
abstract: The chief executive of Nvidia, Jensen Huang, has taken advantage of popular loopholes in the federal estate and gift taxes, which have quietly been eviscerated.
lead_paragraph: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, is the 10th-richest person in the United States, worth $127 billion. In theory, when he dies, his estate should pay 40 percent of his net worth to the government in taxes.

headline: The NFT Is Dead. Long Live the NFT?
abstract: The giddy craze for nonfungible tokens brought the crypto crowd to art auctions. Now, long after the bubble burst, some still believe.
lead_paragraph: “It was a mania,” said Noah Davis. “But manias are fun.”

headline: When a Cathedral Is a Catwalk
abstract: When the Cathedral of Notre-Dame reopens this week, the clergy will be wearing new liturgical garb designed by Jean-Charles de Castelbajac.
lead_paragraph: Five years after a devastating fire gutted Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris, the medieval church will reopen this week with processions of hundreds of bishops, priests and deacons in new liturgical garb by the French designer Jean-Charles de Castelbajac.

headline: Gazans With Disabilities Face ‘Impossible Times’ of Chaos and War
abstract: A family fled carrying a 9-year-old girl for hours on their backs. Sisters with visual impairments pleaded for help as Israeli airstrikes fell. “It’s a nightmare,” one wheelchair user said.
lead_paragraph: When the Israeli military ordered evacuations in part of northern Gaza about a year ago, Zuhair Abu Odeh rushed out with his 9-year-old daughter, who uses a wheelchair, in search of a safer place.

headline: The Best Romance Novels of 2024
abstract: Here are the novels our columnist loved most.
lead_paragraph: A critic’s best-of list is on some level a confession: You can deduce a lot about my year from the stories I found solace in. So in addition to the expected delights of this year’s romances — lush historical eras, dazzling space battles, scenes of love triumphant — there’s a resonant thread of grief running through the fractured timelines, vengeful heroines, and small-scale victories of the books below.

headline: What Do 5 Million Brazilians Have in Common? A Name With a Grim Past
abstract: Silva, the surname of presidents and soccer stars, has long carried stigma over its colonial links. Now, many see its legacy in new ways.
lead_paragraph: Fernando Santos da Silva’s surname — shared by 150 relatives — is an heirloom from a grim chapter of Brazil’s history.

headline: A Japanese-Inspired, Brooklyn-Built Lighting Collection
abstract: Kawabi’s handmade designs put a new spin on traditional craft.
lead_paragraph: The partners in life Aaron and Irisa Na Kawabi never set out to be partners in business. After their 2014 graduation from the Parsons School of Design, where they met as students, Irisa, now 32, worked as a product designer while Aaron, 35, focused on cabinetmaking, architectural fabrication and retail interiors. But when they married and moved into an apartment-cum-studio in Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in 2022, they ended up making “almost everything we needed together, from cups to chairs,” says Irisa. One highlight: a piece they now call the Cascade Pendant, a ceiling light constructed from two interlocking pieces of American maple embedded with three ellipse-shaped lanterns crafted out of kozo, a highly prized mulberry-bark paper that they source from Shikoku, Japan. Inspired by kengai, a style of bonsai pruning in which branches are trained to grow in a downward direction, as well as by the couple’s shared Asian background (both are of Chinese heritage) and fascination with Japanese design, the pendant was, says Irisa, “a true collaboration because it’s better than what either of us could have done alone.” And so, after a year of planning, they decided to launch Kawabi, a collection of handmade lighting.

headline: Bright, Playful Clothes Designed for a Good Time
abstract: Take a vacation — whether mental or actual — in the season’s most colorful, joyful pieces.

headline: The Winter Arc Asks You to Lock In for 3 Months. Some Take It to an Extreme.
abstract: The wellness challenge became popular this fall through social media, and has sparked a wide array of interpretations.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every day for the past two months, Liv Jordan has woken up at 5:45 a.m., journaled and completed a cardio workout before breakfast. By the end of the day, she has made sure to hit at least 10,000 steps.

headline: A Gothic Ghost Story for All Ages
abstract: Frances Hardinge’s “Island of Whispers” is lush and poetic, and holy moly is it eerie.
lead_paragraph: How often do you find a book that can enchant 10-year-olds and grandparents, that feels both timeless and quirkily specific, that’s super creepy but also hugely life-affirming?

headline: The Best Historical Fiction of 2024
abstract: Our columnist picks the year’s outstanding books.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s the luck of the publishing draw, maybe the emotional weather, but my choices for the 10 best historical novels seem to have more bite than in past years. Here they are, ready to be argued about, in alphabetical order.

headline: Ethiopia’s Agony: ‘I Have Never Seen This Kind of Cruelty in My Life’
abstract: A rare look inside a region still reckoning with the toll of war crimes, even as new conflicts roil the nation.
lead_paragraph: Before war broke out in Ethiopia, in late 2020, Mehari could take the bus home from her work as a doctor at a public hospital in Axum, a town in the country’s northern region Tigray. But then fighting between its ruling party, the Tigray People’s Liberation Front, and Ethiopia’s federal government shut down public transportation, and Mehari was forced to walk 40 minutes between home and the hospital. After federal troops took the town and imposed a 6 p.m. curfew, Mehari would leave the hospital at the last possible moment, staying as long as she could to care for her patients. “I had to run from work to home almost every day,” she recalled. She was afraid soldiers would find her alone after curfew. “Maybe being killed could be the easiest thing that happens to you,” she said.

headline: Coming for Selfies, Staying for Art: Dakar’s Biennale Draws Young Crowd
abstract: Encouraged by Senegal’s new president, teenagers and young adults, with social media tools in hand, have thronged an art exhibition that is usually the exclusive realm of the wealthy and elite.
lead_paragraph: Every two years, the Dakar Biennale draws in wealthy collectors and stylish art aficionados, who show up at exhibitions in Senegal’s capital with sunglasses they’re too cool to take off.

headline: Best Video Games of 2024
abstract: It was supposed to be a sleepy year for the video game industry. Then came surprise hits like Balatro, Animal Well and Astro Bot.
lead_paragraph: Last year was particularly strong for the video game industry. Several major releases found critical and commercial success, including Baldur’s Gate 3 and The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, while smaller indie puzzlers like Chants of Sennaar also delighted audiences.

headline: Democrats Must Stop Treating Black Women as an Afterthought
abstract: If the party fails to see this, it will be the one left behind.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the 2024 presidential election, at times it has felt as though all Democrats could talk about was which demographic groups had drifted away from the Democratic Party and why. What’s generally lost in that conversation is the fact that Black women rallied behind Vice President Kamala Harris. The Democratic nominee earned an overwhelming majority of their votes, including in swing states like Georgia, Nevada and Michigan, even as other groups shifted significantly to the right compared with 2020.

headline: Oh, to Own the Lost Portrait of Arthur Rimbaud!
abstract: The discovery of a rare picture of the tragic, handsome poet, made by his lover Paul Verlaine, set off a bidding war in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The story sounds like the plot of a novel. It all started with a portrait of the poet Arthur Rimbaud, drawn in 1872 by his fellow writer and companion Paul Verlaine.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubai
abstract: Beyond the over-the-top luxury and futuristic towers, discover bustling souks, a contemporary art district and desert cycling trails.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the over-the-top luxury and futuristic towers, discover bustling souks, a contemporary art district and desert cycling trails.

headline: Where Are Rent Prices Rising the Most in New York City?
abstract: Rental inventory is rising in Queens and Brooklyn, and declining in Manhattan. How are new developments altering the rental market?
lead_paragraph: The median asking rent in New York City rose 2.1 percent from October 2023 to October 2024, according to a report from StreetEasy. But even if the average rental is a bit more expensive, the annual growth rate has slowed as inventory has increased, according to researchers, “indicating a calmer market.”

headline: A Jaw-Dropping Show Gives Martha Diamond Her Due
abstract: In her cityscapes, a visionary Manhattan painter created delicate registers of light and shadow, and bravura expressions of abstraction and figuration.
lead_paragraph: Martha Diamond didn’t exactly work in obscurity. A downtown painter who died last year at age 79, she went to college with the critic Peter Schjeldahl, credited the painter Joan Mitchell with changing her practice during a 1970 studio visit and had an early fan in Alex Katz. Her prescient painting of the twin towers as two plumes of smoke was even included in the 1989 Whitney Biennial. But the recognition she enjoyed was never quite in proportion to her achievement, and we can only hope that “Martha Diamond: Deep Time,” a small but jaw-dropping survey now at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, will be the first step in her ascent into the upper reaches of art history.

headline: ‘The End’ Review: It’s All Come to This
abstract: Joshua Oppenheimer’s postapocalyptic musical about a wealthy family in an underground bunker is placidly disturbing.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Oppenheimer is our age’s great bard of cognitive dissonance. His previous two films, “The Act of Killing” and “The Look of Silence,” are technically documentaries about the horrific Indonesian mass killings in 1965-66. But they’re more fundamentally about the extraordinary lengths to which the human mind — or, really, the human soul — is prepared to go in justifying its own coldblooded atrocity. I don’t have to tell you that this goes far beyond one historical event, and so do these two documentaries. The subjects are men who perpetrated the massacre and seemingly feel no remorse at all. Something inside them has rotted away.

headline: ‘Nightbitch’ Review: Motherhood, Woof
abstract: Amy Adams plays a stay-at-home mom who comes to believe that she’s a dog in Marielle Heller’s adaptation of the Rachel Yoder novel.
lead_paragraph: The sly, teasing conceit in “Nightbitch,” a fantasy starring Amy Adams, is that one day her character — a beleaguered, bone-weary mother — turns into a dog. That isn’t a metaphor, though maybe it is. The movie is wily on that point, even as you see her turning into a glossy-coated, tail-wagging, fang-baring canine. It looks kind of fun. Unlike poor Gregor Samsa, whose transformation into a giant insect in Kafka’s “The Metamorphosis” ends tragically, the mother’s change proves exhilarating. Among other things, she no longer needs to behave like a good girl. Hers is a galvanizing rebirth, one that’s red in tooth and claw.

headline: ‘Oh, Canada’ Review: The Confession Booth
abstract: Richard Gere and Jacob Elordi star in Paul Schrader’s meditative drama about guilt and seeking forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: Near the beginning of “Oh, Canada,” Paul Schrader’s adaptation of his friend Russell Banks’s novel “Foregone,” a small camera crew is preparing a room for a documentary interview. It’s a beautiful room, with dark wood-paneled walls, antique furnishings, a case containing awards and trophies. It looks like the home of someone who has led an interesting and successful life.

headline: ‘Y2K’ Review: Dying Like It’s 1999
abstract: A computer glitch makes electronics go haywire in this zany and nostalgic horror-comedy from the comedian Kyle Mooney.
lead_paragraph: The first 20 minutes of the director Kyle Mooney’s “Y2K” are so densely packed with references to turn-of-the-millennium pop cultural ephemera — AND1 apparel, “That 70s Show,” devil sticks, Tae Bo and the Dancing Baby, to name a handful — that I was exhausted by nostalgia before the end of the first act.

headline: ‘Unstoppable’ Review: A Fearless Athlete, at Home and Away
abstract: In “Unstoppable” a focused Jharrel Jerome stars as Anthony Robles, who won a 2011 NCAA wrestling title and was born with one leg.
lead_paragraph: “Unstoppable” tells the story of Anthony Robles, who won a 2011 NCAA wrestling title and was born with one leg. But despite the training montages and the hustling to qualify for teams and competitions, William Goldenberg’s feature directing debut comes to life more often as a conventional family drama than as a conventional sports movie.

headline: For the Once-Sinful Luna Luna, It’s Safety at the Shed
abstract: The New York version of an art carnival has lost the anarchic charge it was born with almost four decades ago (though a new act may thrill the kids).
lead_paragraph: Somewhere, in a city of 8 million people, there must be New Yorkers with amazing flatulence and extraordinary sphincter control.

headline: Pam Bondi’s Journey From Traditional Republican to Warrior for Trump
abstract: The president-elect’s choice for attorney general is known for her charm and fealty to him.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: The Most Stylish People of 2024
abstract: Our Styles desk sees “style” more broadly than the way people dress. It’s your mannerisms, the way you conduct yourself, the way you move through the world. Anthony Rotunno, a fashion news editor for The New York Times, walks us through just some of the people — and surprises — on this year’s most stylish people list.
lead_paragraph: Our Styles desk sees “style” more broadly than the way people dress. It’s your mannerisms, the way you conduct yourself, the way you move through the world. Anthony Rotunno, a fashion news editor for The New York Times, walks us through just some of the people — and surprises — on this year’s most stylish people list.

headline: Do You Like Giving and Receiving Gifts?
abstract: A Wirecutter editor writes that presents are “a tactile gesture of love and appreciation.” Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: It’s the winter holiday season, and for many that means taking part in the ritual of giving and receiving gifts.

headline: The U.K. Voted to Legalize Assisted Dying. Which Other Countries Allow It?
abstract: Assisted dying is legal or partly legal in about a dozen countries, and more are considering allowing it.
lead_paragraph: When lawmakers in Britain last week voted in favor of a proposal to legalize assisted dying for some terminally ill patients, it signaled a profound shift in a country that decisively rejected the idea almost a decade ago.

headline: Taxi, Italian Style: The Classic Yellow Cab That’s Now in Milan
abstract: Mauro Marroncelli was pushing 40. He had his eye on a Crown Victoria taxi. He had to have it.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out what happened to one of the oldest taxis on the streets after it stopped carrying passengers in New York City.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties on the Upper East Side, in Harlem and in Astoria.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath apartment with a galley kitchen, a formal dining room, an en suite bedroom with a windowed bathroom, a walk-in closet and a stained-glass window, on the first floor of a nine-story prewar building in the Metropolitan Museum Historic District, with a live-in super, shared laundry and shared basement storage. Debra Hoffman and Kimberly T. Hastie, Brown Harris Stevens, 212-381-2397; bhsusa.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom house in Millstone, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Huntington, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 5,473-square-foot house from 2006 that has a two-story living room with a double-sided fireplace, a kitchen with high-end appliances, an office and library, a basement with a screening room, covered front and back porches, an outdoor slate patio and fireplace, and an attached three-car garage, on 3.25 acres. Christine Lane, Compass Realty, 973-202-1707, compass.com

headline: Trump Organization Plans an Ethics Policy Without Banning Foreign Deals
abstract: The family business of President-elect Donald J. Trump is expected to announce some restrictions on transactions but is not likely to accept as many limitations as it did eight years ago.
lead_paragraph: When Eric Trump takes the stage at a cryptocurrency conference in Abu Dhabi next week, he will join a lineup of speakers celebrating “the golden age of Bitcoin.” His headlining performance will also represent a golden opportunity to signal that the Trump Organization is wide open for business.

headline: Two San Francisco Renters Fled the City for a Quieter Life. Would They Find It in Sonoma or Marin?
abstract: Seeking city-style activities in a small-town setting, a young couple headed north out of San Francisco in search of a sunny place with character, preferably for less than $1 million. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: Seeking city-style activities in a small-town setting, a young couple headed north out of San Francisco in search of a sunny place with character, preferably for less than $1 million. Here’s what they found.

headline: ‘Cinnamon Softcore Art Deco’? Spotify Wrapped Falls Flat for Some
abstract: The Sound Towns of 2023 have been replaced with features such as an A.I.-driven podcast about users’ listening habits and word-salad-like genre summaries.
lead_paragraph: For Sydney Brown, the annual release of Spotify Wrapped, the personalized rundown of her music streaming habits, has always been a momentous occasion.

headline: Anna Sui Shares Her Favorite Lipstick and Eyeliner
abstract: Plus: jewelry with a resilient spirit, a riverside hotel in Lisbon and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I start out by washing my face with my line’s cleansers, the clearing oil and cleansing water. Then I use my plumping lotion; it has these gold specks in it and it really does something nice to your skin. I use Clearstem’s Hydraglow stem cell moisturizer before I put on my foundation, and then at night I’ll put on their Clearity serum with vitamin C and mandelic acid as well as their CellRenew serum. The beauty product most nostalgic to me is red lipstick. It’s something I started to wear once I moved to New York, because my mom didn’t let me wear lipstick as a teenager. I’ve been using Anna Sui Cosmetics the longest; we’re going on 25 years of that. We always do a red lipstick, number 400, that I wear. I also like the Nars lip pencil in Dragon Girl that I put underneath my lipstick. And I always wear my Perfect eyeliner. I use this eyeliner brush that’s Thierry Mugler, and it’s thick — it gives me that wide eyeliner look that I like. I wear my signature winged eyeliner everywhere, even when I go to the gym, even when I go to the drugstore. I love going to Bigelow [in the West Village] because they have a bubble bath that I like, Mistral in Lychee Rose Floral. I realize that bubble baths must not be popular now, because it’s really hard to find. But I like those bubbles. I guess from old movies, you always see the glamour pusses in the bathtub with all the bubbles. Garren New York, he’s cut my hair forever and nobody cuts hair like Garren. I get so many comments like, “You have such a great haircut.” I get my hair cut maybe three times a year, but I trim my own bangs in between with whatever scissors I have on hand. I wash my hair with R+C Television shampoo and conditioner or the Primary shampoo and conditioner and masque from their Bleu collection. I always use a Denman brush. Every time I go to London, I buy some from Boots. I also just bought a Dyson flat iron. I guess I copy my mom because she always wore fragrance, Chanel No. 5, and lipstick. I wear fragrance every day. I’ve been wearing our new Electric Whisper. I love the black currant and lychee, which give a slight fruitiness, but then the pink pepper patchouli and vetiver add a spiciness. And of course the hint of rose. Again to the gym, to the drugstore … it’s just natural for me to wear it all the time like my mom. The other thing I always wear is nail polish. My favorite color is Seafoam Green. I hate chipped nails, so I usually do my own, twice a week.

headline: Can Martial Law Happen in America?
abstract: Events in South Korea have people thinking.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was dangerous — and absurd.

headline: Notre-Dame Is Restored, but Macron’s Legacy Is in Jeopardy
abstract: The 860-year-old cathedral has been repaired in a time frame many thought impossible. But rather than basking in success, President Emmanuel Macron is mired in political crisis.
lead_paragraph: When the president of France speaks at the reopening on Saturday of the fire-ravaged Notre-Dame Cathedral, the jewel in the heart of Paris, it should by rights be a delicious moment of glory.

headline: China Slaps Sanctions on 13 U.S. Defense Firms
abstract: The largely symbolic move is in response to the Biden administration’s latest arms sales to Taiwan, the island democracy that China considers its own.
lead_paragraph: China imposed sanctions on more than a dozen U.S. defense firms and several American defense industry executives on Thursday in retaliation for the Biden administration’s latest batch of arms sales to Taiwan, the self-governing island claimed by Beijing.

headline: Listen: ‘My Senior Year’
abstract: What can the story of an exchange student from Gaza tell us about senior year in an American high school?
lead_paragraph: Proms. Yearbooks. Homecoming. Senior sunrise.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,266
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Supreme Court Takes On Transgender Care for Minors
abstract: The justices are posed to rule on a ban in Tennessee, with consequences across the country.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court heard a major case on the rights of transgender children that could help uphold or dismantle dozens of laws across the country.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 544
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Manhunt in Manhattan, and Another Trump Pick in Trouble
abstract: Plus, the A.I. that aces weather forecasts.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Death and Taxes
abstract: We explain why the estate tax isn’t working.
lead_paragraph: The federal estate tax — which is imposed on a tiny sliver of rich Americans when they die — is being eviscerated.

headline: ‘Bona’: A Filipina Superstar Wreaks Vengeance in a Two-Fisted Melodrama
abstract: Recently rediscovered and now digitally restored, Lino Brocka’s 1980 movie, starring Nora Aunor, opens for a week at Metrograph.
lead_paragraph: The title character in “Bona,” a stark tale of selfless devotion by the Filipino director and prominent political activist Lino Brocka (1939-1991), is a middle-class Manila schoolgirl who develops a fierce, morbid attachment to a narcissistic movie extra — a fantasy all the more desperate for being set and shot on location in the miserable slum where her idol lives.

headline: ‘Day of the Fight’ Review: Innovating an Old Cliché
abstract: Revisiting a boxing classic, and honoring a filmmaking legend.
lead_paragraph: A professional fighter, or at least a professional fighter with any sense, does one thing in between bouts: They train. They train and train and train. In 1951, Stanley Kubrick made a short documentary called “Day of the Fight,” which virtuosically distilled the process leading to the middleweight boxer Walter Cartier’s victory in a Newark bout.

headline: ‘The Girl With the Needle’ Review: A Series of Unfortunate Events
abstract: This grim and exceptionally stylish film centers on a Danish woman who becomes tied up in the black-market baby trade.
lead_paragraph: A couple of times in “The Girl With the Needle,” a grim story of a woman out of options, the director Magnus von Horn positions his camera in front of a mass of textile workers streaming out of the mill after their shifts. The moments pay homage to one of history’s first motion pictures, a Lumière film of employees leaving a factory.

headline: ‘Lake George’ Review: An Odd Couple Crime Comedy
abstract: A stoic former convict reluctantly teams up with his would-be victim in this off-kilter film by Jeffrey Reiner.
lead_paragraph: In “Lake George,” what initially carries the air of a gritty crime drama makes way for an off-kilter neo-noir comedy that, at its best, reaches for the blood-splattered sardonicism of a Coen brothers film.

headline: ‘The Order’ Review: Catch Him if You Can
abstract: The thriller, about a white supremacist (Nicholas Hoult) and the killing of a real-life radio host, among other crimes, hits familiar genre beats.
lead_paragraph: After the Jan. 6 Capitol riot in 2021, observers noted the parallels between far-right organizations like the Oath Keepers and the Proud Boys and a group of violent extremists called the Order. The Order, which had splintered from the hate group Aryan Nations and aspired to wage a war against the federal government, was linked to multiple crimes that took place in the western United States throughout 1984, including armored-car robberies, a synagogue bombing and the killing of the Denver talk radio host Alan Berg.

headline: ‘The Return’ Review: Homer, for the Holidays
abstract: Ralph Fiennes and Juliette Binoche burn through the screen in this grim take on the homecoming of Odysseus.
lead_paragraph: The last time Ralph Fiennes and Juliette Binoche shared a movie screen, in “The English Patient” (1996), he was a severely singed explorer and she was his sexy nurse. He is in somewhat better shape as Odysseus, the haggard, haunted heart of “The Return,” Uberto Pasolini’s take on the final section of Homer’s “The Odyssey.”

headline: ‘Super/Man: The Christopher Reeve Story’ Review: A Legend and His Kryptonite
abstract: The original Superman actor gets a comprehensive, if narrow-mindedly celebratory, tribute in this traditional talking-heads-style doc.
lead_paragraph: Biographical documentaries too often turn into hagiographies, so you could imagine how that’s even more easily the case when the subject is as beloved as Christopher Reeve. The actor, who is best known for playing Superman in the original 1978 film (and the three sequels that followed in the 1980s), gets a suitably comprehensive tribute in the HBO doc “Super/Man: The Christopher Reeve Story.”

headline: American Kidnapped in Philippines Is Believed to Be Dead, Police Say
abstract: The police said they believed Elliot Eastman, 26, from Vermont, was killed during the abduction in October. They cited testimony from a suspect in custody.
lead_paragraph: Elliot Eastman, an American living in the Philippines who was shot and abducted from the island of Mindanao in October, was most likely killed by his kidnappers, the Philippine National Police said on Thursday.

headline: The War on Terror Had an Unexpected Outcome
abstract: The rebel group H.T.S. was born as an Islamic State branch. But since pivoting from international jihad, it became dominant in Syria’s northwest.
lead_paragraph: The stunningly successful offensive by Syrian rebels last week accomplished what years of bloodshed by larger factions could not. Within four days, the rebel group, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, captured much of Aleppo, one of Syria’s largest cities, and now controls most of Aleppo Province and all of Idlib Province. Long-entrenched front lines held by government forces and fortified by Russian firepower crumbled.

headline: This Holiday Season, Give Someone a Second Chance
abstract: New Jersey Re-entry Corporation helps people stay out of prison after they’ve been in.
lead_paragraph: This column is part of Times Opinion’s 2024 Giving Guide. Read more about the guide in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: Deadly Israeli Strike Hits Gaza Humanitarian Zone
abstract: The Israeli military said it was targeting senior Hamas militants in the area. Video from the scene showed the charred remains of tents.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military bombed a densely populated tent encampment on Wednesday night in an area of southern Gaza that it had designated as a humanitarian zone, saying the airstrike targeted senior Hamas militants who were operating in the area.

headline: How Global Conflicts Helped Reignite Syria’s Civil War
abstract: Rebels launched sweeping assaults against the forces of President Bashar al-Assad in northwestern Syria, taking control of large portions of territory, including much of the city of Aleppo. Carlotta Gall, a senior correspondent for The New York Times, explains how events beyond Syria’s borders lit the fuse for renewed fighting.
lead_paragraph: Rebels launched sweeping assaults against the forces of President Bashar al-Assad in northwestern Syria, taking control of large portions of territory, including much of the city of Aleppo. Carlotta Gall, a senior correspondent for The New York Times, explains how events beyond Syria’s borders lit the fuse for renewed fighting.

headline: Musk, Trump, A.I. and Other DealBook Summit Highlights
abstract: The economy, inflation, tariffs, the future of media, pardon politics and other big topics that made headlines this year.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. election dominated the news agenda this year, and the two people at the center of Donald Trump’s win came up in nearly every conversation yesterday at the DealBook Summit. The president-elect and Elon Musk may not have been in the room, but questions about how they will shape business and politics were front and center.

headline: South Korean General Gives a Confused Account of a Failed Crackdown
abstract: The military has spent decades trying to rehabilitate its image and win public trust after a brutal past. Its role in President Yoon’s martial law raised a specter from that era.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on South Korea and President Yoon Suk Yeol.

headline: DealBook Summit: 2024’s Speakers
abstract: Hear from Jeff Bezos, Sam Altman, Jerome Powell, President Bill Clinton, Alex Cooper, Ken Griffin, Prince Harry and Serena Williams, among others.
lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

headline: Pantone’s 2025 Color of the Year Is Mocha Mousse
abstract: Is this shade of dusty brown a repudiation of “Brat” green?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Pantone announced its 2025 color of the year: Mocha Mousse. Far softer than the “Brat” green that dominated 2024, the shade is a nougaty brown that reminded Styles staff members of everything from luxury knitwear to swamp water.

headline: Syrian Rebels Storm Another Major City
abstract: Opposition forces advanced on the city of Hama as their startling offensive moved quickly in the direction of the capital, Damascus.
lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels stormed into the city of Hama on Thursday as government forces withdrew, bringing the rebels one step closer to the capital Damascus, the seat of power of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Frigid, Snowy Storm Blasts the Northern United States
abstract: Forecasters warned of the possibility of wind gusts as strong as a hurricane as another round of heavy lake-effect snow and blustery cold moves through the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people across the Midwest, Northeastern United States and southern Ontario, Canada, were under winter weather warnings as snow squalls moved through Thursday morning ahead Arctic temperatures blasting through the region with blustery and potentially damaging wind gusts.

headline: Amnesty International Accuses Israel of Genocide in Gaza
abstract: Israel rejected the charge — the first of its kind by a major human rights organization — saying it was “based on lies.”
lead_paragraph: Amnesty International on Thursday became the first major international human rights organization to accuse Israel of carrying out genocide in Gaza, drawing a rebuke from Israeli officials who denied the claim.

headline: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Embrace the Horror
abstract: Fictional fear can be beautifully distracting from life’s real terrors.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: World’s Priciest Dinosaur Fossil Comes to Museum of Natural History
abstract: The billionaire Kenneth C. Griffin, who bought the stegosaurus fossil for $44.6 million, is lending it to the American Museum of Natural History in New York for four years.
lead_paragraph: The most expensive dinosaur fossil ever sold at auction, a stegosaurus that the billionaire Kenneth C. Griffin bought over the summer for $44.6 million, has a new home: the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

headline: Israeli Strike Hits Densely Populated Tent Encampment in Southern Gaza
abstract: The Israeli military said the strike targeted Hamas militants operating in the area. Wafa, the Palestinian Authority’s news agency, said at least 20 were killed and several more were wounded.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said the strike targeted Hamas militants operating in the area. Wafa, the Palestinian Authority’s news agency, said at least 20 were killed and several more were wounded.

headline: How Trump Targeted Undecided Voters Without Breaking the Bank
abstract: The Trump team had a huge financial disadvantage. It made up for it with a strategy that allowed it to narrow the focus of its ad dollars.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s super PAC called them the streaming persuadables.

headline: OPEC Plus Postpones Plan to Increase Oil Output for Three Months
abstract: The oil cartel had aimed to start opening the taps in January, but delayed in the face of weak demand and plans by other countries to raise production.
lead_paragraph: Once again, major oil producers have postponed a plan to increase production, a decision that comes amid a weak market that is facing slow global demand and increased output from other countries.

headline: Pete Hegseth and His ‘Battle Cry’ for a New Christian Crusade
abstract: The veteran picked to lead the Defense Department has praised the brutal religious military campaigns of the past and has called for a Christian approach to governing.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: It’s Easy Being Green Spaghetti
abstract: Espagueti verde combines silky strips of charred poblanos with crema and heavy cream for a luscious, celebratory pasta dish.
lead_paragraph: I know this ship has very much sailed, but does anyone else miss summer produce? I think wistfully of the gleaming peppers, eggplants and pyramids of corn that filled those warmer months. Perfect heirloom tomatoes, I hardly knew ye. Maybe it’s the fact that it’s currently subzero where I live, or maybe I went too hard on the season’s first squashes, but I find myself craving fresh, zingy, acidic flavors.

headline: This Carcinogen Keeps Cropping Up in Personal Care Products
abstract: Benzene has been found in sunscreen, deodorants, acne creams and more. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Benzene seems to have cropped up everywhere in recent years. First, it was hand sanitizers with “unacceptable levels” of the carcinogen. Then there were recalls of antifungal foot sprays and alarming reports of tainted deodorants, dry shampoos and sunscreens.

headline: The Allure of ‘Microdosing’ Ozempic
abstract: Some people are taking tiny amounts of weight loss medications, hoping to drop pounds while avoiding side effects. Does it work?
lead_paragraph: Erica Liebman wanted to lose weight, but she was nervous to try a drug like Ozempic. Ms. Liebman, a psychologist in Philadelphia, had heard horror stories of side effects — nausea, vomiting, intense constipation.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Eras Tour Book’ Sold 814,000 Copies in its Launch Week
abstract: The print sales over the Thanksgiving weekend nearly matched the first week of Barack Obama’s “A Promised Land.” And she did it while selling only at Target, avoiding Amazon and bookstores.
lead_paragraph: The biggest book release of the year isn’t a blockbuster novel or an explosive celebrity memoir. It’s concert merch.

headline: Poking Fun at Classical Music, With Wigs, Hula-Hoops and Puns
abstract: After 11 years, Eddy Chen and Brett Yang are moving on from their beloved, enormously popular comedy duo TwoSet Violin.
lead_paragraph: The violinists Eddy Chen and Brett Yang arrived in the suburbs of Bangkok recently on a mischievous mission. They had come to record hip-hop videos about Beethoven, Bach and other titans of music as if they were alive today.

headline: Kennedy’s Scary Ideas, and Ones Worth Considering
abstract: Readers worry that “our lives are at stake” if he becomes health secretary but also find areas of agreement. Also: Unity, not revenge; criminal justice in New York.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Prince Johnson, 72, Warlord Who Executed Liberia’s President, Dies
abstract: A rebel leader in Liberia’s civil wars, he was accused of numerous atrocities. The most notorious was the videotaped mutilation and killing of President Samuel Doe.
lead_paragraph: Prince Johnson, a former warlord who calmly sipped a Budweiser and had a woman fanning him as he watched his soldiers mutilate and murder Liberia’s president, Samuel K. Doe, died on Nov. 28 in a suburb of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. He was 72.

headline: Trump’s Cabinet Will Be an Embarrassment of Wretches
abstract: The onslaught of awful makes bad look good.
lead_paragraph: Flash back to Donald Trump’s first campaign for president. It should have been doomed when he mocked John McCain’s years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam. Or when he fantasized about one of his supporters shooting Hillary Clinton. Or when, on that “Access Hollywood” tape, he was heard reveling in the genital prerogatives of fame.

headline: My List: A Different Kind of Review Contest
abstract: Choose three to five works of art or culture to group in some way, then tell us why we should — or shouldn’t — check them out. Contest dates: Jan. 15-Feb. 12, 2025.
lead_paragraph: 20 Unforgettable Looks at the Met GalaFive Action Movies to Stream Now 4 of the Best Veggie Burgers in Los Angeles

headline: Torrent of Hate for Health Insurance Industry Follows C.E.O.’s Killing
abstract: The shooting death of a UnitedHealthcare executive in Manhattan has unleashed Americans’ frustrations with an industry that often denies coverage and reimbursement for medical claims.
lead_paragraph: The fatal shooting on Wednesday of a top UnitedHealthcare executive, Brian Thompson, on a Manhattan sidewalk has unleashed a torrent of morbid glee from patients and others who say they have had negative experiences with health insurance companies at some of the hardest times of their lives.

headline: Ukraine Makes a Case to Trump’s Team as Its Officials Visit U.S.
abstract: Kyiv is feeling a sense of urgency leading up to the Jan. 20 inauguration, given the American president-elect’s vow to end the war quickly.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials are visiting the United States this week to seek continued American support and met with members of Donald J. Trump’s transition team to appeal to a president-elect who has pledged to bring a quick end to Ukraine’s war with Russia.

headline: French Prime Minister Resigns After No Confidence Vote
abstract: French lawmakers voted to oust Prime Minister Michel Barnier, making his three-month-old government the shortest in modern French history.
lead_paragraph: French lawmakers voted to oust Prime Minister Michel Barnier, making his three-month-old government the shortest in modern French history.

headline: Trump’s Threats Over the Dollar Could Accelerate Push for Alternatives
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened to impose tariffs on countries that seek to replace the dollar in trade or undermine its global reserve currency status.
lead_paragraph: When Republicans nominated Donald J. Trump to be their presidential candidate over the summer, the party’s platform included a pledge to maintain the role of the United States dollar as the world’s reserve currency.

headline: He Won’t Leave His Home. The Landlord Is Renovating Around Him.
abstract: A longtime tenant is locked in a standoff with the owner of his Upper West Side building.
lead_paragraph: Eric Abrams struggles up the stairs with his cane, one step at a time.

headline: Veggie Recipe Matchmaker, Part 2
abstract: “My mom is a very picky eater.” “I’m stumped for future dinners.” “I’ve recently discovered that I’m gluten-intolerant.” Let’s go.
lead_paragraph: More recipe recommendations, personalized to Veggie readers’ hyper-specific needs? That’s the gift that keeps on giving. This is Recipe Matchmaker, Part II. (If you missed last week’s on Thanksgiving Day, give it a read here.)

headline: Who Is Tech Really For?
abstract: As Silicon Valley chases military tech and funding, it’s losing sight of what inspires its workers.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: Manhattan Shooter Used a Silencer. Nearly 5 Million Are Registered in the U.S.
abstract: The tightly regulated firearm accessory has long been associated with Hollywood hit men but is rarely seen in real-life murders.
lead_paragraph: The gunman who killed the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday morning appeared to have used a silencer, a tightly regulated firearm accessory that has long been associated with Hollywood hit men but is rarely seen in real-life murders.

headline: Peter B. Teeley, Who Coined the Term ‘Voodoo Economics,’ Dies at 84
abstract: As press secretary for George H.W. Bush, he came up with the expression to attack Ronald Reagan’s economic plan. The term took on a life of its own.
lead_paragraph: Peter B. Teeley, who as the sharp-penned press secretary for George H.W. Bush during his 1980 presidential campaign coined the term “voodoo economics” to describe the tax and spending plans of the candidate’s rival at the time, Ronald Reagan, died on Friday in Washington. He was 84.

headline: A Backpack Maker Believes He Identified the Shooting Suspect’s Bag
abstract: Peter Dering, the founder and chief executive of Peak Design, says he called the N.Y.P.D. tip line on Wednesday after receiving a wave of messages showing the suspect carrying a distinctive backpack.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dering, the founder and chief executive of Peak Design, looked down at his phone Wednesday morning in San Francisco and saw about 10 texts, some from people he had not heard from in years.

headline: NASA Artemis Moon Missions Delayed Until 2026 and 2027
abstract: It is unclear where the program to go back to the lunar surface will head after President-elect Donald J. Trump returns to the White House in January.
lead_paragraph: NASA on Thursday postponed a mission to send four astronauts around the moon and back to Earth until April 2026.

headline: Roommate Murdered Kenyan Gay Rights Activist, Court Finds
abstract: Edwin Chiloba’s body was found stuffed inside a metal box by the roadside last year. A high court judge did not give a motive but said his roommate carried out the murder.
lead_paragraph: The roommate of a prominent gay activist in Kenya was convicted on Wednesday of murdering him, almost two years after the grisly killing shocked the East African nation and spread chilling fear among its gay community.

headline: University of Michigan Ends Required Diversity Statements
abstract: The school, a bastion of D.E.I., will no longer require the statements in hiring decisions and is considering a broader shift in its policies.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan will no longer require diversity statements as part of faculty hiring, promotion and tenure decisions, the school announced on Thursday, marking a major shift at one of the country’s leading public research institutions.

headline: Federal Judge Rejects Boeing’s Guilty Plea Related to 737 Max Crashes
abstract: The agreement, opposed by some victims’ families, would have required the aviation company to pay a fine of up to $487 million and invest in additional safety measures.
lead_paragraph: In a rare move, a federal judge on Thursday rejected Boeing’s proposed agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to conspiracy to defraud the federal government in connection with two fatal 737 Max crashes, according to court documents.

headline: ‘Hard Truths’ Review: Mike Leigh’s Brutal Comedy
abstract: The British director casts the superb Marianne Jean-Baptiste in the role of an excruciatingly lonely character whose pain reveals hidden depths.
lead_paragraph: Some filmmakers like to go easy on you with pacifying stories, appealing characters and reassuring worldviews. Mike Leigh is having none of that. For the past half century, this formidable, rigorous British filmmaker has been making movies that, when they’re not making you gasp with laughter, take the wind out of you as quickly as a gut punch. He makes acidly funny and bitter movies, and is adept at both. The titles of some of those films suggest his expansive interest in the breadth, depth and ordinary poetry of the human comedy: “Bleak Moments,” “High Hopes,” “Life Is Sweet,” “Naked,” “Happy-Go-Lucky.”

headline: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week take you to the top of the world (via Daniel Light’s history of mountaineering) and into the trenches of world politics (via Angela Merkel’s memoir and Rahul Bhatia’s study of India), with detours to Broadway, the megamall and an apocalyptic take on “King Lear.” Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: The Best Sparkly Shoes, From $60 to $1,850
abstract: For holiday party season, easy ballerinas and Mary Janes that catch the light.
lead_paragraph: “For the majority of us who don’t have $1,600 to spend on, say, Loewe’s rhinestone-adorned flats, Zara’s iteration is a close alternative at a more accessible price.”

headline: 7.0 Quake Rattles Northern California, Prompting a Brief Tsunami Warning
abstract: The epicenter was in remote spot offshore. So the earthquake, while powerful, caused limited damage.
lead_paragraph: A powerful earthquake struck 30 miles off the California coast on Thursday morning, prompting emergency tsunami alerts to buzz on more than half a million cellphones and sending cans and bottles crashing to the floors of grocery stores in the rural communities closest to the epicenter.

headline: What to Know About a Landmark Court Case
abstract: Judges in The Hague are weighing what, exactly, international law requires countries to do about global warming.
lead_paragraph: The most important climate case that a lot of people haven’t heard about is playing out this week and next at the International Court of Justice.

headline: Lance Morrow, 85, Award-Winning Essayist for Time Magazine, Is Dead
abstract: His voice carried weight on the influential back page and as the writer of many “Man of the Year” cover articles. As a memoirist he chronicled his heart attacks.
lead_paragraph: Lance Morrow, a journalist and author whose elegant essays, often with historical sweep, appeared for two decades on Time magazine’s back page when it was a significant corner of American opinion journalism, died on Friday at his home in Spencertown, N.Y., in Columbia County. He was 85.

headline: UnitedHealthcare Has Faced Scrutiny Over Denying Claims
abstract: The company has been accused of using algorithms to deny treatments and refusing coverage of nursing care to stroke patients.
lead_paragraph: As one of the nation’s largest health insurers, covering more than 50 million people, UnitedHealthcare has battled a range of complaints and investigations from patients, doctors and lawmakers for its denial of medical claims.

headline: Justice Neil Gorsuch Recuses From Case That Could Benefit Colorado Billionaire
abstract: The justice had been under pressure to step aside from the matter because of his myriad ties to Philip Anschutz, an oil and gas magnate.
lead_paragraph: Justice Neil M. Gorsuch has recused himself from a case that is set to be argued in days after ethics watchdogs and Democratic lawmakers urged him to step aside because the outcome will likely affect the financial interests of a billionaire to whom he has longstanding ties.

headline: No Food, Water or Power for Opponents Hiding From Venezuelan Government
abstract: Six leading opposition activists and advisers have taken refuge at the Argentine diplomatic residence for eight months. Now, the police are cutting off basic services.
lead_paragraph: Several of Venezuela’s leading opposition figures, facing arrest warrants, have been in hiding at the Argentine diplomatic residence in the capital, Caracas, for more than eight months, where they have sought asylum.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in December
abstract: This week in Newly Reviewed, Max Lakin covers Liza Lacroix’s psychic landscapes, Il Lee’s ballpoint wonders and Mel Bochner’s conceptual prank.
lead_paragraph: This week in Newly Reviewed, Will Heinrich covers Raven Chacon’s birdsong, Thornton Dial’s big cats and Park Seo-Bo’s news interventions.

headline: Map: 7.0-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes Northern California
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: Texas Man Who Killed and Dismembered 3 Is Sentenced to Death
abstract: Jason Alan Thornburg, who lured his victims to a motel room, told the police he was “being called to commit sacrifices,” according to an arrest warrant.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man who lured three people to a motel room and then killed and dismembered them because he believed he was “being called to commit sacrifices,” was sentenced to death on Wednesday, prosecutors said.

headline: Memphis Says It Will Not Yet Agree to Federal Oversight of Police Department
abstract: The city’s mayor reiterated his reluctance to enter a consent decree after the Justice Department found a pattern of discrimination and excessive force by its officers.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Memphis reiterated on Thursday that the city would not immediately agree to negotiate an overhaul of the Memphis Police Department with the federal government, with Mayor Paul Young warning that doing so could be “bureaucratic and costly.”

headline: ‘The Sticky’ Is a Taut and Tasty Heist Thriller
abstract: Starring Margo Martindale, the six-episode Amazon series, based loosely on a true story, tells a gonzo tale of a maple syrup heist.
lead_paragraph: “The Sticky,” available Friday on Amazon Prime Video, is the latest quirky crime dramedy to begin with a title card disavowing its veracity: “This is absolutely not the true story of the great Canadian maple syrup heist.” Indeed, “The Sticky” is inspired only loosely by the actual heist of 2011-12, in which thieves in Quebec stole $18 million worth of syrup over the course of several months. The clearer inspiration for the show is all the other shows it resembles, all the far-flung cousins at the “Fargo” family reunion.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Uncrustables
abstract: Should football players eat Uncrustables to become champions?
lead_paragraph: Note: Live-moderation for this graph will take place on Wednesday, Dec. 11. The next graph will be posted by Friday, Dec. 13, with live-moderation on Jan. 8, 2025.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 9, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Note: Live-moderation for this photo will take place on Monday, Dec. 9. The next image will be posted by Friday, Dec. 13, with live-moderation on Jan. 6, 2025.

headline: The Big Question: What Is Underrated?
abstract: Experts from the worlds of music, food, film, etiquette and relationships each reveal something that — up until now — has been underrated.
