lead_paragraph: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: Who Are You Calling ‘You Guys’? Everyone, Actually.
abstract: The story of how a gendered word became a universal pronoun says a lot about how language evolves.
lead_paragraph: Remember the ad that Donald Trump ran accusing Kamala Harris of being “for they/them” while he proudly claimed to be “for you”? I was surprised to see grammar take the lead on issues influencing a presidential election. But pronouns have a rich history as fighting words, and “you” is an especially personal one; it can be at once simple and accusatory, depending on the context. Those Trump ads put me in mind of another such controversy over the use of “you”: “you guys” when it’s directed toward women.

headline: What to Do When There’s a Tsunami Warning
abstract: Tsunamis can’t be predicted, but there are steps you can take to stay safe.
lead_paragraph: A tsunami is in the news. Here are answers to some common questions about the phenomenon.

headline: Remembering Peter Westbrook, Fencing Legend and Father Figure
abstract: He inspired several generations of Black fencers and other athletes.
lead_paragraph: Peter Westbrook, a six-time Olympic fencer, was a force of nature.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Teachers Using A.I. to Grade
abstract: Teenagers and educators weigh in on a recent question from The Ethicist.
lead_paragraph: Is it unethical for teachers to use artificial intelligence to grade papers if they have forbidden their students from using it for their assignments?

headline: Here’s How Earthquakes Are Measured
abstract: What does “moment magnitude” mean, and how do scientists determine the strength of a rupture in the earth?
lead_paragraph: Seismologists register the intensity of an earthquake in units known as moment magnitude, which measure how much energy was released when the rocks along a fault moved during the quake.

headline: We Answer Your Very Specific Restaurant Questions
abstract: Neighborhood gems, Mexican bacchanals and more reader requests.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the nether-period between Thanksgiving and the holidays, when the weather is bleak and the obligations are abundant. To brighten our week, we’re back with our favorite type of newsletter: Answering your questions! We posted on our Instagram story a couple of weeks back to ask for your highly specific requests, and now we’ve got some highly specific recommendations.

headline: Friday Briefing: Syrian Rebels Storm Another City
abstract: Plus, a celebration of art in Dakar.
lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels stormed into the city of Hama yesterday as government forces withdrew in another stunning setback for President Bashar al-Assad. A rebel commander said on social media that their adversaries were in “a significant state of confusion,” with government soldiers and commanders abandoning their posts.

headline: Former Proud Boys Leader Testifies in Defense of Officer Accused of Aiding Him
abstract: Enrique Tarrio appeared in court for the first time since being sentenced to 22 years in prison for seditious conspiracy over his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the far-right Proud Boys, appeared in court on Thursday for the first time since he was sentenced for his role in the events of Jan. 6, 2021, testifying in defense of a police officer accused of improperly feeding him sensitive information.

headline: Jordan Neely’s Father Sues Daniel Penny, Accusing Him of Assault
abstract: Andre Zachery claims that Mr. Penny, who put Mr. Neely in a chokehold on a subway train last year, caused his son’s death through “negligence, carelessness and recklessness.”
lead_paragraph: The father of Jordan Neely, a 30-year-old homeless man who died on a New York City subway car last year after another passenger put him in a chokehold, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against Daniel Penny, the man who choked his son.

headline: Taking a Closer Look at Southern Cooking, One Region at a Time
abstract: With her cookbook, “Our South,” Ashleigh Shanti is one of a few chefs who are focusing closely on regional cuisine — and redefining it in the process.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard for the chef Ashleigh Shanti to pick a favorite region of the South, but if pressed, she says she’d pick Appalachia, specifically Carroll County, Va., where her great-aunt Hattie Mae lived.

headline: Defiant Hegseth Fights to Keep Pentagon Bid Alive, as Votes Remain Uncertain
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s choice to lead the Pentagon said he would try to earn every vote so long as he remained the president-elect’s pick, despite continued concern among Republican senators about his past conduct.
lead_paragraph: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s embattled choice for secretary of defense, defiantly vowed on Thursday to earn the votes necessary for confirmation, seeking to allay Republican concerns over his fitness for the job and persuade Mr. Trump to stick with him.

headline: Images of Unmasked Suspect Emerge as the Police Track C.E.O.’s Killer
abstract: The man sought in the killing of Brian Thompson wore a hood and a smile in surveillance photos. Investigators visited a hostel on the Upper West Side as they mapped his movements.
lead_paragraph: Security-camera images of a man wearing a hooded jacket and an easy smile. A fake ID. A cellphone found on a Manhattan sidewalk. Bullets marked with the words “deny” and “delay.”

headline: A Defiant Macron Says He Won’t Resign as France’s Leader
abstract: A day after his chosen prime minister was forced to resign, President Emmanuel Macron denounced his political opponents.
lead_paragraph: A day after his government fell in a no-confidence vote, forcing his handpicked prime minister to resign, President Emmanuel Macron of France lashed out at his political opponents on Thursday, calling them irresponsible and power-hungry, and declaring he would not step down.

headline: Motherhood at 74: World’s Oldest Known Wild Bird Lays Egg
abstract: Wisdom, a 74-year-old Laysan albatross, laid an egg at Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge at the northwestern edge of the Hawaiian Archipelago.
lead_paragraph: Wisdom, a 74-year-old Laysan albatross, laid an egg at Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge at the northwestern edge of the Hawaiian Archipelago.

headline: Think You Know How to Brush Your Teeth?
abstract: Dentists would like a word.
lead_paragraph: Dentists would like a word.

headline: Listen: Sample 4 Best Books of 2024
abstract: You’ve read our list of the year’s best fiction and nonfiction. Now start listening to them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Book Review editors spent all year reading, debating and finally selecting their top 10 fiction and nonfiction titles of 2024. Now you can hear how they sound.

headline: A Spate of Vandalism Rattled Estonia. Russia Was to Blame, Officials Say.
abstract: Several people were convicted in connection with small acts of vandalism carried out at the behest of Russia’s military intelligence service, prosecutors announced Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For years, Allan Hantsom was a fixture in Estonia’s tight-knit pro-Russian political movement. He belongs to a political party sympathetic to Russia’s war in Ukraine, he frequently railed against the United States and NATO on social media, and he contributed to a Kremlin-sponsored propaganda outlet.

headline: Shalom Nagar Dies; Reluctant Executioner of Adolf Eichmann
abstract: He was the hangman chosen to carry out the sentence on the fugitive Nazi war criminal, in Israel’s only case of capital punishment.
lead_paragraph: Shalom Nagar, who was a reluctant 23-year-old Israeli prison guard when he was chosen to hang Adolf Eichmann — the fugitive Nazi war criminal convicted of crimes against humanity and genocide in the murder of six million Jews — died on Nov. 26 in Israel. He was in his late 80s.

headline: Hegseth Is Fighting to Keep His Nomination Alive
abstract: Also, the police are chasing several leads in New York manhunt. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Pete Hegseth, who Donald Trump picked to be defense secretary, pledged today to continue to fight for the role, even as several Republican senators have already expressed concern about allegations that he committed sexual assault and drank to excess. Hegseth met this afternoon with senators whose votes could be crucial.

headline: U.S. Is Closing California Prison Plagued by Sexual Abuse
abstract: The Bureau of Prisons said in a memo that it was grappling with “a very difficult budget situation along with significant repair and maintenance backlogs.”
lead_paragraph: The Bureau of Prisons is permanently shutting down an infamous women’s prison in California that was the site of rampant sexual abuse as well as disbanding six other facilities as part of a broader consolidation effort, according to a memo sent to bureau staff on Thursday.

headline: McKinsey Agrees to Pay $122 Million to Settle South Africa Bribery Case
abstract: The global consultancy was accused of bribing foreign government officials. A former senior partner pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge.
lead_paragraph: McKinsey & Co. agreed to pay a fine of more than $122 million to resolve a felony bribery investigation stemming from its work in South Africa, federal prosecutors in New York said in a filing unsealed Thursday. It is the latest in a string of legal penalties for the global consulting firm, which in recent years has agreed to pay about $1 billion in settlements for its work with opioid manufacturers.

headline: Senate G.O.P. Super PAC Chief Follows McConnell and Steps Down
abstract: Steven J. Law’s departure represents a changing of the guard for the super PAC and coincides with a new leader for Senate Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The head of the top super PAC for Senate Republicans, Steven J. Law, is stepping aside after a decade running one of the most powerful big-money groups in American politics.

headline: Kindergartners Are ‘Critical but Stable’ After California School Shooting
abstract: Two boys were rushed to hospitals on Wednesday after they were shot by a gunman on their rural school campus in Northern California. The authorities say the suspect had a history of crimes and mental illness.
lead_paragraph: The two kindergartners were on their way to the restroom during lunchtime on Wednesday, in what was supposed to be a simple trip before heading back to class at the Feather River Adventist School.

headline: How a Stowaway at J.F.K. Airport Made It All the Way to Paris
abstract: Prosecutors accused Svetlana Dali, 57, of hiding among other travelers during a busy travel day before Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: A woman who stowed away on a flight from New York to France last week managed to do so without a passport, much less a boarding pass, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: A Visual Timeline of the UnitedHealthcare C.E.O. Shooting
abstract: A gunman killed Brian Thompson in Midtown Manhattan Dec. 4. Maps, surveillance footage and photos show how the shooting unfolded and how the suspect fled.
lead_paragraph: A gunman killed Brian Thompson in Midtown Manhattan Dec. 4. Maps, surveillance footage and photos show how the shooting unfolded and how the suspect fled.

headline: ‘You Are Out of Line’: Acting Secret Service Director Clashes With Congressman
abstract: A congressional hearing on Thursday erupted into a shouting match. Ronald L. Rowe Jr., the acting Secret Service director, accused Representative Pat Fallon, Republican of Texas, of politicizing a 9/11 memorial event.
lead_paragraph: A congressional hearing on Thursday erupted into a shouting match. Ronald L. Rowe Jr., the acting Secret Service director, accused Representative Pat Fallon, Republican of Texas, of politicizing a 9/11 memorial event.

headline: ‘Mary’ Review: An Epic Biopic for the Mother of God
abstract: No genre gesture goes untapped in this Netflix film, a coming-of-age saga about the Virgin Mary featuring Anthony Hopkins as King Herod.
lead_paragraph: Horses gallop across a desert. Christianity’s most famous couple meet cute at a river. Swords clatter. A villain emerges from flames. Insect buzz accompanies the come-ons of a devil. (OK, the Devil.) No genre gesture goes untapped in the deliberately hagiographic “Mary,” a coming-of-age saga about the mother of Jesus. Directed by D.J. Caruso and written by Timothy Michael Hayes, the film aims to draw multitudes.

headline: Biden Team Considers Blanket Pardons Before Trump’s Promised ‘Retribution’
abstract: White House officials believe President-elect Donald J. Trump’s selection of partisan warriors for top law enforcement jobs indicates that he will pursue revenge against his perceived enemies.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s staff is debating whether he should issue blanket pardons for a swath of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s perceived enemies to protect them from the “retribution” he has threatened after he takes office, according to people familiar with the discussion.

headline: Elon and Vivek’s DOGE Goes to Congress
abstract: The tycoons in charge of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s amorphous government efficiency initiative made the rounds on Capitol Hill, bashing debt but revealing little about how they will tackle it.
lead_paragraph: As far as congressional meetings go, Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy’s huddle with Republicans was remarkably efficient.

headline: Head of Secret Service and Congressman Get Into Shouting Match at Hearing
abstract: The agency’s acting director took offense when a Texas representative questioned him about where he was standing in a photo commemorating the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: The acting director of the Secret Service and a Republican congressman from Texas got into a shouting match in a congressional hearing on Thursday over the acting director’s appearance in an official photo during a remembrance ceremony in New York on Sept. 11.

headline: Avett Brothers Musical ‘Swept Away’ to Close on Broadway After Short Run
abstract: The new musical, about a shipwreck and its aftermath, opened Nov. 19 at the Longacre Theater.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: On Dec. 10, the producers of “Swept Away” said that they would postpone the show’s final performance until Dec. 29, citing “a surge in ticket sales” following the announcement that the show would close.

headline: House Blocks Release of Ethics Report on Gaetz as Republicans Close Ranks
abstract: In largely party-line votes, the House turned back two measures that would have forced the Ethics Committee to make public the results of its investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct and drug use.
lead_paragraph: The House on Thursday night blocked the release of a damaging Ethics Committee report about former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, as Republicans voted to bury it, an expected move that makes it less likely the materials will ever be made public.

headline: Why Was a Tsunami Warning Issued, and Then Canceled? A Forecaster Explains.
abstract: The warning was sent in response to a 7.0-magnitude that struck off the coast of Northern California. A tsunami warning coordinator described the process.
lead_paragraph: About five minutes after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Northern California on Thursday morning, forecasters issued a tsunami warning at the highest of four levels.

headline: Tsunami Warning in San Francisco ‘Felt Like a Science Fiction Movie’
abstract: Many Bay Area residents raced away from the ocean after a jolting cellphone alert warned, “You are in danger.” Others raced toward it.
lead_paragraph: With his surfboard tucked under his arm, Alex Felton was about to walk a couple of blocks to San Francisco’s Ocean Beach on Thursday morning when his cellphone blared. “TSUNAMI WARNING!” an alert screamed. “You are in danger.”

headline: What We Know About the 7.0 Earthquake That Struck Northern California
abstract: State and local officials were working to assess the full scope of the damage, but early reports appeared to show that the quake did not cause major destruction.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 struck off the coast of Northern California on Thursday, briefly prompting a tsunami warning and leaving residents rattled from Southern Oregon to the San Joaquin Valley in California.

headline: A Miracle: Notre-Dame’s Astonishing Rebirth From the Ashes
abstract: Five years after a fire nearly felled the cathedral that has dazzled visitors for almost 900 years, the heart of Paris beats anew.
lead_paragraph: Five years after a fire nearly felled the cathedral that has dazzled visitors for almost 900 years, the heart of Paris beats anew.

headline: In First Post-Election Speech, Obama Calls for ‘Forging Alliances and Building Coalitions’
abstract: “Purity tests are not a recipe for long-term success,” the former president said in the speech in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: In his first speech since the presidential election in November, Barack Obama urged Americans who want democracy to survive to look for ways to compromise, engage with the other side, turn away from identity politics and build relationships with unlikely potential allies.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the challenges Speaker Mike Johnson will face with such a small Republican majority in the House misstated which parts of government Democrats currently control. They control the White House and the Senate, not the House and the Senate.

headline: Trump Names Top Silicon Valley Conservative to Oversee Crypto and A.I.
abstract: David Sacks, a venture capitalist who hosts a hit podcast, has generally called for a looser hand in regulating both emerging technologies.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has named one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent conservative investors, donors and media personalities to help oversee American tech policy.

headline: Insurer Reverses Policy That Would Have Limited Anesthesia Periods
abstract: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield officials had planned to roll out the changes nationwide but said they were misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield, a major health insurer, on Thursday rolled back a policy change that would have capped payments for anesthesia for patients, and would have denied claims altogether if any given procedure exceeded a time limit.

headline: Opposition Grows to South Korea’s President as He Faces Impeachment
abstract: The leader of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party has backed impeachment, on which the National Assembly is set to vote on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea grew increasingly isolated on Friday, after the head of his ruling party came out in support of impeaching the president, and the country’s military said it would not follow any orders to reimpose martial law.

headline: Turning Point
abstract: We wish you a merry Robyn Weintraub Day.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Elon Musk Backed Trump With Over $250 Million, Fueling the Unusual ‘RBG PAC’
abstract: The enormous spending from the world’s richest man quietly fueled allied groups and was revealed only now, as Mr. Musk plays a key role in the presidential transition.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, spent over a quarter of a billion dollars in the final months of this year’s election to help Donald J. Trump win the presidency, federal filings revealed on Thursday.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Shelf-Stable Parmesan
abstract: Can an Italian American use “shaky cheese” if he’s cooking for a toddler?
lead_paragraph: Dean writes: My sisters give my wife and me grief for using “shaky cheese.” This is considered heresy in my Italian American family. But we don’t eat enough pasta to justify buying the expensive stuff. And with a 2-year-old son, we don’t have the time to labor over every meal the way my sisters do.

headline: Trump Picks Former Senator and Election Denier to Be Ambassador to China
abstract: David Perdue would serve in the role at a time when the U.S.-China relationship is considered to be the most consequential in the world.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Thursday that he would nominate David Perdue, a businessman and former senator from Georgia, to be his ambassador to China.

headline: Trump Names 2 Officials to Help Carry Out Immigration Crackdown
abstract: The president-elect picked Rodney S. Scott, an outspoken Border Patrol chief from his first term, to run Customs and Border Protection. And he chose Caleb Vitello to head Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Trump on Thursday tapped a pair of longtime officials for key roles in his planned immigration crackdown, including an outspoken Border Patrol chief from his first term whom the Biden administration ousted.

headline: Quote of the Day: For the Disabled, Life in Gaza Was Always a Struggle. Now, It’s Agony.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We’re living through impossible times.”

headline: The Office Holiday Party Is Back. But What to Wear?
abstract: Tips from The Times’ fashion director on how to navigate the sartorial anxieties of the season.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the joys of Christmas: sleigh bells, fir trees, Santas, the office holiday party.

headline: Two Officiants Walk Into a Wine Bar
abstract: Kaitlyn Barclay and Ingrid Parl have each performed wedding ceremonies for three couples. They recently had their own.
lead_paragraph: Kaitlyn Elizabeth Barclay and Ingrid Sheila Parl are both known in their social circles to be that friend you can call about relationship drama or a first date.

headline: At the Top of Her Bucket List: Saying ‘I Do’
abstract: When Moira Legault, who has brain cancer, was given about a year to live, she knew she wanted to spend the rest of her life with Tyler Ferron.
lead_paragraph: Moira Collette-Jean Legault had just awakened from a brain operation when she received some devastating news. She would most likely have about a year to live.

headline: From the Beginning, Speaking the Same Language
abstract: Laura Guerrero and Temoc Gonzalez, both from Guadalajara, Mexico, met through Instagram and felt an instant connection. “We spoke in Spanglish and just clicked,” Mr. Gonzalez said.
lead_paragraph: Temoc Herrera Gonzalez was instantly smitten when he saw a tagged picture of Laura Guerrero on the Instagram account of the Spanish restaurant Loquita Santa Barbara in August 2020.

headline: A Close Friendship That Developed Into a ‘Soulful Connection’
abstract: Although Samantha Greenstone had many gay friends, her relationship with Jacob Hoff, whom she met nine years ago, was different.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Martin Hoff said, “It was love at first cackle,” when he met Samantha Wynn Greenstone in the lobby of the theater at the Welk, a resort in Escondido, Calif., on Nov. 30, 2015. The two, both actors, were attending a callback for “Fiddler on the Roof.”

headline: A Spark on the Yoga Mat Turned Into a Flame
abstract: Rachael Palm and Carolyn Warhaftig developed a rapport as teacher and regular student. On the eve of a big move, feelings were confessed.
lead_paragraph: In early 2019, Rachael Kesler Palm was teaching an afternoon power sculpt class at FlyDog Yoga in Charlottesville, Va., when Carolyn Ann Warhaftig walked in.

headline: My Son Is Gone. Our Conversation Goes On.
abstract: Three days before my child unexpectedly died, he primed me to keep living.
lead_paragraph: Every night before I go to sleep, I write in a journal to my 12-year-old son, Tommy, and continue a conversation we started on April 13, 2018, just three days before he unexpectedly passed away.

headline: Notre-Dame Reopens: Here’s What to Know
abstract: Millions of visitors will flock to the Parisian cathedral after it reopens in December for the first time since a destructive fire in 2019.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Notre-Dame Cathedral reopening in Paris.

headline: Inside ‘Rail Force One’: The Trains That Take World Leaders to Ukraine
abstract: With airspace closed and missiles flying, visiting Kyiv typically means 10 hours on bumpy tracks — even for presidents, prime ministers and business magnates. It’s plenty of time to reflect.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly three years since Russia invaded Ukraine, Ursula von der Leyen, the European Union’s top official, has grown accustomed to the 10-hour overnight train ride to Kyiv. She passes the time preparing for meetings and reading books about Ukraine, when she is not trying to catch some sleep.

headline: In Britain, Starmer Is Trying to Fight Populism From the Lonely Center
abstract: One of the last centrist leaders left on the global stage, Prime Minister Keir Starmer this week outlined his plan to deliver change for people in the U.K. Will it be enough?
lead_paragraph: Five months after his Labour Party won a thumping election victory, Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain finds himself a lonely figure: Like-minded centrist leaders in France and Germany are in retreat, while in the United States, Donald J. Trump and his populist message have vanquished the Democratic Party.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: A day after a health care executive was assassinated outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan, a frantic manhunt for the gunman continued. The authorities released two images that they said showed the face of the suspect, and a senior law enforcement official said he used a fake New Jersey identification to book a room at a hostel the night before the killing.

headline: Political Turmoil Adds to South Korea’s Economic Woes
abstract: Even before a short-lived declaration of martial law thrust the country into crisis, the economy faced grim prospects.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from the short-lived declaration of martial law by President Yoon Suk Yeol has heaped another worry onto South Korea’s economy, which was already teetering from slowing growth and fears about damage to exports from a shift in U.S. trade policy.

headline: South Korean Who Grabbed Soldier’s Rifle: ‘I Couldn’t Back Down’
abstract: An Gwi-ryeong, a spokeswoman for a political party, went viral after confronting troops during South Korea’s night of martial law. “My first thought was that I just needed to stop the soldiers,” she said.
lead_paragraph: An Gwi-ryeong, a spokeswoman for a political party, went viral after confronting troops during South Korea’s night of martial law. “My first thought was that I just needed to stop the soldiers,” she said.

headline: Climbers Who Went Missing on New Zealand’s Tallest Peak Are Believed Dead
abstract: The police suspended their search for two Americans and a Canadian who went missing while trying to reach the summit of Aoraki/Mount Cook.
lead_paragraph: The New Zealand authorities said on Friday that they believe three climbers who went missing several days ago on the nation’s tallest mountain are likely to have died because of the harsh conditions.

headline: Could Trump Make the Ultimate Deal With Iran?
abstract: Over the next four years, the toxic and seemingly unending psychodrama between the United States and Iran may very well see its final act.
lead_paragraph: In his first term as president, Donald Trump’s approach to Iran crossed almost every red line imaginable.

headline: How Notre-Dame Was Reborn
abstract: It took about 250 companies, 2,000 workers, about $900 million, a tight deadline and a lot of national pride.
lead_paragraph: The embers of Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris were still hot when President Emmanuel Macron vowed that France would rebuild it to be “more beautiful than ever.”

headline: Word of the Day: schwa
abstract: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word schwa has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 30 in “Takeaways From the Scripps National Spelling Bee Final” by Emmett Lindner:

headline: Atrocities Made a South Korean City Infamous. A Novelist Made It Immortal.
abstract: The last time South Korea imposed martial law, Gwangju endured a deadly crackdown. Han Kang, the Nobel Prize-winning author, told its story in “Human Acts.”
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on South Korea and President Yoon Suk Yeol.

headline: Fire at Baltimore Lumberyard Closes Highway and Schools
abstract: No one was injured or evacuated in the fire, which was made more challenging by the wind, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A fire broke out at a city-run lumberyard in Baltimore on Thursday evening and raged into the night, prompting the cancellation of Friday classes at two schools, and the closure of a section of a highway and a portion of the light rail.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: He Mocked the Rich on TikTok for Fun. Now He Can Get $30,000 Per Post.
abstract: Aris Yeager’s “European Kid” videos have been an unexpected hit. Wealthy people and luxury brands have noticed.
lead_paragraph: A rich kid stands in the doorway of a marble-lined bathroom, a cellphone pressed to his ear. His face is strained. He’s yelling and waving his free arm. He swears in French, very clearly having a tantrum, with his father on the line, over money for a trip to Miami.

headline: In the ’90s, She Was a Surprise Oscar Nominee. It May Happen Again.
abstract: Marianne Jean-Baptiste’s lead role in “Hard Truths,” directed by Mike Leigh, is her most substantial onscreen role since “Secrets and Lies” earned them Academy Award nominations in 1997.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2023, Marianne Jean-Baptiste was on a flight from Los Angeles to London, feeling “petrified.”

headline: Stay or Go Chart
abstract: This is part of a chart that appeared in The New York Times this week. Do you know what it is about?
lead_paragraph: This is part of a chart that appeared in The New York Times this week. Do you know what news event it relates to? Why do you think The Times would have published it?

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Thinks Pete Hegseth Cameo Videos Could Soon Be a Thing
abstract: The late-night host wondered if the embattled pick for secretary of defense could end up appearing on the online platform in time for Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Their Fertilizer Poisons Farmland. Now, They Want Protection From Lawsuits.
abstract: A company controlled by Goldman Sachs is helping to lead a lobbying effort by makers of fertilizer linked to “forever chemicals.”
lead_paragraph: For decades, a little-known company now owned by a Goldman Sachs fund has been making millions of dollars from the unlikely dregs of American life: sewage sludge.

headline: No One Should Go Hungry in America
abstract: While lawmakers try to find long-term solutions to food insecurity, Feeding America is filling the void for tens of millions of Americans every day.
lead_paragraph: It is an astonishingly large number: 5.3 billion. That’s how many meals were distributed by the nation’s largest domestic hunger relief organization, Feeding America, in 2023 alone. In a country of more than 330 million people, it is evidence of how widespread and persistent food insecurity remains in the United States.

headline: Everybody Loves FRED: How America Fell for a Data Tool
abstract: From Facebook political debates to college classrooms, the St. Louis Fed’s data tool has gained a major following.
lead_paragraph: Fans post about him on social media. Swag bearing his name sells out on the regular. College professors dedicate class sessions and textbook sections to him. Foreign government officials have been known to express jealousy over his skills, and one prominent economist refers to him as a “national treasure.”

headline: How an Orchestra Plays Along With a Live Video Game
abstract: A controller will direct a conductor’s baton during live performances of Journey at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: For each music cue in the dreamlike, solemn odyssey of the video game Journey, the engine tracking the player’s behavior pulls from a library of compositions, scoring a dynamic path through the game’s vast desert landscapes.

headline: She Revolutionized Medicine. Why Isn’t She a Household Name?
abstract: Lydia Reeder’s “The Cure for Women” tells the story of the remarkable Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi.
lead_paragraph: “I would be great,” wrote a 10-year-old Mary Putnam, circa 1852. “I would do deeds, so that after I had passed into that world, that region beyond the grave, I should be spoken of with affection.”

headline: Trump Should Consider All the Good Congestion Pricing Could Do for His Hometown
abstract: The program will unleash an economic boon, breathing new life into a city still trying to get its bearings post-Covid.
lead_paragraph: After five months in limbo, New York’s congestion pricing program has been given new life. But it is still far from clear whether the plan to ease traffic, reduce air pollution and raise billions of dollars for mass transit in New York City will live or die.

headline: The Best Graphic Novels of 2024
abstract: A sketchbook collection, a Joycean comedy and a brutal self-examination gave us a lot to look at.
lead_paragraph: The year 2024 was an especially good year for comics readers who had been waiting a long time. Olivier Schrauwen brought his magisterial “Sunday” to a close after five years. After 15, Chris Ware published the third volume in his trilogy of “Datebook” comics adapted from his sketchbooks. And Charles Burns finally completed and published in English the project he’d been serializing in French — “Dédales” to our European friends, “Final Cut” to us.

headline: A London Apartment Where Family Life and Treasured Artworks Coexist
abstract: Mathieu Paris and Razid Kalfane have transformed a neglected flat in Marylebone into a home — and a showcase for their gallery-quality collection.
lead_paragraph: PASS THROUGH THE front door of Mathieu Paris’s three-bedroom apartment, on the top floor of a brick four-story Victorian building in London’s Marylebone neighborhood, and you might think that you’ve inadvertently wandered into an art gallery rather than the home of new parents and their toddler daughter. But given that Paris, 41, is the global sales director of White Cube, the international gallery with two outposts in London, perhaps it’s no surprise that even the foyer, though paneled in varnished plywood and sparingly furnished, holds prized pieces.

headline: Fresh Takes on Potato Salad
abstract: Plus: festive fashion, a new destination on the Brazilian coast and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: For Haitian Americans like the chef Gregory Gourdet, 49, potato salad bears little resemblance to the deli counter mainstay. Growing up in Queens, he instead ate salade russe, a traditional Haitian recipe in which potatoes are combined with peas, onions and beets, which turn the dish bubble gum pink. Today, Gourdet serves his own take on that dish as part of the summer menu at his restaurant Kann in Portland, Ore., smoking the beets and binding the ingredients with creamy rémoulade. It’s just one of a number of variations on Russian potato salad, known as Olivier — which was created in 19th-century Moscow and now shows up everywhere from Sweden to Korea — currently appearing on restaurant menus. At Eel Bar on New York’s Lower East Side, the chef-partner Aaron Crowder, 39, makes what he describes as a “New York version of the Spanish version of Russian potato salad,” informed by the ensaladilla rusa served at tapas bars that often includes green olives and roasted red peppers. He tops his with orange trout roe. Tyler Akin, 41, the chef and a partner at the Mediterranean restaurant Bastia in Philadelphia, makes potato confit in chicken fat and then mixes it with saffron-spiked aioli and shavings of Sardinian bottarga. Potato salad, he says, “just so clearly wants to be served warm and soft,” like the bacon-flecked, mayo-free German-style version that his family favors.

headline: In These Dark Times, Stand Up for Human Dignity
abstract: Organizations supporting vulnerable Haitian immigrants are under tremendous strain.
lead_paragraph: In the years ahead, many of us will be asking ourselves: Who is the most vulnerable to whatever comes next? It is, sadly, a rather long list. This has been a brutal year for people in many places across the globe. Sudan is in the grip of a merciless civil war. Bombs, disease and starvation stalk the people of Gaza. The people of Ukraine face another brutal winter in the maw of Russian aggression. These all deserve our attention, but I want to ask you, our readers, to think of someplace a little closer to home, a nation whose history and fate are so deeply intertwined with ours: Haiti.

headline: 7 Things Everyone Should Know About Antidepressants
abstract: Here’s how the drugs can affect weight, mood, libido and other functions.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’ve never taken an antidepressant, you’re probably familiar with the criticism and controversy that surrounds these drugs. It’s not uncommon to hear things like: “Those pills are just a placebo.” “You’ll definitely gain weight.” “Once you start, you’ll become dependent on them.”

headline: See How the War in Syria Has Changed
abstract: A surprise advance by Syria’s rebels has redrawn a conflict marked for more than a decade by unusual, shifting alliances.
lead_paragraph: A surprise advance by Syria’s rebels has redrawn a conflict marked for more than a decade by unusual, shifting alliances.

headline: Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward’s New York Penthouse Is Listed for $9.95 Million
abstract: The celebrated couple bought the co-op overlooking Central Park in the early 1980s and used it as a pied-à-terre — and for big, splashy parties.
lead_paragraph: The longtime Manhattan home of Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, a sprawling penthouse at the exclusive 1120 Fifth Avenue co-op that they had used as a pied-à-terre and to entertain fellow movie stars and other prominent guests, is on the market for the first time in four decades.

headline: The Best Children’s Books of 2024
abstract: Here are the year’s most notable picture, chapter and middle grade books, selected by our children’s books editor.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-six artfully designed, winningly goofy, faux-vintage record jackets gently spoof vinyl’s golden age, with animals standing in for iconic performers. One tune on each album gets the full treatment: lyrics by Bell plus an audio track composed and produced by her real-life musician pals.

headline: Best Podcasts of 2024
abstract: This year’s standouts feature staggering investigations, sparkling conversations and a retooling of the celebrity interview.
lead_paragraph: The 10 best podcasts of the year, listed here in alphabetical order, represent a broad sampling of the medium’s many formats — chat shows, documentaries, storytelling, interviews, true crime. Whether cracking open one of the darkest cases in American military history, giving voice to members of a vast diaspora, or interrogating the craft of audio journalism itself, these shows make a strong argument for the vitality of the field.

headline: When They Hear Plants Crying, Moths Make a Decision
abstract: A new study suggests that the insects rely on the sounds made by distressed vegetation to guide important reproductive choices.
lead_paragraph: You may not want to sit next to a crying baby on an airplane. Apparently, moths feel the same way about plants.

headline: ‘Obsessed With Light’ and the Dancer We All Should Know
abstract: The film argues that Loie Fuller was an inventive artist responsible for things we take for granted. If only the movie were as creative as its star.
lead_paragraph: The master cinematographer Vittorio Storaro has described cinema as “writing with light,” a description I’ve always found — dare I say it? — illuminating. I love that when you watch a movie with a projector, whether you’re in a cinema or someone’s living room, you can accidentally interrupt the picture with your body if it blocks the light. I love that the image can change based on the quality of the light shining through the film or the screen. There’s something wonderfully physical and ephemeral about the experience that even the shift to digital movies hasn’t altogether eradicated.

headline: How Navy Pilots are Harmed by Their Own Planes
abstract: For decades, the Navy has stated that brain injuries have mostly occurred during accidents or leisure activities. But now, a confidential new program is studying whether intense fighter jet operations can cause brain injuries as devastating as those from repeated blast exposure.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Navy has stated that brain injuries have mostly occurred during accidents or leisure activities. But now, a confidential new program is studying whether intense fighter jet operations can cause brain injuries as devastating as those from repeated blast exposure.

headline: The Year in Pop: Hits Without Stars, Stars Without Hits
abstract: Tommy Richman, Teddy Swims and Benson Boone had some of the biggest songs of the year. But Taylor Swift, Zach Bryan and Tyler, the Creator held strong without them.
lead_paragraph: This past spring, Tommy Richman got famous off a TikTok.

headline: Inside the Faithful Restoration of Notre-Dame
abstract: After Notre-Dame caught fire in 2019, France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, promised to reopen the cathedral in five years. The timeline seemed a Hail Mary. Yet here we are. Michael Kimmelman, architecture critic for The New York Times, brings us a behind-the-scenes look at the faithful restoration of Notre-Dame, which opens to the public on Dec. 8.
lead_paragraph: After Notre-Dame caught fire in 2019, France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, promised to reopen the cathedral in five years. The timeline seemed a Hail Mary. Yet here we are. Michael Kimmelman, architecture critic for The New York Times, brings us a behind-the-scenes look at the faithful restoration of Notre-Dame, which opens to the public on Dec. 8.

headline: The Best Science Fiction and Fantasy of 2024
abstract: The year’s best speculative fiction includes a fantasy novel by Kelly Link, alien epics and promising starts to series.
lead_paragraph: Of the many great books I read this year, the following 10 have stayed with me, undergirded my thoughts as I go about my days and provoked excellent, chewy conversations about craft and pleasure, empire and resistance. While I’m a little haunted by the violence publishers seem to be doing to the very concept of a series — claiming sequels are stand-alones, while insufficiently supporting and labeling the parts of actual series — I hope you find something to enjoy among these fantastic works.

headline: Trump Claims a ‘Historic’ Mandate. Polls Show Americans Have Mixed Feelings.
abstract: The public may have more nuanced views on issues like tariffs and mass deportations than it might seem at first blush.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies have declared that his incoming administration has an “unprecedented” and “historic” mandate. While he won the popular vote by only a small margin, it’s true that voters shifted in his favor across the country and sent him back to the White House. But does that equate to a full-throated endorsement of his policy proposals?

headline: A Famous Christmas Poem Could Sell for $500,000
abstract: “A Visit From St. Nicholas” is the beginning of modern Christmas, a manuscript specialist at Christie’s said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a copy of “A Visit From St. Nicholas” that only recently turned up. We’ll also get details on a lawsuit by the father of Jordan Neely, the 30-year-old homeless man who died in a chokehold on the subway last year.

headline: The Gripping Appeal of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy’s Headband
abstract: A wide and tightfitting hair accessory favored by the wife of John F. Kennedy, Jr., has become a hot commodity, 25 years after her death.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Nigro, a 24-year-old software engineer in Brooklyn, was not yet born when a plane crash killed John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy and her sister Lauren Bessette on July 16, 1999.

headline: A $400 Billion Clean Energy Program Is Racing to Get Money Out the Door
abstract: Some fear Donald Trump could freeze the Energy Department’s loan office, which supports electric vehicles, geothermal, nuclear and other novel technologies.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the Biden administration’s efforts to advance clean energy is a $400 billion lending program that has backed dozens of projects across the nation, including battery factories in Ohio and Tennessee, the revival of a shuttered nuclear reactor in Michigan and a novel rooftop solar expansion in Puerto Rico.

headline: $570,000 Homes in Iceland
abstract: A contemporary home near a volcanic crater lake, and a pair of two-bedroom apartments in a harbor district of Reykjavík.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, two-bath, contemporary-style house with a sauna is newly constructed in the municipality of Grímsnes, about an hour east of downtown Reykjavík, Iceland’s capital and largest city.

headline: The Highbrow and Lowbrow of the Trump Era
abstract: Trump culture has been renewed for a second season.
lead_paragraph: Is Donald Trump the chicken or the egg? On the cusp of his second administration, the hosts of “Matter of Opinion” dissect whether the president-elect is a cause or symptom of trends in popular culture.

headline: The Cryptocurrency You May Not Even Know You Own
abstract: Many funds hold stakes in MicroStrategy, which behaves like Bitcoin’s wilder cousin. This may not be what you want in your retirement portfolio, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin has had a phenomenal year. But its rich returns are paltry compared with those of MicroStrategy, a company dedicated to a risky business: buying Bitcoin with money provided by you and other shareholders.

headline: Amy Adams, Marielle Heller and How ‘Nightbitch’ Speaks to Women
abstract: They set out to subvert expectations for depictions of motherhood. “There’s conscientious discomfort,” Heller says. Reactions have been polarized.
lead_paragraph: Within the first 30 minutes of the magical realist dramedy “Nightbitch,” Amy Adams, starring as a newish parent teeming with fury and resentment, discovers that the oozing pustule that appeared on her back contains what appears to be a tail, the clearest sign yet that she is transforming into a dog.

headline: How a Book From 1981 Anticipated This Political Moment
abstract: Two columnists sit down to discuss two books that crystallize this period in America.
lead_paragraph: In this conversation, the New York Times Opinion columnists Carlos Lozada, a former book critic, and Pamela Paul, previously the editor of The Times’s Book Review, each share one book that, in their opinion, can help us understand this point in history.

headline: In Syria, a Rebel Offensive Shatters a Fragile Sense of Normalcy
abstract: Militants stormed out of their stronghold in Idlib Province last week, seizing parts of the nation’s largest city. A Times reporter puts the surprise attack in context.
lead_paragraph: The Arab Spring reached Syria in 2011, when a popular uprising met with a bloody response from President Bashar al-Assad and his government. Soon, Syria was entangled in civil war, with a patchwork of territories controlled variously by rebel groups, the Islamic State, Kurdish militias and government forces supported by foreign militaries. The conflict never really ended, but by mid-2020, the front lines had stopped moving, and Mr. al-Assad’s government had stood firm.

headline: 12 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Amy Adams stars as a stay-at-home mother who turns into a feral dog in this adaptation of Rachel Yoder’s novel directed by Marielle Heller.

headline: What Is Your Choice for Word of the Year?
abstract: The Oxford English Dictionary picked “brain rot” as its 2024 Word of the Year. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: Every year the Oxford English Dictionary selects a Word of the Year that is meant to reflect “the moods and conversations” that have shaped the previous year. For 2024, the publisher chose “brain rot.”

headline: Job Growth Rebounds With a Gain of 227,000 in November
abstract: Hiring bounced back after disruptions from storms and a major strike.
lead_paragraph: Job creation bounced back in November after disruptions from storms and a major strike, reinforcing a picture of modest employment expansion over the past several months.

headline: World’s Oldest Known Wild Bird Lays an Egg at 74
abstract: Wisdom, a Laysan albatross, has outlived at least three mates and the researcher who outfitted her with a tracking band in 1956.
lead_paragraph: The world’s oldest known wild bird, a 74-year-old Laysan albatross named Wisdom, is expected to welcome another baby chick in the coming months, astonishing scientists who have been tracking her since the Eisenhower administration.

headline: The ‘Chilling’ Fatal Shooting of a C.E.O. Has Business Leaders on Edge
abstract: After Brian Thompson of UnitedHealthcare was killed in Manhattan, the phones at corporate security firms were “ringing off the hook.”
lead_paragraph: A Fortune 500 pharmaceutical company raised its drug prices, and then board members and executives received phone calls threatening violence. A health care company’s board meeting was disrupted after board members were targeted in “swatting” attacks that wrongly sent law enforcement officers to their homes.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Dec. 6, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Trump’s F.B.I. Pick Has an Enemies List. Biden Should Pardon Everyone on It.
abstract: The president has a chance to save innocent people from MAGA persecution.
lead_paragraph: There are few good things to be said about Donald Trump’s plan to fire the F.B.I. director, Chris Wray, and install in his place Kash Patel, a thuggish lackey who has spent years fantasizing about taking revenge on Trump’s enemies. But there is one: Patel has helpfully provided us with a list of people President Biden should pardon before he leaves office.

headline: Houseplants Can Make You Healthier
abstract: You don’t need a green thumb to reap the benefits.
lead_paragraph: I was on the phone with a friend the other day, and because I can’t sit still, I started to dust the leaves on my sprawling bird of paradise plant.

headline: He Promised Huge Tax Refunds. Now Trump Wants Him to Lead the I.R.S.
abstract: Since leaving Congress in 2023, Billy Long has peddled a pandemic-era tax credit that the I.R.S. has warned is a magnet for fraud.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Trump’s transition and staff picks.

headline: The Supreme Court Just Showed Us What Contempt for Expertise Looks Like
abstract: In the case involving medical care for transgender adolescents, ignoring doctors is part of the point.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before allowing reporters into the main chamber of the Supreme Court for oral arguments in United States v. Skrmetti, a court employee asked us all if we needed to use a bathroom. The men’s room was right next door, the staff member said, and the women’s room down the hall.

headline: Is the Urban Shift Toward Trump Really About Democratic Cities in Disarray?
abstract: Big cities have faced serious problems lately. But there’s little evidence those problems are what drove voters to the right in November.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election has raised an uncomfortable possibility for big American cities, most of them run by Democrats.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 545
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Texas Village Rethinking Homelessness
abstract: The Community First! Village outside Austin is one of the nation’s largest experiments in affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,267
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Police Track C.E.O.’s Killer, and Biden Aides Consider Blanket Pardons
abstract: Plus, the spectacular rebirth of Notre-Dame.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Arsonists Set Fire to Melbourne Synagogue
abstract: Witnesses saw two people pouring accelerant in the synagogue early Friday, the police said. Australia’s prime minister condemned the attack as antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: The police in Australia are looking for several people who they believe intentionally set fire to a synagogue in a suburb of Melbourne on Friday morning.

headline: What Is Happening in Syria
abstract: We explain the latest updates in the country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Syria and the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s government.

headline: For Those in Need of a Job, Landing One Might Still Be a Challenge
abstract: Layoffs remain relatively low, but people who lose their jobs could be struggling to find new ones.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate, which ticked up slightly to 4.2 percent in November, remains low by historical standards. But under the surface, there are signs that it can be difficult to land a job.

headline: Is Intel Cooked? + What’s Your P(Dyson Sphere)? + Hard Fork Gift Guide
abstract: The sudden departure of Intel’s C.E.O. reignites concerns about U.S. dependence on foreign manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: This week, Pat Gelsinger stepped down as chief executive of Intel. We talk with The New York Times’s Don Clark about why Gelsinger was ousted, what it means for the chip industry and how his departure could affect national security. Then, Kevin and Casey report back from an artificial intelligence conference, where experts debated how long it would take to build a structure around the sun to capture the star’s energy — also known as a Dyson sphere. And finally, gift guides have taken over the internet. We dig into why, and offer up suggestions for gear dads, home cooks and even tech billionaires in our first ever Hard Fork gift guide.

headline: Was Brian Thompson’s Killer a Hit Man? Unlikely, Experts Say.
abstract: The murder of Brian Thompson did not appear to have been committed by a coldly calculating professional, according to people who study criminal behavior.
lead_paragraph: For the general public, the shooting in Manhattan of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare on Wednesday seemed like something off Netflix: a coldblooded morning murder outside a hotel, a hooded man shooting a corporate bigwig from behind, the victim turning to face the attacker before crumpling to the ground, mortally wounded.

headline: Syrian Rebels Push South, Edging Closer to Damascus
abstract: Government forces appeared to be reinforcing crucial strongholds including the capital, Damascus, and the major city of Homs.
lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels pushed further south on Friday toward the major city of Homs, edging another step closer to the capital, Damascus, in their dramatic offensive, according to the rebels and a war monitoring group.

headline: The Growing Cost of Making C.E.O.s Safe
abstract: The tragic killing of UnitedHealthCare’s Brian Thompson has spurred companies to ratchet up security for their most senior executives.
lead_paragraph: On the sidelines of the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, one topic dominated discussions: the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s C.E.O., Brian Thompson, just blocks away in Midtown Manhattan by a shooter who is still at large.

headline: As Trump Threatens Tariffs, Europe and South America Strengthen Ties
abstract: The European Union and four South American countries have reached an agreement to establish one of the largest trade zones in the world.
lead_paragraph: The European Union reached a major trade agreement on Friday with four South American countries, concluding a long-delayed negotiation that took on new urgency as President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened to impose tariffs on some of the world’s largest economies.

headline: The Guardian Sells U.K.’s Oldest Sunday Paper to a Media Start-Up
abstract: The Guardian Media Group said it had struck a deal to sell The Observer to Tortoise Media, shortly after a 48-hour strike by journalists ended.
lead_paragraph: The Observer, a British Sunday newspaper that has been running for more than two centuries, will be sold to the digital media start-up Tortoise Media, said the Guardian Media Group, which owns The Observer.

headline: It’s Not Too Late to Rein In Holiday Spending
abstract: Research suggests that you’ll spend less than you otherwise would by setting a strict budget — even if you go over the budget.
lead_paragraph: Black Friday and Cyber Monday have come and gone. So you may think that setting limits on holiday spending is a lost cause, right?

headline: Canada Moves to Protect Arctic From Threats by Russia and China
abstract: Ottawa says its focus on the Arctic comes after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine “has shaken the foundations” of international cooperation in the northern region.
lead_paragraph: Citing growing interest by China and Russia in the Arctic as global warming makes the region more accessible, Canada on Friday said it would focus on building stronger alliances with other nations in the region, particularly the United States.

headline: Why Wouldn’t ChatGPT Say This Dead Professor’s Name?
abstract: A bizarre saga in which users noticed the chatbot refused to say “David Mayer” raised questions about privacy and A.I., with few clear answers.
lead_paragraph: Across the final years of his life, David Mayer, a theater professor living in Manchester, England, faced the cascading consequences of an unfortunate coincidence: A dead Chechen rebel on a terror watch list had once used Mr. Mayer’s name as an alias.

headline: Romanian Court Annuls Presidential Election Results and Orders a New Vote
abstract: The decision came days after the government asserted that there had been “cyberattacks” meant to undermine the vote and security council documents indicated possible Russian meddling.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s efforts to contain a resurgence of nationalism and Russian interference entered dangerous new territory on Friday when Romania canceled a high-stakes presidential election, just two days before a runoff vote that an ultranationalist candidate had been well positioned to win.

headline: Trump Defends His Imperiled Pick for Defense Secretary, Pete Hegseth
abstract: The post amounted to a public dare to Republican senators, a number of whom have expressed private concerns about Mr. Hegseth, to vote against Mr. Trump’s wishes.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump was scheduled to give his first  gave a public show of support to his embattled choice for defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, on Friday morning, saying in a social media post that he will be “fantastic” in the job and that he has a “military state of mind.”

headline: We Cannot Forget the World’s Political Prisoners
abstract: No mission is more important than preserving the lives of those who have been jailed for their principles.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: A Washington Institution Delays Its Transition: the Kennedy Center
abstract: As the nation’s capital prepares for a second Trump administration, the performing arts center announced that its chairman would not step down in January as planned.
lead_paragraph: The White House was not the only Washington institution planning to welcome new leadership in January. The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts had announced that its longtime board chairman, David M. Rubenstein, would step down in January and had appointed a search committee to find a successor.

headline: ‘The Piano Lesson’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Malcolm Washington narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Danielle Deadwyler.
lead_paragraph: The director Malcolm Washington narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Danielle Deadwyler.

headline: Tim Walz Says He Was ‘a Little Surprised’ Trump Won
abstract: In his first interviews since the election, Kamala Harris’s running mate told Minnesota television stations that he had thought the country would embrace the Democratic ticket’s positive message.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said this week that he was “a little surprised” that he and Vice President Kamala Harris lost the presidential election to Donald J. Trump because he had believed the country was ready for the Democratic ticket’s “positive message.”

headline: Watch the Stirring Climax of ‘The Piano Lesson’
abstract: The director Malcolm Washington narrates a sequence from the film featuring Danielle Deadwyler.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: TikTok Faces U.S. Ban After Losing Bid to Overturn New Law
abstract: The law will ban the video app in the United States by Jan. 19 if its owner, ByteDance, does not sell it to a non-Chinese company.
lead_paragraph: TikTok is one step closer to disappearing in the United States after a panel of federal judges on Friday unanimously upheld a new law that could lead to the banning of the popular Chinese-owned video app by mid-January.

headline: Trump’s Allies Go Global: ‘Make Argentina Great Again’
abstract: At its international conferences, CPAC is giving a stage to right-wing politicians and hunting for ideas for use back home.
lead_paragraph: From a distance, Alejo de Gennaro would have fit in at any Trump rally. He wore a MAGA hat and a wide smile as he listened to a parade of speakers slam socialists and decry wokeness.

headline: Maitake au Poivre, Peruvian Roast Chicken, Pork Noodle Soup
abstract: Now’s the time for dinners that are simple and delicious and just for you.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There was a Cooper’s hawk sitting on top of a road sign off the Long Island Expressway the other afternoon, in the wake of Thanksgiving. My daughter spotted it and was able to point it out to me because the traffic was crawling and thick. The bird looked under the weather, as I was at the time, and was staring vacantly out toward the Pine Barrens, as I had been staring vacantly at the sea of red brake lights before me.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a sneaky serial killer, a boy’s vengeance quest and a holiday house of horrors.
lead_paragraph: M. Night Shyamalan’s latest psychological thriller is so preposterous it makes “The Front Room,” my pick for the dumbest horror movie of 2024, look like “The Shining.” But unlike “The Front Room,” “Trap” takes itself very unseriously — God, I hope it does — and watching it was the most fun I had at a horror movie this year.

headline: The Transgender Case, and the Role of Activists
abstract: Readers discuss the Supreme Court case and the threats trans people face. Also: Recess appointments; Social Security; pardons; brain injuries and crime.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Stewards of Czech Musical Heritage Return to Carnegie Hall
abstract: Over three nights, the Czech Philharmonic presented Dvorak’s concertos and more, including a rare performance of Janacek’s “Glagolitic Mass.”
lead_paragraph: You could be forgiven for thinking that there has been some kind of festival going on at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Melania Trump Credits Barron Trump With Helping His Father Win
abstract: “He was very vocal” in advising his father on appearing with media personalities popular with young people, Melania Trump said on the morning show “Fox & Friends.”
lead_paragraph: In her first interview since her husband won the presidential election, the former and future first lady Melania Trump said on Friday that their son, Barron, had played an important role in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory, advising him to appear with media personalities popular with younger voters.

headline: A One-of-a-Kind Card Fuels a Treasure Hunt for the Ages
abstract: The Pittsburgh Pirates offered 30 years of season tickets in exchange for a Paul Skenes rookie card, and collectors say it could sell for $1 million. First, someone has to find it.
lead_paragraph: The hunt for rare sports trading cards can feel like a search for buried treasure. There are “chases” and “bounties” and card values that rise and fall like waves. So it makes perfect sense that, at the heart of one of the pastime’s most-hyped pursuits, is a lanky, towering and mustachioed (Pittsburgh) Pirate.

headline: Israeli Attacks Around Gaza Hospital Kill or Wound Scores, Doctors Say
abstract: Airstrikes, gunfire, panic and orders to evacuate in the dark of night combined to cause heavy casualties in the area of Kamal Adwan, one of the last hospitals still operating in northern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes and intense gunfire on the ground around one of the last working hospitals in northern Gaza killed or wounded scores of people early Friday, the hospital’s director said, as Israeli forces ordered the building evacuated.

headline: Most Serious Charge Dismissed in Subway Trial; Lesser Charge Remains
abstract: Jurors in the Daniel Penny trial in Manhattan deadlocked on Friday. Next week they will begin deliberating a lesser charge against him in the death last year of Jordan Neely.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan judge overseeing the case of a man accused in the choking death of a  mentally ill subway passenger last year dismissed the most serious charge against him on Friday afternoon, leaving jurors to consider a lesser charge when they return to court next week.

headline: Owner of Los Angeles Times Plans ‘Bias Meter’ Next to Coverage
abstract: Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong said that he planned to introduce the tool, which he said would appear next to the paper’s news articles and opinion pieces, in January.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, the billionaire owner of The Los Angeles Times, said on Thursday that he planned to introduce a “bias meter” next to the paper’s news and opinion coverage as part of his campaign to overhaul the publication.

headline: The Consumer Bureau Is Likely Here to Stay, but Big Changes Await
abstract: Republicans are unlikely to abolish the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, but they will drastically rework its rules and activities.
lead_paragraph: Rohit Chopra is using his final weeks as director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to remind banks and other financial industry groups that there’s something for them to love about the regulator they mostly love to hate.

headline: In Japan, Designers Fit Big Ideas Into Tiny Homes
abstract: Some newer houses around the country are barely wider than a common family car.
lead_paragraph: In the labyrinthine back streets of Tokyo stands an odd geometric structure that looks nothing like the houses surrounding it. With its vertical wood siding, imposing oblong form and almost total lack of windows, it looks like an artwork, or a mini fortress. Appropriately enough, it’s called The Keep. And it’s designed as a home.

headline: Rosé Sets Herself Free, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Sky Ferreira, Bad Bunny, Sakura Tsuruta and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: At Truth Social, Kash Patel Investigated Trump’s Estranged Co-Founders
abstract: Mr. Patel was directly involved in building a case that two co-founders of Trump Media & Technology mismanaged the debut of Truth Social in 2022. He was paid about $130,000 as a consultant.
lead_paragraph: Kash Patel, whom Donald J. Trump has tapped to lead the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has attacked Mr. Trump’s critics, vowed to investigate Mr. Trump’s opponents and profited from his association with the president-elect by selling pro-Trump merchandise.

headline: As India-Bangladesh Tensions Rise, So Do Fears of Tit-for-Tat Violence
abstract: A diplomatic dispute over claims of persecution of Bangladeshi Hindus threatens to upend Bangladesh’s interim government.
lead_paragraph: Relations between India and neighboring Bangladesh reached a perilous new low this week as Indian politicians and Hindu extremists intensified accusations that minority Hindus in Bangladesh are being persecuted.

headline: Federal Judge Upholds Racial Preferences in Naval Academy Admissions
abstract: A group that successfully challenged affirmative action at the Supreme Court had also sued the military academies. But, the judge said, “the U.S. Naval Academy is distinct from a civilian university.”
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday denied an effort to stop the U.S. Naval Academy from considering race and ethnicity in admissions, finding that the academy has a distinct interest in using affirmative action to achieve diversity in its student body, and that doing so is a matter of national security.

headline: Could Facial Recognition Help Find Man Sought in C.E.O.’s Killing?
abstract: Experts disagreed on whether running surveillance camera images released by the police through a facial recognition system would produce a reliable lead.
lead_paragraph: A man whom the police are seeking in connection to the brazen killing of Brian Thompson, the UnitedHealthcare chief executive, has passed by numerous surveillance cameras while in Manhattan. Could artificial intelligence-powered facial recognition put a name to the man whose identity has so far eluded the authorities?

headline: Boston City Councilor Indicted on Federal Charges
abstract: The council member, Tania Fernandes Anderson, was arrested on public corruption charges involving an alleged kickback.
lead_paragraph: A city councilor in Boston was arrested on Friday morning and charged with using someone on her staff to take thousands of dollars in public funding for her personal gain, according to federal officials.

headline: The Rage and Glee That Followed a C.E.O.’s Killing Should Ring All Alarms
abstract: It echoes another era of extreme inequality and extreme violence.
lead_paragraph: It started barely minutes after the horrifying news broke that the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, Brian Thompson, had been fatally shot in Midtown Manhattan. Even before any details were available, the internet was awash in speculation that the company had refused to cover the alleged killer’s medical bills — and in debates about whether murder would be a reasonable response.

headline: An Art Movement’s Lasting Impression
abstract: Lessons from the past continue to influence and inspire today’s globalized art world.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: U.S. Milk to Be Tested for Bird Flu Virus
abstract: New federal rules call for testing unpasteurized milk from dairy processors and for farm owners to provide details that would help officials identify and track cases more easily.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Department of Agriculture will begin testing the nation’s milk supply for the bird flu virus known as H5N1, nearly a year after the virus began circulating through dairy cattle, the department announced on Friday.

headline: Eric Adams Doesn’t Rule Out Becoming a Republican Again
abstract: The Democratic mayor of New York City has embraced President-elect Donald J. Trump lately. He was a registered Republican in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: With his political future in doubt, Eric Adams, the Democratic mayor of New York City, has opened the door to returning to the Republican Party.

headline: Woman Who Fell Into Sinkhole Is Found Dead
abstract: After searching since Tuesday, the authorities in Unity Township, Pa., on Friday found the body of Elizabeth Pollard, 64, who disappeared while searching for her cat.
lead_paragraph: A 64-year-old woman who fell into a sinkhole in a former coal mining community in western Pennsylvania on Monday evening, apparently while looking for her missing cat, has been found dead, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Air Force Not Ready to Stop Buying Human-Piloted Jets
abstract: Elon Musk has mocked the Air Force for continuing to purchase expensive traditional fighter jets instead of drones. But military officials say human pilots are still needed.
lead_paragraph: The Air Force is at least decades away from being ready to stop buying and flying human-piloted fighter jets like the F-35, but it also does not want to rush into building a next generation of these high-priced fighting machines until it has a better idea of just what it needs.

headline: Beyond the Blockbusters, 7 Key Songs From 1984
abstract: The Pointer Sisters, Minutemen and more sounds from a landmark year in pop music.
lead_paragraph: If you’re halfway decent at math, you know that it is currently the 40-year anniversary of 1984 — which is not only the name of a George Orwell novel and a Van Halen album, but a particularly pivotal moment in popular music. This week, we’re running a few articles that look back at the music of 1984, beginning with a sharp, well-reported piece by Ben Sisario about the way a number of ’70s rockers (ZZ Top, Don Henley and Yes among them) rebooted their sounds and images for the brave new world of the 1980s.

headline: How Childhood Tragedy Shaped the Doctor Trump Picked for Surgeon General
abstract: At the age of 13, Dr. Janette Nesheiwat said she accidentally knocked over a box in a darkened room. A handgun went off, leaving her father dead.
lead_paragraph: Needing a pair of scissors, a 13-year-old girl went into the bedroom where her father was sleeping and reached for a fishing tackle box on a shelf above the bed. But in the darkened room, she accidentally knocked it over.

headline: Ghana’s Voters Look for Leader to Fix a Broken Economy
abstract: Ghanaians voting on Saturday are confronted with a choice familiar to Americans: Return a one-term former president to office, or promote the vice president, at a time when anger over the economy is widespread.
lead_paragraph: The 80-year-old two-term president of the West African nation of Ghana, Nana Akufo-Addo, would like to pass the baton to his vice president, a protégé he’s groomed to succeed him when he steps down on Jan. 7.

headline: Dick Van Dyke, Approaching 99, Dances in Coldplay’s Latest Video
abstract: In the clip, which was filmed in October, Van Dyke sings, dances barefoot and offers meditations on aging, family and love.
lead_paragraph: Dick Van Dyke, the lithe and witty nonagenarian whose career spans more than seven decades, has added yet another role to his lengthy résumé: music video star.

headline: Falling in Love With Nora Ephron
abstract: Ilana Kaplan’s new coffee table book pays tribute to the godmother of the modern rom-com.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll have what she’s having.”

headline: Ocasio-Cortez Seeks House Post That Would Make Her a Top Foil to Trump
abstract: After years of challenging her party from the left, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a New York Democrat, announced a bid to join its leadership ranks in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York built her reputation clashing with House Democratic leaders. Now, for the first time, she will take a shot at joining their ranks.

headline: In Mexico, Heat Waves Are Even Killing Younger Adults
abstract: It’s not just the elderly. More than three-quarters of heat-related deaths in Mexico occurred among people younger than 35, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: As climate change pushes global temperatures higher, attention has focused predominantly on the threat that heat poses to older adults, whose physiology makes them more susceptible to health complications.

headline: Rocket Mortgage Sues HUD Over Its Inclusion in Appraisal Lawsuit
abstract: The nation’s largest lender says the government tied its hands with regulations that prevented it from exerting control over appraisal values.
lead_paragraph: Rocket Mortgage, the nation’s largest lender, has sued the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, saying its reputation was sullied by a Justice Department lawsuit over appraisal bias, and that it should not have been included in the first place.

headline: Fact-Checkers Cannot Save Us
abstract: In our interconnected modern world, education is critical in the fight against disinformation.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: Trump’s Treasury Pick Isn’t Alarming, but He Is Unusual
abstract: Some of Scott Bessent’s economic views are outside the mainstream. But at least he’s qualified.
lead_paragraph: Scott Bessent, Donald Trump’s pick for Treasury secretary, has some pretty unorthodox views. Unorthodoxy can be a good thing at times, and it’s conceivable that Bessent will end up a big success at Treasury. But deviation from the norm is not necessarily what you look for in a Treasury secretary, who is responsible for formulating the nation’s economic, financial and tax policies.

headline: The Regimes of the Post-Post-Cold War World
abstract: The liberal world order, remixed.
