lead_paragraph: Good morning. You could spend a lifetime perfecting cacio e pepe, the classic Roman pasta dish of cheese and black pepper mixed with spaghetti.

headline: Will We Ever Elect a Woman as President?
abstract: Readers react to a column by Gail Collins. Also: Advice for immigrants; presidential immunity; words of the year.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Angela Alvarez, Great-Grandmother Who Won a Latin Grammy, Dies at 97
abstract: Her only album made her a media star after she had raised four children and worked as a house cleaner — proving, she said, that “it’s never too late.”
lead_paragraph: Angela Alvarez, a Cuban-born singer and songwriter who, at age 95, became the oldest performer to win the Latin Grammy Award for best new artist, died on Friday in Baton Rouge, La., where she had settled after immigrating to the United States in the early 1960s. She was 97.

headline: As Syrian Rebels Take Charge, Freeing Prisoners of Assad Is a Priority
abstract: Many people want to determine the fates of loved ones who disappeared into a notorious military prison that was a symbol of human rights abuses under President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: For many Syrians, the fall of President Bashar al-Assad provides an opportunity — at last — to try to discover the fates of loved ones who disappeared into a notorious military prison that has become a symbol of human rights abuses under his rule.

headline: Records Seized by Israel Show Hamas Presence in U.N. Schools
abstract: While Israel asserts that the United Nations has tried to minimize the problem, the global organization says Israeli officials are waging an unfair campaign to discredit it.
lead_paragraph: To his students, Ahmad al-Khatib was a deputy principal at an elementary school in Gaza run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees. To Hamas’s military wing, documents say, he was something else entirely: an infantryman operating out of the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis.

headline: With Assad’s Fall, Iran’s ‘Axis of Resistance’ Unravels
abstract: Tehran’s main regional allies are weakened or collapsing: Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, has fled his country, Hezbollah is battered by conflict with Israel, and Hamas is still at war.
lead_paragraph: Over the past four decades, Iran devoted its best military minds, billions of dollars and sophisticated weapons to a grand project — countering U.S. and Israeli power in the Middle East through what it called the “axis of resistance.”

headline: New Image Shows Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting in Back of Taxi
abstract: The manhunt for the gunman who fatally shot Brian Thompson, chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, entered its fifth day, and the police released two new images.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has released two new images of the man it believes fatally shot the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, including one showing him in the back seat of a taxi on the day of the shooting.

headline: Nations and Leaders React to Toppling of Syria Regime
abstract: The U.N. special envoy called it a “watershed moment” on Sunday as world leaders reckoned with the news.
lead_paragraph: Global leaders reacted to the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria with cautious optimism and support for the Syrian people on Sunday.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump on ‘Meet the Press’: Tariffs, Immigration and More
abstract: The president-elect repeated several false and inaccurate claims on a range of topics that were staples of his 2024 campaign.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump, in his first sit-down broadcast interview since his re-election last month, repeated several false and inaccurate claims on a range of topics that were staples of his 2024 campaign.

headline: Bogged Down in Ukraine, Russia Pays a Price in Syria
abstract: With the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Vladimir V. Putin has suffered one of the biggest geopolitical setbacks of his quarter-century in power.
lead_paragraph: Lines of Russian troops in desert khaki greeted President Vladimir V. Putin in Syria in 2017. Declaring that Moscow had accomplished its mission in Syria’s civil war, Mr. Putin pledged that Russia was there to stay.

headline: The Campaign by Syrian Rebels to Topple Assad Was Swift
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad had kept opposition forces at bay for a decade with help from Russia and Iran. But rebels struck at a moment of weakness for those countries.
lead_paragraph: The government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, which had kept rebel forces at bay for more than a decade with Iranian and Russian military support, collapsed with astonishing speed on Sunday morning after an advance by opposition forces on the capital, Damascus.

headline: The Winners and Losers Following the Fall of al-Assad
abstract: Two cheers for the end of the regime, but be wary of what happens next.
lead_paragraph: The stunning collapse of the brutal Assad regime in Syria, a family business since the 1970s, is a geopolitical earthquake creating winners and losers around the world. First, the losers:

headline: What’s Next for Syria After the Collapse of Assad’s Government?
abstract: Predicting Syria’s future is challenging, as the government’s sudden demise took many people who have watched the region for years by surprise.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of the government of President Bashar al-Assad has sparked jubilation inside Syria and beyond, but it has also plunged the country into deep uncertainty.

headline: Trump Suggests Kennedy Will Examine Debunked Link Between Vaccines and Autism
abstract: The president-elect has promoted the theory for more than a decade and said on Sunday that he was “open to anything” to address a nationwide rise in autism.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump, who has promoted the debunked theory that vaccines cause autism for more than a decade, suggested on Sunday that he would have his choice for health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., look into the issue.

headline: Space Age Blues and the ‘Dancing Spirit’ of Judith Jamison
abstract: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater returns for its annual December season with an enigmatic premiere by Jamar Roberts and the revival of “Grace.”
lead_paragraph: When the curtain rises on “Al-Andalus Blues,” Jamar Roberts’s new work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, it does so deliberately and unwaveringly, as if building drama before a big reveal. In this mysterious tableau, a group is planted on and around a glowing rock formation. (It looked like a lumpy mattress.) One figure draws the eye: Hannah Alissa Richardson, a dancer and a warrior rolled into one. Her arms serpentine around her. She looks like a flame.

headline: Syrians in Lebanon Start to Head Home, With Both Joy and Worry
abstract: Thousands who fled during the country’s civil war celebrated the toppling of the Assad government — and their long-awaited return home — at the Syria-Lebanon border crossing.
lead_paragraph: They poured by the thousands into the street outside Lebanon’s main border crossing with Syria, celebrating the toppling of the Assad regime — and their long-awaited return home.

headline: Biden Weighs Approach to Rebels in Syria Amid Secret Message Exchange
abstract: President Biden faces the challenge of deciding how to engage the main armed group that toppled President Bashar al-Assad, even though it remains designated a terrorist organization by the United States.
lead_paragraph: For President Biden, the fall of Syria’s tyrant on Sunday was a moment to cheer what he called a “fundamental act of justice” and to claim a measure of credit for his own policy.

headline: The Assad Family’s Legacy Is One of Savage Oppression
abstract: A dynasty bombed and detained thousands of opponents, building fearsome internal security agencies to quash unrest.
lead_paragraph: Over decades, ghastly, chilling images from Syria have cemented the Assad family’s legacy of savagely oppressing the country’s population.

headline: Syria’s Army Was Hollowing Out Long Before Rebels’ Advance
abstract: While multiple factors contributed to the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, corrosion inside his own military did not help, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: For years, Syrian soldiers have been complaining on Facebook about their bosses. Commanders who took bribes in exchange for leave. Leaders who ordered soldiers to loot. Officers who stole their troops’ food or got drunk on the job.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 547
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Five Quick Takes on Regime Change in Syria
abstract: Assad’s fall creates vast dangers and opportunities that everyone in the region will seize upon.
lead_paragraph: For the past few weeks, I have been arguing that Israel has inflicted the equivalent of a Six Day War-level defeat on Iran and its resistance network, and this would have vast consequences. Well, irony of ironies, the Assad family in Syria took power in 1971, in part because of Syria’s devastating defeat in the 1967 war. What goes around comes around.

headline: Marvin Laird, Musical Presence on and Off Broadway, Dies at 85
abstract: He conducted Broadway shows and worked with Bernadette Peters. But he was probably best known for writing the music for the darkly comic “Ruthless!”
lead_paragraph: Marvin Laird, a conductor for Broadway musicals and for performers like Bernadette Peters and the composer of the music for “Ruthless!,” the campy, award-winning Off Broadway show about a girl who will do anything — including kill — to star in a school play, died on Dec. 2 in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 85.

headline: Judge Pauses Sexual Abuse Lawsuit Against Trump’s Education Secretary Pick
abstract: Linda McMahon is accused of failing to stop abuse in the 1980s within W.W.E., which she led at the time. The suit is on hold pending a ruling over a state law related to such cases.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Maryland has paused a lawsuit against Linda McMahon, the former World Wrestling Entertainment executive whom President-elect Trump chose for education secretary, while another court weighs a recent state law involving such cases.

headline: With Assad Gone, a Brutal Dictatorship Ends. But the New Risks Are Huge.
abstract: The overthrow of the Assad government could mean Russia’s bases in Syria are closed and Iran’s pathway to Hezbollah is cut off. Now Iran, newly vulnerable, will have to decide between negotiation and the bomb.
lead_paragraph: For years, the American strategic map of the Middle East was dominated by Iran at the center of power of a “Shia crescent,” with Syria as the funnel for the Iranian arms used by terrorism groups to attack Israel, and as the home to Russia’s naval and air presence in the region.

headline: Threatened With Jail, Cheney Condemns Trump’s ‘Assault on the Rule of Law’
abstract: Liz Cheney, the former Republican representative, said President-elect Donald J. Trump “lied about” the bipartisan House committee that investigated his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative Liz Cheney on Sunday called President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to imprison her and other members of a congressional committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol an “assault on the rule of law and the foundations of our republic.”

headline: Monday Briefing: Al-Assad Flees Syria as Rebels Claim Power
abstract: Plus, Notre-Dame reopens.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad has resigned and fled Syria for Russia, according to Russian state news media outlets, a stunning fall for a longtime dictator who had kept rebel forces at bay for years with the help of Moscow and Tehran. Follow for live updates here.

headline: Israeli Ground Forces Cross into Syria, Officials Say
abstract: Israeli ground forces have overtly crossed into Syrian territory for the first time since the 1973 October War, passing the demilitarized border zone, two Israeli officials said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli ground forces advanced beyond the demilitarized zone on the Israel-Syria border over the weekend, marking their first overt entry into Syrian territory since the 1973 October War, according to two Israeli officials speaking anonymously to discuss sensitive developments.

headline: Humdrum Routines
abstract: Elliot Caroll makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Notre-Dame Holds First Public Mass in Years: ‘Fire Has Not Conquered Stone’
abstract: Sunday was the first opportunity for worshipers to return to the cathedral, beloved by the faithful and secular alike, since the 2019 fire that devastated it.
lead_paragraph: Many Parisians can tell you exactly what they were doing when they heard that Notre-Dame was burning five years ago.

headline: Steve Mensch, President of Tyler Perry Studios, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Mensch, a longtime supporter of the film industry in Georgia, died in a plane crash on Friday in Florida, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: Steve Mensch, a film executive in Georgia who pushed for state policies to support the industry and who was the president of Tyler Perry Studios, died in a plane crash in Florida on Friday. He was 62.

headline: Syrians in New York City Celebrate the Fall of Assad
abstract: Syrian expatriates and their supporters beat drums and sang revolutionary songs in Arabic at a gathering in Washington Square Park.
lead_paragraph: Around 100 people gathered in Washington Square Park in Lower Manhattan on Sunday afternoon to celebrate the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, who fled his country after rebel forces stormed the capital earlier in the day.

headline: Stunned Iranian Officials Try to Distance Their Country From Assad
abstract: A reckoning emerged in Iran on Sunday as officials and commentators swiftly moved to distance the government from a tyrant it had supported.
lead_paragraph: Iranians watched in astonishment over the weekend as the reign of their nation’s longtime political and military ally, Bashar al-Assad, came to a crashing end. By Sunday, the reckoning had arrived as officials and pundits recognized that Iran was taken by surprise, and they hurried to distance Iran from a tyrant the country had supported in maintaining power.

headline: With Syria in Flux, Turkish Forces Attack U.S.-Backed Forces
abstract: Rebels supported by Turkish air power fired on a Kurdish-controlled city in northern Syria, pitting proxies of the U.S. and Turkey — NATO allies — against each other.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish military fired on U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in northern Syria this weekend, a war monitoring group and a spokesman for the Kurdish group said on Sunday, illuminating the tangle of competing interests and alliances in Syria in the wake of the government’s collapse.

headline: The Call
abstract: One call to a very unusual hotline, and everything that followed.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Trump Picks Former Ambassador to Mexico for Deputy Secretary of State
abstract: Christopher Landau is a longtime lawyer and the son of a veteran U.S. diplomat who served as ambassador to three nations in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Sunday that he had picked Christopher Landau, a lawyer and former ambassador to Mexico, to be the deputy secretary of state.

headline: Jay-Z, Accused in Suit of Raping Minor With Sean Combs, Calls It Blackmail
abstract: The entertainer said the suit, which accuses him of assaulting an unnamed 13-year-old girl in 2000, was an effort to gain settlement money by putting forward “idiotic” claims.
lead_paragraph: Jay-Z was accused of raping a 13-year-old girl with Sean Combs in a lawsuit filed Sunday by an unnamed plaintiff. He vehemently denied the allegation and accused the lawyer who brought the suit of trying to blackmail him with false claims.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Flying at Extremes May Hurt Navy Pilots’ Brains
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Those turns look graceful from the ground, but inside the cockpit you are vibrating like crazy and fighting to stay conscious.”

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Ol’ Blue Eyes
abstract: The sisters have a terrifying vision. Desmond gives a terrifying display of his power and loyalty. Any connection?
lead_paragraph: Two blue lights shine in the darkness, like the eyes of an insectoid machine. Guttural sounds, like speech in a language not yet invented, accompany them, but only for a second.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy’: Travis Fimmel on His Character’s Fiery Rise to the Top
abstract: Desmond Hart has been a wild card since he burned a young prince alive with his mind. The actor who plays him talked about what motivates Desmond’s drive for power.
lead_paragraph: This interview contains mild spoilers for Season 1, Episode 4 of “Dune: Prophecy.”

headline: Minnesota Vikings Find Unlikely Muse for Celebration Dance: ‘White Chicks’
abstract: Not everyone loved the 2004 film “White Chicks.” But 20 years later, some N.F.L. players are paying homage to it in the end zone.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t remember, “White Chicks” was a 2004 comedy in which the Black actors Marlon and Shawn Wayans donned heavy makeup to disguise themselves as white women.

headline: Massacre in Haiti’s Capital Leaves Nearly 200 Dead, U.N. Says
abstract: The killings in a Port-au-Prince slum, which appeared to target practitioners of Voodoo, were ordered by a gang leader, a Haitian human rights organization said.
lead_paragraph: More than 180 people were killed in a massacre over the weekend in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Haiti’s capital, the United Nations’ human rights chief said on Monday.

headline: The Art of the Gift: Kristen Arnett
abstract: The author keeps a list on her phone of gift ideas. “During the year, if someone close to me mentioned something that they really like or really want, I put a note in right then.”
lead_paragraph: Kristen Arnett, 43, is the New York Times best-selling author of “Mostly Dead Things” and “With Teeth.” Her next novel, “Stop Me If You’ve Heard This One,” is due to publish in March. She lives in Orlando, Fla. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

headline: Britain’s Flawed Jobs Reports Leave Economists ‘Second-Guessing’
abstract: Officials are grappling with an incomplete picture of Britain’s labor market as the national statistics agency strains to improve data quality.
lead_paragraph: An essential ingredient in economic policymaking, from interest rates to government spending, is reliable data. But government officials, economists and other number crunchers in Britain are expressing deepening concern over a long-running issue with a data set used to understand a crucial area: the country’s jobs market.

headline: India’s Luxury Property Market Is a Boon to Trump’s Business
abstract: The Trump Organization finds a warm welcome in India, where status-hungry home buyers clamor for a famous American brand.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump started his first campaign for the presidency, two Trump-branded buildings were going up in India, one in the financial capital of Mumbai and the other nearby in Pune. Before he won in 2016, the Trump Organization expanded its business in India, signing deals in two more big cities.

headline: Revolutions Swept the Middle East in 2011. Will Syria’s End Differently?
abstract: Bashar al-Assad’s downfall evokes memories of uprisings in Egypt, Libya, Tunisia and Yemen, each of which brought civil war or authoritarian rule. Syrians hope for better.
lead_paragraph: When protesters started trying in 2011 to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, they were part of a cascade of revolutions, known as the Arab Spring, that aimed to oust authoritarian leaders across the Middle East.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: A historic transition of power in Syria.
lead_paragraph: In a stunning fall, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has fled to Russia, state media there and two Iranian officials said yesterday, after he lost his hold on power to a lightning fast offensive by rebels. Here’s the latest.

headline: She Won Over Italy. Now She’s Bringing Trumpism to Europe.
abstract: Giorgia Meloni is ready to be the bridge between Donald Trump and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Unless Donald Trump decides to communicate with European allies solely in the acerbic language of tariffs, he will have to address the famous question usually attributed to Henry Kissinger: Whom do I call when I want to talk to Europe?

headline: ‘The Creep Tapes’ Finale, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
abstract: Mark Duplass reprises his serial killer role in a new series. And reality TV royalty, Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie, reunite.
lead_paragraph: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are broadcast live or available for streaming this week, Dec. 9 to Dec. 15. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Al-Assad’s Syria Was Brutal. Will What Comes Next Be Better?
abstract: It is hard not to worry that Syrians’ sense of deep relief today could be followed by a new set of horrors tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: It is hard not to rejoice while watching images of ecstatic Syrians toppling statues from the regime of the deposed dictator Bashar al-Assad and hearing the shouts of joy of prisoners, many of whom may have been tortured and starved, released from his dungeons. Mr. al-Assad’s Syria was brutal for the regime’s opponents, and 13 years of civil war and a kleptocratic regime made life dangerous and miserable for ordinary Syrians. In addition to striking a blow for human freedom, Mr. al-Assad’s fall also removes an Iranian-backed, anti-American and anti-Israel dictator from the Middle East chessboard.

headline: South Korea Bars President From Traveling Abroad
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol cannot leave the country as an investigation unfolds into whether he led an insurrection last week when he briefly imposed martial law.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s political dysfunction deepened Monday as its Ministry of Justice barred President Yoon Suk Yeol from leaving the country while officials investigate whether his brief declaration of martial law last week amounted to leading an insurrection.

headline: Word of the Day: permafrost
abstract: This word has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word permafrost has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 30 in “The Right Kind of Tipping Point” by David Gelles:

headline: How a Criminal With Close Ties to China Became a New York Power Broker
abstract: John Chan was a Chinatown gangster before remaking himself into a powerful force in New York politics — one closely aligned with the Chinese Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: On a Monday in March, in the heart of China’s capital, more than 2,000 delegates of a rubber-stamp advisory body to the authoritarian government of President Xi Jinping gathered for their annual meeting.

headline: An Elite School and the Criminal It Hired to Teach Math
abstract: Saint Ann’s School hired Winston Nguyen knowing he had been imprisoned for fraud. Then someone began soliciting graphic sexual images from its students.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month into Winston Nguyen’s teaching career at Saint Ann’s, an elite private school in Brooklyn, his eighth-grade students discovered that he was a felon.

headline: Three-Quarters of Earth’s Land Got Drier in Recent Decades, U.N. Says
abstract: Human-caused global warming helped increase dry conditions on every continent, scientists said in a new report, as talks on halting desertification were underway in Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: From the American West to eastern China, more than three-quarters of Earth’s land became persistently drier in recent decades, according to a new United Nations report that called the shift a “global, existential peril.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Road to Damascus Littered With Relics of Fallen Assad Government
abstract: Reporters for The New York Times entered Syria on Monday, finding remnants of former President Bashar al-Assad’s oppressive rule.
lead_paragraph: We arrived in Damascus early Monday, after passing surreal scenes on the highway leading into the city from Lebanon. Scattered across the main highway to the Syrian capital are newfound relics of the government of Bashar al-Assad whose oppressive rule has defined the country for decades.

headline: ‘We Came Here Gloating’: Syrians Loot Assad’s Palace
abstract: Thrilled by the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, Syrians took furniture and appliances from his official residence. Some posed for photos.
lead_paragraph: Thrilled by the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, Syrians took furniture and appliances from his official residence. Some posed for photos.

headline: What Kind of Cat Litter Is Best for the Planet?
abstract: We’ve got the scoop on traditional clay box fillers and the alternatives.
lead_paragraph: House training cats is easy. Most will use a litter box instinctively before they’re a month old. But what’s the environmental cost of the litter they’ll need over the years?

headline: How to Multiply the Power of Women and Girls in Africa
abstract: CAMFED combines skills training with basic education for girls, a proven model for helping them lift themselves and their communities.
lead_paragraph: I got my start in journalism in Kenya. Before I became a reporter, I spent more than a year as a volunteer teacher in a classroom for children who couldn’t afford real school. I had arrived in the town of Machakos, an hour outside Nairobi, determined to teach the kids who spent their days begging outside the supermarket. I realized that there was a Kenyan teacher, Alex Zakayo Mutiso, who was already doing that, so I became his unpaid intern. Every morning, I walked the dusty red roads to his classroom at the top of a hill, where the children came for the bowls of githeri, a dish made with corn and beans, but stayed to learn how to read and write.

headline: How to Avoid Pickpockets and Street Scams
abstract: Staying aware, keeping your valuables close and employing “layers of security” are among the ways to improve your street savvy.
lead_paragraph: Street theft isn’t petty to a victim. Having your pocket picked or bags stolen can ruin your trip and your finances.

headline: Spying on Student Devices, Schools Aim to Intercept Self-Harm Before It Happens
abstract: New technology alerts schools when students type words related to suicide. But do the timely interventions balance out the false alarms?
lead_paragraph: Dawn was still hours away when Angel Cholka was awakened by the beams of a police flashlight through the window. At the door was an officer, who asked if someone named Madi lived there. He said he needed to check on her. Ms. Cholka ran to her 16-year-old’s bedroom, confused and, suddenly, terrified.

headline: 3-D Mammograms Are Overtaking Traditional Scans. But Are They Better?
abstract: Here’s how good the tests are at detecting cancer and preventing false positive results.
lead_paragraph: Women going in for routine mammograms are increasingly being screened with a new type of imaging tool: digital breast tomosynthesis.

headline: Curbside Composting: What to Do and What Not to Do
abstract: New York City has extended its curbside composting program to all five boroughs. Here’s how to sort through the heap of rules and guidelines.
lead_paragraph: This fall, New York City expanded its curbside composting program to all five boroughs, good news for New Yorkers looking to lessen their environmental footprint. As part of the program, residents must now separate their food scraps and yard waste from other garbage and place them in a bin for pickup.

headline: Ukraine Asks if Telegram, Its Favorite App, Is a Sleeper Agent
abstract: The messaging app’s popularity has soared during the war with Russia, leading Ukrainian officials to increasingly weigh Telegram’s upsides against its security risks.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly three years since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the messaging app Telegram has been a lifeline for millions of Ukrainians. It provides information about coming attacks and helps communities organize food, medical aid and other support.

headline: Best Theater of 2024
abstract: Broadway roared back, but the kitties were downtown and the prayer service was in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Broadway always looks its healthiest around the holidays, and indeed, right now, most of its 41 theaters are lit, with the rest soon set to load in new tenants. Box office grosses, if not quite back to prepandemic levels, seem likely to meet or exceed last year’s $1.6 billion. But the real health of the commercial theater, for me, is demonstrated by how much it offers its audiences, not its investors. That’s why, most years, my list of best shows is top-heavy with the provocative work being brewed Off Broadway. If my latest list tilts the other way, perhaps that reflects Broadway’s liberal borrowings from the noncommercial sector — borrowings and often improvements. My Top 10, listed chronologically and covering the period from December 2023 through the end of November, are therefore mostly shows that, wherever they started and wherever they wind up, put a premium on provocation, sure, but also entertainment. That’s what I call healthy.

headline: 9 Best Theater Moments of 2024
abstract: “The Outsiders,” “Sunset Boulevard” and “Ragtime” were among the productions with stage moments that stood out this year.
lead_paragraph: Climate protesters disrupting a performance of “An Enemy of the People,” the outdoor walking scene in “Sunset Boulevard” and the giggles prompted by a character’s reaction to a hunky celebrity’s glutes in “Hold On to Me Darling”: The rewards of live theater were aplenty this year. Here, nine other stage moments that especially stood out, listed chronologically.

headline: How Some Voters Moved From Bernie Sanders to Donald Trump
abstract: For some young men in particular, the populist pitches from Mr. Sanders and Mr. Trump aligned with their attitudes about the ruling class.
lead_paragraph: They feel frustrated by the status quo, and they’re fed up with the system. They don’t trust politicians, and they want revolutionary change.

headline: Desperate Haitians Who Fled to the Dominican Republic Are Being Sent Back in Cages
abstract: Relations between the neighboring countries on the island of Hispaniola have long been frosty. They are now complicated by up to 10,000 deportations a week.
lead_paragraph: Cage-like trucks fitted with iron bars that appear designed to carry livestock line up every morning at the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

headline: Stephanie Koenig and Her Three Rings
abstract: Two proposals, a wedding and three family heirlooms later, the co-star of Hulu’s “English Teacher” is learning to love jewelry.
lead_paragraph: In the car on the way to her first proposal, Stephanie Koenig, who stars in “English Teacher” on Hulu, asked her soon-to-be fiancé, Chris Riggi, “You’re not proposing, are you?”

headline: Chinese Carmakers Are Taking Mexico by Storm While Eyeing U.S.
abstract: BYD and other manufacturers are importing cars from China and scouting factory sites in Mexico as part of a global expansion that, for now, excludes the United States.
lead_paragraph: Behind a crumbling brick wall in a working-class neighborhood of Mexico City lurks a seemingly innocuous car lot. But it could be a sign of a potentially grave threat to the North American auto industry.

headline: Best Songs of 2024
abstract: Listen to 68 tracks that made major statements, boosted big beefs, propelled up-and-comers and soundtracked the party this year.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a dipperful of worthwhile tracks from the ocean of music released this year. The top of my list is big-statement songs, ones that had repercussions beyond how they sound. Below those, it’s not a ranking but a playlist, a more-or-less guided cruise through what 2024 sounded like for one avid listener. I didn’t include any songs from my list of top albums, which are worth hearing from start to finish. But in the multiverse of streaming music, there are plenty of other possibilities.

headline: The Most Popular Recipes of 2024
abstract: You loved these recipes. Now see what made our Top 25.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was fast: It was January, we blinked and now it’s December. Quite a bit has happened in the last 300 or so days, and the team at New York Times Cooking created, tested and published about 1,000 delicious recipes to help you eat well through it all. Your favorites — the dishes you added to your rotation, the meals your kids actually (OK, mostly) ate, the dinners you were excited to cook — are below. Once again, the three Cs (comfort, convenience and chicken) were king. You can view the complete list of our 50 most popular recipes here. Find one you haven’t cooked yet, and try it tonight. Happy cooking and Happy New Year.

headline: Running Spies Is Not a Game for Amateurs
abstract: Will Trump be satisfied with servile leadership, or is he seeking to dismantle the system and make agencies responsive to his demands?
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump’s promises to destroy what he calls the “deep state” predate his first term in the White House. The sentiment raises fears in the intelligence community that there will be purges of career professionals, and that intelligence designed to protect American lives will be twisted to fit Mr. Trump’s personal interests.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A waterfront house in Richmond, a midcentury modern home in Pasadena and a Spanish-style residence in Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, three-and-a-half bathroom house, made of steel, concrete and walls of glass, is in the Brickyard Cove neighborhood, once home to the Richmond Brick Company. Directly on the San Francisco Bay, the house has a large private dock and a smaller one for guests, and both the nearby Brickyard Marina and the Richmond Yacht Club are easily reachable by boat. A brewery is a five-minute drive, as are a handful of convenience stores, while downtown Berkeley takes 25 minutes.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Grand Total: A Record $2 Billion
abstract: Over 21 months, the pop superstar’s culture-dominating stage show doubled the gross of its closest competitor, according to ticket sales figures confirmed for the first time.
lead_paragraph: For the last 21 months, Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour has been the biggest thing in music — a phenomenon that has engulfed pop culture, dominated news coverage and boosted local economies around the world.

headline: One of Japan’s Great Sushi Masters Is Working, Quietly, in Manhattan
abstract: To little fanfare, Keiji Nakazawa is sweating the details of the exacting Edomae tradition at Sushi Sho in Midtown.
lead_paragraph: An iron law of sushi holds that the more impressive the restaurant, the smaller the sign.

headline: A Comedian’s Path From Small-Town Tennessee to Breakout Fame
abstract: Leanne Morgan went from helping her husband sell mobile homes to sudden success in her 50s.
lead_paragraph: On many insomniac nights, when I’m trying to quiet the voices in my head, I listen to stand-up comics. I’ve been back and forth through Netflix’s roster: the blue-collar and the big city, the clean and the crude, the capital-W woke and the close-to-canceled, the ironists and the oafs, the oldies and the mere pups.

headline: The Power Struggle Behind Trans Youth Health Care
abstract: And why the debate over gender-affirming care could have far-reaching implications.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of “The Opinions,” the New York Times Opinion columnists Lydia Polgreen and M. Gessen discuss the historic Supreme Court case United States v. Skrmetti, its implications for gender-affirming care for minors in Tennessee and what it could mean for how the federal government interprets “equal rights” moving forward.

headline: The Killings of Young Mothers
abstract: For women under 25, getting pregnant more than doubles their risk of homicide.
lead_paragraph: For women under 25, getting pregnant more than doubles their risk of homicide.

headline: Pardon You
abstract: Who among us deserves a get-out-of-jail-free card?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Do you think it would be a good idea if Joe Biden gave presidential pardons to us in advance — as well as anyone else Donald Trump might go after once he’s back in office?

headline: Should Lessons Based on the Bible Be Taught in Public Schools?
abstract: Texas has become the latest state to bring Christianity into the classroom. What is your reaction?
lead_paragraph: In June, Louisiana passed a mandate that the Ten Commandments be displayed in every public classroom. Days later, Oklahoma’s state superintendent directed every public school to teach the Bible. And last month, Texas education officials approved a new elementary school curriculum that includes lessons based on the Bible.

headline: How Can I Make Corduroy Look Cool?
abstract: A reader seeks advice on how to style corduroy in a modern fashion. Our critic offers guidance on wearing the highly versatile fabric.
lead_paragraph: Corduroy is one of those materials that have been with us for so long that it has acquired a whole encyclopedia’s worth of cultural references.

headline: How to Keep Your Own Soul Safe in the Dark
abstract: Even at my lowest, I have never entirely given up my faith that good people working together can change the world for the better.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Thanksgiving, my husband and I finally moved our indoor plants back indoors. In years past we brought them inside in late September, just to be safe, because in those days frost often fell in early October, and a killing freeze inevitably came by the end of the month. This year, the first killing freeze finally came on Nov. 30, our latest first freeze in history. My indoor plants have become outdoor plants for all but four months of the year.

headline: E.P.A. Bans Cancer-Causing Chemicals Used in Dry Cleaning
abstract: The two solvents, known as Perc and TCE, cause kidney cancer and other ailments, and have been the subject of years of controversy.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday banned two solvents found in everyday products that can cause cancer and other serious diseases. It was a move long sought by environmental and health advocates, even as they braced for what could be a wave of deregulation by the incoming Trump administration.

headline: A Century-Old Law’s Aftershocks Are Still Felt at the Supreme Court
abstract: In 1925, Congress let the justices choose the cases they would decide. That change “continues to prompt political contention and crisis,” a scholar argues.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly a century ago, in February 1925, Chief Justice William Howard Taft persuaded Congress to grant the Supreme Court an extraordinary power: to pick which cases it would decide.

headline: Why Street Vendors Are Upset About a Ballot Measure
abstract: Proposition 2, which gives the Sanitation Department more authority to conduct sweeps of vendors, will hit immigrant vendors hard, an advocacy group said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at some concerns from street vendors about Proposition 2, one of the ballot measures approved by New York City voters last month.

headline: China Eases Overall Monetary Policy Stance for First Time in 14 Years
abstract: Faced with a faltering economy and falling prices, the Politburo loosened the policy approach of China’s central bank and called for “extraordinary” measures.
lead_paragraph: China’s ruling Politburo loosened the country’s overall monetary policy on Monday for the first time in 14 years, the latest in a series of measures aimed at recharging economic growth and stopping a broad decline in prices.

headline: France’s First Big #MeToo Case Goes to Trial
abstract: The actress Adèle Haenel has accused the director Christophe Ruggia of grooming and sexually assaulting her when she was 12. If found guilty, he faces up to a decade in prison.
lead_paragraph: She accused him of isolating her during rehearsals and filming. Of grooming her for three years, when on Saturday afternoons he would touch her sexually. When it began, he was 36. She was 12.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,270
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Syria’s New Reality, and Trump Lays Out Aggressive Agenda
abstract: Plus, the end of the Eras Tour.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Inside the Fall of Syria’s Brutal Dictator
abstract: Over the weekend, President Bashar al-Assad was ousted by rebel forces. What comes next?
lead_paragraph: Syria has been controlled by one family for more than half a century. It ruled by repression, devastation and violence.

headline: Iran’s Very Bad Year
abstract: We explain the country’s annus horribilis.
lead_paragraph: Most questions about Syria’s future don’t have clear answers. Will the Islamist rebels who have taken over the country create a harsh Taliban-style government? Or do the rebels’ recent hints of moderation point toward something gentler? The situation remains uncertain.

headline: Israel Claims Credit for al-Assad’s Ouster, but Sees Risk in His Absence
abstract: For Israel’s leaders, Bashar al-Assad’s downfall was made possible by their recent assaults on Hezbollah, Iran and Syria, all of which weakened the Iran-backed axis.
lead_paragraph: For the past year, Israel’s allies and enemies pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to limit his attacks on Iran and its partners in Lebanon and Syria, hoping to avoid a regional escalation.

headline: Syrians Displaced by War Rush to Return Home
abstract: The 13-year conflict in Syria caused one of the “largest displacement crises in the world,” according to the United Nations. Now, an untold number of people are trying to go back.
lead_paragraph: When Abdo Bakri returned to his hometown in northwestern Syria on Saturday after more than five years roaming the area in search of safe shelter for his family during the country’s civil war, he did not know what he would find.

headline: Dries Van Noten Names a New Dries Van Noten
abstract: Julian Klausner, who has been head of its women’s studio, is stepping into the founder’s shoes.
lead_paragraph: A new creative power structure in fashion is beginning to emerge. On Monday, five months after Dries Van Noten (the man) shocked the style world by retiring, Dries Van Noten (the brand) named Julian Klausner as its new creative director, elevating a longtime member of the design team to the top post.

headline: China Opens Investigation Into Nvidia Over Potential Antitrust Violations
abstract: The move by Chinese regulators came a week after the Biden administration expanded curbs on the sale of advanced U.S. technology to China.
lead_paragraph: China’s antimonopoly regulator announced on Monday that it was investigating potential violations of antitrust law by Nvidia, the American company that makes a vast majority of the computer chips that power artificial intelligence systems.

headline: Two Major Ad Agencies to Merge, Creating Global Giant
abstract: If successful, Omnicom and Interpublic would become the largest advertising company in the world, with more than $25 billion in combined revenue.
lead_paragraph: Omnicom Group, one of the world’s largest advertising agencies, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Interpublic Group, a large rival.

headline: Golden Globes 2025: The Full List of Nominees
abstract: The movies and TV series competing for the 82nd Golden Globe Awards. The ceremony will air on Jan. 5.
lead_paragraph: The nominations for the 82nd Golden Globes were announced Monday, and “Emilia Pérez” and “The Brutalist” are the top nominees.

headline: Trump Gives Powell a Reprieve, but Pledges Big Moves Elsewhere
abstract: The president-elect said he would not try to replace the Federal Reserve chair, but would seek to cut immigration, impose tariffs and more.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump used his first broadcast interview since the election to promise a fast-moving and disruptive administration that could shake up American and global business, including raising tariffs and cutting immigration.

headline: A Surprise Advance to Damascus, Captured on Video
abstract: Bashar Al-Assad’s grip over Syria was visible everywhere in the capital. It was all dismantled in less than 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: A brazen nighttime prison release. Presidential posters set on fire. Children playing in the halls of a palace once controlled by the former regime.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 9, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Matea Gold Named Washington Editor of The New York Times
abstract: Ms. Gold, a managing editor at The Washington Post, is the latest in a series of high-profile departures from the paper.
lead_paragraph: Matea Gold, a managing editor at The Washington Post who until recently was a contender for the newspaper’s top editing role, is joining The New York Times as a senior editor in its Washington bureau.

headline: Explosion at Fuel Depot Near Florence Kills at Least Two
abstract: Officials said it would take time to determine the cause of the explosion. At least 26 people were injured in the blast.
lead_paragraph: At least two people were killed and another 26 injured Monday in an explosion at a fuel depot on the outskirts of Florence, according to city officials and the company that ran the facility. The cause of the explosion had not yet been determined, the company said.

headline: Crowds Throng to Prison in Syria, Desperate to Find Relatives and Friends
abstract: The Assad regime ran a network of torture centers that swallowed up tens of thousands of Syrians. Now that the rebels have opened the gates, many see a chance to learn of the detainees’ fates.
lead_paragraph: Crowds descended on a prison on the outskirts of Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Monday, desperate to learn the fate of friends and relatives detained at a place that symbolized terror and death under the regime of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: New York City Council Sues Adams for Blocking Solitary Confinement Ban
abstract: The lawsuit charges that Mayor Eric Adams exceeded his authority when he declared a state of emergency to block a ban on the practice in city jails.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to force Mayor Eric Adams to carry out a law banning solitary confinement in city jails.

headline: ‘Emilia Pérez’ Tops Golden Globe Nominations
abstract: The movie received 10 nods, leading the field. Angelina Jolie, Timothée Chalamet, Pamela Anderson and Zendaya drew acting nominations.
lead_paragraph: The point of the Golden Globes has become clearer in recent years: It’s a cash register masquerading as an awards show — an opportunity to sell advertising, promote winter movies and flog designer gowns.

headline: Nobody Is Coming to Save Us
abstract: The fine artist and illustrator Oliver Jeffers on climate change, A.I. and the idea that maybe everything is pretty much our fault.
lead_paragraph: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: Do You Know These Winter Holidays and Popular Books of the Season?
abstract: Celebrate the literature of this festive month with with a five-question quiz that comes with its own reading list.
lead_paragraph: Celebrate the literature of this festive month with with a five-question quiz that comes with its own reading list.

headline: This Race Was Decided by 734 Votes. The G.O.P. Wants to Disqualify 60,000 Ballots.
abstract: One of the closest state elections in North Carolina history now hinges on the latest power struggle between state Republicans and Democrats — and a voter form dating back 20 years.
lead_paragraph: From voter ID laws to district map-drawing to judges redeciding cases, North Carolina has long been a laboratory of sorts in ways to amass political power. In recent years, Republicans in particular have changed both state laws and election rules to hamstring Democrats’ influence.

headline: 24 Things That Happened for the First Time in 2024
abstract: A series of surprising milestones, events and trends that were unprecedented until now.
lead_paragraph: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: A Quick Arab Pivot: From Welcoming al-Assad to Managing the Chaos
abstract: Only weeks ago, Arab nations had been working hard to bring Bashar al-Assad back into the fold, assuming he was there to last. They were badly mistaken.
lead_paragraph: Only weeks ago, Sunni Arab nations, led by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, were trying to bring President Bashar al-Assad of Syria back into the fold, urging him to break with a weakened Iran.

headline: Golden Globes 2025 Snubs and Surprises: Danielle Deadwyler, ‘The Substance’ and More
abstract: Female directors were well-represented, while “Dune: Part Two” and “Sing Sing” didn’t do as well as expected.
lead_paragraph: The 82nd Golden Globes nominations were announced Monday morning and the unconventional musical “Emilia Pérez” had plenty to sing about: The Netflix film topped all movies with 10 nominations, followed by “The Brutalist” and “Conclave.” Here are some of the most notable takeaways from this year’s field.

headline: Lara Trump to Step Down as R.N.C. Co-Chair Amid Florida Senate Speculation
abstract: The daughter-in-law of President-elect Donald J. Trump, Ms. Trump gave no indication of her next move. Senator Marco Rubio’s seat would become open if he’s confirmed as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: Lara Trump, whose name has been floated to fill a possible Senate vacancy in Florida, is stepping down as co-chair of the Republican National Committee.

headline: Your Running Form Matters Less Than You Think
abstract: Many runners believe their natural stride could be improved. Here’s what to know before trying to change yours.
lead_paragraph: Want to get better at tennis? Fine-tune your serve. Swimming? Perfect your stroke. But what about running? If you improve your form — from your posture to the way your foot hits the ground — will that make you faster and more efficient?

headline: Give Your Salmon an Anchovy Butter Boost
abstract: In my five-star salmon dinner, anchovies lend their intense and pungent bite to the sweet pink fillets.
lead_paragraph: Of all the ways to add oomph to weeknight cooking, the one I turn to most is anchovies. Honestly, I add them to pretty much everything short of ice cream, and I’ll go double if fish is on the menu. Tossing a couple of salty, saline anchovies into a pan of salmon or hake fillets is an easy move to bring out a deep umami funk that’s earthy rather than fishy.

headline: Quantum Computing Inches Closer to Reality After Another Google Breakthrough
abstract: Google unveiled an experimental machine capable of tasks that a traditional supercomputer could not master in 10 septillion years. (That’s older than the universe.)
lead_paragraph: In 2019, a team of Google researchers said they had built a machine capable of performing tasks that were not possible with traditional supercomputers. They described this machine, called a quantum computer, as a turning point in the evolution of information technology.

headline: How to Apply Makeup That Lasts
abstract: Advice from the musician Tinashe, the cabaret performer Justin Vivian Bond and the makeup artist Yadim.
lead_paragraph: In this season of back-to-back parties, there’s an extra premium on makeup that stays put. That need for longevity is something that stage performers — who must contend with sweat, bright lights and hurried costume changes — understand well. We asked three people familiar with those challenges about the products and techniques they rely on. Below, tips from Valentino Beauty’s global makeup artist, Yadim; the cabaret artist Justin Vivian Bond, whose show “Flakes” opens Dec. 12 at Joe’s Pub in New York; and the musician Tinashe, now on tour with her latest album, “Quantum Baby.”

headline: China’s Critical Minerals Embargo Is Even Tougher Than Expected
abstract: Beijing ordered companies around the world not to allow critical minerals mined in China to reach the U.S., while deepening its efforts to replace imports with domestic products.
lead_paragraph: Alarm is rising among multinational companies doing business with China about Beijing’s decision last week to order a trade embargo on the export of four critical minerals to the United States. The central subject of concern is a provision extending the ban to companies in other countries that transfer minerals to American firms after acquiring them from China.

headline: At the Kennedy Center, a Send-Off to Biden and Questions About the Future
abstract: A bipartisan crowd honored Francis Ford Coppola, the Grateful Dead, Bonnie Raitt, Arturo Sandoval and the Apollo Theater. Some wondered if Donald J. Trump would attend next year.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the president to the center box is typically a pro forma affair each year at the Kennedy Center Honors. But President Biden’s arrival on Sunday night carried the tinge of a Washington on the verge of change.

headline: Expanding the Laws on Assisted Dying
abstract: Readers discuss the British vote on the issue and urge actions in the U.S. Also: Safeguarding our food; taxing cow burps in Denmark; a crossword tale.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Syria Needs in Order to Rebuild
abstract: U.S. sanctions policy in the country must change.
lead_paragraph: After more than a decade of war, everything about Syria’s political landscape has changed in the space of 72 hours. Now U.S. sanctions policy must change with it.

headline: In Syria, an Image of Rebellion Embodied in a Hoodie
abstract: The quotidian uniforms of Syrian rebels, as they appeared on television, draws a powerful contrast to the image of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: The rebels appeared on Syrian state television over the weekend in puffer jackets and sweatshirts. One wore what appeared to be a trucker hat. A man in the center — the group’s appointed spokesman — wore a black hoodie as he addressed the Syrian people.

headline: Daniel Penny Is Acquitted in Death of Jordan Neely on Subway
abstract: Mr. Penny choked Mr. Neely in a minutes-long struggle on the floor of an F train. The case reflected the pathologies of post-pandemic New York.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Penny, a former Marine who choked a fellow subway rider on an uptown F train last year, was acquitted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide on Monday, ending a case that had come to exemplify New York City’s post-pandemic struggles.

headline: Who Is Alina Habba, the Lawyer Trump Picked to Serve as Counselor to the President?
abstract: Ms. Habba, who has advised the president-elect on legal matters in recent years, offered fiery defenses of him during his civil fraud trial in New York.
lead_paragraph: Alina Habba, who President-elect Donald J. Trump said would serve as a counselor to the president in the White House during his second term, has advised him on legal matters since he left office in 2021.

headline: How a Realtors’ Nonprofit Quietly Funds Conservative Advocacy Groups
abstract: The National Association of Realtors has created a nonprofit that gives more heavily to one side of the political aisle and to groups that have little to do with real estate and housing.
lead_paragraph: The National Association of Realtors — the largest trade organization in the United States — wields substantial influence over the American housing industry. To help hold on to that power, it also runs one of the biggest political action committees, routinely outspending even major companies like Amazon.

headline: U.S. Investigating Child Labor Claim at HelloFresh Subsidiary
abstract: The Labor Department investigation focuses on a plant in Aurora, Ill., operated by Factor75, a meal kit delivery company that HelloFresh acquired in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Labor Department is investigating allegations that migrant children have worked at a meal preparation delivery facility in Illinois that is a subsidiary of the popular meal kit company HelloFresh, the company and federal regulators said.

headline: Activists Call on Biden to Clear Death Row Before Trump Takes Office
abstract: The series of open letters from human rights activists and former corrections officials aligned with a larger push from Democrats for sweeping clemency action for those in prison.
lead_paragraph: A group of human rights activists, former corrections officials and families of crime victims asked President Biden on Monday to use his clemency power to take all 40 inmates off federal death row before he hands over power to President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: After N.R.A.’s Supreme Court Win, a Dispute Over Key Facts
abstract: The Supreme Court’s ruling in favor of the N.R.A. in May hinged on a secret meeting involving a New York regulator. The participants say it didn’t happen.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the sharply divided Supreme Court came together to decide unanimously in favor of the National Rifle Association. The N.R.A., the justices ruled, could pursue its claim that a New York State regulator had infringed on its First Amendment rights when she sought to discourage insurers and banks from doing business with the gun group after the 2018 school massacre in Parkland, Fla.

headline: Elaine May Makes a Rare Appearance to Talk About ‘Mikey and Nicky’
abstract: At a screening of the gangster tale starring Peter Falk and John Cassavetes, the director recalls her battle with Paramount to get the film released.
lead_paragraph: At Metrograph theater on Friday, a crowd of around 175 people was treated to the cinephile’s equivalent of a Bigfoot sighting on the Lower East Side: A rare public appearance by the 92-year-old writer, director and actress Elaine May.

headline: A Contemporary Music Festival Trolls for Aesthetics’ Sake
abstract: The directors of the London Contemporary Music Festival discuss this year’s edition, the event’s 10th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Recently, the London Contemporary Music Festival released a limited run of merchandise. There was a graphic T-shirt featuring the names of musicians whose creations have appeared at past festivals, plotted on a graph with two axes: the Y labeled “twee” to “brutal,” and the X “top” to “bottom.” Brian Ferneyhough was a brutal top, Cornelius Cardew a twee bottom, and Laurie Anderson was somewhere in between.

headline: Arts Patron Aims to Help Underrepresented Museum Professionals
abstract: Allison Berg has established a foundation to elevate the careers of six emerging visual arts curators, educators and administrators each year.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2020, the arts patron Allison Berg listened to the book “From Generosity to Justice: A New Gospel of Wealth” by the Ford Foundation president Darren Walker. She had what she called a lightbulb moment, “hearing Darren speak to the difference between band-aiding a problem and actually taking action to influence systemic change toward equity and justice.”

headline: Judge Denies Nadine Menendez’s Request to Postpone Trial Further
abstract: Ms. Menendez, the wife of New Jersey’s former senator, is scheduled to stand trial on Jan. 21, eight days before her husband is expected to be sentenced for taking bribes.
lead_paragraph: Nadine Menendez arrived at federal court in Manhattan on Monday without her husband, New Jersey’s disgraced former U.S. senator, her right arm in a sling and her face largely covered by a pink surgical mask.

headline: TikTok Asks Court to Temporarily Freeze Sale-or-Ban Law
abstract: The company is requesting a pause on a law that requires the app to be sold or face a ban in the United States by mid-January, aiming to buy time for the Supreme Court or the incoming Trump administration to rescue it.
lead_paragraph: TikTok asked a federal court on Monday to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a ban in the United States, as it looked to the Supreme Court and the incoming Trump administration to rescue it.

headline: Supreme Court Turns Down Cases on Admissions, Gender Identity and Guns
abstract: Conservative justices voiced objections and concerns about the court’s failures to take up a series of cases on major social controversies.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday turned away cases on admissions policies, gender identity and gun control, eliciting objections from conservative justices that suggested rifts on the court about whether and when to address major questions left open by recent decisions.

headline: How Old Is Too Old to Be President? Democrats Still Don’t Want to Say.
abstract: At a gathering of Democratic governors, many were reluctant to discuss the issue that sank President Biden’s campaign: age. Others are ready for a Gen X president.
lead_paragraph: Voters long believed that President Biden was too old to seek a second term. The issue torpedoed his campaign and saddled his vice president with an extraordinarily short political runway.

headline: Easy-to-Assemble Ghost Guns Have Been a Major Issue in Gun Control
abstract: The weapons do not have serial numbers and are sold online as do-it-yourself kits, making them popular among criminals barred from buying ordinary guns.
lead_paragraph: The man held in the killing of a health care executive, arrested on firearms charges in Pennsylvania on Monday, possessed what investigators believe was a so-called ghost gun, said Joseph Kenny, the chief of detectives for the New York police.

headline: Southern California Braces for Another ‘Particularly Dangerous’ Fire Forecast
abstract: Wildfire risk is high in Southern California, where little rain has fallen recently. The threat will skyrocket this week as offshore winds pick up.
lead_paragraph: Strong Santa Ana winds are expected to intensify the wildfire threat in Southern California early this week and create a “particularly dangerous situation” in Ventura and Los Angeles Counties, similar to circumstances in early November that helped fuel a significant wildfire, forecasters warned on Monday.

headline: Trump Says He Would Let ‘Dreamers’ Stay. But He Once Tried to Gut the Program.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s stance on the immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children is filled with contradictions.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said he would look for ways to spare immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children, known as Dreamers, from deportation.

headline: New York Taxpayers Could Get Refunds of Up to $500 Under Hochul Plan
abstract: The proposal, which Gov. Kathy Hochul intends to include in next year’s state budget, would send $3 billion in refunds to roughly 8.6 million New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Looking ahead to next year’s state budget and, perhaps, her re-election race the following year, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Monday proposed sending $3 billion in “inflation refund” checks to most taxpayers.

headline: Why I Still Send Holiday Cards — and You Should, Too
abstract: They serve a social function that’s surprisingly important.
lead_paragraph: With every Christmas card I write, I’m dreaming of a white Christmas, but I’m also pondering “The Strength of Weak Ties,” a seminal 1973 paper by the sociologist Mark Granovetter, then of Johns Hopkins University, now of Stanford.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Fails in Bid to Change Family Trust
abstract: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Mr. Murdoch, who was trying to give full control of his empire to his son Lachlan and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant.
lead_paragraph: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to change his family’s trust to consolidate his eldest son Lachlan’s control of his media empire and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant, according to a sealed court document obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Syria’s President Had Stocks of Chemical Weapons. What Happens to Them Now?
abstract: While experts believe that Syria has retained some stocks of chemical weapons, their quantities likely have been depleted and it would be hard for rogue actors to use them.
lead_paragraph: Rebels seized control of Syria’s capital on Sunday, ending the reign of Bashar al-Assad, who infamously used chemical weapons to kill thousands of his own citizens during the country’s 13-year-long civil war.

headline: ‘Strong Person of Interest’ Is Arrested in Health Care C.E.O.’s Shooting
abstract: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested on gun charges and for questioning in connection with last week’s killing of a health insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested on gun charges and for questioning in connection with last week’s killing of a health insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Events to Shake, or Gently Rattle, the World in 2025
abstract: Planning your calendar for next year? Here are some events to look out for.
lead_paragraph: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

headline: Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting Had a Manifesto, Police Say
abstract: The handwritten document found with Luigi Mangione criticized health care companies for prioritizing profits and conveyed “ill will toward corporate America,” according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: The man who was arrested on Monday in connection with the killing of the health care executive Brian Thompson was found with a handwritten document that spoke to his “motivation and mind-set,” Jessica Tisch, the commissioner of the New York Police Department, said at a news conference.

headline: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Showed Interest on Social Media in Self-Improvement
abstract: Figures like Andrew Huberman, Tim Urban and the Unabomber feature in posts shared by accounts that appear to belong to the man arrested on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The social media accounts that appear to belong to Luigi Mangione, the man the police have identified as the suspect in the killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, seemed to show an interest in self-improvement, clean eating and critiques of contemporary technology.

headline: Review: Resistance and Struggle in a Dance of Private Rites
abstract: A solo by the choreographer Bintou Dembélé, the first showing of her work in the United States, explored the crossover between hip-hop and diasporic African ritual.
lead_paragraph: When I asked the man if the seat next to him was taken, he didn’t even open his eyes. That’s when I first wondered whether he might not be just another member of the audience.

headline: The Most Memorable Things We Saw at Miami Art Week
abstract: And what the last art fairs of 2024 say about where the art world is going.
lead_paragraph: The art fair Art Basel Miami Beach, and the satellite events that have emerged around it, collectively known as Miami Art Week, have been held the first week of December every year since 2002, except in 2020 because of the pandemic. But even that year, Libbie Mugrabi, the ex-wife of the art dealer David Mugrabi, riding high from an enormous divorce settlement, threw a lavish dinner at the Faena Hotel. (“I can do whatever I want with it,” she told The New York Times of the payout. “And this is what I want to do.”) Last week, one gallery owner from New York summed up the purpose of the fair to me succinctly: “I need to make money,” he said. Miami is especially good for gauging the mood of the art business, and the direction it might be heading in. Prices at art auctions have been declining over the past two years, but a lot of people did indeed make money. And there was some evocative art on view, too. Below are a few takeaways.

headline: Why Chinese Americans Have Shifted Rightward
abstract: A growing number of Chinese Americans, especially naturalized immigrants, say Democrats have become too lenient on crime and homelessness.
lead_paragraph: For the three decades after she became an American citizen, Annie Tan tried to stay out of the fray. Politics, she thought, was for politicians, not for “regular people” like her, a 71-year-old Chinese American immigrant from Taiwan living in Southern California.

headline: Crowds Go to Syria’s Sednaya Prison In Search of Loved Ones
abstract: Rebel forces released many detainees from the notorious Sednaya military prison in Damascus. The government complex has a long history of human rights abuses under the rule of fallen President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: Rebel forces released many detainees from the notorious Sednaya military prison in Damascus. The government complex has a long history of human rights abuses under the rule of fallen President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Syrian Rebels Rush to Establish Order
abstract: Plus, a lawsuit for trans rights in China.
lead_paragraph: The rebels who took over Damascus announced yesterday that a new government would begin work immediately, as millions of Syrians and the wider world struggled to process the stunning end to the Assad family’s decades-long reign. Rebel fighters took up positions outside public buildings and directed traffic in a show of their newly claimed authority. Here’s the latest.

headline: Cease-Fire Talks Between Israel and Hamas Gain Momentum, Officials Say
abstract: While a deal was not yet in hand, a crack in the stalemate comes after Israel and Hezbollah reached a truce and President-elect Donald J. Trump ratcheted up the pressure for an agreement.
lead_paragraph: Cease-fire talks between Israel and Hamas to end the war in Gaza and free the remaining hostages are quietly advancing behind the scenes, mediators and officials say, after the Israel-Hezbollah truce in Lebanon and pressure from President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: U.S. Scrambles to Navigate Perils of a New Syria
abstract: The Biden administration is relying on Turkey to convey messages to Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which toppled Bashar al-Assad but is designated by the U.S. as a terrorist organization.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is scrambling to find ways to engage with groups in Syria and around the Middle East as victorious militias begin shaping the nation’s future after the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad, the longtime autocrat.

headline: Nobel Laureates Urge Senate to Turn Down Kennedy’s Nomination
abstract: Elevating Mr. Kennedy to secretary of H.H.S. “would put the public’s health in jeopardy,” more than 75 laureates wrote.
lead_paragraph: More than 75 Nobel Prize winners have signed a letter urging senators not to confirm Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: 58 Jazz Luminaries Assembled for This Photo. Only One Remains.
abstract: Art Kane’s “Harlem 1958” gathered giants of the music. Sonny Rollins, 94, looks back at the historic picture.
lead_paragraph: Art Kane’s “Harlem 1958” gathered giants of the music. Sonny Rollins, 94, looks back at the historic picture.

headline: Luigi Mangione, Suspect in C.E.O.’s Killing, Attended Elite Institutions
abstract: He grew up in Maryland, graduated from a private high school in Baltimore and went on to the University of Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Mangione, 26, the man who was taken into custody Monday morning in Altoona, Pa., and identified as a suspect in the killing of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare in Midtown Manhattan last Wednesday, appears to have been a well-educated and well-traveled enthusiast of computer programming and gaming with an interest in self-improvement.

headline: The Mets Stole Juan Soto From the Yankees. Who’s the Big Spender Now?
abstract: The Yankees didn’t just lose a superstar; they lost him to the Mets. Is the balance of power shifting in New York?
lead_paragraph: Did you feel the ground shake Sunday night? Did New York suddenly tilt from the Bronx down to Queens?

headline: Suspect Is Charged in C.E.O.’s Murder After Arrest in Pennsylvania
abstract: Luigi Mangione was arrested after a tip from a McDonald’s in Altoona. On Monday night, Manhattan prosecutors charged him with murder.
lead_paragraph: The tipster’s call to the local police came in shortly after 9 a.m. Monday from a McDonald’s in western Pennsylvania.

headline: Read the Letter From Nobel Laureates Urging That Mr. Kennedy Not Be Confirmed
abstract: More than 75 laureates have written an open letter describing Mr. Kennedy’s selection for H.H.S. secretary as detrimental to public health.
lead_paragraph: More than 75 laureates have written an open letter describing Mr. Kennedy’s selection for H.H.S. secretary as detrimental to public health.

headline: Jay-Z Sued Lawyer as a ‘Celebrity’ John Doe Before Assault Accusation
abstract: Lawyers for the rapper accused Tony Buzbee of attempting to “extort exorbitant sums” from him by making false assault claims.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks before Jay-Z was accused in a lawsuit of raping a minor with Sean Combs, he received a letter from a plaintiff’s lawyer threatening to “immediately file” a “public lawsuit” against him unless he agreed to resolve the matter through mediation for money, his lawyers said.

headline: How Netflix Made Magic Look Real in ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’
abstract: The first-ever screen adaptation will be released this week — a feat even the author didn’t think possible. We traveled to the set in Colombia to see how it was done.
lead_paragraph: The first-ever screen adaptation will be released this week — a feat even the author didn’t think possible. We traveled to the set in Colombia to see how it was done.

headline: Can Trump End Birthright Citizenship? Not Easily.
abstract: The president-elect has revived his wish to do away with automatic citizenship for anyone born in the United States. The Constitution stands in his way.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has revived talk of abolishing birthright citizenship — the guarantee, rooted in common law and enshrined in the Constitution for more than 150 years, that anyone born in the United States is automatically an American citizen.

headline: My Last Column: Finding Hope in an Age of Resentment
abstract: Where have all the good vibes gone?
lead_paragraph: This is my final column for The New York Times, where I began publishing my opinions in January 2000. I’m retiring from The Times, not the world, so I’ll still be expressing my views in other places. But this does seem like a good occasion to reflect on what has changed over these past 25 years.

headline: Trump Tests Ethical Boundaries With Branded Merch. (And All Sales Are Final.)
abstract: Everything around President-elect Donald J. Trump has become something to monetize, including a moment of comity with Jill Biden at Notre-Dame over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump learned a long time ago that photo opportunities could get him attention and that slapping his name on everything from skyscrapers to steaks could make him money.

headline: Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting Has Background in Games Industry
abstract: Luigi Mangione was passionate about game development and programming from a young age, teaching himself to code in high school.
lead_paragraph: The digital footprint of Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the killing of a UnitedHealthcare executive last week, indicates that he has a background in the technology and video games industry.

headline: Ernst, Under MAGA Pressure, Signals Backing for Hegseth’s Pentagon Bid
abstract: Senator Joni Ernst, an Iowa Republican who is facing re-election in 2026, appeared less skeptical after President-elect Donald Trump’s supporters threatened her with political retribution.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, signaled on Monday that she would not oppose Pete Hegseth’s bid for defense secretary, hinting at a turnabout after days of hectoring and threats by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s hard-right supporters who threatened political retribution if she failed to fall into line.

headline: Police Arrested a ‘Strong Person of Interest’ in Killing of C.E.O.
abstract: Also, rebels asserted control in Syria. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: After a five-day manhunt, police arrested a man today in connection with the brazen killing of a health insurance executive last week in Midtown Manhattan. Here’s the latest.

headline: Syrian Military Officials Charged With War Crimes as Government Falls
abstract: The officials, Jamil Hassan and Abdul Salam Mahmoud, ran an infamous prison in Damascus and “sought to terrify, intimidate and repress any opposition, or perceived opposition, to the regime,” according to the indictment.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has charged two top Syrian military officials with war crimes committed against Americans and others at a notorious prison in Damascus during the Syrian civil war, according to an indictment unsealed on Monday.

headline: A Test for the System
abstract: Donald Trump will take office with weakened checks on his power.
lead_paragraph: When the makers of “Schoolhouse Rock” set out in the 1970s to explain how the federal government works, they likened it to a three-ring circus. It was more than just a comment on the chaos of Washington — it was a metaphor for the three coequal branches of government that make our democracy what it is.

headline: Shock, Glee and Unease as Syrians Celebrate the Unthinkable
abstract: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city.
