abstract: “Her Story” touches on sensitive topics in China, like censorship and gender inequality. But its humorous, nonconfrontational approach may have helped it pass censors.
lead_paragraph: The movie calls out stigmas against female sexuality and stereotypes about single mothers. It name-drops feminist scholars, features a woman recalling domestic violence and laments Chinese censorship.

headline: Word of the Day: toboggan
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word toboggan has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 1 in the interactive “36 Hours in Zurich” by Noele Illien:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel: America’s ‘Going Nuts’ Over a Murder Suspect’s Abs
abstract: Kimmel applauded people for “moving away from nonstop election coverage” to instead obsess over the looks of Luigi Mangione, who was charged with killing a C.E.O.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: For Rastafarians, Marijuana Is Sacred. Should the Law Account for That?
abstract: Members of the religious group would like to see New York’s cannabis legalization law revised to include accommodations for those who use the drug in worship.
lead_paragraph: For Rastafarians like Richard Chung, a leather craftsman with a bundle of salt-and-pepper dreadlocks, marijuana has long been both sacred and a livelihood.

headline: Meeting (and Ignoring) Former Chimp Stars
abstract: Retired performing chimpanzees are living in zoos and sanctuaries across the country, where they are trying to relearn how to be apes.
lead_paragraph: As a longtime animal lover, I have what I consider to be the best beat at The New York Times: covering animal health and science as a reporter for the Science desk. I’m also a sucker for a messy docuseries, so I was intrigued to learn about “Chimp Crazy,” an HBO docuseries released this fall.

headline: $765 Million Contract
abstract: Superstar slugger Juan Soto agreed to a $765 million deal, the biggest in pro sports history. Is he — or anybody — worth it?
lead_paragraph: After helping to lead the New York Yankees to the World Series last year, 26-year-old slugger Juan Soto turned down his team’s offer in order to accept a $765 million, 15-year deal with their crosstown rivals, the Mets. It is the largest contract in professional sports history.

headline: The Amazing Kreskin, Mentalist and 1970s Television Star, Dies at 89
abstract: His display of mysterious mind-reading powers on TV made him a pop culture phenomenon in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: George J. Kresge, who as the entertainer the Amazing Kreskin used mentalist tricks to dazzle audiences as he rose to fame on late-night television in the 1970s, died on Tuesday in Wayne, N.J. He was 89.

headline: Want to Eat Well in 2025? Take Our 5-Day Challenge.
abstract: It doesn’t involve overhauling your diet.
lead_paragraph: Close your eyes and imagine a shopping cart full of ultraprocessed foods.

headline: Maria Callas: A Visual Dictionary
abstract: The things that made Callas Callas.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a century after her quiet death in a Paris apartment, Maria Callas continues to exert a hold on our imagination. Her interpretations of the canon are impossible to escape; her legend has — so far — proved impossible to eclipse.

headline: Can the U.S. Climb Out of Its ‘Unprecedented’ Housing Crisis?
abstract: The 2024 housing market was the slowest in decades. Next year’s might not be much better. It may come down to how many new homes can be built.
lead_paragraph: A young family in Grand Rapids, Mich., has been looking for a larger house for three years, losing countless bidding wars. In Portland, Maine, a 29-year-old data analyst has been anxious to get out of their rental for a year, but hasn’t found a home to buy.

headline: 6 Engrossing Historical Novels to Keep the Chill Away
abstract: Curl up with these transporting reads.
lead_paragraph: These days, it’s hard to envision what Seiler’s translator, Tess Lewis, calls “the heady atmosphere of hope and disorientation” that followed the fall of the Berlin Wall. Luckily, Seiler’s STAR 111 (New York Review Books, 496 pp., paperback, $19.95) brings it all vividly back. An autobiographical picaresque, his novel reconstructs the exhilarating yet often terrifying experiences of individual East Germans in that brief period between the collapse of the Communist regime and reunification. Its central character, a 26-year-old aspiring poet, drifts through East Berlin’s anarchic underground squatter scene even as his parents abandon their home in Thuringia for a refugee camp in the West. All three find that freedom is a frustratingly vague concept, requiring constant improvisation. But what choice do they have, fleeing the ruins of an “abruptly obsolete, discontinued life”?

headline: Read Your Way Around Chicago
abstract: Chicago is a city of bookish abundance, home to countless literary giants past and present. The author Rebecca Makkai recommends works that capture its spirit.
lead_paragraph: Chicago is too big, enormous in both geography and spirit, to capture in its entirety. Locals understand this. If you find a book set in a nonspecific “Chicago” — a book purporting to take the whole place as its subject, or one that assumes downtown is the entire ethos — you know it was written by someone who only visits.

headline: A Palestinian Winemaker Carries On
abstract: In the West Bank, Sari Khoury is trying to resurrect ancient traditions with grapes that reflect “the prehistory of modern winemaking.”
lead_paragraph: Sari Khoury, the proprietor of Philokalia in the West Bank, would prefer to speak of the craft of winemaking and the ancient winemaking history of Palestinians rather than of the precarious circumstances he must currently navigate simply to get his work done.

headline: ‘The Texas Chain Saw Massacre’ Score, a Noisy Gem, Will Arrive at Last
abstract: Fifty-one years after the smash horror movie, its groundbreaking and unconventional music — long a “holy grail” — will arrive on vinyl.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, years before helping to found the experimental rock institution Animal Collective, David Portner and Brian Weitz were Baltimore high school pals who diligently hunted for the soundtrack album that perfectly meshed their love of the unorthodox sound worlds of musique concrète and the thrills of horror movies: “The Texas Chain Saw Massacre.” “It wasn’t really till years later that I found out that it had never been released,” Portner said.

headline: The Gold Rush at the Heart of a Civil War
abstract: Famine and ethnic cleansing stalk Sudan. Yet the gold trade is booming, enriching generals and propelling the fight.
lead_paragraph: The luxury jet touched down in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, on a mission to collect hundreds of pounds of illicit gold.

headline: For Tesla Owners, a Referendum Through Bumper Stickers
abstract: As Elon Musk has become a key player in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s world, Tesla owners are marking their cars to signify where they stand — for or against.
lead_paragraph: It was the last week of October, with the election fast approaching, and business was booming for Matthew Hiller. His Etsy shop was receiving hundreds of orders per day. He was preparing to leave for vacation in France, and was hoping that while he was away Elon Musk wouldn’t do anything “particularly crazy.”

headline: The Grandpa Shoe Goes Hype
abstract: With a zesty collaboration arriving this week, the French shoemaker Mephisto is suddenly something it never dreamed of being before: cool.
lead_paragraph: Since Brian Procell first chanced upon Mephisto’s wide-set sneakers at his local suburban New Jersey mall in the 1990s, he has been smitten by the shoes.

headline: In ‘Our Town,’ the Characters Are Fictional. The Bacon Is Real.
abstract: Backstage at the Broadway play, they’re frying up the aroma of breakfast — part of a long tradition of adding scents to plays and movies.
lead_paragraph: The curtain had just come down on a recent Wednesday matinee of the Broadway revival of “Our Town,” Thornton Wilder’s 1938 play set in a small New Hampshire town. But cast and crew members were already in the basement of the Ethel Barrymore Theater, lining up to assemble BLTs.

headline: Adam Lambert Is Finding the Fun, and the Fear, in ‘Cabaret’
abstract: Making his Broadway debut as the show’s Emcee, the singer is reveling in what he calls “a thinking piece of musical theater.”
lead_paragraph: Over at the Kit Kat Club, the change in “Cabaret” is apparent in the show’s first moments. The Emcee, as played by the singer-songwriter Adam Lambert, is nothing like the Emcee as played by the film star Eddie Redmayne, who opened the current Broadway revival last spring after it transferred from London.

headline: Opioids Ravaged a Kentucky Town. Then Rehab Became Its Business.
abstract: In Louisa, an unbearable social crisis has become the main source of economic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Louisa, Ky., is a small town of about 2,600 on the border of West Virginia with a single pair of railroad tracks running through it. If you follow these tracks south, against the flow of the Big Sandy River, you’ll go between the public library and the Main Street Park and over Lick Creek, one of the manifold creeks that web eastern Kentucky like capillaries. Follow Lick Creek past a baseball diamond and a pawnshop and you’ll arrive behind an ordinary gray mobile home in a small lot of grass where Ingrid Jackson was living in the fall of 2023. The days were still long and the afternoon sun settled gently on nearby mountains, turning leaves a lambent red. Reedy gospel music played from inside the trailer, announcing Jackson’s presence as she opened the door. Her hair, normally figured in light brown curls, was packed into a shower cap. She smiled from the entryway. It was a smile difficult not to smile back at.

headline: Sticky Toffee Pudding Is the Best Low-Stress Holiday Dessert
abstract: Time is precious. Let this treat do some of the work.
lead_paragraph: Remaining festive over the festive season can require a game plan. Contrary to what rom-coms might suggest, making the good times roll is not always a lark. The expectations of kids to be surprised, the traditions of extended family and their need to be delighted, the pressures of the season more generally: Accommodating all these can be a lot.

headline: Holiday Romance Novels to Make Your December Merry and Bright
abstract: New festive stories center the many ways people celebrate the season, and each other.
lead_paragraph: Romance is an ever-expanding genre, with each new release adding stories that reflect its diverse readership. Holiday romances are no exception. This popular subgenre — which shares many hallmarks with its cinematic counterpart, the holiday rom-com — has exploded in recent years. Choose from a plethora of new festive offerings that center the many ways we celebrate our seasons and one another.

headline: 2024 Review: A Few Misses, but the Polls Got the Big Stories Right
abstract: They told us a lot about the major demographic and political trends, well before the election.
lead_paragraph: There’s a decent case that the polls were the best they’ve ever been in 2024.

headline: ‘The Bibi Files’ Review: The Case Against Netanyahu
abstract: This documentary about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel looks at the corruption investigation and his enduring grip on the government.
lead_paragraph: “The Bibi Files” opens by promising to show viewers leaked videos from the police investigation of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel (ubiquitously known as Bibi), who is currently standing trial on corruption charges. The videos, a title card says, “are being shown for the first time in this film.”

headline: Sex, Death, and Nicole Kidman
abstract: Between her experience on “Babygirl” and her mother’s death, the star has come to understand a lot about women in unfulfilled lives.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Kidman’s eyes widened. “Haven’t you been to the Rockettes?” she asked. “I go every year. Oh yeah, I’m obsessed!”

headline: The ‘Trump Dance’ Was Rebellious. Now It’s Just Everywhere.
abstract: Athletes did the awkward little shimmy to troll an imagined establishment. No one’s taking the bait.
lead_paragraph: Last month, in a game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the San Francisco 49ers’ star defensive end, Nick Bosa, celebrated a routine sack with a cheerful and ungainly series of hip-swivels and fist-pumps, not unlike the movements of an automaton gaining sentience.

headline: Recent Immigration Surge Has Been Largest in U.S. History
abstract: Under President Biden, more than two million immigrants per year have entered, government data shows.
lead_paragraph: The immigration surge of the past few years has been the largest in U.S. history, surpassing the great immigration boom of the late 1800s and early 1900s, according to a New York Times analysis of government data.

headline: Dating Apps Suck. A.I. Clones Are Making Them Even Weirder.
abstract: Eli wasn’t finding a connection on the apps, so he did something drastic.
lead_paragraph: Fake profiles. Unresponsive texters. Boring conversations. An endless stream of dudes on boats holding the fish they’ve caught. Talk to single people using dating apps, and they are likely to tell you that the experience is awful, but that they have to be there. Dating apps are just how singles meet one another these days. But what if artificial intelligence could fix modern dating? The Times reporter Eli Tan explored that hypothesis.

headline: Democrats Don’t Have an Easy Way Out
abstract: The party’s weakened condition leaves it ill prepared to defend itself against a Republican Party determined to eviscerate liberalism and the left.
lead_paragraph: The weakened condition of the Democratic Party leaves it ill prepared to defend itself against a Republican Party determined to eviscerate liberalism and the left.

headline: A Local’s Guide to Celebrating the Holidays in New York
abstract: Facing crushing throngs and high prices can be as off-putting as a rock-hard bagel. Here’s how New Yorkers enjoy their hometown’s seasonal traditions without much challenge to their patience or pocketbook.
lead_paragraph: In December, New Yorkers like to indulge in frothy hot chocolate and other traditional Yuletide treats as much as the city’s holiday visitors do, but facing crushing throngs and high prices, particularly at home, can be as off-putting as a rock-hard bagel.

headline: A Political Reckoning Will Come for Trump, Too
abstract: His cabinet picks show that the Republicans are hollowed out, too.
lead_paragraph: In our candidate-centric political system, every president is a singular figure in his own way, whose appeal to the public is at least a little distinct from that of his party. But presidents still have a relationship to that party, and their choice of cabinet members and other high-level officials can tell any close observer a good deal about the nature of that relationship.

headline: $1.35 Million Homes in New York, Nevada and Connecticut
abstract: A home from 1900 in Woodstock, a midcentury modern house in Las Vegas and a converted barn in Chester.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath house, which also has a guesthouse with a full bathroom, was part of the Byrdcliffe Arts Colony, founded in the early 20th century, and host to painters, novelists and performers over decades. Some original character has been restored, including dark wood siding and turquoise window trim. Mechanical and HVAC systems, gutters and the roof are new.

headline: What the Suspect in the C.E.O.’s Killing Has Revealed About Himself
abstract: The man arrested in Brian Thompson’s murder “views himself as a hero of sorts,” the police have said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at what’s known about Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the murder of a health care executive outside a Manhattan hotel. We’ll also get details on the city’s plan to close a shelter to head off concerns that it could be targeted by the Trump administration.

headline: Best Dance Performances of 2024
abstract: Once-in-a-generation ballerinas, topical works that transcended politics and a voguing “Cats” were highlights of the year.
lead_paragraph: If this year has shown me anything, it’s that I am pulled toward dance that is raw and cathartic, brave and complex. There might be beauty, but that’s not the draw — even with a dancer as astonishing as Mira Nadon of New York City Ballet. Her willingness to go for it is what matters, her fearlessness. As is the depth of feeling of Chloe Misseldine of American Ballet Theater. Twyla Tharp’s blend of the soulful interior with the virtuosic exterior. Ralph Lemon’s range and rage. Bill T. Jones’s bravery in exposing his vulnerability. And, particularly now, the imagination and commitment of a new generation. It’s dance that takes itself seriously.

headline: Traveling to the U.K. Soon? You Might Need to Apply and Pay a Fee First.
abstract: As of Jan. 8, an electronic travel authorization will be required for visitors from dozens of visa-exempt countries, including the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Travelers from the United States, Canada and dozens of other countries who do not require visas to enter the United Kingdom will soon need to apply for digital authorization in order to visit or transit through the country.

headline: Al-Assad’s Fall Has Changed the Future of the Middle East
abstract: As a new reality in Syria sets in, a reordering of regional power dynamics is already taking shape.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of the regime of Bashar al-Assad not only upends decades of Assad family rule in Syria, it also promises to realign power across the Middle East.

headline: Prepare for Guacamole to Be a Luxury Item
abstract: Trump’s immigration and tariff plans will strain American farming and raise the prices you see at the store.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for guacamole to become a luxury item?

headline: The Best Genre Movies of 2024
abstract: We look at the finest in science fiction, horror, action and international films, all available to stream.
lead_paragraph: It’s been an odd year for science fiction. One of the best such narratives was the Broadway musical “Maybe Happy Ending,” set in 2064 Seoul and in which two obsolete robots fall in love. Streaming series gave us an astounding range of stories and aesthetics, from “Sugar” to “Fallout” to “Dune: Prophecy.”

headline: Biden Administration Looks to Reinforce U.S.-China Ties Ahead of Trump’s Return
abstract: Senior Treasury officials are holding a final round of talks with a new round of economic volatility on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is making a final push to reinforce the communication channels it established between the United States and China before the relationship between the world’s largest economies potentially faces fresh upheaval when President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office next month.

headline: Inflation Ticks Up, but Details Are Encouraging for the Fed
abstract: Inflation sped up last month, but the details suggested cooling ahead. Next week, the Fed will make its final rate decision for 2024.
lead_paragraph: Fresh inflation data released on Wednesday made clear that the Federal Reserve’s fight against rapid price increases was not over. Still, the details of the report probably gave central bank officials enough confidence to cut interest rates at their meeting next week.

headline: In Aleppo, Rebels Give a Sense of What May Come in Syria
abstract: Rebel fighters who took control of Aleppo about two weeks ago have promised security and continuity. Prices have skyrocketed, but residents express some hope for the future.
lead_paragraph: The rebels who are now Syria’s de facto rulers have started to make their mark on the country’s government.

headline: The One Thing the U.S. Can Do to Help Syria Now
abstract: The editorial board writer Farah Stockman argues that ending the sanctions on Syria is the best way for America to help stabilize the country after the collapse of the Assad regime.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of “The Opinions,” Farah Stockman, a member of The Times’s editorial board, argues that letting U.S. sanctions against Syria expire, while not without risks, could go a long way to helping ordinary Syrians build a prosperous and stable nation.

headline: Suspect in C.E.O.’s Killing Fights Extradition to New York
abstract: Luigi Mangione, who was charged with murder in the fatal shooting of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, is a 26-year-old Ivy League graduate from a prominent Maryland family. Maria Cramer, a New York Times reporter covering crime, describes what else we know.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Mangione, who was charged with murder in the fatal shooting of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, is a 26-year-old Ivy League graduate from a prominent Maryland family. Maria Cramer, a New York Times reporter covering crime, describes what else we know.

headline: What’s Your All-Time Favorite Toy?
abstract: Furbys, Nintendo Switch, Rubik’s Cube, American Girl dolls, or Squishmallows: What’s on your Mount Rushmore of toys?
lead_paragraph: What are your favorite toys of all time? Do you go for old school classics like Etch A Sketch, Play-Doh and Barbie? Or the latest video games and high-tech gadgets? What’s on your Mount Rushmore of toys?

headline: Storm Aid vs. Partisan Power: A Showdown Looms in North Carolina
abstract: As Republicans try to muscle through a bill that is nominally dedicated to hurricane relief but in fact erodes Democrats’ influence, residents of the areas hit hardest say they urgently need help.
lead_paragraph: In the mountains of western North Carolina, the BearWaters brewery has sat vacant and decaying for nearly three months, its windows cracked or missing and the beer menu from its last day open still scrawled on one of them in white marker.

headline: Trump’s Admiration for Royals Could Make Them a Potent Diplomatic Tool
abstract: A meeting between President-elect Donald J. Trump and Prince William showed Britain’s hope that the Windsors could help safeguard relations with Washington.
lead_paragraph: When President Donald J. Trump visited Britain in 2019, British officials arranged for him to have afternoon tea with Charles, then the Prince of Wales, at his London residence, Clarence House. The thinking among British diplomats was that the 70-something heir to the throne would be a good partner for the 70-something heir to a real estate fortune.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,272
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 550
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Notre-Dame Rises From the Ashes
abstract: The Paris cathedral has reopened, five years after a devastating fire. The Times’s chief architecture critic tells its story.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, after a fire that many feared would destroy it, and a swift renovation that defied all predictions, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame reopened to the public.

headline: A Search for Syria’s Disappeared, and New Details in C.E.O. Killing Investigation
abstract: Plus, another World Cup raises human rights fears.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: How Many People Have Died in Syria’s Civil War?
abstract: The United Nations and human rights organizations have faced challenges in counting all those killed and missing in the conflict that began in March 2011.
lead_paragraph: With the end of President Bashar al-Assad’s regime in Syria, the task of tallying the cost in human lives of a nearly 14-year-long civil war is continuing. Death toll estimates from the conflict are as high as 620,000, a staggering number in a country with a prewar population of 22 million.

headline: The Largest Immigration Surge in U.S. History
abstract: We explain the scale of recent immigration to America.
lead_paragraph: My colleagues and I worked with government officials and outside experts in recent weeks to analyze the magnitude of the recent immigration surge in the United States. We published the results of that analysis this morning.

headline: Exxon Plans to Sell Electricity to Data Centers
abstract: The country’s largest oil company is designing a natural gas power plant outfitted with carbon capture technology to meet the voracious power demand of technology companies.
lead_paragraph: Demand for electricity is rising so quickly in the United States that even Exxon Mobil, the country’s largest oil and gas company, is planning to get into the power business.

headline: Blast in Afghanistan Kills a Taliban Leader, Khalil Haqqani
abstract: The government accused the Islamic State of being behind the attack, which struck at the heart of the Taliban’s power structure after years of essentially unchallenged dominance.
lead_paragraph: An explosion in Afghanistan’s capital on Wednesday killed a Taliban official who was a member of one of the country’s most powerful political families, government officials said.

headline: The F.T.C.’s Next, More Deal-Friendly Leader
abstract: Andrew Ferguson is expected to go easier on mergers than the agency’s current chief, Lina Khan. But he could take a similarly tough approach to policing Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s picks for merger enforcement is complete: The president-elect has chosen Andrew Ferguson to lead the Federal Trade Commission, making him one of the nation’s top antitrust cops — and an almost polar opposite to the agency’s current leader, Lina Khan.

headline: Macy’s Details Multimillion-Dollar Accounting Error in Downbeat Report
abstract: Analysts see much bigger challenges for the retailer than lax accounting.
lead_paragraph: With just two weeks until Christmas, Macy’s has been operating under a cloud.

headline: Police Say Suspect’s Notebook Described Rationale for C.E.O. Killing
abstract: “It’s targeted, precise and doesn’t risk innocents,” said a sentence in a spiral notebook belonging to the man charged with murdering Brian Thompson.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Mangione, who has been charged with killing the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare outside a company investors’ day in Manhattan, was arrested with a notebook that detailed plans for the shooting, according to two law enforcement officials.

headline: Syria After al-Assad: How Will the Rebels Govern?
abstract: After a rapid rise to power, the Hayat Tahrir al-Sham group is trying to unite a fractious country where fighting is ongoing.
lead_paragraph: Ahmed al-Shara, the leader of the rebel group that ousted the Assad regime in Syria, said this weekend that “Syria’s war-weary condition, after years of conflict and war, does not allow for new confrontations.”

headline: A Friend Saw My Daughter-in-Law Flirting With Another Man. What Should I Do?
abstract: A mother-in-law is unsure whether to say something to her son (or his wife) after hearing through the grapevine about an upsetting scene at a hotel bar.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine saw my daughter-in-law in a hotel bar with a man who is not my son. As my friend reported it, my daughter-in-law was dressed to the nines, draped all over the man and feeding him with her fingers. My friend walked over to her and asked, “Where are your husband and the kids?” My daughter-in-law answered calmly, and my friend walked away. This information is making me quite angry and sad. Do I tell my son about it, ask my daughter-in-law or keep it to myself?

headline: Men in Caring Jobs Will Make Society More Equal
abstract: Less stigma against male caregivers is all to the good.
lead_paragraph: In her prescient 2012 book, “The End of Men,” my friend Hanna Rosin described a modern American dynamic between archetypes that she called “Plastic Woman” and “Cardboard Man.” These comic book characters represented American women who made miraculous social progress in the 20th century and American men who stalled out. That’s because women in the past 60 years or so have been able to be infinitely flexible and responsive to structural economic changes and men remained rigid planks. This hasn’t just caused a shift in the job market; it’s caused a shift in the marriage market, too. If men aren’t breadwinners and they’re not caregivers, either, what are they for?

headline: Albertsons Backs Out of Merger Deal and Sues Kroger After Court Rulings
abstract: The supermarket chain had tried to join forces with Kroger, but judges sided with federal and state regulators who charged that the merger would reduce competition.
lead_paragraph: The grocery chain Albertsons said on Wednesday that it had backed out of its $25 billion merger with Kroger and sued its rival for failing to adequately push for regulatory approval, after both a federal and state judge blocked the deal on Tuesday.

headline: Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie Revisit ‘The Simple Life’
abstract: The celebutantes-turned-businesswomen are rebooting the show that provided a blueprint for the past 20 years of reality TV.
lead_paragraph: How would two troubled Los Angeles heiresses manage as members of the Bible Belt working class?

headline: Scholz Calls for Confidence Vote, in Step Toward German Elections
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz, who had few alternatives after his three-party coalition broke up, is widely expected to lose when Parliament takes up the measure on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called for a confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday, taking the first formal step toward disbanding the German government and leading to snap elections likely to oust him from office.

headline: The Torlonia Marbles Are Coming to Museums in Chicago, Texas and Montreal
abstract: For the first time, the ancient marbles are traveling out of Europe to the United States and Canada, for a prolonged stint.
lead_paragraph: Stashed away in a cavernous Roman deposit, hidden from the world for the better part of the last century, the Torlonia Collection — the largest collection of classical sculpture still in private hands — now appears to be continuing its jet-set itinerary that started in 2020.

headline: Who Set the Stage for al-Assad’s Ouster? There Are Different Answers in the U.S. and Israel.
abstract: President Biden says he weakened Russia, Iran and Hezbollah, laying the groundwork for Bashar al-Assad’s ouster. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says the Syrian leader would still be in power had he listened to American advice.
lead_paragraph: Bashar al-Assad had barely settled into his new quarters in Russia before the argument broke out over who can take the credit for ousting him, ending 53 years and two generations of brutal family rule over Syria.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Decide Nvidia Securities Fraud Case After All
abstract: In an unsigned order, the justices dismissed the case against the tech giant as “improvidently granted,” meaning they had concluded that it had been a mistake to take it up.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, which heard arguments last month about whether to allow a lawsuit accusing Nvidia of misrepresenting its reliance on the cryptocurrency mining industry, announced on Wednesday that it would not decide the case after all.

headline: Google Unveils A.I. Agent That Can Use Websites on Its Own
abstract: The experimental tool can browse spreadsheets, shopping sites and other services, before taking action on behalf of the computer user.
lead_paragraph: Today, chatbots can answer questions, write poems and generate images. In the future, they could also autonomously perform tasks like online shopping and work with tools like spreadsheets.

headline: Tracking Tropical Cyclone Chido
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Chido.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Chido.

headline: ‘Maria’ Review: A Diva in Decline
abstract: Angelina Jolie plays the opera star Maria Callas in a movie that can’t figure her out.
lead_paragraph: There is a moment, a little way into “Maria,” when you realize it shares a cinematic universe with another of the director Pablo Larraín’s recent films. This movie’s main character is the celebrated opera singer Maria Callas (Angelina Jolie). In a flashback rendered in monochrome, we see the night she met the absurdly wealthy business magnate Aristotle Onassis (Haluk Bilginer) — and he’s the future husband, we know, of Jackie Kennedy, who was the subject of Larraín’s 2016 film “Jackie.” Onassis, still married to his previous wife, claims he’s fallen in love with Callas through his opera glasses and invites her and her husband aboard his yacht; she seems lightly amused and a little irritated. “There’s a point where self-confidence becomes a kind of insanity,” she tells him.

headline: Reflections on Motherhood, Careers and Identity
abstract: Readers respond to an essay by Daniela J. Lamas. Also: Andy Griffith’s Mayberry today; Donald Trump’s loyalty test; never an exile; choosing charities.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A.D.H.D. Diagnoses Are Surging Among Older Americans
abstract: Many say they are relieved to finally have an explanation after decades of struggle.
lead_paragraph: Over her life, Tanya Murphy had become accustomed to hiding her depression. In the Christian social circles in Georgia where she raised her three children, this was the rule — not the exception, she said.

headline: ‘This Is the Best Salmon I’ve Ever Made’
abstract: Andy Baraghani’s sticky miso salmon bowl, and more of our most popular recipes from 2024.
lead_paragraph: It’s Best-Of season, our chance to rummage through 2024 to pick out a few things that really lit up our year. At New York Times Cooking, we published a thousand new recipes, and it would be nearly impossible to choose among them. That staggering total, and the stunning quality of each, couldn’t have happened without a truly stellar group of recipe editors and developers to shepherd the ideas, and the entire photo and food styling team to bring them to life. It makes my head spin.

headline: Malibu Fire Reminds Residents of the Perils of Living in Paradise
abstract: Flames threatened residential areas and forced thousands to flee, as firefighters fought to contain the Franklin fire.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters in Southern California on Wednesday began to contain a fire that erupted in Malibu late Monday night and has burned more than 4,000 acres, destroyed several structures and forced thousands to evacuate the area.

headline: Who Is Mohammed al-Bashir, Syria’s Caretaker Prime Minister?
abstract: Mr. al-Bashir previously headed a rebel-led administration in northwestern Syria. He has been tasked with running the country’s interim government until March.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed al-Bashir is an electrical engineering graduate who had been administering a sliver of rebel-held territory in northwestern Syria before he was tasked this week with heading Syria’s interim government, as the country faces many grave challenges.

headline: Wisconsin Man Who Faked Kayaking Death and Fled U.S. Is in Custody
abstract: Ryan Borgwardt returned to the United States on his own after staging his own drowning death and fleeing the country, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin man who faked his own drowning death in August and fled the country returned of his own accord several months after he disappeared and was in custody, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: F.D.A. Tries Last-Ditch Move to Slash Nicotine Levels in Cigarettes
abstract: The agency is asking the White House, in the final days of the Biden era, to move ahead with plans to drastically reduce the addictive substance in traditional tobacco cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: In the final days of the Biden administration, the Food and Drug Administration is seeking White House approval to propose a drastic reduction in the amount of nicotine in cigarettes, a longstanding goal of public health experts that has faced stiff opposition from the powerful tobacco lobby.

headline: Prominent Real Estate Agents and Brothers Charged With Sex Trafficking
abstract: Oren and Tal Alexander, once stars of the real estate industry, had a precipitous fall after women filed lawsuits accusing them of sexual assault. Their brother Alon was also charged.
lead_paragraph: Two star luxury real estate brokers and their brother are accused of using their wealth and status to lure, drug and then sexually assault and rape dozens of women, according to a federal indictment made public on Wednesday.

headline: Shadow of a Childless Woman: The Mythic Roots of Strauss’s ‘Frau’
abstract: What’s behind the strange emphasis on childlessness in “Die Frau ohne Schatten,” the Strauss-Hofmannsthal opera now at the Met? Look to the ancients.
lead_paragraph: Although the music of “Die Frau ohne Schatten” (“The Woman Without a Shadow”) is often transcendentally beautiful, it is among the least performed of the Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal operas at the Metropolitan Opera. Its relatively rare appearance on the Met stage is, I believe, in large part because of its weird, somewhat incomprehensible, and to some contemporary tastes offensive, libretto. The opera compounds the felony by being (at over four hours) the longest of all the Strauss-Hofmannsthal operas. Only “Der Rosenkavalier” comes close, but as “Rosenkavalier” is the best loved of all the pair’s operas, the length of “Frau” cannot be the only culprit.

headline: Sundance Film Festival Unveils a Lineup Heavy on Politics
abstract: The annual event also makes room for a remake of the musical “Kiss of the Spider Woman” and the return of Justin Lin.
lead_paragraph: There is a point during every Sundance Film Festival, usually as movie fans are trudging through the cold, slushy snow in Park City, Utah, when they wonder, why do they hold this in January? And yet, so often current events — most often of the political nature — are reflected not only in the films being screened on the mountain but also in the happenings around town.

headline: How a Soprano With Dyslexia Rose to the Heights of Opera
abstract: Elza van den Heever, a star of “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” at the Metropolitan Opera, no longer sees dyslexia as a hindrance — just a different way of learning.
lead_paragraph: When the soprano Elza van den Heever was hired to sing the role of the Empress in Strauss’s “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” at the Metropolitan Opera, she was elated. It was a dream role — the kind that could cement her reputation as a leading singer.

headline: Objectifying the Accused
abstract: What happens when violent crimes are overshadowed by appearances?
lead_paragraph: From the moment the world saw the smiling, unmasked face of the young man in the New York City hostel, memes began spreading about his looks. In the days since, after Luigi Mangione was identified and charged in the murder of the UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson, it has been impossible to escape his photo. Or photos. They are proliferating.

headline: Bipartisan Lawmakers Seek to Break Up Giant Health Care Conglomerates
abstract: New legislation would force UnitedHealth Group, CVS Health and Cigna to each sell their pharmacies within three years.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress are pushing legislation that threatens to break up some of the nation’s biggest health care conglomerates, including UnitedHealth Group and CVS Health, by forcing them to sell off their retail or mail-order pharmacies.

headline: 120 Miles of Russian Forest Couldn’t Keep These Two Tigers Apart
abstract: Boris and Svetlaya were raised together as orphaned cubs, and then reintroduced to the wild separately. But Boris went on a trek that surprised the researchers who were monitoring him.
lead_paragraph: When Russian scientists released a pair of orphaned Amur tiger cubs into the wild in a remote corner of Russia’s far east in 2014, they were trying to save a species. While the tigers, sometimes called Siberian tigers and the world’s largest big cat, remain endangered, the scientists created something else: an unlikely love story.

headline: Like a Family Reunion, but With More Tears (and Tonys)
abstract: The cast of the 2008 Broadway revival of “South Pacific,” including Kelli O’Hara and Matthew Morrison, reunited for a benefit performance. The emotions were the guest of honor.
lead_paragraph: The Sweetgreen salads had barely been distributed when the tears started.

headline: Alexander Brothers Sex Trafficking Indictment
abstract: The federal indictment against Oren Alexander, Tal Alexander and Alon Alexander, on conspiracy to commit sex trafficking.
lead_paragraph: The federal indictment against Oren Alexander, Tal Alexander and Alon Alexander, on conspiracy to commit sex trafficking.

headline: Preet Bharara to Investigate State Police Slowdown in New Jersey
abstract: New Jersey’s attorney general has chosen Mr. Bharara, a former U.S. attorney, to investigate a steep dip in tickets for speeding and drunken driving.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s attorney general announced on Wednesday that he had enlisted Preet Bharara, a former Manhattan federal prosecutor, to lead a criminal investigation into a protracted slowdown in traffic enforcement by State Police troopers.

headline: Private Insurers Must Now Cover Dyslexia Testing in New York
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul signed into law a first-in-the-nation bill requiring insurance companies to cover costs associated with dyslexia diagnoses.
lead_paragraph: A significant hurdle facing dyslexic children in New York was cleared on Wednesday, when Gov. Kathy Hochul signed a bill into law that requires private insurers to cover the costs of key diagnostic tests.

headline: Raygun Shuts Down Musical Inspired by Her Jeered Olympic Breaking
abstract: The comedian behind the parody about the Australian breaker who became a summer celebrity said she was willing to make some changes to avoid legal drama.
lead_paragraph: A performance of “Breaking: The Musical,” a parody exploring the journey of the Australian breaker known as B-girl Raygun, whose unusual routines at the Paris Olympics this summer led to mockery and memes, was shut down after a cease-and-desist letter.

headline: With His Usual Flair, John Galliano Exits Maison Margiela
abstract: The star designer, who has often courted controversy, rebuilt his reputation at the Parisian fashion house. After 10 years, he said goodbye with an Instagram post.
lead_paragraph: The year couldn’t end without another industry-rattling departure in the fashion world. On Wednesday, John Galliano, one of the last consensus megastar designers, stepped down from his post as artistic director of Maison Margiela.

headline: Christopher Wray Says He’ll Step Down as F.B.I. Director
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump had already signaled his intention to replace Mr. Wray with a longtime loyalist, Kash Patel.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, said on Wednesday that he intended to resign before the Trump administration took office, bowing to the reality that President-elect Donald J. Trump had publicly declared his desire to replace him.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Two of You Are Sickening’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: For 22 years, Steve has been my tough, motorcycle-riding, dog-loving neighbor. He knows my life’s chaos — a broken heart, elder care, house repairs — and takes it upon himself to look out for me. This Christmas, he noticed my undecorated house. “You don’t have lights,” he declared matter-of-factly. Bypassing my protests about effort, waste and aesthetics, he admitted that he had already bought me some, then proceeded to string bright, mismatched bulbs across my porch. They’re not my style, but they’re unmistakably Steve: bold, unapologetic, full of heart. Sometimes love is letting someone’s unsolicited care light up your life. — Aimee Norman

headline: Collins Grills Hegseth but Remains Undecided on His Bid for Defense Secretary
abstract: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said she questioned President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon on the misconduct allegations against him and other topics.
lead_paragraph: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said she had privately questioned Pete Hegseth on both policy issues and the misconduct allegations against him but would not decide whether to back President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon until after a thorough vetting.

headline: This Ohio-Hating Michigan Democrat Has Thoughts on Why Her Party Lost
abstract: Kristen McDonald Rivet won a tough House race in a heavily white, working-class area even as many Democrats in such places lost. In an interview, she warned against a “tone-deaf” economic message.
lead_paragraph: Democrats, rejected by many voters and headed for life in the minority in Washington, see few reasons for optimism these days.

headline: Far-Right Militias Seek Role in Trump Deportation Plan
abstract: The incoming administration said it would not rely on outside groups to carry out its plan to deport millions of immigrants, but militias have a long record of inserting themselves into patrolling the border.
lead_paragraph: A few days after the election, William Teer, who runs the Texas Three Percenters, a local far-right militia group, wrote to President-elect Donald J. Trump with an offer: His organization could help Mr. Trump carry out his plan to deport millions of people who are in the United States illegally.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Biden Plan to Address Toxic Coal Ash
abstract: The court’s order was provisional, rejecting a request from a Kentucky electric utility to block the plan while an appeals court considers its challenge.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected a request from an electric utility in Kentucky to block an Environmental Protection Agency effort to address the health risks presented by coal ash, a toxic substance created by burning coal to produce electricity.

headline: Technologists: Smarter-Than-Humans A.I. Will Likely Be Here by 2030
abstract: Most members of a DealBook Summit panel described immense benefits from artificial intelligence and saw its risks as manageable.
lead_paragraph: Powerful technologies have always been double-edged swords. That’s been true since fire; it could cook your food and keep you warm, but, out of control, burn down your hut.

headline: U.K. Bans Puberty Blockers for Teens Indefinitely
abstract: A freeze placed this year on their use to treat gender dysphoria will remain in place for young people under 18, except in clinical trials, Britain’s government said.
lead_paragraph: Britain is to ban indefinitely the use of puberty blockers for young people under 18 with gender dysphoria, except in clinical trials, the government said on Wednesday, making permanent a set of temporary restrictions put in place earlier this year.

headline: Women Need More Help to Rise in the Workplace
abstract: A DealBook Summit panel said a lack of helpful policies was hindering female advancement, while freezing eggs to postpone motherhood did not always work out.
lead_paragraph: While women appear to be doing better in many ways — two have even run for U.S. president as major party candidates — there has been limited progress in gaining leadership positions in business. That has to do with a lack of corporate and government policies to support women as they balance work life and home demands, concluded a task force of female business leaders, entrepreneurs and activists convened by The New York Times at the DealBook Summit on Dec. 4.

headline: Man Who Leaped Over Bench to Attack Nevada Judge Gets Decades in Prison
abstract: A courtroom video recorded Deobra Redden as he ran up and attacked Judge Mary Kay Holthus at his sentencing hearing.
lead_paragraph: A man who was captured on video as he leaped over a judge’s bench and lunged at her in a Las Vegas courtroom earlier this year has been sentenced to decades in prison.

headline: Seismic Political Shifts Are Likely to Continue
abstract: A lively DealBook Summit task force agreed on little except that the electorate is restless.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 presidential election isn’t over.

headline: For Athletes, the Draw and the How of Branding
abstract: A task force at the DealBook Summit discussed how from college to pro sports, becoming a brand is a challenge.
lead_paragraph: If you’re Michael Jordan, the basketball superstar, you can be silent and still be a brand. But every other athlete needs to figure out how to position themselves if they want to move from great player to top recipient of sponsorship dollars and to one day being their own brand.

headline: Serena Williams Is Competing on a New Court: Investment
abstract: “I’ve learned to trust my instincts in any business venture or brand I’m championing,” the retired tennis star said in an interview at the DealBook Summit.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams may have retired in 2022 from a record breaking career in professional tennis that catapulted her to global fame, but her post-tournament life keeps her just as professionally engaged, albeit in a different realm.

headline: From the DealBook Summit: Influential People Share Their Insights
abstract: Industry leaders attending the conference were asked about artificial intelligence, the economy, international relations and more.
lead_paragraph: At last week’s DealBook Summit in New York City, leaders in business, tech, media, law and other disciplines were invited by The New York Times to lead conversations about pressing issues in their fields. Ahead of the summit, The Times sent questions to each of the Groundbreakers. Their answers have been edited and condensed.

headline: Could Cats Become a Carrier of Bird Flu?
abstract: A new study highlights the need for public health officials to ramp up bird flu surveillance in our feline companions.
lead_paragraph: Domestic cats could provide an unexpected new route for the bird flu virus H5N1 to evolve into a more dangerous form, according to a new study published on Monday.

headline: Building Trust in an Age of Distrust
abstract: At this year’s DealBook Summit, there was a sense that trust was becoming harder to come by and that the rules for how people judge the truth had shifted.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of my more than hourlong interview last week with Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder and space entrepreneur, there was a comment that struck me — that’s been rattling around in my brain for days.

headline: Trump Wants Mass Deportations. He Will Need Jails and Sanctuary Cities to Help.
abstract: Immigration experts say the Trump administration would need cooperation from local law enforcement to deport millions of people.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said little about the specifics of how he would carry out the promised largest deportation effort in American history. But immigration experts say it would be nearly impossible to execute without some critical assistance, particularly from jails and prisons.

headline: ‘The Best Government Money Can Buy’
abstract: Under the influence of a coterie of tech boosters, it’s full speed ahead.
lead_paragraph: For a while, it seemed, the future had disappeared from American politics. Bill Clinton sold us his bridge to the 21st century. George W. Bush plotted a rebranding of the conservative party and then reimagined American empire. Barack Obama campaigned on hope and change in what was called, at the time, the first Facebook election.

headline: Hunt Continues for U.S. Journalist Who Disappeared in Syria
abstract: The U.S. has identified prisons of interest as it searches for clues about Austin Tice, who was abducted in 2012 and whose fate remains unknown.
lead_paragraph: The United States has identified a handful of prisons in Syria that might provide clues to the fate of Austin Tice, an American journalist who was abducted in 2012 and believed held by the Syrian government.

headline: Syria’s Rebel Group Destroys Tomb of Ousted President’s Father
abstract: Rebels damaged and burned the tomb of former Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad, in what some are calling an act of revenge.
lead_paragraph: Rebels damaged and burned the tomb of former Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad, in what some are calling an act of revenge.

headline: The Pistachio Martini Is Beloved. And Baffling.
abstract: The creamy, pastel green drink is an enigma, but that doesn’t stop bartenders across the country from adding it to their menus.
lead_paragraph: At Caffé Vittoria in the North End of Boston, a drink arrives in a conical glass, a scoop of pistachio ice cream melting into the light green liquid. Served with a demitasse spoon, its taste falls somewhere between dessert and a boozy cocktail.

headline: Colleges Warn Foreign Students to Get to Campus Before Trump Takes Office
abstract: Harvard, Penn and U.S.C. were among the universities and colleges that issued advisories in anticipation of possible travel bans.
lead_paragraph: With students at many colleges wrapping up final exams this week and preparing for their winter break, a number of schools, including Harvard, U.S.C. and Cornell, are advising their international students to return to campus before President-elect Donald J. Trump is inaugurated on Jan. 20.

headline: New Jersey Politician Fakes Spotify Wrapped to Show All Springsteen Songs
abstract: Representative Josh Gottheimer, a Democrat who is running for governor, may well be a huge fan of the Boss. But his Spotify Wrapped was not real.
lead_paragraph: In what has become an annual tradition for millions of Spotify users, Representative Josh Gottheimer, who is running for governor in New Jersey, recently shared his list of top songs for the year.

headline: ‘Golden Bachelor’ Star Announces Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: Gerry Turner rose to prominence as a septuagenarian star of a reality dating show. In an interview with People, he said he has a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
lead_paragraph: Gerry Turner, the reality TV star known for his tumultuous turn as the first “Golden Bachelor,” announced on Wednesday that he had been diagnosed with a form of blood cancer.

headline: Russian Military and Commercial Activity Appears Halted at Key Syrian Port
abstract: Satellite images from last week and this week show that naval vessels docked at the port city of Tartus have left. According to marine tracking data, no cargo ships have entered or left Tartus since Monday.
lead_paragraph: Satellite imagery and ship tracking data reviewed by The New York Times show that Russian naval and commercial activity in the key Syrian port of Tartus — which has played a critical role in Moscow’s projection of military power in the region — has ceased since Bashar al-Assad’s government fell on Sunday.

headline: New York Times and Tech Guild Reach Deal
abstract: The union, which represents some 600 tech workers at the publication, had been negotiating for a contract for more than two years. It will vote on ratifying the deal next week.
lead_paragraph: The Times Tech Guild, which represents tech workers at The New York Times, said on Wednesday that it had reached a tentative deal with The Times on a contract, after more than two years of bargaining and a weeklong strike.

headline: Are Those Drones Over New Jersey? Despite Sightings, U.S. Is Skeptical.
abstract: Drones have been reported in at least 10 counties of the state. But a White House spokesman suggested many of them were actually manned aircraft.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of reported drone sightings in the skies above New Jersey have alarmed lawmakers and local officials and left them searching for answers.

headline: Biden’s Top Aides Race to Middle East as Militias Wield Power in Syria
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken plans to hold meetings in Jordan and Turkey. Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, is visiting Israel.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s two top national security officials left for the Middle East on Wednesday as the sudden fall of Bashar al-Assad, Syria’s longtime autocratic ruler, to militias has prompted a diplomatic scramble in the region.

headline: U.S. Strategy on Syria Risks ISIS Resurgence, Kurdish General Warns
abstract: Gen. Mazlum Kobani, commander of Kurdish forces in Syria, said recent decisions by the U.S. in Syria potentially “leaves a vacuum” that ISIS could take advantage of.
lead_paragraph: The commander of Syria’s largest Kurdish militia has accused the United States of abandoning its Kurdish allies in Syria, key partners in America’s fight against the Islamic State, and warned of a resurgence by the Islamic State amid political uncertainty in Syria.

headline: Thursday Briefing: The Struggle to Create Order in Syria
abstract: Plus, China’s surprising box office hit.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the rebel force that overthrew Bashar al-Assad called on other countries to hand over any “criminals” who had fled Syria so they could be held accountable for the torture or killing of prisoners under al-Assad.

headline: Why Was a Murder Suspect’s Instagram Taken Down, but Not His Goodreads?
abstract: Luigi Mangione’s social media accounts attracted swift attention after he was arrested in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive. When do companies scrub a digital trail?
lead_paragraph: Moments after the authorities announced that Luigi Mangione had been arrested in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive on Monday, people delved into his digital trail.

headline: In Aleppo, Residents Cheer and Refugees Return to a Jubilant but Ravaged City
abstract: Though excitement and frenzy were on full display in some parts of Aleppo, the city is still gripped by uncertainty after the sudden end of a 13-year civil war.
lead_paragraph: The many monuments of the Assad regime that once dotted the Syrian city of Aleppo have been toppled, torn or burned.

headline: North Carolina G.O.P. Brushes Aside Democratic Governor to Expand Power
abstract: After cloaking a bill that strips key powers from Democrats as hurricane aid, the state’s Republican-controlled legislature overrode a veto from Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat, to pass it into law.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in North Carolina muscled through a sweeping expansion of their own power on Wednesday, overriding the Democratic governor’s veto of a bill that will give the G.O.P. increased control over elections, judicial appointments and whether its laws stand up in the courts.

headline: House Passes Defense Bill Denying Transgender Health Coverage for Minors
abstract: The $895 billion measure was approved over the opposition of most Democrats, who rejected a provision inserted by Republicans to deny the coverage to the minor children of military personnel.
lead_paragraph: A divided House on Wednesday passed a defense policy bill that would direct $895 billion to the Pentagon and other military operations, moving over the opposition of Democrats who objected to a provision denying coverage for transgender health care for the children of service members.

headline: The ‘Ballad of Keiko’ Music Video
abstract: This is the story of the real-life whale from “Free Willy” and his odyssey back to the ocean. In Episode 5 of the “Good Whale” podcast, Keiko disappears in Icelandic waters. For four weeks, nobody knew what had happened to him. So we reimagined this mysterious time — as a musical.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of the real-life whale from “Free Willy” and his odyssey back to the ocean. In Episode 5 of the “Good Whale” podcast, Keiko disappears in Icelandic waters. For four weeks, nobody knew what had happened to him. So we reimagined this mysterious time — as a musical.

headline: The F.B.I. Director Said He Would Resign
abstract: Also, A.D.H.D. diagnoses are surging among older Americans. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Wray, the F.B.I. director, told bureau employees today that he would resign before Donald Trump took office in January. In his address, Wray said he believed the move was “the best way to avoid dragging the bureau deeper into the fray.”

headline: So Much Losing
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump is stocking his administration with people who have lost elections.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has long boasted about how much he likes winners and how much he likes winning.

headline: Martin Benson, Regional Theater Impresario With Impact, Dies at 87
abstract: South Coast Repertory, a California company he founded with a partner, grew to stage world premieres of major works that made their way to Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Martin Benson, a founder and longtime artistic director of South Coast Repertory, a nationally renowned regional theater in Southern California that won a Tony Award in 1988, died on Nov. 30 at his home in Huntington Beach, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Syria’s New Leaders Balance Huge Struggles Amid Disorder
abstract: The rebels who seized control called for foreign help in prosecuting atrocities, while trying to restore order in a fractured country.
lead_paragraph: The rebels who seized control of Syria confronted the challenge on Wednesday of striking a balance between obtaining justice for the victims of atrocities committed under the ousted Assad regime and preventing the newly liberated country from descending into unchecked vengeance.

headline: What Is Extradition? Can Fighting It Help the Midtown Shooting Suspect?
abstract: Under the Constitution, states are obliged to hand over other states’ fugitives if requested. But the process can be challenged in court. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Before New York can put Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the killing of a health insurance executive on a Manhattan street, on trial for murder, it has to get him back in the state.

headline: Why Trump Soured on F.B.I. Director Christopher Wray
abstract: By the time Donald J. Trump left the White House, he was eager to fire Mr. Wray, but he held back. His antipathy only heightened in the years after his presidency.
lead_paragraph: The announcement by Christopher A. Wray on Wednesday that he would step down as F.B.I. director ends a turbulent relationship in which President-elect Donald J. Trump repeatedly denounced a law enforcement agency he could not control.

headline: New Friends After 50? Yes, Please!
abstract: The people in our lives are a dynamic constellation.
lead_paragraph: For many years I followed a no-new-friends ethos, one that became cemented in popular culture with the 2013 release of the track “No New Friends” by DJ Khaled, featuring Drake, Rick Ross and Lil Wayne.

headline: Promoter of ‘Stop the Steal’ Is Choice for Management and Budget Staff Chief
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump selected Ed Martin, a Missouri Republican with a long track record as an anti-abortion activist, for a top position in the agency that administers the budget.
lead_paragraph: Ed Martin, who has been chosen by President-elect Donald J. Trump to be the chief of staff for his Office of Management and Budget, is an anti-abortion activist who helped to organize the “Stop the Steal” movement to overturn the 2020 election for Mr. Trump.

headline: N.C. Elections Board Rejects G.O.P. Effort to Toss 60,000 Ballots
abstract: The ruling comes in a dispute over a State Supreme Court race that the Democratic incumbent won by 734 votes.
lead_paragraph: The North Carolina State Board of Elections rejected on Wednesday a Republican bid to throw out more than 60,000 votes in a closely contested election for a State Supreme Court seat that an incumbent Democrat won by 734 votes.

headline: F.B.I. Looks Into Plot Targeting Athletes as Joe Burrow’s Home Is Burglarized
abstract: The homes of a handful of N.B.A. and N.F.L. players in the Midwest have been burglarized since September. The F.B.I. believes “South American Theft Groups” could be responsible, according to one memo.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is investigating whether a transnational organized crime group may be responsible for a handful of recent burglaries at the homes of professional athletes in the Midwest, according to local police agencies and professional sports league memos.

headline: Labor Board Classifies ‘Love Is Blind’ Contestants as Employees
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board’s case against the Netflix hit could have ripple effects across the reality TV industry.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint against the hit reality show “Love Is Blind” on Wednesday in which it classified the show’s contestants as employees, opening a case that could have ripple effects across the reality television industry.

headline: Health Insurance Workers Fearful Amid Public Anger After Slaying of C.E.O.
abstract: Employees at UnitedHealthcare and other companies described being anxious after an outpouring of online vitriol.
lead_paragraph: The fatal shooting last week of an executive on the streets of New York City plunged his family members and colleagues into grief. For rank-and-file employees across the health insurance industry, the killing has left them with an additional emotion: fear, with many frightened for their own safety and feeling under attack for their work.

headline: Dean of Students at Massachusetts School Charged With Conspiring to Traffic Cocaine
abstract: Federal prosecutors said Lavante Wiggins of Pittsfield High School and another man had conspired to traffic “large quantities” of the drug in western Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The dean of students at a high school in western Massachusetts was arrested on Wednesday and charged with conspiring to traffic “large quantities of cocaine” after a nine-month investigation, federal authorities said.

headline: In Defiant Speech, South Korea’s President Defends Martial Law Decree
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol vowed to “fight to the end,” despite the opposition’s push to impeach him and his own party’s demand that he resign.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise shift from remorse to defiance, President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea on Thursday refused to step down and lashed out at those who sought to oust him over his short-lived decision to place his country under military rule.

headline: Drones, Dogs, Drug Labs: Canada’s Plan to Avoid Trump’s Tariffs Takes Shape
abstract: Two weeks after a Mar-a-Lago dinner with Donald J. Trump, details of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s plan to stave off a showdown with the United States are emerging.
lead_paragraph: Canada is working on a broad plan, including drones and police dogs, to address concerns raised by President-elect Donald J. Trump about the shared border between the two nations, underscoring the urgency of avoiding threatened tariffs that would send its economy into meltdown.

headline: Trump Considers Kennedy’s Daughter-in-Law for C.I.A. Deputy Director
abstract: Amaryllis Fox Kennedy, a former C.I.A. officer who is married to the son of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., raised alarms for publishing a book about her work at the agency without going through a review process.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is considering Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s daughter-in-law to serve as the deputy director at the C.I.A., according to four people briefed on the matter.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 12, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Wednesday about the poet Nikki Giovanni referred incorrectly to the people fatally shot by a student in 2007 at Virginia Tech, where Ms. Giovanni taught. He killed 33 people including himself, not 32; and his victims were students and faculty members, not just students.

headline: Serious Hang Time
abstract: Daniel Bodily’s puzzle will have you looking in all directions.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Quote of the Day: Israel, Seeing an Opportunity, Demolishes Syria’s Military Assets
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 12, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I’ve just watched dots all over the place — it’s been literally hundreds of attacks in the last 48 hours.”

headline: The Magic of Less ‘Holiday Magic’
abstract: Some people respond to the stress of the season by adopting a Marie Kondo approach: relinquishing the rituals that no longer bring them joy.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on Dec. 9, 2022.

headline: Ready for the Next Extreme-Weather Catastrophe? Here’s How to Pack a ‘Go Bag.’
abstract: If the trend continues, extreme weather will occur more frequently. Here’s how experts suggest you prepare.
lead_paragraph: Extreme weather is happening more frequently across the country, as we have seen this year with Hurricane Helene’s catastrophic impact on Asheville, N.C., November’s wildfires in New York and New Jersey and this month’s fast-spreading Malibu fire. Nearly 20 percent of all Americans have had to evacuate their homes because of unexpected severe weather, according to a new study by the analytics firm YouGov.

headline: Meta Donates $1 Million to Trump’s Inaugural Fund
abstract: The move follows a visit that Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, made last month to Mar-a-Lago to meet with President-elect Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Meta said on Wednesday that it had donated $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, in the latest move by Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, to foster a positive rapport with Mr. Trump.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: The latest from Syria.
lead_paragraph: The rebels who seized control of Syria must strike a balance between obtaining justice for the victims of atrocities committed under the ousted Assad regime and preventing the newly liberated country from descending into unchecked vengeance.

headline: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Is Sentenced to Nearly 2 Years in Federal Gun Case
abstract: The rapper, whose real name is Kentrell Gaulden, admitted to possessing guns as a felon in Louisiana. He faced a maximum sentence of 25 years.
lead_paragraph: YoungBoy Never Broke Again, one of the most-streamed hip-hop artists in the United States, has been sentenced to nearly two years in prison by a federal judge in Utah for possessing weapons as a felon.

headline: Trump Chooses Kari Lake to Lead Voice of America
abstract: Ms. Lake, a former TV news anchor turned right-wing firebrand who has called journalists “monsters,” would be in charge of a federally funded news outlet with a huge global audience.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday night chose Kari Lake to lead Voice of America, aiming to put a fierce loyalist who has called journalists “monsters” in charge of a federally funded news outlet that reaches hundreds of millions of people around the globe.

headline: Word of the Day: azure
abstract: This word has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word azure has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 18 in “California Mountain Towns Are Too Risky for Insurers, but Residents Want to Stay” by Soumya Karlamangla:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: How the Resurrected Congestion Pricing Plan Could Die in the Courts
abstract: Manhattan’s new tolling program is still being challenged in federal and state courts, with rulings possible before it begins on Jan. 5.
lead_paragraph: E-ZPass readers and cameras are in place to start New York City’s congestion pricing program on Jan. 5.

headline: N.Y.C. Grocery Prices Are High. Could City-Owned Stores Help?
abstract: A New York City mayoral candidate wants the city to open its own, more affordable grocery stores. The idea has gained momentum in Chicago and other cities.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that many Americans are worried about inflation and the high cost of groceries, and those concerns were a driving factor in Donald J. Trump’s victory.

headline: The Highs and Lows on London Stages in 2024
abstract: Our critics discuss which A-lister performances on the West End were worth the ticket price, and why so many new musicals struggled this year.
lead_paragraph: This year saw London host buzzy productions like Jamie Lloyd’s “Romeo and Juliet,” starring Tom Holland and Francesca Amewudah-Rivers, and Robert Icke’s take on “Oedipus,” with Mark Strong and Lesley Manville. Other productions struggled, including more star vehicles — and some musicals, particularly.

headline: An Article on Hysterectomies Asks What Might Have Been Lost
abstract: Rachel E. Gross, a health reporter, was used to asking tough questions, but here her reporting presented a new challenge: Some patients didn’t know which organs had been removed from their bodies.
lead_paragraph: I first heard Stacia Alexander share her hysterectomy experience in March 2023, on a panel hosted by the group Let’s Talk Menopause. I was stunned by her candor as she recounted being plunged into surgical menopause at the age of 45.

headline: Power, Intimidation and the Resurrection of Trump’s Support for Hegseth
abstract: The president-elect became convinced that letting Pete Hegseth fail would set off a feeding frenzy among senators. What followed was a MAGA swarm that helped salvage his bid, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: Just last week, Pete Hegseth was twisting in the wind.

headline: Will This Man Be New Jersey Transit’s ‘Train Daddy’?
abstract: Kris Kolluri, who until recently managed the project to build a $16 billion rail tunnel under the Hudson River to New York City, will become the agency’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Kris Kolluri has just been handed what may be the most thankless job in the transportation business: running New Jersey’s much-maligned transit agency.

headline: Stephen Colbert Is Surprised by Luigi Mangione’s ‘Minifesto’
abstract: “He could’ve just made it a Yelp review: ‘American health care sucks. One star,’” Colbert said of the content of a notebook found with the crime suspect.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Rights Groups See a Chance to Seek Justice for Syrian Regime’s Victims
abstract: It seems unlikely that deposed President Bashar al-Assad, who fled to Russia, will be forced to stand trial. That is not deterring activists who have worked for years to document his government’s crimes.
lead_paragraph: The fall of Syria’s government has breathed new life into a long push for justice over crimes committed by the Assad regime. Now, at last, there is a chance for human rights groups to inspect prison sites, freely interview witnesses and quickly build legal cases for prosecution.

headline: Bad News, Democrats: America Is About to Get Even Redder
abstract: Americans are fleeing unaffordable blue states — and they’re taking the Electoral College with them.
lead_paragraph: Americans are fleeing unaffordable blue states — and they’re taking the Electoral College with them.

headline: S.E. Hinton Leans on Dave Barry for Post-Election Comfort
abstract: “You can’t read a page without laughing,” says the author of “The Outsiders,” who’s watched the stage musical of the novel become a Tony Award-winning hit this year.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: A Black Art Dealer Lent Paintings to a Museum. His Heirs Want Them Back.
abstract: Dozens of artworks owned by Marshall Marcell have spent the past century with the Louisiana State Museum.
lead_paragraph: In its founding years in the early 20th century, the Louisiana State Museum borrowed dozens of artworks from Marshall Marcell, a successful African American art dealer in New Orleans, to hang on its almost empty walls. More than a century later, Marcell’s descendants say they want them back.

headline: Why Not Tell Someone They Look Great Today?
abstract: Don’t underestimate the simple power of complimenting a stranger.
lead_paragraph: One Monday morning a couple of weeks ago, I was riding the downtown local train to work when I noticed a woman slightly farther down the car in a perfect outfit. It wasn’t that there was anything showy about it — if memory serves, she wore green trousers, a button-down shirt, Mary Janes and a cropped tweed jacket — but the proportions were perfect. The ensemble had clearly been put together with thought and care.

headline: A Message for Girls About Womanhood
abstract: Girls would be less dispirited if more of them felt their intrinsic power.
lead_paragraph: Is being a woman really all that awful?

headline: Our Book Critics on Their Year in Reading
abstract: Jennifer Szalai, Dwight Garner and Alexandra Jacobs look back at the books that “offered refuge from the wheels grinding in our heads.”
lead_paragraph: This year’s best books mattered because they offered refuge from the wheels grinding in our heads. They made us feel less alone and reminded us that we are still sane.

headline: It’s Time to Talk About Pornography, Scholars Say
abstract: More adolescents than ever are watching it. What’s needed, researchers say, are frank conversations and “porn literacy.”
lead_paragraph: Brian Willoughby knows he’s doing a good job when parents become uncomfortable. That’s because part of his job involves telling them that their teenagers are looking at pornography — hard-core, explicit, often violent. Sometimes, the conversation is with a church group.

headline: His Daughter Went Missing in 1999. He Couldn’t Let It Go.
abstract: A father’s 25-year search for his missing daughter in South Korea made him a tragic national symbol of unwavering parental devotion.
lead_paragraph: The blue-and-yellow banners fluttering across South Korea showed a 17-year-old girl with gentle eyes and a neat bob, her smile frozen in time. The red letters beside her portrait cried out with an urgency that never dimmed for a quarter century.

headline: The C.E.O.s Are Tripping. Can Psychedelics Help the C-Suite?
abstract: A growing cottage industry is dedicated to the theory that mind-altering drugs can improve business leadership.
