lead_paragraph: Burrowed in the foothills of the Canadian Rockies is a wooden house, a retreat center made of pine and spruce and filled with mushroom carvings, tapestries of periwinkle and indigo paisley, books about “The Indoctrinated Brain” and other paraphernalia nodding to the promised transformation: Enter as a chief executive, emerge as an enlightened one.

headline: Best Art of 2024
abstract: This was a year whose high points included Joan Jonas’s luminous survey, the extravaganza “PST ART,” and the 24-karat beauty of a show “Siena: The Rise of Painting, 1300-1350.”
lead_paragraph: Art-wise, 2024 had an in-between-things vibe. It was a year of big-deal biennials, but the consensus was that none delivered much firepower. There was a lot of talk about money — what sold for what, and to whom — but no radically record-busting news. In general, the institutional art world veered, as it always does, between uplift (some strong museum shows) and cringe (the $6.2 million banana). I’ll go mostly with uplift in the (unranked) list of highlights below.

headline: Is Facial Hair the Last Taboo in Women’s Beauty?
abstract: Millions of women regularly remove it. Does it have to be that way?
lead_paragraph: The day before Rosemary Greenwood’s first wedding, in 1984, she sat in her backyard in the gleaming sun with a mirror and tweezers. For over two hours she plucked hairs off her face. “Not the way most brides spend the day before their wedding,” said Greenwood, 69. She had often considered bringing up her struggles with her facial hair with friends, but never mustered the courage. “Pretending that none of us had this issue, which of course was ridiculous. The silence made it shameful.”

headline: Is It Safe to Put Hot Food in the Fridge? And More Food Safety Questions, Answered
abstract: There’s a universal — and easy — answer to a common kitchen predicament.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a steamy pan of food that needs refrigerating — or six, on holidays and other feast days — we may find ourselves in an apparent predicament: Do we wait for the food to cool on the counter (and risk lingering too long at temperatures that let harmful bacteria proliferate)? Or do we rush it to the fridge, potentially warming everything inside?

headline: Birth Control’s (First) Civil War
abstract: In “The Icon and the Idealist,” Stephanie Gorton tells the story of two women who fought a patriarchal system — and each other.
lead_paragraph: In the days after Donald Trump’s election, abortion pill providers were inundated with orders for Mifepristone and Misoprostol.

headline: Could This Tiny School Break Down the Wall Between Church and State?
abstract: Officials in Oklahoma are laying the groundwork to push Christianity into public schools.
lead_paragraph: “We will bring God back to schools and prayer back in schools in Oklahoma,” Ryan Walters told an audience at a Family Research Council meeting in September last year. The state’s superintendent for public instruction, Walters was appearing at a panel discussion titled “Strategies for Saving America’s Schools and School Children.” Less than 10 years earlier, it would have been hard to envision his transformation into today’s culture warrior. He had been a finalist for the state’s teacher-of-the-year award, a beloved U.S.-history and Advanced Placement world-history instructor in a public school, one who would tweet about his classroom assignments such as “Re-enacting the Debate on Indian Removal in 1824.” Now, at the F.R.C. panel, he called the constitutional separation of church and state a “myth” and a creation of the United States Supreme Court.

headline: In Milei’s Argentina, Economic Albatross Is Tamed but Life Is Much Harder
abstract: A year after becoming president, Javier Milei has been praised inside and outside Argentina for reining in galloping inflation. But his economic policies have inflicted widespread hardship.
lead_paragraph: At home and abroad, Argentina’s president, Javier Milei, is a man with plenty of fans. And not just any fans.

headline: Read This Before Buying That Video Game
abstract: Big corporations turned video games from an engaging artistic medium into something addictive and gambling-adjacent.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child in the 1990s, I began my campaign for my first video game console several months before Christmas. My parents, like some parents who came before them and most who came after, were wary. They associated video games not so much with the thrilling secrets of Super Mario’s undulating hills or the literary flair of Infocom’s interactive fiction games, but instead with vague ideas of truancy, delinquency and probable ruin. My grandmother, a pragmatic woman, took pity. She secreted under the tree a Game Boy and a copy of the Soviet-era miracle that is Tetris.

headline: ‘Endless Summer Syndrome’ Review: Who’s Lying?
abstract: In this sun-dappled French psychological thriller, a lawyer receives a call accusing her husband of having an affair with one of their children.
lead_paragraph: Every year there seems to be a new book or movie on the subject of incest in France — most recently Catherine Breillat’s “Last Summer.” Extending from this tradition, in which a sunny French bourgeois family is secretly rotting from the inside, is “Endless Summer Syndrome,” a promising debut feature by the Iranian director Kaveh Daneshmand that frames the crime as a twisty detective story.

headline: ‘Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim’ Review: Side Quest
abstract: This anime adaptation, drawn from Tolkien’s appendices, focuses on a shield maiden, but mostly it serves as an excuse to revisit Middle-earth.
lead_paragraph: There’s something so tantalizing about discovering the story within a story — the old tale, the side quest or the bit of lore that is relegated to a brief mention or note. Or, possibly, to a reference in the appendix. That’s the case in “The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim,” a hot-and-cold anime adaptation of a tale mentioned in the appendices of “The Lord of the Rings.”

headline: ‘Nickel Boys’ Review: Childhood’s Brutal End
abstract: This visually inventive adaptation of a Colson Whitehead novel follows two boys at an abusive school in Jim Crow-era Florida.
lead_paragraph: The first time that you clearly and truly see the teenage heartbreaker in “Nickel Boys,” he is walking up to a new friend. Elwood (Ethan Herisse) has just arrived at the fictional reform school referenced in the title when he sits down opposite Turner (Brandon Wilson) at a communal table. They’re in a large dining room crowded with children of varying sizes, shapes and bearings, and while some seem to be on the cusp of manhood, many look too obscenely young to be here. Their chatter and laughter obscures the horrors of this place. You only need to look closer to see that some of these children are already ghosts.

headline: How to Resurrect a Radical Artist
abstract: Forty years after his death, the Californian activist Peter Carr gets a revival of his acerbic paintings and drawings. To make it happen, his protégé spent both labor and love.
lead_paragraph: Canvas burns quickly, so when a wildfire spread through Orange County, Calif., this summer, Andrew Tonkovich, a writer and editor, crammed some paintings into the bed of a pickup and sped down a mountain to safety.

headline: Tired of Swiping Left? Here Are the Best U.S. Cities for Singles.
abstract: A recent study ranked large U.S. cities on the quality of dating life. A city in the South came out on top.
lead_paragraph: Tired of swiping left? Perhaps it’s time to relocate. A new study by WalletHub scrolls through the best and worst American cities based on their “dating friendliness.”

headline: Help Yourself! How Readers Fought the Travel Industry and Won.
abstract: You don’t always need professional help to make things right after a travel snafu. Here are four ways readers got refunds and resolutions on their own.
lead_paragraph: Who needs you? After we first connected, you said you’d take on my problem. But while you dawdled working on other travelers’ issues, I got my money back from that dastardly airline/travel site/car rental agency on my own. Sam Q. Traveler, Everywhere

headline: In a Rudderless Europe, Italy Has Its Moment
abstract: With Germany and France mired in crisis, the government of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni looks like a haven of stability, turning the continent’s usual pattern on its head.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s biggest economies are in turmoil. France’s government fell last week. Germany is facing a snap election after a fragile coalition collapsed. Financial markets are nervous and E.U. authorities are worried.

headline: 36 Hours in Venice
abstract: Winter — with its famous fogs and reduced crowds — provides breathing room and deepens the mysteriousness of Venice’s narrow passageways and centuries-old buildings.
lead_paragraph: Winter — with its famous fogs and reduced crowds — provides breathing room and deepens the mysteriousness of Venice’s narrow passageways and centuries-old buildings.

headline: Bad News, Democrats: America Is About to Get Even Redder
abstract: Americans are fleeing unaffordable blue states — and they’re taking the Electoral College with them.
lead_paragraph: Every year, millions of Americans bounce around the country like electrons, moving from one state to another. But there are patterns in this chaos, and one of the clearest in recent decades is that Americans are moving from blue states to red states. As the Opinion video above explains, that has some big political implications for the Democrats.

headline: The Couple Living and Working in a Holiday ‘Emerald City’
abstract: Each year, Emily Eerdmans, a design historian, and her husband, Andrew McKeon, an environmentalist, transform their rented Manhattan duplex apartment into a freewheeling holiday bazaar.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Emily Eerdmans and her husband, Andrew McKeon, were living in a rented Brooklyn Heights garden apartment with low ceilings. They both worked from home: His office was very small, with a door. Her office was the ivory damask sofa in the living room — a perch she described as the “ideal backdrop for my needlepoint pillow collection.”

headline: Young Koreans, Seeing Democracy at Stake, Take to the Streets
abstract: South Korea’s night of martial law was a jolt for some members of a generation accused of political apathy. They say they aren’t going away.
lead_paragraph: Lee Suyoon, a 20-year-old student, was at home just outside of Seoul on Dec. 3, sharing late-night fried chicken dinner with her mother when her phone started buzzing. A flurry of messages from her friends alerted her that martial law had been declared in South Korea and soldiers were breaking into the National Assembly.

headline: Best Art Books of 2024
abstract: The art critics of The Times select their favorites, from the biography of a “famously unknown” artist to an ode to the Louvre from 100 poets.
lead_paragraph: Say what you will about digital futures, print still rules when it comes to art books. And 2024 has brought us a batch of hold-in-your-hand beauties. They include a souvenir document of a highlight show from this year’s Venice Biennale; a jumbo compendium of architectural projects never (often for good reason) realized,  a bouquet of tributes to a much-loved gallerist and a book-length exit interview with a veteran art critic: page-turners all. HOLLAND COTTER

headline: How to Talk to Your Teen About Pornography
abstract: Odds are your adolescent has already encountered online pornography. Your role is to openly address it, scholars say.
lead_paragraph: The average American first sees online pornography at age 12, and nearly three-quarters of all teenagers have encountered it, according to a 2023 survey of adolescents by Common Sense. It’s enough to make most any parent squirm, but Brian Willoughby, a social scientist at Brigham Young University who studies the pornography habits of adolescents and the impact on relationships, has some advice: “Don’t panic.” Instead, he says, help your child understand that “this is a normal and acceptable topic, even if you’re stressed out.” Here are some suggestions for how to broach the subject:

headline: The Whitney Is Now Free for Those 25 and Under
abstract: The painter Julie Mehretu donated $2 million to the art museum to encourage young people to visit.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out about the Whitney Museum’s plan to expand free admission to those 25 and under. We’ll also get details on a new state law requiring insurance companies to pay for testing for dyslexia.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s Cabinet Picks
abstract: Linda Qiu, a New York Times reporter, fact-checks some claims by three of President-elect Donald Trump’s cabinet picks: Pete Hegseth, Tulsi Gabbard and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
lead_paragraph: Linda Qiu, a New York Times reporter, fact-checks some claims by three of President-elect Donald Trump’s cabinet picks: Pete Hegseth, Tulsi Gabbard and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Midtown, on the Upper West Side and in Parkchester.
lead_paragraph: A 603-square-foot studio apartment with white oak floors and cabinets, marble countertops, a double vanity, radiant-heat bathroom floors, a dishwasher, a garbage disposal, a washer/dryer, central air-conditioning and Juliet balconies, on the seventh floor of a 29-story new development with a doorman, a resident manager, a concierge, a roof deck with a pool and cabanas, a spa, a salon, a gym and a private restaurant. Jade Chan, Alexander Boriskin and McKenzie Ryan, Douglas Elliman, 929-751-6900; elliman.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Dobbs Ferry and a six-bedroom in Moorestown, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 2,717-square-foot house dating to 1895, with an enclosed front porch offering Hudson River and Palisades views, a formal living room with built-ins and a fireplace with a wood-burning stove insert, a formal dining room with a coffered ceiling, a kitchen with a breakfast area, an office, a primary bedroom suite with a terrace, a mudroom, 440 square feet of finished attic space, a grassy backyard with a stone patio, and a one-car garage, on a 0.52-acre corner lot in the Riverview Manor section of Dobbs Ferry. Patty Anker, Julia B. Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, 917-543-3966; williampitt.com

headline: What Trump Could Do to the U.S. Military
abstract: Americans have counted on the indispensability of a constitutionally alert military. Will that continue?
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump and members of his transition team have reportedly considered plans to fire Gen. C.Q. Brown, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and senior officers connected to former Gen. Mark Milley, and to potentially ensure the promotion of senior officers based on their personal loyalty to the president. These would be radical moves, well outside the boundaries of standard Pentagon procedures.

headline: Humbled in Syria, Putin Seeks Vindication in Ukraine
abstract: An ally’s downfall has prompted calls in Russia for a definitive victory closer to home.
lead_paragraph: The downfall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has humiliated his main backer, Russia, exposing the limits of the Kremlin’s military power and global influence.

headline: What the Glorification of Luigi Mangione Reveals About America
abstract: The shooting of Brian Thompson marks a new era of rage for this country.
lead_paragraph: The political scientist Robert A. Pape has studied political violence for the past 30 years. In this episode of “The Opinions,” he describes what his research illuminates about the homicide of United Healthcare’s chief executive, Brian Thompson. Pape also explains why he is not surprised by the background of Luigi Mangione, who has been charged with the killing.

headline: The Figure Skater Who Treats the Rink as a Runway
abstract: Madison Chock has earned a reputation for ice dancing in costumes as dazzling as her performances.
lead_paragraph: The Chrysler Building. Salvador Dalí. Billie Eilish. Aliens. All have inspired costumes worn by the figure skater Madison Chock, who is known not only for intricate twizzles and lifts but also for competing in ensembles that have raised the bar for fashion in her sport. Almost all of her costumes over the last two decades have been designed by Ms. Chock herself.

headline: On a Treadmill
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: This is what 4 of Trump’s agency picks think of the departments they would lead.
abstract: Pete Hegseth, Tulsi Gabbard, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Kash Patel have been fierce critics of the agencies they are in line to oversee.
lead_paragraph: Pete Hegseth, Tulsi Gabbard, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Kash Patel have been fierce critics of the agencies they are in line to oversee.

headline: How Do You Stay Focused on an Important Task?
abstract: Do you find it hard to concentrate? What can we learn from a Formula 1 driver’s mental tool kit?
lead_paragraph: Are you easily distracted? When you have a homework assignment to complete, a book to read, an instrument to practice or a room to clean, is it easy for you to stay focused and do it, or does your mind wander so that you often end up performing the task poorly?

headline: Three Columnists Wrestle With the Lionizing of Luigi Mangione
abstract: What other kind of company inspires this sort of hatred?
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Michelle Goldberg, Tressie McMillan Cottom and Zeynep Tufekci about the reaction and backlash to the killing of UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson and the murder charge against a suspect, Luigi Mangione.

headline: A Swiss Ski Chalet That Calls to Mind a Spy Movie
abstract: Plus: a Muji designer’s museum show, deodorant inspired by “The Iliad” and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: If evil villains skied, this cliffhanging lair in Switzerland’s Canton Valais would top their bucket list. From the outside, the new exclusive-use, three-bedroom property opening Dec. 15 looks more like a gondola station than it does a luxury chalet. The geometric fortress of concrete, galvanized steel, chimneys and solar panels sits solitary on a rocky ridge atop the ancient Tortin Glacier at an elevation of 9,500 feet. Its cantilevered glass windows reflect the surrounding pink alpenglow and bluebird skies that the 4 Vallées Ski area — Switzerland’s largest, including Verbier — is known for. Inside, the mind-clearing Scandinavian minimalism of the Norwegian architect Snorre Stinessen focuses on the elements with a blond wood grain ceiling, sauna and log fireplace. The ski-in, ski-out accessibility is off-piste, ensuring discreet and quick getaways. But fear not: Dog sleds and caterpillar-tracked buggies for those less active can be arranged by the staff, as can wine-pairing meals, massages and an emergency oxygen supply, just in case the plan for world domination fails. From about $68,000 for three nights for six people with full board; when not occupied, a self-catering option is available from about $2,260 per night, cabanetortin.com.

headline: New Federal Rule Limits Overdraft Fees at Large Banks
abstract: It is unclear whether the rule, which could help save Americans billions in fees each year, will remain in place after President-elect Donald J. Trump returns to office.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau finalized a rule on Thursday that would limit overdraft charges at large banks and credit unions, a move that federal officials said could help save Americans billions in fees each year.

headline: Biden Has a Pair of Gifts for Trump
abstract: What will the president-elect do with them?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is a lucky man.

headline: How America Created the Enemy It Feared Most
abstract: The United States killed its own allies, sabotaging itself in a part of Afghanistan where it never needed to be.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban war hero scans the crowd, searching. From the back, he snatches a man with a flop of dusty hair and a face marred by shrapnel.

headline: What I Learned From a Reclusive Taliban Commander
abstract: Mullah Osman Jawhari led one of the deadliest assaults on American forces in Afghanistan, a battle that came to symbolize the war itself.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban commander wore sunglasses and a heavy wool coat, as if he might leave at any moment. Between us, on a plastic-covered table doused in fluorescent light, sat an untouched mountain of lamb and rice.

headline: Biden Commutes the Sentences of 1,500 Americans, a Record for One Day
abstract: Most of those being granted clemency had been placed in home confinement during the pandemic. Some Republicans have tried to push legislation that would have forced those people to return to prison.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Thursday that he is commuting the sentences of nearly 1,500 people and pardoning 39 people convicted of nonviolent crimes in a sweeping act of clemency during his final weeks in office.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 551
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,273
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Watch: ‘Is Creativity Dead?”
abstract: Is internet culture killing our creativity? Or, are powerful algorithms just hiding it?
lead_paragraph: Note: This is the last Film and Podcast Club of 2024. Be sure to join us when we return in the new year on Jan. 9.

headline: How China Hacked America’s Phone Network
abstract: It’s an alarming new breach, and its scope demonstrates the growing power of one of the United States’ biggest adversaries.
lead_paragraph: An alarming new hack by China has penetrated the nerve center of the United States: its telephone network.

headline: F.B.I. Chief to Step Out of ‘the Fray,’ and Housing’s Terrible Year
abstract: Plus, a labor fight that could upend reality TV.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: C.E.O.s Are Tripping
abstract: Why executives are using psychedelics to get ahead.
lead_paragraph: Psychedelic drugs have come a long way. They once belonged to the counterculture (“tune in, drop out”). Now they are finding a home in the C-suite.

headline: ‘The Man in the White Van’ Review: Sleazy Rider
abstract: In this derivative thriller, set in the early 1970s, young women are stalked by an anonymous killer.
lead_paragraph: “The Man in the White Van,” loosely based on the exploits of the Florida killer Billy Mansfield Jr., is a flaccid and formulaic thriller more beholden to horror-movie conventions than those of true crime.

headline: ‘Young Werther’ Review: Updating an 18th-Century Love Triangle
abstract: This charming film, starring Douglas Booth and Alison Pill, bridges the gap between Goethe’s novel and the adaptation’s modern city setting.
lead_paragraph: There is a boisterously nimble quality to the way in which Douglas Booth plays the titular character of “Young Werther.”

headline: Russian Troops Advance to Within 3 Miles of Key Ukrainian Transit Hub
abstract: Russia is pushing toward Pokrovsk, a strategic city for Ukraine’s army with important rail and road connections, in a rapid capturing of ground in the Donetsk region.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s top general said on Thursday that his troops were facing “extremely fierce” fighting as Russian forces close in on the strategic eastern city of Pokrovsk, and that “unconventional decisions” would have to be made to bolster Ukrainian defenses.

headline: Man Found in Syria Appears to Be a Missing American
abstract: The man told reporters that his name was Travis Timmerman and that he had entered Syria on a religious pilgrimage. He said he had been detained for months.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s new authorities said on Thursday that an American citizen who had been imprisoned while Bashar al-Assad was in power had been found outside Damascus and handed over to the rebel group that now controls the capital.

headline: She Invested in Her Future and Her Family. Which Property Would Work for Both?
abstract: Seeking an income-generating home and a place for her brother to potentially live, a New Yorker scanned the Bronx, Westchester and southern Connecticut for the perfect spot.
lead_paragraph: Seeking an income-generating home and a place for her brother to potentially live, a New Yorker scanned the Bronx, Westchester and southern Connecticut for the perfect spot.

headline: China Pledges More Stimulus to Shore Up Flagging Economy
abstract: At a meeting to set the party’s economic policy agenda, China’s leadership said it would borrow more and cut interest rates in a bid to bolster growth.
lead_paragraph: China’s top leaders on Thursday pledged more stimulus measures to shore up the country’s economy, building on steps they have taken in recent months to bolster growth.

headline: Donald Trump Is Time Magazine’s Person of the Year
abstract: Mr. Trump also received the title in 2016, after his first presidential election victory. He has had a tempestuous relationship with the publication.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump, who has both derided Time magazine and pined for its approval, was named the publication’s person of the year on Thursday.

headline: Remembering David Bonderman, a Private Equity Pioneer
abstract: A former lawyer, he cofounded the giant investment firm TPG and became known for complex deals that remade corporate America. He died on Wednesday at 82.
lead_paragraph: David Bonderman, a corporate lawyer who co-founded the giant investment firm TPG and helped transform private equity into a multitrillion-dollar industry that reshaped Wall Street, died on Wednesday morning. He was 82.

headline: European Central Bank Cuts Interest Rates as the Economy Weakens
abstract: The bank has been lowering rates since June as inflation slowed, but other risks are growing, including the threat of higher tariffs promised by President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank lowered interest rates on Thursday, the fourth cut this year amid growing concerns that the region’s economic outlook is darkening.

headline: BuzzFeed Strikes Deal to Sell ‘Hot Ones’ Company for $82.5 Million
abstract: The sale, to a group that includes the show’s host, Sean Evans, and Soros Fund Management, will allow BuzzFeed to pay down tens of millions of dollars in debt.
lead_paragraph: BuzzFeed on Thursday said it had reached a deal to sell the company behind the popular interview show “Hot Ones” for $82.5 million, easing a cash crunch that has loomed over the media company for months.

headline: Trump Says His 1st Acts Will Include Deportations and Jan. 6 Pardons
abstract: In a wide-ranging Time magazine interview, President-elect Donald J. Trump said he might supporting getting rid of some childhood vaccines if data shows links to autism.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said in a new interview that he will use the opening hours of his presidency to pardon people convicted of participating in the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol assault, begin deportations of undocumented immigrants and increase oil production.

headline: The Most Memorable Wines of 2024
abstract: The scarcity and fragility of rare old bottles makes them naturally memorable, but these 12 younger wines had their own unforgettable charms.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had the privilege of drinking some wonderful wines this year, including a few rare, breathtakingly gorgeous old bottles.

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Informant Agrees to Plead Guilty to Lying About Bidens
abstract: Alexander Smirnov’s deal with the special counsel overseeing the investigation into Hunter Biden could lead to 48 to 72 months in prison, though a federal judge would need to review the deal.
lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. informant accused of fabricating a claim that President Biden and his son Hunter were each paid a $5 million bribe by a Ukrainian oligarch has agreed to plead guilty to a range of federal charges, according to a court filing on Thursday.

headline: Ev Williams Was Lonely. He Doesn’t Want You to Be.
abstract: The serial internet entrepreneur, who co-founded Twitter and created Medium, was turning 50 and feeling detached from friends. Maybe a new start-up could fix that.
lead_paragraph: Evan Williams did not want to start another start-up. He had already enjoyed the kind of rare, unfathomable success most entrepreneurs only dream of, starting tech companies that made products used by millions — the early blogging site Blogger, the social media giant Twitter, the publishing platform Medium.

headline: A Symbol of India’s Global Soft Power Stumbles After U.S. Indictments
abstract: Countries in Asia, Africa and elsewhere have been distancing themselves from Gautam Adani, the Indian magnate, after accusations of bribery and conspiracy by American prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Hours after U.S. officials indicted Gautam Adani, one of India’s most successful businessmen, on fraud and conspiracy charges, Kenya’s president publicly backed away from lucrative infrastructure deals with Mr. Adani’s companies to overhaul Nairobi’s international airport and the country’s electricity grid.

headline: How Covid Can Change Your Gut
abstract: Diarrhea, constipation, pain, bloating: We asked experts why the virus causes these issues and what to do about them.
lead_paragraph: Food used to be a daily source of joy for Sarah Carter. A self-described “vegetable head” in San Mateo, Calif., she loved perusing farmers’ markets, tending her garden, cooking elaborate meals and exploring Bay Area restaurants.

headline: Victor Brombert, Princeton Scholar With a Secret Army Past, Dies at 101
abstract: As a Jewish teen, he fled the Nazis for America — then landed at D-Day and swept across Europe in a unit that gathered intelligence. Its work was hidden for decades.
lead_paragraph: Victor Brombert, a respected scholar of comparative literature who late in life revealed that he had worked for a secret American intelligence program in World War II, which took him to D-Day, the liberation of Paris and the Battle of the Bulge, died on Nov. 26 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 101.

headline: Perfect Instant Ramen
abstract: That’s what you get when you add an egg, a pat of butter and a slice or two of American cheese to a bowl of steaming noodles.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, I asked a bunch of chefs and food personalities about their favorite instant ramen for New York Magazine’s The Strategist. Lucas Kwan Peterson, the former food columnist for The Los Angeles Times, astutely pointed out that “there’s usually (but not always) a direct correlation between the number of sachets of different things — oils, sauces, powders, dried veggies — included in a package and how good it is. The more, the better!”

headline: Activist Who Told the World About Torture in Syria Is Laid to Rest
abstract: Mazen al-Hamada spread the word about the plight of Syrians and his own abuse in the Assad regime’s prisons. He was found dead in Syria this week.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Syrian pro-democracy activist known for alerting the world to torture that he and other detainees experienced at the hands of the Assad regime did not survive to celebrate the government’s fall.

headline: A Visual Tour of ‘Oh, Mary!,’ Broadway’s Hit Comedy
abstract: Cole Escola stars as a self-involved Mary Todd Lincoln who dreams of becoming a cabaret star. Here’s how the creative team came up with the show’s aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: Cole Escola stars as a self-involved Mary Todd Lincoln who dreams of becoming a cabaret star. Here’s how the creative team came up with the show’s aesthetic.

headline: Blinken Appeals for Unity Behind New Syrian Government
abstract: The secretary of state said the goal of visits to Jordan and Turkey was to unite countries behind a peaceful transition.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Thursday that his goal during a trip to Jordan and Turkey was to unite countries in the region behind a peaceful transition to a new Syrian government after the fall of the Assad regime.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Elfin Magic
abstract: Are all elves magical? Or just some?
lead_paragraph: Jessie writes: This dispute arose during a game of 20 Questions: Does Legolas from “The Lord of the Rings” use magic? I say no. He has inherent elfin capabilities, such as a keen sense of sight and agility — like how birds have hollow bones for flight. My partners believe all elves are magical. One fancies themself an expert because they read “The Silmarillion.”

headline: A New Female Designer Takes Center Stage
abstract: Bottega Veneta announced that Louise Trotter will replace Matthieu Blazy as creative director.
lead_paragraph: In the fashion equivalent of a nuclear chain reaction, Bottega Veneta announced on Thursday that Matthieu Blazy, its designer of three years and the man who made it into a must-see brand in Milan, was leaving the house. He is expected to become the new designer of Chanel.

headline: The Furor Over Health Insurance in America
abstract: Readers discuss the anger over health insurance set off by the killing of a C.E.O. Also: Gun safety laws; money in politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Dirty Angels’ Review: Women on a Mission
abstract: In this heavy-handed action movie, Eva Green plays a Marine who leads a squad trying to rescue schoolgirls in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The action thriller “Dirty Angels” — a fictional story about a group of soldiers who set out to rescue kidnapped schoolgirls in Afghanistan held hostage by members of the Islamic State, or ISIS — suffers from the discord between the real-life conflicts that make up its setting and the cartoonish characters who propel its plot.

headline: How U.S. Firms Battled a Government Crackdown to Keep Tech Sales to China
abstract: An intense struggle has unfolded in Washington between companies and officials over where to draw the line on selling technology to China.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting in Washington this spring, tech company representatives and government officials once again found themselves at odds over where to draw the line when it came to selling coveted technology to China.

headline: The Geminids Meteor Shower Is Peaking. Here’s How to Watch.
abstract: The shower forms from the debris of an asteroid and peaks this weekend. But a nearly full moon could interfere with viewing.
lead_paragraph: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can observe only a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.

headline: Take a Whiff of Eau de Trump. It Reeks.
abstract: Like Trump himself, Trump’s new line of fragrances is big on braggadocio, short on details and gaudily packaged.
lead_paragraph: If you could smell like any U.S. president, who would it be?

headline: Musk’s Foundation Gave Away Less Money Than Required in 2023
abstract: Private foundations must donate 5 percent of their assets every year. Elon Musk’s enormous charity missed that standard for three consecutive years.
lead_paragraph: For the third year in a row, Elon Musk’s charitable foundation did not give away enough of its money.

headline: Trump’s Middle East Adviser Pick Is a Small-Time Truck Salesman
abstract: The lore around Massad Boulos, Tiffany Trump’s father-in-law, is that he is a billionaire dealmaker. Records show otherwise.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump’s incoming Middle East adviser, Massad Boulos, has enjoyed a reputation as a billionaire mogul at the helm of a business that bears his family name.

headline: Defying Veto Threat, House Approves Measure Adding 66 New U.S. Judges
abstract: President Biden and House Democrats objected to the bipartisan measure that would immediately give President-elect Donald J. Trump about two dozen new judicial seats to fill.
lead_paragraph: The House on Thursday brushed off a veto threat from President Biden and approved legislation that would create 66 new federal district court seats over the next decade, moving over the opposition of Democrats who were unwilling to hand President-elect Donald J. Trump the power to name more judges.

headline: Chanel Fills the Hottest Job in Fashion
abstract: Matthieu Blazy is getting the coveted post. Here’s how it went down.
lead_paragraph: The hottest job in fashion has finally been filled. After six months without an artistic director, Chanel, the second largest luxury fashion brand in the world and the only couture house in the top three, has named a new designer: Matthieu Blazy. Most recently the man behind Bottega Veneta, Mr. Blazy will be in charge of all fashion, couture and accessories for Chanel, creating 10 collections a year. He will make his debut next October during the Paris shows.

headline: Minnesota and New Jersey Sue Glock Over Lethal Add-On for Guns
abstract: The two suits claim the company’s leaders have known for decades that significant design characteristics of the weapon make it susceptible to conversion to a machine gun.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota and New Jersey sued Glock on Thursday over the design of its iconic 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol, claiming that the company had failed to make changes to prevent its easy conversion to a deadly, illegal machine gun.

headline: Selena Gomez and Benny Blanco Announce Their Engagement. The Internet Rejoices.
abstract: The couple, who have been publicly discussing their relationship for a year, were deluged with congratulations on social media.
lead_paragraph: The actor and singer Selena Gomez announced her engagement to Benny Blanco, the record producer and songwriter, in a social media post Wednesday night, and Taylor Swift, one of Gomez’s closest friends, quickly offered to be her flower girl.

headline: The Benefits and Risks of Fluoride, Explained
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has said he wants to curb water fluoridation nationwide. Here’s what the science shows.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s skepticism about fluoride has become a focal point in the debate about whether he’s suitable to run the nation’s health department.

headline: Prosecutors in Three States Press Ahead with Election Interference Cases
abstract: The cases, which stem from efforts to keep Donald J. Trump in office after his 2020 loss, are proceeding even as Mr. Trump prepares to return to the White House.
lead_paragraph: In a flurry of moves on Thursday, state prosecutors made clear that they are pressing forward with criminal cases against Donald J. Trump and his allies related to interference in the 2020 election.

headline: F.A.A. Administrator Will Resign Before Trump Takes Office
abstract: Mike Whitaker, who runs the Federal Aviation Administration, is leaving the leadership position after serving only one year of a five-year term.
lead_paragraph: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration, Mike Whitaker, announced on Thursday that he is stepping down at the end of the President Biden’s term, leaving the agency without crucial leadership as ongoing safety challenges and questions about oversight of Boeing persist.

headline: Trump’s Choice to Run Energy Says Fossil Fuels Are Virtuous
abstract: Chris Wright, Donald Trump’s pick for energy secretary, says oil, gas and coal are key to solving global poverty. Some call that misleading.
lead_paragraph: Chris Wright, the fracking magnate and likely next U.S. energy secretary, makes a moral case for fossil fuels.

headline: How to Stir the Pot With Your Family (in a Good Way)
abstract: Vegetarian lasagna Bolognese, hand-pulled noodles and pupusas welcome extra helping hands.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone! Mia here, filling in for Tanya this week.

headline: Why Do Some Rebel Governments Last When Others Fall?
abstract: One factor matters most, and it could be a problem in Syria.
lead_paragraph: In Syria, “forever” is over.  The regime of former President Bashar al-Assad, whose supporters once chanted “our leader forever,”  has been deposed by an alliance of rebel groups after a 13-year civil war.

headline: Mayor Adams Meets Trump’s ‘Border Czar’ as Immigration Crackdown Looms
abstract: Thomas D. Homan, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s designated border czar, has cited Eric Adams’s willingness to work together as a model for Democratic mayors.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams met on Thursday with President-elect Donald J. Trump’s incoming “border czar,” Thomas D. Homan, the mayor’s first sit-down meeting with a top Trump administration designee as New York City braces for an immigration crackdown.

headline: Why Some British Pubs Are Running Out of Guinness
abstract: Guinness’s parent company has limited the amount of the beer that U.K. wholesalers and distributors can buy each week, after surging demand led to fears of shortages.
lead_paragraph: British pubs are facing something of a crisis: They cannot get enough Guinness.

headline: F.B.I. Didn’t Instruct Informants to Encourage Violence at Capitol, Report Says
abstract: The review acknowledged that several informants were in Washington on Jan. 6, but said that only a handful were collecting information for the F.B.I. that day, contrary to conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: More than two dozen F.B.I. informants were in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021, but contrary to widespread conspiracy theories, bureau officials did not order anyone to break the law as a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol that day, according to a report by a Justice Department watchdog released on Thursday.

headline: ‘September 5’ Review: When the Munich Games Changed Our News
abstract: Tim Fehlbaum’s journalism procedural, starring Peter Sarsgaard, tracks the broadcast coverage of the terrorist attack at the 1972 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: A tense ethical showdown with the racing pulse of a thriller, “September 5” revisits the day in 1972 when the Munich Olympics became a very different kind of international spectacle. Before dawn that morning, while many of the world’s elite athletes were still sleeping in the Olympic Village or drunkenly heading for bed, eight heavily armed members of Black September, a militant Palestinian group, easily scrambled over a perimeter fence in the village. They quickly made their way to the building where the Israeli delegation was housed and took 11 of its members hostage, shooting two men, who soon died.

headline: F.T.C. Sues Largest U.S. Alcohol Distributor for Illegal Pricing
abstract: The suit, under a long-dormant antitrust law, accuses Southern Glazer’s of charging small businesses “drastically” more than big chains.
lead_paragraph: With just six weeks left in office, the Biden administration announced a new push, using an old law, to crack down on anticompetitive business practices.

headline: Rebel Group’s Terrorist Label Could Hinder Efforts to Aid Syria
abstract: The United States and others call Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, now taking power in Syria, a terrorist group, blocking funding and even contact with the group. Experts say that should change.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, world leaders likely were not thinking about Hayat Tahrir al-Sham and its designation as a terrorist organization. But now, the rebel faction that drove a surprise offensive that toppled the Assad regime is Syria’s de facto government.

headline: Dommaraju Gukesh, 18, Becomes Youngest World Chess Champion
abstract: It had been an unexpectedly close contest in Singapore with Ding Liren. When he won, the normally stoic Gukesh clasped his hands at the board and burst into tears.
lead_paragraph: Dommaraju Gukesh, an 18-year-old Indian grandmaster, captured the World Chess Championship in Singapore on Thursday by winning the last game of his match against the reigning champion, Ding Liren of China. In so doing, Gukesh became the 18th and youngest undisputed world champion in history.

headline: A ‘Second Tree of Life’ Could Wreak Havoc, Scientists Warn
abstract: Research on so-called mirror cells, which defy fundamental properties of living organisms, should be prohibited as too dangerous, biologists said.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, 38 prominent biologists issued a dire warning: Within a few decades, scientists will be able create a microbe that could cause an unstoppable pandemic, devastating crop losses or the collapse of entire ecosystems.

headline: Ocean Heat Wiped Out Half These Seabirds Around Alaska
abstract: About four million common murres were killed by a domino effect of ecosystem changes, and the population is showing no signs of recovery, according to new research.
lead_paragraph: The first evidence was the feathered bodies washing up on Alaskan beaches. They were common murres, sleek black-and-white seabirds that typically spend months at a time away from land. But in 2015 and 2016, officials tallied 62,000 emaciated corpses from California to Alaska.

headline: Superflares Erupt From Stars Like Our Sun Once Every 100 Years
abstract: New findings suggest that an extraordinarily powerful and dangerous burst of radiation might flare from our sun in the future.
lead_paragraph: Our sun is a violent place. Bursts of radiation snap off the solar surface with the strength of millions of volcanic eruptions. Hot plasma churns and spews, streaming particles that can harm astronauts and satellites in space and damage electrical systems on the ground. They can also brighten up our skies with colorful lights.

headline: Overlooked No More: Fidelia Bridges, Artist Who Captured the Natural World
abstract: A prolific artist, she was known for her graceful watercolors of birds, plants and butterflies, and was considered as the equal of Winslow Homer in her day.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Oldest Human Genomes Reveal How a Small Group Burst Out of Africa
abstract: DNA from European fossils dating back 45,000 years offers new clues to how our species spread across the world.
lead_paragraph: Some 45,000 years ago, a tiny group of people — fewer than 1,000, all told — wandered the icy northern fringes of Europe. Across thousands of miles of tundra, they hunted woolly rhinoceros and other big game. Their skin was most likely dark. To keep warm in the bone-chilling temperatures, they probably wore the hides and furs of the animals they killed.

headline: Patel’s Warm Senate Welcome Reflects the G.O.P.’s Turn Against the F.B.I.
abstract: Senate Republicans have largely embraced President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to run the bureau, demonstrating that his anti-F.B.I. stance is now party orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: Kash Patel, President-elect Trump’s pick to lead the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has called the top ranks of the bureau “a threat to the people” and published a list of enemies, vowing retribution for investigations of top Republicans.

headline: Syrians Celebrate the Fall of al-Assad, and Look to Rebuild
abstract: After five decades under a brutal regime that kept many in fear and poverty, families flooded back from Lebanon, eager to start the slow process of healing.
lead_paragraph: In the days after Syria’s government fell and President Bashar al-Assad fled to Moscow, Syrians celebrated the sudden end of a dynastic regime that had kept them in fear and poverty for five decades.

headline: Hallmark’s First ‘Mr. Christmas’ Goes Home for the Holidays
abstract: And he’s single.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, when Ezra Moreland, 31, a former Navy swimmer raised in Wichita, Kansas, applied for a new reality TV competition, he knew only that the production was family oriented.

headline: Man Freed From Syrian Prison Appears to Be a Missing American
abstract: The man, who told reporters his name was Travis, said he was imprisoned in Syria for several months. The State Department said it was aware of an American found outside Damascus and was “seeking to provide support.”
lead_paragraph: The man, who told reporters his name was Travis, said he was imprisoned in Syria for several months. The State Department said it was aware of an American found outside Damascus and was “seeking to provide support.”

headline: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Literature is often concerned with “the way we live now,” as Anthony Trollope memorably put it, but this week we recommend three books that focus more narrowly on where we live — as in real estate. There’s Gu Byeong-mo’s novel “Apartment Women,” about a group-living experiment in South Korea, and Charif Majdalani’s novel “A History of the Big House,” about a grand estate subject to the changing tides of Lebanese history, and Patrick Hutchison’s charming memoir “Cabin: Off the Grid Adventures With a Clueless Craftsman.” Those three authors could pull up a seat at the bar with Paul, the real estate novelist in Billy Joel’s “Piano Man,” and commiserate about their Zillow valuations.

headline: Los Angeles Times Owner Wades Deeper Into Opinion Section
abstract: Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong’s public comments and actions, including recently blocking an editorial weighing in on President-elect Trump’s cabinet picks, have concerned many staff members.
lead_paragraph: After President-elect Donald J. Trump announced a cascade of cabinet picks last month, the editorial board of The Los Angeles Times decided it would weigh in. One writer prepared an editorial arguing that the Senate should follow its traditional process for confirming nominees, particularly given the board’s concerns about some of his picks, and ignore Mr. Trump’s call for so-called recess appointments.

headline: Democrats Ask That Trump Cabinet Picks Produce Communications With Epshteyn
abstract: The two top Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee said prospective nominees should be prepared to testify about any discussions with Boris Epshteyn about their selections.
lead_paragraph: The two top Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday told Republicans they want President-elect Donald J. Trump’s cabinet picks to hand over all of their communications with Boris Epshteyn, Mr. Trump’s top legal adviser, amid allegations that he sought money in exchange for promoting potential nominees.

headline: Three Questions From Cutting-Edge Climate Science
abstract: An annual gathering of scientists this week offered a glimpse into the latest efforts to answer some of the most intriguing questions about our warming planet.
lead_paragraph: Every December, more than 25,000 scientists from around the globe descend upon a cavernous convention center to eat dry sandwiches, drink weak coffee and ponder all things Earth and climate and space.

headline: Incoming West Virginia Lawmaker Is Accused of Making Terroristic Threats
abstract: Joseph de Soto, 61, was elected last month to represent the 91st District, but he was arrested before he was sworn in.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before a newly elected Republican was scheduled to be sworn in to the West Virginia Legislature, the incoming lawmaker was arrested on Thursday in connection with making threats against government officials, the authorities said.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 8, 2025
abstract: What do you notice about book bans across the United States?
lead_paragraph: Note: We will live-moderate a discussion about this graph on Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2025, and then post the graph’s Reveal by the morning of Friday, Jan. 10.

headline: How to Dangerously Misread a Very Important Verdict
abstract: What happened on that subway train — and the acquittal that followed — deserves a more measured response.
lead_paragraph: Since Monday, when a jury found Daniel Penny not guilty in the death of Jordan Neely on a New York City subway, the conversation has threatened to go off the rails.

headline: Donald Trump’s Perfect 1980s Day
abstract: For a man who rose to fame in the gilded yuppie era of New York City, today’s ringing the bell to open the stock exchange, and being named Person of the Year by Time, must have a certain appeal.
lead_paragraph: By many standards, Donald J. Trump has lived a remarkable American life.

headline: A Cozy House, a Spooky Setting and a Leap of Faith: Creative Writing by Teens
abstract: Some favorite student responses to three recent Picture Prompts.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Morgan Wallen Pleads to Reduced Charges in Chair-Throwing Incident
abstract: The country superstar agreed to misdemeanor reckless endangerment charges and a week at a D.U.I. education center.
lead_paragraph: The country superstar Morgan Wallen pleaded guilty on Thursday in a Nashville courtroom to misdemeanor reckless endangerment charges stemming from an arrest in April, in which he was accused of throwing a chair from the sixth-story roof of a downtown bar.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 6, 2025
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Months Before C.E.O.’s Killing, the Suspect Went Silent. Where Was He?
abstract: New details are emerging about Luigi Mangione’s growing impatience with “a capitalist society” and his search for refuge in the mountains of Japan.
lead_paragraph: After a drizzly hike through one of Japan’s lush mountain ranges earlier this year, Luigi Mangione, a computer engineer in his mid-20s who had set off on a long solo trip to Asia, paused to record a voice message to a friend he had met while traveling abroad.

headline: Chinese-Flagged Ship Suspected of Cutting Cables Remains Halted Weeks Later
abstract: After fiber-optic cables under the Baltic Sea were cut last month, European officials hurried to stop the Yi Peng 3. It’s still at anchor there, with no update on three nations’ investigation.
lead_paragraph: When two fiber-optic cables were severed under the Baltic Sea last month, European officials acted fast, with some declaring sabotage. They sent coast guard vessels to halt a Chinese-flagged commercial ship that their governments suspected of involvement.

headline: The Perfect Takeout for a Night In
abstract: An Ethiopian spread from Bunna Cafe, perfectly packaged sushi from Sugarfish and roast chicken from Poulet Sans Tete.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what’s in my fridge right now: a stick of butter, two beers, a pint container of rice, four Persian cucumbers that are beginning to shrivel and every condiment known to mankind. This is all to say, there will be takeout tonight.

headline: When a Glock Isn’t a Glock: The History of the Pistol Found With Luigi Mangione
abstract: Part of the gun that the police believe was used to kill the C.E.O. of UnitedHealthcare was made by a 3D printer using a popular design found online.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the gun in the police photographs — the one the authorities believe Luigi Mangione used to kill the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare — appears to be a Glock-19, a 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol used by military forces, police officers, civilians and criminals all over the world.

headline: What Do You Expect From a Second Trump Presidency?
abstract: We want to hear how you imagine the next four years will unfold for you and your loved ones.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump prepares for his presidency, we would like to know your hopes, fears and needs for the coming year. What can the government do to make your life better? How do you think the second Trump presidency will affect your family, finances or job? Who did you vote for?

headline: Louisville and Justice Dept. Reach Deal on Federal Oversight of Police
abstract: The agreement comes after the Justice Department documented excessive use of force, illegal searches and car stops and widespread discrimination against Black people and those with mental illnesses.
lead_paragraph: The city of Louisville and the Justice Department reached an agreement on Thursday to address misconduct by the local police after the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor in 2020 brought attention to far-ranging abuses by law enforcement.

headline: A Ten Commandments Tablet Goes Up for Auction, and Questions Abound
abstract: Bids may rise to a million or more, Sotheby’s estimates, though some experts say that fakes and forgeries abound.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s auction house is selling a stone version of the Ten Commandments that it says is the world’s oldest, dating to A.D. 300-800. The artifact even comes with a fun story about missing one of the commandments, and having been used as a paving stone.

headline: Friday Briefing: Israeli Forces to Stay in Syria for Now
abstract: Plus, British pubs are scrambling for Guinness.
lead_paragraph: As countries in the Middle East and beyond worked out how to respond to the fall of the Assad government, Israel said that its military would stay in Syrian territory it had seized until “a new force” was established that met its security demands. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israeli soldiers would deploy “temporarily,” but he did not give a timeline for their departure.

headline: ‘No Good Deed’ Is Star-Studded California Gothic
abstract: Lisa Kudrow and Ray Romano star as a Los Angeles couple with secrets trying to sell their house. Things get complicated quickly.
lead_paragraph: “No Good Deed,” now on Netflix, is the latest rich-people-with-sad-secrets show, filled exclusively with famous faces, luxurious real estate and brittle misery.

headline: The Stock Market and TV: Trump’s Most Durable Guardrails
abstract: The curbs on President-elect Donald J. Trump’s impulses are mostly gone, but the old standbys are still in effect, people close to him say.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday with news cameras rolling, the moment perfectly captured two of the president-elect’s biggest obsessions: the stock market and television.

headline: Enslaved People’s Graves Discovered at Andrew Jackson’s Hermitage
abstract: The burial ground at the former American president’s home in Nashville is the latest to be discovered at a presidential site.
lead_paragraph: The South is a land of lost graves.

headline: Clarke Reed, Who Helped the G.O.P. Conquer the South, Dies at 96
abstract: He built Mississippi’s Republican Party into a conservative powerhouse, making himself a regional power broker in the process.
lead_paragraph: Clarke Reed, a courtly Mississippi conservative who pushed his state’s Republican Party from irrelevance to dominance in the 1970s and helped lead the charge in turning the South from deep blue to ruby red, died on Sunday at his home in Greenville, Miss. He was 96.

headline: U.S. and Allies Race to Shape a New Syria Trying to Get on Its Feet
abstract: As a rebel alliance with a tenuous hold on power struggles to assert control of the fractured country, Israel, Turkey and the United States are trying to influence what Syria will become.
lead_paragraph: As Syria’s new leaders take on the task of governing the country, world powers sent emissaries into the region on Thursday to begin trying to shape Syria’s future and their relations with the rebels who toppled Bashar al-Assad from the presidency.

headline: Astro Bot Wins Top Honor at the Game Awards
abstract: The exploration of Sony history held off Balatro and Metaphor: ReFantazio, which each received several awards at an annual showcase for the industry.
lead_paragraph: The plucky platformer Astro Bot won the top prize at the Game Awards on Thursday, a crowning achievement for a character who originated as an asset for a PlayStation tech demo.

headline: U.S. Couple on Holiday Visit Are Shot and Killed in Western Mexico
abstract: The killings, and other violent episodes this year, have marred the first few months in office of Mexico’s new president, who has vowed to tackle the country’s bloodshed.
lead_paragraph: Two U.S. citizens were fatally shot by gunmen on Wednesday night in western Mexico, local officials said, a setback to the Mexican government’s efforts to curb the violence gripping several regions in the country.

headline: Stanley Recalls More Than 2 Million Travel Mugs Over Burn Hazard
abstract: Stanley, which also makes trendy tumblers that are wildly popular on social media, urged consumers to contact them for replacement lids.
lead_paragraph: After concerns that loose lids could lead to burn injuries, Stanley issued a recall of about 2.6 million travel mugs on Thursday, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.

headline: U.S. Hopes for a Gaza Cease-Fire and Hostage Deal ‘This Month’
abstract: In the Middle East for a last-ditch diplomatic effort before leaving office, Jake Sullivan, a top White House official, said the current talks were different than those in the past.
lead_paragraph: The White House national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, said on Thursday that his goal was to be able to close a deal between Israel and Hamas for a cease-fire in Gaza and the release of hostages held there “this month.”

headline: Air Force Academy Sued Over Race-Based Admissions Policy
abstract: The lawsuit was the latest in a series by a prominent anti-affirmative action group that is seeking to overturn the use of racial preferences in the nation’s military academies.
lead_paragraph: A prominent anti-affirmative action group filed a lawsuit challenging racial preferences in admissions at the United States Air Force Academy in federal court on Tuesday.

headline: D.E.I. Official at University of Michigan Is Fired Over Antisemitism Claim, Lawyer Says
abstract: The official, an administrator of multicultural programs, was accused of making antisemitic remarks in a conversation. Her lawyer said that the school fired her this week, and vowed to sue.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan has fired an administrator who worked on diversity initiatives over accusations that she made antisemitic comments, according to her lawyer. The lawyer said she planned to sue the school.

headline: Biden Commuted the Sentences of 1,500 Americans, a One-Day Record
abstract: Also, Israel said it would stay in Syria for now. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced today that he would pardon 39 people convicted of nonviolent crimes and commute the sentences of 1,499 others. The White House said it was the largest number of commutations by an American president in a single day.

headline: Dolores Madrigal, Plaintiff in Landmark Sterilization Case, Dies at 90
abstract: She was among hundreds of women who said they were coerced into sterilization at a California hospital in the 1970s. The lawsuit led to state and national reforms.
lead_paragraph: Dolores Madrigal, the lead plaintiff in a landmark lawsuit brought by Latina women in California who said they were coerced into unwanted sterilization during childbirth at a Los Angeles hospital in the early 1970s, died on Nov. 9 in Las Vegas. She was 90.

headline: Brothers Charged With Sex Crimes Remain in Custody
abstract: Tal and Oren Alexander, once stars of the luxury real estate industry, and their brother, Alon Alexander, were arrested on Wednesday in Miami.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news events.

headline: YouTube TV Raises Monthly Charge 14 Percent, to $82.99
abstract: The increase is the latest for the streaming service, which debuted in 2017 at $35 a month. The company blamed “rising content costs.”
lead_paragraph: YouTube TV is becoming more expensive — again.

headline: Under Trump, Voice of America Journalists Fear Politicization
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s choice of Kari Lake to lead Voice of America goes against recent efforts to shield the federally funded news organization from politicization.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice of Kari Lake to serve as the director of the federally funded broadcaster Voice of America sent a chill through the ranks of the organization, where journalists expressed anxiety about Ms. Lake and what the future could hold.

headline: Selena Gomez’s Engagement Ring Has People Talking
abstract: A lyrical Easter egg may have predicted her marquise diamond ring, which one jewelry designer calls “the hot stone of the moment.”
lead_paragraph: Some brides-to-be openly discuss their dream engagement rings, creating mood boards, getting fittings and going shopping ahead of the proposal. In Selena Gomez’s case, some say she may have dropped the ultimate ring hint as a lyrical Easter egg in her 2015 song, “Good for You.”

headline: Report on New Jersey’s Worst Nursing Home Finds Rampant Fraud and Abuse
abstract: A trio of relatives in New Jersey defrauded the state’s Medicaid program out of millions of dollars while neglecting patient care, the state comptroller found.
lead_paragraph: Three men running a group of nursing homes in New Jersey will be barred from being Medicaid providers after an investigation by the state comptroller’s office found that they were funneling millions of dollars into their personal accounts and other businesses while severely neglecting vulnerable residents in their care.

headline: An Easy Holiday Manicure With a Secret Ingredient
abstract: The nail artist Mei Kawajiri shares a festive nail design you can recreate at home in just five steps, using products you probably already own.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes I want to take three hours to do a detailed design,” says the New York-based nail artist Mei Kawajiri, who has created elaborate custom looks for pop stars such as Tyla, Dua Lipa and Sabrina Carpenter. But while Kawajiri is well known for her 3-D manicures, adorned with everything from miniature teddy bears to dollops of caviar, she also understands the power of what she calls a pared-down “good idea.” Here, she demonstrates how to accomplish a festive version of “aura nails” — which feature gradient color accents against a solid base — using just a handful of products including, perhaps surprisingly, eye shadow.

headline: ‘Carry-On’ Review: Travel Nightmares Amplified
abstract: In this tense thriller, Taron Egerton plays a T.S.A. agent who goes up against an implacable terrorist (Jason Bateman). The man has a funny idea of what he wants to bring on a plane.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a fan of white-knuckle-tension suspense thrillers, you know the debate as to whether or not the 1988 classic “Die Hard” is a Christmas movie. “Carry-On,” directed by the expert technician Jaume Collet-Serra, makes absolutely no bones about being a Christmas movie as it seeks to work your nerves in the “Die Hard” tradition.

headline: Trump Backs Dockworkers in Dispute Over Automation
abstract: The president-elect’s intervention could help the longshoremen’s union win concessions and avoid the resumption of a strike on East and Gulf Coast ports.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Thursday offered his support to a union representing dockworkers at East and Gulf Coast ports that is negotiating a new labor contract. His intervention could help the union win concessions from the companies that operate port terminals and avoid the resumption of a strike that was suspended in October.

headline: Sotheby’s Lays Off More Than 100 Staffers as Auction Sales Slump
abstract: As the high-flying art market has contracted, the company is looking elsewhere, expanding its luxury brand and real estate in New York, Paris and Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s laid off more than 100 staff members around the globe this week, roughly 6 percent of its 1,800-person work force. The cutbacks, which came three weeks after the auction house’s major November sales, were part of an effort to improve the company’s financial picture amid shrinking auction revenue. They came despite a recent $1 billion cash infusion from Abu Dhabi’s sovereign wealth fund and investment company, ADQ.

headline: Why Wray’s Resignation May Signal a Shift in F.B.I. Tradition
abstract: Mr. Wray’s voluntary departure could usher in a new era at the nation’s premier law enforcement agency, one in which the job of director changes with the administration.
lead_paragraph: Christopher A. Wray had considered resigning as F.B.I. director before. More than once, confronted with angry demands from President Donald J. Trump and his allies, he contemplated calling it quits.

headline: For Those Granted Clemency by White House, a Moment to Celebrate and Plan
abstract: Among those whose sentences were commuted was Rebecca Parrett, an Arizona woman who now hopes to travel to meet her great-grandchildren for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Early on Thursday morning, Rebecca Parrett received a phone call from her former hairdresser.

headline: Match the Taylor Swift Song to the Poem Inspired By Her Music
abstract: Famous poets (tortured or not) have taken inspiration from Swift's music. Can you match the poem to the song?
lead_paragraph: Famous poets (tortured or not) have taken inspiration from Swift's music. Can you match the poem to the song?

headline: Amazon Plans $1 Million Donation to Trump’s Inaugural Fund
abstract: The move follows Meta’s donation of the same amount to the fund earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said on Thursday that it was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, part of a pattern in which tech companies and their leaders are taking steps to repair their relationships with Mr. Trump.

headline: Humpback Whale Sets Record for How Far It Traveled
abstract: The adult male swam more than 8,000 miles from South America to Africa, most likely in search of a mate, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: A humpback whale set a record by traversing at least three oceans and more than 8,000 miles — most likely in search of a mate, according to a new study.

headline: U.S. Charges Ex-Syrian Prison Official With Torture
abstract: The indictment was the second time in a week that the Justice Department announced that it had charged top Syrian officials with human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury in Los Angeles charged a former Syrian government official on Thursday with torturing political dissidents at a notorious prison in Damascus.

headline: A Bagel Shop Closed, and the Upper West Side Is Absolutely Losing It
abstract: The neighborhood reaction to the sudden closure of a Manhattan bagel shop was intense: “No no no no no no no no no no no!!”
lead_paragraph: In the vast constellation of New York City bagel shops, Absolute Bagels on the Upper West Side has held a lofty but unusual position of honor.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 13, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about government data on recent immigration into the United States referred incorrectly to a figure in the Census Bureau’s estimate of immigration from 2020 to 2023. The bureau estimated that the foreign-born population changed by an average of about 900,000 from 2020 to 2023, not that net migration changed by that amount. (The first category does not take into account the death of foreign-born people already living in the United States; the second one does.)

headline: Mount Vernon Police’s Strip Searches Were Unconstitutional, U.S. Says
abstract: A report by federal prosecutors found that a Westchester County police department violated the Fourth Amendment “on an enormous scale.”
lead_paragraph: Two women, 65 and 75 years old, were taken to a police station in Mount Vernon, N.Y., after a traffic stop in 2020. Officers instructed both women to undress. Then they were told to bend over and cough.

headline: First Pass Friday, or How I Made My Way Into a Tough Puzzle
abstract: Ryan Patrick Smith’s crossword put up quite a fight, but there is always a way to win.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to First Pass Friday, an occasional Wordplay column in which I show you my first few passes through the clue list. This serves two purposes: It provides encouragement for those who are just starting to solve the harder, end-of-the-week puzzles, and it proves to those who have finished the crossword that they are much smarter than I am.

headline: ‘Cult of Love’ Review: We Wish You a Wretched Christmas
abstract: A hilarious, harrowing holiday gift from Leslye Headland, who brings another unhappy family to Broadway. Zachary Quinto and Shailene Woodley star.
lead_paragraph: Though figgy pudding is on the menu, Evie Dahl has a different Yuletide horror in mind. “Christmas is exactly the time to talk about the things we never talk about,” she tells her reluctant siblings.

headline: One Dead in Small Plane Crash Near Westchester County Airport
abstract: A second person on the flight was in serious condition. The single-engine plane crashed shortly after the pilot reported engine issues.
lead_paragraph: A small plane crashed on Thursday, killing one person on board, on a highway near the Westchester County Airport about five miles northeast of White Plains, the New York State Police said.

headline: Creator of The Last of Us Reveals New Sci-Fi Game
abstract: Neil Druckmann said Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet, the adventure of a galactic bounty hunter, would be a story about faith.
lead_paragraph: After becoming known for cinematic storytelling and heartbreaking realism through franchises such as The Last of Us and Uncharted, Neil Druckmann said his next video game would take place in the fantastical reaches of space, where a tattooed bounty hunter watches anime and drives a Porsche-branded rocket ship.

headline: Quote of the Day: Lean Supplies Trouble Lovers of Stout
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 13, 2024
lead_paragraph: “If you come in and order Pepsi and we don’t have it, we’ll give you Coke. There’s no real substitute for Guinness.”

headline: Move Over, Charlie Brown: Lessons From ‘The Boondocks’ Christmas Special
abstract: With “A Huey Freeman Christmas,” the show continued what “A Charlie Brown Christmas” began: acknowledging the weight of the holiday.
lead_paragraph: One of the most beloved holiday traditions that doesn’t involve gift-giving is “A Charlie Brown Christmas.” The 1965 animated special, depicting the trials of the titular sad sack and a crew of kids wearied beyond their years by commercialism, has inspired repeat viewings and countless appraisals, including in The New York Times. But the genre of Christmas specials it inspired, including “How the Grinch Stole Christmas!” and “Frosty the Snowman,” largely leaned away from Charlie’s melancholy and toward a wholesome belief in the righteous power of the holiday spirit.

headline: She Swapped Her ‘Spinsterlicious Life’ for Him
abstract: Eleanore Wells loved her single, child-free life so much that she wrote a book about it. Then, at 60, she moved to Australia where she met Anthony Graham.
lead_paragraph: As far as Eleanore S. Wells was concerned, marriage was overrated. She boasted more than 60 years of singledom, and even wrote a memoir, “The Spinsterlicious Life,” as a testament to that belief.

headline: For Two Indian Movie Stars, a Love Language Expressed in Telugu
abstract: Sobhita Dhulipala and Naga Chaitanya Akkineni bonded over their South Indian roots and a shared language that felt like home. They married in an “intimate” ceremony of 300.
lead_paragraph: Sobhita Dhulipala was unable to attend the 52nd International Emmy Awards, where the Hindi-language television show she starred in, “The Night Manager,” was nominated for best drama series. But she had a good reason: She was getting ready to marry her fellow actor, Naga Chaitanya Akkineni.

headline: Marriage, Baby and House, Though Not in That Order
abstract: Jocelyn Weigel and Zac Troughton matched on a dating app at the height of the pandemic, when both were lonely and looking for love.
lead_paragraph: When Jocelyn Kay Weigel and Zachary Perry Troughton were matched on Hinge in August 2020, they were both feeling lonely and seeking companionship. Though attuned to the risks of dating during the pandemic, it was clear to both that there was a connection.

headline: Surprise, ‘We’re Getting Married Right Now!’
abstract: Daniel Howarth and Jonathan Marotto gathered their closest friends and family for a celebration that also happened to be their wedding.
lead_paragraph: When friends and family joined Daniel Alan Howarth and Jonathan Frank Marotto at a restaurant in Miami Beach on Nov. 20, they thought they were there to celebrate the couple’s recent wedding at the Miami Beach courthouse earlier that day. But they hadn’t actually gotten married.

headline: Please Let Me Love My Wife
abstract: Her pronouns changed. Our bond didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Our story never failed to charm at cocktail parties. We were college sweethearts addicted to one another’s company, pen pals while abroad, intellectual soul mates who moved together from Montana to Manhattan, goofy newlyweds who never stopped rooting for each other.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: As the allies and adversaries of Syria reckon with how to respond to its change of government, Israel said that its military would stay in seized Syrian territory until “a new force” was established that met Israeli security demands. Here’s the latest.

headline: Dating on the Front Line: Ukrainian Women Travel to Keep Love Alive
abstract: Many women are making dangerous trips to places where loved ones are fighting Russian forces. “We try to imagine that for these two days, there is no war,” one said.
lead_paragraph: Everything happened so fast. On their first in-person date, they went to see a play, and she whispered in his ear, “I think I’ve fallen in love with you.” Soon after, they were married. And shortly after that, he was sent back to the front.

headline: The First New Foreign Policy Challenge for Trump Just Became Clear
abstract: Because of Syria’s centrality in the Middle East, positive change there could radiate out in all directions.
lead_paragraph: I have a simple rule of thumb when assessing the potential instability of Middle Eastern countries. They come in just two varieties: countries that implode and countries that explode. That is, countries where, when central control collapses, the ruined pillars fall inside their borders, and countries where, when central control collapses, the blast radius of all the political shrapnel extends far and wide.

headline: Word of the Day: efficient
