abstract: This word has appeared in 1,694 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word efficient has appeared in 1,694 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 19 in “Through the Turnstile and Down the Aisle” by Sarah Lyon:

headline: Time’s Person of the Year Doesn’t Surprise Late Night Hosts
abstract: “Trump is the first man in history to be Time’s person of the year and McDonald’s employee of the month,” Jimmy Fallon said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Money in Suitcase
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Uber and Lyft Found a Loophole in a Driver Pay Law. Drivers Pushed Back.
abstract: As ride-hailing companies and labor unions each push New York City to amend its rules, drivers hurt by widespread app lockouts are struggling to make ends meet.
lead_paragraph: New York City was the first place in the United States to mandate minimum pay rates for drivers for companies like Uber and Lyft. But after the companies found a loophole that made it much harder for some drivers to get by, the city is looking to change its law, prompting dueling pressure campaigns as both sides seek to influence the outcome.

headline: Sorry, but This Is the Future of Food
abstract: Every farm, even the scenic ones with red barns and rolling hills, is a kind of environmental crime scene, an echo of whatever wilderness it once replaced.
lead_paragraph: This is the final essay in What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

headline: A Modernist’s Dream on Copenhagen’s Harbor
abstract: A couple hired an architect with experience designing floating homes, after a decade of downsizing on dry land.
lead_paragraph: “I’m swimming almost every morning, even now when it’s starting to be very cold,” said Soren Hvalsoe Garde, speaking in October from Scandinavia.

headline: Looking for Friends? Start With Family.
abstract: How a brother-in-law became my best friend.
lead_paragraph: Friends, it is often said, are the family you choose. But sometimes, it goes the other way.

headline: Would You Buy a Perfume You Had Never Smelled?
abstract: A half-million people are on the Ffern wait list hoping to do just that.
lead_paragraph: “We have this conviction that fine fragrance is like fine wine,” said Owen Mears, the founder of Ffern, a line of perfumes based in London. “Everybody knows it’s just grapes, but you can’t simply recreate it, because there is craft involved.” He was drinking tea at the Nine Orchard hotel next to his sister, Emily Cameron, Ffern’s creative director.

headline: What Is Venture Capital Now Anyway?
abstract: The opposing paths taken by two powerful firms — Benchmark and Andreessen Horowitz — embody a profound debate about the future of an industry that funds and fosters American innovation.
lead_paragraph: Three decades ago, five men formed a venture capital firm on Sand Hill Road in Silicon Valley with a simple pitch: Small is beautiful.

headline: As East Village’s Little India Fades, One Place Keeps Its Lights On
abstract: Three neighboring South Asian restaurants with string light-filled windows survived for decades. Only one remains as Sixth Street’s “Curry Row” moniker fades.
lead_paragraph: Four windows at the bottom of a brick building in the East Village used to entice passers-by, with string lights and glowing chili peppers as far as the eye could see.

headline: In a Growing Utah City, Residents Are Turning Against Their Mayor
abstract: Residents voted to rein in a mayor who they say has a penchant for secrecy and is overly deferential to developers.
lead_paragraph: Residents say Julie Fullmer was the type of mayor who would give out her cellphone number, responding to complaints at all hours about unplowed snow routes or broken sprinklers. She regularly encouraged residents, especially women, to run for City Council and volunteer on boards.

headline: The Best Book Covers of 2024
abstract: A Book Review art director selects the book jackets that made a compelling impression.
lead_paragraph: If most book cover designs are conceived as quick-to-metabolize marketing tools, a great one can make the reader do a double take in slow motion. A good first impression is, of course, the goal: to elicit curiosity and excitement before you’ve even picked the book off a shelf. But a great cover can fortify itself in our consciousness, resonating more deeply as we absorb the text within, ideally prompting a second impression after we finish reading.

headline: Big Tech Is Embracing Trump. How Long Will It Last?
abstract: Three new books explore the fraught relationships between tech companies and the U.S. government through close looks at Jeff Bezos’ Amazon and Elon Musk’s X.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk wasn’t always such a big fan of Donald Trump. In December 2016, he reluctantly joined Trump’s business advisory council, only to leave it a few months later after the Republican president pulled out of an international climate agreement. Trump also played hot and cold with the tech industry. During his first term in office, he was generally critical of Big Tech tycoons and their power, even as critics lined up to argue that social media platforms, exploited by foreign agents and hyper-political outlets, had helped deliver him to the White House.

headline: What Is (or Was) ‘Perks Culture’?
abstract: After mass layoffs and a pivot to A.I., the tech industry has been scaling back on the splashy and quirky benefits it had become known for.
lead_paragraph: A deep-tissue massage. Housekeeping and laundry services. A haircut after lunch.

headline: Two’s a Crowd: 3 New Chapter Books Sing the Praises of Me Time
abstract: The protagonists of “A Day With Mousse,” “Little Shrew” and “Lone Wolf Goes to School” feel happiest on their own.
lead_paragraph: “Hell is — other people!,” as a character in Sartre’s one-act play “No Exit” famously exclaims.

headline: Exploring the Brazil Where Schnapps and Grappa Flow
abstract: A road trip through Brazil’s Rio Grande do Sul state leads to German and Italian cuisine, dialects and a surprising number of music festivals.
lead_paragraph: I had intricately planned my road trip exploring the Italian and German heritage of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil’s southernmost state, to maximize immigrant cuisine, unsung wineries and villages with charming timber-frame buildings. I’d visit Antônio Prado, the self-proclaimed “most Italian city in Brazil,” drive along rural roads lined with hydrangeas, and explore Gramado, a town whose center this time of year resembles an Epcot version of an Alpine ski town, decked out with Santa statues and massive candy canes.

headline: 36 Things That Stuck With Us in 2024
abstract: The movie scenes, TV episodes, song lyrics and other moments that reporters, critics, editors and visual journalists in Culture couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
lead_paragraph: Real tennis, like real dancing, happens when the body is rapt and alive, where visceral sensation takes over and the only thing left is the crystallization of every nerve and muscle, both aligned and on edge. That last match was a dance.

headline: ‘Kraven the Hunter’ Review: A Seriously Silly Movie
abstract: Aaron Taylor-Johnson’s buff Marvel hero is overshadowed by unabashedly fun villains.
lead_paragraph: Built on brawn, J.C. Chandor’s action sci-fi picture “Kraven the Hunter” is limited by incomprehensible plotting and dodgy one-liners delivered by a cast who seem to be practicing their worst Russian accents. If not for the bevy of anticlimactic fights, “Kraven the Hunter” could be so bad it’s good. Instead, it’s merely another excursion away from the Marvel Cinematic Universe to Sony’s series of defanged comic book villains.

headline: Six Childhood Scourges We’ve Forgotten About, Thanks to Vaccines
abstract: Most Americans, including doctors, have no memory of the devastating diseases that routinely threatened children until the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Some of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks for the government’s top health posts have expressed skepticism about the safety of childhood vaccines. It’s a sentiment shared by a growing number of parents, who are choosing to skip recommended shots for their children.

headline: Who Better to Explore the Mysteries of the Brain Than Werner Herzog?
abstract: In “Theater of Thought,” he talks to scientists and other experts about consciousness, quantum computing and whether parrots understand human speech.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in “Theater of Thought” (in theaters) when Darío Gil, the director of research at IBM, is explaining quantum computing to Werner Herzog, the movie’s director. Standing before a whiteboard, Gil draws some points on spheres to illustrate how qubits work, then proceeds to define the Schrödinger equation. As he talks and writes, the audio grows quieter, and Herzog’s distinctive resonant German accent takes over. “I admit that I literally understand nothing of this, and I assume most of you don’t either,” he intones in voice-over. “But I found it fascinating that this mathematical formula explains the law that draws the subatomic world.”

headline: At the Piano With Jon Batiste
abstract: How the artist found the blues in Beethoven
lead_paragraph: Jon Batiste, the Grammy Award-winning composer, television personality and jazz and R&B artist recently released “Beethoven Blues,” his first classical album. Batiste blends Beethoven’s most familiar compositions, like “Für Elise” and the Fifth Symphony, with improvised jazz, blues and funk, finding “soul” in the composer’s work. Javier Hernández, a classical music reporter, sits down at the piano with Batiste for an interview and a music lesson at Electric Lady Studios in Manhattan.

headline: For Wild Animals, the Bird Flu Disaster Is Already Here
abstract: Scientists are concerned that the H5N1 virus could set off another human pandemic. But it is already putting species under pressure in the wild.
lead_paragraph: Every spring, more than 200,000 northern gannets — stocky seabirds with dazzling white feathers — journey to the coast of eastern Canada. There, they blanket oceanside cliffs and rocky outcroppings, breeding in enormous colonies before flying back south for the winter.

headline: Gas Could Mean Billions for Indigenous People in Canada. Some Fear a Cost.
abstract: New export terminals along the rugged Pacific coastline have reignited a generations-old debate over identity and environmental stewardship.
lead_paragraph: With her hair pulled back into a tight ponytail, her arms and legs covered with 20 tattoos, and her compact frame fitted out in athleisure, Crystal Smith, the elected chief of the Haisla people, looked more like the hometown basketball star she once was than the fossil fuel exporter she’s about to become.

headline: I Traded My News Apps for Rumble, the Right-Wing YouTube. Here’s What I Saw.
abstract: After watching 47 hours of video, I found an alternate reality curated for Trump supporters.
lead_paragraph: After watching 47 hours of video, I found an alternate reality curated for Trump supporters.

headline: Kennedy’s Lawyer Has Asked the F.D.A. to Revoke Approval of the Polio Vaccine
abstract: Aaron Siri, who specializes in vaccine lawsuits, has been at Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s side reviewing candidates for top jobs at the Department of Health and Human Services.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer helping Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pick federal health officials for the incoming Trump administration has petitioned the government to revoke its approval of the polio vaccine, which for decades has protected millions of people from a virus that can cause paralysis or death.

headline: In New York and Paris, Church Organs Return to Life
abstract: On Palm Sunday five years ago, fire struck two cathedrals: Notre-Dame and St. John the Divine. Both their organs are now restored.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about the return of pipe organs that went silent for five years after fires broke out at their cathedrals. We’ll also look at a mayoral candidate’s proposal for city-owned grocery stores.

headline: Where Opera Is Still the Center of the Universe
abstract: There is nothing quite like opening night of Teatro alla Scala in Milan, a temple of opera, for pomp, pageantry and politics.
lead_paragraph: Television reporters stood shoulder to shoulder delivering breathless, minute-by-minute commentary, part of a pack of more than 120 journalists from 10 countries.

headline: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Angelina Jolie stars as the opera star Maria Callas during her tumultuous final days in this biopic directed by Pablo Larraín.

headline: How Christian Slater Went From Bad Boy to Good Dad
abstract: The actor’s tumultuous past has given way to a “very happy” family life. He plays a father on “Dexter: Original Sin,” too — but to keep a serial killer in check, you still need some edge.
lead_paragraph: On a July morning, the actor Christian Slater sat on a bench at the Long Beach marina, grimacing in the California sunshine. Slater sighed, he scowled, he groaned. He looked like a man facing some terrible moral quandary. Or like a man with severe indigestion.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a sequel to a 1980s Tim Burton classic and an animated tale of a Christmas nearly gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: One of the joys of parenthood is introducing your child to classic films that you once loved. It thrills me that my 7-year-old son adores “E.T.” and the original “Star Wars” and “Indiana Jones” films. Watching him mimic the “Banana Boat (Day-O)” dance in Tim Burton’s 1988 goth horror comedy “Beetlejuice” has been one of the highlights of my year. For older children that love scary-ish movies, Burton’s long-awaited follow-up film is a kooky medley of wacky scares and outrageous scenarios. Winona Ryder returns as a grown-up Lydia. She’s now a widow who hosts a ghost show on TV, and her goth teenage daughter, Astrid (Jenna Ortega), is every bit as brooding as her mother was at her age.

headline: $3 Million Homes in the Caribbean
abstract: A villa-guest cottage combo and a sleek contemporary house in Barbados, and a luxury bungalow in the Bahamas.
lead_paragraph: Situated in the private island resort of Kamalame Cay, which occupies a 96-acre cay off the northeast coast of the Bahamas’ largest island, this three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath home features vaulted ceilings and an indoor-outdoor layout. Andros Island is home to the Andros Barrier Reef, which stretches 124 miles. This house sits on a split of land — a cay is a low-elevation island on the surface of a reef. One side faces a white-sand beach and the Atlantic Ocean, and on the other side faces salt marshes and the mainland. The resort community is 14 miles from Andros Town, the island’s capital and home to Andros Town International Airport.

headline: The Smithsonian Looks at How the Slave Trade Shaped the World
abstract: “In Slavery’s Wake,” at the National Museum of African American History and Culture, looks beyond the United States to tell a global story.
lead_paragraph: “In Slavery’s Wake,” a new exhibition at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, deals in huge themes and vast numbers. Over four centuries, an estimated 12 million Africans were transported across the ocean on more than 36,000 voyages, an epochal forced migration that reshaped societies on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: A Broken System Is No Excuse
abstract: Our broken system can test us, but it shouldn’t break our morals.
lead_paragraph: When Brian Thompson was shot to death, something strange — and disturbing — happened: The gunman was lauded. Why? Because his victim was the C.E.O. of one of the largest health insurance companies in the country. And so the shooter, observers assumed, must be a victim of those companies.

headline: How Hegseth Salvaged His Secretary of Defense Nomination
abstract: The president-elect became convinced that letting Pete Hegseth fail would set off a feeding frenzy among senators. What followed was a MAGA swarm that helped salvage his bid, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: The president-elect became convinced that letting Pete Hegseth fail would set off a feeding frenzy among senators. What followed was a MAGA swarm that helped salvage his bid, at least for now.

headline: Should You Be Able to Copyright a Vibe?
abstract: One influencer has accused another of copying her aesthetic on social media. Should stealing someone’s vibe be against the law?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever scrolled through Instagram or TikTok and seen two creators whose content looks nearly identical? They have the same look, are wearing the same outfit, are striking the same pose. In short, they have the same vibe.

headline: What ‘Wicked’ Has to Say About Our Current Political Moment
abstract: By breaking the story into two movies, the emphasis in “Part One” shifts to a nation’s potential decline into authoritarianism. Sound familiar?
lead_paragraph: In the big-screen adaptation of “Wicked,” Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) uses magic to defend her sister and unwittingly destroys a courtyard mural of the Wizard at Shiz University. When her outburst shatters the wall, it also unearths an image that has been intentionally covered up: the school’s original founders, animal professors whose ability to speak, teach humans, and organize politically posed a threat to the Wizard’s autocratic reign.

headline: Timothée Chalamet Joins a Rarified Club of Actors Singing in Musical Biopics
abstract: The actor’s vocals so impressed the film’s director that he used the live recordings, instead of prerecorded ones. Here’s a look at other actors who have hit their own high notes.
lead_paragraph: In one trailer for the upcoming Bob Dylan biopic, “A Complete Unknown,” a fan pleads with the musician, played by Timothée Chalamet, saying that she can’t hear the music at his sold-out concert.

headline: I Don’t Want a Pardon From Biden. None of Us Should.
abstract: We should show that we trust the fairness of the justice system.
lead_paragraph: In his 2023 book, “Government Gangsters,” Kash Patel, whom Donald Trump says he intends to nominate as the next director of the F.B.I., named 60 people whom he classified as “members of the executive branch deep state” — a “cabal of unelected tyrants” who posed “the most dangerous threat to our democracy.” Mr. Patel has since said that the incoming Trump administration must deal with the “deep state,” be it “criminally or civilly.”

headline: The Syrian Upheaval Has Iranian Leaders Reeling, Too
abstract: For decades, Iran poured money and military aid into Syria, backing the Assad regime in its ambition to confront Israel. Now many Iranians are openly asking why.
lead_paragraph: In the days since the abrupt and unexpected obliteration of Iran as a dominant presence in Syria, the government has faced a fierce public backlash over the billions of dollars spent and the Iranian blood shed to back the Assad regime.

headline: Tell Us What Brought You Joy in 2024
abstract: Where did you find comfort, joy, fun or just distraction this year?
lead_paragraph: Is there a movie, a book, a meme, a memory, a hobby you took up or a vice you quit that stayed with you this year, or helped you unwind and forget about everything else? Times Opinion wants to hear about it.

headline: Media Moguls Set the Stage for Deal Mania
abstract: Comcast and Warner Bros. Discovery are rearranging their businesses for mergers and acquisitions. Experts say the next year could transform the media industry.
lead_paragraph: The people in charge of the world’s biggest media companies are setting the stage for a flurry of deal making.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Dec. 13, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Waiting for a Test Result Can Be Brutal. Here’s How to Deal.
abstract: Anxious anticipation is natural, but there are things you can do to ease it.
lead_paragraph: Jancee Dunn is out this week. I’m Maxwell Strachan, an editor on the Well desk, filling in today.

headline: UnitedHealth Group C.E.O.: The Health Care System Is Flawed. Let’s Fix It.
abstract: No one would design a system like the one we have. And no one did.
lead_paragraph: As Brian Thompson’s family, friends and colleagues mourn his killing, we are bearing a grief and sadness we will carry for the rest of our lives. Grief for the family he leaves behind. And grief for a brilliant, kind man who was working to make health care better for everyone.

headline: The Fall of al-Assad Quickly Infuses Europe’s Debate Over Asylum
abstract: Nearly a million Syrians in Germany alone have made new lives. But after the fall of Bashar al-Assad, some politicians across the continent have suggested that refugees could return home.
lead_paragraph: Just hours after President Bashar al-Assad boarded a plane for Russia on Sunday, thousands of Syrians who had fled to escape his rule and the civil war to unseat him celebrated in the streets across Germany.

headline: Syrian Rebels Seize Large Captagon Factory
abstract: Rebel fighters found stockpiles of addictive pills, some hidden in fruit or furniture and ready for export as part of the Assad regime’s illegal drug operation.
lead_paragraph: Rebel fighters found stockpiles of addictive pills, some hidden in fruit or furniture and ready for export as part of the Assad regime’s illegal drug operation.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,274
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 552
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Turning Point for Ultraprocessed Foods
abstract: The wide-ranging category includes sodas, processed meats, many breakfast cereals, snack foods and frozen meals.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that nearly three-quarters of American adults are now obese or overweight, and there’s growing concern — among politicians, scientists and consumers — about one potential culprit: ultraprocessed foods.Alice Callahan, a nutrition and health reporter for The New York Times, discusses how these foods came to be such a big part of what we eat, and why that’s so hard to change.

headline: A Profile of the C.E.O. Killing Suspect, and Tech Giants Give to Trump Fund
abstract: Plus, a mystery in New Jersey’s skies.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Prince Andrew’s Links to Chinese Spy Suspect Are Revealed by U.K. Court
abstract: A London immigration court upheld a ban on a Chinese citizen described as a “close confidant” of the prince’s, on the grounds of national security.
lead_paragraph: Prince Andrew, the younger brother of King Charles III, has been caught up in a suspected case of Chinese spying, after a British court upheld a decision to bar from the country a Chinese man who was a “close confidant” of his on national security grounds.

headline: Emmanuel Macron Appoints Key Ally as France’s New Prime Minister
abstract: François Bayrou, a veteran centrist politician, is the fourth prime minister in a year, a record for France.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron on Friday tapped François Bayrou, a veteran centrist politician and one of his top allies, as the new prime minister,  a move that few expect would stabilize France’s roiling politics.

headline: The End Game in Ukraine
abstract: How the war could come to a close next year.
lead_paragraph: No matter who won the presidential election, the war in Ukraine was likely to end next year. Both Ukraine and Russia are running out of troops and struggling to call up more young men for the front lines. That reality always meant that 2025 would be a year of negotiations.

headline: TikTok’s Last Stand, Google’s Quantum Breakthrough and the Cult of Claude
abstract: “The president was given a very clear and easy opportunity to say, ‘Yes, I am going to save TikTok,’ and he absolutely did not say that.”
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, a panel of federal judges denied TikTok’s petition to overturn the law that could force the ban of the app in the United States. We walk through the judges reasoning and explain why TikTok’s First Amendment argument was unsuccessful. Then, Julian Kelly, the director of quantum hardware at Google Quantum AI, explains how close we are to quantum computers that can solve practical problems. Finally, we talk about a new sentiment sweeping Silicon Valley: affection for the chatbot Claude.

headline: Turkey Emerges as a Big Winner in the Wake of al-Assad’s Ouster
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had long worked with the rebels who overtook Damascus. His influence over Syria is now likely to grow.
lead_paragraph: In the messy aftermath of the fall of the Assad regime in Syria, many questions remain about the country’s future, but one thing is clear: Turkey has emerged as a winner, with more influence than ever over the rebels who now control most of Syria.

headline: Breaking the Cycle of Childhood Poverty in New York
abstract: Children’s Aid provides essential help with food and housing for families in New York City, where tens of thousands of children live in poverty.
lead_paragraph: New York State has one of the worst child poverty rates in the country. In New York City, one in every four children lives in poverty. Tens of thousands of children are not getting enough food to eat, and their families are struggling to make rent.

headline: Health Protections for Migrant Children in Custody Are Set to Expire
abstract: A 2022 legal settlement established requirements to protect the health of minors detained at segments of the southern border. It ends nine days after Donald Trump takes office.
lead_paragraph: A court-ordered system for protecting the health of children detained at the southern border, put in place two years ago after several children died in  custody, is set to expire nine days after Donald J. Trump takes office with plans to intensify the deportation of migrants.

headline: With al-Assad Gone, Syrians Seek Answers in an Underground Jail
abstract: Guided by cellphone flashlights, relatives searched a notorious lockup in Damascus for traces of loved ones who were snatched during the regime of Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: Her brother was pulled from his car at a military checkpoint nearly a decade ago, her brother-in-law dragged from his house by the police. Two of her cousins were arrested near the airport in the Syrian capital, Damascus. She said she never had heard from any of them again.

headline: Russia Hits Ukraine’s Energy Infrastructure in a Renewed Assault
abstract: Military analysts had speculated that Moscow could escalate such attacks as a show of force after the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, its ally.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a missile attack on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure early Friday, in an assault that President Volodymyr Zelensky described as “one of the largest strikes” on his country’s power facilities.

headline: Elon Musk and DOGE vs. Regulators
abstract: The billionaire has needled government agencies, armed with potential influence over their budgets. But some of these organizations are also looking into his interests.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk remains perhaps the most consequential figure in President-elect Donald Trump’s orbit, with a commission for cutting government spending headed by him and Vivek Ramaswamy — widely known by its acronym, DOGE — promising huge reductions.

headline: The Fed Is Stuck Fighting the Last War
abstract: Mired in a battle to contain surging prices, the central bank also needs to be nimble enough for the economic downturns to come, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The battle against inflation during the Biden years is almost behind us. But we’re in danger of learning the wrong lessons from it.

headline: A New Frontier in Paleontology for Profit: Selling Shares in a Stegosaurus
abstract: As academics fear being priced out of the fossil market, a private company announced that it aims to raise $13.75 million by selling shares in a stegosaurus fossil.
lead_paragraph: With dinosaur fossils fetching millions of dollars at recent auctions, it was perhaps inevitable: A private company said Friday that it had set the date for a public offering that will allow investors to buy shares in a stegosaurus fossil.

headline: Tired of Tipping? Holidays May Be the Exception.
abstract: Consumers have said they are confused and frustrated with tipping expectations generally. But, one expert says, “people generally want to feel more generous around the holidays.”
lead_paragraph: The tradition of holiday tips to thank service workers endures, even as Americans have gotten tired of the regular requests for tips the rest of the year.

headline: How Claude Became Tech Insiders’ Chatbot of Choice
abstract: A.I. insiders are falling for Claude, a chatbot from Anthropic. Is it a passing fad, or a preview of artificial relationships to come?
lead_paragraph: His fans rave about his sensitivity and wit. Some talk to him dozens of times a day — asking for advice about their jobs, their health, their relationships. They entrust him with their secrets, and consult him before making important decisions. Some refer to him as their best friend.

headline: 10 Great Thrillers Set in Remote, Hard-to-Reach Places
abstract: Ruth Ware, the author of “The Woman in Cabin 10,” recommends locked-room mysteries and psychological horrors by Agatha Christie, Stephen King, Andy Weir and more.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who’s read one of my novels knows, I adore a Setting with a capital S: a tropical island, a super yacht in the North Sea, a glass cabin in the woods, a cell in a high-security women’s prison — the more remote the better. Because what could be more fun than confining your characters somewhere they cannot escape, and then slowly tormenting them as the plot unfolds?

headline: Democrats Argue That the 2024 Election Actually Had Its Bright Spots
abstract: Some leaders have begun to put a sunnier spin on the November outcome by pointing to down-ballot victories — a possible sign that Democrats may not tear down their party after all.
lead_paragraph: For most Democrats, losing to Donald J. Trump was a devastating gut punch that sent them hurtling into the political abyss.

headline: Celebrate the Holidays Like You’re Frank Costanza
abstract: After an appearance on “Seinfeld” in 1997, the pole took on a life of its own as the embodiment of the anti-holiday spirit.
lead_paragraph: Let’s make a Festivus pole.

headline: What to Know About ‘The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim’
abstract: You don’t have to know an orc from a Mumakil to enjoy the new animated adventure, though it’ll certainly help.
lead_paragraph: If you would like to know who the Helm of Helm’s Deep is, you are in the right place.

headline: Mapo Ragù Is an Ideal Wintertime Feast
abstract: It’s a meat-sauce mashup of Chinese, Korean and Italian cuisine, sweet-salty and fiery all at once, with tangles of braised kale and chewy rice cakes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We hit Del Fiore in Rocky Point for late-morning sandwiches, Italian subs from the northeastern reaches of Brookhaven on Long Island, then pushed west along the Washington Spy Trail toward Port Jefferson, Setauket, Nissequogue, thinking about cooking all the way.

headline: ‘Tune Back In. Our Democracy Depends on It.’
abstract: Readers discuss staying involved during difficult times. Also: Supreme Court ethics; South Korea’s example; too much feedback; new friendships.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Under-the-Radar Philippine Island That Evokes 1970s Bali
abstract: A guide to Siargao, a surf spot turned luxury escape, with insider tips on where to find powdery beaches and coconut slushies.
lead_paragraph: Spend a few days in Siargao, the fig-shaped Philippine island in the country’s southeast, and locals will tell you, with a mix of anxiety and excitement, that the coconut tree-covered enclave is what Bali was in the 1970s. Or they might say, as the documentarian and trans-rights activist Queenmelo Esguerra told me last month, that laid-back hotels and cafes that’ve opened this decade (like Siago), “feel inspired by Tulum, no?”

headline: Critics Complain That Italy’s Government Is Interfering in the Arts
abstract: Italy’s culture ministry dismissed experts preparing an exhibition on Futurism and put in its own appointees, who created a show that seems to glorify the Mussolini years.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, hundreds thronged to Rome’s National Gallery of Modern and Contemporary Art for the highly anticipated opening of a major exhibition on Futurism, arguably Italy’s most notable contribution to 20th-century art. Coming on the heels of cubism, Futurist art broke with the past to capture the movement and dynamism of the modern age. Yet with its nationalistic and warmongering rhetoric, Futurism is also intertwined, in part, with Mussolini’s Fascist regime.

headline: How to Turn Up the Heat on Your Mulled Cocktails
abstract: A mulled white wine made with coriander, fennel and elderflower liqueur, a punchy nonalcoholic mulled cider, and mulled beer fortified with Cognac will make the season bright.
lead_paragraph: Cold weather makes a near universal case for hot drinks. Add in a festive season and mulled wine quickly enters the chat.

headline: Daniel Penny, Newly Acquitted, Will Join Vance and Trump at Army-Navy Game
abstract: Vice President-elect JD Vance said he invited Mr. Penny, a former Marine who had been charged in the death of a man he placed in a chokehold in a New York City subway car.
lead_paragraph: Vice President-elect JD Vance on Friday said that he had invited Daniel Penny, a former Marine who was acquitted this week on a charge of criminally negligent homicide after putting a man in a chokehold in a New York subway car, to attend the Army-Navy football game on Saturday with him.

headline: What the Polio Vaccine Has Meant for Public Health
abstract: A lawyer working with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has asked the F.D.A. to withdraw approval of the current shot because it hasn’t been tested against a placebo. Scientists say such a test would be unethical.
lead_paragraph: On the day in 1955 that Jonas Salk’s polio vaccine was pronounced “80 to 90 percent effective” against the form of the disease that caused paralysis, 500 medical scientists and 150 reporters jammed into an auditorium at the University of Michigan for the announcement. Pots clanged, horns honked and factory whistles blew around the country.

headline: Louis Nelson, Designer of Korean War Mural, Dies at 88
abstract: A designer of signage and product packaging, he was best known for his work on the 164-foot mural wall at the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Louis Nelson, an industrial designer who conceived a central element of the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington, drawing on his experiences as a peacetime Army officer and art student when he encountered veterans of the Korean conflict, died on Dec. 4 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: What Is Captagon, the Illegal Stimulant That Made al-Assad’s Syria a Narcostate?
abstract: The illegal amphetamine, used across the Middle East, became Syria’s biggest export during its 13-year civil war.
lead_paragraph: Rebel fighters in Syria said on Friday that they had found vast stockpiles of an illegal amphetamine called captagon in a Damascus warehouse.

headline: Elon Musk’s Playbook for DOGE Has a Precedent: X
abstract: Mr. Musk is wielding his X account to single out federal employees and agencies for cuts. He has used this method before.
lead_paragraph: Since President-elect Donald J. Trump last month named Elon Musk to help lead a new Department of Government Efficiency, the tech billionaire has turned to X to trumpet his plans.

headline: How the Wackiest, Most ‘Annoying’ Christmas Song Became a Hit
abstract: It started with a novelty songwriter stranded on a snowy night. Decades later, listeners still can’t get his tune, “Grandma Got Run Over By a Reindeer,” out of their heads.
lead_paragraph: On a cold and snowy night in November 1978, the members of Randy Brooks’s country band, Young Country, found themselves stranded after a gig at the Hyatt Hotel on the Nevada side of Lake Tahoe. The brakes on their van were frozen. With nowhere to go, Mr. Brooks and his bandmates went back inside to watch the next act, a bluegrass group fronted by the husband-and-wife duo of Elmo Shropshire and Patsy Trigg.

headline: Trump’s Treasury Pick Is Poised to Test ‘Three Arrows’ Economic Strategy
abstract: Scott Bessent’s “3-3-3” plan to stimulate growth, reduce the deficit and expand oil production will soon face economic realities.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe set out to rejuvenate Japan’s economy more than a decade ago, he laid out a strategy known as the “Three Arrows,” which aimed to banish deflation by easing monetary policy, increasing government spending and restructuring the economy so that it was poised for growth.

headline: OpenAI’s Sam Altman to Donate $1 Million to Trump’s Inaugural Fund
abstract: Mr. Altman and OpenAI have recently hired key executives who previously worked for the Clinton, Obama and Biden administrations.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Friday that its chief executive, Sam Altman, was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, joining a number of tech companies and executives who are working to improve their relationships with Mr. Trump.

headline: Harris to Deliver Speech Urging Young People to Stay Civically Engaged
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has kept a relatively low profile since she lost the election, will speak in Maryland on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has kept a low profile since she lost the presidential election, will give a speech in Maryland next week urging young people to stay civically engaged, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: Blinken Discusses Syria’s Future on Unannounced Visit to Iraq
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he talked with Iraq’s prime minister about the situation in Syria, including efforts to encourage Syria to transition to an inclusive, non-sectarian government.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he talked with Iraq’s prime minister about the situation in Syria, including efforts to encourage Syria to transition to an inclusive, non-sectarian government.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include an Irish drama about a pirate-queen, a found-footage movie made from lost Palestinian films, a coming-of-age thriller from Mexico and more.
lead_paragraph: Shot on 16 mm and drenched in aquamarine hues, the new film by Donal Foreman is a lovely and unclassifiable thing. Two women — an American filmmaker, Maire (Dale Dickey) and an Irish scholar, Cait (Judith Roddy) — go to a remote Irish island to make a film about a 16th-century pirate-queen, and are drawn into the shifting sands of reality and fiction, myth and history.

headline: Fortnite Players Get Millions in Refunds for Unwanted Purchases
abstract: Epic Games is making the payments, which average about $114, after settling accusations from the federal government that the studio tricked people into buying in-game items.
lead_paragraph: Fortnite players who were charged for unwanted purchases in the game where cartoony characters battle on a virtual island are starting to receive what could be $245 million in refunds from Epic Games for what the federal government called manipulative online practices.

headline: Gillibrand Presses Biden to Amend the Constitution to Enshrine Sex Equality
abstract: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York is leading the charge for Democrats to persuade President Biden to adopt the Equal Rights Amendment, which would invite a Supreme Court battle.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York is on a mission in President Biden’s final days in office. She wants to convince him that he can rescue his legacy by adding the century-old Equal Rights Amendment, which would explicitly guarantee sex equality, to the Constitution as a way to protect abortion rights in post-Roe America.

headline: McKinsey to Pay $650 Million in Opioid Settlement With Justice Department
abstract: A former senior partner will also plead guilty to obstruction of justice after destroying company documents.
lead_paragraph: McKinsey & Company has agreed to pay $650 million to settle a Justice Department investigation of its work with the opioid maker Purdue Pharma. A former senior partner has also agreed to plead guilty to obstruction of justice for destroying internal company records in connection with that work.

headline: Bank of America Flagged Suspicious Payments to Epstein Only After He Died
abstract: Senate staff members are urging that Bank of America be investigated for the way it reported payments to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier.
lead_paragraph: When Bank of America alerted financial regulators in 2020 to potentially suspicious payments from Leon Black, the billionaire investor, to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier, the bank was following a routine practice.The bank filed two “suspicious activity reports,” or SARs, which are meant to alert law enforcement to potential criminal activities like money laundering, terrorism financing or sex trafficking. One was filed in February 2020 and the other eight months later, according to a congressional memorandum reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Can Berlin Really Afford 3 ‘Magic Flutes’ in a Single Week?
abstract: Each of the city’s opera houses is presenting a different production of the Mozart classic. With arts cuts looming, it looks like a last hurrah.
lead_paragraph: Opera has always tended toward grandeur. Berlin, home to three world-class opera houses, regularly takes things to the next level.

headline: Pelosi Hospitalized in Luxembourg After Falling
abstract: A person familiar with the incident said the former House speaker, 84, had tripped going down stairs at a palace. People close to her said she had fractured her hip in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi was hospitalized on Friday after being injured while traveling abroad on a bipartisan congressional delegation to Luxembourg, a spokesman said on Friday.

headline: Most Americans Say They Have Good Health Insurance, Polls Show
abstract: Many have encountered problems with their coverage, but the recent rage on social media is only part of the picture of Americans’ views on health care.
lead_paragraph: Americans voted last month in an election that polls showed was largely about the economy. Less than 1 percent of likely voters ranked health care as their top issue.

headline: Review: Reveling in a Wry Storybook, Full of Characters
abstract: The choreographer Tess Dworman inhabits an assortment of people (and an ottoman) in her dance-theater work “Everything Must Go.”
lead_paragraph: Tess Dworman is rarely just Tess Dworman. This choreographer and dancer is a shape-shifter with a biting wit. She inhabits other people as if she were flipping through sketches and bringing them to life. You grasp who they are through Dworman’s delivery, an endearing mix of sharp and guileless.

headline: Avant Gardner, Troubled Brooklyn Venue, Promises Security Changes in Major Renovation
abstract: The planned overhaul comes more than a year after two patrons who left the mega-club were found dead nearby.
lead_paragraph: The new chief executive of Avant Gardner, one of Brooklyn’s largest event venues, said the company was overhauling the space and making sweeping security changes. The overhaul comes during a fraught period for the venue, including the deaths of two patrons found nearby last year.

headline: A Stunning Year in Sports: Caitlin Clark, Shohei Ohtani and Record Viewership
abstract: It was also a year highlighted by the pageantry and competition of the Paris Olympics.
lead_paragraph: In sports this year, everything was richer, brighter, bigger.

headline: Martial Solal, French Jazz Piano Virtuoso, Is Dead at 97
abstract: Mr. Solal, who also wrote music for films and symphony orchestras, was revered in Europe and hailed in the United States on his rare visits there.
lead_paragraph: Martial Solal, Europe’s pre-eminent jazz pianist, who recorded dozens of startlingly original albums in a career of almost three quarters of a century and who wrote scores for numerous films, including Jean-Luc Godard’s masterpiece “Breathless,” died on Thursday in Versailles, France. He was 97.

headline: F.B.I. Passed Tip About Mangione to New York Police After C.E.O. Killing
abstract: It was unclear when the information arrived, or whether it would have helped speed an arrest in the death of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare.
lead_paragraph: Investigators received a tip from the San Francisco Police Department identifying Luigi Mangione as a suspect before he was arrested in the killing of an insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan, the New York F.B.I. field office said Friday.

headline: A Very Senatorial Goodbye: Nostalgia, Legacy and Gratitude, Live on C-SPAN
abstract: The farewell address is a Senate ritual that reflects the culture of the chamber, which prizes tradition, individual relationships, lofty debates and long-winded speeches.
lead_paragraph: The way Senator Joe Manchin III tells it, the senatorial bashes he hosted on his beloved houseboat Almost Heaven were so good they could inspire the most liberal of Democrats and the most conservative of Republicans to start writing bills together.

headline: What Song Did You Discover, or Rediscover, in 2024?
abstract: We want to know why it resonated with you.
lead_paragraph: In a recent edition of The Amplifier newsletter, Lindsay Zoladz shared the music that shaped her year. She rediscovered a classic from the Smiths thanks to a karaoke party, dug into Neil Young’s back catalog after seeing him in concert, and revisited a Frank Sinatra standard because it reminded her of a cherished trip to Vermont.

headline: U.S. Considered Border Buoys Months Before Texas Put Them In
abstract: Border officials explored using floating barriers from Texas to California in 2022. The effort could help pave the way for their deployment under President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: On the U.S.-Mexico border, they are perhaps the most visible symbol of Gov. Greg Abbott’s effort to deter migrants from entering Texas: giant, orange buoys floating in the Rio Grande, designed to make it harder to cross.

headline: The Messy Modern Music Business, According to Larry Jackson
abstract: On this week’s episode of Popcast, an interview with a record label veteran who has worked closely with Whitney Houston, Drake, Chief Keef and Lana Del Rey.
lead_paragraph: The music executive Larry Jackson, a founder of the entertainment company Gamma, has seen several sea changes in the recording business from different vantages over different eras of disruption.

headline: 10 Songs That Explain My Year
abstract: A musical memoir of our critic’s 2024, with tracks from MJ Lenderman, Cass Elliot and Women.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I shared a massive playlist of some of the best music released in 2024 — over 100 tracks, selected by Times music critics, from our lists of the year’s greatest albums and songs. Today, it’s time for another end-of-year Amplifier tradition: my playlist of older songs that defined my year.

headline: Hochul Launches Investigation Into Drone Sightings in New York
abstract: The governor made the announcement on Friday as sightings spread across New York and New Jersey. State and federal authorities said the flying objects posed no threat to the public.
lead_paragraph: As reports of drone sightings continued to spread across New Jersey and New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Friday said she was investigating the matter with federal law enforcement agencies.

headline: Patel Distorts Justice Dept. Benghazi Inquiry, Inflating His Role
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s pick to be the next F.B.I. director has both exaggerated his importance in the government’s criminal inquiry into the 2012 attack and misleadingly distorted its conduct and results.
lead_paragraph: Kash Patel, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to be F.B.I. director, often burnishes his credentials as a former prosecutor even as he portrays law enforcement agencies as an inept and politicized “deep state.” A critical piece of that narrative is the investigation into the 2012 attack on a diplomatic compound and a C.I.A. annex in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.

headline: Do I Have to Tell My Boyfriend I’ve Been Paid for Sex?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the kinds of information romantic partners deserve to know about one another’s pasts.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when I was struggling with addiction, I would occasionally (once a month or less) engage in sex work to help make ends meet. This was voluntary — no one made me do anything I didn’t want to do — but it’s still uncomfortable for me to think about sometimes. I always used protection during these encounters and continue to get screened for S.T.D.s regularly. If anything, I think I’m slightly less likely than the general population is to pass anything on.

headline: America’s Health Care System Needs Better Economics, Not Bullets
abstract: If only fixing it were as easy as finding someone to blame.
lead_paragraph: I can predict when one of my newsletters is going to divide a lot of readers. This is one of them. I’m going to argue that the problem with health insurance and the health care system overall is misaligned incentives. It is, in other words, a problem of structure, not any individual’s morality. Evil should not be part of the conversation. Nor — and I hate to have to say this — should killing.

headline: A Murder in Midtown Sent the Police Scrambling. Reporters Weren’t Far Behind.
abstract: A reporter’s ability to develop sources is important amid events like the shooting death of Brian Thompson and the search for his killer.
lead_paragraph: The early morning shooting death of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, on a Manhattan sidewalk last week shocked the nation, and sent law enforcement on a mad scramble to find the killer.

headline: Eric Adams’s Advisers Are Trying to Get Him a Trump Inauguration Ticket
abstract: Members of the Democratic mayor’s team have put out the word to New York Republicans that he is interested in attending Donald J. Trump’s swearing-in.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has spent weeks inching closer to President-elect Donald J. Trump, flouting the concerns of many fellow Democrats.

headline: Miley Cyrus Gives Showgirl Pathos, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Benjamin Booker, Julien Baker and Torres, and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Dec. 14, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Syrians Celebrate in Damascus During Friday Prayers
abstract: Joyful chants erupted in and around the historic Umayyad Mosque in Syria’s capital as large crowds gathered to pray and celebrate the country’s newfound sense of liberty.
lead_paragraph: Joyful chants erupted in and around the historic Umayyad Mosque in Syria’s capital as large crowds gathered to pray and celebrate the country’s newfound sense of liberty.

headline: Our Book Critics on What Stuck With Them in 2024
abstract: Dwight Garner, Jennifer Szalai and Alexandra Jacobs discuss highlights from their year in books.
lead_paragraph: “This year’s best books mattered because they offered refuge from the wheels grinding in our heads,” writes Dwight Garner in a piece in which the Book Review’s three staff critics look back on their years in reading. Jennifer Szalai and Alexandra Jacobs joined him in conversation with Book Review editor Gilbert Cruz to reflect on their 2024 reading.

headline: Conan O’Brien’s Parents Die 3 Days Apart
abstract: Thomas O’Brien, an epidemiologist, and Ruth O’Brien, a lawyer, juggled successful careers with raising six children, including the comedy star.
lead_paragraph: The parents of Conan O’Brien, the longtime late-night television host and a star in the comedy world, died this week within days of one another.

headline: Jerome Kohn, Keeper of Hannah Arendt’s Flame, Dies at 93
abstract: He devoted his career to guarding the legacy of the philosopher known for her writings on totalitarianism and “the banality of evil.”
lead_paragraph: Jerome Kohn, who devoted his career to decoding, defending and disseminating the work of Hannah Arendt, the provocative philosopher who diagnosed the roots of 20th-century totalitarianism and who controvertibly wrote that the convicted Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann embodied “the banality of evil,” died on Nov. 8 in Bay Shore, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 93.

headline: This Chef’s Stunning Christmas Spread Is Unexpectedly Effortless
abstract: Anchored by juicy braised duck and finished with an unforgettable family-size crème brûlée, this menu from Clare de Boer will have everyone talking.
lead_paragraph: A feast is only a feast if both effort and bounty are shared.

headline: Bill Belichick Has Stores Cutting the Sleeves Off Sweatshirts
abstract: Chapel Hill has embraced North Carolina’s hiring of a legendary N.F.L. coach, with “Chapel Bill” shirts and cutoff hoodies.
lead_paragraph: As rumors circulated this week that Bill Belichick could become the new football coach at the University of North Carolina, Jamie Mottram knew that his company needed to be prepared.

headline: Judge Says Former ByteDance Executive Lied in Suit Against Company
abstract: A judge said this week that a former executive at ByteDance seemed to have fabricated evidence and submitted false statements in a high-profile 2023 lawsuit against the company.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in San Francisco said on Thursday that a former executive at ByteDance lied in statements to the court and seemed to have fabricated an important witness in a high-profile case against the company.

headline: Charles Handy Dies at 92; Philosopher Envisioned Today’s Corporate World
abstract: Joining a pantheon of management thinkers, he embraced a humanistic path for business and foresaw outsourcing, remote work and a gig economy.
lead_paragraph: Charles Handy, a writer, social philosopher and management theorist who presciently imagined a brave new corporate world where employees worked remotely, jobs were outsourced and workers had “portfolio careers,” working for themselves and contracting their skills to companies, died on Friday at his home in London. He was 92.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to California Tailpipe Emissions Limits
abstract: The justices agreed to decide whether industry groups have suffered the sort of injury that gave them standing to sue over an unusual waiver.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to consider whether business groups may challenge an unusual federal program that lets California set its own limits on tailpipe emissions to combat climate change.

headline: Syrians Celebrated a New Chapter
abstract: Also, McKinsey will pay $650 million in an opioid settlement. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Jubilant crowds gathered today in cities across Syria for the first Friday Prayer since rebels toppled President Bashar al-Assad. Elsewhere in the country, Russia’s military appeared to be packing up equipment at a critical base.

headline: It’s Going to Be Normal to Have Extreme Beliefs
abstract: What the fascination with a C.E.O.’s killing reveals about this political era.
lead_paragraph: I promise not to make every installment of this newsletter a further elaboration on what it means to live after the post-Cold War liberal order, in a world where a certain kind of neoliberal consensus politics has dissolved without any new consensus sweeping in to take its place. But I’ll go once more to the well for the case of Luigi Mangione, who has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, Brian Thompson, and who has become a source of general fascination and, to some, a peculiar kind of outlaw hero.

headline: McConnell Defends Polio Vaccine, an Apparent Warning to Kennedy
abstract: “Efforts to undermine public confidence in proven cures are not just uninformed — they’re dangerous,” said the Republican leader, who is a polio survivor.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader and a survivor of polio, issued a pointed statement in support of the polio vaccine on Friday, hours after The New York Times reported that the lawyer for Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has petitioned federal regulators to withdraw the vaccine from the market.

headline: Tim Cook Dines With Trump at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: The chief executive of Apple is the latest in a series of technology  executives who are traveling to Florida to meet with the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Tim Cook held a meeting on Friday with Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago, marking the first time that Apple’s chief executive has met with the president-elect since voters elected him to a second term last month.

headline: Texas Attorney General Sues New York Doctor for Mailing Abortion Pills
abstract: The lawsuit appeared to be among the first attempts to stop doctors from mailing the medication to states that ban abortions.
lead_paragraph: The Texas attorney general opened a new front in the contentious battle over access to abortion this week by suing a New York doctor for sending abortion pills into Texas. It appeared to be among the first attempts to stop the mailing of such medication into states that ban abortion.

headline: Tell Us: What’s Your Favorite Movie About Politics?
abstract: Share your pick with the On Politics newsletter.
lead_paragraph: You might be tired of politics after this roller coaster of a presidential election. Maybe you’ve tried escaping to the movies — only to find that some of the season’s marquee releases, like “Gladiator II” or the Ralph Fiennes pope thriller “Conclave,” are themselves about campaigns, conniving and democracy’s viability.

headline: Rodney Jenkins, Star of the Show-Jumping Circuit, Dies at 80
abstract: He had a feel for how horses behaved and thought, and won more than 70 Grand Prix events.
lead_paragraph: Rodney Jenkins, an equestrian who dominated shows in the 1970s and ’80s by deftly guiding horses in competition with a rare feel for their abilities and thoughts, died on Dec. 5 at his home in Maryland. He was 80.

headline: Trump Ordered to Sit for Deposition in ABC News Defamation Suit
abstract: The deposition, if it is held as scheduled next week, will take place even as the president-elect is in the throes of defending cabinet nominees and putting together his administration.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump was ordered by a federal judge on Friday to sit for a deposition next week in the defamation lawsuit he brought this spring against ABC News and one of its anchors, George Stephanopoulos.

headline: Joy Buoys Syria’s First Friday Prayers Since Assad Ouster, but Hardships Loom
abstract: In an impoverished, war-ravaged country, the first prayers after the fall of a brutal regime drew jubilant crowds, even in areas seen as regime strongholds.
lead_paragraph: Jubilant crowds gathered in cities across Syria for the first Friday Prayers since rebels toppled President Bashar al-Assad, including at the historic Umayyad Mosque in the capital, where civilians and fighters worshiped side by side and joyful chants erupted over the collapse of a long authoritarian dynasty.

headline: OpenAI Fires Back at Elon Musk’s Lawsuit
abstract: The artificial intelligence start-up argues that Mr. Musk is trying to hamstring its business as he builds a rival company.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Elon Musk asked a federal court to block OpenAI’s efforts to transform itself from a nonprofit into a purely for-profit company.

headline: The Texas Millennial Trying to Rebrand the Democrats
abstract: “We can’t bring a policy book to a gunfight,” said Representative Greg Casar of Texas, the incoming chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
lead_paragraph: Ever since they lost big in November, Democrats have talked about how much their party needs to change.

headline: U.S. Officials Say Sightings Are Mix of Planes, Stars and Legal Drones
abstract: Reports of flying objects continue to occur throughout the Northeast, but the authorities say they do not pose a threat. Here’s what we know.
lead_paragraph: Bright lights floating or flying in the night sky above New Jersey are a combination of airplanes, helicopters, stars and drones being flown legally, four federal agencies said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Paula Abdul Settles Sexual Assault Lawsuit Against Nigel Lythgoe
abstract: Mr. Lythgoe, a producer she worked with on “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance,” had vehemently denied her allegations.
lead_paragraph: Paula Abdul and Nigel Lythgoe, a television producer, have settled a lawsuit that Abdul filed accusing him of sexually assaulting her when they worked together on “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance.”

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Catholic Charity’s Bid for Tax Exemption
abstract: The justices agreed to hear an appeal from a Wisconsin Supreme Court ruling that the charity’s activities were insufficiently religious to qualify.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Wisconsin was free to deny a tax exemption to a Catholic charity on the grounds that its activities were not primarily religious.

headline: Gerd Heidemann, Journalist Duped by Fake Hitler Diaries, Dies at 93
abstract: What was supposed to be the crowning scoop of his career became his downfall when a trove of notebooks he acquired in Germany turned out to be forgeries.
lead_paragraph: Gerd Heidemann, a globe-trotting, high-flying German journalist who thought he had landed the scoop of the century — the private diaries of Adolf Hitler — but who came crashing back to earth after they were exposed as crude forgeries, died on Monday at a hospital in Hamburg, Germany. He was 93.

headline: U.S. Court Denies TikTok’s Request to Freeze Sale-or-Ban Law
abstract: TikTok had sought to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent to sell the app or face a U.S. ban next month. The case may now head to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A federal court on Friday denied TikTok’s request to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a ban in the United States as of Jan. 19, a decision that puts the fate of the app in the Supreme Court’s hands.

headline: Biden Administration Is Said to Allow California to Ban New Gas-Powered Cars
abstract: California and 11 other states want to halt the sale of new gas-powered cars by 2035. President-elect Donald Trump is expected to try to stop them.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is expected in the coming days to grant California and 11 other states permission to ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, one of the most ambitious climate policies in the United States and beyond, according to three people briefed on the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it publicly.

headline: Timothée Chalamet Dresses Like Bob Dylan at ‘A Complete Unknown’ New York Premiere
abstract: The actor also joined Elle Fanning and Edward Norton — stars of a new film tracing the musician’s ascent — for an after-party at the Chelsea Hotel.
lead_paragraph: “I saw him,” said Charlotte Barbié, 18, who stood outside the SVA Theater on Friday night, shaking from either the cold or the excitement. “He was blond.”

headline: Tea Supplier
abstract: Owen Bergstein makes a proud debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent, sure-footed challenge from Owen Bergstein, a new constructor to The New York Times. There’s a lot of whimsy, but the cuteness is intertwined with tough stuff, too difficult to be saccharine. There are lots of odd expressions in the long entries, yes, but they really work on a Saturday. I have to tip my hat when I don’t know where an entry is going after I have six of 11 letters, for instance, and then find that the right answer is a commonplace reference.

headline: C.E.O.’s Killing Poses Early Test for New N.Y.P.D. Commissioner
abstract: Weeks ago, Jessica Tisch was in charge of street sweeping and trash pickup. On Monday, she found herself overseeing a ferocious manhunt as the head of the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Jessica S. Tisch, New York’s police commissioner, was giving her two sons their morning cereal on Dec. 4 when she got a text from a deputy telling her that the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare had been shot dead on a Manhattan sidewalk.

headline: The Message: Impeach South Korea’s President. The Tune: ‘Feliz Navidad.’
abstract: Baek Jae Gil, whose viral anthem calls for the ouster of President Yoon Suk Yeol, has a long history with the country’s pro-democracy movement.
lead_paragraph: While calling for President Yoon Suk Yeol’s removal, tens of thousands of South Korean protesters have danced to traditional percussion, sung a pop genre called trot and blasted “Whiplash,” a hit by the girl group Aespa.

headline: Quote of the Day: Europeans Eye Giving Syrians A Nudge Home
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “When I was born, that statue was there, and I’ve been wanting to remove it my entire life.”

headline: The Art of the Gift: Julio Torres
abstract: “A good gift is like a bridge between two people,” the creator of “Los Espookys” said. “It’s a way of communicating, ‘You are on my mind when you’re not in front of me.’”
lead_paragraph: Known for his surrealist comedy, the El Salvador-born, Brooklyn-based performer Julio Torres, 37, is a former staff writer on “Saturday Night Live” and the co-creator of the HBO series “Los Espookys.” He most recently wrote, directed and starred in the film “Problemista” and the HBO series “Fantasmas.” This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Dancing in the Park: How an M.T.A. Worker Spreads Joy
abstract: For eight years, Anthony Johnson has danced to Soca and disco music in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. He has a loyal following.
lead_paragraph: Even in New York City, where more than eight million people are largely accustomed to sticking to themselves and often expect the worst from each other, it’s possible to build a relationship with a stranger.

headline: How a Children’s Tennis Instructor Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Joyce Short, who has worked with New York Junior Tennis and Learning for decades, takes a popcorn break in between classes, and plays pickleball with friends.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Short, 77, has survived many things.

headline: As the Right Lionizes Daniel Penny, His Prosecutor Faces a Familiar Fury
abstract: Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney who won a conviction of Donald J. Trump, has been a target of the right. After Mr. Penny’s acquittal in a subway choking, Mr. Bragg faces fresh anger.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Penny broke into a smile at midmorning Monday, hugging both of his lawyers in a Manhattan courtroom and getting a kiss on the cheek from one. Moments before, a jury forewoman had said Mr. Penny was not guilty of criminally negligent homicide in the death of a homeless subway passenger he had restrained in a chokehold last year.

headline: Where It Isn’t Christmas Until the City Shoots Lasers at 20,000 Crows
abstract: In Rochester, N.Y., every year in early December thousands of crows descend on the city, which tries to shoo them away with loud noises and bright lights.
lead_paragraph: In Rochester, N.Y., there are telltale signs that the holiday season is underway.

headline: How the President Alienated South Korea, One Group at a Time
abstract: Even before Yoon Suk Yeol’s fateful decree, the public had been infuriated with near-constant scandals and unpopular decisions since he took office.
lead_paragraph: Even before Yoon Suk Yeol’s fateful decree, the public had been infuriated with near-constant scandals and unpopular decisions since he took office.

headline: Saving England’s Music Oasis From a New Wave of Development
abstract: The working-class city of Manchester has birthed legendary bands for decades. But in its quest for growth, its musical legacy is in danger of being muted.
lead_paragraph: Glass towers crowd the skyline in Manchester, encroaching a bit more each year on the legacy of this northern English city with a musical soul.

headline: Guggenheim Offers the Poetry of Motion: Sign Language Verses
abstract: The museum’s poet in residence for 2024 is putting poetry by deaf and hard-of-hearing artists on display.
lead_paragraph: Noah Buchholz, a deaf poet, was standing on a stage on the ground floor of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Wednesday night, with a gentle smile.

headline: 4 Mysteries Shot Through With Malice and Grief
abstract: Our columnist on the month’s best new releases.
lead_paragraph: Pek’s debut “The Verifiers” was the book I most wanted to review in 2022, but didn’t. It wasn’t perfect, but I admired the fresh, sweetly sardonic voice of the amateur sleuth and mystery-novel aficionado Claudia Lin, as well as the way Pek raised questions about living, dating and lying online.

headline: Here Comes the Bride (Just Not to That Song)
abstract: More couples are skipping the traditional processional to Richard Wagner’s “Bridal Chorus.”
lead_paragraph: When Becky Pedroza began planning her wedding, she imagined a celebration as vibrant and free-spirited as her relationship with Erik Revelli.

headline: The Trump Show Is Returning. Will It Be Triumph, Tragedy or Farce?
abstract: TV has fixated on one person, as news, comedy material and dramatic subtext, since 2015. Can it do another four years?
lead_paragraph: On his last show before Election Day, John Oliver allowed himself to dream a little dream. Mr. Oliver, whose “Last Week Tonight” speaks to a mostly left-of-center crowd, spent most of the episode making the case for Kamala Harris. But also, he asked his audience, wouldn’t it be nice, for the first time since 2015, to have the option of simply ignoring Donald J. Trump’s existence? “I want so badly to live in that world!” he said.

headline: To Dial Down Campus Tensions, Colleges Teach the Art of Conversation
abstract: Dialogue is an essential part of college. As anger over the war in the Middle East has brought upheaval to campuses, it has also become a key way schools try to reduce conflict.
lead_paragraph: On a warm November day, a group of Columbia University professors set up “listening tables” near the center of campus and hailed students rushing to class, inviting them to stop and talk.

headline: Are Childhood Vaccines ‘Overloading’ the Immune System? No.
abstract: Vaccines today are more efficient and contain far fewer stimulants to the immune system than some used decades ago.
lead_paragraph: It’s an idea as popular as it is incorrect: American babies now receive too many vaccines, which overwhelm their immune systems and lead to conditions like autism.

headline: Richard Gere Calls ‘Blonde on Blonde’ His All-Time Favorite
abstract: “He’s our Picasso,” the actor said of Bob Dylan.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than four decades since an Armani-clad Richard Gere slunk around Los Angeles in Paul Schrader’s “American Gigolo.”

headline: The Joy of Bundling Up
abstract: As winter approaches, strolls around Central Park offer a leisurely way to take in the festive and cozy attire of the season.
lead_paragraph: The storybook holiday season in New York brings a certain coziness to Central Park, even as the landscape’s palette fades from autumnal reds, oranges and yellows to muted greens and browns. Stroll around and you are likely to spot telltale signs of wintertime in the city: couples bundled up for a long walk, families dressed to ice-skate, tourists looking for landmarks and tiny nooks featured in films like “Home Alone 2: Lost in New York.”

headline: An Art World Satire Invokes a (Literal) Ghost
abstract: In Ella Baxter’s novel “Woo Woo,” a feminist performance artist starts to question herself on the eve of a provocative solo exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Sabine Rossi is a week out from the opening of her solo art exhibition at a gallery in Melbourne, Australia, at the start of Ella Baxter’s second novel, “Woo Woo.” Each of the show’s 15 photographs depicts the artist in a costume comprising the mask of a female archetype and a sheer “skin” — a “wearable puppet” — that sheathes her body without concealing it.

headline: A Surprise Blockbuster in Brazil Stokes Oscar Hopes, and a Reckoning
abstract: Decades after her mother missed out on an Oscar, Brazil’s Fernanda Torres may have a chance to win a golden statuette with a role in a film that has set off deep soul-searching.
lead_paragraph: Fernanda Torres still remembers the day her mother, Brazil’s grande dame of film, came within reach of cinema’s most coveted prize: an Oscar.

headline: Another New Twitter? Good Luck With That.
abstract: Users are now flocking to Bluesky. But every social media platform becomes a wasteland in the end.
lead_paragraph: Recently, while talking to a friend who used to run a large media website, I casually mentioned the rise of Bluesky. More than a million users have deleted their X (formerly Twitter) accounts and moved over to the upstart social media site, which they see as a healthier replacement.

headline: A Postal Strike Means Fewer Gifts Under Canadian Christmas Trees
abstract: For many remote communities in the sparsely populated nation, Canada Post is the only parcel delivery option. Even Amazon relies on it.
lead_paragraph: Every Christmas season, Elizabeth Teasdale sets aside an entire room in her house on Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia to store presents for her family’s large holiday gathering. By now, 20 to 30 packages should be stashed away.

headline: ‘Home Alone’ Hits the Road, With Macaulay Culkin. ‘Filthy Animals’ Cheer.
abstract: In Chicago, where the suburbs served as locations, a showing of the film featured an appearance by the star. Delighted fans made their devotion known.
lead_paragraph: It has been 34 years since Kevin McAllister paint-canned two sour-faced bandits in “Home Alone.” And every Christmas since, fans have taken self-made tours of suburban Chicago sites in the classic holiday movie, which finds 8-year-old Kevin defending himself against robbers after his family leaves for a vacation without him. The stately residence where exteriors were shot in Winnetka, Ill., is the area’s top tourist attraction, with thousands of visitors annually.

headline: A.T.F. Braces for a Likely Rollback of Its Gun-Control Efforts
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is almost certain to choose a gun-rights advocate as director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives or to simply leave the job vacant.
lead_paragraph: Many federal agencies are bracing for the Trump era — but few are likely to face the powerful backlash that awaits the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which pursued an aggressive gun control agenda under President Biden.

headline: My Apartment Is Way Too Cold! How Do I Make the Landlord Fix It?
abstract: If your rental is not properly heated, gather your neighbors and complain together.
lead_paragraph: Q: We live in one of many Manhattan market-rate prewar rental buildings owned by a real estate family. We always had enough heat. Then the family hired a third-party management company. Now, a new heating system provides the legal minimum of 68.2 degrees of heat. At times, the heat rises, but not for very long. We are miserably cold. Many tenants here and elsewhere have complained. What can we do without provoking management retaliation? We fear our lease won’t be renewed if we speak up.

headline: In Port Labor Dispute, Trump Backed a Union That Courted Him
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is supporting the International Longshoremen’s Association, which could strike soon if it doesn’t reach a deal on automation with employers.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of some labor unions tried to establish good relations with Donald J. Trump before the election — and for one of them, that effort may already be paying off.

headline: Searching for Syria’s Disappeared
abstract: Taher al-Zain’s father disappeared 12 years ago at the height of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Now, like thousands of other Syrians, he is trying to find clues about what happened, and whether or not his father may still be alive.
lead_paragraph: Taher al-Zain’s father disappeared 12 years ago at the height of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Now, like thousands of other Syrians, he is trying to find clues about what happened, and whether or not his father may still be alive.

headline: Why Democrats Lost More Seats in Vermont Than Any Other State
abstract: Even though Kamala Harris easily won the state, voters ousted more than two dozen Democratic legislators, who they felt had not addressed an affordability crisis.
