lead_paragraph: It was no surprise that most voters in Vermont rejected Donald J. Trump on Election Day, favoring Vice President Kamala Harris by a margin of more than 30 points.

headline: An Artist Who Has Something in Common With Her Subjects
abstract: Rachel Handlin is possibly the first person with Down syndrome to receive an M.F.A., and one of just a few to hold a bachelor’s. Her first solo show features her portraits of others like her.
lead_paragraph: On the evening in early November when I met the artist Rachel Handlin at White Columns, the prestigious nonprofit gallery in the West Village, she immediately outstretched her arms.

headline: Cajole, Plead and Flatter: Ukraine Makes Its Case to Trump
abstract: Using diplomacy, flattery and the occasional shot in the dark, Ukraine is doing everything it can to win over President-elect Donald J. Trump to its side.
lead_paragraph: From desperate stabs at diplomacy to fanciful expressions of flattery, Ukrainian officials are doing everything they can to bring President-elect Donald J. Trump into their corner as they try to strengthen their position in the war against Russia.

headline: Trump’s Transition Business Largely Happens After Night Falls
abstract: At his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida, the president-elect has been hosting diplomatic dinners, announcing cabinet picks and firing off texts to his aides — all after the sun goes down.
lead_paragraph: It was past midnight in Florida this week when President-elect Donald J. Trump decided to mock Justin Trudeau on social media, calling the prime minister of America’s neighbor the “governor” of “the Great State of Canada.”

headline: In Display of Fealty, Tech Industry Curries Favor With Trump
abstract: It was a week of frenzied activity, as Silicon Valley billionaires and their companies brandished checks and compliments for the President-elect.
lead_paragraph: The $1 million donations came gradually — and then all at once.

headline: Syria Shudders as Assad’s Prison Atrocities Come Into the Light
abstract: At the country’s most notorious prison, Syrians confront their worst fears: that they will never know what happened to the loved ones who disappeared.
lead_paragraph: People came by the thousands the day after the rebels arrived in Damascus, racing down the once desolate stretch of road, up a jagged footpath cut into the limestone hillside and through the towering metal gates of Syria’s most notorious prison. They flooded the halls lined with cells, searching for loved ones who had disappeared into the black hole of torture prisons under Bashar al-Assad’s government.

headline: Rick Steves Refuses to Get Cynical About the World
abstract: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.
lead_paragraph: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.

headline: Rick Steves Refuses to Get Cynical About the World
abstract: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, just after I graduated from college, I put on a backpack and set off to see the world. I climbed the Andes in Ecuador, taught English in Cambodia and spent months visiting monasteries in Tibet. It was the most transformative period of my life.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,275
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 553
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Rare Cross-Canada Political Consensus Forms Against Trump’s Border Threat
abstract: Canadian leaders agreed to tighten the border, but not on how to respond if President-elect Donald J. Trump follows through on 25 percent tariffs.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Chrystia Freeland, the finance minister and deputy prime minister, will present her much-delayed fall economic statement just in time for the holidays. And the government has promised that it will address the issue that preoccupied politicians this week: how to respond to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to impose potentially devastating 25 percent tariffs on exports to the United States from Canada and Mexico unless the two nations tighten their borders.

headline: Sweet Season
abstract: The holidays are upon us. It’s time to start baking.
lead_paragraph: Cookie hive, assemble. Why? Because it’s the most wonderful time of the year.

headline: Palestinian Authority Deploys Security Forces Against Militants in West Bank
abstract: The authority, which has struggled to crack down on powerful armed groups in the territory, is under pressure from the United States to escalate law-and-order operations.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian Authority announced an unusually public crackdown on militants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Saturday, sending armored vehicles through a city’s streets and engaging in gun battles with armed groups.

headline: Moody’s Downgrades France’s Credit Rating, Citing Political Turmoil
abstract: The action, which will put pressure on the nation’s borrowing costs, reflects doubt that a new government can mend the deteriorating financial situation.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise announcement, Moody’s rating agency downgraded France’s debt rating early Saturday, hours after President Emmanuel Macron appointed a new prime minister in a bid to stabilize a government that has been rocked by months of political turmoil.

headline: U.S. in Direct Contact With Rebels Who Took Over Syria
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the United States was communicating directly with Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, the dominant rebel faction, despite its designation as a terrorist group.
lead_paragraph: The United States has been in direct contact with the Syrian rebel group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which overthrew the dictatorship of Bashar al-Assad a week ago, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Saturday.

headline: Joy and Celebrations in Seoul for Protesters as Yoon Is Impeached
abstract: “Long live South Korea!” demonstrators chanted, describing a wave of relief after days of anger over the president’s surprise declaration of martial law.
lead_paragraph: Braving the cold, the protesters seeking President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ouster had gathered in the thousands on Saturday outside South Korea’s National Assembly, where lawmakers were to decide whether to impeach the leader. The crowd was boisterous in its insistence: “Impeach Yoon!”

headline: Applying Psychotherapy to Heal Our Political Divide
abstract: Readers respond to an essay by a couples therapist.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Marketing Hurricane of ‘Wicked’ Says a Lot About Our Culture
abstract: The movie’s marketing push, involving 400 brand tie-ins, shows how our culture has become littered with formulaic and meaningless collaborations.
lead_paragraph: Even before “Wicked” opened, the movie’s signature green and pink colors were turning up everywhere, from drinks topped with matcha foam at Starbucks to aisles lined with merch at Target. This cultural bludgeoning was, of course, orchestrated. Today, not even large marketing budgets can achieve such ubiquity without help.

headline: The Menendez Brothers’ Case Challenges the Limits of Our Understanding of Abuse
abstract: Society knows more about abuse now, but it may not matter to the judicial system.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a Los Angeles judge delayed a hearing for Erik and Lyle Menendez in their bid to be resentenced for the murder of their parents 35 years ago. Renewed interest in the brothers’ case, fueled by Netflix’s recent docudrama series and documentary on the brothers, has drawn celebrity advocates to call for their release, alongside an army of TikTok accounts. Unfortunately for the brothers, social advocacy rarely corresponds to judicial change.

headline: How Sweden Could End Its Epidemic of Gang Violence
abstract: We know that tough-on-crime policies for children have been tried repeatedly elsewhere and have failed. So why is my country headed that way?
lead_paragraph: We used to believe in Sweden that the rights and well-being of children should always come first. But over the past two decades, a surge in gang violence has shaken that commitment. In 2023, 363 shootings took the lives of 53 people; this year, over 100 bombings stemming from gang violence had already been recorded by November. Our country now has one of the highest per capita rates of gun violence in the European Union. One key factor in the phenomenon: Gangs are grooming and recruiting children as young as 11, the police say, as contract killers.

headline: The Unabomber’s Influence Is Deeper and More Dangerous Than We Know
abstract: To some disaffected young Americans, the ruthlessly intellectualized turn to violence can seem justified. It is not.
lead_paragraph: I published a novel about the Unabomber this year, and during a book tour stop in Seattle, a high school teacher raised his hand and asked me what he could tell his students about Ted Kaczynski, because he was a hero to so many of them. The question stopped me cold, reminding me that Mr. Kaczynski’s influence is deeper and more widespread than most people realize.

headline: Is There a Better $600 Investment?
abstract: Women with obstetric fistulas suffer year after year, even as a $619 surgery can restore them.
lead_paragraph: One of the most dangerous things a woman can do in much of the world is become pregnant, and the risks caught up with a Kenyan named Alice Wanjiru a decade ago.

headline: What Does Rupert Murdoch Do Now?
abstract: “I love each of my children,” said the patriarch. “But these companies need a designated leader.”
lead_paragraph: In the final season of “Succession,” the HBO drama about a fictional media clan, the show’s grisly patriarch, Logan Roy, dishes out some characteristically choice words to his privileged children: “I love you, but you are not serious people.”

headline: Can We Make Pop Culture Great Again?
abstract: Worrying that even if the rest of American society starts moving, our storytelling is still going to be stuck.
lead_paragraph: When “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” debuted together late last month, there was a painful attempt to call their shared box office success “Glicked” — a reference to the portmanteau of “Barbenheimer” that described the joint cultural triumph of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” in the summer of 2023.

headline: Vote For the Best Metropolitan Diary Entry of 2024
abstract: We will have published 250 Diary entries this year by the end of December. We need your help choosing the best. New York Times editors narrowed the field to five finalists. Now it’s up to you to vote for your favorite.
lead_paragraph: We will have published 250 Diary entries this year by the end of December. We need your help choosing the best. New York Times editors narrowed the field to five finalists. Now it’s up to you to vote for your favorite.

headline: Sam Altman on Microsoft, Trump and Musk
abstract: The OpenAI C.E.O. spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit.
lead_paragraph: Since kicking off the artificial intelligence boom with the launch of ChatGPT in 2022, OpenAI has amassed more than 300 million weekly users and a $157 billion valuation. Its C.E.O., Sam Altman, addressed whether that staggering pace of growth can continue at the DealBook Summit last week.

headline: South Korea’s President Is Impeached After Martial Law Crisis
abstract: Some members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. But the political uncertainty is far from over.
lead_paragraph: Eleven days ago, President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea made a bold power grab, putting the country under military rule for the first time in 45 years, citing frustration at the opposition for obstructing his agenda in Parliament.

headline: Georgian Lawmakers Hand Presidency to Far-Right Former Soccer Star
abstract: The vote, boycotted by opposition parties in Parliament, sets up a standoff with the sitting president and deepens turmoil in the country after protests and a disputed election.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s governing lawmakers handed the presidency to a former soccer star turned far-right politician on Saturday, setting up a standoff with the sitting president and deepening the country’s political turmoil after weeks of protests and a disputed parliamentary election.

headline: It’s Time for Nutella Tres Leches Cake
abstract: Though, to be fair, it’s hard to imagine a time when Rick Martínez’s chocolaty take on the classic dessert wouldn’t be welcome.
lead_paragraph: Nutella tres leches cake!

headline: Trump Has Little Room for Error
abstract: How Trump might cut short his political honeymoon.
lead_paragraph: The annals of American political history are littered with the remains of once-great presidential mandates.

headline: Brazilian Police Arrest Close Ally of Ex-President Bolsonaro, Official Says
abstract: Gen. Walter Braga Netto was Jair Bolsonaro’s running mate. The arrest was for meddling in an investigation into a plot to stage a coup, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Brazilian police on Saturday arrested Gen. Walter Braga Netto, a close ally of former President Jair Bolsonaro and his running mate in 2022, according to a police official, accusing him of meddling in their investigation into a plot to stage a coup after Mr. Bolsonaro lost the election.

headline: Pelosi Has Hip Replacement Surgery After Fall
abstract: The former speaker of the House “is well on the mend,” her spokesman said. She fell while in Luxembourg as part of a congressional delegation to mark the 80th anniversary of the Battle of the Bulge.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, had hip replacement surgery on Saturday after falling while on an official trip to Luxembourg, her office said in a statement.

headline: Argentina’s President Receives Italian Citizenship, Angering Law’s Critics
abstract: Javier Milei is proud of his Italian ancestry and has tried to bolster ties with Italy’s conservative prime minister. But his new passport angered critics of Italy’s rules on citizenship.
lead_paragraph: When President Javier Milei of Argentina stepped onto the grounds of Giorgia Meloni’s party festival at Rome’s Circus Maximus, a conservative fair that mixed holiday and Italy-First energy, he found a skating rink, a Christmas tree and an upbeat, anti-woke crowd.

headline: Personal Data of Rhode Island Residents Breached in Large Cyberattack
abstract: An “international cybercriminal group” harvested the personal data of potentially hundreds of thousands of people from the state’s social services and health insurance systems, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The personal and private information of possibly hundreds of thousands of people who applied for government assistance in Rhode Island could be in the hands of hackers after a huge cyberattack, state officials said on Friday.

headline: Thanks to a Prank, Sculptures Make Googly Eyes at Oregon Residents
abstract: The eyes were attached to eight installations, to the delight of residents. City officials, who lamented the cost of repairs, were less amused.
lead_paragraph: If you travel through Bend, Ore., and have the feeling that you’re being watched, it’s not a stroke of paranoia: Googly eyes were affixed to eight public art sculptures around the city, to the chagrin of some local officials but to the delight of many residents.

headline: South Korea’s Leadership Crisis, Explained
abstract: After moving to oust President Yoon Suk Yeol, opposition lawmakers voted to impeach the interim leader as well. Here’s how the turmoil unfolded.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s short-lived declaration of martial law has created South Korea’s biggest constitutional crisis since the country democratized in the late 1980s.

headline: ABC to Pay $15 Million to Settle a Defamation Suit Brought by Trump
abstract: The outcome of the lawsuit marks an unusual victory for President-elect Donald J. Trump in his ongoing legal campaign against national news organizations.
lead_paragraph: ABC News is set to pay $15 million to settle a defamation lawsuit brought by Donald J. Trump.

headline: Hezbollah Loses Supply Route Through Syria, in Blow to It and Iran
abstract: The militant group’s leader admits that the toppling of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, cut off an important land route from Iran.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah acknowledged on Saturday that its supply route through Syria had been cut off by rebels who toppled the government last weekend, dealing another blow to Hezbollah and its patron, Iran.

headline: Trump Brings Hegseth to Watch Army-Navy Game
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump made a public show of support for his choice to lead the Defense Department.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump attended the annual Army-Navy football game in Maryland on Saturday with Pete Hegseth, his embattled choice for defense secretary, sending a message of support ahead of Senate confirmation hearings that are likely to take place next month.

headline: South Koreans Celebrate the President’s Impeachment in Seoul
abstract: A dozen members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. Lawmakers sought to impeach the president after his declaration of martial law drew public outrage.
lead_paragraph: A dozen members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. Lawmakers sought to impeach the president after his declaration of martial law drew public outrage.

headline: Robert Fernandez, Who Survived Pearl Harbor as a Teen, Dies at 100
abstract: He was a 17-year-old sailor aboard the U.S.S. Curtiss when Japanese forces attacked. He said he had joined the Navy to see the world.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fernandez, one of the last known American survivors of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, died on Wednesday in Lodi, Calif., just days after the 83rd anniversary of the attack. He was 100.

headline: No Evidence Drones in Northeast Are a Threat, Officials Say
abstract: Numerous sightings of flying objects in recent weeks have raised alarm, but federal law enforcement officials say that at least some were manned aircraft, such as airplanes or helicopters.
lead_paragraph: After reviewing thousands of tips, federal law enforcement officials on Saturday reaffirmed that mysterious drones spotted in the Northeast in recent weeks pose no national security threat and in most cases are not even drones.

headline: Strong Storm Brings a Rarity in San Francisco: A Tornado Warning
abstract: Less than two weeks after a tsunami warning, residents were jolted awake before 6 a.m. to consider a new potential disaster scenario.
lead_paragraph: Powerful storms swept through parts of Northern California on Saturday, knocking down trees, causing widespread power outages and prompting weather officials to issue what they said was the first-ever tornado warning for San Francisco.

headline: Art Heist
abstract: David Kwong draws us in with a magical challenge.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Isak Andic, Founder of Mango Fashion Chain, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Andic got his start by selling T-shirts in Barcelona in the mid-1980s. He died in a fall during a hike.
lead_paragraph: Isak Andic, who built the fashion brand Mango from a Spanish storefront into a global giant with more than 2,000 stores on five continents, died in a fall while hiking near Barcelona on Saturday. He was 71.

headline: Trump Says He Supports an End to Daylight Saving Time
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on social media that the time change is “inconvenient” and that the Republican Party would try to put an end to it.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump called daylight saving time “inconvenient, and very costly to our Nation” in a social media post on Friday and said the Republican Party would try to “eliminate” it, in the latest effort to end the twice-yearly time change.

headline: Weeks of Drone Sightings Leave New Jersey on Edge
abstract: In the Garden State, where the rash of sightings started a month ago, residents are looking to the skies, wondering why they still don’t have definitive answers from officials.
lead_paragraph: The day after Thanksgiving, Susan and Lorelai Woodruff saw approximately 10 brightly lit objects banking and turning quickly in the night sky above their home in Elsinboro, in southern New Jersey.

headline: Devin Nunes, Pugnacious Trump Loyalist, to Lead Espionage Advisory Board
abstract: As chair of the House Intelligence Committee, he attacked the Russia inquiry and Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment. Now, Mr. Nunes runs Mr. Trump’s social media company.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Saturday that he would appoint Devin Nunes, a former member of Congress who had used his role as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee to try to delegitimize the Trump-Russia investigation, to head an independent advisory board on espionage policy.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 14, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about an agreement reached by the city of Louisville, Ky., and the Justice Department to address misconduct by Louisville police misstated the circumstances by which the police in Louisville searched the home of Breonna Taylor, who was fatally shot by officers. The police department had approval for a no-knock warrant to enter Ms. Taylor’s apartment, but officers were later instructed to knock and identify themselves. It is not the case that they used no warrant at all.

headline: Quote of the Day: In the Land of Christmas Trees, Hope After Helene
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 15, 2024
lead_paragraph: “There’s such a difference between hurting without hope and hurting with hope.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 15, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption in the table of contents for an article on Dec. 1 about war and superbugs misidentified the type of testing being performed. Test strips were used to identify bacteria, not to test for antibiotic resistance.

headline: Trump Names Richard Grenell for ‘Special Missions’ Role
abstract: A combative loyalist and the president-elect’s former ambassador to Germany, Mr. Grenell had hoped to be secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump named Richard Grenell, his former ambassador to Germany and former acting director of national intelligence, as his “envoy for special missions,” Mr. Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform on Saturday.

headline: A Christmas Gnome Tradition, More Than 1,000 Strong
abstract: The writer Andrew Solomon recounts his enduring love for the cheerful little heroes of Swedish folklore, handed down from his late mother.
lead_paragraph: First, advent calendars; then gnomes; then the tree; and then Christmas itself. Only as an adult did I discover that one element in this sequence separated us from other New York families. In my early childhood, my mother, awakened to a novel festive touch by a Swiss friend with Swedish tastes, had collected more than a hundred little hand-carved wooden figures — Scandinavian gnomes, dressed in red, mostly with cotton-wool hair.

headline: As Ambassador, Rahm Emanuel Says His Impatience Nudged Japan Forward
abstract: In a society used to quiet consensus-building, Tokyo has made bold changes to its defense policy. “Did I contribute to that?” Mr. Emanuel asked. “Uh, yeah.”
lead_paragraph: Patience, Rahm Emanuel likes to say, is a waste of time.

headline: Security Strategy of Recruiting Cheap Militiamen Backfires in Africa
abstract: By arming civilians who are poorly trained and have little to no respect for human rights, the military in Burkina Faso has brought the West African nation to the brink of civil war.
lead_paragraph: They were falling asleep on a thin mat that they had been sharing since they were married five years ago. Suddenly, the roar of motorcycles woke them up. Armed men then dragged Rainatou Diallo and her husband, Adama Diallo, out of bed and into their courtyard.

headline: ‘They Had the Desire to Return’
abstract: Elated residents are trickling home to their shattered Syrian town, a rebel stronghold controlled until recently by the government.
lead_paragraph: The skies were quiet the other night in the northwestern town of Tel Rifaat, Syria, and relief was palpable among fighters and civilians who have lived for years under the constant threat of bombardment.

headline: This Unreadable Russian Novel Is Xi Jinping’s Spiritual Guide
abstract: The Chinese leader is digging into the language of revolution, and a radical Russian novel, as he prepares for battle with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: In late October, while much of the world was focused on the buildup to the U.S. elections, President Xi Jinping of China was issuing a call for global resistance to the American-led world order.

headline: With al-Assad Gone, the Risk of an ISIS Resurgence Grows
abstract: With the fall of al-Assad’s regime, the risk of an ISIS resurgence increases.
lead_paragraph: After more than 53 years of a brutal dictatorship and nearly 14 years of debilitating conflict, the Assad government fell in just under two weeks. The sudden collapse of the regime — which killed, tortured and repressed countless Syrians — has brought a remarkable sense of unity and euphoria across longstanding divides in the country.

headline: At Least 11 Dead as Cyclone Devastates Islands in Indian Ocean
abstract: The prefect of Mayotte said the death toll could climb. The storm, the equivalent of a Category 3, made landfall in Mozambique on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Cyclone Chido made landfall in Mozambique on Sunday after causing destruction in Mayotte, a French archipelago of about 300,000 people in the Indian Ocean, where at least 11 people died, France’s interior ministry said on Sunday.

headline: Hochul May Face a Challenger She Knows Well: Her Lieutenant Governor
abstract: Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado has begun to carve out his own political path, potentially putting him on a collision course with his boss, Gov. Kathy Hochul.
lead_paragraph: In the two months leading up to Election Day, Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado’s schedule was booked solid, but not with the typical ribbon cuttings associated with the somewhat anonymous job of being New York’s No. 2.

headline: An Epidemic of Vicious School Brawls, Fueled by Student Cellphones
abstract: Cafeteria melees. Students kicked in the head. Injured educators. Technology is stoking cycles of violence in schools across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Ricardo Martinez, an 11th grader, was in his high school lunchroom in April when a mass brawl erupted.

headline: Automakers Thrived in the Pandemic. Many Are Now Struggling.
abstract: Changing technology, political turmoil and competition from China are cutting into profits and forcing carmakers to cut jobs and close factories.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, automakers were celebrating record profits as the pandemic created shortages of new cars, allowing them to raise prices. Now the hangover is setting in.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: ‘At the End of the Bench, a Man Was Leaning Against the Railing’
abstract: Curiosity rewarded on the C train, a Christmas gift and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Walt Disney, Painted Out of the Photo
abstract: A photo found in The New York Times’s clippings library held a secret: One famous figure had been cropped out in order to spotlight another.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Roth, the caretaker of the morgue, The New York Times’s clippings and photo archive, was looking through the file of Igor Stravinsky, the Russian composer, this year when he discovered a curious black-and-white photo.

headline: Saving Christmas in North Carolina, One Tree at a Time, After Hurricane Helene
abstract: The storm upended the Christmas tree industry in the state’s western region. Now, farmers and residents are eager for the comfort of the season’s rituals.
lead_paragraph: Curve around the mountain on a cool, wet morning, and you’ll see them rising through the fog: row after row of silver-green trees, their layers of soft needles and branches primed to hold a string of lights, a glittering bauble or a child’s handmade ornament.

headline: ​After Impeachment, South Korea Is Left With No Elected Leader
abstract: The suspension of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s powers left a seasoned but unelected prime minister in charge of a country facing daunting challenges at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment and suspension from office has left South Korea, one of the United States’ most important allies, without a strong​ elected leader to tackle challenges like a belligerent North Korea and a deepening political polarization at home.​

headline: One Ski Resort’s Long-Shot Bet to Survive Low Snowfall and Devastating Wildfires
abstract: The closest ski hill to Los Angeles recently sold to an investment group with big plans. But can those ideas work amid catastrophic climate threats that continue to plague the mountain?
lead_paragraph: For much of its 85-year existence, the Mount Waterman resort has drawn skiers and outdoor enthusiasts from around Los Angeles for its no-fuss, no-frills experience.

headline: The Rise of the Noodle Boys
abstract: As an era of macho politics sets in, sinewy stars like Timothée Chalamet, Dominic Sessa and Mark Eydelshteyn embody a slinky alternative image of white masculinity in American pop culture.
lead_paragraph: He’s reedy like a long-distance runner; his flopsy curls tumble like overcooked fusilli. He’s attractive but in a way you can’t always put your finger on. He’s Hollywood’s white boy of the moment, and he has ambled into the movie industry to counter the broad and built look that the Marvel cinematic onslaught helped usher in during the 2000s.

headline: Four Years Later, CrossFit’s Disgraced Guru Attempts a Comeback
abstract: Greg Glassman, who sold the company amid sexual harassment complaints, has a new health and fitness venture. It sounds a lot like his old one.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2021, Josh Hunnicutt, a longtime personal trainer and the owner of the New Species CrossFit gym in Royal Oak, Mich., had a surprising opportunity: Greg Glassman, CrossFit’s contentious but charismatic co-founder, offered — more or less out of the blue — to pick him up in his private jet and fly him to a party in Ohio. The pitch was for the two of them to drink vodka sodas and rub elbows with other luminaries of the health and fitness industry.

headline: It’s Hard to Be the Brother of a Genius Who Died Young
abstract: In “Ira Gershwin: A Life in Words,” Michael Owen offers a sympathetic portrait of the lyricist, overshadowed in a life that had him tending the legacy of his younger sibling George.
lead_paragraph: The lyricist Ira Gershwin once suggested his epitaph should be “Words Failed Me”: a joke tinged with ineffable sadness.

headline: Weeks of Upheaval Have Paralyzed This South American Nation. Here’s Why.
abstract: Protests in Bolivia triggered by a feud between the president and a political rival have caused turmoil. One fallout: fuel shortages that have left drivers lining up for gas for days.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations have rocked Bolivia for more than two months. A longstanding political rivalry has boiled over, with supporters of the president and his chief opponent clashing in the streets. Protests have blocked the movement of goods, exacerbating fuel shortages. Some Bolivians lined up for days to buy gas.

headline: The Alienation of Jaime Cachua
abstract: His friends and family members in Rome, Ga., voted to support mass deportation. Now he’s scrambling to stay in the country.
lead_paragraph: His wife was spiraling into insomnia, and his children were afraid to go to school, so Jaime Cachua sought out the person he trusted most in a crisis. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Georgia across from his father-in-law, Sky Atkins, the family patriarch. Jaime, 33, hadn’t seen his own father since he was 10 months old, when he left Mexico in a car seat bound for the United States. It was Sky, 45, who had stood by Jaime at his wedding, helped him move into his first house and stayed at the hospital overnight when one of Jaime’s children was sick with pneumonia.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 554
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,276
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: For the Sake of 600,000 Children, Science Must Be Bold
abstract: Gene drives offer hope in our battle against malaria.
lead_paragraph: Bold ideas in science research used to thrill us; now they seem pretty threatening. When I have written about the ethics of genetically engineered mosquitoes to combat malaria, many of my friends have expressed alarm. “What if it goes badly wrong?” they ask. What if there are unintended consequences that ripple across ecosystems? What if this is one of those technologies that cross the line from innovative to utterly world-destroying?

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What if A.I. Is Actually Good for Hollywood?’
abstract: It’s already powering remarkable visual innovations, like in the new movie “Here.” But boosters think that’s just the beginning.
lead_paragraph: “You couldn’t have made this movie three years ago,” said Robert Zemeckis, the director of “Here.”

headline: The Trouble Began When #MeToo Became #ChurchToo
abstract: Yes, people want justice — as long as justice costs them nothing or very little.
lead_paragraph: When did we know that the #MeToo moment was truly over?

headline: Israel Strikes Military Sites in Syria, Monitor Says
abstract: The Israeli military hit weapons depots and air defenses, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Israel has said it aims to keep military equipment away from extremists.
lead_paragraph: Israel struck Syrian weapons depots and air defenses overnight, a group monitoring the conflict said Sunday, in what appeared to be part of an effort Israel says is aimed at depriving “extremists” of military assets after rebels seized power in Syria.

headline: How Biden Should Spend His Final Weeks in Office
abstract: The president can still do a lot before he leaves the White House.
lead_paragraph: The days are dwindling to a precious few before President Biden relinquishes his tenancy at the White House to Donald Trump. Four years ago, in his Inaugural Address, Mr. Biden promised to “press forward with speed and urgency, for we have much to do in this winter of peril and possibility.” The peril remains, but so do the possibilities.

headline: How Will the Rebels Rule Syria? Their Past Offers Clues.
abstract: The Islamist rebels who ousted Syria’s dictator ran a pragmatic and disciplined administration in the territory they controlled. They also jailed their critics.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, when farmers across the rolling, red dirt hills of Idlib Province in northern Syria harvest their olive crops, they routinely find at least one representative of the local tax authority stationed at any oil press.

headline: A Trip to New York
abstract: Expert advice to make the most of a New York City vacation.
lead_paragraph: It’s prime Yuletide in New York City.

headline: Google’s Sundar Pichai on Antitrust, Trump and A.I.
abstract: Google’s chief executive spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit
lead_paragraph: Google got a head start in the artificial intelligence race, and at the DealBook Summit on Dec. 4, its chief executive, Sundar Pichai, snapped back at suggestions that it should be more competitive considering its vast resources.

headline: My 500-Mile Journey Across Alaska’s Thawing Arctic
abstract: I had read about how the rapid warming of the Arctic was upending the landscape and its people. Now I’ve seen it.
lead_paragraph: Flames were leaping out of the forest beneath the float plane taking us deep into the remote interior of northern Alaska. Our destination was the glacial Walker Lake, which stretches 14 miles through Gates of the Arctic National Park.

headline: Don’t Cut an Agency So Vital to Our Health
abstract: Readers worry about cuts to the National Institutes of Health. Also: Maternity wards; overdose deaths; vetting presidential candidates; tech tycoons in charge.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Luigi Mangione Is Busting Out All Over
abstract: As Chris Rock hosts, the man charged in the UnitedHealthcare shooting dominates this week’s riffs on the news.
lead_paragraph: The 50th season of “Saturday Night Live” continues to provide the show with opportunities to revive many of its long-running characters. Last week, it was the Church Lady; this week, it was Nancy Grace, the TV personality and frequently outraged true-crime commentator, who has been frequently impersonated on “S.N.L.” over the years by cast members including Ana Gasteyer and Amy Poehler.

headline: When ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Gets the Anime Treatment
abstract: “The War of the Rohirrim” is the latest and most high-profile anime adaptation of a Western franchise to hit screens big and small.
lead_paragraph: When Warner Bros. approached the filmmaker Peter Jackson and his longtime screenwriting partner Philippa Boyens about making a new animated “Lord of the Rings,” Boyens at first had a hard time wrapping her head around the notion. But when studio executives suggested that the film could be told via Japanese anime — suddenly it clicked.

headline: Israel’s Military Strikes Northern Gaza After Days of Deadly Bombardment
abstract: Israel’s military said it carried out strikes and raids against Hamas targets in northern Gaza on Sunday. The actions followed days of deadly attacks across the territory.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said it carried out strikes and raids in northern Gaza on Sunday after days of deadly bombardments across the territory.

headline: Perfect Broiled Salmon, Beef Chow Fun and Mushroom Smash Burgers
abstract: A list of excellent recipes to cook this week (no need to check it twice).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s list-making season. I’m cataloging gifts I want to give family and friends, tabulating all the work that needs to be done on the skiff before the fish return in the spring, putting basement chores on the docket, indexing every book I’ve read this year. I’m looking forward, looking back, taking stock and making plans.

headline: Trump and His Picks Threaten More Lawsuits Over Critical Coverage
abstract: The small flurry of threatened defamation suits is the latest sign that the incoming Trump administration appears poised to do what it can to crack down on unfavorable media coverage.
lead_paragraph: The legal threats have arrived in various forms. One aired on CNN. Another came over the phone. More arrived in letters or emails.

headline: Israel Shutters Its Embassy in Ireland, Citing ‘Anti-Israel Policies’
abstract: Amid mounting international criticism of its military conduct in Gaza, Israel says it will deepen ties with countries it considers friendly toward it.
lead_paragraph: Israel announced on Sunday that it was closing its embassy in Dublin in light of what it described as “the extreme anti-Israel policies of the Irish government.”

headline: Grand Jury Said to Hear Evidence Against Chief Adviser to Mayor Adams
abstract: Prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office have presented evidence that is focused at least in part on Ingrid Lewis-Martin, who was the top aide to Eric Adams until her resignation.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors investigating corruption allegations against Ingrid Lewis-Martin, the chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams, have presented evidence to a grand jury and could seek an indictment as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Graham Says Hegseth Plans to Release Accuser From Confidential Agreement
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham said that Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump’s defense secretary pick, promised to release his accuser from a settlement that his lawyer has said was already breached.
lead_paragraph: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Defense Department, told Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina that he planned to release the woman who accused him of sexual assault from a confidential settlement agreement, Mr. Graham said on Sunday.

headline: Jamie Foxx Recovering After Being Hit With a Glass in the Mouth
abstract: Foxx was celebrating his birthday at a restaurant on Friday when someone from another table threw a glass, a representative for the entertainer said.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning actor, singer and comedian Jamie Foxx was recovering after a physical altercation at a restaurant on Friday night in which someone from another table threw a glass that hit him in the mouth, a representative for the entertainer and the police said.

headline: Read the email from Revere’s principal
abstract: The email the principal of Revere High School sent to parents about the June 2023 cafeteria fight.
lead_paragraph: The email the principal of Revere High School sent to parents about the June 2023 cafeteria fight.

headline: Polly Mellen, Fashion’s Storied Cheerleader, Dies at 100
abstract: With photographers like Richard Avedon, Irving Penn, Bert Stern and others, the veteran editor created some of the most indelible images of modern fashion.
lead_paragraph: Polly Mellen, the irrepressible and indomitable fashion editor who was the last link to a long golden age when fashion editors were fearsome creatures who ruled by fiat, and a photograph in Vogue magazine, where Ms. Mellen worked for more than a quarter century, moved not just markets but the culture, died on Wednesday in Salisbury, Conn. She was 100 — an attractive round number, which Ms. Mellen, ever the perfectionist, surely appreciated.

headline: Jury Awards Woman $34 Million for Wrongful Conviction
abstract: Kirstin Blaise Lobato sued the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department and two detectives after she spent nearly 16 years in prison for a murder she did not commit.
lead_paragraph: Kirstin Blaise Lobato, who spent nearly 16 years in prison for a murder she did not commit, was awarded more than $34 million by a federal jury in Nevada on Thursday.

headline: See How Much NYC's Congestion Pricing Plan Would Cost You
abstract: A new toll on drivers hopes to reduce traffic in one of the world’s most congested cities. How would it work?
lead_paragraph: A new toll on drivers hopes to reduce traffic in one of the world’s most congested cities. How would it work?

headline: Monday Briefing: South Korea’s Power Vacuum
abstract: Plus, how travel benefits us.
lead_paragraph: After South Korea’s National Assembly voted to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol on Saturday, people celebrated his removal from office, even as the country was left with a political vacuum at the top that could last for months.

headline: Man Gets 100 Years in Prison for His Role in 2020 Shooting Spree
abstract: The rampage on Thanksgiving Day killed one person and injured several others in Nevada and Arizona.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man has been sentenced to at least 100 years in prison for his part in a two-state shooting spree on Thanksgiving Day in 2020 that killed one person and wounded several others across Nevada and Arizona.

headline: Lorraine O’Grady, Artist Who Defied Category, Is Dead at 90
abstract: She worked in collage, photography, performance, video and installation, and she dealt forthrightly with the complexities of race and gender.
lead_paragraph: Lorraine O’Grady, a conceptual artist who had careers as a research economist, literary translator and rock critic before producing her first art in her 40s, and who went on to influence a generation of younger Black artists, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: Expect Icy Roads in Parts of the Northeast on Monday Morning
abstract: Light snow and freezing rain in parts of Connecticut, New Jersey and New York could make the commute hazardous, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Light snowfall and sleet overnight in parts of Connecticut, New Jersey, New York was expected to make roads icy for Monday morning commuters, forecasters said.

headline: Two Alvin Ailey Productions Head for the Light
abstract: Hope Boykin’s “Finding Free” and Lar Lubovitch’s “Many Angels” aspire to find higher ground at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: Dancers moving from being scorned to rocking their souls in the bosom of Abraham — this is the narrative arc of Alvin Ailey’s masterpiece, “Revelations.” And that redemptive passage into the light is the template that many choreographers for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater try to replicate.

headline: Colonel Found Guilty of Sexual Harassment in Trial Seen as a Milestone
abstract: The conviction is considered one of the first of its kind since Congress required the military to change how its legal system addresses sexual assault and harassment.
lead_paragraph: A former Army battalion commander has been found guilty in a military court of sexually harassing a subordinate, one of the first cases of its kind brought after an overhaul of the military’s legal system that established sexual harassment as a criminal offense.

headline: Faller in Fall
abstract: Ailee Yoshida crafts her origin story.

headline: ‘Malcolm in the Middle’ Is Getting a Four-Episode Revival on Disney+
abstract: The return of “Malcolm in the Middle,” which aired from 2000 to 2006, will follow Malcolm as he helps his parents celebrate their 40th wedding anniversary, Disney+ announced.
lead_paragraph: One of America’s wackiest families is making a comeback.

headline: Private Schools Group Apologizes After Claims of Antisemitism at Event
abstract: After criticism from Jewish groups over speeches at a conference, the president of the National Association of Independent Schools said future addresses would be vetted.
lead_paragraph: A prominent national private schools group has apologized for remarks some speakers made at a conference about diversity and inclusion earlier this month, after leaders of several Jewish organizations condemned the comments as antisemitic.

headline: The Narrator
abstract: Banias is an 8-year-old living in Gaza, and she has a story to tell — many stories, in fact.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Quote of the Day: Blunt U.S. Ambassador in Nicety-Bound Japan
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “If you only want to do big things that nobody disagrees with, they’re not going to be very big.”

headline: Zakir Hussain, Tabla Virtuoso Who Fused Musical Traditions, Dies at 73
abstract: His collaborators included John McLaughlin, Béla Fleck, Ravi Shankar, Herbie Hancock, Yo-Yo Ma and members of the Grateful Dead.
lead_paragraph: Zakir Hussain, a percussionist and composer who was both a master of North Indian classical music and a linchpin of far-reaching world-music fusions, died on Sunday in San Francisco. He was 73.

headline: The Joy of Christmas Ornaments (as a Jew)
abstract: After I met my husband, I realized there was a whole little world inside these ornaments.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I thought Christmas ornaments were tchotchkes you bought at CVS — shiny, uniform bulbs that came in neat packages of eight. In my secular Jewish family, it never occurred to me that decorating a tree had any value beyond the aesthetic.

headline: Myanmar’s War Has Forced Doctors and Nurses Into Prostitution
abstract: Nearly four years into a grinding civil conflict, the economy is in ruins, and people — even professionals with degrees — are desperate.
lead_paragraph: After seven years of medical school in Myanmar, May finally achieved her goal of becoming a doctor. But a month after she graduated and found a job, her dreams started unraveling.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, the Islamist rebel movement that just spearheaded the overthrow of the Assad dynasty in Syria, has roots in the Islamic State and Al Qaeda. But since around 2016, the group has modified and moderated its own jihadist orientation.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Mother Inferior
abstract: A sister with history shows up at the emperor’s palace. Not everyone is pleased. Nor should everyone be.
lead_paragraph: It is a time of revelations. In this week’s episode of “Dune: Prophecy,” character after character learns some shattering truth about another — or the audience is clued in to something previously unknown about a familiar face. It’s about time, too. In a show this focused on plot and lore, at times to its dramatic detriment, the characters involved in both deserve a real turn in the spotlight.

headline: Tales of Messy Romances, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
abstract: Watch how “The Ultimatum,” “Laid” and “Virgin River” test relationships in different ways. Get into the holiday spirit with Josh Groban.
lead_paragraph: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, Dec. 16 to Dec. 22. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Four Scenarios for Ukraine’s Endgame
abstract: The war is entering what could be its final phase. What happens next?
lead_paragraph: Almost three years after Vladimir Putin ordered Russia’s troops to invade Ukraine, the war is entering what could be its final phase, and a deal to end it seems likelier than ever.

headline: Word of the Day: vocational
abstract: This word has appeared in 220 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word vocational has appeared in 220 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 21 in “How High School Graduates Can Improve Their Earnings Potential” by Steve Lohr:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Five ‘Bali Nine’ Drug Smugglers Return to Australia After Two Decades
abstract: The men were the last Australians still imprisoned in Indonesia for trying to smuggle heroin in 2005, in a case that became a diplomatic flashpoint between the countries.
lead_paragraph: The last five members of the so-called Bali Nine, a group of Australians who were convicted of smuggling heroin nearly two decades ago, have been released from prison in Indonesia and are back in Australia, according to the authorities in both countries.

headline: ​Impeachment in South Korea Has Cost Washington a Staunch Ally
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol shifted his country closer to Washington and stood up to Beijing. But that foreign policy could be recalibrated in the future.
lead_paragraph: President Yoon Suk Yeol has changed the course of South Korea’s diplomacy like no leader before him. He put his country in lock step with the United States by countering North Korea with sanctions and joint military drills. He won Washington’s plaudits when he overcame a century of historical grievances Koreans held against Japan​ and helped lay the ground for trilateral cooperation to deter China.

headline: How the Swedish Dungeons & Dragons Inspired Helldivers 2
abstract: The studio behind the fastest-selling PlayStation title of all time adjusts its story arc based on corporate decisions by players.
lead_paragraph: As Arrowhead Studios was putting the finishing touches on its multiplayer sci-fi shooter Helldivers 2, Johan Pilestedt was firming up the game’s online infrastructure.

headline: Seeking Relief From Brain Injury, Some Veterans Turn to Psychedelics
abstract: Unable to find effective treatments at home, veterans with brain-injury symptoms are going abroad for psychedelics like ibogaine that are illegal in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: A van full of U.S. Special Operations veterans crossed the border into Mexico on a sunny day in July to execute a mission that, even to them, sounded pretty far out.

headline: Why Ultraprocessed Foods Aren’t Always Bad
abstract: The category of ultraprocessed foods is so broad it borders on useless.
lead_paragraph: The way we eat desperately needs to change. Experts estimate diet is a bigger contributor globally to early death than smoking. In America, nearly half the adult population has Type 2 diabetes or pre-diabetes.

headline: A Ride-Hailing Start-Up in Washington Tries to ‘Out-Uber Uber’
abstract: A company called Empower is trying to take on Uber, Lyft and local regulators as it piles up fines and draws new passengers to its service.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday morning outside Union Station’s train hall in Washington, a stream of taxicabs, Ubers and Lyfts pulled to the curb to pick up passengers.

headline: The Breakout Stars of 2024
abstract: Across the arts world, these 10 performers broke away from the pack this year by channeling guts and grit into their work.
lead_paragraph: Audacious, original and wielding a clear vision, the stars who rose to the top in 2024 pushed boundaries and made bold, even risky, choices. Here are 10 artists who shook up their scenes and resonated with fans this year.

headline: 11 New Entries to a Hallowed Catalog: The Holiday Album
abstract: Our critics on Christmas records from Jacob Collier, Megan Moroney, the Christmas Tree-O and more.
lead_paragraph: A holiday album offers musicians a chance to adopt — or reinvent — a classic format and show fans a different side of themselves. Here’s a sampling of this year’s releases, from singers exploring the standards and artists rethinking the meaning of the holidays.

headline: Why I’m Not Dreading Holiday Chores This Season
abstract: Holidays often mean more work. Here’s how to view that work differently.
lead_paragraph: After having kids, the United Methodist minister Lydia Sohn was an avid subscriber to services that promised to make her life easier: She DoorDashed dinner, fixed furniture with the help of TaskRabbit and hired a cleaner. But that all changed when she discovered the philosophy behind the Benedictine monks who embraced physical labor in their daily lives. In this episode, Sohn argues something magical happens when you begin viewing household chores as more than just another item on your to-do list.

headline: What Will Stick With You From 2024?
abstract: What from your own life, around the globe, or in the world of art, culture and sports will you remember about this year?
lead_paragraph: When you look back on 2024, what will you remember?

headline: Powell’s Fed Appears Headed for Another Collision With Trump
abstract: Rates may not come down as much or as quickly as had been expected, just as Trump — a self-declared “low-rate guy” — returns to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Inside the halls of the Federal Reserve’s headquarters overlooking Constitution Avenue in Washington, casual mentions of the incoming Trump administration are cautious and infrequent. That’s by design.

headline: The Reverberations of the Daniel Penny Verdict
abstract: Penny was acquitted in the chokehold killing of Jordan Neely. The case has set off a debate over justice, race and the treatment of mentally ill people.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll take a closer look at the verdict that cleared Daniel Penny in the chokehold death of Jordan Neely, a fellow passenger on an F train who witnesses said had been shouting at riders.

headline: Alaska in Winter: Reveling in a Playground of Ice and Snow
abstract: Juneau, a popular cruise port in summer, becomes a deal-seeker’s base for skiing, skating, hiking and glacier-gazing in winter.
lead_paragraph: Twelve inches of fresh powder had just fallen at Eaglecrest Ski Area in Juneau, Alaska, when I arrived for my first day of skiing last February. Snow packed the slumping branches of towering pines and frosted the beards of draping moss. From the chairlift, skiers below me appeared from the thighs up, their lower halves plowing fresh tracks. Whoops of delight rang out from sources unseen.

headline: The Modern Prince Lighting Up the Ballet Stage in Paris
abstract: Guillaume Diop has reached the highest level in the Paris Opera Ballet. He has also become a fashion-world darling and a symbol of a more diverse France.
lead_paragraph: Guillaume Diop had heard the whispers: His feet were flat, his bottom too big; he would never get into the Paris Opera Ballet School. He proved the naysayers wrong, entering the school at 12.

headline: With This MoMA Artist, the Painting Does the Talking
abstract: Marlon Mullen’s show at the Museum of Modern Art, the first by a developmentally disabled artist, speaks volumes.
lead_paragraph: Before Marlon Mullen begins a painting, he likes to tidy his work space. He’ll pre-mix his paints — Golden acrylics in recycled pots — and lay out his brushes and canvas on his table. Often, he’ll empty the studio’s trash cans. Sometimes he’ll even sweep the yard outside, or rearrange objects on the studio shelves according to their relation to colors he plans to use in his painting. As I learned when I visited him in Richmond, Calif., one recent rainy morning, this ritual process can take days.

headline: Is Mikhail Baryshnikov the Last of the Highbrow Superstars?
abstract: Fifty years since he left the Soviet Union, he insists on using his huge fame to bring attention to difficult, esoteric art.
lead_paragraph: We were on the third or fourth flight of thick marble steps in a prewar Midtown apartment building when Mikhail Baryshnikov turned to ask if I was OK. I was clutching my inhaler, sweat rolling down my forehead. Totally fine, I answered. Was he OK? He was, after all, three decades my senior, with a lifetime of wear from leaps and pirouettes and enough knee surgeries that he forgets the exact number. But his face was dry and his breathing steady: “I think I can manage,” he said.

headline: $1.1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A craftsman-style house in Oakland, a 1922 home in Stockton and a midcentury modern-style house in Santa Rosa
lead_paragraph: This two-bedroom, two-bathroom, wood-shingled house is a few blocks from College and Telegraph Avenues and their bakeries, coffee shops and restaurants. A Safeway and a Trader Joe’s are each 15-minutes on foot, as is Market Hall and its many food stalls.

headline: Trump Hates the ‘Deep State.’ But He Also Needs It.
abstract: He should fuse these two impulses into a single governing ideology.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump won the 2024 election after promising to wage war on elements of the federal work force. “Either the deep state destroys America, or we destroy the deep state,” he said in the first major rally of his campaign. Russell Vought, whom Mr. Trump has tapped to head the Office of Management and Budget, has said he wants bureaucrats to be “increasingly viewed as the villains.” Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, the leaders of Mr. Trump’s new Department of Government Efficiency, promise to enact “mass head-count reductions across the federal bureaucracy.”

headline: A Mild Defense of Lara Trump
abstract: The Senate takes itself seriously, but its members aren’t always public-servant all-stars.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lara Trump.

headline: Percival Everett’s Prose Is Having a Moment. How Is His Poetry?
abstract: The winner of this year’s National Book Award in fiction has published several collections of poems. Our critic takes a look.
lead_paragraph: Percival Everett’s first novel was published in 1983. How long ago was that? It was same year Madonna, R.E.M. and Metallica released their first albums. Much of the world has only recently begun to catch up with him.

headline: Why America’s Kurdish Allies Are Under Threat in a New Syria
abstract: The Kurds helped the United States contain the Islamic State. Now they fear a resurgent Turkey that has long considered them an adversary. Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: The 13-year civil war between Syria’s government and rebel fighters has ended. But the peril is not over for Syria’s Kurdish minority.

headline: Trump Is the Wrong Answer to the Right Question
abstract: The president-elect and the president are in transition.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, this is our last conversation of 2024. We’ll be back in January, as will, um, President Trump. Any New Year predictions? Wishes? Desperate hopes?

headline: Short Books Are Perfect for Our Distracted Age
abstract: There is something special about works I can read in full on a rainy Sunday afternoon or in the lamplight hours between supper and bedtime.
lead_paragraph: When the news is one report of human suffering — or environmental degradation or violation of democratic norms — after another, people might be forgiven for averting their eyes from the headlines in favor of getting a better night’s sleep. The only problem: In a democracy, tuning out means giving the foxes full run of the henhouse.

headline: Is It Ever OK to Go Barefoot in Public?
abstract: A shoeless talk-show appearance leads a reader to contemplate the current rules around going barefoot in public, and our critic weighs in on naked feet in fashion and society.
lead_paragraph: It may seem strange to be discussing the ethics and aesthetics of bare feet in public as Christmas approaches, a time when many of us are contemplating the allure of fuzzy slippers and fleece socks. But very public fashion rule-breaking by celebrities has a way of starting conversations, not to mention trends, and Angelina Jolie did just show up on “The Tonight Show” couch in an elegant long black dress — and no shoes.

headline: Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie Give a Surprising Education in Opera
abstract: “Paris & Nicole: The Encore,” a sequel to “The Simple Life,” is a comedic lark about creating an opera, with enlightening lessons along the way.
lead_paragraph: It was a sight I certainly didn’t expect to see this year, or ever: Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie sitting down with Thomas Adès, one of the greatest living composers, to learn about opera.

headline: Hundreds Feared Dead After Cyclone Hits French Territory of Mayotte
abstract: Officials on the archipelago off the eastern coast of Africa said the number of people killed by Tropical Cyclone Chido could be much higher than the 21 now confirmed dead.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers and families on Monday desperately searched for victims after a storm devastated the French territory of Mayotte, off the eastern coast of Africa. Officials fear that hundreds or even thousands could be dead, far higher than the current confirmed toll of 21.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,277
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 555
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Trump Threatens More News Outlets, and Injuries at Amazon’s Warehouses
abstract: Plus, a troubling trend in American schools.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Amazon Disregarded Internal Warnings on Injuries, Senate Investigation Claims
abstract: A staff report by the Senate labor committee, led by Bernie Sanders, uncovered evidence of internal concern about high injury rates at the e-commerce giant.
lead_paragraph: For years, worker advocates and some government officials have argued that Amazon’s strict production quotas lead to high rates of injury for its warehouse employees. And for years, Amazon has rejected the criticism, arguing that it doesn’t use strict quotas, and that its injury rates are falling close to or below the industry average.

headline: Pete Hegseth Was Toast. The MAGA Swarm Came to His Rescue.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his supporters exerted intense political pressure to salvage his pick for the Department of Defense.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: Israel Carries Out Heavy Strikes on Syria’s Coast, Monitor Says
abstract: Overnight strikes targeted former army positions, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a war monitor. Israel has said it aims to keep military equipment away from extremists.
lead_paragraph: Israel carried out a heavy wave of airstrikes overnight on Syria’s coastal region, a war monitor said early on Monday, as the Israeli military continued to pound Syria in a bid to destroy the country’s military assets after rebels seized power.

headline: A Chaotic Start
abstract: We cover the people who will surround Donald Trump in his second term.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has named most of the advisers and cabinet officials whom he wants to surround him in a second term. To make sense of the team, I asked for help from three of my colleagues who cover Trump: Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Jonathan Swan. Our exchange follows.

headline: Netanyahu Tells Trump Israel Must ‘Complete Its Victory’
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he told President-elect Donald J. Trump that the country had delivered “a tough blow” against Hamas and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he had told President-elect Donald J. Trump in a telephone conversation over the weekend that Israel needed to “complete its victory” over Iranian proxies and bring back hostages held in Gaza.

headline: Are Tariffs Inevitable?
abstract: World leaders and C.E.O.s are struggling to convince President-elect Donald Trump to shift his position on imposing new levies against America’s trade partners and its rivals.
lead_paragraph: Investors appear largely unfazed by President-elect Donald Trump’s tough talk on tariffs, with the S&P 500 up more than 5 percent since Election Day.

headline: Syria’s New Leadership Takes Early Steps Toward Recognition
abstract: A little over a week after taking power, the rebel alliance that led the overthrow of the Assad regime has begun to receive diplomats in the Syrian capital, Damascus.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a week after overthrowing the longtime Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad, the rebel alliance that took power in Syria was making rapid progress toward international recognition of its legitimacy as its officials began to receive diplomats from the United Nations, the Middle East and Europe.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 16, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: A Constitutional Convention? Some Democrats Fear It’s Coming.
abstract: Some Republicans have said that a constitutional convention is overdue. Many Democratic-led states have rescinded their long-ago calls for one, and California will soon consider whether to do the same.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans prepare to take control of Congress and the White House, among the many scenarios keeping Democrats up at night is an event that many Americans consider a historical relic: a constitutional convention.

headline: Top Canada Minister Resigns, Threatening Trudeau’s Hold on Power
abstract: Chrystia Freeland, the deputy prime minister and finance minister, had been helping lead Canada’s response to the incoming Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s hold on power was threatened on Monday after the deputy prime minister who led Canada’s response to the first Trump administration resigned abruptly, in a stinging rebuke to the country’s leader.

headline: 12 Die at Georgian Ski Resort From Suspected Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
abstract: The police say the bodies were found in a room above an Indian restaurant not long after a generator had been plugged in nearby.
lead_paragraph: Twelve people were found dead of suspected carbon monoxide poisoning in Gudauri, a ski area in the Caucasus Mountains in Georgia, the country’s Ministry of Internal Affairs said.

headline: How Well Do You Know the London of Charles Dickens?
abstract: Try this short quiz to see how many landmarks and locations around the city you remember from the great author’s works.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz to see how many landmarks and locations around the city you remember from the great author’s works.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Trump’s Health Secretary Pick, Meets With Lawmakers
abstract: Mr. Kennedy has begun meeting with Republican senators to build support for his confirmation, which could be imperiled by his anti-vaccine stance.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for health secretary, began meeting with Republican lawmakers late Monday afternoon to make his case for a spot in Mr. Trump’s cabinet.

headline: Adams Is Denied Public Matching Funds, Hampering Re-election Campaign
abstract: The New York City Campaign Finance Board voted to withhold as much as $4.3 million in matching funds from Mayor Eric Adams, as he faces federal corruption charges focused on his fund-raising practices.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams was denied public matching funds for his re-election campaign on Monday as he faces federal corruption charges focused on his fund-raising practices, dealing a major setback to his bid for a second term.

headline: Is Protein Powder a Scam?
abstract: Most people don’t need to consume this supplement, experts say, but it can be useful in certain situations.
lead_paragraph: On TikTok, influencers tout protein powder as key to building muscle and nourishing their bodies — all in a quick, convenient scoop added to coffee or a smoothie.

headline: German Government Collapses at a Perilous Time for Europe
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote, deepening the political turbulence in one of the continent’s most powerful economies.
lead_paragraph: The German government collapsed on Monday as Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote in Parliament, deepening a crisis of leadership across Europe at a time of mounting economic and security challenges.

headline: Letby’s Lawyers Seek Appeal After Lead Expert ‘Changed Mind’ on Murders
abstract: Lawyers for Lucy Letby, a British nurse found guilty of murdering seven babies, said that the prosecution’s expert witness was not reliable after he changed his mind about why three infants died.
lead_paragraph: The defense team for Lucy Letby, a British nurse found guilty of murdering babies in her care, said on Monday that it will ask the Court of Appeal to review all of her convictions, because the lead prosecution expert has changed his mind about how three of the babies died.

headline: E.B. Furgurson III, Who Covered Massacre at His Newspaper, Dies at 70
abstract: After five people were killed in the newsroom, he set up a work space in the back of his pickup truck and made sure the next day’s issue was published.
lead_paragraph: E.B. Furgurson III, a reporter who, after five of his colleagues at the Maryland newspaper The Capital were massacred in their newsroom by a grudge-fueled gunman, helped produce the next day’s issue from his pickup truck, died on Nov. 25 in Annapolis, Md. He was 70.

headline: France Sends Soldiers to Find Survivors Following Cyclone Chido
abstract: The French territory of Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa was left devastated by Tropical Cyclone Chido. French authorities said it could take days to establish a death toll.
lead_paragraph: The French territory of Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa was left devastated by Tropical Cyclone Chido. French authorities said it could take days to establish a death toll.

headline: Sweet and Sour, Festive and Fast
abstract: This cranberry-orange chicken works just as well for a quiet Tuesday dinner as it does a Friday night gathering with friends.
lead_paragraph: As a festive main dish, chicken thighs may sound like a stretch. As opposed to, say, a glistening, bronze-skinned whole roasted bird, a panful of thighs can feel a little basic — not so much “Happy holidays!” as “Welp, it’s Tuesday.”

headline: The Deadly Lure of Subway Surfing
abstract: For more than a century, people have climbed on top of moving trains in search of a thrill. Now social media has attracted a new generation of daredevils.
lead_paragraph: On a late spring afternoon, two boys celebrating the last day of sixth grade set out through their New York City neighborhood in search of an adventure.

headline: Sudden Loss of Undocumented Workers Threw Tech Supplier Into Upheaval
abstract: Jabil says it required “herculean efforts” to replace employees from a staffing agency. Other businesses are bracing for “an enforcement storm” under President-elect Trump.
lead_paragraph: Jabil, a major manufacturer of electronics components for the tech industry, made a startling discovery in the spring of 2021: It had been relying on dozens of undocumented workers, contracted from a staffing agency, to power its manufacturing sites near Silicon Valley.

headline: Ex-Bangladeshi Leader Orchestrated Mass Disappearances, Inquiry Finds
abstract: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and top officials are implicated in a centralized program that abducted dissidents and held them in secret prisons, an official commission’s preliminary report said.
lead_paragraph: Bangladesh’s ousted prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, and senior officials orchestrated a centralized program of enforced disappearances with thousands of likely victims, a commission set up by the country’s interim government said in a preliminary report.

headline: Ways to Fix the Health Insurance Debacle
abstract: Responses to an essay by Andrew Witty, the C.E.O. of UnitedHealth Group. Also: Threats to democracy, in Hungary and America; a check on Trump; avoiding taxes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Men in Tights and Tutus: The Trocks Turn 50, Humor Intact
abstract: The Trocks were never interested in making a political statement, their artistic director said. “We are men doing performances of ballet in drag for comedic purposes.”
lead_paragraph: The ballerinas of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo never change. With the never-say-die showbiz spirit of a faded Russian touring company, and a whiff of greasepaint and glamour, Ida Nevasayneva, Maya Thickenthighya and the other ballet warriors are eternally giving heroic performances, triumphantly knocking off a technical trick or two, flirting with the audience, elbowing rivals out of the way.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Former Lt. Gov.’s Bid to Dismiss Charges
abstract: The former lieutenant governor of New York, Brian Benjamin, is accused of funneling state money to a local real estate developer in exchange for campaign contributions.
lead_paragraph: Brian A. Benjamin, the former lieutenant governor of New York, must face trial on federal corruption charges, after the U.S. Supreme Court turned down a request on Monday to dismiss much of the case.

headline: Biden Prepares to Target Chinese Legacy Chips With Trade Investigation
abstract: The investigation could result in tariffs on older types of chips from China, though the decision would ultimately fall to Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is preparing a trade investigation into China’s production of older-model semiconductors, in response to fears that the United States’ growing dependence on these products could pose a national security threat, according to people familiar with the matter and government and industry documents reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Gov. Murphy Grants First Pardons, Freeing 3 Women Convicted of Murder
abstract: The women, who had been abused, were recommended for clemency by a panel that Philip D. Murphy, New Jersey’s governor, set up.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey on Monday commuted the prison sentences of three women who had been abused and were convicted of killing men close to them — as he made the first pardons of his two-term administration.

headline: We Were All Just Catching Up to Lorraine O’Grady
abstract: Through her writing and performances, the artist helped new audiences to understand the cultural roots of racism and sexism.
lead_paragraph: Lorraine O’Grady, the conceptual and performance artist who died on Dec. 13 at age 90, was an inveterate correspondent — you never got a short note from Lorraine, you got the full intensity of her warmth, intellect and inquisitiveness in long missives often sent in the middle of the night, her favored time to work.

headline: An Exiled Conductor’s Once and Future Orchestras Present Dueling Concerts
abstract: Banished from his ensembles after striking a singer, John Eliot Gardiner has assembled a new group, with the same programming at the same venue.
lead_paragraph: Marten Root, a flutist specializing in historical instruments, has played under the conductor John Eliot Gardiner for over 35 years, and considers him a profoundly intelligent and honest musician.

headline: Trump Says He Would Consider Pardoning Eric Adams
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s comment reflects an unusual relationship that Mr. Adams, the New York mayor, has encouraged as his federal corruption trial nears.
lead_paragraph: The question has hung over New York City politics for months: If Mayor Eric Adams was convicted on federal corruption charges, would Donald J. Trump pardon him?

headline: Trump Holds Forth on Vaccines, the Media and Drones
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced a $100 billion investment from SoftBank, a Japanese company, then jumped from one topic to another in his first news conference since the election.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J.
