Trump said on Monday that he was skeptical of mandatory vaccines for schools, threatened more lawsuits against media companies and accused the Biden administration of hiding the truth about recent drone sightings during his first wide-ranging news conference since the election.

headline: 11 Fun Party Appetizers That Start With Frozen Puff Pastry
abstract: These golden, flaky bites are sure to impress your guests during the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: The wise Ina Garten once said — then repeated again, and again — “store-bought is fine.” And, each time, she was absolutely right, especially when it comes to puff pastry, the ultimate way to take any party app to the next level. It’s easy to work with, affordable and available at most supermarkets. Put a few sheets to use with these 11 golden, flaky snacks and treats that are sure to impress your guests this holiday season.

headline: Tice’s Mother Asks Netanyahu for Pause in Syria Strikes to Search for Journalist
abstract: Debra Tice wrote to the Israeli prime minister that her family had “credible information” that Austin Tice may be held in a prison outside Damascus, in an area where Israel had been conducting military operations.
lead_paragraph: The mother of the missing American journalist Austin Tice has told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in a letter that her family has “credible information” that Mr. Tice may be held in a prison outside the Syrian capital, Damascus, and urged the Israelis to pause military strikes in the area to allow rescuers to search the site.

headline: Several Killed in Wisconsin School Shooting, Including Juvenile Suspect
abstract: The police responded to a shooting at a private Christian school in Madison, Wis., on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The police responded to a shooting at a private Christian school in Madison, Wis., on Monday.

headline: Germany’s Olaf Scholz Loses a Vote of Confidence
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called for the confidence vote after his three-party coalition broke up. Lawmakers voted to dissolve the existing government by a vote of 394 to 207, with 116 abstaining.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called for the confidence vote after his three-party coalition broke up. Lawmakers voted to dissolve the existing government by a vote of 394 to 207, with 116 abstaining.

headline: A Hanukkah-Ready Recipe That Does Everything Right
abstract: Inspired by a Ukrainian cafe and a mother-in-law’s classic, this take on kasha varnishkes is rich with caramelized onions.
lead_paragraph: When my daughter Daniela returned from a work trip to Eastern Europe last summer, she raved about the kasha varnishkes at Kafe Jerusalem, a tiny Ashkenazic Jewish restaurant in Lviv, Ukraine. According to her, it was even better than mine.

headline: Hegseth’s Guard Left the Army After the Beating of a Civilian During Training
abstract: John Hasenbein, who has escorted Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary to meetings on Capitol Hill, said he was unjustly prosecuted for the 2019 episode.
lead_paragraph: When Pete Hegseth visited senators on Capitol Hill this month in an effort to show that he has the qualifications and judgment to lead the Defense Department, he was escorted by a security guard with a dark episode in his past.

headline: How to Understand the Collapse of Germany’s Government, and What’s Next
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote in the German Parliament, ending the unpopular three-party coalition government he has led since 2021.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called a confidence vote in the German Parliament on Monday. He lost by a tally of 394-207, with 116 abstaining. That effectively ends the unpopular government he has led since 2021.

headline: Orrin H. Pilkey, Warrior in a Fight to Save Imperiled Beaches, Dies at 90
abstract: An eminent geologist, he argued against putting condos and hotels on vulnerable coastal landscapes. Environmentalists applauded; many others didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Orrin H. Pilkey, a coastal geologist whose blunt and often successful arguments against sea walls and other armor on the saltwater beaches of the United States won him reverence from environmentalists and condemnation from developers and politicians, died on Friday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 90.

headline: Putin Stays Silent on Syria, With Russia’s Future There in Question
abstract: In an hourlong televised meeting with his top military brass, Vladimir Putin left Syria unmentioned and made it clear that winning in Ukraine was his top priority.
lead_paragraph: For an hour on Monday, President Vladimir V. Putin and his defense minister presided over a televised, annual meeting of the Russian military’s top brass. They held forth on NATO, Ukraine and issues as obscure as mortgages for service members.

headline: Blocked Muslim Judicial Nominee Decries Senate ‘Smear Campaign’
abstract: Adeel Mangi, who would have been the first Muslim American federal appellate court judge, wrote an angry letter to President Biden describing bigotry he faced in the confirmation process.
lead_paragraph: The first Muslim American to be nominated for a federal appellate court judgeship lashed out at senators and the judicial confirmation process in a letter to President Biden on Monday, saying he had been the victim of a bigoted smear campaign.

headline: Read the Letter
abstract: Adeel Mangi, who would have been the first Muslim American federal appellate court judge, wrote an angry letter to President Biden describing bigotry he faced in the confirmation process.
lead_paragraph: Adeel Mangi, who would have been the first Muslim American federal appellate court judge, wrote an angry letter to President Biden describing bigotry he faced in the confirmation process.

headline: How Does A.I. Think? Here’s One Theory.
abstract: It may employ a kind of reasoning humans use all the time — but you’ve probably never heard of it.
lead_paragraph: In the roughly two years since the public release of ChatGPT, artificial intelligence has advanced far more rapidly than humanity has learned to use its good features and to suppress its bad ones. On the bad side, for example, it turns out that A.I. is really good at manipulating and deceiving its human “masters.”

headline: Japan’s SoftBank Makes Big Investment Pledge Ahead of Trump’s Inauguration. Again.
abstract: The technology company plans to invest $100 billion in U.S. projects, echoing the multibillion-dollar pledge it made after Donald J. Trump’s first election victory in 2016.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s first news conference since the election covered a wide range of topics, but it began with an eye-catching pledge: a $100 billion investment in the United States by SoftBank, a Japanese technology company.

headline: Max Ends Its Partnership With ‘Sesame Street’
abstract: The venerable children’s series must find a new home after airing on HBO and then the streaming service Max. Old episodes will be available on Max through 2027.
lead_paragraph: “Sesame Street” is relocating.

headline: TikTok Asks Supreme Court to Block Law Banning Its U.S. Operations
abstract: The company and its Chinese parent invoked the First Amendment in urging the justices to step in before a Jan. 19 deadline to sell or be shut down.
lead_paragraph: TikTok asked the Supreme Court on Monday to temporarily block a law that would effectively ban it in the United States in a matter of weeks.

headline: Carlos Watson, Ozy Media Co-Founder, Is Sentenced to Almost 10 Years in Prison
abstract: A federal jury in July found Mr. Watson, who started the digital media company in 2013, guilty of trying to defraud investors and lenders.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Watson, a co-founder of the now-defunct digital media company Ozy Media, was sentenced on Monday to almost 10 years in prison for trying to defraud investors and lenders by lying about the company’s finances.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Syria’s New Leader Calls for Lifting Sanctions
abstract: Plus, the breakout stars of 2024.
lead_paragraph: Ahmed al-Shara, the leader of the rebel coalition that swept to power in Syria last week, urged the U.S. and other nations to lift sanctions against the country, saying in an interview with journalists yesterday that his urgent priority was rebuilding.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s First Post-Election News Conference
abstract: The president-elect made inaccurate claims about a small-business survey, the federal budget, autism rates and pesticide use, among other claims.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump, in his first news conference since the election, again displayed his penchant for exaggeration.

headline: House Tour | Dennis Maher
abstract: The artist’s Victorian home in Buffalo, N.Y., is filled with found objects, including over 100 dollhouses.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s Victorian home in Buffalo, N.Y., is filled with found objects, including over 100 dollhouses.

headline: An ‘Architectural Dream World’ Filled With Hundreds of Dollhouses
abstract: The artist Dennis Maher — who rescued his Buffalo, N.Y., home from the brink of destruction — has always treasured what others have overlooked.
lead_paragraph: When the visual artist Dennis Maher, 48, acquired his 1890s duplex in Buffalo, N.Y., in 2009, it was slated for demolition. The relatively unassuming wooden building in the city’s historic Fargo Estate neighborhood, with a gable roof and two stacked front porches, had sat unoccupied for a year and was scheduled to be replaced by a parking lot. Maher stepped in, and for $10,000, the house was his.

headline: Young Republicans Gather, Ready to Make America Vengeful Again
abstract: At a gala on Wall Street for the New York Young Republican Club, attendees were looking forward to retribution from the next Trump era, and musing on another run in 2028.
lead_paragraph: Late Sunday night, in a banquet hall inside the grand old Merchants’ Exchange building on Wall Street, the Republican operative Stephen K. Bannon was putting on one of his over-the-top, apocalyptic performances.

headline: Black Student Enrollment at Harvard Law Drops by More Than Half
abstract: After a Supreme Court decision ended race-based admissions, some law schools saw a decline in Black and Hispanic students entering this fall. Harvard appeared to have the steepest drop.
lead_paragraph: The number of Black students entering Harvard Law School dropped sharply this fall after last year’s Supreme Court decision banning affirmative action in college admissions, according to enrollment data released on Monday.

headline: Real Estate Leaders Sue to Stop New York City’s Overhaul of Broker Fees
abstract: A law in New York City shifting broker fees from renters to landlords is set to take effect in June. Real estate leaders want to stop it.
lead_paragraph: Real estate leaders in New York City filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to halt a new law that would shift expensive broker fees from renters to landlords.

headline: Gilgo Beach Prosecutor Promises Major Development in Serial Killing Case
abstract: The defendant, Rex Heuermann, is due in court Tuesday. Investigators have been trying to tie him to other unsolved killings on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Investigators on Long Island on Tuesday morning will announce a “significant development” in the investigation of Rex Heuermann, the Massapequa Park architectural consultant accused in the Gilgo Beach serial killings.

headline: The Ordinary Explanations Behind the Mysterious Lights in the Skies
abstract: As tips roll in, most reported incidents involve piloted planes and hobby drones, not foreign spying or secret programs, officials say.
lead_paragraph: As reports of strange lights in the sky over New Jersey and other parts of the East Coast have grown, government officials have been stating more firmly that, in essence, there is nothing to see here.

headline: ‘Unfettered’ Gas Exports Would Harm U.S. Economy, Energy Secretary Warns
abstract: Jennifer Granholm said a new analysis showed that the continued pace of exports was “neither sustainable nor advisable.”
lead_paragraph: If the United States were to continue exporting liquefied natural gas in the way that has made it the world’s biggest gas supplier, it would drive up costs for American consumers and businesses, pollute struggling communities and increase global greenhouse gas emissions, according to a letter written by Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm that was obtained Monday by The Times.

headline: Syrian Rebel Leader Calls for Lifting of Sanctions, as al-Assad Defends Exit
abstract: Ahmed al-Shara urged nations to remove sanctions from Syria and the terrorism designation from his group so Syria could rebuild. Bashar al-Assad also gave his first account of fleeing to Russia.
lead_paragraph: Ahmed al-Shara, the leader of the rebel coalition that swept into Damascus last week and ousted the Assad regime, urged the United States and other nations to remove sanctions imposed on the country, saying in an interview on Monday that all constraints needed to be lifted so that Syria could rebuild.

headline: Trump Held His First News Conference as President-Elect
abstract: Also, Syria’s new leader called for sanctions to be lifted. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump invited reporters to his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida today for his first news conference since the election. The president-elect spent nearly half an hour jumping from one topic to another, including border security, tax cuts and the war in Ukraine, before taking questions.

headline: Why Do You Think the Killing of a Health Care C.E.O. Has Sparked Such an Intense National Conversation?
abstract: Have you been following the story? What do you think the news and our reactions to it say about America today?
lead_paragraph: Please keep in mind that this forum is for teenagers only. While there are many places on NYTimes.com for adults to comment, this is the only dedicated spot for the voices of young people.

headline: Dick Van Arsdale, 81, One of First Identical Twins in the N.B.A., Dies
abstract: A three-time All-Star, he played for the Knicks and the Phoenix Suns. For one season, he and Tom Van Arsdale were hard-to-tell-apart teammates.
lead_paragraph: Dick Van Arsdale, a three-time All-Star who, with his brother, Tom, was half of the first set of identical twins to play in the N.B.A. after starring and confusing opponents and teammates alike in high school and at Indiana University, died on Monday at his home in Phoenix. He was 81.

headline: Jay-Z Will Seek Dismissal of Assault Lawsuit His Lawyer Calls a ‘Sham’
abstract: The woman who accused him of raping her in 2000, when she was a minor, acknowledged to NBC that there were inconsistencies in her account, but stood by her claim.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Jay-Z plan to ask a judge to toss a lawsuit accusing the rapper of raping a 13-year-old in 2000, pointing to what they described as “glaring inconsistencies” that emerged in an NBC interview of the accuser, who was not named in the suit.

headline: An Offhand Remark by Trump Gives a Glimpse Into His Worldview
abstract: “The first term, everybody was fighting me,” the president-elect said. “In this term, everybody wants to be my friend.”
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump had been holding forth for about an hour when he gave an unsolicited assessment of the difference between his White House transition eight years ago and now.

headline: Trump Meets the Press
abstract: Reflecting on how much has changed, and hasn’t, for Donald Trump since he first became president.
lead_paragraph: Nearly eight years ago, I remember walking into the lobby of Trump Tower to cover President-elect Donald Trump’s first news conference after the 2016 election. On Monday, as I watched him turn Mar-a-Lago into the backdrop of his first news conference since he became president-elect for the second time, I couldn’t help but reflect on how much has changed.

headline: Judge Denies Trump’s Bid to Throw Out Conviction Over Immunity Ruling
abstract: Justice Juan M. Merchan thwarted one of several attempts by Donald J. Trump to clear his record of 34 felonies before returning to the White House.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Monday rejected Donald J. Trump’s argument that a recent Supreme Court ruling had nullified his criminal case in New York, upholding the former and future president’s felony conviction for falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal.

headline: Biden Administration Takes First Step to Retaliate Against China Over Hack
abstract: The Commerce Department is banning the few remaining operations of China Telecom in the United States, a move that appears unlikely to deter Beijing from conducting sophisticated cyberoperations.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has taken its first step to retaliate for China’s broad hack of American telecommunications firms, moving to ban the few remaining operations of China Telecom in the United States.

headline: This Is the Secret to the Perfect Baked Potato
abstract: A simple trick yields crisp outsides and fluffy insides, ready to be topped in three smart, exciting ways from Eric Kim.
lead_paragraph: Turns out, the baked potato has always been big and great.

headline: The Great Capitulation
abstract: Powerful Americans have lost the will to resist Trump.
lead_paragraph: At a press conference at Mar-a-Lago on Monday, Donald Trump described recent visits from Tim Cook, C.E.O. of Apple, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, and other tech barons. “In the first term, everyone was fighting me,” he said. “In this term, everyone wants to be my friend.” For once, he wasn’t exaggerating.

headline: Review: In ‘Eureka Day,’ Holding Space for Those You Hate
abstract: A hilarious new Broadway production asks: Can the superwoke vaxxers and anti-vaxxers at an elite private school learn to get along?
lead_paragraph: Just in time, laughter is making a big comeback on Broadway. Better yet, it comes in several varieties.

headline: Woman Who Stowed Away on Paris Flight Tries to Flee by Bus to Canada
abstract: The woman, Svetlana Dali, had been ordered to wear an ankle monitor after her arrest, but she cut it off and boarded a bus, a law enforcement official said.
lead_paragraph: The woman who stowed away on a plane from New York City to Paris late last month was arrested on Monday after trying to leave the country again, this time on a bus bound for Canada, two law enforcement officials said.

headline: Florida Man Is Sentenced to Death for Killing 5 Women in a Bank in 2019
abstract: The man, Zephen Xaver, 27, will have his case automatically appealed to the Florida Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who killed five women inside a bank in January 2019 by forcing them to lie down on the floor as he fatally shot each one was sentenced to death on Monday.

headline: Sirens, Then an Excruciating Wait for School Families
abstract: It would be hours before any details emerged about Monday’s shooting at Abundant Life Christian School, including that the shooter was a student at the school.
lead_paragraph: Inside Abundant Life Christian School, a chilling message came over the intercom late Monday morning: “Lockdown. This is not a drill.”

headline: Map: 7.3-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Vanuatu
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 17, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Dec. 9 about a confidential Navy program studying a possible link between intense fighter jet operations and brain injuries misspelled the given name of the woman who was Jake Rosales’s girlfriend at the time of his death. She is Ann-Marie Avanni, not Anne-Marie. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

headline: Powerful Earthquake Jolts Vanuatu, Damaging Buildings
abstract: A tsunami alert was lifted for the Pacific island nation, but government websites were offline after the quake. The U.S. Embassy building was seriously damaged, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck near Vanuatu early Tuesday afternoon, triggering small tsunami waves, causing serious damage to the U.S. Embassy in the capital and knocking out most of the internet connectivity in the Pacific Island nation.

headline: Possible, but Not Looking Good
abstract: Kathy Lowden makes a few changes.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Justice Dept. Charges 2 Men in Deadly Drone Attack on U.S. Soldiers
abstract: The men are accused of supplying key parts in Iranian drones that killed three U.S. service members and injured dozens of others at an American military base in Jordan.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has charged two men with illegally supplying parts used in an Iranian-backed militia’s drone attack in January that killed three U.S. service members and injured more than 40 others at an American military base in Jordan, federal prosecutors in Boston announced on Monday.

headline: Abundant Life’s Precautions ‘Helped Keep Students Safe,’ Official Says
abstract: Training and precautions taken by the Christian school in Wisconsin may have prevented the shooter from harming even more people, officials said.
lead_paragraph: When the words “Lockdown. This is not a drill” echoed over the intercom, Kellen Lewis’s four children knew what to do, he said.

headline: 15-Year-Old Girl Identified as the Shooter in a Wisconsin School
abstract: Natalie Rupnow was identified by the police as the shooter in the attack at Abundant Life Christian School. Investigators are still trying to piece together what led up to the shooting.
lead_paragraph: The shooter who killed at least two people on Monday at a Christian school in Madison, Wis., was identified as Natalie Rupnow, a 15-year-old student who later died from what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said.

headline: Musings on Love (and Gummies) From Tom Hanks, Jon Stewart and Fran Lebowitz
abstract: Actors and comedians offered relationship advice at a performance of the new Broadway play, “All In: Comedy About Love,” by Simon Rich.
lead_paragraph: On Monday evening, more than a dozen comedians walked into a Broadway theater near Times Square game to talk about love.

headline: Officials Release Names of Victims in Wisconsin School Shooting
abstract: The police in Madison, Wis., were working to establish a motive for the attack, which left a 14-year-old student and 42-year-old teacher dead and six others injured.

headline: Quote of the Day: Democrats Aim to Foil a Constitutional Rewrite
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We’re in an unprecedented time in American history, so it’s hard to make predictions about anything.”

headline: Listen: Can You Guess These 12 Christmas Movies?
abstract: Find out if you deserve the expert’s Santa hat or a big old lump of coal.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on Dec. 24, 2022.

headline: Confidence in U.S. Courts Plummets to Rate Far Below Peer Nations
abstract: Very few countries have experienced similar declines, typically in the wake of wrenching turmoil. Experts called the data, from a new Gallup poll, stunning and worrisome.
lead_paragraph: Public confidence in the American legal system has plunged over the past four years, a new Gallup poll found, putting it in the company of nations like Myanmar, Syria and Venezuela.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Germany’s political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: The German government collapsed as Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote in Parliament, deepening a crisis of leadership across Europe at a time of mounting economic and security challenges, including the war in Ukraine.

headline: Pope Francis: There Is Faith in Humor
abstract: The best thing to do in front of a mirror is to laugh at ourselves. It is good for us.
lead_paragraph: Life inevitably has its sadnesses, which are part of every path of hope and every path toward conversion. But it is important to avoid wallowing in melancholy at all costs, not to let it embitter the heart.

headline: The Germany We Knew Is Gone
abstract: The economically prosperous, socially cohesive and politically stable country is no longer itself.
lead_paragraph: When I recently picked up a rental car in Las Vegas — I was in America to cover the elections — the agent at the counter insisted on “upgrading” me to a BMW. “So you feel at home,” he said, looking at my German driver’s license, smiling. I took the keys and made a mental note: Outside Germany, Germany is still intact.

headline: Water Main Break in the Bronx Floods Streets and Cuts Off Power
abstract: Some cars were submerged by the rising water. By Tuesday morning, the flooding had mostly stopped as crews worked to repair the problem.
lead_paragraph: City officials were dealing with the aftermath on Tuesday of a major water main break in the Bronx that submerged cars and forced roads to close Monday night.

headline: Ukraine Says It Killed General Who Led Russia’s Nuclear Defense Force
abstract: A Ukrainian official said Kyiv was responsible for the assassination in Moscow of Gen. Igor Kirillov, the chief of Russia’s radioactive, chemical and biological defense forces.
lead_paragraph: A general in charge of the Russian military’s nuclear and chemical weapons protection forces was killed by a bomb on a Moscow street on Tuesday, in one of the most brazen assassinations since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine nearly three years ago.

headline: Massive Earthquake in Vanuatu Damages U.S. Embassy
abstract: The embassy was one of many damaged buildings filmed by a resident after the 7.3-magnitude earthquake.
lead_paragraph: The embassy was one of many damaged buildings filmed by a resident after the 7.3-magnitude earthquake.

headline: Word of the Day: primatology
abstract: This word has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word primatology has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year, on June 20 in “After a Weather Disaster, a Surprise: Some Ornery Monkeys Got Nicer” by Rachel Nuwer:

headline: Late Night Delights in Pie-in-the-Sky Theories About the Drones
abstract: Jimmy Fallon said no one knows where the drones spotted on the East Coast come from or why they exist: “It’s basically air crypto.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: As Adams and Trump Get Cozier, Some N.Y. Republicans Recoil
abstract: Donald J. Trump is speaking sympathetically about Mayor Eric Adams, but Republicans in New York still view the mayor with skepticism.
lead_paragraph: Sid Rosenberg, an outspoken radio host in New York City and an ardent supporter of President-elect Donald J. Trump, was at a loss.

headline: ‘Life-Changing’ Psychedelics, for When Life Is Ending
abstract: People are turning to psilocybin, ketamine and other treatments for palliative care.
lead_paragraph: Barry Blechman, 81, an international relations analyst with metastatic bladder cancer, traveled last winter from his home in Washington, D.C., to a clinic in Bend, Ore., where he drank a tea containing psilocybin, the psychoactive component of magic mushrooms. He then stretched out on the floor and closed his eyes.

headline: Holiday Break
abstract: How will you spend your time off from school?
lead_paragraph: Many students have time off from school between Christmas and New Year’s Day.

headline: Aaron Rodgers, an Aching Achilles and Ayahuasca
abstract: A documentary about Rodgers, the 41-year-old quarterback, delves into drugs, religion and politics (and yes, that’s Robert F. Kennedy Jr.).
lead_paragraph: Aaron Rodgers has been in the spotlight throughout his two-decade N.F.L. career, winning a Super Bowl and four Most Valuable Player awards with the Green Bay Packers while generating headlines about his separation from his parents and his distrust of the coronavirus vaccines.

headline: What North Korea Gains From Its Alliance With Russia — and What It Risks
abstract: Sending troops to fight against Ukraine has gotten North Korea much-needed cash and diplomatic leverage. But there may be hidden costs, too.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, has taken his boldest diplomatic gamble by supplying an estimated 11,000 troops and stockpiles of weapons to Russia to support its war against Ukraine.

headline: U.S. Cites ‘Indications’ North Korean Soldiers Died Fighting for Russia
abstract: The Pentagon spokesman said the North Koreans had entered combat last week in the Russian region of Kursk, but he did not specify the number of casualties.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has seen “indications” that the North Korean forces who have been sent to Russia to help the Kremlin in its war against Ukraine have suffered their first casualties, according to a U.S. official.

headline: How to Get a Party Buzz Even When You’re Not Drinking
abstract: These tips for sober socializing may not have you dancing on tables, but they’ll help you have plenty of fun.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t matter why you’ve chosen not to drink this holiday season: Your reasons are your own, and they are good enough. But regardless of whether you are sober year-round or you’re just giving yourself a break in December, you are likely facing a series of festive occasions that test your will to make merry with nothing but your unadulterated personality and an ugly sweater. Scrooge may have faced three spirits, but none of them were the Ghost of Christmas Small Talk.

headline: Can You Be Allergic to Your Christmas Tree?
abstract: Itchy eyes, wheezing, sniffles, sneezing: Here’s how to keep “Christmas tree syndrome” symptoms at bay.
lead_paragraph: Q: I always get sneezy and congested around the holidays. Is my Christmas tree to blame?

headline: Books That Make Great Gifts
abstract: Joumana Khatib, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, recommends a few books to readers looking for gifts for their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Joumana Khatib, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, recommends a few books to readers looking for gifts for their loved ones.

headline: Yellowstone in Winter: 5 Ways to Enjoy the Quiet Season
abstract: Forget the summer crowds, exploring wide-open landscapes by ski, snowmobile or snowshoe, and revel in a solitude that few park visitors ever get to experience.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that Yellowstone National Park can be jampacked in the summer, when up to one million people jockey for space each July. But February typically draws fewer than 50,000 visitors. That makes winter the best time to beat the crowds, as well as to experience a captivating and seldom-seen world revealed only when the park is covered in snow.

headline: The Extremely Offline Joy of the Board Game Club
abstract: Hungry for in-person interaction, Gen Z and millennial players are joining old-fashioned chess, mahjong and backgammon groups.
lead_paragraph: When Michelle Kong started a chess club last year, hoping to meet other players in their 20s, attendance was so meager that she needed only one chessboard. She posted about the club on social media until a tattooed cross section of young people in Los Angeles began showing up to exchange pawns and phone numbers.

headline: Oh, the Places We Went!
abstract: This year, of the 52 destinations on our annual list, our writers and photographers touched down in 11 to capture their essence. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: Each January, the Travel section offers a list of “52 Places to Go” in the coming year, filled with recommendations for destinations that we think are prime to be visited. Our choices are meant to be an inspiration for travelers — and dreamers — not a checklist to be ticked off (though for two years we did send 52 Places Travelers racing around the globe). With next year’s list almost ready to go, here’s a look at how The Times’s writers and photographers covered the places we showcased on our 2024 list when they visited them this year.

headline: Giant Companies Took Secret Payments to Allow Free Flow of Opioids
abstract: Drugmakers including Purdue Pharma paid pharmacy benefit managers not to restrict painkiller prescriptions, a New York Times investigation found.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, the drug industry middleman Express Scripts announced that it was taking decisive steps to curb abuse of the prescription painkillers that had fueled America’s overdose crisis. The company said it was “putting the brakes on the opioid epidemic” by making it harder to get potentially dangerous amounts of the drugs.

headline: Trump’s Tariffs Helped Northern Vietnam Boom Like Never Before. What Now?
abstract: The north benefited from the global search for alternatives to Chinese manufacturing. No one knows whether a second Trump term will impede or accelerate that growth.
lead_paragraph: Pham Van Thinh can see the back of an LG electronics factory from his patio, and in his eyes, nothing is more beautiful than that bright white behemoth.

headline: The 26 Best Dishes We Ate Across the U.S. in 2024
abstract: A perfectly beefy suadero taco, a studded arroz caldo and more of our favorite bites from a year of eating.
lead_paragraph: After months of traveling to more than 30 states and eating in hundreds of restaurants, it’s not easy to keep track of all the dishes that crossed our tables. But on the other hand, there are some we couldn’t forget (including many from New York City, which we gave its own list). Whether soups or sweets, a single tasting-menu course or a perfect ham sandwich, these are the bites from 2024 that will linger in our minds well into the new year. BRIAN GALLAGHER

headline: Here’s a Hollywood Twist: Streaming Success Runs Through Theaters
abstract: Just a few years ago, media executives thought theatrical releases didn’t benefit their streaming services. Now, many of them think the opposite.
lead_paragraph: Amazon Studios spent $250 million to make “Red One,” a comedic holiday action film starring Dwayne Johnson and Chris Evans. Then the company pushed the film into more than 4,000 theaters, spending tens of millions more to market it.

headline: The Mayor’s Week Gets Off to a Rough Start
abstract: Eric Adams loses his closest aide and is denied access to public matching funds. But Donald Trump said he would consider pardoning him.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at why this week didn’t start well for Mayor Eric Adams. And the suspect in the Gilgo Beach serial killings is due in court on Long Island this morning, with investigators promising they’ll announce a “significant development” after the hearing.

headline: People Are Putting Beef on Their Faces. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: Natural, tallow-based cosmetics can be made at home or bought from artisans. Doctors aren’t thrilled, but they’re all the rage on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: When Sascha Green goes to Costco, she buys ground pork, turkey and chicken breasts for a week of dinners. And then she gets steak for her face.

headline: On Disc, the Conductor Michael Tilson Thomas Is Prolifically Himself
abstract: As Thomas turns 80, new collections of his recordings reveal the legacy of a maestro who has exuberantly refused to conform to expectations.
lead_paragraph: The conductor Michael Tilson Thomas has always had a way with words, but one refrain of his is especially memorable.

headline: Trump Can Pull Us Back From the Nuclear Brink
abstract: He is about to regain control of the country’s nuclear arsenal at one of the most volatile times in history.
lead_paragraph: He is about to regain control of the country’s nuclear arsenal at one of the most volatile times in history.

headline: What Satan’s Biographer Can Teach Us About Tyranny and Resistance
abstract: A new book about John Milton and “Paradise Lost” traces the 17th-century epic’s influence and relevance through the ages.
lead_paragraph: Cast out of America in 1952 as a political subversive, the Trinidadian historian C.L.R. James was imprisoned for a time at Ellis Island while he challenged his deportation. From his cell, James — the author of “The Black Jacobins” (1938), still the seminal history of the Haitian Revolution — had a view of Manhattan’s glittering skyline. This episode inspired him to write “Mariners, Renegades and Castaways,” an unusual book of literary criticism that read the American character through “Moby-Dick.” According to James, there is always an impulse toward American totalitarianism as embodied by someone like the narcissistic and megalomaniacal Captain Ahab, content to use anyone as a means to an end.

headline: The Pure Liberation of a Personal Urination Device
abstract: A plastic aqueduct provides new pathways for relief.
lead_paragraph: The device appeared on the front porch for my birthday: seven inches of sturdy pink plastic shaped like a deep-bowled spoon. “Happy Peeing!” my friend — who, like me, is an avid hiker — had written on a note tied with a ribbon.

headline: Is ‘S.N.L.’ Too Online, or Are We All?
abstract: Sketches are constantly gesturing toward internet culture — which makes sense, since the show has long been internet culture itself.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment during the cold open of a recent “S.N.L.” episode that made for a pretty good microcosm of the show’s current state. It was Nov. 16, and the sketch was built around Donald Trump (as played by James Austin Johnson) visiting the White House to meet with Joe Biden (played, in a guest performance, by 1990s “S.N.L.” alum Dana Carvey). Johnson and Carvey are both excellent enough impressionists to carry a sketch, but within a minute, this one was making a different kind of joke: Carvey’s Biden gestured toward a fireplace and said, “I’m gonna sit here and smile, while ignoring the giant fire right behind me.” Part of why that got a laugh was the way it captured the stiltedness of the real-life photo op — but another was the way it gestured toward a decade-old internet meme, an image in which a wide-eyed dog placidly enjoys a cup of coffee in the midst of a raging house fire, calmly saying, “This is fine.” If you didn’t catch the reference, though, never fear: After the laugh break, Carvey spelled it out. “Just like the meme,” he said. “Can we put it up, side by side?” And then we saw the original meme in split screen with Carvey’s Biden, matching the dog’s posture, a kind of internet-poisoned tableau vivant. “This is fine,” Carvey intoned.

headline: ‘No Place to Hide’: Trapped on the Border, Immigrants Fear Deportation
abstract: Undocumented immigrants whose children or spouses are U.S. citizens are feeling particularly vulnerable to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats to push them out.
lead_paragraph: For the last quarter of a century, Maria’s version of the American dream has been confined to a small corner of South Texas, tucked between the border with Mexico and a fortified Border Patrol checkpoint 77 miles north.

headline: Tackling the Difficult Subject at the Heart of ‘It’s a Wonderful Life’
abstract: A festival devoted to the film usually focuses on its comforting message. This year, it also underscored suicide prevention.
lead_paragraph: Every year in Seneca Falls, N.Y., a festival celebrates “It’s a Wonderful Life,” Frank Capra’s heartwarming 1946 drama about the trials and triumphs of a family man named George Bailey, played by Jimmy Stewart in a beloved role.

headline: The ‘Unexpectedly Sly’ and ‘Brilliantly Scuzzy’ Shows, Music and Movies Readers Loved
abstract: Critical favorites like “Anora,” “Cowboy Carter” and “The Bear” still left room for more recent arrivals like “Wicked” and Broadway’s “Maybe Happy Ending.”
lead_paragraph: Our culture critics named their favorites for the year so far, but what did readers think?

headline: Paul Krugman: After 25 Years, My Parting Words to Readers
abstract: A columnist reflects on a quarter-century of contrarian opinions at The Times.

headline: What’s Funny About John Mulaney and Simon Rich’s Friendship? Everything.
abstract: The former “S.N.L.” writing partners have reunited for Rich’s “superficially wacky” Broadway show, “All In: Comedy About Love.”
lead_paragraph: The comedian John Mulaney joined the writing staff of “Saturday Night Live” in 2008. On his first day, he began working with Simon Rich, a boy-wonder Harvard grad who had already published two collections of short fiction. Their first sketch, “Cash for Silver,” a werewolf-accented parody of the cash-for-gold cable ads made it to the dress rehearsal, but was bumped before it aired.

headline: Should the President Have Nuclear Sole Authority? We Asked 530 Incoming Congress Members.
abstract: If there is a widespread urgency in Congress to cooperate on bills that create safeguards around nuclear war, it was not apparent.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to include additional responses.

headline: ‘A Sword and a Shield’: How the Supreme Court Supercharged Trump’s Power
abstract: The legal scholars Gillian Metzger and Kate Shaw discuss how recent Supreme Court decisions could enable Trump in his second term.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: ‘Star Trek II’ and ‘Dirty Dancing’ Join National Film Registry
abstract: The movies, along with “Uptown Saturday Night,” “Mi Familia” and “The Social Network,” are among the 25 selected by the Librarian of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Attention all Trekkies: The Library of Congress is doing its part to ensure that “Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan” will live long and prosper.

headline: High on Hope, Wall St. Hears What It Wants From Trump
abstract: Investors and executives are often emphasizing what they like in the president-elect’s agenda, while dismissing what they don’t as mere posturing.
lead_paragraph: If you ask many a Wall Street investor, tax cuts are poised for extension, deregulation is all but guaranteed, immigration reform for high-skill workers has real potential and President-elect Donald J. Trump’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) might just cut the deficit.

headline: Cafes Can’t Play Music, but the Water Taps Work: Life Under Syria’s Rebels
abstract: The Islamists who now lead Syria have ruled the city of Idlib for years. Residents say they imposed some strict laws, but also heeded some complaints and improved public services.
lead_paragraph: On the second floor of the Shababeek cafe, overlooking the clock tower square in the city of Idlib, the side reserved for men was empty recently except for two young men nursing cups of Turkish coffee. The family side, where women are allowed, was nearly full.

headline: Nate Bargatze Wants Your Family to Stop Fighting for an Hour. Maybe Two.
abstract: On a CBS Christmas special and a new stand-up hour for Netflix, the comic keeps audiences connected by finding the magic in deliberately quotidian subjects.
lead_paragraph: An unexpected perk of Nate Bargatze’s leap from journeyman comic to stand-up star is his irrevocable connection to George Washington, the founding father he played in two appearances on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: If Men Are in Trouble, What Is the Cause?
abstract: The declining ability of many boys and men to compete at school and in the workplace has become both a social and a political issue.
lead_paragraph: The declining ability of many boys and men to compete at school and in the workplace has become both a social and a political issue.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 556
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,278
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Perilous Time for Europe, and a Brazen Assassination in Moscow
abstract: Plus, a school shooting in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Syria Unearths Years of Atrocities
abstract: After the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s regime, tens of thousands have been released from his brutal prisons. This is the story of one man who made it out.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains descriptions of torture and death. It also contains audio of death and grief.

headline: France Rushes Aid to Mayotte, Island Territory ‘Devastated’ by Cyclone
abstract: Hundreds are feared dead after the storm razed entire neighborhoods in Mayotte, a series of islands off the eastern coast of Africa, before unleashing its destructive force on Mozambique.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in the French archipelago of Mayotte introduced a curfew on Tuesday as they rushed to get food and water into the territory in the aftermath of a tropical cyclone that killed at least 22 people and flattened entire neighborhoods.

headline: The Unintended Consequences of Tariffs
abstract: The biggest benefits often emerge outside the countries engaged in a trade war.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump promises to impose big tariffs on Chinese products. The last time he did that, in 2018, he made at least one country boom: Vietnam.

headline: After Trump’s Victory, Republicans Trust the Election System Again
abstract: Surveys taken since Donald Trump’s win show a resurgent faith among the president-elect’s supporters, and little Democratic appetite for conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: Americans are more confident in the country’s election system than they have been at any time since the 2020 election, according to a new study — a shift owed to a sea change in Republican sentiment since Donald J. Trump’s election.

headline: New Berlin Film Festival Director Walks a Tightrope Over Israel
abstract: Can the event’s American-born leader reinvigorate the festival and maintain its commitment to open debate while satisfying German lawmakers?
lead_paragraph: When Tricia Tuttle opens her first edition of the Berlin International Film Festival in February, she will need to tread carefully.

headline: Bracing for a Fed Pullback
abstract: Wall Street sees the central bank cutting interest rates on Wednesday. But growing worries about inflation are adding to investor uncertainty about its policy agenda for 2025.
lead_paragraph: The Fed is set to wrap up its last policy meeting of the year on Wednesday, with markets essentially convinced that the central bank will lower interest rates for a third time since September.

headline: How to Repair the Planet? One Answer Might Be Hiding in Plain Sight.
abstract: We tend to look at environmental problems in isolation. A holistic approach would be more effective, a new report says.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, human needs can make problems like climate change and biodiversity collapse seem insurmountable. The world still relies on fossil fuels that are dangerously heating the planet. People need to eat, but agriculture is a top driver of biodiversity loss.

headline: ‘Bluey’ Is Headed to Theaters, Backed by Disney
abstract: BBC Studios and the Walt Disney Company will collaborate on a movie about the hit children’s character.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Mouse and Bluey are expanding their business partnership.

headline: Alabama Woman Receives Nation’s Third Pig Kidney Transplant
abstract: The patient, Towana Looney, was in better health than previous recipients, and her case could signal progress toward solving the organ-supply shortage.
lead_paragraph: A 53-year-old Alabama woman with kidney failure who waited eight years for an organ transplant has received a kidney harvested from a genetically modified pig, NYU Langone Health surgeons announced on Tuesday.

headline: Behind Germany’s Political Turmoil, a Stagnating Economy
abstract: One of Europe’s powerhouses is losing its competitive edge, and the political class can’t agree on why — or what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: If you are looking for a quick explanation for why Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government in Germany dissolved on Monday, consider this.

headline: Syria’s Rebel Leader Vows to Disband Armed Factions
abstract: The leader of the rebel coalition that swept to power last week said that fighters would be brought under the defense ministry’s authority. It was not immediately clear how that would be achieved.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the rebel coalition that swept to power in Syria over a week ago said that all armed groups in the country would be dissolved, Syrian state news media reported Tuesday, as the new government tries to rebuild a functioning state.

headline: Bomb Kills Russian Military General in Moscow
abstract: Gen. Igor Kirillov was responsible for Russia’s radioactive, chemical and biological defense forces. A Ukrainian official said Kyiv was behind his assassination.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Igor Kirillov was responsible for Russia’s radioactive, chemical and biological defense forces. A Ukrainian official said Kyiv was behind his assassination.

headline: Paul Watson, Anti-Whaling Activist, Is Released After 5 Months in Prison
abstract: Mr. Watson was facing extradition to Japan but was released after Denmark decided to reject the extradition request, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Paul Watson, the prominent anti-whaling activist, was released from custody in Greenland five months after being detained on an international arrest warrant, his lawyer said.

headline: The Search for van Gogh’s Lost Masterpiece
abstract: Cast off by the Nazis, but heralded by curators, the artist’s painting of his doctor, made just before van Gogh’s suicide, has not been seen in 34 years.
lead_paragraph: When the hammer fell at Christie’s in Manhattan on May 15, 1990, a Vincent van Gogh painting, “Portrait of Dr. Gachet,” set the record at the time for the most expensive work of art ever sold at auction, going to a Japanese paper magnate for $82.5 million.

headline: Who Was Igor Kirillov, the Russian General Assassinated in Moscow?
abstract: The general had faced sanctions for using chemical weapons in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Igor Kirillov, a general in charge of Russia’s military’s nuclear and chemical weapons protection forces, was killed on Tuesday by a bomb in Moscow, the Russian authorities said.

headline: Gilgo Beach Defendant Rex Heuermann Is Charged in a Seventh Killing
abstract: The man whom authorities call a serial killer was charged with second-degree murder in the case of Valerie Mack, who disappeared in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors say Rex Heuermann, the architectural consultant accused in the Gilgo Beach serial killings, created a grim planning document in 2000 that delineated his methods of hunting, torturing and killing humans.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Trump’s Health Secretary Pick, Lines Up Support From Receptive Senators
abstract: He is expected to meet this week with more than 20 senators, many of them receptive to his case to run the Health and Human Services Department.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for health secretary, encountered little pushback from Republican lawmakers on Tuesday as he sought to smooth over controversy from his record as an anti-vaccine activist who has supported abortion access.

headline: In Visit to Territory Seized in Syria, Netanyahu Says Troops Will Stay
abstract: The previously unannounced trip highlighted Israel’s expanded military presence across the de facto border with Syria since the fall of Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday met with military officers in territory Israel recently took control of in Syria,  and vowed that Israeli troops would remain in the country for the foreseeable future.

headline: Simply Having a Wonderful Weeknight Dinner
abstract: Recipes that live at the intersection of easy and fancy: salmon with salsa verde; chicken all’arrabbiata; BBQ pepper shrimp.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are as good a time as any to go all out with your cooking. For me, that means making relatively simple dishes that I rarely make the rest of the year, rather than spending days in the kitchen doing something one-off and involved. (The exception was December 2020, when I decided to make cassoulet for two adults, a toddler and a baby.)

headline: Old Voice Mails? Instructional VHS Tapes? They’re Music to His Ears.
abstract: Paul de Jong makes collaged songs out of obscurities he collects in his Mall of Found: a library of low-budget, homespun and dated pieces of spoken-word media.
lead_paragraph: Paul de Jong was busy digitizing “Doug Wead Narrates the Promises,” a 1981 reading of Bible scriptures on cassette. It was a drizzly November afternoon, and he was deep into the Book of Job. Outside his studio in North Adams, Mass., the darkening Berkshire Mountains loomed.

headline: A Look Inside Huawei’s Phone Shows How China’s Chip Advance Has Stalled
abstract: An analysis of Huawei’s latest series of smartphones, the Mate 70, found chips that showed little progress from those used in last year’s devices.
lead_paragraph: In the tense geopolitical rivalry between China and the United States for control of advanced technology, Huawei is often in the middle.

headline: Arlene Croce, Dance Critic With a Biting Wit, Dies at 90
abstract: Writing for The New Yorker, she was both admired and feared, wielding a sometimes merciless pen. Her study of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers drew accolades.
lead_paragraph: Arlene Croce, who as the dance critic of The New Yorker from 1973 to 1996 was both the most revered and the most feared dance writer in the United States, died on Monday in Johnston, R.I. She was 90.

headline: Tech Makes an Economic Case for Skilled Immigrants. Will Trump Bite?
abstract: Silicon Valley hopes that tech giants like Elon Musk could help to push the incoming Trump administration toward offering more visas to highly skilled foreign workers.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Levie, the chief executive of the cloud software company Box, said he was more hopeful than he had been at any point in the past 15 years that America could soon accept more highly educated immigrants — the sort of skilled foreigners he hires as software engineers.

headline: PG&E Secures $15 Billion Loan From U.S. Energy Department
abstract: The loan, the biggest-ever commitment from the Loan Programs Office, is intended to fund the California utility’s grid and climate resiliency projects.
lead_paragraph: The Energy Department plans to offer a record $15 billion loan guarantee to Pacific Gas & Electric, California’s largest utility, to improve its electrical grid and fund climate resiliency projects, the department said on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Black Doves’ Is a Fun, Festive Spy Thriller
abstract: From the creator of “Giri/Haji” comes an international-intrigue drama full of smarts, thrills and great performances by Keira Knightley and Ben Whishaw.
lead_paragraph: We’re in a spy-show boomlet, and the Netflix series “Black Doves,” starring Keira Knightley and Ben Whishaw, brings us a jazzy, Christmas-y iteration, full of fun fight scenes and stylish dialogue. Even when the plot holes widen, the performances are strong enough to bridge the gap.

headline: How OpenAI Hopes to Sever Its Nonprofit Roots
abstract: As the maker of ChatGPT battles Google and Meta for A.I. supremacy, it’s also fighting to end control by a nonprofit board.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, the nonprofit that controls OpenAI tried to fire the company’s high-profile leader, Sam Altman. It failed.

headline: Why Does OpenAI Need So Much Money?
abstract: Building a chatbot like ChatGPT requires billions upon billions of dollars. That’s the driving force behind OpenAI’s plans to change how it’s managed.
lead_paragraph: Early last year, OpenAI raised $10 billion. Just 18 months later, the company had burned through most of that money. So it raised $6.6 billion more and arranged to borrow an additional $4 billion.

headline: Jeff Bezos Prepares to Close the Gap in His Space Race With Elon Musk
abstract: A new rocket from Mr. Bezos’ company Blue Origin and a satellite system from Amazon could heat up competition with SpaceX, owned by Mr. Musk.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos have become the two wealthiest men in the world thanks to their breakthrough technology companies. But Mr. Musk, through SpaceX, has long held a big lead in the pursuit closest to their hearts: colonizing space.

headline: Worthwhile Canadian Resignation
abstract: Chrystia Freeland’s departure raises questions about how sharply Trudeau will counter Trump.
lead_paragraph: It may be that Chrystia Freeland could have resigned even more dramatically from Justin Trudeau’s government in Canada, though it would have taken something akin to kneeing him in public. But after the humiliation the prime minister visited on one of his most loyal and talented cabinet ministers, he should have seen it coming.

headline: Pre-emptive Pardons, Wanted or Not
abstract: Responses to a guest essay by Sarah Isgur, who is on Kash Patel’s enemies list. Also: A strategy intended to prevent suicides; a renewal of hope.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Richard Foreman Play Puts a Twist on His Metaphysical Puzzles
abstract: New York theater’s elder statesman of the avant-garde brings “Suppose Beautiful Madeline Harvey” to the stage, his first new work in over a decade.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 13 — a Friday, wouldn’t you know — I heard Richard Foreman talking to me as if in a dream. As had always been his wont, he was ruminating with a kind of appalled resignation about the unreliability of our own thoughts and perceptions.

headline: You Can’t Mess Up This Holiday Roast
abstract: Want to impress with a glistening, delicious centerpiece this holiday season? This miso-marinated pork will stay juicy no matter what.
lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of days, but, somehow, losing the usual week between Thanksgiving and the start of December compressed the holiday marathon into a 100-yard dash. I was winded by the time I pulled the first batch of cookies out of the oven, and now it’s time to host another feast?

headline: ‘Stay in the Fight’: Harris Urges Young Voters Not to Give Up on Politics
abstract: In her first major speech since her election loss, Vice President Kamala Harris suggested she did not intend to fade into the background in the years ahead.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Tuesday suggested she did not intend to fade into the background after President-elect Donald J. Trump’s November victory, and used her first major post-election speech to urge young people to “stay in the fight.”

headline: What Kennedy Has Said About the Polio Vaccine in Recent Years
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump’s choice for health secretary has suggested that the polio vaccine cost more lives than it saved and that the vaccine did not wipe out the disease in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. began a tour of Capitol Hill this week to pay courtesy calls on senators who will vote on his nomination to be health secretary and to calm concerns that he would limit access to vaccines, especially for polio. “I’m all for the polio vaccine,” Mr. Kennedy said to a throng of reporters on Monday.

headline: A Grisly Discovery at a Bronze Age Mass Grave: The Victims Were Eaten, Too
abstract: “It’s taken us all aback,” said a professor who led a study revealing that 37 people in a prehistoric site in England were likely consumed by their attackers.
lead_paragraph: The bones were spread out across a nearly 50-foot ditch, thousands of them, bearing marks of a grisly end. Snapped femurs. Bashed skulls. Bones with slicing cuts, as if someone had butchered the skin around them.

headline: British Authorities Criticized Over Sewage Spills in Public Waterways
abstract: The condemnation by a watchdog comes as England’s largest water company asks for an emergency loan and the nation wrestles with water pollution.
lead_paragraph: An acrimonious national debate about Britain’s private water companies intensified this week as the country’s environmental watchdog accused regulators of failing to comply with laws concerning sewage flowing into public waterways, a complaint that coincided with a request from England’s largest water company seeking a cash bailout.

headline: Tainted Drinks: How to Protect Yourself While Traveling
abstract: Deaths and hospitalizations of travelers in Laos and Fiji after they consumed drinks containing alcohol raised concerns about possible methanol poisoning. Here are signs you can look out for.
lead_paragraph: Australian officials have issued warnings for travelers to be alert for potential methanol poisoning after seven tourists were hospitalized in Fiji last week after drinking alcohol-based cocktails at a luxury resort bar. The alert comes less than a month after six backpackers in Laos died, and others were hospitalized, from what some officials worldwide suspect was methanol poisoning.

headline: Harris Urges Young People to ‘Stay in the Fight’
abstract: In her first major speech since conceding defeat, Vice President Kamala Harris expressed optimism for the nation’s future to young voters.
lead_paragraph: In her first major speech since conceding defeat, Vice President Kamala Harris expressed optimism for the nation’s future to young voters.

headline: Tech Entrepreneur Convicted of Second-Degree Murder in Death of Cash App Founder
abstract: Nima Momeni, 40, was convicted by a San Francisco jury in the fatal stabbing of Bob Lee, a well-known tech executive.
lead_paragraph: A tech consultant was convicted on Tuesday of second-degree murder in the death of Bob Lee, the wealthy founder of Cash App who was killed last year in a slaying that inflamed tensions over the safety of San Francisco streets after the pandemic.

headline: Elon Musk and SpaceX Face Federal Reviews After Violations of Security Reporting Rules
abstract: Federal agencies have opened at least three reviews into whether the company and its leader complied with disclosure protocols intended to protect state secrets, people with knowledge of the matter said.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk and his rocket company, SpaceX, have repeatedly failed to comply with federal reporting protocols aimed at protecting state secrets, including by not providing some details of his meetings with foreign leaders, according to people with knowledge of the company and internal documents.

headline: Richard W. Murphy, Roving Diplomat in World Hot Spots, Dies at 95
abstract: As a State Department Arabist, he served as ambassador to three Arab countries and helped broker the end of a 15-year civil war in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Richard W. Murphy, a diplomat whose colorful career included serving as ambassador to three Arab countries and as an assistant secretary of state in the 1980s — when he was the top Mideast expert in the State Department and helped end a long civil war in Lebanon — died in Manhattan on Nov. 22. He was 95.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez Loses Vote to Be the Top Democrat on the Oversight Panel
abstract: The New York progressive’s defeat was a counterpoint to generational change in the Democratic ranks, as House members chose younger members for top posts on other committees.
lead_paragraph: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the Democratic phenom from New York, on Tuesday lost an internal contest to lead her party on the Oversight Committee in the next Congress, a blow to a younger contingent of progressives eager for fresh faces to take on the hand-to-hand political battles of the Trump era.

headline: For Years, U.S. Collected Tips About Austin Tice’s Disappearance in Syria
abstract: Nongovernmental workers and journalists have scoured prisons for clues about his fate in the absence of an official American presence in the country.
lead_paragraph: For years, the United States has collected tips about the whereabouts of Austin Tice, an American journalist who was abducted in Syria in 2012, briefly escaped and then vanished in that country’s gruesome prison system.

headline: Families at a Tightknit Wisconsin School Wonder How a Shooting Occurred
abstract: Officials in Wisconsin gave little new information on Tuesday about a shooting that left a student and a teacher dead and six others injured.
lead_paragraph: Parents sent their children to Abundant Life Christian School in Madison, Wis., for many reasons. Some said they were drawn by the school’s rigorous academics, its high-performing sports teams or its grounding in Christian principles. Many said that the school, a small but growing academy that serves toddlers through teenagers, helped its students form unique connections.

headline: 6 New Songs You Should Hear Now
abstract: Hear just-released music from Julien Baker and Torres, Horsegirl and Amber Mark.
lead_paragraph: I feel bad for the songs released in this current temporal buffer zone — after most people have made their year-end lists, but before the next year begins. A lyric from a recent Vampire Weekend song comes to mind: “Capricorn, the year that you were born / Finished fast, and the next one wasn’t yours.”

headline: Fusion Start-Up Plans to Build Its First Power Plant in Virginia
abstract: Commonwealth Fusion Systems, an M.I.T. spinoff, aims to generate carbon-free electricity in an industrial park near Richmond in the early 2030s.
lead_paragraph: Commonwealth Fusion Systems, a start-up founded by scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said on Tuesday that it planned to build its first fusion power plant in Virginia, with the aim of generating zero-emissions electricity there in the early 2030s.

headline: Elon Musk Met With Nigel Farage at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: The British politician shared an image on social media that showed him at Donald Trump’s Florida resort with the tech billionaire.
lead_paragraph: As preparations for President-elect Donald J. Trump’s return to the White House continue at Mar-a-Lago, his Florida resort, several political leaders from other countries have made pilgrimages there to share tactics and learn from his victory.

headline: Wayward Fare Explores the Deep Mediterranean Pantry
abstract: F&F gets a more formal extension for pizza and more, Entre Nous offers 3,500 bottles of wine and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Originally called Wayward Kitchen, the new name suggests adventure, not a kitchen off-track. At this new brick-walled restaurant, adjacent to his Alta Calidad for Mexican dining, Akhtar Nawab explores a Mediterranean pantry to draw on ingredients like pomegranate, olives, cherry peppers, preserved lemon, quince, saffron and Urfa pepper. Expect takes on vegetables, dumplings, chicken and seafood, including whole local porgy roasted in the wood-fired oven and dusted with Baharat, a warm, musky Middle-Eastern blend. The oven, left from the previous tenant, a pizzeria, is also put to use burnishing cabbage, oysters, eggplant and squash. (Opens Friday)

headline: C.I.A. Director Arrives for Talks Amid Rising Hopes for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: The pace of peace talks has picked up, pushed by multiple factors, including wars in Lebanon and Syria that have seriously weakened Hamas’s allies and the election victory of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, landed in Qatar on Wednesday to try to advance a deal between Israel and Hamas to finally end the war in Gaza and free the remaining hostages held there, amid rising optimism that an agreement could be coming together after months of fruitless negotiations.

headline: New U.S. Vehicles Must Have Rear Seatbelt Alarms by Late 2027
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration changed an existing rule to expand and enhance seatbelt warning requirements.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will require new vehicles to sound a warning if back-seat passengers don’t use their seatbelts — a rule that will take effect in September 2027, the agency said this week.

headline: When Your $3 Million Cello Gets Bumped From Your Flight
abstract: The cellist Sheku Kanneh-Mason had to cancel a concert in Toronto last week after an airline refused to let him board with his instrument, even though he had bought a ticket for it.
lead_paragraph: The miseries of flying for work are well documented. Delays. Cancellations. The eternal gamble: to check or not to check bags, risking damaged or lost luggage.

headline: With Trump Ascendant, Even Ukraine’s Allies in Congress Rethink Aid
abstract: Reality has set in on Capitol Hill that with President-elect Donald J. Trump poised to take office, the era of U.S. military support for Ukraine is coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden made a last-minute request to Congress recently that lawmakers include an extra $24 billion in military aid for Ukraine in their year-end spending package, it received little attention and no serious consideration from members of either party.

headline: U.S. Releases Kenyan Prisoner Held for Nearly 18 Years Without Charges
abstract: The detainee was approved for transfer from Guantánamo Bay three years ago as the Biden administration tried to empty the wartime prison.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has released a Kenyan prisoner who was held at Guantánamo Bay for nearly 18 years on suspicion he was tied to an affiliate of Al Qaeda that plotted attacks against Israeli tourists in East Africa two decades ago.

headline: A Weary Biden Heads for the Exit
abstract: Still stinging from the election, President Biden is pushing for his final priorities but has largely absented himself from the national conversation about Donald Trump after warning repeatedly that he was a threat to American democracy.
lead_paragraph: It was a long day in Angola. President Biden had already visited a port facility bracketed with cranes and toured a factory filled with conveyor belts. So by the time he sat down at a large wooden circular table in a warm, stuffy room with African leaders, he put his head in his hand and briefly closed his eyes as the speeches droned on.

headline: Suit Accuses Georgetown, Penn and M.I.T. of Admissions Based on Wealth
abstract: The schools were accused of giving special treatment to wealthy students who might not otherwise have been admitted.
lead_paragraph: For years, Georgetown University’s longtime president, John J. DeGioia, flagged 80 students to be added to a special admissions list — but not, apparently, for their academic or athletic prowess, documents in a lawsuit claim.

headline: Judge in Adams Corruption Case Upholds Bribery Charge Against the Mayor
abstract: Lawyers for Mayor Eric Adams of New York had asked for the bribery charge to be thrown out, but the judge was not persuaded.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing the corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday rejected an attempt by his lawyers to have a bribery charge against him thrown out.

headline: Trump Sues The Des Moines Register, Escalating Threats Against the Media
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said he would use his power to punish people he claims have wronged him. Those goals are now coming into focus.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump sued The Des Moines Register for running a poll before the election that showed him trailing Vice President Kamala Harris, escalating his threats to seek retribution against the mainstream media and his political enemies.

headline: What’s Mitchell-Lama? Timothée Chalamet (Kind of) Explains
abstract: The actor’s family were the beneficiaries of a New York State housing program aimed at middle-income residents.
lead_paragraph: “You know about Mitchell-Lama?” Timothée Chalamet asked the podcaster Theo Von, who responded, “Oh yeah, the restaurant stars or whatever?”

headline: Syria’s Rebel Leader Vows to Disband and Integrate Armed Factions
abstract: Ahmed al-Shara said that fighters would be brought under the defense ministry’s authority. The announcement came as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel visited captured Syrian territory.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the rebel coalition that took power in Syria this month said that all armed opposition groups in the country would be dissolved, Syrian state media reported on Tuesday, as the new government worked to build a functioning state.

headline: With Sports Gambling Surging, Federal Regulation Is Discussed
abstract: With the industry’s popularity on the rise, the Senate Judiciary Committee held a hearing to discuss its effect on athletes, the public and the integrity of games.
lead_paragraph: A Senate committee discussed the potential for federal regulation of sports gambling during a nearly two-hour hearing on Tuesday that focused on how the industry’s widespread legalization across the United States was affecting athletes, the general public and the integrity of amateur and professional sports.

headline: Video Captures Moment When Blast Killed Russian General
abstract: A video clip that recorded the assassination of Igor Kirillov, a high-ranking general, gives a few clues about the power and the placement of the explosive device.
lead_paragraph: The doors swing open, and two figures emerge from a nondescript building. A scooter is propped against the front wall. A man identified by Russia as Igor Kirillov, a high-ranking general, takes a few steps forward.

headline: Gas Exports Pose Some Risks to U.S. Economy and Environment, Study Says
abstract: The long-awaited study was criticized by the oil and gas industry and could help environmental groups that want to stop new export terminals.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Tuesday released a lengthy study that outlined the economic and environmental risks of shipping more liquefied natural gas overseas, a move that could complicate President-elect Donald J. Trump’s plans to approve additional gas export terminals.

headline: The Next Evolution of Cantonese Food
abstract: A wave of new restaurants are challenging diners to go beyond sesame chicken and crab Rangoon.
lead_paragraph: Cantonese food for many American diners has long been associated with easy, comforting flavors: sesame chicken piled in a ring of steamed broccoli, creamy crab Rangoon dipped in sweet-and-sour sauce and moo shoo pork rolled into pancakes with tangy hoisin. But at New York’s recently opened Cha Cha Tang restaurant, the menu is more adventurous. The pork chops are fried katsu style and come from pampered Kurobuta pigs; afterward, guests can enjoy French toast stuffed with violet ube cream. In Toronto, at Yan Dining Room, Cantonese noodles are dressed with a clam- and baijiu-infused beurre blanc. Jatak, in Copenhagen, offers grilled Danish lobster tails, plated in a pool of golden long pepper sauce, with youtiou, a fluffy fried dough strip, on the side for dipping.

headline: ‘Emilia Pérez’ Makes a Strong Showing on the Oscar Shortlists
abstract: The musical appears twice for best song, along with big names like Pharrell Williams and Elton John. “Wicked” is potentially up for best score.
lead_paragraph: Major names from the music world could figure prominently at the Oscars in March if the shortlists that the academy released Tuesday are any indication.

headline: Monday Briefing: Ukraine says it killed a Russian General
abstract: Plus, the search for a van Gogh masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: A general in charge of the Russian military’s nuclear and chemical weapons protection forces was killed by a bomb on a Moscow street yesterday. Ukraine said it was responsible for the killing, which was one of the most brazen assassinations since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine nearly three years ago.

headline: Powerful Earthquake Causes Extensive Damage in Vanuatu
abstract: The 7.3-magnitude earthquake caused heavy damage to buildings, including the U.S. Embassy, and knocked out the internet across most of the Pacific Island nation.
lead_paragraph: The 7.3-magnitude earthquake caused heavy damage to buildings, including the U.S. Embassy, and knocked out the internet across most of the Pacific Island nation.

headline: Some of New York’s Best Pastry (and Plenty More) Is in Astoria
abstract: Levant, in Little Egypt, is an impressive addition to Steinway Street, a thoroughfare already thick with fascinating food choices.
lead_paragraph: There we were, three of the chattiest women you’ve ever met, rendered completely speechless by pastry. We sat, astonished, at our tiny table, cheeks speckled with powdered sugar.

headline: Matilda Djerf Apologizes Amid Claims of Workplace Toxicity
abstract: The popular Swedish influencer began a fashion brand in 2019. Some employees say working there wasn’t as great as it looked on social media.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t know Matilda Djerf by name, you might know her by her hair.

headline: Databricks Is Raising $10 Billion, in One of the Largest Venture Capital Deals
abstract: The artificial intelligence start-up’s funding shows investors remain enthusiastic about the A.I. boom.
lead_paragraph: In October, OpenAI, the start-up behind ChatGPT, raised one of the largest rounds of venture capital, bringing in $6.5 billion.

headline: Mangione Faces First-Degree Murder Charge That Brands Him a Terrorist
abstract: A grand jury formally indicted Luigi Mangione in the killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Mangione on Tuesday was accused of first-degree murder in the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, a charge that branded him a terrorist.

headline: This Brazilian Velvet Ant Is So Dark That It’s Ultrablack
abstract: Scientists found that the dark markings on a species of fluffy wasp reflected less than 1 percent of light.
lead_paragraph: The first thing to understand about velvet ants is that they are not, in fact, ants. They’re wasps, some of which are wingless, and are named in part for their fluffy exteriors.

headline: How Much Progress Have Women Made at Work?
abstract: At the DealBook Summit, nine prominent female leaders set out to answer the question, “Why aren’t there more women at the top levels of corporate America?”
lead_paragraph: Women have made many strides in recent decades. Young women are now more likely to obtain a bachelor’s degree than their male counterparts. Four of the nine Supreme Court justices are women. Twice women have been nominated by a major party for president.

headline: Worrying Signs From the Arctic
abstract: Scientists are seeing changes that could have consequences for the whole planet.
lead_paragraph: In a year full of troubling signs that Earth’s climate is rapidly changing, some of the most alarming signals came from the Arctic.
