abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about New Jersey Gov. Philip D. Murphy commuting the prison sentences of three women who had been abused and were convicted of killing men close to them misstated the circumstances of the crimes committed. They were all convicted of killing men close to them. The victims were not all boyfriends of the women.

headline: Suspect in Insurance C.E.O.’s Murder Is Said to Face Federal Charges
abstract: The nature of the potential charges against Luigi Mangione was unclear, but they could allow federal prosecutors to seek the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive on a Manhattan sidewalk this month will now face federal charges in addition to the state murder indictment brought against him, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Baby Bear
abstract: Brandon Koppy asks us to pivot.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Editors’ Note
abstract: This article was published prematurely.

headline: New York City Approves New Contract for Specialized High School Test
abstract: The vote by the Panel for Educational Policy came after a contentious five-hour meeting. The exam for eight highly competitive high schools will now be computerized.
lead_paragraph: A New York City education panel voted late Wednesday night to approve a new contract for a contentious testing system for admission into the city’s elite public high schools.

headline: Quote of the Day: A Top van Gogh Is Out of View. The Hunt Is On.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It is part of history, but it is also part of our lives now, and not knowing where it is is unbearable.”

headline: Starbucks Has a Pumpkin Spice Latte Problem in China
abstract: For years, Starbucks was the dominant coffee chain in China. Now rivals offering local flavors and cheaper prices are crushing the company’s bottom line in its second-largest market.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks has a China problem: coffee and tea drinkers who want more for less.

headline: G.M. Led in China for Years. Here’s How It Ended Up 16th in Sales.
abstract: General Motors has gone from market leader to also-ran in the world’s largest car market, stymied by its own missteps and Chinese policies that favored its local rivals.
lead_paragraph: General Motors was a pioneer in China, where for a quarter-century the company drew enormous profits and vied with Germany’s Volkswagen as the top seller of cars.

headline: The Pelicot Trial: A Timeline
abstract: Dominique Pelicot received a 20-year sentence after he admitted to drugging and raping his wife, Gisèle. Here’s how the events unfolded.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Pelicot, the ex-husband of Gisèle Pelicot, was convicted on Thursday of aggravated rape and other charges after admitting to drugging and raping Ms. Pelicot for almost a decade, and arranging for dozens of strangers he met online to abuse her unconscious body.

headline: Europe Has a Leadership Vacuum. How Will It Handle Trump?
abstract: With Germany and France both in political turmoil, the new administration of Donald J. Trump will begin at a time of instability for the continent.
lead_paragraph: When President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met European leaders for dinner in Brussels on Wednesday, the shadow of President-elect Donald J. Trump hung over the gathering. But it is not just Mr. Trump’s return to the White House that has scrambled Europe’s response to the war in Ukraine.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Syrian soldiers step toward amnesty.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of soldiers and police officers who served under Bashar al-Assad heeded the call of Syria’s new rulers to formally relinquish their ties to his ousted regime.

headline: Bibi Netanyahu Is Failing Ever Upward
abstract: The Israeli prime minister remains in power.
lead_paragraph: In late November the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued an unusual set of arrest warrants: one for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, one for his former defense minister Yoav Gallant and one for the deceased Hamas military chief, Muhammad Deif. Each man was accused of crimes against humanity and war crimes related to the ongoing conflict in Gaza.

headline: Chinese Spacewalk Apparently Breaks a Record (Barely)
abstract: China said two of its astronauts spent nine hours outside the Tiangong Space Station. The longest previous spacewalk, by Americans, was eight hours and 56 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Two Chinese astronauts aboard their country’s orbiting space station spent nine hours working outside in the cold vacuum of space, the longest recorded spacewalk, the Chinese space administration has said.

headline: Chinese Astronauts Spend 9 Hours Outside Space Station
abstract: The spacewalk appears to be the longest in history, barely breaking a record set by American astronauts in 2001.
lead_paragraph: The spacewalk appears to be the longest in history, barely breaking a record set by American astronauts in 2001.

headline: Word of the Day: combustion
abstract: This word has appeared in 97 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word combustion has appeared 97 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 7 in The New York Times Magazine article “One City’s Secret to Happiness: The Annual Burning of a 50-Foot Effigy” by Caity Weaver:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: It Was a Haven for New York Families. Now They Can’t Afford to Stay.
abstract: Families in Washington Heights are being pushed out by rising rents and costs, and New York City is losing its youngest demographic group.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Fermin is part of a close circle of friends with children in the Washington Heights neighborhood in Upper Manhattan. They push strollers along tree-shaded blocks and meet up for play dates and birthdays.

headline: Holiday Hints From a Gift-Guide Maker
abstract: Mari Uyehara helps develop the dozens of guides published by Wirecutter. She likes gifts you can’t buy in more than one place.
lead_paragraph: You probably have gifts on your mind right now. Mari Uyehara is thinking about them all year long.

headline: 2024 in Pictures
abstract: Which of the images in this Times collection best capture how you’ll remember this year?
lead_paragraph: In her introduction to “2024: The Year in Pictures,” Carolyn Ryan, a managing editor for The New York Times, writes:

headline: They Thought It Was an Old Baseball. It Was a Mastodon Tooth.
abstract: Remarkably well preserved ice age remains like those discovered recently in a yard near Scotchtown, N.Y., are rare — but not as rare as you might think.
lead_paragraph: A married couple arrived in Cory Harris’s office in late September, carrying a plain cardboard box about the size of a dictionary. They were excited to open it, and to show Dr. Harris the amazing things inside.

headline: Late Night Continues to Drone On About Sightings in the Sky
abstract: “‘Nothing nefarious, apparently’ doesn’t exactly inspire confidence,” Stephen Colbert said of President Biden’s comments about mysterious drones seen over New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: The Face of Courage
abstract: The French rape trial is over. The verdicts have been levied. And Gisèle Pelicot’s image has become a symbol of female strength around the world.
lead_paragraph: Until Sept. 2, 2024, most of the world did not really know what Gisèle Pelicot looked like.

headline: The Design Trend Taking Over Rural America
abstract: Barndos, large, open-plan structures, have surged in popularity with the recent exodus from urban to rural areas.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, the “barndominium” was designed with the horse owner in mind. A Connecticut developer came up with the name — a mash-up of “barn” and “condominium” — to refer to a lot and horse stall purchased together, in a subdivision where owners had a stake in a shared equestrian center.

headline: ‘The Mark Leyner Reader’ Doesn’t Mean Mark Leyner Is Done Writing
abstract: “I’m like one of those deranged soldiers they find on some remote island still fighting a war that’s ended decades ago,” he says. “A Shimmering, Serrated Monster!” is his collection of comic fiction.
lead_paragraph: Describe your ideal reading experience.

headline: When a Barndominium Won’t Do, Try a Shouse
abstract: Homeowners and builders weighed in on the difference between the two design styles taking over rural America.
lead_paragraph: The world of real estate has no shortage of mash-ups — condops and dockominiums, starchitects and plyscrapers. One of the most recent additions to the lexicon is the shouse, which is not to be confused with the barndominium.

headline: Maxed Out on L.A., He Chased His Hollywood Dream to Albuquerque
abstract: Would life in the Southwest be easier for someone doing gig work in the television and film industry?
lead_paragraph: In March, Raul Riveros showed up for work on a Jonah Hill movie when he keeled over in pain and was promptly rushed to the emergency room. He had undergone several surgeries to repair hernias he suffered from lifting large carts containing monitors and computers, and now a mesh implant had become entangled with his intestines.

headline: Biden, Headed to the Exit, Sets an Aggressive Climate Goal for the U.S.
abstract: The promise of deeper emissions cuts will very likely be ignored by the Trump administration, but officials hoped it would send a signal to the world.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Thursday announced an aggressive new climate goal for the United States, saying that the country should seek to slash its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 61 percent below 2005 levels by 2035.

headline: Weight Loss Drugs Changed Their Lives. Then They Lost Coverage.
abstract: In Michigan, the state’s largest insurer has tightened restrictions around medications like Wegovy. Patients are panicking.
lead_paragraph: The letter came in June. Mindy McCormick, 67, read that her insurer would soon stop covering the weight loss drug Wegovy, which she had been taking for more than two years.

headline: How to Actually Sleep on an Airplane
abstract: These tested strategies can help you get some degree of rest, even in an unforgiving upright seat.
lead_paragraph: What’s worse than being crammed in a too tight, too upright seat on an overnight flight? Being wide-awake the entire time. Short of receiving a golden ticket (i.e., an upgrade to a lie-flat pod), there are some strategies for making a long flight more restful so you won’t arrive feeling totally wrecked.

headline: As China Seeks Influence, It Has a Cuddly Way Into City Hall: Pandas
abstract: Records and interviews show that Beijing has used pandas as leverage to shape policy on Taiwan and to cultivate relationships with local U.S. politicians.
lead_paragraph: After joining the Chinese leader Xi Jinping for dinner last year, Mayor London Breed of San Francisco accompanied him to the airport to bid him farewell. There, on the tarmac, she made her request: pandas.

headline: Best TV Episodes of 2024
abstract: Examples from “The Bear,” “Blue Lights,” “Chimp Crazy” and others topped our three TV critics’ list of standout episodes this year.
lead_paragraph: This list may not be as definitive as our best-of-the-year list — no human can watch every episode of TV made in a year — and it includes many less-than-famous titles. But for my money, it is always the most fun list to put together. What you learn, spending a year watching series after series that you may never end up writing about, is that greatness can pop up anywhere, sometimes where you would expect it, sometimes in an offbeat documentary or an off-the-radar streaming curio.

headline: Digging Deep for Musical Gems: The Year in 18 Boxed Sets and Reissues
abstract: Joni Mitchell’s experimental period, Green Day’s ambitious concept album and Alice Coltrane’s thrilling 1971 Carnegie Hall concert arrived in new packages this year.
lead_paragraph: Every year, recording companies plunge deeper into their vaults, unveiling demos, outtakes, rough drafts, live recordings and more. The boxed sets that emerge from those excavations are reminders of all the options and decisions that go into every official album release. This year’s crop reveals artists at work, with plenty of opportunities to second-guess — or appreciate anew — their stray inspirations and forking paths. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times discuss 18 of the year’s most notable boxed sets.

headline: Cooper Hewitt’s Triennial Critiques American Power but Is Shy on Solutions
abstract: The Smithsonian’s “Making Home” winds up with an uneven mix of beauty, politics and platitudes.
lead_paragraph: When the Cooper Hewitt introduced its triennial design series, in 2000, the goal was straightforward: to offer a snapshot of the field that reflected, typically with an optimistic gloss, the preoccupations and triumphs of American designers. Early editions were filled with consumer products in a range of streamlined, candy-colored styles; recent shows have added healthy portions of save-the-planet ingenuity. Toothbrushes and sneakers on 1. Biodegradable tires on 3.

headline: Skiing’s Budget Secret: It Can Be Cheaper in Europe
abstract: We do the math on a winter vacation in the Alps or Dolomites, where lift tickets and lodging are often a fraction of what you’d pay at a U.S. resort.
lead_paragraph: This winter, if the bookings at Ski.com, North America’s largest ski-focused travel agency, are any indication, one of skiing’s biggest secrets is out: It can be cheaper to ski in Europe than at a U.S. mountain resort.

headline: The Wedding Vendors Helping L.G.B.T.Q. Couples Marry Before Trump’s Next Term
abstract: Some couples have been speeding up plans to marry since the election, and wedding vendors have reached out with free or discounted services.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Adams and Madeline Shelton didn’t have much time to pick out their wedding outfits, but they were both happy with what they wore to their Dec. 17 “microwedding,” as they called it, in Beaverton, Ore.

headline: The Year in Micro News
abstract: Blink and you might have missed these viral but fleeting moments.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of big news happened in 2024. A top presidential candidate dropped out of the race late; another survived two assassination attempts; and voters rejected the incumbent administration at the ballot box. This year also included conflicts abroad, the Summer Olympics and two (yes, two) Emmy Award ceremonies.

headline: How to Dance Through the Holidays
abstract: The New York dance instructor Angela Trimbur, known for her high-fun vibes, shares easy choreography for the season’s festive — and socially challenging — occasions.
lead_paragraph: The dancer and choreographer Angela Trimbur may qualify as New York’s most whimsical dance teacher, with more than 100,000 followers on Instagram alone watching her get silly and spin. Her classes and recitals draw dancers with little experience — and those burned out on the rigors of formal (read: judgmental) training. The ethos is that movement should be accessible and fun for everyone, no matter whether you can tell a box step from a pas de bourrée.

headline: Obscene Prices, Declining Quality: Luxury Is in a Death Spiral
abstract: Luxury brands have triggered their own death spiral by selling overpriced, overexposed and lower-quality products.
lead_paragraph: The holiday shopping season is hitting its apex. And do you know what I, a longtime fashion editor, will not be buying my loved ones this year? Big-name luxury fashion. I’d sooner set my eyebrows on fire.

headline: The Year Country Went Everywhere, and Everyone Went Country
abstract: Our critic hit the road to talk with Jelly Roll, Shaboozey, Tanner Adell and other artists to understand why country music was inescapable in 2024.
lead_paragraph: For a clear glimpse into the evolving soul of modern country music, you could have done far worse than to travel to Charleston, W.Va., this fall to catch a stop on Jelly Roll’s headlining arena tour.

headline: Here Are 4 Reasons China Meddles in Local U.S. Politics
abstract: American intelligence agencies have warned of influence operations targeting city halls and statehouses. But what’s in it for Beijing?
lead_paragraph: When a former aide to New York’s governor was charged this year with acting as a Chinese agent, the federal indictment suggested a surprising level of interest by Beijing in state-level governance in the United States.

headline: Two Debut Games That Are Captivating and Strange
abstract: 30 Birds takes its visual cues from Persian miniatures and asks the player to gather birds for a ritual. Threshold has the quality of a bad dream: It’s brief, a bit illogical and haunting.
lead_paragraph: As we race to the end of 2024, the number of new video games has slowed to a trickle. Thankfully, those looking for grand, sweeping fare have Indiana Jones and the Great Circle to keep them busy. But for anyone looking for something more compact and under the radar, here are two recent debuts from tiny development studios that are noteworthy for their winning strangeness.

headline: Even Mobile-Home Prices Keep Rising
abstract: From 2018 to 2023, the average sale price of a new manufactured home grew faster than that of a new single-family home, according to a recent study.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. housing market is on track for its second straight year of historically sluggish sales, the result of scant inventory, high prices and stubborn interest rates. Many prospective buyers are sticking with the rental market, but even people considering more affordable options are facing headwinds: According to a study by LendingTree, the average price of new manufactured homes — also know as mobile homes — is rising faster than that of new single-family homes.

headline: ‘The Count of Monte Cristo’ Review: Mission Impeccable
abstract: Stirringly acted and gorgeously filmed, this swashbuckler leaves previous versions of Dumas’s famous revenge saga in the dust.
lead_paragraph: Adapting “The Count of Monte Cristo,” Alexandre Dumas’s voluminous adventure yarn, is not for the fainthearted. But the French filmmakers Matthieu Delaporte and Alexandre de la Patellière prove lacking in neither heart nor style: Refusing to pander to restless derrières, they’ve given this big, bounding, beautifully cinematic swashbuckler almost three hours to breathe. Yet their pacing is so frisky — and Celia Lafitedupont’s editing so elegant — your derrière is unlikely to complain.

headline: ‘The Room Next Door’ Review: A Life Worth Leaving
abstract: Pedro Almodóvar’s moving drama stars Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton as friends facing mortality together.
lead_paragraph: At the end of James Joyce’s 1914 story “The Dead,” the main character is watching the snow fall on Dublin, late in the dark after a Twelfth Night dinner party. He’s just learned something profoundly affecting about his wife’s past, something he didn’t know until now, and it’s made him ruminative. Some day, every person he knows — even him — will be nothing more than memory. This thought is mortal, but not morbid. He finds it moving. “His soul swooned slowly,” Joyce writes, “as he heard the snow falling faintly through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead.”

headline: ‘Mufasa: The Lion King’ Review: Squeaking, Not Roaring
abstract: This wan photorealistic prequel to a remake, the latest addition to the Disney juggernaut, was directed by Barry Jenkins of “Moonlight” fame.
lead_paragraph: The fur looks more silkily luxurious in “Mufasa: The Lion King,” the African landscapes bolder and brighter, but much remains the same in its horizonless empire. Just five years ago, in the photorealistic remake of the first “Lion King,” Mufasa — the big cool cat then voiced with imperial gravitas by James Earl Jones — was ruling his animated kingdom with the kind of benevolent authoritarianism that suggests Hollywood isn’t the progressive hotbed it’s reputed to be. By the end, villainy was vanquished, order restored and hereditary monarchy reconfirmed. The circle of life, as the song goes, remained reassuringly unbroken.

headline: ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 3’ Review: Life Comes at You Fast
abstract: Keanu Reeves steps in as Shadow, while Jim Carrey doubles his fun as Robotnik in this action-adventure comedy.
lead_paragraph: Sonic the Hedgehog has always been a star. When introduced in the early 1990s, the fuzzy blue speedball was the mascot and lead character for Sega’s home video game console, a potent rival to Nintendo’s plumber Mario, who originated in arcade games. Mario got a still-risible start in movies back in 1993, in “Super Mario Bros.,” a live-action picture starring Bob Hoskins and John Leguizamo that has since developed a cult following. He bounced back in 2023 with an animated adventure replete with eye-popping graphics but lacking a certain “it’s-a me” charm.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Staten Island
abstract: This week’s properties are in the East Village, Chelsea and Port Richmond.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 900-square-foot duplex condo with a private entrance, a kitchen with a vented range, an open living and dining area, an upper-level terrace, zoned electric heat, a vented washer/dryer and outdoor access to a patio and driveway, on the first two floors of a four-story walk-up with a super. Jeremy Kamm and Josue Gonzalez, Coldwell Banker Warburg, 212-439-4561; cbwarburg.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom house in Westport, Conn., and a five-bedroom in New Rochelle, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 4,068-square-foot home from 1976 with hardwood floors, a living room with a large wood-burning fireplace, an open family room with a bay window that connects to an eat-in kitchen, an en suite primary bedroom with an oversized walk-in closet and a jetted tub, an office with a skylight, a laundry room, and a two-car attached garage, on 1.43 acres on a cul-de-sac. Beth Saunders, 203-913-2762, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, bhhsneproperties.com

headline: In This Industrial Design Class, Students Eat Their Homework
abstract: The Rhode Island School of Design uses recipes to teach the trial-and-error process of tweaking and refining a product.
lead_paragraph: From the first meeting of the industrial design class he took this fall, Zhiye Lin knew he was at a disadvantage. The other 10 students were experienced cooks. Mr. Lin was not.

headline: ‘It’s a Beaut, Clark!’ What’s It Take to Light Up the Griswold House?
abstract: The blinding light display in “National Lampoon’s Christmas Vacation” dazzled the Griswolds and nearly broke the power grid. What would it cost, and how much power would it really need?
lead_paragraph: How much power does it take to light 25,000 imported Italian twinkle lights?

headline: 10 Life Lessons for Grown-Ups From Children’s Classics
abstract: Even in a world populated by devious wolves, beauty shines through occasionally.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to get sentimental about the joy children’s books bring to kids. But picture books must also be read by adults, who, depending on the text, may not be quite as charmed. (My sympathies to anyone worn out by the vast “Biscuit” oeuvre.)

headline: Bodies in Repose? Not at This MoMA Show.
abstract: “Vital Signs: Artists and the Body” draws from MoMA’s 20th-century collection to show that identity is broader than physical form. But in skipping social media the show can’t go far enough.
lead_paragraph: Any show about “the body” has the backhanded blessing of wide appeal. Everybody has one — so what? The thesis of “Vital Signs: Artists and the Body,” a survey of more than 65 modern and contemporary artists currently on view at the Museum of Modern Art, is more specific than its title suggests: It proposes that 20th-century artists used abstraction to explore the human body’s changeability, and press the limits of identity.

headline: The Congresswoman Wore an F.D.N.Y. Jacket
abstract: In her official portrait, former Representative Carolyn Maloney posed in the jacket, which referenced her support for health benefits for 9/11 workers.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why former Representative Carolyn Maloney wore a firefighter’s jacket for a just-unveiled portrait. We’ll also get details on the bribery investigation involving Mayor Eric Adams’s former chief adviser.

headline: Luka Doncic Wants Young Players to Embrace ‘Mess and Joy’
abstract: The N.B.A. star is worried that for too many youth basketball players, the sport is no longer fun. He’s trying to find ways to change that.
lead_paragraph: Luka Doncic was 13 when he moved from his native Slovenia to Spain to play for Real Madrid. He didn’t know English or Spanish, but he could speak basketball fluently, and the expectations of a storied professional organization hung over him.

headline: With al-Assad Gone, Syrians in Homs Assess the Destruction
abstract: The ancient city, an early stronghold of opposition to Bashar al-Assad’s oppressive regime, was ravaged by a government crackdown. New York Times correspondents in Homs spoke to people who were reacting to his fall with smiles and tears.
lead_paragraph: Members of the family ducked under an empty doorway and stepped over the rubble from their home.

headline: 36 Hours in Innsbruck, Austria
abstract: Futuristic architecture rubs shoulders with centuries-old opera houses in this picture-perfect Austrian ski town.
lead_paragraph: Futuristic architecture rubs shoulders with centuries-old opera houses in this picture-perfect Austrian ski town.

headline: The Jewelry of the Moment Is Bigger and Bolder. And Silver!
abstract: Record-high gold prices and a fatigue with so-called quiet luxury set the stage for a resurgence of statement silver pieces.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s and ’90s, Robert Lee Morris’s sculptural silver earrings, breastplates and cuffs earned him certain trappings of fashion stardom: a yearslong collaboration with Donna Karan, a friendship with Karl Lagerfeld, exporting his namesake jewelry brand to Japan.

headline: Thomas Friedman on Syria, the U.S. and Trump
abstract: The columnist on why Trump’s biggest challenge will be weak states, not strong states.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Opinion columnist Thomas Friedman and the Opinion editor Daniel Wakin discuss how and why the United States should use its influence in Syria following the ousting of its longtime dictator Bashar al-Assad.

headline: The Moments That Shaped 2024, in 17 Photos
abstract: The people, places and objects that held our collective attention in this election year.
lead_paragraph: The people, places and objects that held our collective attention in this election year.

headline: Traveling for Christmas? Here’s Where Weather May Snarl Your Plans.
abstract: A day-by-day look at the snow, cold and rain that may make driving or flying home for the holidays more difficult.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for holiday cheer around the fire, sweaters in the snow and cozy gatherings out of the winter wind.

headline: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Agrees to Be Extradited to New York
abstract: Luigi Mangione, jailed in Pennsylvania, was charged in New York this week with first-degree murder in what prosecutors said was part of an “act of terrorism.”
lead_paragraph: The 26-year-old man accused of murdering a health care executive in Manhattan agreed at a court hearing on Thursday to be extradited to New York, where he is facing a first-degree murder charge.

headline: Where Does a ‘Remarkable’ U.S. Economy Go From Here?
abstract: America’s economy is far outstripping its peers, but there are serious risks, including from the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy is pulling ahead of its global peers. Inflation is moderating, and the Federal Reserve is cutting interest rates.

headline: How to Make the Drone Panic So Very Much Worse
abstract: Incidents like these require quick, clear communication from the government. That’s not what people are getting.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, a few people in the town of Bellingham, Wash., reported seeing pits and dings on their windshields — perhaps the work of vandals. Roadblocks were quickly set up. This became front-page news in nearby Seattle, prompting people to rush to check their own windshields. Thousands then reported that they, too, had mysterious dings, in an ever-widening area from Seattle to Vancouver, British Columbia.

headline: How Do You Feel About Winter?
abstract: This season can be difficult, but experts share how to make it more bearable. What can you find to love about winter?
lead_paragraph: Winter in the Northern Hemisphere officially begins on Dec. 21. Is this a season you look forward to each year? Or do you dread the onset of these dark, cold months?

headline: A D.I.Y. ‘Messiah,’ Starring You and Yours as Choristers
abstract: Our critic joined with amateur singers and professionals for a “Messiah” sing-in at David Geffen Hall, just one “Messiah” on the city’s holiday calendar.
lead_paragraph: The orchestra was done tuning. The soloists had taken their seats at the front of the stage and the conductor had ascended the podium. But there was one more item of business before Tuesday’s performance of Handel’s “Messiah” by the National Chorale at David Geffen Hall could begin. “You know what we need to do,” the conductor Everett McCorvey said, gesturing for audience members to rise from their seats. “We have to warm up.” Then he led the whole auditorium in a sequence of lip trills and scales.

headline: The Queer Book Shops Opening Across the Country
abstract: Plus: a stylist’s new fragrance line, a sophisticated stationery box and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: When the stylist Beverly Nguyen opened her Manhattan home and gift store, Beverly’s, in April 2021, she kept thinking of her grandmother who ran what Nguyen calls an “everything shop” in Vietnam. It carried snacks, drinks, beauty products and even refrigerators. “She transformed the space depending on what people needed,” says Nguyen, “and that’s exactly my ethos with Beverly’s,” which sells objects ranging from handcrafted ceramics to bamboo steamers. Now, a new line of three-in-one home, fabric and body sprays draws on Nguyen’s family history and her own early years in Orange County, Calif. One of the three scents, Dawn, which has hints of lemon, orange blossom and musk, is designed to capture the magic of 5 a.m. trips to the beach to watch the sunrise. Joy Ride, which has notes of sandalwood, white vetiver and leather, was inspired by excursions in the family’s Mercedes convertible. “My dad would be driving and my mom was in the front seat,” both dressed for work, says Nguyen. “Me and my sisters [were] in the back seat, messy and in T-shirts with the wind in our hair.” The final fragrance, Wedding, mixes frankincense and cedar and is intended to conjure, says Nguyen, “the ritual of going to church together.” Decorating the handmade Italian glass bottle is a wedding photo of her parents. For Nguyen, the collection is about “sharing more of my world with people,” she says. $65, available in-store at Beverly’s and online at atmosfragrance.com.

headline: Priced Out of New York, She Took Her $350,000 Budget to Philadelphia. Here’s What She Found.
abstract: After a near-death experience gave her a new lease on life, a writer ‘broke up with New York’ and headed south to find a one-bedroom or two-bedroom apartment.
lead_paragraph: After a near-death experience gave her a new lease on life, a writer ‘broke up with New York’ and headed south to find a one-bedroom or two-bedroom apartment.

headline: Week 16 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: A Team-by-Team Guide
abstract: With three weeks to go in the N.F.L. season, these detailed tables and scenarios explain every team’s paths to the playoffs — and to better seeding.
lead_paragraph: With three weeks to go in the N.F.L. season, these detailed tables and scenarios explain every team’s paths to the playoffs — and to better seeding.

headline: There’s Still Time for the Senate to Support the First Amendment
abstract: Trump hasn’t been the least bit reticent about his plans to reshape Washington in his image.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s private lawsuits against ABC News, CBS News and most recently The Des Moines Register are only the first phase of his promised battle to “straighten out the press.” Once he gets back in office next month, a far more troubling phase will begin: his promised effort to use government power to force reporters to reveal their sources for national security articles he doesn’t like.

headline: Put Down the Laser Pointer, Please, and Then Let’s Chat
abstract: The drone panic isn’t just about drones.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon, the F.B.I. office in Newark posted one of the most bizarre official statements I’ve ever read. It warned the public “against pointing lasers at manned aircraft” or attempting to shoot down suspected drones.

headline: Chaos Consumes Drive to Avoid Government Shutdown, With 2 Days to Go
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s denunciation of a bipartisan spending bill all but buried that deal while leaving unclear what form a new agreement could take.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump denounced a bipartisan spending deal that would fund the government until mid-March, telling Republican lawmakers that it would be “suicidal” to vote for it. His intervention all but buried the agreement with government funding scheduled to lapse in less than two days.

headline: Israel Launches Airstrikes Against Houthis in Yemen as Netanyahu Issues Warning
abstract: The Houthis have been attacking ships in the Red Sea for more than a year in what they have described as a campaign in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the Israeli military struck Houthi targets in Yemen early Thursday in response to the militia’s attacks on Israel, and appeared to suggest that Israel might take further action in its campaign to weaken Iran-backed groups.

headline: On a Flight With Gaza’s Rare Evacuees
abstract: The war in Gaza is one of the few conflicts most civilians can’t escape. But a small number of sick or critically injured people have been evacuated. The Times Magazine reporter Nicholas Casey went on a rare evacuation flight to try to understand what it takes to leave.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza is one of the few conflicts most civilians can’t escape. But a small number of sick or critically injured people have been evacuated. The Times Magazine reporter Nicholas Casey went on a rare evacuation flight to try to understand what it takes to leave.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,280
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 558
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Crypto’s Big Bet Is Paying Off
abstract: How the cryptocurrency industry grew to where it is now, and how Donald Trump gave it a boost.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald J. Trump won the 2024 election, cryptocurrency has surged to its highest level ever.

headline: 51 Men Found Guilty in France Rape Trial, and a U.S. Shutdown Looms
abstract: Plus, man vs. hornet.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Electoral Wishcasting
abstract: We cover a lesson from the Democrats’ 2024 defeat.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats’ 2024 defeat had many causes, starting with inflation and immigration. In today’s newsletter, I’ll examine another item on the list: candidate quality.

headline: Putin Glosses Over Russian Setbacks, Including Syria
abstract: The Russian president, in a marathon annual news conference, said that he had not yet met with Bashar al-Assad, the ousted Syrian leader who fled to Moscow, but that he planned to.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday tried to paper over or shift the blame for recent setbacks at home and in the Middle East, while making a fresh appeal to Donald J. Trump that he was ready to talk to the U.S. president-elect “any time.”

headline: ‘Homestead’ Review: A Home Away From Armageddon
abstract: The moment these Doomsday preppers have been waiting for has arrived, and from within their secure compound they’re confronting unexpected complications.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that a feature film ends with a teaser for a series that is already available to stream, but “Homestead,” released by Angel Studios, the distributor of “Sound of Freedom” and various Christian-themed projects, is less a self-contained movie than a pilot for a show that already exists. The quality of the acting can only improve.

headline: ‘The Six Triple Eight’ Review: Tyler Perry Salutes the Greatest Generation
abstract: Kerry Washington leads a female postal battalion on a moving mission in this World War II drama.
lead_paragraph: In Tyler Perry’s World War II drama, “The Six Triple Eight,” Oprah Winfrey appears as the humanitarian Mary McLeod Bethune. Susan Sarandon (wearing outsized choppers) arrives as Bethune’s friend Eleanor Roosevelt, the first lady of the United States. Together Roosevelt and Bethune convince President Franklin D. Roosevelt (Sam Waterston) to press a piqued general into using Black female soldiers to address the mountains of undelivered mail — to soldiers and from them — sitting in airplane hangars in Scotland.

headline: Who Are the 51 Men Convicted in the Gisèle Pelicot Rape Trial?
abstract: Most of the accused received sentences of eight to 10 years, less than the 10- to 18-year terms that the public prosecutor had recommended.
lead_paragraph: All 51 defendants in the Gisèle Pelicot rape trial were found guilty on Thursday. Most of the accused received sentences of eight to 10 years, less than the 10- to 18-year terms that the public prosecutor had recommended.

headline: Britain’s Economy Is ‘Bumbling’ Into the New Year
abstract: Stubborn inflation, tax rises and high interest rates make it difficult for many to muster optimism, at least in the short term.
lead_paragraph: It’s a somber end to the year in Britain, dampened by a string of disappointing economic news. Inflation has jumped, the economy has stagnated and consumer confidence surveys are deeply downbeat.

headline: Publishers Battle for the C-Suite
abstract: Numerous media outlets, looking for new lucrative lines of business, are pursuing newsletters and events aimed specifically at top executives.
lead_paragraph: When the digital news start-up Semafor began in 2022, its founders talked about reaching a vast global audience of 200 million college-educated, English-speaking people.

headline: Why the Specter of Trump Hangs Over the Fed, Congress and the Markets
abstract: The President-elect takes office in a month, but his influence on policy is already being felt by investors and across Washington.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Jay Powell has been sending markets the message that the Fed is entering a more cautious phase, signaling that high borrowing costs would linger for longer.

headline: Amazon Delivery Drivers at Seven Hubs Walk Out
abstract: The retail giant said it expected its operations to be largely unaffected by the strike of some drivers at contracting firms Amazon uses to deliver packages.
lead_paragraph: Workers who deliver packages from seven Amazon facilities across the country went on strike Thursday morning, according to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the union that represents them.

headline: Popular Arthritis Drug for Dogs May Have Severe Side Effects, F.D.A. Says
abstract: The agency recommended that the maker of Librela update its label to reflect the possibility of more serious adverse reactions.
lead_paragraph: A popular drug for dogs with arthritis may be associated with a variety of potentially severe neurological effects, including seizures and a loss of muscle control, according to a recent review by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which approved the drug last year. In some cases, dogs have died or have been euthanized after developing these symptoms, the agency noted.

headline: Zelensky Raises Prospect of European Peacekeepers in Ukraine
abstract: But many European leaders say that with no sign that Russia is interested in peace, it is too early to discuss the presence of peacekeeping forces.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Thursday that he had discussed with European leaders the possibility of sending European peacekeeping forces to Ukraine as part of a cease-fire or peace deal, as the country’s allies consider options on how to help Kyiv end the fighting with Russia on favorable terms.

headline: ‘We Just Want Mercy’: A Gaza Hospital Pleads for a Respite
abstract: Medical workers at one of the last functioning hospitals in the north of the territory say the facility has come under heavy attack by Israel this week.
lead_paragraph: The last functioning intensive care unit at a hospital in northern Gaza was severely damaged by Israeli shelling this week, according to medical staff at the facility who have been pleading for a respite from violence to bring in essential supplies.

headline: This Corpse Has Had a Wild Journey. Its Next Stop? Broadway.
abstract: “Dead Outlaw,” a musical about the mummified body of a bandit, will open at the Longacre next spring, following a successful Off Broadway run.
lead_paragraph: “Dead Outlaw,” a rambunctious musical that tells the hard-to-believe-it’s-true story of a bandit’s corpse that became a spectacle in early-20th-century America, will open on Broadway next spring.

headline: If You Can See the Tree, There Is Room for More Decorations
abstract: Minimalism is on the naughty list this Christmas as people decorate their trees with bows, garland, tinsel, ornaments and, well, anything else that will fit on a branch.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve tired of sad beige holidays, with Christmas decorations stuck in muted neutral tones and minimalist greenery, it might be time to give maximalism a try.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Invisible-Ink Graffiti
abstract: Does it count as vandalism? What if it’s funny?
lead_paragraph: Jim writes: We recently remodeled our kitchen, and my 10-year-old son wrote, “Are you eating cereal?” on the new countertop in invisible ink. We can’t see it unless we shine a UV light on the area. But I don’t think he should draw on any part of the house. He should also have additional cleaning chores for two weeks.

headline: A Lottery Drawing Included Four Consecutive Numbers. What Are the Odds?
abstract: A Mega Millions drawing turned up 66, 67, 68 and 69. Is that unusual?
lead_paragraph: A total of 70 balls went into a drum for a lottery drawing. Five were pulled out: 56, 66, 67, 68 and 69.

headline: A Famed Iowa Pollster’s Career Ends With a ‘Spectacular Miss’ and a Trump Lawsuit
abstract: Known for her “gold standard” polls of Iowans, J. Ann Selzer is facing retribution from Donald Trump after her final 2024 survey showed a surprising, and ultimately wrong, winner.
lead_paragraph: The surveys of J. Ann Selzer once carried the hopes and fears of the men and women who sought to lead the nation, recording with uncanny accuracy the views of Iowa voters who exercised outsize influence in the choosing of American presidents.

headline: F.A.A. Bans Drone Flights Near Key Sites in New York
abstract: The temporary ban covers parts of Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. The F.A.A. also issued a monthlong ban on drone flights over a large swath of New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration has temporarily banned drone flights over parts of New York State, including sections of New York City, Long Island and Yonkers.

headline: Gisèle Pelicot Speaks After Rape Trial Verdict: ‘We Share the Same Struggle’
abstract: In brief remarks after her ex-husband and 50 other men were convicted, she said she had never regretted her decision to allow the trial to be public.
lead_paragraph: Gisèle Pelicot gave brief remarks to reporters outside the courthouse in Avignon, France, on Thursday after her ex-husband, Dominique, and 50 other men were convicted in a rape trial. Mr. Pelicot admitted to drugging and raping her over nearly a decade and inviting other men to participate.

headline: After the House Delayed a Bill to Add Judges, a Biden Veto Looms
abstract: The Senate backed a bipartisan bill to add dozens of judges, but the House held off on voting until after Election Day. Now, Donald Trump would be assured at least 22 picks.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the wheels of the federal judiciary have been turning ever more slowly, as the number of federal judges has failed to keep pace with rising caseloads.

headline: Appeals Court Disqualifies Fani Willis From Prosecuting Georgia Trump Case
abstract: The panel overruled the trial judge, who had allowed Fani T. Willis to keep the case despite a romantic relationship that defendants said created a conflict of interest.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s Court of Appeals on Thursday disqualified the Atlanta prosecutor who brought an election interference case against President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies, a surprise move that threw the entire case into disarray.

headline: What It Looks Like on an Island Steamrolled by a Cyclone
abstract: A visit to the Indian Ocean islands of Mayotte, which were struck by Cyclone Chido last weekend, reveals the devastating toll of the storm on an impoverished territory that belongs to France.
lead_paragraph: The hillsides surrounding the harbor of the tiny French territory of Mayotte have been transformed into barren mounds of leafless, uprooted trees. Sailboats lie on their sides, consumed by the warm waters of the Indian Ocean.

headline: Could This 20-Year-Old Be One of the Democrats’ Bro Whisperers?
abstract: Dean Withers argues online with right-wing stars like Charlie Kirk and Ben Shapiro. His goal? To reach their young, male followers.
lead_paragraph: In a YouTube video that was uploaded about a month before the election, a young, blond man in baggy jeans and a graphic T-shirt sits alone at the center of a circle of folding chairs.

headline: Elon Musk Flexes His Political Strength as Government Shutdown Looms
abstract: The world’s richest man led the charge to kill a bipartisan spending deal, in part by promoting false and misleading claims about it.
lead_paragraph: When President-elect Donald J. Trump picked “the Great Elon Musk,” the world’s richest man, to slash government spending and waste, he mused that the effort might be “the Manhattan Project of our time.”

headline: White Chicken Chili to Welcome Them Home
abstract: Lidey Heuck’s customizable, five-star chili replenishes and restores.
lead_paragraph: What’s your Welcome Home Meal? You know, the dish you use to greet someone after a long day of travel or a long time away? Do you tailor the Welcome Home Meal for each person based on favorites and preferences, or is there a time-honored go-to that guests can expect when they grace your doorstep?

headline: Calls to the Media: Fight Trump’s Lawsuits
abstract: Readers discuss lawsuits against The Des Moines Register and ABC News. Also: Violence in school; a Mideast bridge; cash and the disabled; murder is wrong.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The 73 Best Illustrations of 2024
abstract: The most memorable illustrations of the year, chosen by art directors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The most memorable illustrations of the year, chosen by art directors at The New York Times.

headline: Government Lurches Toward Shutdown After House Tanks Trump’s Spending Plan
abstract: Dozens of right-wing Republicans joined Democrats in opposing a bill ordered up by President-elect Donald J. Trump to tie a government funding extension to a two-year deferral of the debt limit.
lead_paragraph: The government lurched toward a shutdown after the House on Thursday rejected a hastily produced plan ordered up by President-elect Donald J. Trump to keep funding flowing, with dozens of Republicans defying his demand to pair the spending with a two-year suspension of the federal debt limit.

headline: Trump Tossed a Debt Limit Grenade Into Spending Talks. Here’s Why.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump was forced to negotiate with Democrats over the borrowing cap during his first term.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump injected debt limit politics into already-fraught congressional spending talks this week, urging lawmakers to lift the debt limit or abolish it entirely before he takes office next month.

headline: Is the Tech Industry Already on the Cusp of an A.I. Slowdown?
abstract: Companies like OpenAI and Google are running out of the data used to train artificial intelligence systems. Can new methods continue years of rapid progress?
lead_paragraph: Demis Hassabis, one of the most influential artificial intelligence experts in the world, has a warning for the rest of the tech industry: Don’t expect chatbots to continue to improve as quickly as they have over the last few years.

headline: Nvidia’s Booming A.I. Business Collides With U.S.-Chinese Tensions
abstract: The chipmaker expects more than $10 billion in foreign sales this year, but the Biden administration is advancing rules that could curb that growth.
lead_paragraph: In early August, the king of Bhutan, Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck, traveled from the mountains of his landlocked Asian country to the headquarters of Nvidia, a maker of artificial intelligence chips in the flatlands of Silicon Valley.

headline: Kylie Kelce Doesn’t Want to Talk About Besting Joe Rogan
abstract: But in her first interview since her podcast reached No. 1, she does share ideas about why the show has become a breakout hit.
lead_paragraph: When a podcast hosted by Kylie Kelce, a 32-year-old high school field hockey coach, unseated “The Joe Rogan Experience” as the top-ranked show in the United States this month, strong reactions followed.

headline: All They Want for Christmas? This Mariah Carey Bar.
abstract: A New York City lounge devoted to the singer plays her 1994 holiday hit every 15 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Even before the shiny red curtains opened at 5 p.m., a line of people, dressed head to toe in red-and-green sequins, formed outside Mariah Carey’s holiday bar, a new pop-up lounge inside the Virgin Hotels New York.

headline: It’s a Mistake to Charge Luigi Mangione With Terrorism
abstract: It could complicate a simple case and turn it into a political circus.
lead_paragraph: The murder of the health care executive Brian Thompson on a Midtown Manhattan sidewalk was shocking, brazen and seemingly methodical, but it wasn’t all that sophisticated.

headline: Giséle Pelicot’s Ex-Husband Found Guilty in Mass Rape Trial
abstract: A French court found the ex-husband of Ms. Pelicot, Dominique Pelicot, guilty and sentenced him to 20 years in jail. Fifty other men were also convicted in the mass rape trial.
lead_paragraph: A French court found the ex-husband of Ms. Pelicot, Dominique Pelicot, guilty and sentenced him to 20 years in jail. Fifty other men were also convicted in the mass rape trial.

headline: What if Trump Doesn’t Need to Keep Any of His Promises?
abstract: For the 47th president, illusion is the new accountability.
lead_paragraph: Now, supposedly, Donald Trump must deliver.

headline: Trump’s Return May Worsen Financial Woes for Global Health Institutions
abstract: The U.S. provides nearly half of the aid for global health, including childhood vaccination, H.I.V. treatment and disease surveillance.
lead_paragraph: The election of Donald J. Trump, with his mistrust of international institutions and his history of proposing deep cuts to foreign aid, has complicated a perilous landscape for global health organizations that were already in a frantic competition for sharply reduced funds.

headline: Maps: See Israel’s Moves in Syria Since al-Assad Was Toppled
abstract: Israeli fighter jets have launched hundreds of airstrikes, while soldiers have seized a buffer zone and captured military posts in territory formerly under Syrian control.
lead_paragraph: Since President Bashar al-Assad fled Syria, Israel has mounted a military offensive in the country unlike anything it has conducted there in decades, fearing  chaos that could spill across the border.

headline: With Guilty Verdicts, Rape Victim’s Ordeal in France Becomes a Message of Hope
abstract: Dozens of men who abused Gisèle Pelicot were convicted, including the man who invited them to do so: her husband of 50 years. She wanted the public trial to show rape victims they were not alone.
lead_paragraph: In a packed courtroom on Thursday in Avignon, France, the head judge asked each of the dozens of men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot — while she was near-comatose and at the invitation of her husband of 50 years — to stand briefly. Then he pronounced their convictions swiftly, one after the other: all guilty.

headline: Kennedy Returns to Capitol Hill With New ‘Make America Healthy Again’ Caucus in Senate
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the president-elect’s pick for health secretary, has spent much of the week meeting with friendly Senate Republicans, including some who appear to be trying to institutionalize his influence in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to run the Health and Human Services Department, visited Capitol Hill on Thursday for a fourth straight day of meetings with Senate Republicans, who have pressed him on his commitment to their anti-abortion agenda but so far offered little resistance to his candidacy.

headline: U.S. Files Murder Charge Against Mangione That Could Bring Death Penalty
abstract: Federal authorities filed a total of four counts against Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Thursday unsealed a murder case against the suspect in the shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, holding out the possibility of the death penalty even after a trial on separate state charges.

headline: Andrew Cuomo Plans to Sue Harassment Accuser for Defamation
abstract: Mr. Cuomo, the former governor of New York, accused a former aide, Charlotte Bennett, of falsely saying that he sexually harassed her, harming his political future.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo submitted a notice Thursday that he intended to file a defamation lawsuit against one of the first women to accuse him of sexual harassment while he was in office.

headline: 2024 Was the Year of Chickpea Anxiety
abstract: It was also a good year for easy, excellent bean recipes and cooking yourself cauliflowers.
lead_paragraph: There are a few circumstances you can count on in the twilight of the year. Everyone will want to “circle back in January,” as out-of-office replies quickly outnumber incoming requests. The cookie swaps will reach their zenith. You’ll get a remarkably inopportune cold. And a blizzard of best-of lists will ask you to reflect on yet another whirl around the sun. (Remember the Olympics? “Brat”? Moo Deng?)

headline: The Simplest Way to Make Creamy Scrambled Eggs for a Crowd
abstract: All it takes is one pot, two dozen eggs and 10 minutes of cooking to serve breakfast to a full house.
lead_paragraph: To make fluffy, creamy, dreamy scrambled eggs for more than a few people, you don’t need a fancy pan or a newfangled hack. You don’t need boundless time or attention, either. You don’t even need the coffee to kick in yet — in fact, you’ll be rewarded for moving slowly.

headline: Read the Criminal Complaint Against Luigi Mangione
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have filed four charges against Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have filed four charges against Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive.

headline: What Are ‘Healthy’ Foods? The F.D.A. Updates the Labeling Terms.
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration released final rules on labeling foods as “healthy,” tightening limits for sugar, sodium and saturated fat.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday updated the definitions of the term “healthy” for labeling on foods, a move that reflected changes in nutrition and that tightened limits on saturated fat, sugar and salt in food that could be sold under that claim.

headline: Hidden ‘Junk’ Fees Must Be Disclosed, F.T.C. Rule Says
abstract: Hotels, short-term rentals and event ticket-sellers must advertise the full price of their offerings under the rule, which is supposed to go into effect in the coming year. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: It is a common scenario for anyone booking online: That affordable hotel room or concert ticket suddenly gets pricey at checkout, when service and other fees get tacked on.

headline: ‘The Brutalist’ Review: Ambitions Unbound
abstract: Adrien Brody stars as a talented architect who flees postwar Europe to meet his match in America, a power-hungry industrialist played by Guy Pearce.
lead_paragraph: “The Brutalist” is a bursting-at-the-seams saga of bold men and their equally outsized visions. Set across several decades in the aftermath of World War II, it is a grave, serious, visually sumptuous movie that puts a great many ideas into play, starting with the tension between art and commerce. It largely focuses on one man in one place, but its concerns are more expansive and touch on everything from utopia to barbarism, desire, death, form, content, immigration, assimilation and the promise and perils of modernity. Many movies offer up a slice of reality; true to the architectural aesthetic that its title invokes, this one offers a slab.

headline: Adams Hosts Fox News at City Hall, as N.Y. Leaders Mute Trump Hostility
abstract: In an interview, Mayor Eric Adams criticized the Biden administration and did not take aim at President-elect Donald J. Trump. He is not the only New York Democrat treading lightly.
lead_paragraph: The setting, not to mention the event itself, was unusual: Eric Adams, the Democratic mayor of New York City, had invited Fox News into City Hall on Wednesday for a sit-down interview.

headline: Avian Flu Has Hit Dairies So Hard That They’re Calling It ‘Covid for Cows’
abstract: The virus has spread rapidly in California, the nation’s largest producer of milk. Farmers are frustrated that their herds are getting infected despite various precautions.
lead_paragraph: A fast-growing outbreak of avian flu has upended California’s dairy industry, the nation’s largest producer of milk, infecting most of the state’s herds and putting thousands of farmworkers at risk for contracting the virus.

headline: Billionaire Rivals Bezos and Musk Are Said to Have Dined With Trump at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, and Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder, ate with President-elect Donald J. Trump. Both have courted Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump had dinner at his Mar-a-Lago resort on Wednesday with Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos, the world’s two richest men and longtime business rivals who have cultivated relationships with the president-elect, according to two people briefed on the get-together.

headline: Ex-Top Aide to Mayor Adams and Her Son Are Charged in Corruption Case
abstract: Ingrid Lewis-Martin, who resigned as the mayor’s chief adviser, was charged in a bribery scheme involving $100,000 for a new Porsche for her son.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors on Thursday charged the former chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams and her son with taking $100,000 in bribes from two businessmen in exchange for intervening with city regulators on the businessmen’s behalf.

headline: France’s Horrifying Rape Trial Has Changed the Country
abstract: Gisèle Pelicot has opened up a conversation about sexual violence in a country where a serious reckoning was well overdue.
lead_paragraph: It is over. Dominique Pelicot has been found guilty of orchestrating and participating in the mass rape of his wife, Gisèle Pelicot, in their home in the quiet town of Mazan in the South of France. He has been given the maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. All of the co-defendants have been found guilty of sexual assault, attempted rape or rape.

headline: William J. Hennessy Jr., Sketch Artist of Courtroom Drama, Dies at 67
abstract: His lively drawings of historic Supreme Court arguments, impeachment trials and murder cases gave the public a peek into venues where cameras were banned.
lead_paragraph: William J. Hennessy Jr., a prominent courtroom artist whose sketches documented important chapters in history, including the impeachment trials of Presidents Bill Clinton and Donald J. Trump and the Supreme Court case that decided the 2000 presidential election, as well as thousands of scenes of quotidian courtroom drama, died in Key West, Fla., on Dec. 9, his 67th birthday.

headline: Former Uvalde Schools Police Chief Fails in Bid to Avoid Prosecution
abstract: Investigations have singled out Pete Arredondo, the former chief, for the delayed police response to a 2022 school shooting in Texas. A judge denied his request to quash the charges against him.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Thursday denied an effort to throw out charges against the former police chief of the school district in Uvalde, Texas, who faces blame for his role in the 77 minutes it took to end the rampage at Robb Elementary School on May 24, 2022.

headline: How the Climate Crisis Became an Insurance Crisis
abstract: Even in formerly low-risk areas, home insurers are raising premiums and ending coverage. The upheaval could push down home values and reverberate through the economy.
lead_paragraph: Spend enough time talking about climate change, and you’ll eventually get pulled toward this question: What would have to happen for global warming to strike most people as an urgent crisis?

headline: ‘Laid’ Is Acerbic, Raunchy Fun
abstract: Starring Stephanie Hsu and Zosia Mamet, the series tells a darkly comic story about a woman whose past sexual partners start dying. And keep dying.
lead_paragraph: “Laid,” on Peacock, follows a party planner named Ruby (Stephanie Hsu) whose previous sexual partners start dying. At first it seems like unlucky coincidence, but the pattern quickly emerges, and suddenly the number of deaths in Ruby’s wake is getting pretty distressing. Her bestie and roommate, A.J. (Zosia Mamet), makes a crazy wall, labeled “Ruby’s Sex Timeline,” and a morbid, prickly “High Fidelity” is afoot.

headline: Wisconsin School Shooter May Have Plotted With California Man
abstract: At the request of law enforcement officials, a judge ordered a man, who reportedly corresponded with the shooter about a second attack, to surrender his guns.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials grew concerned this week that the Wisconsin school shooting on Monday may have been part of a broader plot that could have included an attack on a government building, according to a court document filed in California.

headline: New York to Pay $10 Million in Woman’s Death After Abuse in Group Home
abstract: The state in 2019 paid a $2 million abuse settlement. In retaliation, staff members withheld the victim’s medicine, and she died in a hospital.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, New York agreed to pay $2 million each to the families of three developmentally disabled residents of a group home who had been beaten, smacked and humiliated by workers who called the facility the “Bronx Zoo.”

headline: ‘Getting Your Pink Back:’ How Moms Felt Like Themselves Again After Having a Baby
abstract: Flamingos, which can lose their bright color when tending to their young but get it back over time, have been a helpful metaphor for some women in their postpartum experiences.
lead_paragraph: With five young children, Linnea Chambery had found herself at one of her most challenging points as a mother.

headline: Movie Shelved After Jonathan Majors’s Arrest Gets Release Date
abstract: Before the actor was charged with assault, “Magazine Dreams” generated Oscar buzz for his performance as a bodybuilder. The movie is now scheduled to reach theaters in March.
lead_paragraph: “Magazine Dreams,” a bodybuilding drama that was considered an Oscar contender last year before it was shelved when its star, Jonathan Majors, was accused of assaulting his girlfriend, is now scheduled to reach theaters in March.

headline: The First-Ever ‘Where to Eaties’ Awards
abstract: The best place to wash your hands, the restaurant that will scare your parents and more 2024 superlatives.
lead_paragraph: By now you’ve probably read through our distinguished critics’ list of the city’s best new restaurants and best new dishes, each selection carefully considered and thoughtfully discussed. But who but us could take stock of the aspects of New York City dining that don’t fit into neat categories of taste and quality. That’s where the first-ever “Where to Eat”  year-end awards come in, highlighting our most peculiar, confusing and delightful dining experiences in 2024.

headline: Joanne Pierce Misko, Ex-Nun Who Made F.B.I. History, Dies at 83
abstract: She and Susan Malone were sworn in together in 1972 as the first female agents, only months after the bureau opened the door to women.
lead_paragraph: Joanne Pierce Misko, a former Roman Catholic nun who in 1972 became one of the first two women sworn in as special agents for the F.B.I., breaking the bureau’s longstanding bar against women in frontline law-enforcement roles, died on Friday in Wheatfield, N.Y., east of Niagara Falls. She was 83.

headline: Friday Briefing: 51 Men Convicted in French Rape Trial
abstract: Plus, the year in viral moments.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Pelicot, who admitted to drugging and raping his wife, Gisèle, for almost a decade and inviting dozens of strangers to join him, was convicted yesterday in France and sentenced to the maximum 20 years in prison. The court also convicted the 50 other defendants, most of them on rape charges.

headline: Spending Deal Debacle Threatens Johnson’s Tenuous Hold on His Job
abstract: A Republican backlash to the speaker’s plan to temporarily fund the government has sparked new talk of ousting him, and highlighted the challenges he will face if he manages to keep his job.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the looming government shutdown.

headline: 5 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The other day, listening to old-fashioned terrestrial radio while I was putting dishes away, I was struck by the transition from a Nirvana song to a Neil Young song with a similar guitar lick — just the sort of segue that makes you appreciate unartificial intelligence, by demonstrating knowledge and intention and a spirit of play on the part of the D.J. That’s the same mind-set we try to apply here each week, recommending books that may be as different as an ice-bound whaling novel and a comedian’s memoir; what unites them isn’t always clear (a rich grasp of historical vagaries, in this case), but we’re always sure you’ll find something you can groove to. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: SeaQuest, Interactive Aquarium Where Many Animals Died, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: After the chief executive stepped down, the company acknowledged that “mistakes were made.”
lead_paragraph: SeaQuest, a chain of interactive animal parks and aquariums across the country, filed for bankruptcy protection this month, after years in which many of its facilities drew scrutiny from federal and state regulators, and several shut down.

headline: Rupert Murdoch’s Appeal to Alter Family Trust Faces Uphill Battle
abstract: Mr. Murdoch’s appeal over whether he can consolidate his son Lachlan’s power over his media empire is due just before Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to change his family trust to consolidate his son Lachlan’s leadership of his global media empire — and lock in its conservative editorial direction after his death — now depends on a long-shot move in the highly specialized Nevada probate court system.

headline: American Airlines Settles Racial Discrimination Case
abstract: Three Black men had accused the airline of wrongly forcing them to get off a plane for an hour because of a complaint about body odor.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines said on Thursday that it had settled a racial discrimination lawsuit filed by three Black men who said they and several others had been wrongly and temporarily removed from a flight in January by the airline’s flight attendants.

headline: Artificial Intelligence in 2030
abstract: At the DealBook Summit, ten experts in artificial intelligence discussed the greatest opportunities and risks posed by the technology.
lead_paragraph: Modern artificial intelligence is expected to be one of the most consequential technologies in history. But there is a big debate over what those consequences will be: Will the technology power an age of prosperity, in which humans work less? Will it be used to wipe out humanity?

headline: Amazon Reaches Settlement to Resolve Federal Safety Accusations
abstract: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration agreed to withdraw citations at nine of 10 warehouses where it had flagged violations; the company agreed to a $145,000 penalty.
lead_paragraph: Federal health and safety regulators announced a corporatewide settlement with Amazon on Thursday, bringing an end to cases involving accusations of safety violations at 10 warehouses in several states.

headline: Why Silent Film Still Speaks Volumes
abstract: The old movies have a great deal to say, and linguistics can explain why.
lead_paragraph: Recently I took my two daughters to see a silent film at Film Forum here in New York. “Kid Boots” was a hit romantic comedy of 1926, starring the stage comic Eddie Cantor (roughly the Martin Short of his era) and Clara Bow (think Britney Spears circa 2000).

headline: More Than Twice as Many U.S. Troops Are in Syria as Previously Disclosed
abstract: A Pentagon spokesman said the increase was unrelated to the fall of President Bashar al-Assad to rebel forces in early December.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said on Thursday that 2,000 American troops were in Syria, more than twice the number officials had cited for months.

headline: Mayotte Residents Struggle With Cyclone Chido Aftermath
abstract: Residents of Mayotte began relief efforts after Cyclone Chido devastated the French territory. Emmanuel Macron, President of France, surveyed the damage and received a mixed welcome.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Mayotte began relief efforts after Cyclone Chido devastated the French territory. Emmanuel Macron, President of France, surveyed the damage and received a mixed welcome.

headline: Oysters Sicken at Least 80 at Restaurant Event in Los Angeles, Officials Say
abstract: The county Health Department said that the outbreak at the 101 Best Restaurants event was linked to a broader outbreak from oysters that have since been recalled.
lead_paragraph: A norovirus outbreak linked to oysters sickened at least 80 people who attended an event celebrating The Los Angeles Times’s annual list of the 101 best restaurants in the city, local health officials said this week.

headline: Assessing Elon Musk’s Criticisms of the Government Spending Deal
abstract: The world’s richest man posted or amplified inaccurate claims about the bill’s provisions for congressional salaries, a football stadium and biological research.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the looming government shutdown.

headline: Republicans Offered a Plan to Avoid a Government Shutdown
abstract: Also, country music was ubiquitous in 2024. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans put forward a new plan this afternoon in an attempt to avert a government shutdown. Their proposal, which would fund the federal government at its current levels through mid-March, was devised after Donald Trump stepped in yesterday to torpedo a spending deal that House Speaker Mike Johnson had struck with Democrats.

headline: 2024 Faces Quiz: Politics
abstract: See how well you know the politicians of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.
lead_paragraph: See how well you know the politicians of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

headline: 2024 Faces Quiz: Sports
abstract: See how well you know the athletes of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.
lead_paragraph: See how well you know the athletes of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

headline: 2024 Faces Quiz: Culture
abstract: See how well you know the television, movie, music and literary figures of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.
lead_paragraph: See how well you know the television, movie, music and literary figures of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

headline: 2024 Faces Quiz
abstract: See how well you know the defining personalities of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.
lead_paragraph: See how well you know the defining personalities of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

headline: Rick Kaufmann, Impresario of Art Furniture, Dies at 77
abstract: Was it art or was it furniture? No one was quite sure what to make of the New York movement that an idiosyncratic gallerist led in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Art et Industrie was not a typical SoHo gallery, even in its heyday, the raucous 1980s. And its proprietor, Rick Kaufmann, a lanky, underfunded autodidact from Detroit, was not a typical SoHo gallerist.

headline: Philadelphia City Council Says Yes to New 76ers Arena Next to Chinatown
abstract: The mayor and labor unions touted the economic promise of the $1.3 billion project. Opponents said the arena would decimate the city’s storied Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: Despite vociferous community opposition, the Philadelphia City Council on Thursday approved a $1.3 billion plan to build a downtown basketball arena next to Chinatown for their hometown 76ers that had been championed by Mayor Cherelle Parker.

headline: The Timeless Craft of the Courtroom Sketch Artist
abstract: In courtrooms where cameras are banned, these artists provide a curious public a glimpse behind closed doors. Here’s how they do it.
lead_paragraph: Courtroom sketch artists serve as quiet chroniclers of history, recording the tension, drama and emotion of trials where cameras are not allowed.

headline: Neil Cavuto, Longtime Fox News Host, Signs Off the Network
abstract: “Your World with Neil Cavuto” was shown in the 4-5 p.m. slot for 28 years, since the network began in 1996.
lead_paragraph: Neil Cavuto, a business journalist who hosted a weekday afternoon program on the Fox News Channel since the network began in 1996, signed off for the final time on Thursday.

headline: 51 Men Guilty in Rape Trial That Horrified France
abstract: Dominique Pelicot, who admitted to drugging and raping his wife for almost a decade and to inviting dozens of strangers to join him, was convicted on Thursday of aggravated rape and other charges and was sentenced to the maximum 20 years in prison. The court also convicted the 50 other defendants, most of them on rape charges. Catherine Porter, a New York Times reporter, followed the four-month trial and reports from Avignon.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Pelicot, who admitted to drugging and raping his wife for almost a decade and to inviting dozens of strangers to join him, was convicted on Thursday of aggravated rape and other charges and was sentenced to the maximum 20 years in prison. The court also convicted the 50 other defendants, most of them on rape charges. Catherine Porter, a New York Times reporter, followed the four-month trial and reports from Avignon.

headline: The Shock of Faith: It’s Nothing Like I Thought It Would Be
abstract: The word “faith” implies the possession of something, whereas I experience faith as a yearning for something beautiful that I can sense but not fully grasp.
lead_paragraph: When I was an agnostic, I thought faith was primarily about belief. Being religious was about having a settled conviction that God existed and knowing that the stories in the Bible were true. I looked for books and arguments that would convince me that God was either real or not real.

headline: Britain to Name Peter Mandelson as Ambassador to the U.S.
abstract: The veteran Labour lawmaker chosen by Prime Minister Keir Starmer has experience in trade policy and business and was once nicknamed “the Prince of Darkness” for his political tactics.
lead_paragraph: The British government is expected to appoint Peter Mandelson, a Labour Party elder, as ambassador to the United States, two senior British officials said on Thursday, putting an influential onetime aide to Tony Blair at the helm of a potentially fraught relationship with President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Its Syrian Bases in Doubt, Russia Sends Cargo Flights to Libya
abstract: A Libyan officer said the stepped-up flights from Russia and Syria delivered military gear.
lead_paragraph: With the fate of its military bases in Syria uncertain, Russia has been sending cargo planes in recent days to Libya, where it also maintains a military foothold in the Middle East, Libyan officers said.

headline: How Each House Member Voted on the Bills to Avoid a Government Shutdown
abstract: The House passed a measure to fund the federal government for a few months, extend the farm bill and provide new disaster aid.
lead_paragraph: The House passed a measure to fund the federal government for a few months, extend the farm bill and provide new disaster aid.

headline: Here’s What Could Happen in a Government Shutdown
abstract: With a funding deadline approaching, workers are bracing for the possibility of a disruptive holiday season, which could include longer wait times for travelers.
lead_paragraph: There have been more than 20 gaps in federal government funding since 1976, with varying levels of shutdowns that have affected agencies — and the public — in different ways. During Donald J. Trump’s first term as president, roughly 800,000 of the federal government’s more than two million employees were sidelined for over a month starting in December 2018. The economy took a major hit.

headline: Many Videos That Purport to Show Drones in New Jersey Likely Show Planes, Visual Analysis Finds
