abstract: Here’s why it’s hard to distinguish objects in the night sky.
lead_paragraph: Starting in mid-November, a mystery began to take hold in northern New Jersey, when residents of Morris County began posting videos that appeared to show brightly lit flying objects hovering or soaring across the night sky, in some cases above their homes.

headline: Tisch Shakes Up N.Y.P.D. Staff and Orders 500 Officers Back to Key Roles
abstract: Commissioner Jessica Tisch is replacing the Police Department’s head of communications, who had clashed with reporters, and sending many officers back to patrol.
lead_paragraph: Jessica S. Tisch, New York City’s police commissioner, announced on Thursday that she was replacing the department’s combative head of communications, part of a shake-up of the department’s upper ranks and other moves that suggest she is trying to restore order to an agency reeling from chaos and dysfunction at the top.

headline: Macau Is the Casino Capital of the World. For China, That’s Not Enough.
abstract: A quarter century after the former Portuguese colony was made a Chinese territory, Macau’s economic boundaries with the mainland are being blurred.
lead_paragraph: Macau, the world’s gambling capital, is becoming more intertwined with a Chinese neighbor — one person, train and building at a time.

headline: Ex-Police Chief Who Sexually Assaulted 17-Year-Old Gets 25 Years in Prison
abstract: Larry Allen Clay Jr., 58, of Fayetteville, W.Va., was also a sheriff’s deputy at the time of the crimes, which he tried to cover up, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former police chief in West Virginia was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Thursday for paying a woman $100 to twice sexually assault her 17-year-old stepdaughter and then trying to cover it up, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Chinese National Charged in California After Aiding Local Candidate, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The man is charged with acting as an illegal foreign agent. The move is part of an effort by the authorities to prevent China from influencing American politicians.
lead_paragraph: U.S. officials on Thursday arrested a Chinese man prosecutors say was at the center of an effort to influence local politics in California, charging him with acting as an illegal foreign agent over his role in getting a politician elected to a City Council position in the Los Angeles area.

headline: Former Knicks Star Clashes With Dolan Lawyer Over Run-In at Garden
abstract: Charles Oakley answered questions in a federal courtroom on why he didn’t preserve old text messages that might have shed light on the case.
lead_paragraph: During his decade-long run as a star for the New York Knicks, Charles Oakley was known as a bruising player who embodied a hardnose style of basketball that endeared him to the fans at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Dozens of House Republicans Defy Trump in Test of His Grip on G.O.P.
abstract: Thirty-eight Republican lawmakers resisted the president-elect’s command to support a spending and debt deal, showing that at least some of his followers are willing to buck his leadership in the right circumstances.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s hammerlock on the Republican Party was shaken on Thursday night when 38 of his party’s lawmakers in the House voted to defy his command to support a spending and debt deal.

headline: Move Like a Crab
abstract: Henry Josephson makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Starbucks Workers Begin a Strike in 3 Cities on Friday
abstract: The walkouts in Los Angeles, Chicago and Seattle come after talks between the company and the workers’ union failed to produce an agreement on raises.
lead_paragraph: A union representing Starbucks workers said that baristas in Los Angeles, Chicago and Seattle walked off the job Friday morning and that the strikes would spread to hundreds of stores by Tuesday, Christmas Eve, unless the company improved its wage offer in contract negotiations.

headline: Quote of the Day: 51 MEN CONVICTED OF RAPE AT TRIAL
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I wanted, by opening the doors of this trial on Sept. 2, that society would take up the debates that have been launched.”

headline: How to Make a D.I.Y. Menorah
abstract: Creating your own candleholder can be a fun way to teach kids about the holiday — and to spread a bit of festive light.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on Dec. 30, 2022.

headline: Love in a Time of War
abstract: Anastasia Savka and Oleksiy Levchenko met at a rehabilitation facility earlier this year after surviving critical injuries as Ukrainian soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Oleksiy Levchenko wasn’t worried when his fiancée Anastasia Savka fell off a galloping horse during a film shoot in Kyiv, Ukraine, this summer.

headline: Looking for the Restless Soul of Nella Larsen in Copenhagen
abstract: The celebrated Harlem Renaissance author was inspired by her experiences as a mixed-race teenager and young adult in the Danish capital, a time that informed her 1928 novel, “Quicksand.”
lead_paragraph: When Helga Crane, the main character in Nella Larsen’s novel “Quicksand,” walked through the streets of Copenhagen, people were amazed. “Her dark, alien appearance was to most people an astonishment,” wrote Larsen, an acclaimed Harlem Renaissance author. “Some stared surreptitiously, some openly, and some stopped dead in front of her in order more fully to profit by their stares.”

headline: To Make Him Less Nervous, She Kissed Him
abstract: When Brianna Brown and Kevin Malinak were introduced in 2015, they didn’t know the dramatic journey the next nine years would hold.
lead_paragraph: Brianna Nicole Irene Brown and Kevin Russell Malinak shared their first kiss in January 2015 on the night they met — more than a year before their first official date.

headline: Grief Makes Us Time Travelers
abstract: A neuroscientist studying memory, I used to believe time was linear. Then my mother had a stroke.
lead_paragraph: I am in my pajamas, watching a Netflix documentary about space telescopes when I begin to think about my mother.

headline: A First Date She Nearly Called Off
abstract: Blair Smith and Alec Hall met on a gloomy winter night, but their time together took a celebratory turn when he popped a bottle of champagne.
lead_paragraph: Moments before Blair Julia Smith showed up to her umpteenth first date, this time at a bar in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, she nearly called it off.

headline: A Union That Could Not Wait
abstract: After a year of dating, Adrian Burrus and Quinn Sames began considering marriage. But when the presidential election results were announced, getting married became a priority.
lead_paragraph: It was a provocative sign about racism that Adrian James Burrus was carrying that first caught Quinn Dipboye Sames’s eye at a Black Lives Matter protest on June 11, 2020, in downtown Lexington, Ky. The protest was in response to the deaths of George Floyd in Minneapolis and Breonna Taylor in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Review: In a Stripped-Down ‘Gypsy,’ Audra’s Gonna Show It to Ya
abstract: Hold your hats and hallelujah, our leading musical tragedienne offers an ultra-dramatic Rose in George C. Wolfe’s Broadway revival.
lead_paragraph: It’s only fitting that we pore over “Gypsy” as if it were holy writ. It was, after all, written by three of the holies: Jule Styne (music), Stephen Sondheim (lyrics) and Arthur Laurents (book).

headline: Ukrainians Mourn the Loss of a Young Journalist and Her Stories
abstract: Viktoria Roshchyna died in September in Russian custody. The reporter had been well-known for her stories about life in parts of occupied Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Viktoria Roshchyna reported from places most other Ukrainian journalists would not go. She was one of the last to report openly from the territory in Ukraine forcibly taken by Russian troops. And then she went further and entered Russia.

headline: On Avignon’s Ancient Ramparts, Modern Messages Denounce ‘Rape Culture’
abstract: A feminist collective, the Amazons of Avignon, has been plastering the walls of the city with testimony from the trial of the 51 men who were convicted in the Gisèle Pelicot rape case.
lead_paragraph: The buttery yellow ramparts encircling the center of Avignon stretch 2.6 miles and are notched with arrow slits and gaps for dumping boiling water or cooking oil on attackers below.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The rape trial that horrified France.
lead_paragraph: In a packed courtroom in Avignon, France, all 51 of the men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was unconscious were found guilty yesterday. The trial has convulsed France and transformed the woman at its center into a feminist icon for her bravery in allowing the case to be tried publicly.

headline: A Mouse That Swims and Dozens More Species Are Discovered in a Peruvian Jungle
abstract: A 38-day expedition in the remote Alto Mayo region, where development threatens wild habitats, turned up one previously unknown animal after another.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2022, researchers trudged into the jungles of the Alto Mayo region of Peru in search of undiscovered creatures. This remote yet populous region had experienced significant deforestation, so the team didn’t expect to find much.

headline: Senior U.S. Diplomats Meet With Governing Militias in Syria
abstract: The U.S. officials in Damascus are also looking for signs of Austin Tice, a missing American journalist, as well as other U.S. citizens.
lead_paragraph: Senior American diplomats traveled through Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Friday to meet with militias controlling the country and with civil society groups, and to look for signs of the journalist Austin Tice and other missing U.S. citizens, the State Department said.

headline: Trump Puts $4 Billion in Shares of His Media Company in a Trust
abstract: A regulatory filing showed that the president-elect transferred some 115 million shares of Trump Media to a trust controlled by his son Donald Trump Jr.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump transferred all of his shares in the social media company that bears his name to a trust controlled by his eldest son, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday night.

headline: Seth Meyers: Donald Trump Got ‘Cable Guy’-ed by Elon Musk
abstract: The “Late Night” host likened Trump’s relationship with Musk to the 1996 Jim Carrey movie: “You let him do you a favor, and now you can’t get rid of him.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: animatronics
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word animatronics has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 11 in “Farewell, Chuck E. Cheese Animatronic Band” by Jesus Jiménez. The excerpt below includes a quote by David McKillips, the chief executive of Chuck E. Cheese.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: What Broadway Gets Right and Wrong About Journalism
abstract: A Culture writer takes stock of recent stage productions that depict newsrooms and reporters.
lead_paragraph: One can hardly blame people for believing journalists have questionable ethics.

headline: Hochul Weighs Legislation Limiting A.I. and More Than 100 Other Bills
abstract: A bill passed by the New York State Legislature to regulate the state’s use of artificial intelligence is among more than 100 that await Gov. Kathy Hochul’s decision.
lead_paragraph: It is an end-of-year State Capitol tradition, a lawmaker’s parallel to the tree lighting at Rockefeller Center: a holiday checklist of scores of bills that await Gov. Kathy Hochul’s signature or veto before the new year.

headline: Is New Jersey the New Area 51?
abstract: No matter how many official voices declare there is no drone emergency, conspiracy theories continue to flourish. We’ve been here before.
lead_paragraph: As you may have almost certainly heard, New Jersey has recently become the epicenter of aerial-object obsession, some might say panic. Mysterious drones, or planes, or maybe extraterrestrial spycraft depending on your view, seem to have been lighting up the night sky for the past month, and theories about their purposes and origins abound.

headline: Googly Eyes
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Trump Is Threatening Europe With Tariffs. Is It Ready?
abstract: The incoming president promised “tariffs all the way” unless Europe bought more U.S. oil and gas. European officials have no clear strategy for avoiding a trade war.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats of tariffs on allies and adversaries alike have unsettled companies and governments across Europe, setting off a scramble for what they fear could be a trans-Atlantic trade war.

headline: At 23, Surviving Scandal to Take a Green Seat in the E.U. Parliament
abstract: Lena Schilling, the youngest lawmaker in Brussels, faced a harsh questioning of her character and credibility before winning a chance to fight against climate change in the halls of power.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning for a seat in the European Parliament this spring, Lena Schilling was already facing an uphill battle, with her Green Party expected to fare poorly in the election across the continent.

headline: How Your Car Might Be Making Roads Safer
abstract: Researchers say data from long-haul trucks and General Motors cars is critical for addressing traffic congestion and road safety. Data privacy experts have their concerns.
lead_paragraph: Darcy Bullock, a civil engineering professor at Purdue University, turns to his computer screen to get information about how fast cars are traveling on Interstate 65, which runs 887 miles from Lake Michigan to the Gulf of Mexico. It’s midafternoon on a Monday, and his screen is mostly filled with green dots indicating that traffic is moving along nicely. But near an exit on the outskirts of Indianapolis, an angry red streak shows that cars have stopped moving.

headline: A Legacy of Essential Humanitarian Aid
abstract: Catholic Charities provides help to the poor, homeless, hungry and the most vulnerable immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Catholic Charities is the oldest beneficiary of The New York Times Communities Fund, and the need for its services has only grown over the decades. Though run by the Catholic Church, Catholic Charities serves people of all denominations and backgrounds. Its work ranges from running a pop-up food pantry in the Bronx to assisting undocumented immigrants expelled from Texas, arranging shelter for Ukrainian refugees after they were abandoned by their sponsor, or organizing a relief fund for victims of Hurricane Milton.

headline: Your College Football Team, Now Brought to You by Whiskey
abstract: The high cost of amateur athletics has led to some unlikely partnerships.
lead_paragraph: At SHI Stadium at Rutgers University, advertisements for Eric LeGrand Whiskey flashed across the Jumbotron and on digital billboards during football games this season as bartenders used it to whip up old-fashioned cocktails in premium seating areas.

headline: Can Wall Street Pressure Ease Brutality in India’s Sugar Fields?
abstract: Pension funds and big investors are pressuring Coca-Cola, Pepsico and others over brutal working conditions in India’s cane fields. Some of the sugar buyers are tiptoeing toward change.
lead_paragraph: The New York City comptroller, who oversees hundreds of billions of dollars in pension investments, is pressuring some of the world’s major sugar buyers to stop profiting off child labor, debt bondage and coerced hysterectomies in western India.

headline: Postmortems Are Bad at Predictions: Democrats May Just Need a ‘Change’ Election
abstract: An opening will probably emerge for Democrats in four years, but it may not be what the party and pundits expect today.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot about politics that’s hard to predict, but there’s something you can count on every four years: One party loses a presidential election, and the recriminations begin.

headline: One of the Most Unpredictable Actresses of the ’70s Is Back From Exile
abstract: Jessica Harper made risky moves (“Suspiria” over “Annie Hall”), then took time off for family. Her “Nightbitch” role is a nod to her career choices.
lead_paragraph: The actress Jessica Harper was first profiled in The Times on Aug. 19, 1977. The occasion was the release of the Italian horror film “Suspiria,” and much was made of the fact that she had turned down a small role in Woody Allen’s “Annie Hall.” She explained, “I would have loved to do ‘Annie Hall’ but this was a big role and it meant going to Rome. I couldn’t pass it up, but I don’t know if it was a wise choice.”

headline: They Entered Treatment. Drugs, Overdoses and Deaths Followed.
abstract: Baltimore addiction programs draw patients with free housing while collecting millions. Some say one company offered little help.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Vlakos had been living for years in rat-infested abandoned buildings in Baltimore, fighting an addiction to opioids, when she learned of a possible escape: a drug-treatment program that offered patients free housing.

headline: Staffers at The Times on the Books They Enjoyed in 2024
abstract: A taboo-busting Brooklyn memoir, a tender Japanese novel about the beauty of connection, a book by a death doula: Editors and writers from around the newsroom describe their favorite books of the year.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know why I picked up LOVED AND MISSED. It must have caught my eye through some sort of bookstore magic, because I had never seen it before and I didn’t recognize the author’s name. I had a professor in college who said novels remind us of what it means to be human. This is a book that does exactly that. It’s about a woman named Ruth who takes in her granddaughter because her daughter is hopelessly addicted to drugs. Actually, she doesn’t just take her in. Ruth hands over an envelope of cash to her addled daughter and backs away fast with the baby in her pram.

headline: Packed Cubicles, Empty Corner Office: Remote Work Is Increasingly a Right of the Rich
abstract: Remote work is increasingly a privilege enjoyed by the most affluent Americans.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to remote work, executives want workers to do as they say, not as they do.

headline: Why It’s Hard to Control What Gets Taught in Public Schools
abstract: Politicians on both the left and the right have sought to change or limit what teachers can do inside classrooms. Teachers often ignore them.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma and Texas are among more than 20 states that have passed laws since 2021 seeking to control how race, gender and American history are discussed in schools.

headline: For These Picture Book Heroes, Daydreams Are What Life Is Made Of
abstract: Like Max and Madeline, this boy and girl keep faith with the intangible treasures of their imaginations.
lead_paragraph: Children have a knack for finding the signs and wonders they need to feel at home in the world. They find them where and when they can. Resilient Madeline, in the Ludwig Bemelmans classic, spies a friendly rabbit crouching in the crack-lines of her orphanage dormitory ceiling. Maurice Sendak’s Max sees in the four plain bedposts of his own dreary room the first intimations of the untamed forest of his dreams.

headline: Ten Years Later, a Political Exile Returns to a Syria in Transition
abstract: In 2014, Sawsan Abou Zainedin left Syria during a civil war, while Bashar al-Assad was in power. Now, with rebel militants in control, Ms. Abou Zainedin is working on the country’s delicate political transformation.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Sawsan Abou Zainedin left Syria during a civil war, while Bashar al-Assad was in power. Now, with rebel militants in control, Ms. Abou Zainedin is working on the country’s delicate political transformation.

headline: New Year’s Eve in New York: What to Do, See and Eat
abstract: Whether you brave Times Square, pop into a drag show or snuggle up in a heated igloo, we have you covered for this year’s countdown.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s Eve is right around the corner, which means now is the time to start planning your day (and night and the next morning). From oddball classes to inspirational concerts, splashy parties to silent hikes, here are a few ways to ring in 2025 around New York City.

headline: ‘It Will Be a More Robust Check on Trump Than the G.O.P. Congress’: Three Legal Experts on Trump 2.0
abstract: Opinion writers discuss potential legal issues and executive power in a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: Kate Shaw, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation with Times Opinion columnist David French and Jack Goldsmith, a law professor at Harvard and a co-author of “After Trump: Reconstructing the Presidency,” to discuss some of the key legal questions likely to arise in the second Trump administration.

headline: Yes, Biden’s Green Future Can Still Happen Under Trump
abstract: Jigar Shah and Robinson Meyer discuss how the decarbonization rollout can continue during the second Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Artists We Lost in 2024, in Their Words
abstract: Shelley Duvall, Quincy Jones, Faith Ringgold and Paul Auster are some of the greats who died this year.
lead_paragraph: Hands that gripped paintbrushes, pens and drum sticks; eyes that saw new meaning in the familiar; feet that leaped across stages, stood before microphones or tapped underneath desks as their resolute owners wrote. By expressing themselves, the many creative people who died this year helped us better understand ourselves. Here is a tribute to some of them, in their voices.

headline: Meet the Director Who Reinvented the Act of Seeing
abstract: In “Nickel Boys,” RaMell Ross uses what he calls “sentient perspective” to convey the characters’ view of their world. Critics say the result is stunning.
lead_paragraph: A year after RaMell Ross finished filming “Nickel Boys,” he learned to fly.

headline: Table for 2 at Tatiana? There Used to Be a Bot for That.
abstract: A new state law will clamp down on what Gov. Kathy Hochul called a “predatory black market” for restaurant reservations.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a new state law that targets apps that make restaurant reservations available — for a price. We’ll also get details on entries in the notebook Luigi Mangione was carrying when he was apprehended in Pennsylvania.

headline: Why Composers of Any (or No) Faith Are Drawn to Sacred Music
abstract: Many Christmas standards were not written by Christians. David Lang explains the appeal for him, a Jewish composer of a modern holiday classic.
lead_paragraph: If you like Christmas music, “It’s the Most Wonderful Time of the Year” isn’t just the name of a song.

headline: The Books Readers Loved in 2024
abstract: Memorable characters, delightful nonfiction and poignant novels stuck with people across the world.
lead_paragraph: Every year the Book Review publishes lists of the best new books. But we know that’s not the full story.

headline: The Great Drone Freak-Out Is Coming
abstract: The Drone Age is already upon us and the skies are going to get a lot more crowded.
lead_paragraph: The public has already been given the government’s best answers to the latest panic over mysterious lights in the sky over New Jersey. Many Americans simply don’t like a mundane answer — fixed-wing piloted aircraft, smaller planes, hobbyist drones — that implies they are rubes at best and paranoid at worst.

headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Adrien Brody stars as László Tóth, an architect and survivor of the Holocaust who lands in America in this sprawling drama directed by Brady Corbet.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in Thessaloniki, Greece
abstract: The area in and around Greece’s second-largest city offers traditional Greek houses, modern renovations and waterfront views.
lead_paragraph: Built on a hillside in the seaside village of Vourvourou, this four-bedroom, four-bathroom house is in the Settlement of Professors, a gated community built as a cooperative for academics from the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki in the 1960s. Now a development of about 150 homes, the area maintains its wide streets and treed landscapes. Professors still own most of its houses.

headline: A Solstice of the Soul
abstract: For his next trick, your cosmic correspondent for the past quarter-century will (try to) retire.
lead_paragraph: As the day shrinks into its annual darkness, here’s what I know about the cosmos — so far.

headline: How a Scrappy New Publisher Landed 25 Books on the Best-Seller List in a Year
abstract: Bloom Books took off with the help of E L James, the author of “Fifty Shades of Grey.” It broke with tradition and became the fastest-growing imprint in romance.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Scarlett St. Clair was working as a librarian in Oklahoma, self-publishing romance novels on the side, when one of her books went viral on TikTok.

headline: ‘Elton John: Never Too Late’ Burnishes a Career (but Charmingly)
abstract: The star is in positive, future-looking mode in this Disney+ documentary, directed by his husband, David Furnish, and R.J. Cutler.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve been as famous as Elton John for as long as Elton John — he’s been a solo professional for 55 years — it can be hard to find a new way to tell your story. The contours of his career are almost archetypal for a musician: early virtuosic success, a crash-and-burn moment, then redemption. In John’s case, that redemption story is tied up with both getting sober and meeting David Furnish, who later became his husband, in the early 1990s.

headline: How Drug Overdose Deaths Have Plagued One Generation of Black Men for Decades
abstract: In dozens of cities, the recent rise of fentanyl has put older Black men in particular jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: Young Black men in cities across America died of drug overdoses at high rates in the 1980s and 1990s. During the recent fentanyl crisis, older Black men in many cities have been dying at unusually high rates.

headline: Are Amazon’s Drones Finally Ready for Prime Time?
abstract: A recent visit to the company’s overhauled drone delivery program in Arizona left me impressed by the drones, but skeptical that the public will welcome them.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, concerned New Jersey residents have craned their heads skyward to track the movements of what appeared to be mysterious drones overhead, formulate theories about their origins and strategize about how to get rid of them.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Holiday Movie or TV Special?
abstract: “Elf,” “Home Alone” or “A Charlie Brown Christmas” — what’s on your must-watch list each holiday season?
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of the year again — not just for gift-giving but for cozying up with family and friends and watching holiday movies and television specials together. (Take a Times quiz to test your knowledge of the beloved seasonal classics.) What are some of your favorites? What lessons have you learned from them about the holidays or life in general?

headline: The Surprising Sexual Politics of Nicole Kidman’s Kinky ‘Babygirl’
abstract: The film feels like an artifact of a more optimistic feminist moment.
lead_paragraph: It has been a ghastly year for American women — at least those of us who are not looking forward to being ruled by a claque of cartoon chauvinists — but a pretty rich year for women in the movies.

headline: Maurice Berger Held a Mirror to a Racist Art World
abstract: A posthumous anthology of photo essays by the curator and art historian reveals the “troubling reality” of prejudice and the power of images to “undermine the very concept of difference.”
lead_paragraph: To hear Maurice Berger tell it, growing up among mostly Black and Puerto Rican families in a low-income housing project in New York City sharpened his lens on the layers and levels of discrimination in America. “As a gay man and as a Jew, I’ve experienced homophobia and antisemitism in my life,” he writes in RACE STORIES: Essays on the Power of Images (Aperture/The New York Times, $40). “But the racism the kids I grew up with experienced, in front of my eyes, left me realizing that nothing quite compared to that in terms of prejudice.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Dec. 20, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: How to Talk to a Loved One About Their Drinking
abstract: There are ways to broach the topic successfully — it’s all about time, place and tone.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are a time of excess. Too much food. Too much drink. And sometimes an alcohol problem can masquerade as high spirits and good cheer.

headline: Three Deals in 12 Days: How Australia Is Countering China in the Pacific
abstract: In separate agreements with Nauru, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, Australia is attempting to edge out China’s influence in the region.
lead_paragraph: A bank. A rugby team. A larger police force.

headline: Musk, Ring-Kissing and a Looming Shutdown
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin sits down with Michael Barbaro to discuss raising the debt ceiling and Elon Musk’s political impact.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Ross Sorkin sits down with Michael Barbaro to discuss raising the debt ceiling and Elon Musk’s political impact.

headline: Ring-Kissing, Defamation Lawsuits and a Looming Shutdown
abstract: On this week’s round table, Michael Barbaro sits down with Maggie Haberman, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Catie Edmondson to discuss the latest news in Donald J. Trump’s transition to power.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s round table, Michael Barbaro sits down with Maggie Haberman, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Catie Edmondson to discuss the latest news in Donald J. Trump’s transition to power.

headline: Ring-Kissing, Lawsuits and a Looming Shutdown
abstract: Watch or listen to our political round table about the aftermath of the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before his inauguration, President-elect Donald J. Trump is pushing the federal government toward a shutdown, corporate titans are flocking to Mar-a-Lago to gain his favor and a major media company has capitulated to Trump’s legal strategy of suing those who cross him.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 559
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,281
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: What a Shutdown Could Look Like, and a ‘Healthy’ Food Fight
abstract: Plus, real estate’s trendiest mash-up: the “barndo.”
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Romanian Court Blocks Andrew Tate’s Case From Heading to Trial
abstract: An indictment against Mr. Tate, the online influencer facing accusations of human trafficking and sexual misconduct, was sent back to prosecutors, an appeals court said.
lead_paragraph: A trial in Romania for Andrew Tate, the online influencer who is facing criminal accusations involving human trafficking and sexual misconduct, will not go ahead, at least for now, after an appeals court sent an indictment back to prosecutors on Thursday.

headline: When We Roll Back the Rules
abstract: We cover America’s embrace of individual freedom.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana and sports gambling tell a story about American politics. Twenty years ago, both were largely illegal. Now, most people can partake in them legally.

headline: Is Amazon’s Drone Delivery Finally Ready for Prime Time?
abstract: We flew to Arizona to test the recently debuted service ourselves.
lead_paragraph: This week, we took a field trip to the Phoenix suburbs to see Amazon’s newest iteration of drone delivery service in action. We toured the facility where these drones are in operation, spoke with the vice president and general manager of Prime Air, David Carbon, and watched from a local backyard as our own order dropped from the sky.

headline: Britannica Didn’t Just Survive. It’s an A.I. Company Now.
abstract: The encyclopedia maker could have become a casualty of the Wikipedia era. But it has remade itself into a digital learning giant that is weighing going public.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 250 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica was a bookshelf-busting series of gilt-lettered tomes, often purchased to show that its owners cared about knowledge.

headline: Who’s in Charge?
abstract: Donald Trump has yet to take office but the president-elect and Elon Musk are already influencing policy, putting the federal government hours away from a shut down.
lead_paragraph: Washington is on the brink of crisis, as 38 House Republicans joined nearly all Democrats last night in rejecting a government funding plan backed by President-elect Donald Trump and Elon Musk. If a last-minute deal isn’t reached, the government will shut down at 12:01 a.m. Eastern.

headline: Cyclone Chido Death Toll Nearly Doubles in Mozambique
abstract: The swirling wind and rain hit an area where a yearslong insurgency had already forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their homes.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from Cyclone Chido in Mozambique has risen to 75, the government said on Friday, nearly doubling the previously reported number.

headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Measure Sped Up in November
abstract: The Personal Consumption Expenditures index climbed 2.4 percent from a year earlier, though the report’s details were more subdued than expected.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are closely watching how inflation shapes up as they contemplate when and how much to cut interest rates in 2025, and the latest inflation data offers reasons for both wariness and hope.

headline: Wall St. Is at It Again, Making Irrelevant Market Predictions
abstract: Optimistic guesses about the future are not forecasts, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: An annual ritual is underway at the major Wall Street investment houses: predicting exactly where the S&P 500 will finish the next calendar year.

headline: How a New Year’s Resolution Can Set Up Your Financial Goals for Success
abstract: Don’t give up on resolving to do better, psychologists and personal finance experts say. The key is to reframe the way you think about it.
lead_paragraph: Thinking about making a New Year’s resolution to get your finances in order? You might have better luck sticking to it than you’d expect.

abstract: Listen to our interview with Alex Cooper.
lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

abstract: Listen to our interview with Serena Williams.
lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

headline: Bill Clinton: ‘There Was No Plan’ After Biden Dropped Out
abstract: Listen to our interview with Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

headline: From Amazon to Space — Jeff Bezos Talks Innovation, Progress and What’s Next
abstract: Listen to our interview with Jeff Bezos.
lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 20, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Syria’s first domestic flight since the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s government referred incorrectly to the territory held by the rebel alliance that ousted Mr. al-Assad. The alliance holds much of Syria’s northwest, not its northeast.

headline: How Anti-Obesity Drugs are Redefining Pharma and Wellness
abstract: Listen to our interview with David Ricks and Fatima Cody Stanford.
lead_paragraph: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

headline: ‘The Tempest’ Review: A Weak Wind Blows for Sigourney Weaver
abstract: The veteran actress, playing Prospero in her West End debut, is strangely absent from Shakespeare’s narrative.
lead_paragraph: Sigourney Weaver has inhabited some unusual realms in the course of her storied film career. So it’s not overly surprising that the star of “Alien” and “Avatar” might choose to come to the West End in “The Tempest,” Shakespeare’s otherworldly play.

headline: The Government Shutdown: What Travelers Need to Know
abstract: The failure to act by Congress could cause airport lines and other disruptions across the travel industry during a busy holiday travel period.
lead_paragraph: A government shutdown could snarl plans for tens of millions of Americans traveling for the December holidays if Congress fails on Friday to pass legislation to keep the government functioning. Nonessential federal operations would cease at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday.

headline: Mushroom Bourguignon, Ginger Sesame Granola and Fried Eggplant Heroes
abstract: Weekend kitchen shenanigans to keep everyone festive and fed.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. One of the more satisfying wintertime weekend activities is the making of stock: beef, say, or chicken or vegetable. (Lobster if you’re fancy.) These come in handy when you want to make a risotto of uncommon flavor, amp up a soup or supercharge a gravy.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s sci-fi picks, time loops, zombie apocalypses and robot/dog friendships.
lead_paragraph: What if a zombie apocalypse wasn’t even the scariest thing to happen to your family? Carlo Ledesma’s film takes place in the Filipino countryside, where Francis (Sid Lucero) and Iris (Beauty Gonzalez) have fled with their young sons, Lucas (Aiden Tyler Patdu) and Joshua (Marco Masa). They are looking for refuge in Francis’s isolated childhood home, which feels relatively safe from the marauding undead. This is, of course, a fairly common premise but Ledesma puts a dramatic twist on it by focusing on Francis’s unraveling. His relationship with Iris is already on the rocks when we meet them, and he crumbles further into jealousy, paranoia and violence as the pressure mounts.

headline: ‘The Room Next Door’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Pedro Almodóvar narrates a sequence from his film starring Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Almodóvar narrates a sequence from his film starring Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton.

headline: This Classic Kwanzaa Cookbook Invites Improvisation
abstract: Dr. Jessica B. Harris revisits and expands “A Kwanzaa Keepsake,” her highly personal book from 1995.
lead_paragraph: As 2024 was running out and a new year loomed, the prolific cookbook author and culinary historian Jessica B. Harris was thinking about Oxford’s word of the year: brain rot.

headline: Watch Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton Connect in ‘The Room Next Door’
abstract: The writer and director Pedro Almodóvar narrates a bittersweet sequence between the two at a luxurious home.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Weather’s Impact on Your Wallet: See How Much You Know
abstract: Where do wildfires threaten the most homes? How much can an inch of floodwater in your house cost you? Take our quiz to find out.
lead_paragraph: Where do wildfires threaten the most homes? How much can an inch of floodwater in your house cost you? Take our quiz to find out.

headline: Top Senate Democrats Want Epshteyn to Address Pay-to-Play Allegations
abstract: The chairmen of the Finance, Judiciary and Banking Committees demanded answers from a Trump lawyer accused of soliciting payments from potential administration nominees.
lead_paragraph: Three top Senate Democrats on Friday wrote to Boris Epshteyn, a top Trump lawyer, demanding answers to allegations that he solicited payments from potential Trump administration nominees.

headline: Trump Wanted Shutdown to Happen on Biden’s Watch, Not His
abstract: The president-elect was eager to evade responsibility for the consequences of a potential shutdown even as he blew up a bipartisan deal that would have kept the government open.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump, who derailed a bipartisan spending deal in Congress, tried on Friday to escape responsibility for the consequences, saying it would be better to let the government shut down under President Biden’s watch than to allow a politically damaging stalemate once he takes office next month.

headline: More People Are Now Dying From the Cold
abstract: A new study finds that deaths related to cold weather in the United States have risen in the past two decades.
lead_paragraph: Deaths related to cold weather have risen steadily nationwide in recent decades, new research shows, underscoring the continued risks of cold exposure even as average temperatures continue to climb.

headline: Musk Expresses Support for Far-Right Party in Germany’s Election
abstract: It was not the first online intervention by Elon Musk, the entrepreneur and adviser to Donald Trump, on behalf of once-fringe anti-immigrant parties in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man and a close adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, on Friday endorsed Germany’s far-right party, a group with ties to neo-Nazis whose youth wing has been classified as “confirmed extremist” by German domestic intelligence.

headline: One of 2024’s Last Meteor Showers Is About to Reach Its Peak
abstract: The astronomical event, which overlaps with the Winter Solstice, is often overlooked because of the winter chill.
lead_paragraph: The longest night in the Northern Hemisphere is upon us. And it will be accompanied by a holiday light show from the Ursids, the last major meteor shower of the year to peak.

headline: The Story of Hong Kong’s Billionaire Dissident
abstract: “The Troublemaker” is a brisk account of the life and work of Jimmy Lai, the media mogul and democracy activist currently on trial for national security offenses.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Aug. 10, 2020, scores of armed police arrived at the headquarters of Apple Daily, one of Hong Kong’s most prominent pro-democracy newspapers. They rifled through the offices, hunting for evidence of treason, and frog-marched the paper’s billionaire publisher, Jimmy Lai, through his own third-floor newsroom. Lai soon faced charges under a new security law of colluding with foreign powers. A few months later, Mark L. Clifford writes in “The Troublemaker,” a brisk account of Lai’s life and work, the gravity of his predicament began to set in, and Lai sent a laconic WhatsApp message to his associates: “Delete everything.”

headline: The Fair Catch Free Kick, and 4 Other Obscure-but-Real N.F.L. Rules
abstract: On Thursday, the Los Angeles Chargers pulled off a rare “free-kick field goal.” There are other oddball rules in the book if you dig deep enough.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. rule book is long.

headline: Book Club: Let’s Talk About Claire Keegan’s ‘Small Things Like These’
abstract: This slim novella about one Irishman’s crisis of conscience during the Christmas season is the topic of our December book club discussion.
lead_paragraph: Clare Keegan’s slim 2021 novella about one Irishman’s crisis of conscience during the Christmas season, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, has also been adapted into a film starring Cillian Murphy. In this week’s episode, MJ Franklin discusses the book with his colleagues Joumana Khatib, Lauren Christensen and Elisabeth Egan.

headline: Regulators Sue 3 Big Banks Over Rampant Fraud on Zelle
abstract: Action against Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo may not survive President-elect Donald J. Trump’s return to office.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration brought new, sweeping accusations of fraud on Friday against three of the largest banks in the country — but President-elect Donald J. Trump’s administration will have the opportunity to drop the case as soon as next month.

headline: Volkswagen Reaches Labor Deal, Avoiding Germany Plant Closures
abstract: The automaker agreed to keep all 10 of its factories in Germany open and to guarantee workers’ jobs until the end of 2030.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen, Germany’s largest automaker, reached an agreement with its union on Friday, ending a three-month standoff that had rattled the country and brought to light the extent of German industrial decline.

headline: Why Britain Has So Many White Christmases (Technically)
abstract: Bing Crosby dreamed of it and Charles Dickens romanticized it, but the truth about a white Christmas in Britain may surprise you.
lead_paragraph: It’s the fantasy festive image: snow on Christmas Day. Immortalized on countless holiday cards, inspired in the collective consciousness by Charles Dickens’s depictions of snow blanketing the cobbled, crowded streets of London in “A Christmas Carol.”

headline: Markets Rally, Shaking Off Threat of Government Shutdown
abstract: The S&P 500 jumped after a November inflation reading helped ease worries. A partial government shutdown, analysts said, wouldn’t have a lasting economic impact.
lead_paragraph: Stock investors took their cue from data showing that inflation continued to slow in November, shrugging off the looming threat of a government shutdown.

headline: Elon Musk’s Growing Political Influence
abstract: Readers discuss his role in the government shutdown negotiations. Also: Trump austerity; G.O.P.’s future; clean energy; guns and young people.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Meet the 38 Republicans Who Defied Trump on the Spending and Debt Deal
abstract: The rebels are largely the most conservative lawmakers who are passionate about slashing spending and debt. They hail from deep-red districts where a primary challenge is less of a danger.
lead_paragraph: The 38 House Republicans who refused to vote for the spending deal pushed by President-elect Donald J. Trump are largely limited-government fiscal hawks who believe they are impervious to a primary threat in their bids for re-election.

headline: Are Weight-Loss Drugs Causing a Rift in Your Relationship? We Want to Hear About It.
abstract: For an upcoming article, we are looking for stories about what happens to a long-term relationship when one partner decides to get much thinner.

headline: Kelly Clarkson’s Christmas Love Song, and 12 More New Holiday Tunes
abstract: Hear tracks from Bartees Strange, Madi Diaz, GloRilla and Kehlani, and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Would You Wear Jeans at the Gym?
abstract: Frequent images of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others lifting weights in jeans and boots raise the question of what can be classified as proper gym attire.
lead_paragraph: As political plotlines go, this one is more sweaty than salacious.

headline: 21 Movies, Books and Albums With a Theater Focus to Consume During the Holidays
abstract: Make it through the holidays with these movies, books and music from the past year that are adapted from stage productions or evoke a theatrical spirit.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to an abundance of film adaptations of stage productions, theater-centric books and a spate of newly released cast albums, there’s enough theater to go around from the comfort of home. (There’s also lot to see on and Off Broadway, and you can read our reviews here and additional theater coverage here.)

headline: Virginia Student Accused of Plot to Attack Israeli Consulate in New York
abstract: A freshman at George Mason University, who is a citizen of Egypt, was arrested on Tuesday after being accused of planning an attack.
lead_paragraph: A freshman at George Mason University in Virginia is accused of plotting an attack at the Israeli consulate general in New York. He faces a charge of distributing information relating to weapons of mass destruction, according to federal court documents.

headline: E.P.A. Administrator Michael Regan to Depart at End of December
abstract: Mr. Regan informed agency employees that he would leave before the formal end of the Biden term.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Regan, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will step down at the end of this month, before the formal end of the Biden administration, he announced in an email to employees Friday.

headline: We Need a Great American Fantasy
abstract: In search of a New World answer to Narnia and Hogwarts.
lead_paragraph: Any cultural critic can complain, as I did in last weekend’s column, about the lack of creativity in American popular culture right now and the unmet “hunger for a certain kind of popular art” amid so much institutionalized unoriginality. It’s a bit harder to give writers or filmmakers specific marching orders. What exact kind of popular art are we missing? What specific achievement should American creators be aiming for?

headline: Matteo Salvini Acquitted After Blocking Rescue of Migrant Boat in Italy
abstract: The deputy prime minister and the leader of the far-right League party claimed he was a victim in the fight against illegal immigration that has swept across Europe.
lead_paragraph: An Italian court acquitted Matteo Salvini, the country’s deputy prime minister and the leader of the anti-immigrant League party, after he was accused of illegally refusing to allow a boat carrying migrants to dock in Italy five years ago.

headline: In Memoriam: The Musicians We Lost in 2024
abstract: Hear songs from Quincy Jones, Melanie and Toby Keith.
lead_paragraph: As we look back at 2024, it’s important to honor the many great musicians we lost this year. Over the past 12 months, we’ve said goodbye to some towering legends of American song (Quincy Jones, Kris Kristofferson), beloved cult heroes of underground music (Steve Albini, the Can vocalist Damo Suzuki), and pop idols of different cultures and generations (the Shangri-Las’ Mary Weiss, One Direction’s Liam Payne and the French icon Françoise Hardy, to name just a few). On today’s playlist, all of their disparate sounds and styles will mingle as one long, eclectic musical memorial.

headline: Trump Used Government Shutdowns as Leverage During His First Presidency
abstract: A partial government shutdown in Donald J. Trump’s first term was the longest in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, during Donald J. Trump’s first presidency, he said he would be “proud” to shut down the government if a deal was not reached that included funding he wanted for his proposed wall along the southern U.S. border.

headline: Five Books That Explain the Chaos of 2024
abstract: And one to read for fun.
lead_paragraph: I like to use my last column of the year to wrap up the major developments of the previous 12 months. But the events of 2024 feel fundamentally un-wrappable: The news is just moving too rapidly.

headline: Russia’s Abrupt Setback in Syria Creates Headaches for Putin
abstract: Losing Syrian military bases would hurt the Kremlin’s attempts to project power in the Middle East and Africa.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Russia has been trying to rebuild its influence in the Middle East. But after the rapid collapse of the Assad regime in Syria, the Kremlin is scrambling to salvage whatever it can.

headline: French Court Convicts 8 People Tied to Events That Led to Teacher’s Killing
abstract: Samuel Paty was beheaded in 2020 by an Islamist extremist after showing caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad to his students to illustrate free speech.
lead_paragraph: A Paris court on Friday convicted eight people for their roles in the events that led to the killing of Samuel Paty, a history teacher whose stabbing and decapitation by an Islamist terrorist in 2020 deeply shocked France.

headline: Trump Moves to Replace Officials Whom New Presidents Traditionally Leave Alone
abstract: Congress devised some positions to stay on during changes in administrations. But Donald Trump has declared his intent to replace at least three.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has moved to install loyalists in jobs that Congress did not intend for new presidents to replace at the start of their terms, eroding a traditional constraint on executive power even before he takes office.

headline: Indiana Man Sentenced to 130 Years for Killing 2 Teenage Girls
abstract: Richard Allen, of Delphi, Ind., received the maximum sentence, concluding a case that came to be known as the Delphi Murders. His lawyers plan to appeal.
lead_paragraph: An Indiana judge has sentenced a man to 130 years in prison for the killings of two teenage girls in 2017 that became known among true-crime followers as the Delphi Murders. It was the maximum sentence for the charges he faced.

headline: As RFK Jr. Pursues Bid for Health Secretary, Federal Authorities Begin Campaign for Childhood Vaccines
abstract: “Parents have heard so much misinformation,” Kaye Hayes, a federal infectious disease official, said in a statement announcing the campaign.  “Many of them are overwhelmed.”
lead_paragraph: The Health and Human Services Department began a campaign on Friday to support childhood vaccinations that federal health officials said was intended to “cut through the noise of misinformation.”

headline: Marisa Paredes, Acclaimed in Almodóvar Films, Is Dead at 78
abstract: An esteemed Spanish actress, she was best known for her work in Pedro Almodóvar’s movies like “All About My Mother.” But their relationship was stormy.
lead_paragraph: Marisa Paredes, an award-winning actress who was considered one of the great divas of Spanish film, gaining international acclaim for her work with the renowned director Pedro Almodóvar, died on Tuesday in Madrid. She was 78.

headline: The World Is Falling Apart. Should I Scrap My Plans to Have Kids?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on family planning in uncertain times.
lead_paragraph: I have a question about planning for the future in light of the recent presidential election and the prospect of potentially having a dictatorship in America. I’m a 33-year-old woman. For a long time I’ve wanted to start a family. I’m about to start investing substantial money into family planning. In view of climate change, overpopulation and now the result of the election, I’ve started to wonder if maybe it’s just not meant to be. There are so many wars going on, and with America turning isolationist, I fear for the world. It feels like everything is falling apart; there’s so much uncertainty, and it doesn’t feel safe anymore.

headline: The Fate of This Federal Program Helps Explain Trump’s Win
abstract: It was a cushion for workers hurt by free trade. Why did Congress let it lapse?
lead_paragraph: I thank Paul Gottlieb, an economics professor at Rutgers University, for inspiring today’s newsletter. He wrote to me recently to point out “one of the least-covered stories in economics during the Biden administration.” Namely, that “in mid-2022, the 50-year-old federal program known as Trade Adjustment Assistance was allowed to expire,” leaving it to hobble on until its funding runs out or Congress intervenes.

headline: Driver Rams Christmas Market in Germany, Killing at Least 2 in Suspected Attack
abstract: Video showed a car plowing into a large crowd in the city of Magdeburg. The driver, identified as a 50-year-old Saudi Arabian citizen who worked as a doctor, was arrested.
lead_paragraph: A driver plowed a vehicle into a Christmas market in the central German city of Magdeburg on Friday evening, killing an adult and a small child and injuring dozens of other people in what officials indicated was a targeted attack.

headline: OpenAI Unveils New A.I. That Can ‘Reason’ Through Math and Science Problems
abstract: The artificial intelligence start-up said the new system, OpenAI o3, outperformed leading A.I. technologies on tests that rate skills in math, science, coding and logic.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI on Friday unveiled a new artificial intelligence system, OpenAI o3, which is designed to “reason” through problems involving math, science and computer programming.

headline: The Best Friends They Left Behind
abstract: The beloved pets of some of the notable people we lost this year.
lead_paragraph: The beloved pets of some of the notable people we lost this year.

headline: 2024: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics.
abstract: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories published this year. All free to read for a limited time.
lead_paragraph: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories published this year. All free to read for a limited time.

headline: The Lives They Lived
abstract: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.
lead_paragraph: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.

headline: Key Ally Abandons Trudeau in Fresh Blow to His Government
abstract: The leader of the party that supported Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s Liberal Party vowed to bring down the government, saying Mr. Trudeau had failed Canada.
lead_paragraph: As Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada tried to reverse his plunging fortunes on Friday by rearranging his cabinet, a key political ally called Mr. Trudeau a failed leader and vowed to bring down his government.

headline: Gena Rowlands Refused to Play the Traditional Woman
abstract: She worried that marriage would ruin her acting career. Instead, it fueled one of the most dynamic partnerships in film history.
lead_paragraph: She worried that marriage would ruin her acting career. Instead, it fueled one of the most dynamic partnerships in film history.

headline: James Earl Jones Found His Voice Through Silence
abstract: After refusing to talk for most of his childhood, he discovered the power in performance.
lead_paragraph: After refusing to talk for most of his childhood, he discovered the power in performance.

headline: Jerry West Was the N.B.A.’s Tortured Genius
abstract: One of the world’s greatest basketball players, he thought of himself as a loser.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s greatest basketball players, he thought of himself as a loser.

headline: She Turned in Her ‘Star Trek’ License Plates, but the Tickets Kept Coming
abstract: Beda Koorey, 75, returned personalized plates inspired by the identifying tag on the U.S.S. Enterprise to New York State in 2020. She has since been inundated with tickets for others who used the same tag.
lead_paragraph: Beda Koorey, a retired legal secretary, returned her license plates stamped with “NCC 1701,” like the identifying tag of the U.S.S. Enterprise in the “Star Trek” series, to the Department of Motor Vehicles in New York in April 2020.

headline: Frankie Beverly Created America’s No. 1 Cookout Song
abstract: How the R&B hit ‘Before I Let Go’ became an enduring anthem.
lead_paragraph: How the R&B hit ‘Before I Let Go’ became an enduring anthem.

headline: See Which Government Workers Would be Impacted if a Spending Bill Doesn’t Pass
abstract: Some workers would be forced to report to work, while others would be furloughed.
lead_paragraph: A government shutdown would have significant consequences for more than two million federal employees. Some would be forced to report to work and the rest would be furloughed. None would be paid during the shutdown.

headline: Mary Weiss Influenced Musicians From the Ramones to Amy Winehouse
abstract: Her singing career began and ended before she turned 20.
lead_paragraph: Her singing career began and ended before she turned 20.

headline: Michaela DePrince Danced as if She Were Sprinkled With Pixie Dust
abstract: As a professional ballerina, she inhabited the world of fairy tales. It’s tempting to read her real life as one too.
lead_paragraph: As a professional ballerina, she inhabited the world of fairy tales. It’s tempting to read her real life as one too.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Dec. 21, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: When Willie Mays Was Banned From Baseball
abstract: The strange, sad period when the Hall of Famer was exiled from his sport.
lead_paragraph: The strange, sad period when the Hall of Famer was exiled from his sport.

headline: How Edward Stone Resolved NASA’s Scientific Turf Wars
abstract: To run a scientific expedition that travels billions of miles, it takes more than great engineers — it takes a great manager as well.
lead_paragraph: To run a scientific expedition that travels billions of miles, it takes more than great engineers — it takes a great manager as well.

headline: Paul Auster’s Life and Work Were Marked by Death
abstract: He knew that tragedy comes for us all.
lead_paragraph: He knew that tragedy comes for us all.

headline: Shelley Duvall Made Her Mark Well Before ‘The Shining’
abstract: She redefined how an actress was supposed to be — and then she left Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: She redefined how an actress was supposed to be — and then she left Hollywood.

headline: Eleanor Coppola’s Frustrated Ambitions
abstract: Her own filmmaking aspirations were thwarted by domestic life. Her daughter’s would not be.
lead_paragraph: Her own filmmaking aspirations were thwarted by domestic life. Her daughter’s would not be.

headline: Dr. Ruth and Phil Donahue Answered Life’s Big Questions
abstract: Together, they told us everything we wanted to know about sex.
lead_paragraph: Together, they told us everything we wanted to know about sex.

headline: The Rise and Fall of Ivan Boesky, Notorious Inside Trader
abstract: He was seen as greed incarnate — and never said otherwise.
lead_paragraph: He was seen as greed incarnate — and never said otherwise.

headline: Bob Newhart’s Comedy Left a Lot Unsaid
abstract: For him, comedy became a form of therapy.
lead_paragraph: For him, comedy became a form of therapy.

headline: Janice Burgess Combined High Culture With Childish Delight
abstract: In “The Backyardigans,” she created a world for kids as wildly sophisticated as her own.
lead_paragraph: In “The Backyardigans,” she created a world for kids as wildly sophisticated as her own.

headline: Peter Buxtun Refused to Give Up
abstract: For years, he tried to expose the Tuskegee syphilis study – but no one would listen.
lead_paragraph: For years, he tried to expose the Tuskegee syphilis study – but no one would listen.

headline: Hettie Jones Helped Kickstart New York’s Beat Scene
abstract: Despite her husband's betrayal, she recreated herself as the writer she always was.
lead_paragraph: Despite her husband's betrayal, she recreated herself as the writer she always was.

headline: Angela Bofill Sang What She Could Until the End
abstract: She was a musical virtuoso who never quite got her due.
lead_paragraph: She was a musical virtuoso who never quite got her due.

headline: Were Pete Rose’s Sins Ahead of His Time?
abstract: Banned from Major League Baseball, he turned his disgrace into a personal brand.
lead_paragraph: Banned from Major League Baseball, he turned his disgrace into a personal brand.

headline: How Wally Amos Lost It All — and Found Something New in the Wreckage
abstract: He made his cookies — and himself — “famous.”
lead_paragraph: He made his cookies — and himself — “famous.”

headline: Wafa Al-Udaini Captured the Experiences of Palestinians From Within
abstract: As a journalist, she was determined to tell a story of Gaza that was full of life.
lead_paragraph: As a journalist, she was determined to tell a story of Gaza that was full of life.

headline: The Orphaned Sea Otter Who Became a Foster Mom to 15 Pups
abstract: Despite never having had offspring of her own, she was an instinctive caregiver.
lead_paragraph: Despite never having had offspring of her own, she was an instinctive caregiver.

headline: Naomi Feil Developed a Radical Approach to Caring for Dementia Patients
abstract: She believed that people with dementia were desperate to connect.
lead_paragraph: She believed that people with dementia were desperate to connect.

headline: Police Respond to Vehicle Ramming Attack at German Christmas Market
abstract: Emergency responders attended to an incident at a Christmas market in Magdeburg, Germany, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Emergency responders attended to an incident at a Christmas market in Magdeburg, Germany, on Friday.

headline: Biden Withdraws Proposed Regulations on Student Loans and Trans Athletes
abstract: The decision to withdraw the regulations seemed to be an acknowledgment that they would go nowhere under the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday withdrew some of its main outstanding plans to enact significant federal student loan forgiveness and to set rules around the participation of transgender athletes on school sports teams.

headline: Why Luigi Mangione Faces 2 Murder Cases Tied to One Killing
abstract: Federal and state prosecutors will follow a delicate legal choreography after characterizing Mr. Mangione’s actions differently in the fatal shooting of Brian Thompson.
lead_paragraph: Federal and state prosecutors charged Luigi Mangione this week in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive in Manhattan, a two-pronged legal offensive that could complicate the high-profile case.

headline: The Trinidadian Christmas Staple Worth the Yearlong Wait
abstract: Chow chow, a bright and bracing pickled relish, is essential to the holiday table in Trinidad and Tobago — and the perfect accompaniment to ham.
lead_paragraph: Most condiments understand their role: uplift but never upstage. But in Trinidad and Tobago, the show can’t go on without chow chow, a citrine-colored, spice-laced and veggie-packed relish.

headline: The Other Game
abstract: At the DealBook Summit, seven sports stars and experts discussed how building a brand as an athlete has changed.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, athletes hoping to become superstars had to worry about doing one thing: dominate their sport, and it would attract brands bearing hugely lucrative sponsorship deals. That may have worked for Michael Jordan, but things have changed significantly since he retired in 2003.

headline: The 10 Architectural Sites You Should See in São Paulo
abstract: These buildings and places capture the city’s playful approach to concrete-and-asphalt Modernism.
lead_paragraph: Present-day São Paulo — a sprawl of concrete towers and asphalt laid like a quilt over Brazil’s interior hills — began to take shape at the end of the 19th century, growing alongside the coffee plantations that thrived in the region’s hinterlands. But it was over the course of the following century that its most influential architectural designs were constructed, dotting the city with some of the world’s most extraordinary Modernist buildings.

headline: A Shutdown’s Economic Toll: Less Spending, More Uncertainty
abstract: A short lapse in funding would probably do only modest damage. But it could send a troubling signal about government dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: A federal government shutdown probably wouldn’t be enough to derail the solid U.S. economy. But it could inject more uncertainty into an already murky economic outlook.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Weight Loss Drug to Treat Obstructive Sleep Apnea
abstract: Zepbound is the first prescription drug approved specifically to treat the common condition.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the weight loss drug Zepbound to treat obstructive sleep apnea. It is the first prescription medication approved to treat the common sleep disorder.

headline: Michael Brewer, Whose ‘One Toke’ Was a Big Hit, Is Dead at 80
abstract: The duo Brewer & Shipley reached the Top 10 in 1971 with “One Toke Over the Line,” a ditty about marijuana that ran afoul of Nixon-era censors.
lead_paragraph: Michael Brewer, half of the folk-rock duo Brewer & Shipley, who scored an unlikely Top 10 hit in 1971 with “One Toke Over the Line” — one of the most overt pop odes to marijuana of the hippie era and presumably the only one to be performed on the squeaky-clean “Lawrence Welk Show” — died on Tuesday at his home near Branson, Mo. He was 80.

headline: Biden Administration Weighs Putting Up Roadblocks to Trump’s Deportation Campaign
abstract: The administration may extend protections for hundreds of thousands of immigrants whose legal status is set to expire near the start of the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is considering extending protections for hundreds of thousands of immigrants whose status in the United States is set to expire in the first months of the Trump administration, according to U.S. officials and documents viewed by The New York Times.

headline: Cathy Cade, Groundbreaking Lesbian Photographer, Dies at 82
abstract: She became a photographer the same year she came out, chronicling the lives of women in same-sex relationships — something most people had never seen.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Cade, an activist and pioneering photographer who chronicled same-sex female relationships, producing a 1987 book that was hailed by feminists and gay-rights advocates as a classic, died on Nov. 16 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 82.

headline: Driver Plows a Car Into a Christmas Market in Germany
abstract: At least two people were killed and dozens were wounded after a car rammed into a Christmas market in the city of Magdeburg in central Germany on Friday evening.
lead_paragraph: At least two people were killed and dozens were wounded after a car rammed into a Christmas market in the city of Magdeburg in central Germany on Friday evening.

headline: Why Have So Many Canadians Turned on Justin Trudeau?
abstract: Allies and opponents alike are calling for him to resign as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is under intense pressure to step down after the abrupt and acrimonious resignation of a key deputy on Monday highlighted his deep unpopularity after nearly a decade in power.

headline: Jewish School in Toronto Is Targeted for a Third Time
abstract: Canadian ministers will convene a meeting with the police to discuss antisemitism, after attacks at Jewish establishments in Toronto and Montreal this week.
lead_paragraph: Gunshots struck a Jewish elementary school in Toronto on Friday for the third time in seven months, the latest in a series of antisemitic attacks that prompted officials to announce a new push to address Canada’s rising hate crimes.

headline: At Luigi Mangione’s Perp Walk, Mayor Eric Adams Appeared Stage Right
abstract: In widely seen images, Mayor Eric Adams was behind Mr. Mangione, a murder suspect, when he arrived in Manhattan. Some questioned the mayor’s motives.
lead_paragraph: As perp walks go, few have been more cinematic: Luigi Mangione, handcuffed and wearing an orange jumpsuit, surrounded by a phalanx of armed law enforcement officers as they led him off a helipad.

headline: G.O.P. Spending Hawks Defy Trump on the Debt Limit, Previewing More Clashes
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is known for his tight grip on members of his party, but the rare rejection of his demand to suspend the debt limit reflected a disconnect that could plague his policy agenda.
lead_paragraph: Something unusual happened this week after President-elect Donald J. Trump ordered House Republicans to back legislation raising the debt limit: Dozens refused.

headline: The Budget Fight and Trump’s Nihilistic Style
abstract: A surprise congressional standoff remind us that big, discordant changes could be coming.
lead_paragraph: In about a month, the inauguration will complete a loop: Donald Trump will become president again, eight years after the initial event.

headline: Missouri Governor Commutes Sentence of Detective Convicted in On-Duty Killing
abstract: Eric J. DeValkenaere was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Cameron Lamb. Calls for clemency angered many in Kansas City, Mo.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Parson of Missouri commuted the sentence on Friday of a former police detective who was convicted of manslaughter in a 2019 shooting, an extraordinary intervention in a rare case that sent a police officer to prison for an on-duty killing. The former detective, from the Kansas City, Mo., department, had been released from prison on parole by Friday evening, an official said.

headline: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing to Be Arraigned on State Charges Monday
abstract: Luigi Mangione faces terror and murder charges in New York court. A federal prosecution is proceeding in parallel.
lead_paragraph: The 26-year-old man charged in the predawn killing of a health insurance executive on a Manhattan sidewalk this month is scheduled to make his first appearance in New York State Supreme Court on Monday, prosecutors said.

headline: Troy Masters, Pioneering L.G.B.T.Q. Journalist, Dies at 63
abstract: He was at the helm of several influential publications, notably Gay City News in New York City and, since 2017, The Los Angeles Blade.
lead_paragraph: Troy Masters, a journalistic champion of L.G.B.T.Q. causes in publications that he founded, published or edited since the early 1990s, most recently The Los Angeles Blade, died on Dec. 11 in his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 63.

headline: How Many People Did Cyclone Chido Actually Kill on a French Island?
abstract: Officials have said that the death toll in Mayotte, currently at 35, could end up in the thousands. But in the capital, there were no scenes of public mourning and little talk of searches for missing loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a week after a devastating cyclone, most streets have reopened in Mayotte, a tiny French island off the east coast of Africa.

headline: The House Voted to Avert a Government Shutdown
abstract: Also, Canada’s leader suffered another setback. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The House approved legislation tonight to avert a government shutdown roughly six hours before it was set to begin. A majority of lawmakers in both parties voted to extend funding for the federal government into mid-March and approve disaster relief for parts of the nation still reeling from storms.

headline: Ann Rockefeller Roberts, Champion of Native Americans, Dies at 90
abstract: The eldest daughter of Nelson Rockefeller, she founded a nonprofit to support Indigenous culture and helped fill two institutions with artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Ann Rockefeller Roberts, a champion of the rights, welfare and culture of Native Americans and the eldest daughter of Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former vice president and governor of New York, died on Wednesday at her home in Bedford, N.Y. She was 90.

headline: U.S. Prisons Flout Law by Keeping Inmates Past Release Date, A.C.L.U. Says
abstract: Tens of thousands of prisoners deemed to be at low risk of committing crimes again have languished in lockup for as long as a year after they reached their release date under the First Step Act.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Crowe, a 50-year-old grandmother serving a long federal prison term on drug charges, eagerly enrolled in programs to cut her time behind bars — and was told she was eligible for release in May under a landmark sentencing reform law passed in 2018.

headline: In Late Push, Senate Democrats Narrowly Top Trump on Judicial Confirmations
abstract: With the vote, the Senate approved its 235th lifetime judge of President Biden’s tenure, besting his predecessor by a single judgeship.
lead_paragraph: The Senate confirmed on Friday the 235th lifetime federal judge nominated by President Biden, topping the four-year record set during the first Trump administration by a single judge in a drive that significantly reshaped the federal courts to be more ethnically and professionally diverse.

headline: White Judge Who Threatened to Shoot Black Teens at Party Resigns
abstract: Justice Erin P. Gall of Oneida County, N.Y., faced removal from office after a judicial commission found that she engaged in a “racially offensive, profane” tirade at a high school graduation party.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge who invoked her position and threatened to shoot Black teenagers at a party has resigned and dropped her monthslong fight to remain on the bench after a state commission recommended that she be forced to leave office.

headline: Congress Approves Spending Extension, Ending Shutdown Crisis
abstract: The Senate passed the measure and sent it to President Biden’s desk, shortly after the midnight deadline for funding to lapse.
lead_paragraph: The Senate approved a spending measure early Saturday to keep government money flowing through mid-March, sending it to President Biden for his signature and closing a chaotic endgame in Congress minutes after federal funding had lapsed.

headline: The Best Movies About Politics (According to You)
abstract: Tired of real politics? Try the silver screen instead.
lead_paragraph: As 2024 draws to a close, you might be tired of watching politicians act as if they are the stars of an epic film.
