headline: In Search of Loved Ones, Syrian Women Face Horror of Assad’s Regime
abstract: In Syria, women begin to pick up the pieces of a broken nation.

headline: Guatemalan Officials Raid Compound of Jewish Sect and Remove Dozens of Minors
abstract: The authorities said at least 160 children and teenagers might have been the victims of human trafficking and other crimes on a farm run by Lev Tahor, an ultra-Orthodox sect.
lead_paragraph: Guatemalan officials raided a compound on Friday belonging to Lev Tahor, an ultra-Orthodox Jewish sect with past links to child exploitation. Prosecutors said they had removed at least 160 children and teenagers from the site who they believed were the victims of human trafficking and other offenses.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 21, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Elon Musk leading the charge to kill a bipartisan spending deal misspelled the surname of the representative from Georgia who wrote a social media post referring to Elon Musk. She is Marjorie Taylor Greene, not Green.

headline: It’s a Little Shady
abstract: Barbara Lin and Lewis Rothlein’s puzzle packs the right amount of punch.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is not an easy crossword, but it’s certainly a friendly one. The humor is kindhearted, and the trivia is pleasantly nostalgic. It’s the first collaboration between Barbara Lin and Lewis Rothlein, two terrific constructors. They’re both crafty and clever, and they harmonize beautifully.

headline: Chicago Board of Education Votes to Fire Leader of City’s School System
abstract: The job status of Pedro Martinez, the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools, had been in doubt for months amid tension with Mayor Brandon Johnson.
lead_paragraph: After months of political turmoil, the Chicago Board of Education voted unanimously to fire the chief executive of the city’s public school system on Friday night. The move to oust the executive, Pedro Martinez, represented a show of force for the Chicago Teachers Union and for Mayor Brandon Johnson, a close ally and former employee of the union.

headline: Google Proposes Fix to Solve Search Monopoly
abstract: The search giant’s proposals included allowing flexibility for companies and consumers in choosing a search engine.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Friday what it thought should change to address a ruling that it had illegally maintained a monopoly over online search: not much.

headline: What’s Next for Google’s Search Monopoly
abstract: The federal judge who ruled Google was a monopolist in search is weighing his options to fix the monopoly. Here’s what happens now.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Friday that a federal judge needed to do very little to fix its search monopoly.

headline: Houthi Missile Strikes Tel Aviv as Attacks Increase
abstract: The Israeli military said several people were lightly injured after its air defenses failed to intercept the projectile, which struck a playground in the city.
lead_paragraph: Iranian-backed Houthi militants launched a missile from Yemen that landed in Tel Aviv early Saturday morning after air defenses failed to intercept it, the latest in an increasing barrage of Houthi attacks.

headline: Quote of the Day: When Your $3 Million Cello Is Bumped From Your Flight
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 21, 2024
lead_paragraph: “We guard it like one of our kids. And we spend time with the cello more than with our wives and kids.”

headline: The Winter Solstice Is Upon Us. Here Comes the Sun Bread.
abstract: A joyful baked creation, taken from a children’s book, celebrates the return of longer days.
lead_paragraph: When my oldest daughter started kindergarten, I signed up to be a classroom parent. The school was small, public and in ethnically diverse Jersey City, which meant my daughter shared crayons with kids whose families came from all over the world. When it came time to plan the holiday party, the principal requested that it celebrate the season, but without any specific religious or cultural overtones. No Santa. No menorahs. Just joy.

headline: Terrorism Roars Back in Pakistan, 10 Years After a Campaign to End It
abstract: Political instability, dwindling public support and economic constraints are eroding the costly gains that the country made in combating militancy after a school attack in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Ten years have passed since Ajoon Khan’s son died in a ghastly attack by the Pakistani Taliban that killed about 150 people, mostly children, at a military-run school in Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan.

headline: For Syria’s Economy, the Way Forward Starts With Sanctions Relief
abstract: Years of strife ruined the energy sector, battered the currency and strangled growth. The West must ease financial controls to help the economy, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Although the collapse of President Bashar al-Assad’s government in Syria was shockingly quick, rebuilding the devastated economy he left behind will be painfully slow.

headline: Congress Approves Full Social Security Benefits for Public Sector Retirees
abstract: The popular measure gives full benefits to millions of people who currently receive them at a reduced level. Critics warn the $196 billion cost will speed up the program’s insolvency.
lead_paragraph: The Senate passed bipartisan legislation early Saturday that would give full Social Security benefits to a group of public sector retirees who currently receive them at a reduced level, sending the bill to President Biden.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: How the Founder of a Fruit Jelly Snack Company Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Sophia Cheng, the founder of Oddball, takes a snack tour around the city, breaks for tennis and wards off the Sunday scaries with Channing Tatum.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Hong Kong and Singapore, Sophia Cheng delighted in snacks from across Asia, which were often made with ingredients like seaweed and dried seafood.

headline: New York Is Putting Trash in Bins. Some People Have a Problem With That.
abstract: Citywide rules now require more buildings to place trash bags inside containers for pickup. Many New Yorkers are thrilled to see fewer rats, but some are discovering new headaches.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers played central roles in developing such technological innovations as air-conditioning, toilet paper and the atomic bomb.

headline: 3-Minute Christmas Market Rampage Shakes Germany
abstract: At least five people, including a 9-year-old child, were killed in the attack, which took place in the eastern city of Magdeburg. The authorities are still seeking a motive.
lead_paragraph: It took an attacker just three minutes to kill five people and wound hundreds by ramming an S.U.V. into a crowded holiday market on Friday night, stunning Germany and shattering the peace of its Christmas season.

headline: Audiobooks to Cook (or Eat) To, From Ina Garten to David Chang
abstract: These culinary coming-of-age tales are movable feasts for the gluttonous listener.
lead_paragraph: Take it from me: You don’t have to be a capable cook to appreciate stories about food. Nor do you need to hang around a hot stove or hold a physical book in your hands. I’ve recently discovered the pleasure — and the comfort — of strolling to the sound of cooking memoirs. Here are my favorites, read with honesty and gusto.

headline: How to (Gently) Set Boundaries During the Holidays
abstract: Experts share tips for minimizing irritation and avoiding intrusive questions.
lead_paragraph: Every Christmas, Gabriel Ronquillo dreads the inevitable questions from well-meaning relatives about when he’s getting married or having children.

headline: He’s the Only 3-Michelin-Starred Chef in Seoul. Don’t Cross Him.
abstract: Anh Sung-jae went to America as a 13-year-old, joined the Army, went to culinary school and opened a top restaurant in San Francisco. Now back home in South Korea, he’s a Netflix star.
lead_paragraph: On an early episode of Netflix’s hit cooking show “Culinary Class Wars,” the chef Anh Sung-jae stood in a warehouse filled with makeshift cooking stations and considered the plate in front of him: a rainbow palette of handmade pastas, purées and delicately cooked seafood. On top was a smattering of flower petals.

headline: What Do We Want From the Mall?
abstract: Decades after mega retail centers became a shorthand for bland suburbia, there may be some hope for them yet.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a retail mirage of sorts appeared just off the Hempstead Turnpike on the Queens-Long Island border, next to the Belmont horse racetrack and the UBS arena, home of the New York Islanders hockey team and the occasional Harry Styles concert.

headline: Googie, a Futuristic Style of Architecture, Is Endangered
abstract: Googie architecture is a midcentury design style characterized by dramatic rooflines, pops of color, large glass windows and flashy signs. Anna Kodé, a reporter covering design and culture for the Real Estate section of The New York Times, describes the efforts by preservationists to save examples of the distinctive style.
lead_paragraph: Googie architecture is a midcentury design style characterized by dramatic rooflines, pops of color, large glass windows and flashy signs. Anna Kodé, a reporter covering design and culture for the Real Estate section of The New York Times, describes the efforts by preservationists to save examples of the distinctive style.

headline: Band-Aid Over a Bullet Wound
abstract: Getting shot, and trying to keep it a secret.
lead_paragraph: It felt as if someone were pressing a lit cigarette to my thigh. I knew that burn, thanks to my father’s drunken humor, but this was worse. I’d been shot.

headline: The Fight to Save Googie, the Style of Postwar Optimism
abstract: The car-centric architectural style, characterized by neon signs and dramatic rooflines, is now endangered. Its admirers mourn the loss of the ideals it represented.
lead_paragraph: In June, the Arby’s on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles shut down. The news, announced on the restaurant’s marquee — “FAREWELL HOLLYWOOD TY FOR 55 GREAT YEARS” — didn’t seem surprising, with rents and labor costs on the rise. What was out of the ordinary was the public’s response to it.

headline: After the Wedding Day, These Artifacts Remain
abstract: We recently asked readers to tell us about the one saved item from their wedding day, or the time leading up to it, that they still cherished today. Here are 10 sentimental stories.
lead_paragraph: Wedding keepsakes can help preserve happy memories for a couple. They are infused with celebration, nostalgia, and, of course, love. But occasionally, one item can take center stage and, like a relationship, endures the test of time and grows in sentimental value. Some couples refer to these treasures as wedding artifacts.

headline: How Will Ukraine Keep the Lights on This Winter?
abstract: The Ukrainian energy network has been so battered by Russian attacks that officials are seeking out new options to prevent a crisis, like renting floating power plants and scavenging scrapped ones from the region.
lead_paragraph: With Russia intensifying airstrikes on Ukraine’s power grid over the past month, darkness once again engulfs Ukrainian cities at night. In Kyiv, residents rely on cellphone flashlights to navigate unlit streets. To walk their dogs, they use glow sticks doubling as makeshift collars.

headline: The Black Blackface Performer Who History Tries to Forget
abstract: Bert Williams, the first modern Black entertainment star, was born 150 years ago. The contradictions at the heart of his career are still relevant today.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1890s a Black Bahamian immigrant named Bert Williams stepped on a California stage for the first time. He wore white gloves, a kinky-haired wig on his head and had burnt cork smeared on his face. This was his first show as part of a group called the Mastodon Minstrels, and it was his first time in blackface. Once onstage the usually charismatic Williams froze; he couldn’t remember his lines. He finally blurted out, “If I says anything, those folks’ll laugh at me” before running offstage, according to his biographer, Camille F. Forbes. The audience, thinking it was part of the show, responded with uproarious cheering. Williams was appalled; he swore off wearing blackface.

headline: Death on the Night Shift at Frozen Pizza Factories in Chicago
abstract: Undocumented workers help feed America’s hunger for prepared foods, but some take jobs with staffing agencies that expose them to hazardous conditions.
lead_paragraph: On a brilliant day three years ago, a grieving crowd gathered on the South Side of Chicago to bury Adewale Ezekiel Ogunyemi.

headline: Kyle Mooney on Divorced-Dad Music
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” alum and director of the new horror-comedy movie “Y2K” talks yacht rock, Cheez-Its and “cat” videos.
lead_paragraph: For years, Kyle Mooney has had a low-key fixation on Y2K because as a 15-year-old he found it such a letdown.

headline: Christmas vs. First Night of Hanukkah: What’s an Interfaith Family to Do?
abstract: The two holidays will converge for the first time since 2005. For some, celebrating both means “the best blend of the two.”
lead_paragraph: The Dec. 25 menu is set for Denise Handlarski’s family: Turkey because it’s Christmas. Latkes because it’s Hanukkah.

headline: A Restaurant Is More Than a Workplace for People Often Shunned by Employers
abstract: A popular restaurant in Buenos Aires is staffed almost entirely by workers with neurological challenges, tapping into often-overlooked talent and harnessing their skills.
lead_paragraph: Nacho Fernández Suárez winces when he recalls the eight years he spent as an administrative assistant doing odd errands in Argentina’s Congress. He was part of an inclusion program for people with disabilities.

headline: Is ‘People Pleasing’ Giving You Money Problems? Here’s How to Fix Things.
abstract: Spending money to avoid conflict or gain social acceptance can ruin your finances. Some self-reflection and support from professionals can help turn things around.
lead_paragraph: Hailey Magee often paid for drinks when she went out with friends, bought loved ones expensive dinners and picked up the tab on dates. During the holiday season, Ms. Magee purchased lavish gifts, even when she was on a tight budget.

headline: The Gym in My Apartment Building Is SO LOUD! What Can I Do?
abstract: It’s possible that a gym isn’t even allowed in your building. If it is, it cannot violate the noise code, the warranty of habitability or the lease.
lead_paragraph: Q: I recently moved into an 11th-floor apartment on the Upper East Side. When I was shown the apartment, I wasn’t told that it was directly below the building’s gym, which is open to tenants 24 hours a day. The sound of heavy weights slamming into the ground shakes my apartment. This noise occurs overnight and in the early morning, preventing me from sleeping. There are two other available apartments with the same rent, but management is refusing to let me move. I have asked them to limit the gym hours, but the only response is a suggestion that I soundproof my ceiling. What can I do?

headline: For Pedro Almodóvar’s Movies, the Poster Tells Its Own Story
abstract: The filmmaker has long collaborated with the graphic designer Juan Gatti to make alluring posters for his films, including one for his latest, “The Room Next Door.”
lead_paragraph: Few filmmakers have as distinctive a visual style as the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar. The palette for his work often includes ravaging reds, piquant pinks and bruising blues. And over four decades, Almodóvar’s aesthetic has reached far beyond the silver screen. Posters for his films adorn everything from T-shirts and tote bags to postcards and pins.

headline: The Best Holiday Brunches Start With This Supermarket Ingredient
abstract: Turn store-bought croissants into so much more with these effortless recipes for a crowd.
lead_paragraph: Amid all of the activity on Christmas morning — hosting family, prepping dinner, sharing gifts, tidying up and being present enough to truly experience the moment — it can be challenging to pick a dish that strikes the sweet spot between effortless and impressive, one that adds joy (but not stress) to the occasion.

headline: What Is It About the Doechii Aesthetic?
abstract: Intentionally visible face tape, braids as scalp-to-scalp tethers: Recent looks by the Grammy-nominated rapper have inspired fascination and at least one nail-art tribute.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long after Natasha Shrestha, a seventh-grade history teacher in New York City, saw the cover for Doechii’s latest mixtape that she decided to claim a piece of the Florida rapper’s aesthetic for herself.

headline: From Liberal Icon to MAGA Joke: The Waning Fortunes of Justin Trudeau
abstract: Canada’s prime minister gained global renown 10 years ago for his unabashedly progressive politics. But at home, voters turned sour on him long ago.
lead_paragraph: Justin Trudeau’s career is the stuff of 21st-century political drama, with an arc that has taken him from glamorous liberal standard-bearer to the butt of jokes by President-elect Donald J. Trump and his acolytes.

headline: Hitting Home for the Holidays: A Jump in Egg Prices
abstract: Costs have soared again amid a bird flu outbreak, bringing renewed attention to the fact that while inflation is cooling, prices are still elevated.
lead_paragraph: Americans stocking up on holiday cooking essentials may be greeted with an unwelcome surprise in the grocery aisles: higher prices for eggs, spurred by an intensifying bird flu outbreak.

headline: In ‘Mrs. Stern’ and ‘Racecar,’ Humans Keep Repeating Their Worst Mistakes
abstract: Pernicious patterns figure heavily in two thought-provoking plays on small Manhattan stages.
lead_paragraph: Inside the jail cell, the police officer is registering his freshly arrested prisoner — a young Jewish woman suspected of political criminality. It is 1933 in Berlin, where determining who belongs and who doesn’t is of paramount concern to the government. So he inquires about her birthplace (Germany) and her parents’ (same). And her parents’ parents’.

headline: Jonathan Roumie Plays Jesus to Millions. It Can Get Intense.
abstract: The star of “The Chosen” discusses his early struggles in Hollywood, fans who conflate him with his character and how his own faith informs his work.
lead_paragraph: The star of “The Chosen” discusses his early struggles in Hollywood, fans who conflate him with his character and how his own faith informs his work.

headline: Jonathan Roumie Plays Jesus to Millions. It Can Get Intense.
abstract: The star of “The Chosen” discusses his early struggles in Hollywood, fans who conflate him with his character and how his own faith informs his work.
lead_paragraph: It’s common, maybe even natural, for audiences to conflate actors with the roles they play. To assume, for example, that an onscreen action hero is tough offscreen too, or that a rom-com star is a real-life charmer. That blurring of lines is probably a sign that an actor is doing something right, but it doesn’t make the dynamic any less strange or confusing. Especially if the character you’re famous for playing is Jesus Christ.

headline: André 3000 Performs Surprise Concert in The NY Times Newsroom
abstract: André 3000 and the band behind “New Blue Sun” — featuring Surya Botofasina, Nate Mercereau, Carlos Niño and Deantoni Parks — perform in The Times’ newsroom.
lead_paragraph: André 3000 and the band behind “New Blue Sun” — featuring Surya Botofasina, Nate Mercereau, Carlos Niño and Deantoni Parks — perform in The Times’ newsroom.

headline: After This Interview, André 3000 Performed in Our Newsroom
abstract: The rapper-turned-flutist improvised in the middle of The Times’s office following a wide-ranging conversation on Popcast.
lead_paragraph: Two decades after André 3000, as one half of the rap duo Outkast, won the Grammy Award for album of the year for “Speakerboxxx/The Love Below,” he is again nominated in that category on quite different terms. At the show in February, he’s up as a solo artist, for “New Blue Sun,” an album of improvised music on which he plays a variety of wind instruments and speaks no words. It’s a sonic pivot, but maybe not a philosophical one for a musician who has rewritten his creative approach several times over a 30-year career.

headline: André 3000 Performs in the New York Times Newsroom
abstract: After an interview on The Times’s Popcast podcast, André 3000 and the band behind “New Blue Sun” — featuring Surya Botofasina, Nate Mercereau, Carlos Niño and Deantoni Parks — performed an improvised piece in the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: After an interview on The Times’s Popcast podcast, André 3000 and the band behind “New Blue Sun” — featuring Surya Botofasina, Nate Mercereau, Carlos Niño and Deantoni Parks — performed an improvised piece in the newsroom.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,282
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 560
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: In Top Minister’s Resignation, Shades of an Earlier Political Crisis for Trudeau
abstract: Chrystia Freeland’s departure this week recalls the 2019 SNC-Lavalin affair, in which Jody Wilson-Raybould quit Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s cabinet after a demotion.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, I was on my way out to hole up with other reporters to take an advance look at the government’s fall economic statement, mostly to see what it said about border security. Then Chrystia Freeland put out her resignation letter.

headline: Your Favorite Things
abstract: Today, your highly personal, hyperspecific best-ofs of 2024.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year when things wind down, when people start putting things off until after the holidays, until January, until next year. I find this comforting, like 2024 is full, we’re buttoning it up and packing it away. We couldn’t possibly squeeze in another project or plan. I’ve lost count of the number of conversations and lunch dates and meetings I’ve committed to “when we’re all back.” Can January even contain all the planning we’ve flung in its direction?

headline: For Some, a Silver Lining in Alzheimer’s Caregiving
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay by a woman who finds things to cherish in caring for her dad.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why I Would Never Donate Sperm in the United States
abstract: Children deserve better than to feel left in the dark against their will.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, after thorough deliberation, I made the most meaningful decision of my adult life to become a dad. And, while joyously successful — I now have three sons and two daughters — I’ve never met them. That’s because I donated sperm to a fertility clinic in New South Wales, Australia, where I live. At this stage, a better word for me is “donor.”

headline: A Conversation About the Virgin Birth That Maybe Wasn’t
abstract: The scholar Elaine Pagels discusses her research about ancient accounts suggesting that Jesus’ father might have been a Roman.
lead_paragraph: This is the latest in my occasional series of conversations about Christianity, aimed at bridging America’s God gulf. Previously, I’ve spoken with the Rev. Timothy Keller, President Jimmy Carter, the evangelical writer Beth Moore and others. Here I speak with Elaine Pagels, a prominent professor of religion at Princeton University and an expert on the early church. Our conversation has been edited for clarity and length.

headline: Hollywood Is Desperate for Movie Stars. This Year, the Cavalry Arrived.
abstract: For decades, the film industry seemed to forget how to mint new male matinee idols. Then came a much-needed windfall.
lead_paragraph: As you may have heard, Hollywood has hit a rough patch. The box office has been wobbly, A.I. is looming and this year’s biggest live-action hit, “Deadpool and Wolverine,” is a Marvel movie that cracks jokes about how lousy Marvel movies are these days.

headline: Religion Has Been in Decline. This Christmas Seems Different.
abstract: Why religious trends in the later 2020s might be different from the trends of the 2010s.
lead_paragraph: In March, I drove with my family up from Rome into the mountains of southeastern Umbria, to reach the town of Norcia and the monastery — now an abbey; it’s been promoted since our visit — of St. Benedict on the Mountain, a community of Benedictine monks perched above a wide valley that was then just greening with the spring.

headline: Justice Thomas Did Not Disclose Additional Trips, Democrats Say
abstract: The revelation was included in a report by Democratic staff members on the Senate Judiciary Committee who had conducted a 20-month investigation into ethics practices at the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas failed to disclose two additional trips from a billionaire patron that had not previously come to light, Senate Democrats revealed on Saturday after conducting a 20-month investigation into ethics practices at the Supreme Court.

headline: Heroes in Their Twilight Years, and Still in the Spotlight
abstract: Dear readers,
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: From Inflation to Bitcoin, 9 Charts That Explain 2024
abstract: Rate cuts, stock surges, and Trump’s tariff threats are among the biggest forces shaping business and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Despite a tumultuous U.S. presidential campaign and intensifying global conflicts, the economy is poised to end 2024 in a stable position. Inflation has come down substantially and economic growth remains relatively robust, particularly for the United States. But the outlook for 2025 remains murky, as President-elect Donald Trump’s policy changes could affect the economy in unpredictable ways.

headline: As Drugstores Close, Older People Are Left in ‘Pharmacy Deserts’
abstract: Shuttered drugstores pose a particular threat to older adults, who take more medications than younger people and often rely on pharmacies for advice.
lead_paragraph: In July, a notice appeared on the front door of The Drug Store, the only pharmacy in rural Kernville, Calif. After 45 years, the proprietor wrote regretfully, it would be closing in four days and transferring customers’ prescriptions to a Rite Aid about 12 miles away.

headline: Pope Francis’ Christmas Message to His Top Advisers: Don’t Gossip
abstract: Francis urged the Vatican inner circle to bless more and talk less badly of others. It wasn’t the first time he had used the occasion to scold them.
lead_paragraph: At end-of-year celebrations, some bosses give their employees gifts of appreciation and extend warm wishes. On Saturday, Pope Francis used his annual Christmas message to the leaders of the Vatican’s various departments to admonish them.

headline: Top Uniformed N.Y.P.D. Officer Resigns After Abuse Allegations
abstract: Jeffrey Maddrey demanded sexual favors, according to subordinates, and the federal authorities are investigating. He had previously been accused of harassment on the job.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s top uniformed police officer, the chief of department, abruptly resigned Friday night following allegations of sexual misconduct, setting off local and federal investigations and extending years of turmoil at the Police Department.

headline: ‘We Can Bury Anyone’: Inside a Hollywood Smear Machine
abstract: Private messages detail an alleged campaign to tarnish Blake Lively after she accused Justin Baldoni of misconduct on the set of “It Ends With Us.”
lead_paragraph: Last summer, as the release of “It Ends With Us” approached, Justin Baldoni, the director and a star of the film, and Jamey Heath, the lead producer, hired a crisis public relations expert.

headline: Read the Statement
abstract: Statement to The New York Times from Bryan Freedman, attorney for Justin Baldoni, Wayfarer Studios and all its representatives.
lead_paragraph: Statement to The New York Times from Bryan Freedman, attorney for Justin Baldoni, Wayfarer Studios and all its representatives.

headline: Read the Complaint
abstract: Blake Lively v. Wayfarer Studios LLC et al
lead_paragraph: Blake Lively v. Wayfarer Studios LLC et al

headline: Get Ready for Oohs and Aahs
abstract: Clare de Boer’s rice and squash bombe makes a glorious vegetarian centerpiece or a show-stealing side for a roast or braise.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been to Stissing House, Clare de Boer’s restaurant in Pine Plains, N.Y., but reading her recipes makes the FOMO feverishly real. The holiday menu she created for New York Times Cooking reads like some sort of Christmas poem: spiced orange duck with ginger, thyme and anise. Leafy winter salad with a honeyed vinaigrette. And — be still, my fluttering, rice-loving heart — this rice and squash bombe encased in crisp pita and pebbly pine nuts.

headline: Party City to Close All Stores by February, Company Says
abstract: In an internal letter, the company said inflation and changes in consumer spending had forced it to shut its more than 700 stores.
lead_paragraph: Party City, the party supply store that has provided the glittering backdrops for generations of birthday celebrations, New Year’s Eve bashes and Super Bowl gatherings, announced just days before Christmas that it was closing its doors for good.

headline: Amazon Warehouse Workers in New York City Join Protest
abstract: The workers’ union hopes that adding employees at the Staten Island warehouse to a protest started by delivery drivers will increase pressure on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Signaling an escalation in a labor campaign that began at seven Amazon delivery hubs on Thursday, workers at the company’s largest Staten Island warehouse began a protest there at midnight on Saturday.

headline: Biden Signs Spending Bill, Finalizing End to Shutdown Drama
abstract: President Biden’s signature, while technically coming after the midnight deadline for a shutdown, ensured that there would be no lapse in government funding.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Saturday signed the spending package that allowed federal funds to keep flowing until mid-March, formally ending the week’s unexpected drama over the issue a few hours after the deadline for a shutdown had technically passed.

headline: Donald Trump Is Vulnerable
abstract: His win did not upend the rules of American politics or render him immune to political misfortune.
lead_paragraph: The recurring theme of my writing the past few weeks is that Donald Trump is not invulnerable. His win did not upend the rules of American politics or render him immune to political misfortune. Like everything we experience, his victory was contingent — a function of specific people in specific circumstances making specific choices. To change any of these variables is to change the ultimate destination.

headline: The Waging of an Alleged Smear Campaign Against Blake Lively
abstract: The movie “It Ends With Us” starring Blake Lively was a huge box office hit, even as rumors spread of turmoil behind the scenes. Private messages detail a campaign to tarnish Lively after she accused Justin Baldoni of misconduct on set. Megan Twohey, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: The movie “It Ends With Us” starring Blake Lively was a huge box office hit, even as rumors spread of turmoil behind the scenes. Private messages detail a campaign to tarnish Lively after she accused Justin Baldoni of misconduct on set. Megan Twohey, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.

headline: Germany Bulked Up Christmas Market Security. An Attack Still Happened.
abstract: The latest deadly assault on a beloved German tradition illustrates the challenge of holiday safety.
lead_paragraph: For years, Germany has been strengthening security measures around Christmas markets in reaction to an attack in 2016 in which a man killed 12 people by driving a truck into a market in central Berlin.

headline: Deception and Betrayal: Inside the Final Days of the Assad Regime
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad, who wielded fear and force over Syria for more than two decades, fled the country under the cover of night — and a fake political address.
lead_paragraph: As rebels advanced toward the Syrian capital of Damascus on Dec. 7, the staff in the hilltop Presidential Palace prepared for a speech they hoped would lead to a peaceful end to the 13-year civil war.

headline: Homeless Woman Going Into Labor Is Cited for Violating Camping Ban
abstract: Body-camera footage shows an officer from the Louisville Metro Police Department in Kentucky detain the woman, who gave birth later that day.
lead_paragraph: A homeless woman said that she was going into labor in Louisville, Ky., when a police officer gave her a citation under a law that bans unauthorized public camping, according to her lawyer and body-camera footage released on Thursday.

headline: Iran’s Energy Crisis Hits ‘Dire’ Point as Industries Are Forced to Shut Down
abstract: Although Iran has one of the biggest supplies of natural gas and crude oil in the world, it finds itself in a full blown energy emergency, coming just as it also suffers major geopolitical setbacks.
lead_paragraph: Government offices in Iran are closed or operating at reduced hours. Schools and colleges have moved to online only. Highways and shopping malls have descended into darkness, and industrial plants have been denied power, bringing manufacturing to a near halt.

headline: Rickey Henderson, Baseball’s Flamboyant ‘Man of Steal,’ Dies at 65
abstract: Widely regarded as the greatest leadoff hitter in baseball history, he was not just one of the game’s most exciting players but also one of its most eccentric.
lead_paragraph: Rickey Henderson, the thrilling and charismatic Hall of Fame outfielder who, with his signature crouched stance, blazing speed and unlikely home run power, was widely regarded as the greatest leadoff hitter in Major League Baseball history, died on Friday. He was 65.

headline: Lee Edwards, Historian of the Conservative Movement, Dies at 92
abstract: In his books about Ronald Reagan, Barry Goldwater and other figures on the right, he was, one observer said, “a keeper of the flame and spreader of the gospel.”
lead_paragraph: Lee Edwards, a self-described “cradle conservative” who participated in key moments in the modern conservative movement and then became its all but official historian, writing flattering books about the Heritage Foundation, Ronald Reagan, William F. Buckley Jr. and other subjects, died on Dec. 12 at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 92.

headline: ‘A Gift to Everyone’: A Wisconsin Community Mourns a School Shooting Victim
abstract: Rubi Patricia Vergara was one of two victims killed in Madison this past week. At a memorial service, she was remembered as an empathetic teenager with a passion for music and art.
lead_paragraph: Just this past week, Rubi Patricia Vergara was at a craft fair with her family to support her best friend, who was selling handmade necklaces and keychains. Rubi, who loved arts and crafts, bought the most expensive item, and then skipped around the fair with her friend, Josie Hughes. At the end of the day, the two girls hugged goodbye, saying they would see each other soon.

headline: Go With the Flow
abstract: Adrian Johnson brings his themeless acumen to a larger arena.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — In his print introduction to this grid, Joel Fagliano writes: “Adrian Johnson, from Laramie, Wyo., is currently a substitute teacher in Knox County, Tenn., where he is affectionately known as ‘Mr. A.J.’ He sold his first crossword to The Times three years ago, when he was 21. This is his ninth puzzle for the paper — and the seventh one that is unthemed (his favorite type of crossword to make). Puzzles like this are built on the interlock of long, colorful answers throughout the grid. Many, like 1-, 27-, and 97-Across, are making their Times debut.”

headline: Atmospheric Rivers Will Drench the West Coast
abstract: A parade of storms is expected to heighten the flood risk in the Pacific Northwest and Northern California over the next week.
lead_paragraph: The Pacific Northwest and Northern California, especially Washington and Oregon, have had an onslaught of storms and the run of them is expected to continue over the next week.

headline: Dropped From Spending Bill, Cancer Research and D.C. Stadium Measures Revived by Senate
abstract: Two bills on pediatric cancer research and a football stadium site had been left out of the main spending package, but passed early Saturday as separate legislation.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous few days, President Biden on Saturday signed into law a spending bill that had been heavily trimmed down to 120 pages from 1,547. It had lost provisions targeting hidden fees on concert tickets and criminalizing the publication of some deepfake pornography.

headline: Germany Mourns After Christmas Market Attack
abstract: Germans visited a memorial in Magdeburg, Germany, for the at least five people killed and more than 200 injured at a Christmas market, after an attacker drove a vehicle into a crowd.
lead_paragraph: Germans visited a memorial in Magdeburg, Germany, for the at least five people killed and more than 200 injured at a Christmas market, after an attacker drove a vehicle into a crowd.

headline: Congress Approves Spending Package After Political Drama
abstract: President Biden signed the spending bill early on Saturday, ensuring that there would be no lapse in government funding.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed the spending bill early on Saturday, ensuring that there would be no lapse in government funding.

headline: University of California Resolves Civil Rights Complaints Over Gaza Protests
abstract: Five schools agreed to changes after reports that they failed to protect students from antisemitism and anti-Arab and anti-Muslim discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The University of California has resolved federal civil rights complaints from students who cited antisemitism and anti-Arab and anti-Muslim discrimination at U.C.L.A. and four other campuses following protests over the Israel-Hamas war, the Education Department announced Friday.

headline: Trump Appoints ‘The Apprentice’ Producer as Special Envoy to Britain
abstract: Mark Burnett and President-elect Donald J. Trump had a long and successful collaboration that made Mr. Trump a household name.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has tapped Mark Burnett, the producer who helped turn him into a household name with “The Apprentice,” as special envoy to Britain.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Man Who Drove Pickup Into Texas Mall, Injuring 5
abstract: The police said the man was being investigated for possible drunken driving but instead of stopping, he smashed his pickup truck into a J.C. Penney.
lead_paragraph: Five people were injured on Saturday after a man drove his pickup truck through the glass doors of a J.C. Penney in a mall in Killeen, Texas, and continued to drive through the building before he was shot and killed by the police, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 22, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on page 7 about “S.N.L.’s” internet culture misstates the year “Lazy Sunday” was created. It was 2005, not 2008.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Traditions Overlap as Christmas Meets Hanukkah
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Previously I thought Hanukkah couldn’t hold a candle to Christmas. Now I see, in the fullness of time, that it’s not a competition. It’s making room in your heart for all good things.”

headline: The Art of the Gift: Jenny Lewis
abstract: The Rilo Kiley and Postal Service singer says that her “philosophy in life is ‘one up from the cheapest.’”
lead_paragraph: A former child actress (“Troop Beverly Hills,” “The Wizard”), Jenny Lewis, 48, has spent more than two decades traveling the world as a member of the indie-pop bands Rilo Kiley and The Postal Service, the latter of which recently wrapped a two-year reunion tour. Her fifth solo album, “Joy’All,” was released in 2023. She lives in Los Angeles. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

headline: After Military Took Power, Terrorist Attacks Only Got Worse
abstract: In the West African nation of Niger, killings by insurgents have surged since the military seized power in a coup, expelled U.S. and European troops and stopped negotiations with Islamist groups.
lead_paragraph: Attacks that killed dozens of civilians and soldiers in Niger this month have put a spotlight on the military’s failure to restore security in the West African nation, nearly 18 months after staging a coup.

headline: A Cultural Casualty of the War in Ukraine: ‘The Nutcracker’
abstract: Lithuania’s national opera house had stopped showing Tchaikovsky’s 1892 masterpiece in solidarity with Ukraine over the war with Russia. Then a new minister expressed fondness for the Russian composer, igniting a furor.
lead_paragraph: Unimpressed by the substitute for Tchaikovsky’s “Nutcracker,” the mother and her young daughter left at the intermission, a small protest over a decision by the opera house not to perform the Russian composer’s Christmas classic.

headline: Memes, Jokes and Cats: South Koreans Use Parody for Political Protest
abstract: As South Koreans took to the streets this month demanding the ousting of their president, some found an unexpected outlet to express their fury.
lead_paragraph: As South Koreans took to the streets this month demanding the ousting of their president, some found an unexpected outlet to express their fury.

headline: U.S. Fighter Jet Shot Down Over Red Sea by Apparent Friendly Fire
abstract: A U.S. Navy ship mistakenly fired at the F/A-18, whose two pilots were safely recovered, the military said.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. Navy ship mistakenly shot down an American fighter jet over the Red Sea early Sunday, the U.S. military said, highlighting the potential risks for international forces as they try to stop attacks on cargo ships by the Houthi militia in Yemen.

headline: Things Are Terrible in Europe, and They’re Only Going to Get Worse
abstract: The continent’s parlous economy and ascendant far right augur a grim future.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, France’s center-right Republicans decided to move to a new home. After a decade of demoralizing defeats, the party vacated its headquarters for one closer to France’s National Assembly, hoping the move would bring a change in fortune.

headline: A 1,000-Year-Old Seed Grows in Israel
abstract: For 14 years, scientists have been growing a tree akin to the Judean balsam — the source of the balm of Gilead — but with no modern counterpart.
lead_paragraph: Camels laden with spices, gold and precious stones accompanied the Queen of Sheba on her biblical journey to Jerusalem in the 10th century B.C. A thousand years later, Flavius Josephus, the Jewish Roman historian, wrote that the haul had included the balm of Gilead, a fragrant, highly prized resin also known as Judean balsam, which served as the basis for perfumes, incense and medicinal remedies.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: ‘Before We Got to the Park, Kali Mentioned the Northern Lights’
abstract: Regret over missing a rare occurrence, a nostalgic stroll and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: When the Bar Mitzvah Boy Is 90
abstract: In 1947, Ron Eliran’s 13th birthday in the British Mandate for Palestine was canceled when authorities called a curfew. Now, 77 years later, he has officially become a man.
lead_paragraph: The ceremony was a surprise to everyone, especially to the guest of honor. Ron Eliran, the Israeli “Ambassador of Song,” was getting the bar mitzvah that he never had.

headline: Let’s Agree to Disagree
abstract: Some readers have their own opinions about the workplace advice that this columnist doled out over the past six months.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Favorite Outfits From Around the World
abstract: Three continents, six countries, seven cities and endless inspiration.
lead_paragraph: With trends and attention spans as fickle as they are these days, it can be difficult to remember what attire or dress codes really permeate culture. Thank goodness for pictures. This year, I went to three continents, six countries and seven cities to photograph people in the streets and in the crowds at fashion shows, an endeavor that involved the use of five cameras and six lenses.

headline: Times Company v. Sullivan: The Case That Helped Make Modern Libel Law
abstract: L.B. Sullivan sued The New York Times over a civil rights fund-raising advertisement. The Supreme Court ruled against him in 1964.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago, in New York Times Company v. Sullivan, the Supreme Court crafted powerful protection from spurious libel suits. The justices ruled unanimously that public officials could not succeed in libel claims unless they proved that a “statement was made with knowledge of its falsity or with reckless disregard of whether it was true or false.” They also held that officials could not, as a matter of constitutional law, bring libel suits based on criticism of government activities in general.

headline: How Airlines Pick the Movies on Your Flights
abstract: Sure, everyone likes “Barbie.” But who knew that “Cats” would be a hit at 35,000 feet?
lead_paragraph: On your long-haul trip home for the holidays, you will scrunch yourself into a too-narrow seat, fasten your seatbelt and probably turn on the screen in front of you.

headline: Fighting to Avoid Her Mother’s Fate, for Her Daughters’ Sake
abstract: A mutant gene is coming to steal Linde Jacobs’s mind. Can she find a way to stop it?
lead_paragraph: Linde Jacobs paced back and forth across her bedroom, eyeing the open laptop on the dresser and willing the doctor to appear. Her husband was dropping off their older daughter at school. Their younger daughter was downstairs, occupied by a screen. Linde wanted to be alone when she learned whether she carried the family curse.

headline: Why One of the World’s Most Elusive Writers Still Haunts Readers
abstract: Newly translated letters reveal the inner life of Paul Celan, offering clues to his enigmatic poems.
lead_paragraph: “Paul Celan’s poems reach us, but we miss them,” wrote the philosopher Hans-Georg Gadamer, giving succinct expression to the allure of one of Europe’s most important postwar poets, who remains as intriguing as he is perplexing more than 50 years after his death.

headline: From the Surf to the Sermon: The Christian Surfers of Costa Rica
abstract: A group of missionaries who surf have expanded to a remote part of Costa Rica, where people come from afar looking for the “perfect wave.” And maybe a little Jesus?
lead_paragraph: Chandler Brownlee stood atop a cluster of rocks protruding from a secluded stretch of Costa Rican beach, Bible in hand, gazing at one of the world’s most coveted surfing waves.

headline: How French Crown Jewels Ended Up in New Jersey
abstract: When the French state scandalously sold off most of its crown jewels, Tiffany bought a third of them.
lead_paragraph: Hidden away in a nondescript building in Parsippany, N.J., are four dazzling remnants of the crown jewels of France.

headline: It Can Be Lonely to Have a Middle-of-the Road Opinion on the Middle East
abstract: Some college students and faculty members are seeking space for nuanced perspectives on the Israel-Hamas war on deeply divided campuses.
lead_paragraph: The scene has become emblematic at many American college campuses since the start of the Israel-Hamas war. Students waving Palestinian flags face off against students waving Israeli flags, each group shouting chants that enrage the other side.

headline: Kennedy Wants to Overhaul the F.D.A. Here’s How Experts Would Change It.
abstract: While some agree with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that the agency needs reform, their ideas for fixing it are very different from his.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has set the Food and Drug Administration in his sights. He has claimed that the agency is in the pockets of the industries it regulates, allowing chemical additives to enter the food supply and greenlighting drugs while suppressing “cheap, generic and natural alternatives.” In an October post on X, he warned F.D.A. employees to “1. Preserve your records, and 2. Pack your bags.” After the election, he told NBC News that entire departments at the agency “have to go.”

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Make a Robot Chef?
abstract: Restaurants are experimenting with automation. But in the kitchen, human labor is hard to replace.
lead_paragraph: The robot in the kitchen was upset.

headline: Behold! ‘Christmas Adam’ Is Born.
abstract: First there was Christmas Eve … and then a new celebration was created.
lead_paragraph: Some 2,000 years ago, on a holy night in Bethlehem as stars were brightly shining, a young woman gave birth to a baby and laid him in a manger. The baby Jesus was a thrill of hope for a weary world, the gospel story goes, and Christians ever since remember his birth in the candlelight of Christmas Eve.

headline: Best Classical Music Albums of 2024
abstract: Listen to selections from recordings of a new John Adams opera, Chopin études by Yunchan Lim, Brahms works by Igor Levit and more.
lead_paragraph: John Adams and Peter Sellars’s “Girls of the Golden West” has struggled to catch on since its premiere, but this recording makes the best case yet for its vitality. With nearly an hour of cuts and a treatment of Americana both vivid and terrifying, it’s essential listening for the opera’s doubters. JOSHUA BARONE

headline: The New Climate Gold Rush: Scrubbing Carbon From the Sky
abstract: Investors are betting that they can make a dent in global warming, and healthy profits, with companies that alter the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Bill Gates huddled in London with representatives of some of the world’s wealthiest people, including the Amazon founder, Jeff Bezos, the SoftBank founder, Masayoshi Son, and Prince al-Waleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda on ‘Mufasa’ and the Secret to a Disney Hit
abstract: The “Hamilton” creator, who crafted the soundtrack for the new prequel to “The Lion King,” reflects on writing songs that have a universal appeal.
lead_paragraph: When the director Barry Jenkins approached Lin-Manuel Miranda about writing the songs for “Mufasa,” Disney’s new photorealistic prequel to the 2019 remake of “The Lion King,” he was, to say the least, a little busy.

headline: Refugees Are Bracing for Trump to Cut the Resettlement Program Again
abstract: As Donald J. Trump returns to office, the rebuilt program is under threat. Many vulnerable people approved for resettlement in the U.S. could be stranded abroad.
lead_paragraph: The United States refugee program, long a pillar of American foreign policy, has experienced dramatic ups and downs in recent years.

headline: What’s the Secret to Choosing a Good Airplane Movie?
abstract: You’re about to get on a long flight home, and the options seem overwhelming. Here’s the strategy our critic recommends.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a question for our culture writers and editors? Ask us here.

headline: These Spiritual Democrats Urge Their Party to Take a Leap of Faith
abstract: In a party that has grown less religious, some prominent Democrats say discussing their deepest beliefs can be a way to connect — when it’s authentic.
lead_paragraph: As the Democratic Party wanders in the post-election wilderness after the bruising defeats of 2024, some of its newer leaders are tapping into an ancient form of connection: religion.

headline: Why Are So Many Christians So Cruel?
abstract: It’s a simple question with a complicated answer.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a question I hear everywhere I go, including from fellow Christians: Why are so many Christians so cruel?

headline: ‘Lion King’ Prequel Falls Prey to ‘Sonic’ at the Box Office
abstract: “Mufasa: The Lion King” sputtered in second place at theaters in the United States and Canada. “Sonic the Hedgehog 3” was No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s mighty Mufasa … eaten alive by a hedgehog?

headline: Germany Tries to Untangle Complex Profile of Market Attack Suspect
abstract: The authorities said they were struggling to understand the motives behind ramming a car into a Christmas market in the eastern city of Magdeburg, which left a 9-year-old boy among the five dead.
lead_paragraph: A frequent critic on social media of the German government, as well as of radical Islam. A reclusive neighbor who appeared to live most of his life on the internet. A man whose extreme political postings online prompted an alert to Germany from Saudi Arabia.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,283
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Picturesque New England Town’s Debt to the Right Whale
abstract: We owe it to the right whale — and to so many other species — to reconstruct what our own history has taken from them.
lead_paragraph: The North Atlantic right whale is highly endangered, its survival as a species in doubt. There are only about 370 of these dark, bulbous baleen whales remaining. No one knows exactly how large the population once was, but most estimates place it at almost 30 times that number. Those that remain migrate up and down the Eastern Seaboard each year from their calving grounds off Florida northward in search of food.

headline: Like Kennedy, I Recovered From Heroin Addiction. I Don’t Agree With His Approach.
abstract: America can’t go backward on drug policy.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and I share the experience of recovering from heroin addiction. Like me, he started the process at a residential rehabilitation facility in the 1980s and participated in a 12-step program based on Alcoholics Anonymous, which promotes abstinence from substances. Unlike me, however, he seems to have remained wedded to this treatment model, despite evidence that it fails many people with drug addictions. This could do enormous harm if he is confirmed as secretary of health and human services.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 561
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: We’ve Misunderstood Human Nature for 100 Years
abstract: It’s a source of today’s intense political animosity.
lead_paragraph: One day in the summer of 1924, an anthropologist named Raymond Dart made an incredible discovery — and drew a conclusion from it about human nature that would mislead us for a century.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Alienation of Jaime Cachua’
abstract: His friends and family members in Rome, Ga., voted to support mass deportation. Now he’s scrambling to stay in the country.
lead_paragraph: His wife was spiraling into insomnia, and his children were afraid to go to school, so Jaime Cachua sought out the person he trusted most in a crisis. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Georgia across from his father-in-law, Sky Atkins, the family patriarch. Jaime, 33, hadn’t seen his own father since he was 10 months old, when he left Mexico in a car seat bound for the United States.

headline: The Enigma of Bob Dylan
abstract: We cover a new film about the singer-songwriter.
lead_paragraph: My holiday season has been filled with parties, and as a movie critic, that has meant a lot of conversations about the big upcoming movie. This year there’s a clear winner, at least at the events I’ve been attending. Someone sidles up to me, Negroni or Coke in hand, and asks, sotto voce, Have you seen the Bob Dylan movie? And then the follow-up: So is it any good?

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Tom Hanks Inducts Martin Short Into the Five-Timers Club
abstract: Short, the host, was accompanied by Paul Rudd, Tina Fey, John Mulaney and others, while the Weekend Update hosts riffed on Luigi Mangione and the drone sightings.
lead_paragraph: When you see Tom Hanks on your TV screen sitting in a comfortable seat, you know that either you’re about to get an education on America’s national parks or a new member is going to be inducted into the Five-Timers Club at “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: The Differences Between Running a Business and Running the Government
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay arguing that running government like a business would be disastrous. Also: Liberalism; a tech court; aging gracefully.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Letter Calling for Tracking People of Color Circulates in an Oregon County
abstract: The letter, distributed in Lincoln County, Ore., tells community members to report people who may be undocumented, the sheriff’s office said.
lead_paragraph: A letter circulating in a coastal county in rural Oregon encourages community members to track and report people of color who may be undocumented immigrants, according to the sheriff’s office, which discouraged residents from heeding the call.

headline: China Wants This Deal to Fail. Don’t Let That Happen.
abstract: The Biden administration should approve the proposed $14.9 billion deal with Nippon Steel.
lead_paragraph: This is a pivotal moment for the future of American manufacturing. The United States must make the right decision.

headline: How to Cook a Perfect Prime Rib Roast
abstract: Step 1: Get an instant-read thermometer. There’s no point in spending money on prime rib if you’re just going to guess when it’s done.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. If you’re making a prime rib roast (above) for the holidays this year, today’s the day to head to the butcher with your mortgage broker to pick it up. It’ll be fine in the fridge until Tuesday night or Wednesday morning when you take it out to get the chill off the meat, in advance of flouring it up for the oven.

headline: Small Plane Crashes Into Buildings in Brazilian City, Killing 10
abstract: At least 17 on the ground were hurt, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A small private plane carrying 10 people crashed in a tourist city in southern Brazil on Sunday, clipping buildings as it fell from the sky and injuring at least 17 others, officials said.

headline: Suspect Held After Woman Set on Fire in Subway Car Dies, Police Say
abstract: The police said a man was taken into custody. The victim had been seated in a subway car at the Coney Island-Stillwell Avenue station on Sunday morning when a man set her on fire.
lead_paragraph: Early Sunday morning, a man calmly approached a woman who was sitting motionless and possibly dozing on a stationary F train at the Coney Island-Stillwell Avenue subway station and, without saying anything, lit the woman’s clothes on fire, engulfing her in deadly flames in seconds, the police said.

headline: Trump Picks a Former Treasury Official as His Top Economist
abstract: Stephen Miran, who served during Donald Trump’s first term and now works at a hedge fund, has accused the Biden administration of manipulating markets.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he was choosing Stephen Miran, who served in the Treasury Department during Mr. Trump’s first term, to lead the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: Wes Moore Given Bronze Star, Nearly 2 Decades After Army Service
abstract: The Maryland governor had faced a controversy over whether he had received the medal for his time in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Wes Moore of Maryland last week accepted a Bronze Star for his Army service in Afghanistan nearly two decades ago, putting to rest a controversy over the award that had trailed him through his career.

headline: Trump Previews Second Term in Sprawling Speech to Conservative Conference
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump repeated false claims about immigration and the border, slammed diversity initiatives and discussed the Panama Canal in the 90-minute address.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump delivered a sprawling address on Sunday that he called a “small preview of the common-sense revolution” his administration will bring, pledging to slam shut the nation’s borders, end federal regulations, lower taxes, prosecute his rivals, “stop woke” and “end the transgender lunacy.”

headline: Monday Briefing: Al-Assad’s Final Days in Power
abstract: Plus, parody as protest in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: As rebels advanced toward the Syrian capital of Damascus in early December, the staff in the hilltop Presidential Palace prepared for a speech they hoped would lead to a peaceful end to the 13-year civil war. Aides to President Bashar al-Assad brainstormed messaging ideas. A film crew set up cameras and lights nearby. Syria’s state-run television station was ready to broadcast an address by al-Assad announcing a plan to share power with members of the political opposition.

headline: Surfers Return for Rare Big Wave Contest in Hawaii
abstract: The Eddie Aikau Big Wave Invitational was held for just the eleventh time since its founding in 1984. Landon McNamara, a local of Oahu’s North Shore, won this year’s event.
lead_paragraph: When the prestigious international surf competition known as the Eddie was called some 48 hours before the contest was set to begin, an esteemed list of invitees — 45 competitors and 25 alternates — began scrambling.

headline: Short Snooze
abstract: Glenn Cook makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: They Made Over $100,000 in Overtime. Now the N.Y.P.D. Is Cracking Down.
abstract: Commissioner Jessica Tisch has reassigned at least 29 officers. Some worked under Jeffrey Maddrey, a high-ranking official who was accused of demanding sex from a subordinate in exchange for overtime.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Tisch, the head of the New York Police Department, is cracking down on apparent abuse of overtime pay as the agency faces internal and external investigations into the matter.

headline: ‘All In’ Review: A Slight Affair for John Mulaney-Led Comedy About Love
abstract: A talented cast has fun in Simon Rich’s Broadway debut, but the minimally staged show doesn’t quite justify the hefty price of tickets.
lead_paragraph: You know Broadway is having a comedy moment when actors in plays as diverse as “Eureka Day,” “Cult of Love” and the runaway phenomenon known as “Oh, Mary!” are routinely drowned out by the audience’s laughter.

headline: If You Want to Destroy My Sweater, Hold This Thread as I Walk Away
abstract: When something that should be innocuous unravels your world.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Trump Names His Picks for Top Pentagon Roles
abstract: They include a billionaire investor who supported Mr. Trump’s campaign, a former official who froze aid to Ukraine and a former executive at Uber.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump plans to nominate four men for top leadership roles at the Pentagon, including two who served in his first administration, he announced on social media on Sunday.

headline: Trump Picks Callista Gingrich for Ambassador to Switzerland
abstract: In announcing his choice of various envoys, including ambassador to Denmark, the president-elect again floated the idea of the United States acquiring Greenland.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he intended to nominate Callista Gingrich, who served as his ambassador to the Vatican during his first term, as ambassador to Switzerland.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Building the Perfect Beast
abstract: Valya confronts the limits of her power, and a terrifying truth comes to light about Desmond’s history.
lead_paragraph: “Come, princess. The path to our enemy begins here.”

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 23, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: When Being Together During the Holidays Is Impossible, Send Treats
abstract: I miss the magic and the chaos of a big family gathering — until a box of cookies turns up on my porch.
lead_paragraph: Going overboard on baking is something of a tradition in my family. Every weekend growing up, my grandma would have mother and her six siblings bake cookies by the dozens, so that they’d have a few to stick in their lunchboxes every day. (Once she got to school, my mom would throw away her bologna sandwich and just eat the cookies.)

headline: 4 Men on Abuse at Ireland’s Catholic Schools: ‘I Was Destroyed by It’
abstract: After decades of silence, dozens of older men are talking about the sexual abuse they suffered at schools run by religious orders. We spoke to four of them.
lead_paragraph: They came forward in small groups at first. And then they spoke out in waves.

headline: Organized Looting Throws Gaza Deeper Into Chaos
abstract: Gangs are filling a power vacuum left by Israel in some parts of southern Gaza, hijacking desperately needed aid for Palestinian residents.
lead_paragraph: Hazem Isleem, a Palestinian truck driver, was passing through the ruins of southern Gaza last month with a truckload of aid when armed looters ambushed his convoy.

headline: Quote of the Day: In Some Parts, It’s Christmas Adam Before Eve
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Dec. 24 gets an official title — it gets called Christmas Eve. So what the heck, let’s give December the 23rd a semiofficial imprint as well.”

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: An attack at a Christmas market in Germany.
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, an attacker rammed an S.U.V. into a crowded Christmas market in the German city of Magdeburg. The assault killed five people, including a 9-year-old boy, and wounded hundreds more in a matter of minutes. The driver accelerated to harm as many people as possible before trying to escape, the police said.

headline: Trump and Biden, Make the Hostages Your Priority
abstract: I was held captive in Gaza. Healing will only happen when all the captives have been brought home.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 20, 1981, minutes after Ronald Reagan was sworn in as president, 52 American citizens held hostage in Iran for 444 days were released. Today, 96 hostages in Gaza have been held for nearly the same amount of time. As the American White House changes hands, I implore President Biden and President-elect Trump not to forget about them.

headline: Your Christmas Day Lineup, Plus 4 Things to Watch on TV this Week
abstract: Get ready for football games, floats and Beyoncé, oh my! And start preparing for the new year with specials looking back at 2024.
lead_paragraph: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, Dec. 23-29. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: expediency
abstract: This word has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word expediency has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 13 in “This Year, Make Your Own Festivus Pole” by Tim Heffernan:

headline: The Son Who Couldn’t Leave
abstract: Paul Barreto’s father, Mickey, lived at the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan for five years, paying only $200.57. Paul was desperate to escape.
lead_paragraph: Paul Barreto moved into Room 2565 at the New Yorker Hotel the year after his father, Mickey Barreto, did. It was 2019 and the 135-square-foot queen-bed room in Midtown Manhattan felt like it could be a good home, or at least a better one.

headline: Robbie Williams Never Broke the U.S. Can His Biopic?
abstract: He had 14 No. 1 singles in Britain, but is not well known in America. In the new movie “Better Man,” he’s played by a CGI monkey.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Gracey thinks of Robbie Williams, “I think showman,” he said.

headline: Our Photographer’s Look Inside New York’s Migrant Shelters
abstract: Just over 225,000 migrants have entered New York City since 2022, and more than $6 billion has been spent on a hodgepodge of shelters that morphed into the largest system of emergency housing for migrants in the country. Todd Heisler, a photographer for The New York Times, gained exclusive access to shelters across the city, documenting the experience through the eyes of those living there.
lead_paragraph: Just over 225,000 migrants have entered New York City since 2022, and more than $6 billion has been spent on a hodgepodge of shelters that morphed into the largest system of emergency housing for migrants in the country. Todd Heisler, a photographer for The New York Times, gained exclusive access to shelters across the city, documenting the experience through the eyes of those living there.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: New York City’s Secret Weapon in the War on Rats: Katie the Dog
abstract: She roams Brooklyn’s parks and streets in search of prey. It’s not hard to find.
lead_paragraph: Katie the dog and Sarah Darby entered Prospect Park in Brooklyn beneath a full hunter’s moon. Ms. Darby turned on Katie’s red LED collar, unclipped her leash and Katie sprinted off, looking over her shoulder to make sure her mistress was following.

headline: Dateline: Yonder Star
abstract: As Christmas nears, New York Times journalists send dispatches from places like Santa Claus, Ind., and North Pole, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Each year on or around Dec. 25, The New York Times has used its reporting to channel the meaning and celebration of the holidays into its pages.

headline: 8 Months Inside New York’s Migrant Shelters: Fear, Joy and Hope
abstract: A reporter and photographer documented life in New York City’s shelter system for migrants, through the eyes of those living there.
lead_paragraph: When the first buses carrying migrants from the southern border arrived in Manhattan two years ago, it seemed little more than a political stunt. If New York truly wanted to be a sanctuary city, then the Republican governor of Texas was happy to oblige by sending busloads of migrants its way.

headline: Review: Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of Who Knows When
abstract: Dave Malloy’s musical, which was a hit in New York, comes to London in an antirealist staging that loses the 1812 setting and some emotional punch.
lead_paragraph: In a new London production of Dave Malloy’s Tolstoy-inspired pop opera, “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,” the stage is featureless but for six huge, light-up letters that spell out the show’s setting: Moscow. One of the O’s hangs overhead, and the W is facing backward with its wiring exposed — an apt metaphor for a piece that makes a comic virtue of showing its workings.

headline: Honda and Nissan Aim to Merge as Global Competition Bears Down
abstract: Japan’s second- and third-largest automakers hope the $50 billion deal would help them catch up with Tesla and China’s BYD in electric vehicles and advanced software.
lead_paragraph: Honda Motor and Nissan Motor are exploring a merger to create one of the world’s largest auto groups as they seek to better position themselves for the expensive technological transition reshaping the automotive industry.

headline: My K-Drama Pilgrimage
abstract: With the next season of “Squid Game” about to air, a Korean American writer shares her experience of a group tour in Korea based on the popular streaming genre.
lead_paragraph: My parents were both born in North Korea. The Korean War in the 1950s left them and 10 million other Koreans “ee-san gajok,” separated from their families. A move to the United States allowed them to start over and raise four American-born children in rural Minnesota.

headline: How to Pack Formal Clothing
abstract: Make sure your dresses and suits arrive in tip-top shape with these packing tips from the pros.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are here, which means many of us will soon be trying to squeeze our best festive attire into airline-approved bags. So how to make sure your precious dresses, suits and heels arrive in tip-top shape? Checking a bag means you’ll have room for a variety of dressy outfits. But if all you need are a few, you can travel light, as many business travelers do. Whether you choose to check or carry-on, here’s how to pack formal wear like the pros so you can spend the season celebrating rather than ironing.

headline: Why Do Celebrities All Go to the Same Restaurants?
abstract: Because the management knows how to make them happy. Here’s how a handful of New York dining rooms do it.
lead_paragraph: It sometimes seems there are just two types of restaurants in New York City: the ones where celebrities eat, and everywhere else. Coverage of big-name restaurant outings has been particularly profuse this year; every New York spot Taylor Swift has patronized, for example, has been thoroughly documented and mapped online.

headline: Is Everyone High?
abstract: We need a new language to talk about the chemicals and plants that change our consciousness.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming impossible to count all the options we have these days for altering our consciousness with chemicals and plants. You can buy ketamine from club drug dealers on your phone, or by mail from online medical clinics to treat depression. Alongside vapes and gummies, C.B.D. dispensaries sell kratom, an herbal stimulant that some people use to boost work productivity and others to detox from opioids. Cannabis sellers may or may not be legally licensed, and may also sell psychedelic mushrooms. Some people source their Xanax or Adderall from sites on the dark web, others from a physician. Those seeking an alternative to coffee can head to a kava bar to sip an herbal narcotic long used in traditional Polynesian medicine.

headline: How ‘Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer’ (and Its Writer) Went Down in History
abstract: Johnny Marks wrote the beloved holiday song, as well as “Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree.” But he felt pigeonholed by the success of “Rudolph.”
lead_paragraph: There were “years of heartbreak,” the songwriter Johnny Marks once recalled of his start in the music business in 1935. He eventually found some modest success collaborating on a No. 1 hit for the Ink Spots, “Address Unknown,” and songs made popular by Bing Crosby and Glenn Miller. It was just enough renown for Billboard magazine to briefly note his decision to pause to volunteer for World War II in the spring of 1942, when he enlisted as a U.S. Army private.

headline: An Emotional Boxing Biopic Overcame an Early Knockdown
abstract: “The Fire Inside,” a screenplay by Barry Jenkins about Claressa Shields’s challenging path to Olympic gold, was dropped by its initial studio during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: For three months, Ryan Destiny had trained to portray Claressa Shields, the first American woman to win an Olympic gold medal in boxing, in the biopic “The Fire Inside.” There was a screenplay by Barry Jenkins, the director of “Moonlight,” and an Oscar-nominated cinematographer, Rachel Morrison, making her feature directorial debut.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Wants to Ban Drug Ads on TV. It Wouldn’t Be Easy.
abstract: Attempts to restrict pharmaceutical advertisements have failed many times over the years, often on First Amendment grounds.
lead_paragraph: Since the late 1990s, drug companies have spent tens of billions of dollars on television ads, drumming up demand for their products with cheerful jingles and scenes of dancing patients.

headline: 8 Best Reality TV Moments of 2024
abstract: “Vanderpump Rules” revamped, “Love Island USA” broke out and “Love Is Blind” contestants made headway with labor complaints.
lead_paragraph: Reality television didn’t just entertain us this year — it opened up some important conversations about ethical concerns, the rights of participants and the virtuous circle between TV and TikTok. We’ve gathered the moments in 2024 that revealed where reality TV is going.

headline: In 2024, Sapphic Stars Ruled Pop Culture
abstract: Across music, movies, social media and podcasts, a celebration of lesbianism and Sapphic queerness has been flourishing.
lead_paragraph: When Chappell Roan accepted her MTV Video Music Award for best new artist in September, she had a message for “all the queer kids in the Midwest watching right now.”

headline: Biden Commutes 37 Death Sentences Ahead of Trump’s Plan to Resume Federal Executions
abstract: Those affected by the president’s action on Monday are still subject to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Three men will remain on federal death row.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Monday commuted the sentences of nearly all prisoners on federal death row, sparing the lives of 37 men just a month before Donald J. Trump will return to the Oval Office with a promise to restart federal executions.

headline: U.S. Takes Aim at China’s Production of Essential Computer Chips
abstract: The older-style chips are crucial for a wide array of appliances and other machinery, including weaponry.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Monday initiated a trade investigation into China’s production of older types of computer chips that are integral for cars, dishwashers, telecom networks and military weaponry.

headline: The Full List of Biden’s Death Row Commutations
abstract: Here is a full list of those granted commutations, as well as the three men remaining on death row.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced on Monday that he was commuting the sentences of 37 of the 40 inmates on federal death row.
