The men will continue to serve life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Here is a full list of those granted commutations, as well as the three men remaining on death row. This list was compiled using information from the Death Penalty Information Center.

headline: Quartz Watches Are Having a Movement
abstract: Long scorned despite being cheaper and more accurate than their mechanical counterparts, quartz watches are finally getting some love.
lead_paragraph: Wristwatch enthusiasts can be persnickety. They often have strong opinions about whether bezels should be bidirectional. They can cite the differences between ETA and Sellita movements. They will happily preach the gospel of microadjust clasps and guilloche dials.

headline: Honk if You Understand This Obscure Bumper Sticker
abstract: Gone are the days of “Coexist” or “This car climbed Mt. Washington.” Bumper stickers have lately gotten a lot weirder, and much more niche.
lead_paragraph: You can spot them in the parking lot of a grocery store. They catch your eye at a red light or while stuck in traffic. You squint to read: What do they mean by “Former Baby on Board” or “Keep honking I’m eating your girl’s pasta fagiole”?

headline: Bird Flu, Pneumonia: It’s Time for Weekly Virus Reports
abstract: An epidemiologist on what public health officials can learn from meteorologists.
lead_paragraph: Flu season has arrived again, and we still lack mainstream communication systems about risk levels and how to protect ourselves from seasonal viruses and emerging threats like bird flu. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the epidemiologist Caitlin Rivers argues that public health professionals should take a page from meteorologists and broadcast virus reports like weather reports.

headline: Mpox Is Spreading in Congo’s Capital, Threatening Global Efforts to Contain the Virus
abstract: Our reporter went to Congo, where the mpox epidemic has reached the teeming capital, infecting children and their mothers, who sell sex to survive.
lead_paragraph: Mireille Efonge got sick a few months ago, with a fever and painful blisters on her groin. She became too weak to move, so neighbors carried her to a health center with walls of plastic sheeting in Pakadjuma, a crowded, poor community in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Even Santa Claus Is in Debt This Christmas
abstract: A New York man who plays St. Nick is charging hundreds of dollars for a special family experience, but it’s not enough to get him into the black, he says.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll meet a Santa Claus who says his balance sheet is as red as his Santa suit. We’ll also get details on high-level departures and transfers that shook the New York Police Department over the weekend.

headline: What Economists Could Learn From George Costanza
abstract: Their economic models produced a disaster, but they doubled down.
lead_paragraph: “It has sometimes been remarked that asking five economists a question will generate 10 different answers,” Larry Summers, then the secretary of the Treasury, observed at a hearing of the House Ways and Means Committee nearly 25 years ago. On the issue the committee was discussing that day, however, “there has been only one answer.” He was speaking of “welcoming China into the global economic system,” which economists guaranteed would bring better jobs and greater prosperity to Americans.

headline: She’s the Queen of the Queens of the Night
abstract: Kathryn Lewek has made a specialty of singing the showstopping role in Mozart’s “The Magic Flute.” “It’s my security blanket,” she said.
lead_paragraph: If there is one role that defines opera in the popular imagination — and the emotional extravagance and technical difficulty associated with classical singing — it is the Queen of the Night. The manipulative uber-mother in Mozart’s “The Magic Flute” sings only two arias, but each is a showstopper of volcanic virtuosity and power, performed at the extremity of a soprano’s range, including a fearsome number of high Fs.

headline: Sending Troops to Help Russia Was North Korea’s Idea, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: North Korean troops have now entered Russia’s war with Ukraine in a major way, and some have been killed, Western officials say.
lead_paragraph: When North Korean troops began arriving in Russia this fall, some Western officials believed it was a sign that the Kremlin had reached out in a desperate need for more soldiers.

headline: Remembering When ‘the World Really Made Sense’ on the Comics Pages
abstract: Wildly popular strips like “Bloom County,” “Calvin and Hobbes,” “Cathy,” “The Far Side” “and “Doonesbury” peaked in the 1980s, but they left their mark.
lead_paragraph: One morning in early 1985, the comic strip creator Berkeley Breathed received a call from an unlikely fan: Ronald Reagan.

headline: ‘The Democratic Brand Is in the Toilet’: 4 Writers Dive Deep Into the Party’s Distress
abstract: Assessing newer voices, and future strategies.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation with Tim Ryan, a former representative from Ohio; Anat Shenker-Osorio, a political researcher, a campaign adviser and the host of the podcast “Words to Win By”; and Lis Smith, a Democratic communications strategist and the author of the memoir “Any Given Tuesday: A Political Love Story.” They discussed the future of the Democratic Party and its leadership.

headline: $2.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco, a cottage in Calistoga and a Craftsman in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom house in the Richmond District is less than a mile from the Presidio and the Land’s End Trail, with its sweeping views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Presidio Middle School and George Washington High School are each five-minutes away by foot, and nearby Geary Boulevard offers a dim sum restaurant, and grocery and hardware stores.

headline: Netflix Hopes to Recapture ‘Squid Game’ Magic
abstract: The success of the show’s first season surprised Netflix executives, reaffirming the company’s global strategy.
lead_paragraph: In Los Angeles, 1,600 people ran a 4.56-kilometer race to win admission to an early screening of the show.

headline: What It Means to Have That West Coast Swing
abstract: A wave of viral videos highlight a style that participants call addictive and innovative. Descended from the Lindy Hop, it has few traditional markers of swing.
lead_paragraph: When I first saw the video that hooked me, I assumed it was a hoax.

headline: Who Takes 60 Years to Write a Play? This Guy.
abstract: A new biography of Goethe approaches its subject through his masterpiece and life’s work, the verse drama “Faust.”
lead_paragraph: At what point does an aside become a tangent, a tangent a digression, a digression a meander, a meander a ramble, a ramble a circumlocution, a circumlocution an excursus and an excursus a cul-de-sac? The reader has time to consider such matters while reading A.N. Wilson’s elastic-waisted but hardly unintelligent new biography, “Goethe: His Faustian Life.”

headline: How Babies Teach Us to Be Human
abstract: They make us love them. No matter how closed our hearts, no matter how battered and crusted over with scars.
lead_paragraph: Every year as I’m unpacking my grandmother’s nativity set, I hide the ceramic baby in a drawer. My grandmother installed the baby in the manger on the first day of Advent, but it’s a tradition in this house to wait till Christmas morning. I like the reminder of an empty manger: Advent is a time for waiting.

headline: Haitians in Ohio Work to Keep the Holidays on Track. But They Wonder: Can They Stay?
abstract: Many Haitian immigrants work at an Amazon warehouse near Springfield, packaging thousands of holiday gifts. But after Donald Trump won the election, some worry about their future.
lead_paragraph: In a vast Amazon warehouse in central Ohio, the stress might seem to be all about the work. It’s the holidays, and like every other Amazon fulfillment center, the one in West Jefferson is under the gun. Hundreds of employees are working 12-hour shifts, racing to sort and pack thousands upon thousands of items destined to land in living rooms before Christmas and Hanukkah.

headline: 11 Hyperlocal Works That Helped Me Find Common Ground
abstract: As pop culture continues to fracture, our critic was drawn to art and performances that explored universal themes by way of specific settings.
lead_paragraph: The week of the presidential election, my 12-year-old daughter and I argued over when the next episode of “High Potential,” a crime drama we realized we’d each been avidly watching without the other knowing, would air. Our ignorance stemmed from how we consumed it: She streamed it on the family-friendly Disney, and I on the adult-leaning Hulu, which also meant we caught new episodes after they premiered on ABC. Without a singular broadcast to bring us together, we had different viewing experiences.

headline: How ‘The Brutalist’ Conjures Up a Grand Building That Doesn’t Exist
abstract: It was the production designer who actually drafted an architect character’s vision. Showing it onscreen without constructing it was a film feat.
lead_paragraph: Central to the plot of the director Brady Corbet’s new drama, “The Brutalist,” is an enormous structure known as the Van Buren Institute. Situated in Pennsylvania, it is made of concrete. The negative space between the two towers that stretch high above it forms the symbol of a cross. When light pours into a chapel below, the same emblem illuminates a marble altarpiece.

headline: Why Are North Korean Troops in Ukraine Taking Heavy Casualties?
abstract: The North Korean army is one of the world’s largest.​ As it joins Russia’s war against Ukraine, its soldiers are paying a price for Kim Jong-un’s geopolitical maneuvers.
lead_paragraph: For years, North Korea’s military has helped its leader, Kim Jong-un, keep control of his people and provide a buffer against the country’s sworn enemy, South Korea. With 1.3 million members, the North’s army is among the world’s largest conventional armed forces.

headline: The Oldest Children’s Museum Strives to Be of Brooklyn (and Analog)
abstract: The organization has its eyes on the whole borough, its leader, Atiba T. Edwards, says.
lead_paragraph: The world’s oldest public art museum is considered to be Switzerland’s Kunstmuseum Basel. The world’s oldest orchestra is said to be the Royal Danish (it dates to 1448).

headline: The Typography Maestro Getting Calls From Greta Gerwig and Robert Eggers
abstract: Teddy Blanks, the designer behind the memorable movie titles for films like “Nosferatu” and “Barbie,” has quietly become Hollywood’s go-to guy.
lead_paragraph: Teddy Blanks, a neatly mustached 40-year-old man wearing ripped jeans and battered white sneakers, walked through Times Square one cold recent night to catch a screening of “Wicked” at an AMC multiplex. He hadn’t yet seen the film, and he was eager to see one particular shot: the movie’s opening title.

headline: Will There Ever Be True Size Diversity in Fashion?
abstract: A reader, discouraged by the perpetuation of outdated beauty standards in the fashion industry, wonders if we will ever see genuine inclusivity in fashion models.
lead_paragraph: You are correct in thinking that one of the worst trends of the year was that, after a lot of talk about the importance of diversity of all kinds on the runway and in fashion ad campaigns, we saw a major case of backsliding this year — at least when it came to size. Which was actually a continuation of the backsliding that had begun in 2023.

headline: What Would the Founders Have Thought About TikTok and Online Porn?
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments next month in First Amendment challenges to laws banning the app and shielding minors from sexual materials on the internet.
lead_paragraph: In a pair of arguments next month, the Supreme Court will consider what the First Amendment, ratified in 1791, has to say about TikTok and online pornography.

headline: House Ethics Committee Is Expected to Release Report on Gaetz’s Conduct
abstract: Former Representative Matt Gaetz has been under investigation since 2021 over allegations that include sexual misconduct and illicit drug use.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Trump and the House Ethics Committee’s report on Matt Gaetz.

headline: Under Pressure, Telegram Pulls Off an Elusive Milestone: A Profit
abstract: Even as Telegram faces legal scrutiny and grapples with billions in debt, it is set to be profitable for the first time as it tries cryptocurrencies, subscriptions and ads.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, Telegram, the lightly moderated social media app, has held discussions with investors who lent it more than $2 billion. The goal: to reassure them that the company remains a viable bet after its founder, Pavel Durov, was arrested in France in August on charges related to illicit activities on the platform.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,284
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 562
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Could One Phone Call Lead to the 28th Amendment?
abstract: How President Biden could transform women’s rights and rescue his legacy with just a ring.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of congressional Democrats have a simple pitch to President Biden: with a single phone call he can revolutionize women’s rights and salvage his damaged legacy.

headline: Top Arab Diplomats, in Syria Visits, Aim to Build Ties With New Leadership
abstract: Ministers from Jordan and Qatar were among the first high-ranking Arab diplomats to meet with the leader of the rebel coalition that toppled the Syrian regime.
lead_paragraph: Top Arab diplomats visited the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Monday, the latest in a string of diplomatic overtures by the international community as Syria emerges from years of isolation under President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: The Best Times Graphics of 2024
abstract: Our visual journalists are always on the prowl for innovative ways to tell big news stories.
lead_paragraph: Noah Lyles doesn’t run like other sprinters. When he won gold for the United States in the 100-meter race at the Olympics this summer, he got off to a slow start. During the first 40 meters, he trailed the pack. Only in the final stride did he pull ahead, winning by a fraction of a second.

headline: Silicon Valley Heads to Washington
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump is tapping the technology sector for key roles, and executives from the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz are featuring heavily.
lead_paragraph: The flow of Silicon Valley executives President-elect Donald Trump wants to join his administration is becoming a torrent after he announced more picks over the weekend.

headline: Deal Makers See a Rebound in 2025 as Trump Returns to Power
abstract: It was another down year for mergers and acquisitions, but Wall Street is optimistic that the lengthy lull is coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: By most measures, 2024 was a year of fits and starts for M.&A., especially compared with a year ago. And I.P.O.s were a flat-out dud.

headline: House Ethics Panel Report Accuses Gaetz of ‘Regularly’ Paying for Sex and Using Drugs
abstract: The Florida Republican resigned from the House and withdrew as Donald J. Trump’s attorney general pick in the weeks before the report’s release.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee said on Monday that its lengthy investigation had found that former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s initial choice for attorney general, had regularly paid women for sex, had sex with an underage girl and used illegal drugs.

headline: A Canceled Vote in Romania Hands Russia a Propaganda Coup
abstract: Many in the West have applauded the annulling of the first round of the presidential election, won by a Moscow-friendly candidate, but even his critics say it raises troubling questions about Romanian democracy.
lead_paragraph: When Romania this month annulled the first round of a presidential election won by a Moscow-friendly ultranationalist candidate, many in the West applauded what they hailed as a “solution” to a democratic process gone awry.

headline: The New York Bookstore That Lets You Visit France for an Afternoon
abstract: Albertine, in a Fifth Avenue mansion, is a portal to both Gilded Age New York and the Francophone world.
lead_paragraph: In the children’s section of Albertine, copies of “Le Petit Prince,” stories of Tintin and Babar and other much-loved French classics are for sale beneath a sapphire-colored ceiling gilded with hand-painted constellations. What’s arguably New York’s most enchanting bookstore opened a decade ago inside the palatial Payne Whitney House, an early 1900s landmark built by the architect Stanford White on the southeast corner of East 79th Street and Fifth Avenue that’s served as the headquarters of the French Embassy’s cultural and educational activities in the United States for the past 72 years.

headline: Mangione Pleads Not Guilty in First N.Y. State Court Appearance
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney’s office charged Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, with first-degree murder. His lawyer argued his case had been politicized.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Mangione, the 26-year-old man charged with murder in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, pleaded not guilty on Monday as he was arraigned in New York State Supreme Court.

headline: How Hallucinatory A.I. Helps Science Dream Up Big Breakthroughs
abstract: Hallucinations, a bane of popular A.I. programs, turn out to be a boon for venturesome scientists eager to push back the frontiers of human knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence often gets criticized because it makes up information that appears to be factual, known as hallucinations. The plausible fakes have roiled not only chatbot sessions but lawsuits and medical records. For a time last year, a patently false claim from a new Google chatbot helped drive down the company’s market value by an estimated $100 billion.

headline: Can You Find the 10 Hidden 2024 Best Sellers in This Text Puzzle?
abstract: This year saw a variety of novels on the New York Times best-sellers list, including the 10 titles lurking in this very short story.
lead_paragraph: This year saw a variety of novels on the New York Times best-sellers list, including the 10 titles lurking in this very short story.

headline: Alfa Anderson, Singer With Chic, Dies at 78
abstract: She sang the famous refrain “Le freak, c’est chic” on one of the biggest hits of the disco era and was a sought-after vocalist for many prominent artists.
lead_paragraph: Alfa Anderson, the singer behind memorable disco records including the No. 1 hits “Le Freak” and “Good Times,” has died. She was 78.

headline: Nordstrom Family Strikes Deal to Buy Out Namesake Chain
abstract: The business will be acquired by members of the family and El Puerto de Liverpool, a Mexican real estate and department store company that has owned a stake in Nordstrom since 2022.
lead_paragraph: Nordstrom, one of the country’s oldest department stores, said Monday that it would be taken private by its founding family and a Mexican retail business, reaching an agreement after months of speculation over a potential buyout of the business.

headline: After Christmas Market Attack, Germans Focus on Potential Security Failures
abstract: After an assailant driving an S.U.V. killed five people, calls for solidarity have quickly given way to criticism by rival lawmakers, ahead of snap elections set for February.
lead_paragraph: Days after an attacker driving an S.U.V. killed five people at a Christmas market in eastern Germany, calls for solidarity have given way to political sniping, as questions grew on Monday about the authorities’ inability to prevent the deaths.

headline: Court Upholds Disputed Presidential Poll in Mozambique, Sparking Protests
abstract: The decision paves the way for the governing party’s candidate to take office next month, but the country is on edge because earlier protests after the election left more than 100 people dead.
lead_paragraph: Protesters set fires on the streets across the southern African nation of Mozambique on Monday after the country’s highest court upheld the results of a contested presidential election in which the candidate from the governing party was declared the winner.

headline: You Have F.S.A. Dollars to Burn. Everyone Wants Them.
abstract: A growing number of wellness retailers are vying for health care funds that expire at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Have a flexible spending account? Amazon has a page for you. There you’ll find “surprisingly eligible” items you can use that money for: tampons, pimple patches, laxatives, sunscreens.

headline: My Sister Was Dying of Cancer. A Christmas Gift Helped Me Process It.
abstract: Two and a half feet tall, roots wrapped in burlap — it was much better than a sweater.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, my sister asked me what type of tree I wanted as a Christmas present. This wasn’t a simple question, like “What kind of sweater: V-neck or crew?” Julie was dying and wanted to give me a living gift to remember her by.

headline: Sweet and Sour Cauliflower, Weeknight Wower
abstract: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s clever recipe skips the frying, instead roasting the cornstarch-coated florets for less mess (but lots of crunch).
lead_paragraph: So, got anything going on later this week?

headline: Decisions About Gender-Affirming Care
abstract: Readers discuss a David French column about a Tennessee legal case. Also: Crime and remorse; ultraprocessed foods; ageism in politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Pro-Trump Group’s Risky Bet on Infrequent Voters Seems to Have Paid Off
abstract: Turning Point Action devoted much of its attention to less reliable voters. New data in Arizona showing a sizable Republican edge among them suggests that the strategy succeeded.
lead_paragraph: Heading into the 2024 election, the conservative group Turning Point Action made a risky and expensive bet as it tried to fix Republicans’ early-voting problem: It zeroed in on infrequent voters who seemed to lean to the right.

headline: How We Documented Life Inside New York’s Migrant Shelters
abstract: A Times reporter and photographer spent months with new arrivals as they navigated the city’s pop-up shelter system.
lead_paragraph: I was overwhelmed by the whirlwind of activity inside the Roosevelt Hotel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Read the Ethics Committee’s Report on Matt Gaetz
abstract: A report by the House Ethics Committee accused former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, of regularly paying for sex and using illegal drugs, and of having sexual relations with a 17-year-old girl in 2017.
lead_paragraph: A report by the House Ethics Committee accused former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, of regularly paying for sex and using illegal drugs, and of having sexual relations with a 17-year-old girl in 2017.

headline: Will You Have a White Christmas This Year?
abstract: Look up your location to find out.
lead_paragraph: Look up your location to find out.

headline: Bath & Body Works Needs Holiday Shoppers. Do New Scents Draw Them In?
abstract: Every year, Bath & Body Works introduces a scent that it hopes will break through during the shopping season. It doesn’t have to smell like gingerbread.
lead_paragraph: On a Thursday evening not long before Christmas, as tourists and the after-work crowd started filling up a Bath & Body Works store near Grand Central Terminal, in Manhattan, a woman walked up to a table piled with products labeled “Perfect in Pink.”

headline: Kilauea Volcano Erupts on Hawaii’s Big Island
abstract: Scientists said that the main hazard from the eruption on Monday was increased levels of volcanic gas.
lead_paragraph: Kilauea, one of the world’s most active volcanoes, erupted early Monday on Hawaii’s Big Island, sending out glittering torrents of lava.

headline: Where to Expect Snow and Rain on Christmas Week
abstract: Also, where you’ll find warmer temperatures. Here’s a day-by-day forecast.
lead_paragraph: Fair weather should greet most holiday travelers across the United States, and Christmas is likely to be a transition to unseasonably mild temperatures nationwide.Here is a day-by-day look at what to expect.

headline: The Trumpian Attitude at the Heart of the Gaetz Report
abstract: Both men display the same contempt for the law.
lead_paragraph: There is so much repellently sleazy behavior documented in the House Ethics Committee report about Matt Gaetz that a reader has to stop every few pages to look away and focus on what still seems astounding: This is the man that Donald Trump wanted to be the attorney general of the United States, the highest-ranking law enforcement official in the land, the leader of the Department of Justice.

headline: Research Finds Vaccines Are Not Behind the Rise in Autism. So What Is?
abstract: There is no one factor that causes autism — or explains its growing prevalence. Researchers are seeking explanations for the surge. Here are some possibilities.
lead_paragraph: When President-elect Donald J. Trump mused in a recent television interview about whether vaccines cause autism — a theory that has been discredited by dozens of scientific studies — autism researchers across the country collectively sighed in frustration.

headline: Our Favorite Food Stories of 2024
abstract: From a debate about the most delicious pasta dishes in Italy to a luxurious baked potato recipe, these are the most appetizing and surprising food features T published this year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. This week, we’re looking back at our top food stories from the year. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday, along with monthly travel and beauty guides, and the latest stories from our print issues. And you can always reach us at tmagazine@nytimes.com.

headline: Slovak Leader Visits Putin, Breaking With E.U.’s Policy of Isolation
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Fico’s surprise visit to Moscow on Sunday, reportedly to discuss natural gas and Ukraine, was a blow to European unity against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s efforts to keep a united front against Russia over the war in Ukraine suffered a new blow with a surprise visit to Moscow by Robert Fico, the leader of Slovakia, for talks with President Vladimir V. Putin on natural gas supplies and the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: The Three Death Row Prisoners Biden Chose Not to Spare
abstract: President Biden commuted the sentences of 37 men on federal death row but declined to save the lives of three men convicted of “hate-motivated mass murder” or “terrorism.”
lead_paragraph: The number of prisoners on federal death row shrank from 40 to just three on Monday after President Biden commuted the sentences of 37 men who had been facing the death penalty.

headline: As Budget Impasse Grinds On, Macron Appoints a New Cabinet
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France named the choices less than three weeks after the previous government collapsed. He had already picked François Bayrou as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday appointed a new cabinet less than three weeks after the previous government collapsed over a bitter budgetary stalemate.

headline: D.C. Police Officer Convicted Over Leaking Information to Proud Boys’ Leader
abstract: A federal judge found Lt. Shane Lamond guilty of lying to investigators and undermining police work by sharing tips with Enrique Tarrio, the group’s leader.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday found a former intelligence officer in the Washington police department guilty of obstruction of justice and lying to investigators, ruling that he had improperly concealed details about his relationship with Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the far-right group the Proud Boys.

headline: A Perpetual Champagne, Built One Year at a Time
abstract: A new method of making nonvintage Champagnes is taking hold. Producers see it as a hedge against climate change while improving overall quality.
lead_paragraph: All most people need to know about Champagne is how to safely uncork a bottle. Pouring and savoring the wine are the easy parts.

headline: Takeaways From the House Ethics Committee’s Investigation on Matt Gaetz
abstract: A 37-page report detailed the findings from a yearslong investigation into allegations that Mr. Gaetz engaged in a range of illegal conduct. He has repeatedly denied wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: After a yearslong investigation, the House Ethics Committee released a 37-page report on Monday into former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, and allegations that he engaged in an array of illegal and untoward conduct, including having sex with a 17-year-old girl.

headline: Yoshio Taniguchi, Architect for MoMA’s Expansion, Dies at 87
abstract: He was a surprise choice for the ambitious project, but his design won praise as “drop-dead elegant.”
lead_paragraph: Yoshio Taniguchi, a Japanese architect who gained international fame in 1997 when he was chosen to renovate and expand New York’s Museum of Modern Art, a project that cost $850 million (including an accompanying endowment) and was completed in 2004, died on Dec. 16. He was 87.

headline: Climate Change Is Making Homeownership Even More Unaffordable
abstract: Extreme weather is creating a crisis in the home insurance market that has no easy solution.
lead_paragraph: There is anger and finger-pointing in the homeowners insurance market these days. Many homeowners complain that premiums have become unaffordable. Insurers in more and more parts of the country say they can’t make a profit.

headline: Suspect Charged in Fatal Burning of Woman on Subway
abstract: The man charged with murder in the woman’s death was identified by federal officials as a 33-year-old from Guatemala who was in the United States illegally.
lead_paragraph: The videos rocketed across social media. A woman stands motionless in the doorway of a subway car as flames engulf her body. A police officer strolls by, as people scream out of frame.

headline: The Midnight Pasta to Make for New Year’s Eve
abstract: Skip expensive caviar for sushi-style tobiko in this festive New Year’s Eve recipe from Eric Kim.
lead_paragraph: Torpedo-shaped with large pectoral fins that look like wings, the majestic flying fish can propel itself out of the water and into the air, gliding across short distances to avoid predators.

headline: Netanyahu Signals Progress on Hostage Deal but Gives No Timeline
abstract: Pledging to secure the release of hostages held in Gaza by any means necessary, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said, “I don’t know how long it will take.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Monday that “progress” was being made toward a deal with Hamas to release hostages held captive in Gaza for more than a year, but dismissed pressure to act faster.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: The Matt Gaetz Report is Out
abstract: Plus, celebrating “Chrismukkah.”
lead_paragraph: A report by the House Ethics Committee accused Matt Gaetz, Donald Trump’s former pick for attorney general, of regularly paying for sex and using illegal drugs. He was also accused of having sexual relations in 2017 with a 17-year-old girl, who  was also paid.

headline: Trump’s Wish to Control Greenland and Panama Canal: Not a Joke This Time
abstract: In recent days the president-elect has called for asserting U.S. control over the Panama Canal and Greenland, showing that his “America First” philosophy has an expansionist dimension.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two days, President-elect Donald J. Trump has made clear that he has designs for American territorial expansion, declaring that the United States has both security concerns and commercial interests that can best be addressed by bringing the Panama Canal and Greenland under American control or outright ownership.

headline: Steven Englander, Leader of an Outsider Art Outpost, Dies at 63
abstract: As director of the fiercely independent cultural center ABC No Rio, he led the battle to halt its eviction and later raised money to build a new home for the organization.
lead_paragraph: Steven Englander, who helped lead the pioneering Lower East Side cultural center ABC No Rio for more than 25 years, directing the anarchistic, fiercely independent organization during a long clash with New York City over the occupancy of a crumbling building that ultimately preserved the group’s presence, died on Dec. 12 in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: Ethics Report Accused Gaetz of ‘Regularly’ Paying for Sex
abstract: Also, Biden commuted nearly every federal death sentence. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: A report released today by the House Ethics Committee said that former Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida regularly paid women for sex, had sex with an underage girl and used illegal drugs while he was in Congress.

headline: House Member in Senior Living Facility Draws Fresh Scrutiny to Aging Congress
abstract: Representative Kay Granger, Republican of Texas, has been largely absent from Capitol Hill since the summer and has moved into a retirement home.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, Representative Kay Granger of Texas made history when she became the first Republican woman to lead the powerful House Appropriations Committee.

headline: Donor Expected to Admit to Making Illegal Contributions to Adams
abstract: Federal prosecutors said they planned to charge a businessman who has close ties to New York’s Turkish community with conspiracy to commit fraud.
lead_paragraph: One of the businessmen whom the indictment of Mayor Eric Adams described as having made illegal donations to Mr. Adams’s 2021 campaign was expected to face a criminal charge and wishes to plead guilty, federal prosecutors said in a court filing on Monday.

headline: Here Comes Santa Claus’s Approval Rating
abstract: Despite some debates in the news, Americans’ views on Santa haven’t really changed, polls show. Most parents still say he’ll visit on Christmas Eve.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a vicious rumor going around the last few years that Santa Claus is falling out of fashion among this generation of parents. Some parents have worried on social media (and in advice columns) that furthering the Santa Claus myth with their children amounts to an endorsement of dishonesty, and could even be traumatizing when the truth comes out. Developmental psychologists have studied the debate.

headline: Part of Santa Cruz Wharf in California Collapses in High Surf
abstract: Three people were rescued from the wharf. The powerful surf also fatally trapped a man under debris on a beach in Santa Cruz, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The end of a wharf that draws visitors to Santa Cruz, Calif., collapsed in high surf on Monday, sending three people into the water, while a man died at a nearby beach after being trapped under debris by a wave, the authorities said.

headline: An Architect of Trump’s Tough Latin America Policies Is Named Envoy
abstract: A longtime proponent of harsh sanctions, Mauricio Claver-Carone was forced out of his job at the Inter-American Development Bank in 2022.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump signaled a return to his first term’s maximum-pressure policies against left-wing regimes on Sunday when he named a longtime foreign policy hawk known for hard-line positions on Cuba to be the special envoy for Latin America.

headline: Money for 9/11 Health Care Was Dropped from Year-End Spending Bill
abstract: A plan to ensure long-term funding to address health needs stemming from the terrorist attacks fell to the wayside after President-elect Donald Trump and Elon Musk objected to a bipartisan budget deal.
lead_paragraph: James Brosi, the president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association in New York, traveled to Washington last week to personally thank Speaker Mike Johnson for including long-term funding to help people with the lingering health effects from the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks as part of a bipartisan spending deal.

headline: I.R.S. to Send Out Unclaimed Tax Credit to One Million Taxpayers
abstract: Some Americans who qualified for a pandemic-era tax credit but did not claim it will get up to $1,400 in their account within the next month.
lead_paragraph: About one million taxpayers who were eligible for a pandemic-era tax credit in 2021 but did not claim it can expect a lump sum from the Internal Revenue Service in the coming weeks.

headline: Bill Clinton Is Hospitalized After Developing a Fever
abstract: A Washington hospital admitted Mr. Clinton for testing and observation, and an aide said that the former president was “in good spirits.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton was hospitalized in Washington for testing and observation on Monday afternoon after developing a fever, an aide said on social media.

headline: Matt Gaetz Finds Support in His Former District in Florida
abstract: Republicans in the Panhandle district he represented before stepping down last month said Mr. Gaetz had done good work in Congress and criticized the report as partisan.
lead_paragraph: As new allegations emerged with the release of the House Ethics Committee’s findings on Matt Gaetz, some of his supporters in his former district echoed Mr. Gaetz’s criticisms of the investigation as partisan and unfounded.

headline: New Anti-Money Laundering Measures Pass a Legal Roadblock
abstract: Millions of companies may have to report information about their owners to the Treasury Department by Jan. 1 under an appeals court ruling.
lead_paragraph: A group of American businesses faced a setback on Monday in their legal fight against a new federal anti-money-laundering law.

headline: Deputies Missed Signs Before a Detainee Hanged Himself
abstract: Reports and video footage newly released in Riverside County, Calif., indicate that a man was able to cover his cell window and camera without intervention.
lead_paragraph: Newly released videos and reports provide further evidence that sheriff’s deputies in Riverside County missed signs that a murder suspect awaiting trial at a Southern California jail was planning on taking his life.

headline: National Security Committee Forgoes Decision on U.S. Steel Acquisition
abstract: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States kicked a decision over the merger with Japan’s Nippon Steel to President Biden, who is expected to block the deal.
lead_paragraph: A powerful U.S. national security committee was unable to reach a conclusive decision about whether Japan’s Nippon Steel should be allowed to buy U.S. Steel, according to letters the federal committee sent to the companies and the White House on Monday.

headline: ‘Rust’ Prosecutor Withdraws Appeal of Alec Baldwin Case
abstract: The decision ends the criminal prosecution of the actor for the fatal shooting on a film set. During his trial, the judge dismissed the involuntary manslaughter charge against him.
lead_paragraph: The effort to prosecute Alec Baldwin for the fatal shooting of a cinematographer in 2021 ended on Monday when the special prosecutor withdrew her appeal of the judge’s decision to dismiss the involuntary manslaughter charge during the actor’s trial.

headline: The Men and Women Swirling Around Elon Musk
abstract: A look at the people who influence the world’s richest man, and those who stand to gain from their association with him now.
lead_paragraph: A look at the people who influence the world’s richest man, and those who stand to gain from their association with him now.

headline: Hochul Orders Firing of 14 Prison Workers After Fatal Attack on Inmate
abstract: Video of the deadly assault on Robert L. Brooks was “horrific,” “disturbing” and “devastating,” a lawyer for his family said after they watched it.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York has ordered that 13 corrections officers and a prison nurse be fired after the fatal beating of an inmate in an attack that their union called “incomprehensible.”

headline: Fragments of Santa Cruz Wharf Wash Ashore After Partial Collapse
abstract: Broken wood, debris and a building floated in the ocean after the end of the wharf collapsed.
lead_paragraph: Broken wood, debris and a building floated in the ocean after the end of the wharf collapsed.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about using data from vehicles that have wireless connectivity to study traffic patterns misstated the speed at which people were least likely to be wearing seat belts. It is while going more than 75 miles per hour, not 120 miles per hour.

headline: Ages and Ages
abstract: Sarah Sinclair breaks with tradition.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Baristas at More Than 300 Starbucks Stores Walk Out, Union Says
abstract: The strike began Friday at stores in the Los Angeles, Seattle and Chicago areas and will end on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A union representing more than 10,000 Starbucks employees said a strike that began Friday had expanded to include more than 300 stores on Tuesday, the planned final day of a five-day walkout.

headline: Quote of the Day: Gangs’ Tactical Looting of Aid Deepens Desperation for Gazans
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 24, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Today, the ordinary Gazan’s dream, his aspiration, is to obtain a piece of bread.”

headline: The Times’s Special History With ‘The Night Before Christmas’
abstract: The popular poem, actually titled “A Visit From St. Nicholas,” first appeared in The Times’s pages in 1896.
lead_paragraph: “In thousands of homes and by hundreds of thousands of children these words will soon be repeated: ‘’Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house / Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse.’”

headline: Why Mergers of Carmakers Like Honda and Nissan Often Falter
abstract: The Japanese companies are considering joining forces to survive in a rapidly changing auto industry, but auto history is filled with troubled and failed marriages.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese automakers Honda and Nissan are discussing a possible merger, in a bid to share costs and help themselves compete in a fast-changing and increasingly competitive industry.

headline: Is a Putin Ally in Eastern Europe Making a Cautious Overture to the West?
abstract: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus keeps arresting political opponents, but analysts wonder if a string of unusual pardons is a bid to get sanctions eased.
lead_paragraph: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the autocratic leader of the former Soviet republic of Belarus and an ardent backer of Russia in its war against Ukraine, seems to be back at an old game of maneuvering between East and West.

headline: Under Cambodia’s New Leader, Room for Dissent Narrows
abstract: Hun Manet, who took over as prime minister last year, has followed in the steps of his father, who ran Cambodia for nearly 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Until last year, most Cambodians had lived under only one leader. Hun Sen ruled as prime minister for nearly four decades, tightening his iron grip over the country and systematically silencing the opposition, activists and independent media.

headline: These Students Ousted a Government. Now They’re Rebuilding a Democracy.
abstract: It is a daunting task for Bangladesh. But an unusual mix of young people and seasoned technocrats are determined to make the most of their opening.
lead_paragraph: On a recent evening, in a brand-new office on the first floor of a commercial building where wires dangled from the ceiling and new flooring was still being laid, a group of university students were plotting a new future for Bangladesh.

headline: Sorting Fact From Fiction as Fear Engulfs Bangladesh’s Hindus
abstract: Reports of vandalism and mob violence are real, but wilder accusations emanating from India muddy the picture.
lead_paragraph: The reports, often accompanied by grainy footage, are frequent: Hindu temples vandalized and set on fire in Bangladesh, minority Hindus targeted and killed.

headline: He Inherited a Seat in Britain’s House of Lords. How Will It Feel to Lose It?
abstract: The U.K. government has pledged to remove hereditary peers from Parliament in 2025. For Lord Cromwell and 87 others, it is a wistful departure.
lead_paragraph: Godfrey John Bewicke-Copley, the 7th Baron Cromwell, traces his family’s title back to 1375. His forebears fought the French at the Battle of Agincourt. For the last decade, Lord Cromwell’s day job has been in Britain’s House of Lords, where he mulls legislation, runs to committee meetings and briskly greets fellow lawmakers in Parliament, many of whom are elected.

headline: The Fastest Spacecraft Ever Heads for Its Close-Up With the Sun
abstract: The Parker Solar Probe is attempting the closest ever pass of the sun’s surface on Christmas Eve.
lead_paragraph: This Christmas Eve, a vehicle will travel at incomprehensible speed around a celestial object to bring wonder to the people of Earth — and it’s not Santa’s sleigh.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee said that its lengthy investigation into Matt Gaetz, Donald Trump’s onetime pick for attorney general, found that he had regularly paid for sex and used illegal drugs. He was also accused of having paid for sexual relations in 2017 with a 17-year-old girl.

headline: Christmas? Hanukkah? This Year for Our Family, It’s Chrismukkah.
abstract: Like many members of interfaith families, I get to observe the two holidays on the same day this year.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, there was no Christmas tree, no ornaments, no goose or fruitcake. No, I’m not a member of the Cratchit family, I’m Jewish. Though I grew up largely secular, my family didn’t celebrate the Christian holiday in any way, except by touring the department store windows on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan a few times.

headline: I Come From a Long Line of Housecleaners. After Oct. 7, I Knew What to Do.
abstract: I come from a long line of house cleaners. After Oct. 7, I knew what to do.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of Oct. 7, 2023,, many Israelis felt abandoned by their government. Facing an absence of leadership, volunteer operations popped up to help victims recover. People from around the country stepped in to help with agricultural work and gathered donations for 130,000 internally displaced people.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: A New Way to Shrink Class Sizes: Let Schools Take Charge
abstract: This year, schools were encouraged to come up with their own plans to lower their class sizes and apply to the Department of Education for funding.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, New York State lawmakers passed a measure that required New York City’s public schools to lower their class sizes at a time when the city was in the midst of profound change.

headline: How Drone Fever Spread Across New Jersey and Beyond
abstract: The first sighting was at a military site in New Jersey, then the phenomenon spread into neighboring states. Government assurances that most “drones” were not drones at all have not tamped down curiosity.
lead_paragraph: It was a dry and cool Wednesday evening outside the Army’s Picatinny Arsenal in New Jersey, a longtime military installation that once made the bombs and shells that led to victory in World War II. A contractor there knocked off work and decided to wait out rush hour traffic. He picked up some takeout from Wawa, parked outside a nearby wildlife preserve and settled in to watch an episode of Joe Rogan’s podcast on his phone. Then he saw a flash in the side mirror.

headline: The Hardest Conversation to Have With Your Parents
abstract: Sex is a big part of life. Why is it so hard to talk to family members about it?
lead_paragraph: Sex is a big part of life. Why is it so hard to talk to family members about it?

headline: Christians in Gaza, Huddled in Churches, Celebrate Christmas: ‘We’re Still Here’
abstract: Some say that the community is in danger of losing its 1,600-year foothold in the enclave and that it is far from certain those who have fled will ever feel safe enough to return home.
lead_paragraph: Ramez Souri, a Christian in Gaza, says he has little to celebrate this Christmas. Fourteen months into the war, he still sleeps on the grounds of St. Porphyrius, the ancient Greek Orthodox church in Gaza City where an Israeli airstrike last year killed his three children.

headline: An English City Dressed a Statue as Santa for Years. Then It Vanished.
abstract: The Old General watched over Nottingham, England, for more than a century of profound change before disappearing. This Christmas, he’s finally back.
lead_paragraph: At six feet, the statue was taller than the man ever was. Carved roughly from limestone, his large shoulders hunched under a bright red jacket, the likeness of the man known as the Old General had held its perch in Nottingham, England, for nearly a century, suspended in a display window above the front door of the local pub.

headline: Clean and Calm, in Grays, Blacks and Whites
abstract: A couple found plenty of sunlight in their new house in Chicago. All that was needed was the added “coolness.”
lead_paragraph: When Helen Han and Dan Pan began having children, they quickly realized their apartment in Chicago wasn’t going to cut it much longer.

headline: Mel Robbins Wants You to Lose Control
abstract: The self-help phenom’s new book is all about letting others do as they may. Can she follow her own advice?
lead_paragraph: As Mel Robbins tells it, the concept for her new self-help book, “The Let Them Theory,” came to her on the night of her son Oakley’s junior prom. Overcome by the realization that her youngest child would soon be leaving her, Robbins coped by micromanaging the scene. She pressured Oakley to give his date a corsage. Fretted about the weather. Worried that the teenagers hadn’t made a dinner reservation.

headline: Support in the Teen Mental Health Crisis
abstract: UJA-Federation has worked for decades to fight loneliness among New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Rates of anxiety and depression in adolescents have been rising for years. Millions of Americans with mental health problems are not getting the treatment they need for myriad reasons. Many families can’t afford it. And many young people also don’t know where to turn for help.

headline: A Visual Guide to the Tangled Alliances and Rivalries in Syria
abstract: After the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, old alliances have crumbled, and global powers are figuring out their relationships with Syria’s new de facto leaders.
lead_paragraph: After the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, old alliances have crumbled, and global powers are figuring out their relationships with Syria’s new de facto leaders.

headline: I’m Lactose-Intolerant. Can I Eat Dairy Anyway?
abstract: Some dairy products are easier to digest than others. Here’s how to identify the ones that may cause the least trouble.
lead_paragraph: Q: I recently learned that I’m lactose-intolerant. Do I really need to avoid all dairy, or are some products safe to eat?

headline: Behind Afghanistan’s Fall, U.S.-Backed Militias Worse Than the Taliban
abstract: Trump blamed Biden. Biden blamed the Afghan military. Our investigation found that the U.S. unwittingly laid the groundwork for the Taliban’s victory long ago.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban were inching closer, encroaching on land that had once seemed secure, the American officer warned. Four of his men had just been killed, and he needed Afghans willing to fight back.

headline: The Year in Rap: Beneath Kendrick vs. Drake, a Thriving Underground Roils
abstract: A new generation of hip-hop artists seems less interested in becoming stars and more in becoming myths — and dismantling the status quo.
lead_paragraph: The beef between Kendrick Lamar and Drake absorbed a great deal of oxygen this year, and from a distance it might appear that all the stakes for hip-hop in 2024 boiled down to this war of titans. But if anything, that battle was a head fake — the genre was innovating and mutating at a rapid clip in smaller scenes, and it began to feel as if the biggest stars were largely preoccupied with each other, not with what’s transpiring down below.

headline: A Different Spin on Dog Hair: Knitting With It
abstract: “Knitting With Dog Hair,” a classic how-to book from the 1990s by Kendall Crolius, fueled a dedicated movement. An updated 30th anniversary edition was published this month.
lead_paragraph: An affable tumbleweed.

headline: Last Call for Neon in New York City
abstract: Signs at 30 Rockefeller Plaza and the Apollo Theater are among the latest to lose their vintage glow in favor of LED lighting.
lead_paragraph: For nearly eight decades, the warm glow of a handcrafted red-and-white neon sign beckoned passers-by outside the White Horse Tavern in Greenwich Village. Dylan Thomas, Jack Kerouac and Bob Dylan all imbibed at the storied watering hole, which opened in 1880.

headline: 22 of the Best Bakeries Across the U.S. Right Now
abstract: In this golden age of American bakeries, virtuosic pastries and delightful breads are close at hand, from coastal Maine to downtown Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, in major cities and small towns, a bakery renaissance is underway, fueled by a convergence of economics, post-Covid restaurant changes, diners’ tastes and the marketing power of social media. Which is a fancy way of saying that there are so many amazing things coming out of ovens in so many places, made with rigor by former fine-dining pastry chefs and entrepreneurial hobbyists-turned-professionals alike. This is a great time for American bakeries, and here are some of the standard bearers we have loved from our travels over the last year. BRIAN GALLAGHER

headline: Questions Emerge About Data Used by China to Defend Against Doping Allegations
abstract: China and the World Anti-Doping Agency say that positive tests for a banned drug among elite Chinese swimmers were a result of unwitting contamination. But the science behind that assertion is not so clear.
lead_paragraph: Since the revelation that 23 elite Chinese swimmers tested positive before the 2021 Olympics for a banned performance-enhancing drug, Chinese and antidoping officials have repeatedly defended their decision not to discipline the athletes by invoking scientific analysis.

headline: ‘A Christmas Carol’ Comes Back Every Year. So Does This Actress.
abstract: Over three decades, Sally Vahle has played Scrooge, ghosts and many of the other characters in Dallas Theater Center’s annual production of the Dickens classic.
lead_paragraph: Sally Nystuen Vahle bursts into “A Christmas Carol” from some hellscape beneath Ebenezer Scrooge’s bed, snarling as a wretched, writhing ghost with blood-red hands before being dragged back toward torment by the chains with which she is bound.

headline: The Timeless Spell of Rome’s Oldest Churches
abstract: During the upcoming Jubilee year, millions of Christian pilgrims will flock to the Eternal City’s innumerable holy places. Here are five gorgeous churches that may offer a less-crowded experience.
lead_paragraph: It’s a common complaint that Rome’s churches are overwhelming: There are too many, they look too much alike, their gilt and marble often speak more to the eye than the soul. During the Jubilee year of 2025, when some 30 million Catholic pilgrims are expected to flock to the Eternal City in search of spiritual forgiveness, the ecclesiastical abundance will be compounded by crowds.

headline: What I’m Thinking at the End of 2024
abstract: Ezra Klein answers listener questions about fatherhood, ‘normalizing’ Trump and his outlook on 2025.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: If You’re Worried About the Future of Our Country, Do Something About It
abstract: Involvement in issues beyond the immediate scope of one’s personal life and work, undertaken for the greater good, is more important than ever.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, when I was a co-senior partner at Goldman Sachs, younger people sometimes asked me for advice. I told them, “First, become really good at what you do, and then branch out to get involved in activities and issues in the wider world beyond your work.”

headline: Flaco, Manhattan’s Beloved Celebrity Owl, Gets His Close-Up
abstract: In a new book, two photographers memorialize the bird that charmed New York City and the world.
lead_paragraph: On a drizzly morning earlier this month, Jacqueline Emery pointed to a grassy embankment near the northeastern corner of Central Park and said, “This is where we stood.”

headline: The Mysterious Donor Who Fled Communism and Left Millions to the Art World
abstract: Aso O. Tavitian grew up poor — but at age 64 he began an ‘‘explosion of buying.” Under the radar, he amassed old masters, leaving 331 to the Clark. How did he do it?
lead_paragraph: He did it all quietly. “Nothing about him said, ‘Look at me,’” said Candace Beinecke, president of Aso O. Tavitian’s foundation.

headline: Has Seattle’s ‘Belltown Hellcat’ Lost Its Fearsome Roar?
abstract: A modified Dodge Charger that blasted neighbors out of their sleep appears to have gone quiet, at least downtown, as its owner deals with legal problems.
lead_paragraph: He has been arrested and fined and ordered to modify his raucous vehicle. Now those legal troubles are compounding for Miles Hudson, better known in Seattle as the city’s infamous “Belltown Hellcat.”

headline: You’re Never Too Old to Have ‘the Talk’
abstract: Sex is a big part of life. Why is it so hard to talk to family members about it?
lead_paragraph: Most of us would probably rather die than talk with family about our sex lives. But in the Opinion video above, adult children and parents illuminate a path for having frank conversations about sex.

headline: 5 Getaways for a Cozy Winter Escape
abstract: From Austria to Montana, we found a tempting array of hotels, resorts and other getaways for the perfect winter vacation.
lead_paragraph: It’s the time of year for s’mores and snuggling by a fire, and at these five cozy escapes — four new, and one pulling out the stops for its 200th anniversary — you can make the most of the season. Wander snowy trails and savor hearty cuisine at a boutique hotel in the Catskills, taste wine and play board games at a stylish ranch by Yosemite National Park, even learn the art of yodeling at a hideaway in the Austrian Alps. From a handsome room for two at a Victorian hotel in Ireland to a contemporary mountain home for the whole family in Montana, you just might find yourself wishing for winter to last.

headline: ‘The Fire Inside’ Review: When the Fight Isn’t in the Ring
abstract: The story of the boxer Claressa Shields could have been just another sports movie. Directed by Rachel Morrison and penned by Barry Jenkins, it’s much more than that.
lead_paragraph: Two years before the Flint Water Crisis became national news, a teenage boxer named Claressa Shields, who was born and raised in Flint, won a gold medal at the London Olympics. It was 2012, the first year that women could box at the Olympics, and at 17, Shields was the youngest boxer there. She blew the competition away — and four years later, she’d do it again, becoming the only American boxer, regardless of gender, to pull off that feat.

headline: What Does a Sugar Plum Fairy Sound Like?
abstract: Meet the celesta.
lead_paragraph: In the 1890s, when the Russian composer Tchaikovsky was preparing to write the music for the ballet that would become his holiday classic, “The Nutcracker,” he encountered a brand-new instrument: the celesta. Its glassy, bell-like sound bewitched him. And, as The New York Times’s Joshua Barone reports, the way Tchaikovsky ultimately deployed the instrument in his famous “Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy” has echoed through musical history.

headline: What We Can Learn From the First Truly Modern Composer
abstract: Ferruccio Busoni, who died 100 years ago, was a globe-trotting, forward-thinking composer and teacher with a message of timelessness in music.
lead_paragraph: When Ferruccio Busoni died, in 1924, the composer Kurt Weill wrote that “with him, one of the greatest artistic personalities of all time has passed.”

headline: Sunn’s Chinatown Is a Permanent Space for Its Banchan and More
abstract: Barlume offers up Mediterranean, Casa moves a to a larger TriBeCa home for its Brazilian fare and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Sunny Lee — who worked at Blue Hill, Eleven Madison Park and Insa, and has been doing banchan pop-ups — now has her own place, in partnership with the restaurateur and wine merchant Grant Reynolds. The brick-walled dining room is where you’ll find a Korean spicy tuna roll, a crab gyeranmari omelet and hobak chigae, a squash and short rib stew. Mr. Reynolds’s people are seeing to the wines, soju, makgeolli and lagers. On New Year’s Day Ms. Lee will open at 11 a.m. and serve bowls of tteokguk, a short rib and oxtail broth with sliced rice cake coins for prosperity, an omelet topping and aged kimchi alongside.

headline: David Brooks: I Found Faith in a Crowded Subway Car
abstract: The Times columnist shares his midlife journey from agnosticism to belief.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, the Times columnist David Brooks has gone from agnostic to deeply religious. In this episode he explores the evolving role of faith in his life, a force he describes as “a longing.” As he explains, “The joy is not in the satisfaction of the longing, but the joy is in the longing itself. It’s a good feeling to worship generosity itself.”

headline: The Golden Age of American Bakeries Is Upon Us. Here’s Why.
abstract: A combination of economics, taste and the post-Covid restaurant landscape is making this a great time for craft carbs in America.
lead_paragraph: Alen Ramos and Carolyn Nugent had worked side-by-side in the kitchens of some of the best restaurants in the world, including El Bulli on the Spanish coast and the Fat Duck in the English countryside. But they finally found their calling in the Denver suburbs.

headline: Marv From ‘Home Alone’ Has a New Calling Card: Tangerines and Sculpture
abstract: Daniel Stern has built a social media following by documenting daily life on his family’s farm. “What a crazy way to walk through life,” he said, “to be a little part of people’s lives.”
lead_paragraph: The end of the year may be associated with the holiday season for many, but Daniel Stern refers to it as something else: the “Home Alone” time.

headline: Will Troubled Police Departments Escape Federal Accountability?
abstract: As time runs out for the Biden administration, cities like Minneapolis — where an investigation found abuse and racial discrimination — may avoid oversight.
lead_paragraph: Elected on the heels of global protests over police brutality, President Joseph R. Biden Jr. promised broad reform to American policing.

headline: Why It Matters That Jesus Came From a Dysfunctional Family
abstract: He identified with the least and the lowliest — not just those in his lineage but also those in his life.
lead_paragraph: One of the forgotten facts of the story of Jesus’ life is that he came from a profoundly dysfunctional family.

headline: Trump Will Confront a More Vulnerable but Determined Iran
abstract: “Coercive diplomacy” could leave Tehran to choose either a negotiated disassembly of its nuclear capability, or a forced one.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump will encounter an Iran that is suddenly far more brittle than it was during his first administration, its leadership more uncertain, its nuclear program more exposed and vulnerable to attack.

headline: Elon Musk Is Creating His Own Texas Town. Hundreds Already Live There.
abstract: Employees of SpaceX have filed a formal petition to create the city of Starbase. Its first mayor would be a security manager for the company.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, Elon Musk has expanded his footprint in Texas, moving his companies from California and building offices, warehouses and manufacturing plants across a growing number of Texas counties.

headline: As Rome Prepares for a Tourist Surge, Residents Fear Losing the City’s Soul
abstract: The Catholic Jubilee in 2025 is expected to draw 32 million visitors. Officials are proud of the city’s accompanying makeover, but residents lament soaring housing costs and changes in Rome’s character.
lead_paragraph: Roman drivers finally got some relief on Monday when, after 450 days of traffic chaos and unprintable curses, a ribbon-cutting ceremony heralded the opening of an underpass along the Tiber River near the Vatican that immediately cleared traffic from what is now Rome’s largest pedestrian area.

headline: What a Photographer Saw in New York’s Migrant Shelters
abstract: For months, a photographer and a reporter documented what daily life was like for those living in hotels, tent facilities and former offices across the city.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll hear from a photographer who documented the rhythms and routines in shelters that are home to migrants who arrived in New York City after crossing the southern border. We’ll also get details on a plan for a 72-story apartment tower and a hotel across from the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,285
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: How a Skeptical Critic Came to Love Bad Christmas Movies
abstract: The season’s Hallmark and Netflix movies are corny, predictable and just what our critic needed to embrace the holiday spirit.
lead_paragraph: The story of how a big-city culture critic, Amanda Hess, found love where she least expected it — in the monotony of Hallmark’s Christmas movies.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 563
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Israel Intercepts Houthi Missile and Threatens Militant Group’s Leaders
abstract: Israel said it had repelled an attack, which came hours after Israel’s defense minister vowed to “behead” the Yemeni group’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: The Houthi militia group in Yemen fired a missile at Israel on Tuesday, hours after Israel’s defense minister suggested that his government would seek to kill its leadership, highlighting the difficulty Israel faces in confronting the Iran-backed militants as they ramp up their assaults.

headline: A Day for Games
abstract: Here are a few you can play during the holidays.
lead_paragraph: When you look back on 2024, who comes to mind?

headline: Dutch Court Issues Prison Sentences Over Violence Against Israeli Soccer Fans
abstract: Five people were found guilty of crimes, including public violence, in relation to attacks targeting Israelis in Amsterdam last month.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch court on Tuesday found five people guilty of public violence or incitement of public violence, the first rulings related to last month’s assaults against Israeli soccer fans surrounding a ​match in Amsterdam between an Israeli team and a Dutch team.

headline: Delays Grow After American Airlines Grounds U.S. Flights Over Technical Issue
abstract: Bad weather made delays worse after problems with systems used to release flights on one of the busiest travel days of the year.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of travelers trying to make it to their loved ones for the holidays were stuck at airports through much of Tuesday after American Airlines briefly grounded all its flights in the United States because of a technical issue and bad weather made those delays worse.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Activists Removed From Michigan’s Student Government
abstract: The president and vice president of the University of Michigan’s student assembly were impeached after they demanded divestment and stopped funding campus activities.
lead_paragraph: Alifa Chowdhury’s successful campaign to lead the University of Michigan’s student government promised just one thing: to block financing for campus groups until the university agreed to divest from companies that Ms. Chowdhury said profited from the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My Mother Upstaged Jesus’
abstract: To celebrate the season, we gathered five of our favorite holiday-themed Tiny Love Stories.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine years ago, my mother upstaged Jesus by dying right before Christmas. I was a single mother of a 4-year-old. I made the season merry for my daughter, though inside I felt like the sun would never shine. Over the years, I accepted that sadness would arrive around December. I greeted it at the door with a cocktail in hand — recently, with a pot of coffee. Sad and happy memories will always sit together at my holiday table, like restless houseguests. In the new year, happiness extends its stay while sadness slips quietly out the door. — Gloria Barone Rosanio

headline: Why ‘A Christmas Carol’ Endures
abstract: More than 180 years after its publication, “A Christmas Carol” by Charles Dickens is more relevant than ever.
lead_paragraph: Since its publication in December 1843, “A Christmas Carol” by Charles Dickens has been a cherished presence during the holiday season. The novella — which Dickens wrote to make money when he was broke — has not gone out of print once in more than 180 years and has been adapted into dozens of movies, stage productions, musicals and mini series, attracting stars from Alastair Sim to the Muppets. Today one can hardly think of Christmas without thinking of Scrooge, the Cratchits and Tiny Tim’s “God bless us, every one.”

headline: Quiz: Do You Speak 2024?
abstract: A varied assortment of words entered (or re-entered) the lexicon this year. How well do you know them?
lead_paragraph: Love it or hate it, language is always evolving. This year, the words of the moment seemed to morph at an ever-faster pace, thanks to the momentum of TikTok trends.

headline: Russia Sentences U.S. Citizen to 15 Years for Espionage
abstract: Eugene Spector was already serving a sentence for a bribery conviction when he was charged with spying, for which a court ordered him to serve an additional 13 years.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court sentenced a U.S. citizen on Tuesday to 15 years in a high-security prison for espionage, state media outlets reported, prompting speculation that the Kremlin might seek to use him as leverage in negotiations for a future prisoner swap.

headline: How a Consulting Firm and Trump’s I.R.S. Pick Pushed a Problematic Tax Credit
abstract: Billy Long worked with Lifetime Advisors, a company that solicited clients to claim a pandemic-era tax credit that the I.R.S. said became a magnet for fraud.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Werfel, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, testified before a House committee early this year, he tried to explain how a pandemic-era program had become an expensive government boondoggle.

headline: The 12,000-Year-Old Wolves That Ate Like Dogs
abstract: Animal remains unearthed in Alaska give clues to how wolves were domesticated.
lead_paragraph: As the Late Pleistocene ice age drew to a close, people and wolves began to bond. From there, it was just a few millenniums to puppy yoga and dog influencers. But the details of exactly how and when wolves were tamed and domesticated remain up for intense debate.

headline: Justin Baldoni’s Ex-Publicist Sues Over Alleged Smear Campaign
abstract: An ousted P.R. executive alleges a conspiracy to harm her and steal her clients, in connection with an effort to tarnish Blake Lively.
lead_paragraph: A former publicist for the actor and director Justin Baldoni filed a lawsuit on Tuesday that adds a new dimension to an alleged campaign to undermine the actress Blake Lively. The publicist, Stephanie Jones, said she was forced out of representing Mr. Baldoni and his film studio amid concerns that Ms. Lively would go public with accusations of misconduct against him.

headline: Chicken and Rice With Ginger; Lemony Shrimp and Bean Stew
abstract: And three more one-pot dinners, because you’ve got better things to do than the dishes.
lead_paragraph: Happy holidays, everyone! It’s my last newsletter of the year, and I have a gift for you: five recipes with as little cleanup as possible.

headline: Meditations About Finding Faith
abstract: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks. Also: The Gaetz report; qualifications to serve in the government.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Perry Dahl, Who Downed Nine Planes During World War II, Dies at 101
abstract: His courage in battle brought him the Congressional Gold Medal, the Silver Star, the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Legion of Merit.
lead_paragraph: Col. Perry Dahl, an Army Air Forces fighter pilot who shot down nine enemy aircraft in the Pacific during World War II while surviving emergency landings, a runway crash, a midair bailout and two days in a life raft, died on Dec. 2 at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 101.

headline: Blake Lively Turns the Shame Around
abstract: The actress’s lawsuit may prolong a humiliating episode for her. But the only way to end impunity is to speak up.
lead_paragraph: The actress Blake Lively worked with me on a 2015 PBS documentary exploring sex trafficking in the United States. She was shaken by what we found, deeply compassionate toward survivors and willing to look unflinchingly at an ugliness that many avert their eyes from.

headline: Elon Musk’s xAI Raises $6 Billion in New Funding
abstract: “A lot of compute is needed,” Mr. Musk said in a post about the financing, in which BlackRock, Fidelity and Sequoia participated.
lead_paragraph: The artificial intelligence company founded by Elon Musk, xAI, said on Monday that it had raised $6 billion, giving the start-up a major lift as it competes with rivals, including OpenAI.

headline: Bill Clinton Is Released From Hospital After Having Flu
abstract: The former president was discharged Tuesday morning after being admitted to a hospital on Monday after developing a fever.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton has been released from a hospital in the Washington area after being treated for the flu, an aide said on Tuesday.

headline: History Shows Big Changes in ‘Big Government’ Are Hard to Achieve
abstract: Past efforts to shrink the federal bureaucracy, including basic things like selling off unused government buildings, have come up short. Republicans are set to try again.
lead_paragraph: When the Newt Gingrich-led Republican Revolution swept the G.O.P. into power in the House in 1994 for the first time in 40 years and Republicans also won the Senate, the newly invigorated party set out to revolutionize Washington, shrink the bureaucracy and reduce the federal footprint.

headline: Spending Fight Shows Limits of Trump Power to Change Fiscal Path
abstract: Efforts to cut government spending and eliminate waste are dwarfed by the rising costs of the social safety net programs and interest expenses.
lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, the businessmen that President-elect Donald J. Trump tapped to lead his new Department of Government Efficiency, met with lawmakers in early December, they laid out their plans for cutting federal spending and eliminating waste.

headline: ‘Everything Calls for Salvation’ Is a Beachy Italian Drama
abstract: The seven-episode first season, on Netflix, plays out like a sunnier Italian “Girl, Interrupted.”
lead_paragraph: “Everything Calls for Salvation” is an Italian drama on Netflix (in Italian, with subtitles, or dubbed) about a young man who wakes up in a psychiatric ward. Daniele (Federico Cesari) can’t remember the night before or what prompted this involuntary hold, and he doesn’t think he belongs alongside some of the more ill patients. How is he ever going to make it a week? And why are his parents so mad at him? And why are all the doctors being so abrasive?

headline: Raging Waves Batter California’s Coast and Its Beloved Piers
abstract: An increasingly ferocious and volatile surf is raising questions about the future of the state’s piers, which have defined the coastline for generations.
lead_paragraph: The towering waves that have hammered California’s coast this week have been unusually destructive, killing at least one person and prompting warnings by officials to the public to stay away from the state’s beaches.

headline: I Never Felt Like This in China Before
abstract: America must compete with China, but there’s also a complicated reality that both countries have to face.
lead_paragraph: There were a lot of raised eyebrows and quiet chuckles this month when President-elect Donald Trump invited President Xi Jinping to Washington for his inauguration. Foreign leaders don’t attend our inaugurations, of course, but I think Trump’s idea was actually a good one. Having just returned from a trip to China, I can tell you that if I were drawing a picture of relations between our two countries today, it would be two elephants looking at each other through a straw.

headline: Olympic Snowboarder From Switzerland Dies in Avalanche at 26
abstract: Sophie Hediger, who competed in the 2022 Olympics in Beijing, died in an avalanche in Arosa, Switzerland, according to the police and the Swiss ski federation.
lead_paragraph: Sophie Hediger, a member of Switzerland’s national snowboard cross team, who competed in the Beijing Winter Olympics in 2022, died on Monday in an avalanche in the Swiss Alps, the country’s ski federation said. She was 26.

headline: How to Track Santa: NORAD’s Radars Are on the Case
abstract: Children and the young at heart can see where in the world Santa is and how many gifts have been delivered.
