After his death in 1762, defenders of slavery set out to prove that no person like Williams — both Black and brilliant — could possibly exist. In 1774 Edward Long wrote an account of Williams’s life that was little more than a racist diatribe, denigrating his many abilities. And for centuries, that’s where things stood.

headline: The Bald Eagle Is (Finally) the National Bird of the United States
abstract: The bird of brown and white feathers has long represented the United States as a majestic and soaring symbol, but only this week did a law make it official.
lead_paragraph: The bald eagle received a title this week that many may have assumed it already had: the national bird of the United States.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 27, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Sunday about Ann Rockefeller Roberts, a champion of the rights, welfare and culture of Native Americans, misstated the original location in Manhattan of the Heye Foundation collection of Native American artifacts, which she was instrumental in moving. It was Washington Heights, not Hamilton Heights.

headline: South Korean Lawmakers Impeach Acting President as Crisis Deepens
abstract: The vote was the second major impeachment in two weeks after President Yoon’s ill-fated martial law bid set off turmoil. The country’s currency has plunged.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s leadership crisis deepened on Friday after lawmakers voted to oust a second head of state, the acting president, in less than two weeks.

headline: The Stuff of Legends
abstract: Jem Burch opens our weekend solving.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Two Sailors Die During Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race
abstract: The men suffered head injuries on their yachts in separate episodes, as participants faced challenging weather conditions.
lead_paragraph: Two sailors taking part in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race died in separate accidents overnight during wild weather, the Australian authorities said Friday. They were the first deaths in decades during the annual race, which is one of the most prestigious in the world.

headline: N.F.L. Christmas Games on Netflix Break Streaming Records, With Beyoncé’s Help
abstract: The two games had more than 24 million viewers on average in the United States, Netflix said. Viewership peaked when Beyoncé performed.
lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Chiefs and the Baltimore Ravens notched big Christmas Day victories on their way to the playoffs, and the Netflix streams of those games reaped record ratings.

headline: Quote of the Day: Intricate Sculpture? Root Vegetable? In Vibrant Oaxaca, It’s Both.
abstract: Quote of the Day for Friday, December 27, 2024
lead_paragraph: “It reminds me of my childhood, when they said, ‘Don’t play with your food.’ But here they say, ‘Sculpt something with your food.’”

headline: Yes, Kwanzaa Is Made Up. That’s Why It’s Great
abstract: There’s something uniquely American in both its wanton borrowing from existing tradition and its naked admission of artificiality.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on Dec. 19, 2023.

headline: Running From Shame (for 26.2 Miles)
abstract: After having an affair with a married man, I ran a marathon to absolve my sins. It didn’t work.
lead_paragraph: My first marathon, 15 years ago, was a cry for help. A silent cry, it turned out, because I told almost no one. I signed up for the race in Fresno, Calif., to try to erase a bad year. I figured if I pushed my body hard enough, it would somehow clean my slate and absolve my sins.

headline: Sharing the Spotlight on Their Wedding Day
abstract: Stephanie Morrison and Scott Platt weren’t the center of attention at their wedding. Instead, they shared the day with Ms. Morrison’s beloved aunt, who has a rare condition.
lead_paragraph: When Stephanie Elizabeth Kanani Morrison married Scott Matthew Platt last month in Hawaii, she was more than happy to share the limelight with another woman — a maternal aunt, Frances Nora Wilsey, whom she cares for full time.

headline: A Summer Beach Encounter Leads to a Seaside Proposal
abstract: Kim Mannino and Glenn Alterman met in the Hamptons in July 2020, and by Labor Day knew their connection was more than a passing flirtation.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Ann Mannino and Glenn Stuart Alterman were instantly attracted to each other when they first met on a beach in Montauk, N.Y., in July 2020 through their mutual friends, Emma Silverman and Jeff Shocket.

headline: An Unexpected Proposal, Then a First Date Days Later
abstract: When Cori Harris and Edgar Hayes met at a local supermarket checkout line, she thought he looked like a wizard from “The Lord of the Rings.” A mutual crush emerged.
lead_paragraph: Cori Gail Harris wasn’t feeling great this past August when a man who reminded her of a character from “The Lord of the Rings” pushed his cart into her lane at the IGA supermarket.

headline: It All Started With a Brief Touch on the Shoulder
abstract: Justin Baiardi and Kiera Rommel began chatting while he was working as a nightclub bouncer. “It was so magnetic,” she said of their interaction.
lead_paragraph: Justin Cole Baiardi was accustomed to keeping people out of locations. But when Mr. Baiardi, a bouncer at the Woods in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, saw Kiera Lynn Rommel on March 19, 2016, all he wanted to do was let her in.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: A mysterious vessel in Finnish waters.
lead_paragraph: The Finnish authorities yesterday boarded and seized an oil tanker in Finnish waters on the suspicion that it was involved in cutting vital undersea cables as an act of sabotage. The ship is registered in the Cook Islands in the South Pacific, and it had been sailing from St. Petersburg, Russia, to Port Said, Egypt, when it was detained.

headline: How Would You Do if You Went to Space for Eight Days and Were Gone Six Months?
abstract: Astronauts are made of different stuff from you and me.
lead_paragraph: Most of us would panic if we were stranded in space without a firm return date. But Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore aren’t like most of us.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Months After Hamptons Tragedy, Widow Contends With a Tangle of Debt
abstract: On Instagram, Candice Miller showed the world glittering parties and vacations. When her husband, Brandon Miller, died, he had $33.6 million in debt and just $8,000 in the bank.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Miller might have been largely unknown if not for “Mama and Tata,” the Instagram account of his wife, Candice Miller. For years, she enticed a following of tens of thousands of voyeurs by sharing copious photos of their vintage-cars-private-planes-deep-sea-yachts lifestyle.

headline: A Century of Human Detritus, Visualized
abstract: “Technostuff” built in the last 100 years outweighs all the living matter on Earth.
lead_paragraph: Call us Homo slobbus.

headline: A Key to Unlocking Better Health for Latinos
abstract: The Hispanic Federation has made improving access to health insurance the focus of its work.
lead_paragraph: A lack of medical coverage is hurting the quality of life for millions of people in America, and Latinos have been disproportionately affected. They are among the least likely to have health insurance, they are more likely to die from diabetes than non-Hispanic white Americans, and they are less likely to have routine medical examinations or get treatment for debilitating conditions, a disparity that was exacerbated during the Covid pandemic. That’s why improving access to health insurance is a major focus of the Hispanic Federation, an organization that supports Latino communities through education, advocacy and funding for other nonprofits.

headline: Syria’s Alawite Minority, Favored by the Assads, Looks Nervously to the Future
abstract: Amid an outcry for justice and accountability and threats online, a once-dominant group is feeling deep anxiety after the ouster of Syria’s dictator.
lead_paragraph: The walls of the mausoleum for late President Hafez al-Assad are scrawled with graffiti now — things that Syrians have long felt but could never say aloud during his family’s five-decade dictatorship.

headline: Safari on Your Bucket List? Pick the Right One.
abstract: Choosing an operator that is conservation-minded, with ties to the local community and well-trained guides can add up to the trip of a lifetime and also nurture nature.
lead_paragraph: Last year, an alarming video posted online recorded four-wheel-drive safari vehicles in Kenya’s Masai Mara Reserve racing after hunting cheetahs and nearly scaring them off their kill.

headline: Wall St. Is Minting Easy Money From Risky Loans. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: Everyone from Jamie Dimon to the International Monetary Fund is ringing alarms about the shadowy world of private credit. But the money keeps rolling in.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2015, in the back booth of the retro Putnam Restaurant in Greenwich, Conn., Craig Packer, a partner at Goldman Sachs, sat across from Doug Ostrover and listened to an audacious pitch.

headline: 12 Ways to Get Fitter in 2025
abstract: Here are some ideas to get you moving in the year ahead.
lead_paragraph: At its core, the secret to a healthy fitness routine is simple: Find ways to move. There are limitless options these days, but the best exercise is whatever you enjoy enough to keep doing it.

headline: Trump Disparaged Africa. So Why Are Some Africans Optimistic?
abstract: In his first term, Donald Trump denigrated African nations, but leaders there are hopeful his return will bring more investment and less pressure to uphold democracy and human rights.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s impending return to the White House has raised hopes among some African leaders, who expect it could lead to more investment, more trade deals and less lecturing on issues like democracy and human rights.

headline: The Novel About U.S. Politics So Outrageous It Nearly Wasn’t Published
abstract: Robert Coover’s “The Public Burning” was met with bafflement and awe when it appeared in 1977. Reality has finally caught up to his masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: It was a congressional aide, of all people, who clued me in to “The Public Burning,” Robert Coover’s magnificent novel about American politics, which is even more relevant today than when first published, to puzzlement and acclaim, in 1977. We were eating pastrami sandwiches on I Street in Washington, D.C., sometime during the hopeful early days of the Biden administration, and I asked the aide for a tip — one never just has lunch or a drink in Washington. Instead of conveying the latest piece of Capitol Hill gossip, as is the norm, he directed me to Coover’s classic.

headline: Flood-Soaked Homeowners Face a Costly Choice: Raise or Raze
abstract: As climate change intensifies, flooding is emerging as a threat for homes not previously seen as high-risk. Some residents are responding creatively by lifting up their homes.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after moving into their home in St. Petersburg, Fla., Meghan Martin and her husband noticed a drawback to their new neighborhood. The quiet streets of Shore Acres, a leafy community bisected by canals, occasionally flooded. On some days it was easiest for Dr. Martin, a pediatric E.R. doctor, to reach the hospital by paddle board — a feat she once demonstrated in a widely viewed TikTok.

headline: The E.P.A. Promotes Toxic Fertilizer. 3M Told It of Risks Years Ago.
abstract: The agency obtained research from 3M in 2003 revealing that sewage sludge, the raw material for the fertilizer, carried toxic “forever chemicals.”
lead_paragraph: In early 2000, scientists at 3M, the chemicals giant, made a startling discovery: High levels of PFAS, the virtually indestructible “forever chemicals” used in nonstick pans, stain-resistant carpets and many other products were turning up in the nation’s sewage.

headline: 5 Small but Mighty Games You May Have Missed This Year
abstract: Explore a clone-filled pandemic, take charge of a newspaper’s recovery or delve into the mind of a 19th-century Russian nun in dialogue with the devil.
lead_paragraph: The dozens of video games The New York Times reviewed this year included anticipated blockbusters (Final Fantasy VII Rebirth, Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree) and smaller gems (Ultros, Neva, Mouthwashing).

headline: The Children Who Left Gaza
abstract: Sixteen young people evacuated from Gaza for treatment of dire injuries. Months later, they face new lives in an unfamiliar country.
lead_paragraph: The children and their caretakers know little of the language or the culture. They know even less of what may happen to them or their loved ones in the months to come.

headline: Oasis Reunion Tour Is Definitely Maybe a Win for Tribute Bands, Too
abstract: As the Gallagher brothers prepare for next year’s performances, Oasis covers bands are reaping the benefits with their own sold-out shows.
lead_paragraph: It’ll be another seven months before Oasis, the Britpop band led by Liam and Noel Gallagher, puts aside 15 years of sibling rivalry at a stadium in Cardiff, Wales, for a most unlikely reunion.

headline: Has the Craft Beer Industry’s Keg Finally Kicked?
abstract: After decades of meteoric success, this year marked the first time since 2005 that more breweries closed than opened.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, Phil Bannatyne opened Cambridge Brewing Company in Cambridge, Mass., with a monumental mission “to teach people what craft beer could be,” he said.

headline: Tumbling Tots Hit the Road in Two Surreal Picture Books
abstract: Our reviewer read these stories on a train, as the world rolled by out the window.
lead_paragraph: I’m on an overnight train, rolling westward. I’m traveling from Harpers Ferry, W.Va., to Chicago — off to see my daughter’s college play, an alchemical reimagining of Shakespeare’s “The Tempest” as a circus.

headline: How Virtual Appointments Taught Me to Be a Better Doctor
abstract: I was once intensely skeptical that telehealth could offer good medicine. I was wrong.
lead_paragraph: When I started my training as an emergency room physician, my mind revolved around answering one fundamental question: What does this patient have? Every interaction was a diagnostic puzzle, an attempt to fit a patient’s symptoms together into a cohesive picture.

headline: How Higher Education Can Win Back America
abstract: Jefferson believed in the egalitarian potential of education, and we should, too.
lead_paragraph: Anti-elitism runs so deep in American culture that even our founding fathers thought it was old news. In 1813 Thomas Jefferson warned that the “artificial aristocracy founded on wealth and birth, without either virtue or talents,” represented “a mischievous ingredient in government, and provision should be made to prevent its ascendancy.” Like James Madison and Ben Franklin, he worried that this elite was interested in protecting its own privileges rather than the good of the Republic.

headline: 10 Years Ago, a U.S. Thaw Fueled Cuban Dreams. Now Hope Is Lost.
abstract: A decade since the United States and Cuba restored diplomatic relations — which many believed would transform the island — Cuba is in its worst crisis since Fidel Castro took power.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long ago that Havana’s Plaza of the Revolution was packed with American tourists knocking into each other with selfie sticks while taking photos of the iconic image of the revolutionary Che Guevara and trying to catch a ride in a candy-apple red 1952 Chevrolet Bel-Air.

headline: Why the U.S. Could Come Out Ahead in a Tariff War
abstract: China and Europe are struggling economically. That gives the U.S. the advantage in weathering a tariff war.
lead_paragraph: The world is bracing for Donald Trump’s tariffs and doesn’t think he’s bluffing.

headline: What Really Happened the Night Dylan Went Electric?
abstract: The climax of “A Complete Unknown” is set during that iconic 1965 performance. Even then, fans knew it was a historic moment.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Sunday, July 25, 1965, Bob Dylan appeared at the Newport Folk Festival. He played a Fender electric guitar, and he was backed, for the first time onstage, by an amplified rock ’n’ roll band. They performed three songs. Chaos ensued.

headline: Elon Musk Needs to Teach Our Government How to Lose More Money
abstract: A better industrial policy for the United States involves more risk taking, not less.
lead_paragraph: A newcomer to the byzantine world of congressional appropriations and federal budgeting, Elon Musk has attracted no shortage of skepticism as to whether he can credibly pursue his mandate to improve government efficiency. But there is one kind of federal spending for which Mr. Musk, with his Silicon Valley roots, could offer exactly the perspective we need: the government’s overly conservative yet increasingly critical investment programs.

headline: With ‘Nosferatu,’ Robert Eggers Raises the Stakes
abstract: The filmmaker discusses his adaptation of this vampire tale, stories of female desire and why putting maggots on Bill Skarsgard was a beautiful idea.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know how you’re supposed to behave if you’re being chased by a vampire, or experiencing demonic possession,” said Robert Eggers, smiling a little but deadly serious.

headline: A Retirement Expert Is Giving Her Notice
abstract: Alicia Munnell started the Boston College Center for Retirement Research in 1998. As she prepares to leave, she says fixing Social Security should be a priority now.
lead_paragraph: If there’s anyone ready for retirement, it’s Alicia Munnell. She founded and has been running the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College since 1998, making it one of the leading nonpartisan think tanks examining how American workers can thrive after they leave their jobs.

headline: As North Carolina’s Governor Departs, He Stays Cagey on 2026 and 2028
abstract: In an interview, Roy Cooper spoke about his legacy, how to appeal to Republicans and Democratic speculation that he might run for Senate or for president.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina is set to leave office on New Year’s Day after two terms that began with his effort to undo the state’s “bathroom ban” for transgender people and ended with him muscling through a Medicaid expansion.

headline: The 10 Most Popular International Listings of 2024
abstract: This year, we led readers on more than 125 home tours in 28 countries. Here are our most read installments.
lead_paragraph: If the grass is always greener on the other side, then maybe the water is also bluer, the mountains higher, the forests thicker, the beaches … sandier? This year, The New York Times Real Estate section brought you more international home listings than ever before, with three new possibilities every week, so wherever you might want to move next (or perhaps just dream of moving), we were probably there in 2024. In 28 countries across five continents, we led readers on home tours of Caribbean cottages, Swiss chalets, Australian estates, Maltese manors, Chilean villas and many more.

headline: Ukraine Slows Firing of Missiles Into Russia as Trump Prepares to Take Office
abstract: The long-range missiles provided by the United States and Britain were used to strike inside Russian territory, despite concerns that their use would escalate the conflict. Kyiv’s stockpiles are running out.
lead_paragraph: With much fanfare, Ukraine was granted permission to fire Western long-range missiles at Russian military targets more than a month ago. But after initially firing a flurry of them, Ukraine has already slowed their use.

headline: California School District Pays $17.5 Million to End Coach’s Sexual Abuse Cases
abstract: The settlements culminate a lengthy personal and legal odyssey for the first accuser, Alex Harrison, who was subsequently shunned by teammates and parents.
lead_paragraph: In an unexpected legal twist, a school district in Marin County, Calif., has paid $17.5 million to four former high school students who accused a predatory tennis coach of sexually abusing them in the late 1990s and early 2000s.

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: Picks this month include a Bob Dylan sleeper, a harrowing portrait of Syria, and Will Ferrell and Harper Steele’s road trip.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we select three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a Malaysian war movie, an underwater plane rescue and a single-location western with gutsy gunfights.
lead_paragraph: An invasion of militants in the Malaysian state of Sabah causes the Royal Malaysia Police to dispatch an elite group of soldiers to quell the violence. The writer-director Zulkarnain Azhar’s film was inspired by the real-life Lahad Datu standoff in 2013, when a Filipino group tried to claim the contested area. The movie version is a charged, patriotic war flick whose large ensemble and jungle-set battles often recall Ridley Scott’s 2001 movie, “Black Hawk Down.”

headline: Like ‘Squid Game’? Stream These 9 New Korean Dramas Next
abstract: As more and more K-dramas debut for U.S. viewers, it is becoming harder to choose which to watch. Here are a few favorites that premiered in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Streaming services have been searching for the next “Squid Game” ever since the meteoric 2021 debut of the series, a bloody Korean tale of dystopian class warfare whose first season is the most-watched series in Netflix history.

headline: The Hottest Trend in Publishing: Books You Can Judge by Their Cover
abstract: Elaborately designed books with patterned edges and other effects started as a trend in romance and fantasy, and have now spread throughout the publishing industry.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a romance publisher took an expensive gamble on the latest novel by the best-selling author Rebecca Yarros.

headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: When Romy (Nicole Kidman), a high-powered C.E.O., finds herself involved with an intern (Harris Dickinson), her previously unfulfilled life gets very complicated in Halina Reijn’s film.

headline: 3 Resolutions for Eating and Drinking in 2025
abstract: Reach for a new recipe, to start.
lead_paragraph: Jancee Dunn is off this week. I’m Melissa Clark, a food reporter and Cooking columnist, filling in.

headline: Which Parts of These Images Are A.I.-Generated?
abstract: This quiz shows genuine images that were edited with A.I. tools. Your job: Find what’s fake.
lead_paragraph: This quiz shows genuine images that were edited with A.I. tools. Your job: Find what’s fake.

headline: 7 New Shows Our Theater Critics Are Talking About
abstract: A film adaptation onstage, a Broadway classic, comedy galore: These are the productions worth knowing about this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Jenn Thompson, who played the orphan Pepper in the original 1977 Broadway production, directs this touring version of Thomas Meehan, Martin Charnin and Charles Strouse’s classic orphan tale. It’s a thoughtful interpretation starring Hazel Vogel as the Depression-era redhead darling and Whoopi Goldberg as a tipsy Miss Hannigan.

headline: Osamu Suzuki, 94, Who Turned Automaker Into a Powerhouse, Dies
abstract: He built Suzuki Motor into a Japanese global brand making small vehicles and motorcycles. Entering India’s market in the 1980s was one of his early successes.
lead_paragraph: Osamu Suzuki, who led the Japanese automaker Suzuki Motor for more than four decades and transformed into a global powerhouse, died on Wednesday in Shizuoka Prefecture, southwest of Tokyo. He was 94.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,288
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Year in Music
abstract: Our pop music critics on the biggest stories of 2024.
lead_paragraph: As 2024 comes to a close, critics, reporters and editors at The New York Times are reflecting on the year in arts and culture, including music.Today, The Times’s pop music critics Jon Pareles, Lindsay Zoladz and Jon Caramanica talk with Melissa Kirsch, the deputy editor of Culture and Lifestyle, about a new generation of women in pop, how the rapper Kendrick Lamar beat Drake in their feud, and why so many pop stars went country.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 566
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Dec. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Overlooked Stories
abstract: Read some of our best journalism that you may have missed this year.
lead_paragraph: Journalists learned a tough lesson when they began posting articles online: Sometimes, the stories we work hardest on get overlooked.

headline: The Wirecutter Show: Kitchen Gear That Lasts a Lifetime (or Extremely Close)
abstract: Quality kitchen gear can last a lifetime — but not every pot, pan or knife is made to last.
lead_paragraph: Happy Holidays, everybody! We are off this week, but we wanted to bring you a recent episode from another New York Times podcast: The Wirecutter Show. It’s called “Kitchen Gear That Lasts a Lifetime (or Extremely Close)” and features Michael Sullivan, one of the senior staff writers on Wirecutter’s kitchen team. Michael walks through tips and tricks for finding kitchen gear that will last, what’s worth spending money on, what you can buy used and how to make cast iron last a lifetime.

headline: Israeli Military Forces Patients and Staff to Leave Hospital in Northern Gaza
abstract: The hospital, Kamal Adwan, has been caught in the middle of Israel’s monthslong offensive against Hamas militants in northern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military forced patients and staff members to leave one of the last functioning hospitals in northern Gaza on Friday, leaving health officials in the territory concerned for the people who had been getting treatment there amid continued fighting.

headline: What We Know About the Plane Crash in Kazakhstan
abstract: The Embraer 190 was traveling to Grozny, Russia, but crashed near Aktau, Kazakhstan, killing 38 people onboard. Investigators are focusing on Russian air defense as the likely cause.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were killed when a passenger flight bound for Russia crashed in Kazakhstan on Wednesday.

headline: OpenAI Details Plans for Becoming a For-Profit Company
abstract: OpenAI said it would be restructured as a public benefit corporation, and that the nonprofit that controls the organization would receive shares in the new company.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI revealed details on Friday about its plans to adopt a new corporate structure that will remove the company from control by a nonprofit that has been the focus of contention.

headline: First-Time Home Buyer Shares His Household Hacks
abstract: With more than a million people following along on Instagram, Kyshawn Lane lets you know just when to vacuum your refrigerator coils.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that you should vacuum the hair and dust off the coils in your refrigerator twice a year? What about draining your water heater once a year?

headline: Tesla Investors Are Still Bullish. Can Elon Musk Deliver?
abstract: Sales of the company’s cars are flagging, but investors are focusing on the potential of autonomous driving and Mr. Musk’s ties to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s sales of electric cars have stalled. But Wall Street doesn’t seem to be worried.

headline: NPR and PBS Stations Brace for Funding Battle Under Trump
abstract: Republicans in Congress have tried to defund public media for decades. With the help of Elon Musk, could they finally make good on their threat?
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is gunning for public media.

headline: Italian Journalist Is Detained While Reporting in Iran
abstract: Cecilia Sala, 29, was arrested on Dec. 19, but news of her detention only became public on Friday. The reason for the arrest of Ms. Sala, a well-known reporter, has not been made public.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Italian journalist was arrested in Iran and jailed in the country’s infamous Evin prison after spending days reporting in Tehran, Italian officials said.

headline: In Syria, U.S. Hopes to Avoid Replay of Afghanistan
abstract: American officials are wary as they try to persuade the rebels now in control in Syria to govern with an inclusive and moderate hand.
lead_paragraph: As U.S. officials engage with the rebel group now in control of Syria, they are mindful of a painful episode in recent U.S. foreign policy whose consequences continue to unfold: the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.

headline: A Month on, a Tenuous Cease-fire Holds in Lebanon
abstract: Israel and Hezbollah have exchanged strikes and accusations of breaches. Implementation of the deal has been slow. But the truce has brought some calm to a tumultuous region.
lead_paragraph: A fragile cease-fire between Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has largely held for a month now, halting the deadliest war in years between the two sides and injecting a measure of calm into a region in turmoil.

headline: Cleanse Your Palate With This Smashed Cucumber Salad
abstract: Crunchy, cool and refreshing, it’s the perfect foil for the season’s rich mains and sugary sweets.
lead_paragraph: Hi — Julia here, filling in for Sam.

headline: The Vivid Thread of Memories by the Yard
abstract: Suchitra Mattai uses vintage saris and vivid found materials to weave exquisite tapestries that challenge fixed histories about art and migration.

headline: ‘Squid Game’ Season 2: Finished Watching? Let’s Talk
abstract: Netflix’s hit Korean series about the indignities of modern capitalism is back for more brightly colored mayhem. Here’s a recap of what happened.
lead_paragraph: In Episode 3 of “Squid Game” Season 2, Seong Gi-hun (Lee Jung-jae) — the man who was the sole survivor and big prize-money winner at the end of “Squid Game” Season 1 — finds himself back on the same mysterious island three years later, competing once again in a tournament of children’s games in which the losers are shot dead.

headline: Fire Breaks Out at Bryant Park Holiday Market
abstract: There were no injuries at Bryant Park in Manhattan on Friday, but some holiday booths burned.
lead_paragraph: There were no injuries at Bryant Park in Manhattan on Friday, but some holiday booths burned.

headline: Trump’s Designs on the Panama Canal and Greenland
abstract: Readers are critical of the president-elect’s calls for U.S. control. Also: Dispirited after the election; billionaires and politics; the joy of reading novellas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Berrien Moore III, Pioneering Scholar of Earth Science, Dies at 83
abstract: As a researcher at several universities and an adviser at NASA, he used data analysis to show how the planet’s different systems are interrelated.
lead_paragraph: Berrien Moore III, who for decades spearheaded cutting-edge climate science at several universities and research institutes as well as at NASA, died on Dec. 17 in Norman, Okla. He was 83.

headline: Fire Erupts at Bryant Park Holiday Market
abstract: Several booths at one of New York City’s largest seasonal markets were affected, but there were no injuries.
lead_paragraph: A fire erupted at the popular Bryant Park holiday market in Midtown Manhattan on Friday morning, officials said, burning the booths of multiple businesses and emitting plumes of smoke that could be seen from miles away.

headline: What We Know About the Ship Finland Seized Over Fears of Sabotage
abstract: Finland seized an oil tanker that authorities believe might have deliberately cut vital undersea cables. Finnish authorities believe the tanker may be linked to Russia.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Finnish authorities seized an oil tanker suspected of severing vital undersea cables, NATO said on Friday that it would step up security in northern seas and the European Union threatened new sanctions against Russia amid growing concern about a covert campaign to sabotage European infrastructure.

headline: Migrants and End of Covid Restrictions Fuel Jump in Homelessness
abstract: The number of people experiencing homelessness in the U.S. topped 770,000, an increase of more than 18 percent over last year.
lead_paragraph: Homelessness soared to the highest level on record this year, driven by forces that included high rents, stagnant wages and a surge in migrants seeking asylum, the federal government reported on Friday.

headline: In Trump’s Mind, Greenland Is Just Real Estate
abstract: But that doesn’t mean he can buy it.
lead_paragraph: Did you hear the one about the real estate dealer who got elected president and started fantasizing about buying Greenland? Spoiler: If you elect him again, don’t be surprised when he actually goes for it.

headline: Canadian Ministers Meet Trump Aides at Mar-a-Lago to Discuss Border, and Tariffs
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on Canadian exports unless the country stops the flow of migrants and fentanyl to the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Two top Canadian ministers met on Friday with members of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s circle in Florida about a border security plan that Canada hopes will ward off Mr. Trump’s threats to impose economically damaging tariffs on imports from the country. But the ministers returned home without any assurances.

headline: In a Political Year, Some Deaths Spoke to the Struggles for Democracy
abstract: Among the notable figures who died in a sometimes polarizing 2024, many championed justice, equal rights and political freedom.
lead_paragraph: In a year saturated with politics in an ever more polarized world, where the obituary many feared they’d be reading would be that of democracy itself, one death seemed to encapsulate the historical moment we’re in: that of Aleksei Navalny.

headline: Video Shows Prison Officers’ Fatal Assault of Inmate in ‘Shocking’ Detail
abstract: Robert Brooks died after a savage attack at a New York prison this month that was captured by several officers’ body-worn cameras.
lead_paragraph: Corrections officers punched and kicked a handcuffed, shackled inmate in the groin and chest during a fatal attack at a prison in central New York this month, video footage released publicly on Friday shows.

headline: Arlene Croce Elevated Dance Criticism With Style and Daring
abstract: She was The New Yorker’s first dance critic. Her wit could be devastating but behind it was a belief in beauty.
lead_paragraph: Arlene Croce, who died last week at 90, made dance as important in arts criticism as painting, music, theater and books. The New Yorker’s dance critic from 1973 to 1996, Croce amassed a cult following and not a few detractors. She was also, despite insular origins, one of the most daring and stylish critics in the American canon.

headline: Traveling This Weekend? Where Weather May Complicate Your Plans
abstract: A day-by-day look at the rain and snow expected across the United States, and a peek at the New Year’s Eve forecast.
lead_paragraph: Rain, snow and freezing rain are all in the forecast this weekend through New Year’s Day as a series of storm systems sweeps across the United States, potentially disrupting holiday travel.

headline: Ruth Butler, Who Brought Artists’ Muses to Life, Dies at 93
abstract: After publishing a definitive biography of Rodin, she went on to write about the underappreciated women who modeled for the giants of 19th-century French art.
lead_paragraph: The art historian Ruth Butler was working on her Ph.D. in the late 1950s when she first visited the Musée Rodin in Paris. She would later remember being struck by an arresting plaster portrait of Rose Beuret, Auguste Rodin’s first muse and long-suffering life partner.

headline: The President-Elect Comments Often on the Men Around Him
abstract: “These guys are specimens.”
lead_paragraph: With all due respect, the look that Prince William sported at the starry reopening of Notre-Dame in Paris this month was nothing special: a well-tailored overcoat, a dark blue tie, a pressed white shirt. And, naturally, his new beard.

headline: 2024 Notable Deaths
abstract: As the year winds to a close, we’re recalling those we’ve lost who forged consequential lives.
lead_paragraph: As the year winds to a close, we’re recalling those we’ve lost who forged consequential lives.

headline: After Days of Silence, NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Phones Home
abstract: The probe sent a signal to Earth indicating that it had survived the closest solar encounter ever attempted by a spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 24, NASA’s Parker Solar Probe swooped closer than it ever had before to the sun, just a few million miles above its blazing hot surface.

headline: A Blog, an Anonymous Writer and Twin Brothers Accused of Sexual Assault
abstract: Years before they were charged with sex crimes, Oren and Alon Alexander took legal action to find a mystery blogger who claimed they had committed sexual assault as teenagers.
lead_paragraph: About 15 years before Oren and Alon Alexander would be charged with sex trafficking, an anonymous blog post appeared. It asked a shocking question: “Does anyone know what ever happened to Oren and Alon Alexander, the two twins who raped that girl in that party back in 2003?”

headline: North Korea Is Experiencing Mass Casualties in Russia, White House Says
abstract: The North Korean losses amount to almost 10 percent of the country’s deployment to Russia, the Biden administration said.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 North Korean soldiers were killed or wounded fighting Ukrainian troops in Russia’s Kursk region in the past week, and a few chose suicide over surrender, the Biden administration said on Friday.

headline: Enforcement of Anti-Money-Laundering Law Blocked After Court Reversal
abstract: Businesses will not have to reveal their owners after an appeals court reversed a move that would have forced them to disclose the information by Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Millions of corporate entities will not have to share information about their owners with the Treasury Department after an appeals court reversed a decision that would have required them to do so by Jan. 1.

headline: Investigators Using Video Surveillance to Identify Subway Burn Victim
abstract: The Brooklyn district attorney said the police were trying to retrace the woman’s steps to find a clear picture of her face. The man accused of killing her has been indicted on a first-degree murder charge.
lead_paragraph: Investigators are using video surveillance, fingerprint technology and DNA evidence to try to identify the woman who was fatally burned by another passenger inside a subway train on Coney Island three days before Christmas, Eric Gonzalez, the Brooklyn district attorney, said on Friday.

headline: Why the New Fight Inside MAGA Matters So Much
abstract: It’s what happens when a free-market party confronts reactionary protectionism.
lead_paragraph: Americans used to be enthusiastic about the idea of progress. If you had attended any of the World’s Fairs that were put on over the course of the 19th and 20th centuries in cities like Philadelphia, St. Louis, Chicago and New York, you would have seen great festivals celebrating the wonders of the future. If you went to Disneyworld, you could have visited Tomorrowland and the Carousel of Progress.

headline: Trump Backers Battle Online Over Skilled Immigrants
abstract: A fierce dispute erupted in the president-elect’s camp between immigration hard-liners and tech industry leaders including Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before President-elect Donald J. Trump is to take office, a major rift has emerged among his supporters over immigration and the place of foreign workers in the U.S. labor market.

headline: Too Old to Ace This Year-End Quiz? Ask a Kid for Help.
abstract: A 2024 trivia challenge you’ll need Gen Alpha’s help to beat
lead_paragraph: A 2024 trivia challenge you’ll need Gen Alpha’s help to beat

headline: A Strange Banging Sound, Chaos and Prayers Before a Plane Crashes
abstract: Flight attendants and a passenger described the moments before an Azerbaijan Airlines flight went down in Kazakhstan, killing dozens.
lead_paragraph: At first, there was a strange banging noise outside the plane. Then, while one flight attendant was standing in the cabin, something hit his arm, cutting it. The passengers, sensing something was terribly wrong, began panicking. Some began praying.

headline: Bird Flu Samples From Very Ill Patient Had ‘Concerning’ Mutations
abstract: Tiny genetic alterations could help the bird flu virus enter cells in the upper respiratory tract, the C.D.C. said. But there is no sign that mutations are widespread in nature.
lead_paragraph: After someone in southwest Louisiana was hospitalized with a severe case of bird flu, the first such illness reported in the United States, health workers swabbed the person’s nose and throat, looking for genetic clues about the virus.

headline: Los Angeles Building Featured on Doors’ ‘Morrison Hotel’ Cover Burns
abstract: The building, now boarded up, was made famous when it was featured on the cover of the 1970 album “Morrison Hotel.”
lead_paragraph: A boarded-up former hotel in Downtown Los Angeles that was featured on the cover of the 1970 Doors album “Morrison Hotel” was engulfed by a fire on Thursday.

headline: The Evening: Record Homelessness in the U.S.
abstract: Plus, how to get fitter in 2025.
lead_paragraph: The number of people experiencing homelessness topped 770,000, an increase of more than 18 percent over last year and the largest annual increase since the count began in 2007, the federal government reported today.

headline: Yellen Warns ‘Extraordinary Measures’ Will Be Needed to Avoid Default
abstract: The Treasury secretary urged Congress to protect the full faith and credit of the United States by raising the debt limit.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen informed Congress on Friday that if lawmakers do not act to raise or suspend the nation’s debt limit as soon as Jan. 14 she would most likely need to begin using “extraordinary measures” to prevent the United States from defaulting on its debt.

headline: Trucks Carrying Aid Finally Reach Sudan’s War-Torn Capital Region
abstract: After 20 months of war, and three months of negotiations with the warring sides, a bit of relief arrives for some of the hundreds of thousands of people facing famine.
lead_paragraph: The largest convoy of food and medical aid to reach Sudan’s battered capital region since the start of the civil war finally arrived this week, the World Food Program said on Friday, bringing some relief to a country where hundreds of thousands of people are on the brink of starvation.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Dec. 28, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Trump Urges Supreme Court to Pause TikTok Ban
abstract: The president-elect took no position on the app’s First Amendment challenge to the law, which sets a Jan. 19 deadline to sell or close the popular platform.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump filed an unusual brief on Friday asking the Supreme Court to block a law that requires TikTok to be sold or shut down by Jan. 19.

headline: Greg Gumbel Dies at 78; High-Profile Sportscaster for Over 5 Decades
abstract: A dignified presence on camera, most prominently for CBS, he became the first Black announcer to call a major U.S. sports championship, the 2001 Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Greg Gumbel, the affable and low-key sportscaster who for more than five decades was a convivial play-by-play voice and studio host for N.F.L. games, Super Bowls, the Olympics and, most memorably, the madness that descends on college basketball every March, died on Friday at his home in Davie, Fla. He was 78.

headline: Ex-N.Y.P.D. Leader Denies Sexual Abuse Accusations, Through His Lawyer
abstract: Jeffrey Maddrey, until last week the Police Department’s top uniformed officer, faced reporters for the first time since resigning. He did not say a word.
lead_paragraph: A former top New York Police Department official who resigned last week after being accused of sexually abusing female officers denied the misconduct allegations on Friday, although he let his lawyer do all the talking.

headline: Read the document
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump filed a brief asking the Supreme Court to block a law that requires TikTok to be sold or shut down by Jan. 19, the day before his inauguration.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump filed a brief asking the Supreme Court to block a law that requires TikTok to be sold or shut down by Jan. 19, the day before his inauguration.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 28, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about violent clashes after Mozambique’s disputed election misstated the status of Matola, one of the places where a prison break occurred. It is a city, not a province, in Mozambique.

headline: Sesquipedalia
abstract: Sam Berriman surfs up from Down Under with a corker of a debut puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s nice that the last Saturday grid of 2024 is from a new constructor, and we’re lucky to have this fresh, insouciant grid. There are lots of witty clues for inventive entries and interesting spots where related terms meet (or appear to, anyway, to this solver). This is a really good debut.

headline: Man With Burns on His Body Is Rescued at Penn Station, Police Say
abstract: The cause of the injuries was yet unknown. The episode on Friday night came days after a woman was fatally burned at another subway station in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A man was found with burns on his body at Penn Station in New York on Friday evening and was transported to a hospital, where he was in stable condition, fire and police officials said.

headline: Blue Origin Is Ready to Launch New Glenn Rocket After Critical Test
abstract: The company, owned by the Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, also received approval from the Federal Aviation Administration to launch the vehicle to orbit.
lead_paragraph: A towering new rocket built by Jeff Bezos’ company Blue Origin successfully conducted a dress rehearsal of a launch countdown Friday evening, culminating with the seven engines of the booster stage igniting and firing for 24 seconds.

headline: Quote of the Day: Definitely Maybe Sounding Like Oasis
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I always say: ‘Why? I’m not Noel.’”

headline: Make a Soup, Any Soup
abstract: As the days start to feel shorter and darker and colder, soup can warm both our bodies and our souls.
lead_paragraph: “In this dish you may know heaven,” Pablo Neruda wrote in “Ode to Conger Chowder.”

headline: Greeks Are Defying an Indoor Smoking Ban, Even After 14 Years
abstract: The country, which has one of Europe’s highest smoking rates, is also resisting a wider push for outdoor bans.
lead_paragraph: Greeks smoke more than most other Europeans, and even 14 years after Greece banned smoking in indoor public places, it is not uncommon to see people light up in bars and clubs.

headline: Our Reporter Returned to Afghanistan, Seeking Lessons and Secrets
abstract: Here’s what he found.
lead_paragraph: The Talib looked as ragged as his outpost, a trailer banked on a snowy mountain pass. Holes were bored into its sides to ventilate a sputtering wood stove.

headline: Tormentors Change, but Not the Torment
abstract: Brutally persecuted for years by the military in Myanmar, the Rohingya ethnic minority has now become the target of one of the junta’s most formidable rivals in the country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: When the bombs started falling, they were almost beautiful — like the purple blossoms of the banana tree, Manwara and her sister Shamshida would recall later.

headline: Has Russia’s Shadow Fleet, Built to Evade Sanctions, Added Sabotage to Its List?
abstract: Russia has assembled a fleet of hundreds of vessels to covertly ship its oil. With so many ships at sea, the idea of using some to cause havoc may be proving irresistible to the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: Western officials have long been concerned about Moscow’s so-called shadow fleet, an assemblage of aged tankers created to covertly carry Russian crude oil around the world. Since Russia invaded Ukraine, the worry primarily concerned the use of such off-the-books ships to circumvent Western sanctions and generate revenue to fuel the Kremlin’s war machine.

headline: Stowaway Caught on Delta Plane at Seattle Airport
abstract: The person, who boarded the flight without a ticket, was detected as the plane was preparing to take off for Hawaii on Christmas Eve.
lead_paragraph: A stowaway was caught aboard a Delta Air Lines plane as it was preparing to take off from Seattle for Honolulu, on Christmas Eve, the authorities said Friday, a month after a woman sneaked on to a Delta flight from New York to Paris without a ticket.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: How the Head of a Food Museum Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Nazli Parvizi, the president of the Museum of Food and Drink in Brooklyn, spreads her time between homemade meals with friends, walks with her son and intense card games.
lead_paragraph: Nazli Parvizi thinks about food all the time and not just because, as a former professional cook and caterer, she has spent much of her life in kitchens.

headline: Bob Dylan as the Original Hipster
abstract: The costumes of “A Complete Unknown” are a joy.
lead_paragraph: “A Complete Unknown,” James Mangold’s Bob Dylan biopic (in theaters now), is many things: a star-making vehicle for Timothée Chalamet, a spin through a sliver of Mr. Dylan’s extended discography and, maybe most of all, a reminder that the singer born Robert Zimmerman is one of the music world’s unquestionable style icons.

headline: 7 People (and One Coyote) Who Made New York City a Better Place in 2024
abstract: They were the bright lights during a rocky year, making the city a cooler, and fairer, place to be.
lead_paragraph: The past 12 months have hardly amounted to a banner year in the annals of New York City history.

headline: Winning $1.22 Billion Mega Millions Ticket Is Sold in California
abstract: The identity of the jackpot winner was not immediately known, but lottery officials in California are expected to reveal it.
lead_paragraph: Someone who bought a lottery ticket at a gas station in Northern California has won an estimated $1.22 billion in the Mega Millions drawing on Friday night, beating nearly impossible odds to take home one of the largest jackpots ever in the United States.

headline: Editors’ Note
abstract: This article was published prematurely.

headline: How ‘Health Freedom’ Became a Winning Rallying Cry
abstract: For decades, vaccine skeptics were a vocal protest movement. Now, they find themselves much closer to power.
lead_paragraph: Leah Wilson’s small organization was less than a year old when she realized she was making a difference. It was the beginning of 2020, just before the Covid shutdowns, and hundreds of protesters had gathered to demonstrate outside the State House in Trenton, N.J. They held signs with slogans like “my child, my choice” and “hands off our kids,” urging politicians to vote against a bill that would end religious exemptions for school-mandated vaccines.

headline: You’re Retired. What’s the Best Way to Withdraw Your Savings?
abstract: It’s finally time to start using the money you managed to save and invest over the years. But be careful: Taxes are just one of the tricky parts.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the first thing to remember about withdrawing retirement money: It’s all about the cash flow.

headline: An Old Mining Town in Montana Finds New Gold in Film
abstract: There was a healthy dose of skepticism in Butte, Mont., when Hollywood producers began showing up to shoot their shows. Now, many say the industry’s arrival has been a boon for the city.
lead_paragraph: Paige Layne was several weeks into her new job as a security guard — standing watch outside of the civic center in her hometown of Butte, Mont. — when she found out exactly what it was she had been guarding.

headline: Shrapnel and Sturgeon: Making Caviar Under the Rockets in Israel
abstract: The war with Hezbollah has cleared out the north of the country — save for a hardy few and their thousands of prized fish.
lead_paragraph: Shrapnel kept turning up in the fish pools. The twisted metal had been falling from the sky for 14 months, detritus of Hezbollah rockets and Israeli missile interceptors colliding overhead.

headline: Breaking’s Big Year That Wasn’t
abstract: It was a 50-year journey from the streets of New York to the Paris Olympic Games. But a would-be celebration turned into something of a debacle.
lead_paragraph: Ken Swift has never dribbled a basketball to a beat. Growing up in the Bronx, he never darted for touchdowns while music thumped. Back then, in the late 1970s, sports plugged an important desire for sweat and competition.

headline: Mexico, Betting Trump Is Bluffing on Tariffs, Sees an Opportunity
abstract: Business leaders in Mexico say the incoming U.S. administration will enhance the appeal of their factories as an alternative to plants in China.
lead_paragraph: Like much of the Mexican business world, Daniel Córdova finds himself grappling with an enormous variable looming across the American border: the imminent return of Donald J. Trump to the White House.

headline: In Bomb-Scarred Cities, Risking Life and Limb to Get Civilians to Safety
abstract: The danger and hardship gets worse by the day for civilians in eastern Ukraine. Still, they resist leaving the places that have become their homes.
lead_paragraph: Vasyl Pipa is not a Ukrainian soldier, but his job, at times, can be as dangerous as fighting in the trenches. As members of the White Angels, a branch of the police that evacuates civilians from the front line, he and others take extreme risks to rescue some of the last civilians who remain close to the fighting.

headline: Why Coffee Prices Are Soaring (Again)
abstract: Wholesale coffee prices are trading near a 50-year high because of shortages related to extreme weather and increased global demand.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to coffee, Thaleon Tremain has always tried to ignore what the market is telling him.

headline: Four New York Times Photographers on 2024
abstract: They talk about the historic moments they captured that defined the year — the migrant crisis, the war in Ukraine, arctic war training and hostage returns.
lead_paragraph: They talk about the historic moments they captured that defined the year — the migrant crisis, the war in Ukraine, arctic war training and hostage returns.

headline: Perhaps You Didn’t Know Pamela Anderson Is a Cinephile
abstract: The Golden Globe-nominated star of “The Last Showgirl” is a Criterion Channel fan. “I watch every night before I go to bed. I love Godard and Fellini and Herzog and Cassavetes.”
lead_paragraph: “There’s always an obstacle to great things,” Pamela Anderson said, recalling how the script for “The Last Showgirl” almost slipped through her fingers.

headline: My Condo Sponsor Owes the Building $30,000. How Do We Make Him Pay?
abstract: The office of the New York State attorney general calls the failure of building sponsors to pay dues on unsold units a “serious” problem.
lead_paragraph: Q: I own a condominium in an eight-unit building in Brooklyn. Our sponsor did not pay the homeowners association dues for unsold units, as required under law, and he stopped responding to emails and calls after he transferred control of the building to the board. The dues are about $30,000, plus interest. We are a small building, so this amount is substantial. Other than filing a lawsuit, and incurring more expense, is there a way to get the sponsor to pay the dues with interest?

headline: The New York That ‘Anora’ Travels Does Exist: Take Our Tour
abstract: The movie is structured around a chaotic chase through Brooklyn and Manhattan. The director Sean Baker and his location manager retraced their steps.
lead_paragraph: Midway through “Anora,” Sean Baker’s screwball Cinderella story, Ivan (Mark Eydelshteyn), the son of a Russian oligarch, runs off from the extravagant southern Brooklyn mansion owned by his parents. His new bride, the title character known as Ani (Mikey Madison), and his handlers spend much of the rest of the movie in pursuit, a chaotic chase that culminates at the Manhattan strip club where Ani dances.

headline: Pop Musicians, Please Spare Me the Back Stories
abstract: The power of a lasting song is that it breaks free of its origins. Hits should be more than celebrity narratives.
lead_paragraph: The megahits of 2024 were inseparable from their back stories. And that was exhausting.

headline: As Hopes Rise for Gaza Cease-Fire, Conditions There Have Worsened
abstract: Human rights organizations and residents describe the situation in the enclave as getting more desperate. Here is a closer look.
lead_paragraph: For the past several weeks, Fadia Nasser, a widow sheltering in Deir al Balah in central Gaza, says she has subsisted on nothing but a small sandwich of herbs for breakfast and a tomato she shares with her daughter for lunch.

headline: Playing to Win: How a First Nation Turned Around Its Fortunes
abstract: Steered by an entrepreneurial chief, Membertou First Nation in Nova Scotia led the largest investment by Indigenous people in Canada’s seafood industry.
lead_paragraph: The trip through Cape Breton Island, on the northeastern tip of Nova Scotia, promised scenic driving views. The island regularly appears in travel guides for the world’s best road trips, an agent at the airport’s car rental counter told me in September after I landed in Halifax.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,289
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 567
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Your Best Advice of 2024
abstract: As we start to look ahead, here’s the best advice that readers of The Morning received this year.
lead_paragraph: The piece of wisdom I repeated the most this year came from a reader of The Morning who answered my call for advice last December: “We are all juggling so many balls. Differentiate between glass balls and rubber balls — and don’t be afraid to drop the rubber balls.” Everyone with whom I shared this little gem seemed to find it useful (or maybe they were humoring me?). I’m not sure why this particular advice stuck with me — really, it’s just saying “learn to prioritize,” a colorful riff on “don’t sweat the small stuff.” For whatever reason, picturing the messy, ungovernable realm of worries and to-dos as rubber and glass balls helped me think more clearly in times of stress.

headline: The 19th-Century Technology That Threatens A.I.
abstract: The biggest thing holding America back from dominance in artificial intelligence is the country’s inability to keep up with the demand for electricity.
lead_paragraph: Whatever you hear about the United States as a fading power, it is ahead in the race to gain dominance in artificial intelligence over China, its major rival. That’s a product of Silicon Valley’s unique ability to bring together scientists, entrepreneurs and risk capital. Yet the prospect of continuing dominance in this 21st-century technology hinges on harnessing a 19th-century one: electricity.

headline: I Won’t Feel Good About Flying Until the Airlines Solve This
abstract: The aviation industry should get serious about direct air capture so that its emissions don’t remain in the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: The airlines are magicians.

headline: Schubert Is the Best Cure I Know for Loneliness
abstract: Schubert’s final three piano sonatas are a deep exploration of loneliness, and particularly apt for our age of isolation.
lead_paragraph: We live in an age of isolation. Its dangerous effects are becoming ever clearer: online radicalization, increasingly poisonous politics, evidence that more and more people consider themselves functionally friendless. This crisis is particularly acute during the holidays.

headline: What I Am Looking for in Empty Churches
abstract: In that quiet space there is solace, a silence like nothing else.
lead_paragraph: If you walk into a church right now, you are almost guaranteed to see other people. It’s the busiest time of the year for churches — even the normally empty ones are full. But full churches are what I usually avoid.

headline: My Restaurant Was Named One of New York City’s Best. Here’s Why It Closed.
abstract: My story is one small part of an ongoing struggle for restaurant workers and culinary culture.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, I poured wine, greeted regulars and strangers and bused tables at Contento, the restaurant I co-owned in East Harlem, for the last time. After more than three years of service, during which The New York Times ranked us twice among the 100 Best Restaurants in New York City and the Michelin Guide gave me its sommelier award, I had to say goodbye to my talented staff and lifelong dream of owning a restaurant. The combination of inflation, rising crime that required us to pay for security guards and declining profits simply proved insurmountable.

headline: The Blaming of Joe Biden
abstract: Blame is simplistic. Might I suggest that there is another way to understand what happened with the president? A more humane way?
lead_paragraph: We are now in the final weeks of Joe Biden’s presidency, and I’ve been thinking about the year he had — how different it was from what he hoped last winter as he sought re-election. All presidents think about what they wanted to achieve, in the end, and how Americans will regard them. For some of us, our most vivid memory right now of Mr. Biden is from his televised debate against Donald Trump in June. I’m sure that’s not the moment Mr. Biden wants to be remembered for. But I also know that presidents come to be remembered differently, over time, for better or for worse. Their highs and lows in office, once so clearly and sharply defined, can shift in our perception. I see Mr. Biden differently now from how I did last summer, and I see his last year in office as a window into the messiness of being human.

headline: Syria’s New Government Steps Up Pursuit of Assad Loyalists
abstract: Finding the remnants of the old dictatorship and bringing them to justice has emerged as a top priority for the new administration in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s new administration has stepped up its campaign to track down and arrest members of the ousted Assad dictatorship, signaling that it would act with a heavy hand against people it claims are challenging its ability to impose law and order.

headline: Putin Apologizes but Stops Short of Taking Responsibility for Kazakhstan Crash
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told the Azerbaijani leader, Ilham Aliyev, in a phone call, “that the tragic incident took place in Russian airspace.”
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Saturday apologized for the crash of an Azerbaijan Airlines plane this past week, breaking the Kremlin’s three-day silence on the accident that killed 38 people. He did not explicitly acknowledge Russia’s responsibility for the crash.

headline: Shigeko Sasamori, Hiroshima Survivor Who Preached Peace, Dies at 92
abstract: Severely disfigured when the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Japan, she spent her life warning others about the dangers of nuclear war.
lead_paragraph: Shigeko Sasamori, who was severely burned at 13 when a nuclear bomb exploded over Japan and later, in the United States, championed peace and found comfort in helping others as a nurse’s aide, died on Dec. 15 at her home in Marina del Rey, Calif. She was 92.

headline: A Photo of Nancy Pelosi, Rediscovered Decades Later
abstract: In 1963, the politician Thomas D’Alesandro Jr. submitted a photo to appear with The New York Times’s announcement of his daughter’s engagement.
lead_paragraph: When the daughter of Thomas D’Alesandro Jr., a prominent politician in Baltimore, got engaged in 1963, the family sent her photo to The New York Times to accompany an engagement announcement in the Society pages.

headline: 7 Go-To Dinner Party Dinners
abstract: Or: the New York Times Cooking recipes I trot out when I want to impress without any stress.
lead_paragraph: My cousin texted me the other day with the prompt of all prompts: “Is there a New York Times Cooking recipe that’s an absolute slam dunk in your mind — a go-to if people are coming over for dinner?”

headline: Guards in Fatal Prison Assault Were Accused of Beating Inmates Before
abstract: Three of the 13 guards implicated in the savage beating of Robert Brooks had been accused in lawsuits of earlier attacks in New York prisons.
lead_paragraph: At least three of the New York prison guards implicated in the savage beating death of a handcuffed man had been accused of participating in similar attacks on prisoners across the state.

headline: Interior Dept. Is Caught Between Tribes in Casino Battles
abstract: The Biden administration’s consideration of three proposed tribal casinos in California and Oregon has touched off a fierce debate about tribal sovereignty and land rights.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade ago, members of a Northern California Native American tribe, the Scotts Valley Band of Pomo Indians, made a big bet when they bought 160 untouched acres north of San Francisco to erect a $700 million casino resort they had no approval to build.

headline: Kirsten Simone, International Ballet Star, Is Dead at 90
abstract: One of Denmark’s greatest ballerinas, she toured widely — in London, Moscow and New York — and played a version of herself in a Disney TV production.
lead_paragraph: Kirsten Simone, one of Denmark’s most authoritative ballerinas, who spanned the Danish, Russian classical and dramatic repertoires, died on Dec. 19 in Copenhagen. She was 90.

headline: Michel del Castillo, 91, Dies; Child’s-Eye Chronicler of Concentration Camps
abstract: His first novel, “Tanguy,” published when he was 24, was a fact-based Holocaust story that one reviewer said “begins where Anne Frank’s diary ended.”
lead_paragraph: Michel del Castillo, a Franco-Spanish writer whose wrenching chronicle of a childhood spent in World War II concentration camps brought him renown on both sides of the Atlantic, died on Dec. 17 in Sens, a town in northern Burgundy. He was 91.

headline: Musk Doubles Down on Support for German Far-Right Party
abstract: The world’s richest man, a key adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, ridicules critics over his backing of the German extremist party AfD, as Germany prepares for elections.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man and a close adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, shocked many in Germany last week by endorsing its far-right Alternative for Germany party, which is under surveillance by domestic intelligence for being extremist.

headline: Severe Weekend Weather Disrupts Holiday Travel
abstract: More than 9,000 flights were delayed on Saturday amid threats of rain, snow and tornadoes across the country.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of flights around the country were delayed or canceled on Saturday because of severe weather, disrupting travel for many returning home after the holidays.

headline: State Dept. Designates American Teacher Held in Russia as ‘Wrongfully Detained’
abstract: Marc Fogel was convicted of drug smuggling and sentenced in 2022 to 14 years in prison by the same court that handled the case of Brittney Griner.
lead_paragraph: Marc Fogel, an American teacher serving a 14-year prison sentence in Russia, has been designated by the U.S. government as wrongfully detained, the State Department said on Friday.

headline: Multi-Hyphenates
abstract: Harry Zheng presents a too-fun-to-fail inaugural Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: 2 Are Killed in Texas Tornado and Storms in Mississippi
abstract: A tornado that touched down in Brazoria County, Texas, struck some homes and other structures on Saturday, the authorities said. It was a day of tornado warnings in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Update: Severe weather marched across the Southeastern United States on Sunday, a day after a tornado and storms killed three people in Texas and Mississippi.

headline: How Donald Trump Went From Backing a TikTok Ban to Backing Off
abstract: In 2020, he moved to ban the Chinese-owned app. Now, he is opposing the Biden administration’s effort to do just that.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, President Donald J. Trump denounced TikTok, the Chinese-owned video sharing app, as a threat to America’s national security. This week, as Mr. Trump prepares to retake the White House, he called it a “unique medium for freedom of expression.”

headline: Netanyahu to Have Prostate Removal Surgery on Sunday
abstract: The prime minister was diagnosed with an infection from a “benign enlargement of his prostate.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will undergo surgery to have his prostate removed Sunday after he was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection earlier in the week, his office said in a statement Saturday.

headline: Trump Weighs In on Immigrant Visa Debate but Offers Little Clarity
abstract: He said in an interview that he had used the visas for skilled workers “many times.” But he has mainly used visas for unskilled workers like housekeepers.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump appeared to weigh in on Saturday on a heated debate among his supporters over the role of skilled immigrant workers in the U.S. economy, saying he had frequently used the visas for those workers and backed the program.

headline: Dayle Haddon, Model Who Bucked Age Discrimination, Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Haddon, who carved a path all her own in the modeling world, was found dead on Friday morning from what authorities believed was a carbon monoxide leak.
lead_paragraph: Dayle Haddon, a model and actress who graced many magazine covers in the 1970s and 1980s and who bucked the fashion industry by continuing to model later in life, was found dead on Friday at her daughter’s home in Bucks County, Pa. She was 76.

headline: South Korea’s Acting President Has Been in Office Only Since Friday
abstract: After two impeachments of leaders in two weeks, the country is deep into a political crisis.
lead_paragraph: The plane crash is the first major test for South Korea’s acting president, Choi Sang-mok, who was appointed the interim leader only on Friday, as the country grapples with a political crisis at the highest levels.

headline: Quote of the Day: Sturgeon and Shrapnel — Making Caviar as the Rockets Flew
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 29, 2024
lead_paragraph: “These are animals. They have to be taken care of every day, including weekends. No Shabbat for the fish.”

headline: The Loneliness and Joy of a Late-December Birthday
abstract: It’s hard to have your special day in a month of special days. December babies have one request: Make an effort.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on Dec. 30, 2022.

headline: Despite Attacks, an Underground Church for L.G.B.T.Q. Africans Thrives
abstract: The congregation in Nairobi, Kenya, has been forced to move to 10 different locations over 10 years, and yet it has survived as a sanctuary in an increasingly hostile environment.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Kenya’s only church led and attended by L.G.B.T.Q. people has been chased out of one location after another. Vandals hit the first location, a center for sex workers, church members said. When they moved to Nairobi’s Central Park, the police arrested them. A city building barred them from entry, and at another site, neighbors attacked them with stones.

headline: Ignoring Warnings, a Growing Band of Tourists Venture to Afghanistan
abstract: With the war now over, the Taliban are welcoming foreign travelers, even as governments advise their citizens to stay away.
lead_paragraph: Yi-Pin Lin, an associate professor at Tufts University, proudly says he has vacationed in 120 nations over the past decade.

headline: These 10 Charts Will Help You Understand 2024
abstract: Steven Rattner recaps a historic year in charts.
lead_paragraph: Steven Rattner recaps a historic year in charts.

headline: How to Go Back in Time
abstract: The diary I kept this past year offers me an express ticket back to beautiful moments I’ve lived.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an end-of-2024 quiz: What did you do on April 21? What did you eat for dinner on Oct. 2? Can you name a top headline from Aug. 15?

headline: Going to a Real-Life Version of Gabriel García Márquez’s Macondo
abstract: On a trip to Colombia to see the Netflix production of “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” a reporter was struck by memories of real places.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel García Márquez resisted all offers to turn his best-known novel, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” into a film. Though the Colombian writer loved cinema, he was wary of how Hollywood would reshape his 1967 book.

headline: How Shen Yun Tapped Religious Fervor to Make $266 Million
abstract: The dance group has accumulated enormous wealth, in large part by getting followers of the Falun Gong religious movement to work for free and pay its bills.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, the dance group Shen Yun Performing Arts has made money at a staggering rate.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: A Large Family Built Its Own Little Town. A Hurricane Killed 11 of Them.
abstract: The extended Craig family has suffered an unthinkable loss after landslides slammed into their North Carolina town during Hurricane Helene. The survivors are trying to move forward.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, the Craig family felt safe on their land in western North Carolina, where mountains covered in maple and hickory trees shielded them during storms.

headline: New York Raises These Pheasants to Be Shot. Is It Hunting or Cruelty?
abstract: Some lawmakers hope to end a program that is meant to introduce children to field sports but that critics say makes the birds easy targets, if they don’t die another way.
lead_paragraph: Dead ring-necked pheasants were flattened into feathered splotches along a Long Island road. Heads, wings and plumage were scattered at regular intervals. Live pheasants darted around nervously.

headline: The Best of Metropolitan Diary 2024: The Readers Speak
abstract: An anecdote about an encounter at a park claims the top spot this year, outpolling four other favorites. All five are presented here.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, Metropolitan Diary shared more than 250 tales of life in New York City. Now, readers have chosen the best.

headline: Behind the Dismantling of Hezbollah: Decades of Israeli Intelligence
abstract: A Times investigation shows how extensively Israel penetrated the Lebanese militia, closely tracking the group’s commanders and culminating in the assassination of its leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
lead_paragraph: Right up until he was assassinated, Hassan Nasrallah did not believe that Israel would kill him.

headline: Departing Air Force Secretary Will Leave Space Weaponry as a Legacy
abstract: Frank Kendall, who grew up on an apple farm and then rose to the pinnacle of the U.S. military, has preached the need for better preparation for the next big fight.
lead_paragraph: Weapons in space. Fighter jets powered by artificial intelligence.

headline: Boeing 737-800, a Precursor to the 737 Max, Is Used Widely.
abstract: Nearly 200 airlines use the 737-800, which makes up about 15 percent of the world’s fleet of aircraft.
lead_paragraph: The Jeju Air plane that crashed in southwestern South Korea was a Boeing 737-800, a model that is used widely around the world.

headline: Arizona’s Tiny Taipei: How a Taiwanese Chip Factory Seeded a Community
abstract: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, a global tech giant, brought thousands of workers from Asia to the Phoenix suburbs for jobs at a plant that the Biden administration helped fund.
lead_paragraph: After Helen Wang finishes work at the new microchip plant looming over the Arizona desert, she drives home to start her side hustle: cooking pots of spicy beef soup and pork noodles for Taiwanese colleagues who are hungry for a taste of home.

headline: Bob Dylan on Film: A Guide to the Movies’ True Shapeshifter
abstract: The singer-songwriter was never only a creature of music. Our critic watched every film with him that she could find to better understand the artist.
lead_paragraph: The concert stage-to-Hollywood highway has been wide and inviting for decades. Everyone from Elvis and the Beatles to Madonna and Taylor Swift has journeyed down that road. But there’s something unique about Bob Dylan’s big-screen presence. He is Dylan the troubadour, Dylan the documentary subject, Dylan the car commercial star, Dylan the lurking stranger with a very sharp knife. Over seven decades, he’s been ubiquitous, but never predictable.

headline: In a Year of Anxiety Onscreen, Here’s Who Portrayed It Best
abstract: From “Inside Out 2” to “The Bear,” it was a character, a feeling, a vibe.
lead_paragraph: Anxiety is nothing new, but in 2024 it was a star character in several of the films and TV shows that caught my interest. Sometimes anxiety was literally its own character, like the orange tuft in “Inside Out.” Sometimes it was the state in which we find a character, like Rishi in “Industry.” Sometimes it’s openly named, and other times it’s just implied.
