Below I take a look at the most affecting portrayals of anxiety I found onscreen this year.

headline: A Look at Real Estate in New York City in 2024
abstract: With the year safely in the rearview mirror, StreetEasy looked at the most sought-after amenities and neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: The year 2024 saw many highs and lows in American real estate. Changes in how real estate commissions are advertised and paid went into effect, changing the relationships between brokers and their clients. Housing costs continued to soar. And “barndominiums” — a barn with a twist on the word condominium — became all the rage in rural America.

headline: 12 Predictions for Life in 2025
abstract: What will we wear, eat, buy, believe, desire?
lead_paragraph: At the start of the year, did you foresee the fascination with what Gen Z-ers think, wear and do starting to fizzle? How about the explosion of theme dressing on red carpets? Or rosettes blooming as a popular motif in fashion?

headline: ‘This Is What Makes Us Rich’: Inside a Sinaloa Cartel Fentanyl Lab
abstract: New York Times reporters witnessed the dangerous fentanyl production process inside a secret lab in Culiacán run by Mexico’s most powerful criminal syndicate.
lead_paragraph: We had just walked into the fentanyl lab when the cook poured a white powder into a stockpot full of liquid. He began mixing it with an immersion blender and fumes rose from the pot, filling the small kitchen.

headline: A Year Both Brutal and Bright: 13 Favorite Dispatches From 2024
abstract: In a year marked by wars, extreme weather and general wickedness, many dispatches defaulted to a distinctly dark tone. But as our correspondents traversed the globe, they found pockets of light, too.
lead_paragraph: With major conflicts raging in multiple regions of the world, it is no surprise that many of 2024’s best dispatches — articles focused on a sense of place and people’s lives — were filed from battle zones. Our correspondents showed both the toll of the violence and how everyday citizens are responding to it — from the streets of Kyiv to the hills above Beirut to the jungles of Myanmar.

headline: He Dialed 911 to Save His Baby. Then His Children Were Taken Away.
abstract: The controversial medical diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome can send parents to jail. What if the symptoms are caused by something else?
lead_paragraph: On the 911 call, Nick Flannery’s voice was frantic as he tried to revive his infant son. “Come on, buddy,” he pleaded with the 2-month-old, who had gone limp. “Come on, buddy. Breathe.”

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,290
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Trump-Kim, Part II, Could Shake Up the World
abstract: North Korea is the weak link in the emerging coalition of authoritarian states, and the incoming president is uniquely positioned to exploit this.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump takes office, he will face an array of authoritarian adversaries — China, Russia, Iran and North Korea — that are coalescing into a formidable axis intent on challenging U.S. power. Together, they represent America’s greatest foreign policy threat, and the Trump administration should act quickly to exploit potential weak links in this coalition before it hardens into a unified bloc.

headline: New Yorkers Deserve More Public Restrooms
abstract: Just don’t force people to pay to use them.
lead_paragraph: If you walk long enough on the streets of New York City, you’re going to smell urine. No matter how many flowers or perfume-wearing commuters are around, that pungent odor still sneaks through like a stalker’s head in the bushes. It’s evidence that New York City, as modern as it is, has only 1,000 public restrooms for its 8.3 million residents.

headline: What a Trump Presidency Means for U.S. Business
abstract: Populists may promise low taxes and deregulation, but they also undermine the institutions that help an economy run smoothly.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets have reacted with glee to the news that Donald Trump will be America’s 47th president. Buoyed by hopes of deregulation and tax cuts, global investors pumped a record $149 billion into U.S. equity exchange-traded funds in November, undeterred by fears of policy instability and trade wars. Such euphoria has now pushed U.S. stocks to their highest level compared with global markets since records began over a century ago.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 568
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Ozempic Could Crush the Junk Food Industry. But It Is Fighting Back.’
abstract: As revolutionary new weight-loss drugs turn consumers off ultraprocessed foods, the industry is on the hunt for new products.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Big Food has been marketing products to people who can’t seem to stop eating, and now, suddenly, they can. The active ingredient in new drugs like Ozempic, Wegovy and Zepbound mimics a natural hormone that slows digestion and signals fullness to the brain.

headline: Elon Musk Is a National Security Risk
abstract: His relationship with Chinese leaders and reported contacts with Russian officials are cause for alarm.
lead_paragraph: It is now fair to ask the question: Is Elon Musk a national security risk?

headline: The Case for Resolutions
abstract: Write them with us.
lead_paragraph: Does it feel like there’s something gauche — maybe a little anachronistic — about New Year’s resolutions? They run counter to the idea that we should accept who we are. That we should give ourselves grace. “Do you have any New Year’s resolutions?” It’s a question that asks someone to believe they are inadequate.

headline: What to Know About South Korea’s Worst Plane Crash in Decades
abstract: A plane carrying 181 people crashed while landing, killing most on board. Officials were investigating a possible malfunction with the landing gear and a bird strike.
lead_paragraph: A passenger plane carrying 181 people crash-landed on its belly on Sunday at an airport in South Korea, hitting a barrier and exploding into an orange fireball in the worst aviation disaster in the country in almost three decades.

headline: Editor’s Note: Guess who’s back, back again
abstract: Shortz is back, tell a friend.
lead_paragraph: We celebrated Will Shortz’s 30th anniversary at The New York Times with drinks, gifts and speeches in November 2023. Less than three months later, Will, the crossword editor, was in the hospital after having two strokes back to back.

headline: Anger and Agony in South Korea After Plane Crash-Lands, Killing 179
abstract: A Jeju Air passenger jet carrying 181 people from Bangkok sped off the runway and burst into flames. Two crew were rescued in what was the country’s worst air disaster in decades.
lead_paragraph: The passenger plane with 181 people onboard skidded on the runway at a high speed and slammed into a wall before exploding into flames.

headline: Charles Dolan, Cablevision Founder Who Sat Atop a Media Empire, Dies at 98
abstract: His business choices were diverse and prolific: He founded HBO, bought Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks, and took over a Long Island newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Charles F. Dolan, who founded HBO, merged a group of small Long Island cable TV systems into a network he called Cablevision and amassed a fortune building an innovative communications, entertainment and sports empire that included Madison Square Garden and its professional teams, died on Saturday. He was 98.

headline: Democratic Fears of a Constitutional Convention
abstract: Readers discuss the possibility of Republicans pushing for one. Also: Care for migrant children; sober at parties; Rudolph at Dartmouth.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Azerbaijan Blames Russia for Plane Crash and Rebukes Kremlin
abstract: The leader of Azerbaijan criticized the Russian response to the crash of a passenger jet that Azerbaijani officials said had most likely been hit by Russian air defenses.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Azerbaijan directly blamed Russia on Sunday for the crash of an Azerbaijan Airlines passenger jet last week, calling on Moscow to accept responsibility and offer compensation to victims.

headline: Warren Upton, Who Escaped Sinking Battleship in Pearl Harbor, Dies at 105
abstract: The last survivor of the U.S.S. Utah, he was a 22-year-old Navy radioman when Japanese forces attacked.
lead_paragraph: Warren Upton, the oldest survivor of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 and the last surviving crew member of one of the ships moored there, the torpedoed battleship Utah, died on Wednesday in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 105.

headline: Bright Flavors, Easy Dinners
abstract: Simple, savory fare to see you across the holiday season finish line: lemony skillet chicken; hot and sour soup; white bean dip with chile-cumin oil.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Julia again, filling in for Sam.

headline: Israel Struggles to Halt Attacks From Faraway Foe Once Off Radar
abstract: Even as battles with its enemies on its borders appear to be winding down, Israel is being challenged by intensifying attacks by the Houthi militia in Yemen, 1,000 miles away.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Houthis were the enemy most Israelis didn’t know they had.

headline: Charlie Maxwell, Who Hit Homers in 4 Consecutive At-Bats, Dies at 97
abstract: An All-Star outfielder for the Tigers, he tied a major league record with that feat on a Sunday (what else?) in 1959 playing against the Yankees in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Maxwell, a two-time All-Star outfielder who tied a major league record in May 1959 when he hit home runs in four successive official at-bats while playing for the Detroit Tigers, died on Friday in Paw Paw, Mich. He was 97.

headline: Amid Anti-Western Drift, Georgia Inaugurates a Conservative President
abstract: Even though a figurehead, Mikheil Kavelashvili occupies a symbolic role as the country moves further from the West and toward Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: A former soccer star and conservative critic of the West was sworn in on Sunday as the new president of Georgia, a strategically important republic in the middle of the Caucasus, replacing a head of state who vowed to continue fighting to steer the country closer to Europe.

headline: Bird Strikes Are a Common Problem for Flights
abstract: It is not uncommon for planes to strike wildlife, but most episodes don’t result in deaths or serious injuries.
lead_paragraph: After a plane crashed as it was landing in South Korea on Sunday, killing 179 of the 181 people on board, officials said they were investigating possible causes including a landing gear malfunction and a bird strike.

headline: Stanley Booth, Music Journalist Who Loved the Blues, Dies at 82
abstract: He is best known for his book about the Rolling Stones. But he mostly wrote about blues artists, some of them famous (B.B. King) and some less renowned (Furry Lewis).
lead_paragraph: In late 1967, the music journalist Stanley Booth was on assignment to write about the Memphis soul sound for The Saturday Evening Post when he watched Otis Redding and the guitarist and producer Steve Cropper sit on folding chairs at Stax Records in Memphis as they composed “(Sittin’ on) The Dock of the Bay.”

headline: Monday Briefing: A Plane Crash in South Korea killed 179
abstract: Plus, Falun Gong’s money engine.
lead_paragraph: A Boeing 737-800 plane operated by Jeju Air crashed while landing at an airport in South Korea yesterday, killing 179 of the 181 people on board. It was the worst aviation disaster involving a South Korean airline in almost three decades, officials said.

headline: 4 Dead After Storm System Sweeps Across South
abstract: Strong storms spawned tornadoes in Texas and Mississippi on Saturday and dumped heavy rain on the Carolinas on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Four people were dead in three Southern states over the weekend after a severe weather system marched across the region, unleashing tornadoes in Texas and Mississippi and heavy rains in the Carolinas.

headline: Video Offers Clues to Cause of Plane Crash, but No Immediate Answers
abstract: The cause of the crash probably won’t be determined for months, with investigators expected to focus on a wide range of issues.
lead_paragraph: The footage shows a jet barreling down a runway in South Korea at high speed before it hits a barrier and catches fire, killing 179 of the 181 people aboard. To experts in crash investigations, the video raises more questions than it answers.

headline: The Last Word: Jimmy Carter
abstract: In a never-before-seen interview with The Times in 2006, Jimmy Carter reflects on his life and work as a Cold War leader, Middle East peace broker and post-presidential career as a citizen diplomat.
lead_paragraph: In a never-before-seen interview with The Times in 2006, Jimmy Carter reflects on his life and work as a Cold War leader, Middle East peace broker and post-presidential career as a citizen diplomat.

headline: Jimmy Carter, Peacemaking President Amid Crises, Is Dead at 100
abstract: Rising from Georgia farmland to the White House, he oversaw the historic Camp David peace accords, but his one-term presidency was waylaid by troubles at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter, who rose from Georgia farmland to become the 39th president of the United States on a promise of national healing after the wounds of Watergate and Vietnam, then lost the White House in a cauldron of economic turmoil at home and crisis in Iran, died on Sunday at his home in Plains, Ga. He was 100.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Life Started in Georgia and Expanded to the World
abstract: Mr. Carter spent his childhood on a peanut farm and returned there after serving in the Navy. His political career took him to Atlanta, the White House and beyond.
lead_paragraph: James Earl Carter Jr. was born Oct. 1, 1924, the first of four children, in Plains, Ga. In 1928, the family settled on a nearby peanut farm, where he spent the rest of his childhood.

headline: That Time President Carter Was Menaced by a ‘Killer Rabbit’
abstract: Mr. Carter’s 1979 confrontation with a swimming rabbit was a “throwaway story” that became emblematic of his problems at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: In August 1979, Brooks Jackson, a reporter for The Associated Press, broke the news that a “killer rabbit” had attacked President Jimmy Carter.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Life Was One Big Trust Exercise
abstract: What the 39th president did before he got to the White House is as interesting as what came after.
lead_paragraph: A familiar story surrounds the one-term, small-town president who was James Earl Carter Jr.: a good and honest man, well intentioned but overmatched in his White House tenure, selfless and admired in his postpresidential vocations. When you reach the end of Carter’s 1982 White House memoir, “Keeping Faith,” and find him musing that “as one of the youngest of former presidents, I expected to have many useful years ahead of me,” it’s hard not to smile. Yes, he did.

headline: America Needs More Jimmy Carters
abstract: He was a model ex-president and achieved a great deal in office.
lead_paragraph: There’s no predicting history’s verdict. Up to now, Jimmy Carter, who died on Sunday at age 100 in Plains, Ga., has been judged to be a middle-of-the-pack president, his one term in office remembered for circumstances and events that simply overwhelmed him: the seizure in Iran of 52 American hostages, the bungled attempt to rescue them, the gasoline lines, inflation, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. Yet he is also considered one of America’s greatest ex-presidents, for using the residual star power of his office to help his successors and his country as a peacemaker, backstage diplomat, human rights champion, monitor of free elections and advocate for the homeless while finding time to write poetry and, by his own example, providing the best possible case for traditional religious values.

headline: Rodessa Barrett Porter, Member of a Storied Gospel Trio, Dies at 94
abstract: The Barrett Sisters were a Chicago institution, known for their tight harmonies and joyful performances. She was the last one standing.
lead_paragraph: Rodessa Barrett Porter, the last living member of the Barrett Sisters, a Chicago gospel trio renowned for their exuberant operatic sound and thrilling harmonies, died on Dec. 16 in Harvey, Ill. She was 94.

headline: 8 Books to Read About Jimmy Carter’s Life and Legacy
abstract: For many years, the 39th president generated little attention from authors. But recently books have sought to re-evaluate his reputation. Here is a look at the expanding Carter library.
lead_paragraph: While new books on presidents like Franklin D. Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan pop up regularly on bookstore shelves, Jimmy Carter for a long time generated little attention from authors (other than Carter himself, who wrote 32 books on a wide variety of subjects after leaving office).

headline: Jimmy and Rosalynn’s Relationship Was a Constant Through Wins and Losses
abstract: Their partnership withstood the glare of political campaigns and the strains of raising a family. As their world inevitably narrowed in the dusk of life, the couple came to rely on their bond even more.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, were married for 77 years, longer than any other couple who lived in the White House.

headline: In His Reading Life, Jimmy Carter Favored ‘Anything but Politics’
abstract: A voracious reader, the president liked poetry, Civil War history and Southern fiction. He also sent Erica Jong a fan letter.
lead_paragraph: When Jimmy Carter ran for president in 1976, he was new to the national scene. Of the many questions reporters asked to fill in the picture of the man, one was almost impossible for him to answer: his favorite book. A voracious speed reader, proficient in Spanish, with a vast and eclectic taste in literature, he had taken hundreds of authors to heart. Forced to decide, Carter chose James Agee’s “Let Us Now Praise Famous Men” (1941), which documented the depredations that Southern sharecroppers suffered in the Great Depression.

headline: From Scorn to Respect, Carter’s Legacy Evolved After His Presidency
abstract: The 39th president left the White House with his popularity in tatters. But four decades later, he is judged more kindly, in part for what he did after leaving office.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter left office in 1981 as one of the most unpopular presidents in modern times, defeated for re-election and seemingly doomed to be remembered by posterity as a failed commander in chief with little to show for his four years in office.

headline: The Carter Center’s Statement on Jimmy Carter’s Death
abstract: Mr. Carter died on Sunday at 100.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Carter died on Sunday at 100.

headline: In the Presidents’ Club, Carter Was the Odd Man Out
abstract: Jimmy Carter’s relationship with his successors in the Oval Office, both Republicans and fellow Democrats, was generally tense because of his outspokenness. That never mattered to him.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden stopped by former President Jimmy Carter’s home in Plains, Ga., in April 2021, it was more than just a show of respect from one commander in chief to another. It was the first time in the 40 years since Mr. Carter left the White House that any of his seven successors had visited him in his hometown.

headline: South Korea Plane Crash Kills 179 People
abstract: Only two people survived when a Jeju Air plane crashed at Muan Airport in South Korea on Sunday, the country’s worst aviation disaster in decades. Officials said they were investigating the cause.
lead_paragraph: Only two people survived when a Jeju Air plane crashed at Muan Airport in South Korea on Sunday, the country’s worst aviation disaster in decades. Officials said they were investigating the cause.

headline: Jimmy Carter Deserved Our Thanks and Respect, Not Our Sneers
abstract: We in the media and chattering class jeered at a man who probably improved more lives over a longer period than any other recent president.
lead_paragraph: We in the news media and chattering class mocked Jimmy Carter as a country bumpkin, with cartoons depicting him installing an outhouse next to the White House. His public approval dropped to 28 percent, and when Ronald Reagan succeeded him, the Reagans’ interior designer reportedly smirked about the need to “get the smell of catfish out of the White House.”

headline: The White House Statement on Jimmy Carter’s Death
abstract: Read the statement from President Biden and Jill Biden.
lead_paragraph: Read the statement from President Biden and Jill Biden.

headline: After the Presidency, Shaking Hands and Teaching Sunday School
abstract: Once he left the White House in 1981, Mr. Carter became known for his striking accessibility and his sense of humility.
lead_paragraph: The regular worshipers had come on a Sunday morning to Maranatha Baptist Church in Plains, Ga., as had hundreds of others, some driving and flying in from across the country.

headline: One Week in the Carter Presidency: Brokering Peace and a Nuclear Crisis
abstract: A single week in 1979 underscored just how eventful Mr. Carter’s presidency really was.
lead_paragraph: Long ago as it was, many Americans have forgotten — or perhaps never knew — just how eventful Jimmy Carter’s presidency was as he ricocheted from triumph to crisis and back again. Take one week in spring 1979, when he was brokering international peace one moment and confronting a domestic disaster the next.

headline: Tentative Plans for Carter’s Memorial Services
abstract: Plans include lying in state at the U.S. Capitol and a state funeral at Washington National Cathedral.
lead_paragraph: Memorial services for former President Jimmy Carter will play out over the next eight days, including a state funeral in Washington, D.C., and ceremonies in Georgia before he is buried in Plains, Ga., according to plans that have been in the works for years.

headline: Units of Force
abstract: Hannah Binney makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: What the World Gets Wrong About Jimmy Carter’s Legacy
abstract: Nicholas Kristof on what the former president’s legacy meant to him — and the world.
lead_paragraph: President Jimmy Carter had a rich legacy, often marred by misunderstandings. Despite lasting only one term, his work post-presidency stands tall in its influence around the world. In this audio obituary, the Opinion columnist Nicholas Kristof reminisces on his interactions with the former president, Carter’s social work across countries in Africa and his influence on Kristof’s worldview.

headline: Covering Carter: Seeing Hope Restored in Africa
abstract: A Times reporter visited a clinic in Ethiopia that provided life-changing treatment with the support of Jimmy Carter.
lead_paragraph: Almost two decades ago, I reported on Jimmy Carter’s humanitarian quests to combat trachoma, a blinding disease that often torments women in rural Africa. Repeated bacterial infections lead to scarring of the eyelids, eventually turning the eyelashes inward. Each blink causes the lashes to scratch victims’ eyeballs like thorns, damaging their corneas.

headline: Covering Carter: A Reporter Recalls the President’s Personal Side
abstract: In private, Jimmy Carter could be appealing and unassuming, according to a reporter who covered his presidency for The Times.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I did after starting to cover the presidency of Jimmy Carter for The Times was to read his campaign autobiography, “Why Not the Best?”

headline: Jimmy Carter Opened the White House to the Music He Loved
abstract: The Allman Brothers kick-started his candidacy and Willie Nelson smoked marijuana at the White House. Mr. Carter’s tastes were a confluence of strategy, generational change and forthright appreciation.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter was 52 when he started his presidency. But he embraced the music of the next generation: rock and soul.

headline: Jimmy Carter Was Right About Materialism but, Alas, Wrong About Us
abstract: “Too many of us now tend to worship self-indulgence and consumption,” he said in his 1979 “Crisis of Confidence” speech. If only we had listened.
lead_paragraph: Halfway into his presidency, Jimmy Carter’s back was against the wall. It was July 1979, the height of the energy crisis, and the beleaguered president went on national television to deliver not a speech, but a kind of sermon.

headline: When Jimmy Carter Turned TV Into a Pulpit
abstract: Other presidents were more celebrated for their on-screen presences, but in 1979 he gave one of the White House’s most astonishing televised speeches.
lead_paragraph: “This is not a message of happiness or reassurance. But it is the truth.” — President Jimmy Carter, July 15, 1979

headline: Carter the Critic Didn’t Spare His Successors
abstract: Jimmy Carter defied the unwritten rule of former presidents: Don’t criticize the occupant of the Oval Office.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter grinned in the Oval Office in January 2009 for a photograph, a visible gap separating him from four of his successors. As the others stood shoulder to shoulder, he positioned himself off to the side, a hand in one pocket, as if to distance himself just slightly from that most exclusive club.

headline: U.S. Presidents Pay Tribute to Jimmy Carter
abstract: The living members of the exclusive club of Oval Office occupants said Mr. Carter would be remembered for his efforts to promote peace and democracy.
lead_paragraph: Former presidents joined world leaders and others in mourning former President Jimmy Carter after his death on Sunday at 100, recalling him as a humble humanitarian and global statesman who fought for peace and democracy during his four years in the White House and in his long and active post-presidency.

headline: Carter’s Visit to the Blighted Bronx Blazed a Trail
abstract: Mr. Carter made a ‘sobering’ trip to the South Bronx to reinforce his commitment to urban areas. Other leaders would follow.
lead_paragraph: Accompanied by six motorcycle escorts and a convoy of police cars, a cream-colored limousine maneuvered past rubble-strewn lots and burned-out buildings before stopping, amid bricks bulldozed into piles as much as eight feet high, to let out an important passenger.

headline: Carter Played a Pivotal Role in Israel-Egypt Peace Deal
abstract: Mr. Carter was a lifeline to stalled talks by mediating a summit at Camp David in 1978.
lead_paragraph: It was a watershed moment in Middle East history that raised the prospect of a truce between two nations that had been at war for decades: In November 1977, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt flew to Israel and called for peace in an address to lawmakers.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Family Carved Varied Paths Through Life
abstract: Mr. Carter’s brother hawked Billy Beer and got tied up with the Libyans. His daughter was arrested while protesting the C.I.A. His grandson sought to follow him as governor of Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter’s family members carved their own paths under, and after, the public spotlight of his presidency.

headline: In His Own Words: Carter Had ‘Fear for Our Democracy’
abstract: ‘Our great nation now teeters on the brink of a widening abyss,’ the former president wrote in 2022. ‘Without immediate action, we are at genuine risk of civil conflict.’
lead_paragraph: Over the more than four decades that followed his presidency, Jimmy Carter built homes for Habitat for Humanity, traveled the globe as an emissary and oversaw his namesake organization on missions of peace, democracy and global health.

headline: Carter’s Navy Legacy Includes a Top-Secret Spy Submarine Named After Him
abstract: The former president, who served aboard submarines as a young naval officer, was “in awe” when he learned the capabilities of the U.S.S. Jimmy Carter.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts former President Jimmy Carter, who died on Sunday at age 100, was thrilled when he, as a former naval officer and submariner, found out in the late 1990s that the U.S. Navy would name its newest attack submarine in his honor.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Harris Dickinson’s Love-Hate Relationship With Acting
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Acting is neurotic, always. I say that with great love for the neurosis, with great enthusiasm for that.”

headline: ‘He Always Knew My Name’: Carter Is Remembered at a Bar That Was Dear to Him
abstract: The former president had kicked off his campaign for Georgia governor at Manuel’s Tavern in Atlanta. On Sunday, workers and patrons at the bar raised a glass in his honor.
lead_paragraph: At Manuel’s Tavern in Atlanta, memories of former President Jimmy Carter have peppered the patchwork of political and cultural paraphernalia adorning its walls for decades. In 1970, the Georgia native and peanut-farmer-turned-statesman launched his campaign for governor at the bar and restaurant, where he remains immortalized within a collage of cracked paintings, faded photographs, weathered sports pennants and dusty beer cans.

headline: Carter Had Complicated History With Israel, Despite Camp David Accords
abstract: After his presidency, Jimmy Carter became critical of Israel’s treatment of Palestinians and likened the situation to apartheid.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps former President Jimmy Carter’s most significant achievement was negotiating the Camp David Accords forging peace between Israel and Egypt, an agreement that has survived for nearly half a century and remains a bedrock of Middle East politics and security. But Mr. Carter had a complicated history with Israel.

headline: 13 Cozy Winter Dinners to Warm You Up
abstract: When the weather outside is frightful, cook something delightful.
lead_paragraph: When cooler temperatures hit, sometimes all you want is something warm and tempting to eat. We’ve rounded up a dozen of our favorite sweater weather dishes, including beef stew, cheese enchiladas, niku udon and Jamaican curry chicken, for when you need a low-lift meal to warm you from top to toe.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Jimmy Carter dies at 100.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter, who from 1977 to 1981 served as the 39th president of the U.S., died yesterday at his home in Plains, Ga. At 100, he was the longest-living president in American history. Here’s our obituary.

headline: New Year’s Eve Specials, Plus 3 Things to Watch on TV this Week
abstract: Several networks will host their annual countdowns on Tuesday, and award season will begin with the Golden Globes on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: There are so many ways you can celebrate the end of a year and the start to a new one: You can brave the streets of Times Square to be at the center of the madness, go out in a sparkly outfit to a local bar or pull a Carrie and Miranda, stay in and order Chinese food — all good options. If you want to take the cozy-on-the-couch route, here are some TV specials to watch:

headline: ‘She Was Almost Home’: Father Mourns South Korea Plane Crash Victim
abstract: Jeon Je-young was among the hundreds of family members waiting for news from the authorities about Jeju Air Flight 2216, which crashed at Muan International Airport in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Jeon Je-young was among the hundreds of family members waiting for news from the authorities about Jeju Air Flight 2216, which crashed at Muan International Airport in South Korea.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: Democratic N.Y. Lawmakers Brace for Risks of a Trump Administration
abstract: After President-elect Donald J. Trump’s gains in New York, lawmakers plan to focus on high costs and crime while safeguarding policies about immigration and abortion.
lead_paragraph: When New York lawmakers return to the State Capitol next month, one theme will be prominent: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory in November.

headline: Shen Yun Needed Publicity. The Epoch Times Wrote 17,000 Articles.
abstract: A publisher that rose to prominence promoting right-wing conspiracy theories has also served as sword and shield for the dance group and the religious movement behind it.
lead_paragraph: Steve Klett was so glad to have landed a job as a reporter at an up-and-coming newspaper in New York that he stuck with it even after his managers made him watch a disturbing video about the torture of a religious group in China.

headline: Five Laws Going Into Effect for New York in 2025
abstract: Changes are coming to paid sick leave, insulin costs, restaurant reservations, gym membership cancellations and protections for fashion industry workers.
lead_paragraph: A flurry of legislating has resulted in Gov. Kathy Hochul’s signing close to 700 bills into law that affect paid sick leave, the cost of insulin and even restaurant reservations, among other things.

headline: After Jimmy Carter Won the Presidency, Democrats Lost the South
abstract: Mr. Carter witnessed a shift from what had been a solidly Democratic South to one that Republicans, supported by white voters and particularly evangelicals, came to dominate.
lead_paragraph: On the day he was sworn in as governor of Georgia, Jimmy Carter, an ambitious white peanut farmer from rural Sumter County, announced that “the time for racial discrimination is over.” The declaration landed like the carefully calculated bomb it was intended to be in the South of 1971 — and landed Mr. Carter on the cover of Time magazine, along with the blurb, “Dixie whistles a different tune.”

headline: Samantha Power: The Conscience of Jimmy Carter
abstract: Jimmy Carter viewed his embrace of human rights as a means of restoring faith in America.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter’s elevation of human rights in U.S. foreign policy offers many urgent lessons for today. Whatever challenges he faced consistently applying the principles he championed as the 39th president, he made a radical break with decades of foreign policy tradition, changed the world’s understanding of America’s aspirations, showed deep empathy for individuals who had suffered human rights abuse and, in so doing, made a lasting impact on both the United States and the world.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Quiet but Monumental Work in Global Health
abstract: In his decades as a former president, he and his wife, Rosalynn Carter, helped bring lifesaving treatments and sanitation to poor people around the world.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter’s five decades of leadership in global health brought a hideous disease to the brink of elimination, helped deliver basic health and sanitation to millions of people and set a new standard for how aid agencies should engage with the countries they assist.

headline: Lebanon’s Economy Reels From War: ‘We Are Starting From Zero’
abstract: The conflict between Israel and Hezbollah may be suspended, but the damage is immense. “We came out of this war with nothing,” one man said.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after Israel’s invasion of Lebanon, Hasan Raad went from a decent job and a comfortable life to unemployment and displacement.

headline: 24, and Trying to Outrun Schizophrenia
abstract: Early intervention tries to rein in psychotic disorders before they can ruin young lives. For Kevin Lopez, everything is on the line.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Lopez had just stepped out of his house, on his way to meet his girlfriend for Chinese food, when it happened: He began to hallucinate.

headline: Pregnant With One Child and 295,233 Words
abstract: During the months before she gave birth, our critic wrote — a lot. What happens when the impulse to put pen to paper becomes extreme?
lead_paragraph: How does pregnancy alter the reading and writing mind? I volunteer my own for consideration. While pregnant with my daughter I wrote a 295,233-word Google doc and read very little.

headline: Skiing Palisades Tahoe, California’s ‘Big, Powdery Playground’
abstract: The resort in the Sierra Nevada, known for its challenging terrain, has cool, swagger and a long history. A first-timer is tested by its slopes and its weather.
lead_paragraph: The Palisades Tahoe ski resort has a lot going for it: an idyllic location seven miles from Lake Tahoe’s western shore, a peak elevation of 9,050 feet with 2,850 feet of vertical, and 6,000 skiable acres spread over two bases and served by 43 lifts.

headline: 10 Ways to Keep Your Mind Healthy in 2025
abstract: Adopting even just one of these easy strategies can make a meaningful difference in how you feel and function.
lead_paragraph: Are you feeling mentally ready for 2025?

headline: 7 Strategies to Strengthen Your Relationships in 2025
abstract: These tips can help you fortify your friendships and romantic partnerships in the year ahead.
lead_paragraph: Relationships are beautiful, tricky things that affect our well-being every bit as much as what we eat and whether we get enough sleep.

headline: In the Quarter-Zip Era, These Coaches Still Wear Suits
abstract: Fashion among basketball coaches has been decidedly casual since the pandemic began, but a handful of college coaches are still dressed for success.
lead_paragraph: In April 2021, Mick Cronin reached the pinnacle of men’s college basketball. He was coaching the University of California, Los Angeles at the Final Four in Indianapolis.

headline: Where Is Russia Finding New Soldiers? Wherever It Can.
abstract: From murder suspects to immigrants to a former Olympic gold medalist, Russia pressures those it thinks should fight in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia has ground through repeated waves of soldiers in Ukraine. It lost some of its most experienced troops at the very start of the invasion, then shipped off tens of thousands of convicts without seeming to care whether they survived.

headline: The Rivers Run Dry and the Lights Go Out: A Warming Nation’s Doom Loop
abstract: An extraordinary drought has drained Ecuador’s rivers and reservoirs, leading to power outages of up to 14 hours. Some fear this is the beginning of a larger global crisis.
lead_paragraph: Just a decade ago, the small, resource-rich nation of Ecuador was embarking on a bold transition to hydroelectric power.

headline: The Men Who Use Instagram to Groom Child Influencers
abstract: Photographers and other men offer to build online followings for young girls, but some are pedophiles who work with parents to sexualize them.
lead_paragraph: Everyone had an idea about how the 12-year-old girl should pose in a G-string bikini as they assembled in an Airbnb rental home in a small Louisiana town.

headline: I Wrote a Memoir About Grief. That Was the Beginning.
abstract: When I wrote about grieving my friend’s suicide, readers reached out to share stories of similar loss.
lead_paragraph: When the letters first arrived, the thing that surprised me most was their length. Having published several books of personal essays, I’d received letters from readers before. The senders alternated between laudatory and confessional, insulting by accident and insulting on purpose. They shared a sense of camaraderie between some unsavory aspect of themselves and some unsavory aspect of me. Reading them, I did not develop a thick skin so much as a better awareness of the skin I have, the calluses and soft spots.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Green, ‘Room Next Door’ Red and ‘Substance’ Yellow: It’s a Bold Season
abstract: Some potential contenders were especially vivid. Production and costume designers explain the conundrums they faced and their surprising solutions.
lead_paragraph: Fire-engine red. Egg-yolk yellow. Christmas-tree green.

headline: Looking for Random, but Great, Movies to Stream? Try Pluto TV.
abstract: Our viewing habits these days tend to be so destination-driven that there’s a real throwback pleasure in just seeing what’s on. This streaming platform allows for that.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several months, we’ve examined and recommended several streaming services for the discriminating movie lover — sites and apps for those whose tastes run toward titles a bit more esoteric than the likes of Netflix and Amazon Prime Video. Our latest entry spotlights a robust film and television streamer with a throwback feel.

headline: What’s the Matter With Chicago?
abstract: The burden of debt and public pensions could soon push Chicago into bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: The word bankruptcy has been hanging over Chicago like a storm cloud about to burst. Mayor Brandon Johnson is the latest leader to attempt to close Chicago’s gaping fiscal gap: He proposed a $300 million property tax increase to partly fill Chicago’s $982 million projected budget deficit, only to be unanimously rejected by the City Council. The City Council narrowly passed a budget on Dec. 16, with far less in tax increases than the mayor had initially demanded.

headline: The Number of Murders Kept Falling This Year, but Fear of Crime Persists
abstract: Crime was a talking point on the presidential campaign trail. But after a spike during the pandemic, murders have been dropping steadily, including in big cities like Chicago and San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The number of murders across the United States declined sharply for much of 2024, continuing a recent downward trend, according to data collected by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, cities and independent researchers.

headline: Bringing Modern Dance, Once Forbidden, to China
abstract: An oral history project, “Planting Seeds,” considers the history and impact of an American Dance Festival program to train dancers in China.
lead_paragraph: “Why do they fall down?”

headline: What Period Products Are Best for the Environment?
abstract: You’ve got choices, from menstrual cups to washable pads. Here’s how they stack up.
lead_paragraph: Menstruation may sometimes fill us with dread, but using the right period products can take environmental anxiety out of the equation.

headline: Social Media Companies Face Global Tug-of-War Over Free Speech
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks for the F.C.C. and F.T.C. have vowed to remove censorship online. That conflicts with European regulators who are pushing for stricter moderation.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies have vowed to squash an online “censorship cartel” of social media firms that they say targets conservatives.

headline: This New Year, Resolve to Green Up Your News Feed
abstract: These organizations are capturing local and regional news about climate and environmental justice that often flies under the national radar.
lead_paragraph: During this year’s global election supercycle, as it was called, national elections were held in a record number of countries, accounting for roughly half the world’s population. This scenario made the prospects for a climate turnaround, or at least the beginnings of one, seem especially promising. The human race is growing increasingly concerned about climate change, and 2024 was a global opportunity to elect leaders who were serious about addressing the greatest threat we face as a species.

headline: Time to Retire? Better to Take On a New Challenge.
abstract: At 67, a heart surgeon leaves the suburbs for Brooklyn and for the chance to continue his life’s work in a new hospital.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Scott Schubach grew up on Long Island and built a career there. Then, at 67, he decided he wanted to give life in New York City a try for the first time.

headline: Dungeons & Dragons Rolls the Dice With New Rules About Identity
abstract: The role-playing game replaced “race” with “species” and divorced several character traits from biological identity. Some longtime players are upset (as is Elon Musk).
lead_paragraph: While solving quests in Dungeons & Dragons, the gamers who role-play as elves, orcs and halflings rely on the abilities and personalities of their custom-made characters, whose innate charisma and strength are as crucial to success as the rolls of 20-sided dice.

headline: $4 Million Homes in California
abstract: This week’s listings include a compound in Healdsburg, a 1940s house in Glendale and an ocean-view home in Ventura.
lead_paragraph: This property includes a one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bathroom main house, two guest suites above the detached garage and a barn with a lofted bedroom suite. There’s a one-acre cabernet sauvignon vineyard, a pickleball court and a bocce court. The center of Healdsburg, lined with inns, wine tasting rooms and farm-to-table restaurants, is five minutes away by car. Del Rio Woods Regional Park, which sits on the edge of the Russian River, is a 15-minute drive.

headline: The 2024 High School Yearbook of American Politics
abstract: ​My year-end awards in politics for hottest king maker, biggest flash in the pan, top mean girl, most disappointing draft pick and more.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 political scene is ending where it began, with Donald Trump at center stage. No presidential contender has ever had a year like his: $350 million in court-ordered payments in a civil fraud case, $83.3 million in a defamation case, 34 felony convictions in a hush-money case, two assassination attempts and the biggie — 312 electoral votes. As usual, Mr. Trump was operating according to a different set of rules than everyone else.

headline: Wi Ha-jun of ‘Squid Game’ on the Challenges of Brotherly Love
abstract: All sibling relationships are complex — more so when your brother is a criminal mastermind who shoots you. Wi talked about his character’s predicament.
lead_paragraph: This article includes spoilers for the two seasons of “Squid Game.”

headline: How Top Pollsters Grade 2024’s Polls
abstract: Despite a pretty accurate year, the pre-election polls once again underestimated support for Donald Trump. Does that make it a successful polling cycle, or not?
lead_paragraph: Just after Election Day, Charles Franklin, the director of the Marquette Law School Poll in Wisconsin, received a lot of requests for media interviews.

headline: Olivia Hussey, Teen Star of a ‘Romeo and Juliet’ on Film, Dies at 73
abstract: Her passionate portrayal of Juliet in Franco Zeffirelli’s 1968 adaptation won enduring acclaim. In 2023, she sued over the circumstances of a nude scene.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Hussey, whose performance as the female lead in a 1968 film adaptation of “Romeo and Juliet” became its own Shakespearean tale, encompassing glory improbably achieved, helplessness with newfound power and memories that darkened over the years, died on Friday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 73.

headline: Fiasco!
abstract: Stories of when things go wrong. Really wrong.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Boeing Shares Drop After South Korean Crash
abstract: A widely used Boeing aircraft, the 737-800, was involved in Sunday’s crash-landing of a Jeju Air flight that killed 179 people.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s shares fell on Monday, a day after the deadly crash of a 737-800, a widely used model that is a staple of low-cost airlines, at an airport in South Korea. The passenger plane, operated by Jeju Air, was carrying 181 people, and all but two were killed.

headline: The Life and Legacy of Jimmy Carter
abstract: At 100, he was the longest-lived president in American history, admired more for what he did after leaving office than for his single term in the White House.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, after the Watergate scandal and the country’s withdrawal from the Vietnam War, American voters elected Jimmy Carter, a Washington outsider who had served one term as governor of Georgia, to the presidency. Mr. Carter brought a new humility to the Oval Office but, by 1980, many Americans had tired of his modest sensibility and chose not to re-elect him. As it would turn out, the qualities that hurt Mr. Carter in the White House formed the foundation of a post-presidential period that helped redefine, and redeem, his legacy in the final decades of his life.

headline: Jimmy Carter: Poet, Novelist, Memoirist, Philosopher
abstract: He wasn’t just prolific, publishing 32 books. His output also showed an unusual range that included memoirs and forays into historical fiction and even poetry.
lead_paragraph: As a governor of Georgia harboring higher aspirations, Jimmy Carter did like many other politicians who wanted to be president: He wrote a book declaring his vision for America. After leaving the White House, he wrote another book, a memoir offering his perspective on the conflicts and crises he navigated, just as presidents before and after him had done.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,291
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Dec. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 569
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Jimmy Carter Dies at 100, and Questions Surround South Korean Plane Crash
abstract: Plus, why coffee prices are soaring.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Life of Jimmy Carter
abstract: The former president has died at 100.
lead_paragraph: We’re devoting today’s newsletter to Jimmy Carter, the 39th president, who died yesterday at age 100 at his home in Plains, Ga.

headline: 5 Babies Die From the Cold in Gaza as Temperatures Drop
abstract: A boy less than 3 weeks old was among the latest to succumb to winter weather, Gazan officials said. Families displaced by Israel’s attacks have little more than tents and tarps to protect them.
lead_paragraph: At least five babies have died from the cold in Gaza in the past week, health authorities there say, as winter worsens the toll on a population traumatized by 15 months of conflict.

headline: Jimmy Carter, on Death
abstract: In a culture where death as a subject is often taboo, Mr. Carter left behind a compilation of observations about the end. Here is a selection of those writings.
lead_paragraph: In a culture where death as a subject is often taboo, Mr. Carter left behind a compilation of observations about the end. Here is a selection of those writings.

headline: For South Korean Families, a Grim Wait for Bodies After Plane Crash
abstract: Officials said it could take up to 10 days to prepare the dead for transport, with the uncertainty adding to the shock and grief of relatives packed into an airport hall.
lead_paragraph: South Korean officials on Monday began the slow, painstaking process of piecing together the many body parts found in the wreckage after the country’s worst plane crash in decades, as hundreds of relatives, waiting to receive the victims’ bodies, grew more anguished by the hour.

headline: Linda Lavin, Broadway Actress and Star of TV Sitcom ‘Alice,’ Dies at 87
abstract: She won two Golden Globe Awards and an Emmy nomination for her role on the show. She also earned a Tony Award for best actress in the play “Broadway Bound.”
lead_paragraph: Linda Lavin, the Tony Award-winning Broadway actress who was best known for starring as a waitress and single mom on the long-running sitcom “Alice,” died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 87.

headline: Questions Arise Over Concrete Wall Near Runway in South Korea Crash
abstract: Aviation safety analysts said they expect officials investigating the crash, which killed 179 people, to look into the location and composition of a structure housing an antenna.
lead_paragraph: Aviation analysts are considering several factors that might have contributed to a deadly plane crash in South Korea, including a concrete structure near the runway that the airliner slammed into, exploding and killing 179 of the 181 people aboard.

headline: Carter Funeral Service to Be Held at Washington National Cathedral on Jan. 9
abstract: The state funeral will cap more than a week of remembrances honoring Jimmy Carter, the 39th president of the United States, who died at 100 on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter’s state funeral at Washington National Cathedral will be held on Jan. 9, featuring a eulogy by President Biden and culminating more than a week of ceremonies and tributes, organizers said on Monday.

headline: From Bird Strike to Crash: The Mystery of the Korean Plane’s Four Fateful Minutes
abstract: The time between when the pilot reported a bird strike and when it crashed could be key to unraveling one of the world’s worst aviation disasters in years.
lead_paragraph: Already 30 minutes behind schedule, the pilot flying the Jeju Air jet with 181 people on board was preparing to land at his destination in southwestern South Korea on Sunday morning when the control tower warned him about flocks of birds in the area.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 29, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 29, 2024.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 30, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: After Years in Prison, a Dancehall Star Returns to the Stage
abstract: Vybz Kartel served more than a decade of a murder sentence before his conviction was overturned. Despite imprisonment and a radio ban, his influence has grown.
lead_paragraph: Early into his incarceration in a Jamaican prison, Adidja Palmer, the dancehall artist known as Vybz Kartel, learned to rig a makeshift studio. He would wrap himself inside his mattress and record his vocals on a contraband iPhone, while other inmates would keep watch for approaching guards.

headline: Appeals Are Filed in Mass Rape Case in France, Bringing New Trial for 17 Men
abstract: Dominique Pelicot, the man convicted of raping his wife and of inviting dozens of others to join him in the abuse, did not appeal. But 17 of the other 50 found guilty did.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Pelicot, the 72-year-old who admitted to drugging his wife for years in France and inviting dozens of other men to join him in raping her, will not appeal his conviction on aggravated rape and other charges, his lawyer said on Monday.

headline: 10 Tips to Help You Eat Healthier in 2025
abstract: Throughout the past year, we reviewed seed oils, ultraprocessed foods, Bruce Springsteen’s diet and more. Here’s what we learned.
lead_paragraph: As New Year’s Day approaches every year, the first thing I do is ensure I have black-eyed peas on hand — so I can make Hoppin’ John, the traditional “good luck” dish of legumes and rice. Second, I review what I’ve learned over the past 12 months.

headline: Biden Announces $2.5 Billion in Security Aid to Ukraine
abstract: The Treasury Department also released an additional $3.4 billion in budget aid as the Biden administration rushes assistance to Kyiv in its final weeks in office.
lead_paragraph: The United States is sending nearly $2.5 billion in security assistance to Ukraine, as the Biden administration continues to rush military aid to Kyiv in the weeks before President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office.

headline: From the Grave, Mondale to Eulogize the Man Who Made Him Vice President
abstract: Walter F. Mondale died in 2021, but he left behind the eulogy he planned to deliver at former President Jimmy Carter’s funeral.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale thought he would still be around to speak at the funeral for Jimmy Carter, who was a little more than three years his senior.

headline: Man Dies After Helping His Family Flee Christmas Morning House Fire
abstract: Steven Weatherford ran upstairs to wake his father and two aunts as a fire engulfed their home in Oakland, Calif. He later died of smoke inhalation, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Steven Weatherford was sleeping in the living room of his childhood home in Oakland, Calif., on Christmas morning when his younger brother, Jerry, woke up next to him around 6:30 a.m. and saw smoke coming out from underneath the television.

headline: Read Walter Mondale’s Eulogy of Jimmy Carter
abstract: Before former Vice President Walter Mondale died in 2021, he left behind the eulogy he had planned to deliver. His son Ted Mondale will read it at Jimmy Carter’s memorial service at Washington National Cathedral on Jan. 9.
lead_paragraph: Before former Vice President Walter Mondale died in 2021, he left behind the eulogy he had planned to deliver. His son Ted Mondale will read it at Jimmy Carter’s memorial service at Washington National Cathedral on Jan. 9.

headline: $100 Million for One Square Mile: Deal to Protect Land in Grand Tetons
abstract: After years of negotiations and threats of development, Wyoming will sell a prized piece of land so that it can be preserved inside Grand Teton National Park.
lead_paragraph: Wyoming has agreed to a $100 million deal to turn over a prized parcel of land within the boundaries of Grand Teton National Park, allowing the federal government to protect the plot from the threat of development.

headline: Holding the ‘Title of Citizen,’ Carter Carved a New Mold for Ex-Presidents
abstract: Jimmy Carter redefined what a president can do after departing the White House, leaving a lasting imprint through his work overseas, particularly in the realm of public health.
lead_paragraph: President Jimmy Carter had no idea what he was going to do next when he delivered his farewell address to the nation in January 1981. Defeated after a single term by Ronald Reagan, he simply told Americans that he would leave the White House and “take up once more the only title in our democracy superior to that of president — the title of citizen.”

headline: The New York Times 2024 Culture News Quiz
abstract: How well did you keep up with the world of arts and entertainment this year? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: How well did you keep up with the world of arts and entertainment this year? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: An Easy (and Less Expensive) Way to Ring in the New Year With Caviar
abstract: Eric Kim’s tobiko pasta combines the briny flavor of flying-fish roe with a rich, creamy sauce.
lead_paragraph: Happy New Year’s Eve eve to you all! Do you have your tomorrow-night plans all sorted out? We usually like to stay home, watch an old classic movie and then shimmy into bed right after the countdown. But there have been more effervescent years with friends and noisemakers, Champagne and caviar.

headline: What if Reagan Had Been More Like Carter?
abstract: Carter’s vision and persistence on solar energy deserve to be brightly illuminated.
lead_paragraph: In reflecting on Jimmy Carter’s death, my mind skipped to the Apple TV+ streaming series “For All Mankind,” an alternate reality drama that imagines how the world might have been if it was the Soviets, not the Americans, who walked on the moon first during the Cold War space race.

headline: You Saw the Movie in 2024. Do You Know the Book That Inspired It?
abstract: As the year winds down, the last of the big buzzy films have hit the screen — and these five were based largely on memoirs and biographies. Try this quiz to see how many you know.
lead_paragraph: As the year winds down, the last of the big buzzy films have hit the screen — and these five were based largely on memoirs and biographies. Try this quiz to see how many you know.

headline: Trump Endorses Mike Johnson to Continue as House Speaker
abstract: The question of whether the president-elect would back the speaker for another term has hung over Republicans, especially after recent tensions. But the endorsement does not lock up the job for Mr. Johnson.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump endorsed Speaker Mike Johnson for another term in his post on Monday, moving to shore up the fortunes of a leader whose fate he threw into question this month when he sank a bipartisan spending deal Mr. Johnson had struck to avert a government shutdown.

headline: Jeans in the White House? President Carter Made It So.
abstract: He projected authenticity not just through his actions, but also with his uniform.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, jeans weren’t considered presidential. Former President Gerald R. Ford, a square-jawed Republican, wore stocky suits, and while it’s possible that Lyndon Johnson or John F. Kennedy wore denim in the Oval Office, there is no record of them in Levi’s as they held the nation’s highest office.

headline: Syria’s Rebel Leader Offers Hint of Timetable for Potential Elections
abstract: Ahmed al-Shara, who led the rebel offensive that toppled Bashar al-Assad, offered little clarity on what the electoral process might look like.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s de facto new leader has said it could take up to four years to hold elections, offering the first potential timetable for a transition of power following the overthrow of the country’s longtime ruler, President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: ‘Aida’ Returns to the Met Opera Through Archaeologists’ Eyes
abstract: Michael Mayer is directing the Met’s first new production of Verdi’s classic in nearly four decades, aiming for something fresh yet enduring.
lead_paragraph: When the director Michael Mayer set out to stage Verdi’s “Aida” at the Metropolitan Opera, he knew the stakes were high. Audiences had grown attached to the house’s grand, gaudy, long-running production, and he was resigned to the fact that any replacement might be greeted with skepticism.

headline: The 2024 Good Tech Awards
abstract: In a year of continued A.I. progress, “founder mode” drama and a Trump election win, a few tech projects stood out for their clear benefits to humanity.
lead_paragraph: In the tech industry, 2024 was a year of fast change and shifting winds.

headline: Dark Doldrums Overshadow Europe’s Energy Markets
abstract: Periods of low sun and wind, a weather pattern known as a Dunkelflaute, can increase electricity prices and stoke political tensions.
lead_paragraph: Europe is watching the skies for a gremlin that can roil its energy markets and stoke political tensions between neighboring countries. This weather phenomenon, known as the Dunkelflaute, has become a source of frustration to government ministers and a potential pitfall on their journey to cleaner energy.

headline: Jimmy Carter and Motown Founder Berry Gordy’s Surprising Connection
abstract: According to a detailed family history compiled by one of the former president’s sons, the two men shared a common ancestor in 19th-century Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter could trace his family history back centuries, through an ancestral line that included cotton planters, Quakers, a spy for George Washington at Valley Forge and, of course, Georgia peanut farmers.

headline: Fire-Friendly Weather Predicted for Parts of the High Plains and Southern California
abstract: Forecasters warned of a “critical” wildfire risk on Monday in New Mexico, Texas and Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: A dangerous mix of strong winds, unseasonably warm temperatures and parched landscapes has created conditions favorable for wildfires in the southern High Plains and in Southern California this week.

headline: Five People Indicted in Connection With Liam Payne’s Fatal Fall
abstract: Two people are accused of supplying the singer with drugs and three others with negligence related to his fall from the balcony of a Buenos Aires hotel.
lead_paragraph: Argentine authorities have indicted five people in connection with the death of Liam Payne, the former One Direction singer who fell from a third-floor balcony at a hotel in Buenos Aires in October.

headline: Russia and Ukraine Swap More Than 300 Prisoners Ahead of U.S. Transition
abstract: Exchanges have taken place before, but this deal, involving big numbers on both sides, comes as Trump prepares to take over in Washington, potentially endangering American aid to Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: Russia and Ukraine announced on Monday that they had exchanged more than 300 prisoners of war in a deal brokered by the United Arab Emirates. The swap comes just weeks before American military aid for Kyiv is likely to be thrown into question under the Trump administration.

headline: The Music Is Too Loud. That’s the Point.
abstract: Vinyl-focused listening bars inspired by ones in Japan are opening across New York, attracting audiophiles and city dwellers looking for a respite from the cacophony outside their doors.
lead_paragraph: On one Friday evening, the conversation in the back room of All Blues in TriBeCa, where about two dozen people sat in leather chairs, was overtaken by the music streaming from three large, mid-20th-century speakers.

headline: Amy Carter, Thrust Into the Public Eye at a Young Age, Has Since Receded
abstract: Jimmy Carter’s daughter had an extraordinary and well-documented childhood in the White House. Since then she has for the most part lived a very private life.
lead_paragraph: The moment lingers in the national memory: a 9-year-old girl, golden haired and slightly awkward, traipsing off to public school in the nation’s capital with the Secret Service in tow.

headline: 5 Takeaways From The Times’s Coverage of Shen Yun
abstract: The dance group has exploited its young performers while amassing huge wealth for the Falun Gong religious movement — and getting a publicity boost from The Epoch Times.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, The New York Times has investigated the inner workings of the dance group Shen Yun, known for its instantly recognizable posters and billboards.

headline: The Most Inspiring Houses We Visited in 2024
abstract: From a tiny French fisherman’s cabin to a hexagonal home in Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s T List newsletter, we’re looking back at our top house stories from the past year. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday, along with monthly travel and beauty guides, and the latest stories from our print issues. And you can always reach us at tmagazine@nytimes.com.

headline: Jumping Out of a Plane, With Skydiving Seniors
abstract: To report on the Wuest Ways group, which has been hosting skydives since 1987, a reporter had to strap on a parachute and take the 12,500-foot leap.
lead_paragraph: I was in a tiny plane with skydivers in their 70s and 80s, and I was distracted.

headline: Trump Loses Appeal of Carroll’s $5 Million Award in Sex-Abuse Case
abstract: The president-elect had asked a court to overturn the defamation judgment against him in the case, which centered on E. Jean Carroll’s account of a sexual attack in a dressing room.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday failed to overturn a $5 million judgment that he sexually abused the writer E. Jean Carroll in a Bergdorf Goodman dressing room in the mid-1990s and later defamed her.

headline: Jimmy Carter, the President and the Man
abstract: Readers praise the former president’s accomplishments and character and recall encounters with him.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Elon Musk Has Planted Himself Almost Literally at Trump’s Doorstep
abstract: For much of the period since Election Day, the billionaire has been staying at a $2,000-a-night cottage at Mar-a-Lago, giving him easy access to the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk plays many roles with President-elect Donald J. Trump. He is Mr. Trump’s most important donor, most influential social media promoter and a key adviser on policy and personnel.

headline: What to Know About Celebrating New Year’s Eve in Times Square
abstract: New York’s ball-drop celebration is more than a century old. One important fact about this year: You are likely to get wet.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people from all over the globe will descend on Manhattan on Tuesday to welcome the new year at midnight by watching a scintillating orb drop 66.7 feet in 60 seconds amid storms of confetti.

headline: China Hacked Treasury Dept. in ‘Major’ Breach, U.S. Says
abstract: The episode comes at a particularly sensitive moment, just as the Biden White House is dealing with one of the most far-reaching, and damaging, hacks into American infrastructure in the cyberage.
lead_paragraph: One of China’s intelligence agencies hacked the U.S. Treasury Department, gaining access to the workstations of government employees and unclassified documents, the Biden administration said on Monday, the latest in a series of embarrassing surveillance operations against major American institutions.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Remembering Jimmy Carter
abstract: Plus, the best of 2024.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter, who rose from a peanut farm to become the 39th U.S. president, died on Sunday at his home in Georgia. He was 100.

headline: Assault Charge Against Oklahoma Police Officer Is Dismissed
abstract: Oklahoma’s attorney general dismissed the charge against an Oklahoma City police sergeant who was seen in body camera footage throwing a 71-year-old man to the pavement during an argument over a ticket.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma’s attorney general has dismissed an assault charge against a police officer who slammed a 71-year-old man to the ground, fracturing his neck, during an argument over a traffic ticket in October.

headline: Israel and Hamas Each Claim Wins in Fierce Fighting in Northern Gaza
abstract: As the renewed clashes in the north of the enclave neared the three-month mark, there was no sign of them abating.
lead_paragraph: After nearly three months of an intensified Israeli military campaign in northern Gaza to quell what Israel has said is a Hamas resurgence, fighting raged unabated on Monday, with each side claiming successes against the other’s fighters.

headline: Every Crossword Constructor Debut in 2024
abstract: This year, 88 constructors published their first crossword puzzle in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Despite turning 82 this year, the New York Times Crossword is still full of new entries and new constructors. In the past four years, over 400 people have published their first puzzle in our pages — more than did so from 2009 to 2019. More people are solving the daily crossword than ever before, and some might argue that we’re in a crossword puzzle golden age.

headline: Our Favorite Crossword Debuts of 2024
abstract: Our puzzle editors and Wordplay columnists share their favorite new entries to the New York Times Crossword this year.
lead_paragraph: You might assume that after 75 years of daily publication, the New York Times Crossword had summarily exhausted the dictionary of terms suited for a 15x15 grid. After all, there are language constraints that an American crossword can accommodate — hence the timelessness of vowel-stuffed entries like AUEL, OREO and ELOI.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s legacy
abstract: Plus, the search for answers on the Jeju Air crash. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter’s state funeral will be held on Jan. 9 at the Washington National Cathedral. It’ll feature a eulogy by President Biden and culminate more than a week of ceremonies and remembrances.

headline: Trinidad and Tobago Declares State of Emergency Over Rising Crime
abstract: To curb gang killings and a rise in homicides, the measure empowers the military to make arrests and allows the authorities to enter suspects’ homes without warrants and deny them bail.
lead_paragraph: The government of Trinidad and Tobago, facing an alarming rise in violence, including retaliatory gang killings, on Monday declared a state of emergency. The measure empowers the military to make arrests and allows the authorities to enter suspects’ homes without warrants and deny them bail.

headline: Norovirus Outbreaks Are Rising Nationwide, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Here’s what to know about symptoms and treatment, as well as how to reduce your risk of infection.
lead_paragraph: There have been an unusually high number of norovirus outbreaks sickening people across the country this month, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.There were 91 suspected or confirmed norovirus outbreaks in the first week of December, the most recent data available. This is a higher number than the C.D.C. has recorded during the same week in recent years. It also exceeds the number of outbreaks recorded in early December in the years leading up to the Covid-19 pandemic.

headline: In Carter’s Hometown, a Long Vigil Ends With Sorrow, but Also Uplift
abstract: Plains, Ga., had been bracing for the inevitable through the former president’s ailments and nearly two years of hospice care. Still, his death, at 100, “doesn’t seem real.”
lead_paragraph: The Georgia town known first and foremost as the home of Jimmy Carter had steeled itself time and again for an existence without him. First, there was his cancer diagnosis in 2015, and then the fall that broke a hip, and the disclosure almost two years ago that he had entered hospice care.

headline: ‘Hanging Out With Jimmy Carter,’ Biden Faces the Echoes of History
abstract: President Biden is yet another one-term Democrat hurt by inflation and struggling to free hostages before leaving office. But Mr. Carter’s enhanced reputation offers hope that he too may be remembered more favorably.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden appeared on camera to pay tribute to former President Jimmy Carter, he sounded almost as if he were thinking of himself in these final days in office.

headline: After Judicial Ruling, M.T.A. Says Congestion Pricing to Begin on Sunday
abstract: The decision in a lawsuit brought by the State of New Jersey meant that the tolling plan could go ahead as planned, New York said. A lawyer for New Jersey disagreed.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday found that New York had taken most of the necessary steps to enact a plan that charges drivers when entering the center of Manhattan, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it would go into effect on Sunday.

headline: South Korea Clears Way to Detain President in Martial Law Inquiry
abstract: The police are investigating whether President Yoon Suk Yeol tried to lead an insurrection when he declared martial law and plunged the country into crisis.
lead_paragraph: A court in South Korea cleared the way for officials to detain President Yoon Suk Yeol for questioning on Tuesday, as the authorities investigated whether his declaration of martial law this month, which plunged the country into political crisis, amounted to an insurrection.

headline: Here’s Where Northern Lights May Be Visible on New Year’s Eve
abstract: The northern part of the country could see pink and red streaks in the skies this week, just in time for New Year’s Eve, according to NOAA.
lead_paragraph: Fireworks won’t be the only thing lighting up the sky during New Year celebrations.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 31, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about efforts to identify a woman who was fatally burned by another passenger inside a New York City subway train misstated the name of Mayor Eric Adams’s spokeswoman. She is Kayla Mamelak Altus, not Mamolek.

headline: 11 Data Points and Discoveries That Surprised Us in 2024
abstract: Upshot staff members share a selection of their favorite charts, documents, queries and calculations from the past year.
lead_paragraph: Upshot staff members share a selection of their favorite charts, documents, queries and calculations from the past year.

headline: U.S. Senator’s Son Gets 28 Years for Car Chase That Killed Sheriff’s Deputy
abstract: Ian Cramer, the 43-year-old son of Senator Kevin Cramer,  Republican of North Dakota, led the police on a highway pursuit that killed a sheriff’s deputy.
lead_paragraph: The son of Senator Kevin Cramer, Republican of North Dakota, was sentenced to 28 years in prison on Monday in connection with a high-speed car chase that ended with a crash that killed a sheriff’s deputy last year.

headline: Hochul Installs New Leader at Prison Where Inmate Was Fatally Beaten
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York moved to try to contain the fallout from the death of Robert Brooks, in which 14 corrections workers have been implicated.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Monday installed a new top leader at the upstate prison where 14 corrections workers have been implicated in a fatal attack on an inmate that was captured on video.

headline: Go Around in Circles
abstract: Michael Lieberman brings our solving year to a close.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Pentagon Releases Detainee Held at Guantánamo Since Day 1
abstract: The prisoner, who was repatriated to Tunisia, was never charged. His transfer is part of a Biden administration push to further reduce the dwindling detainee population at the wartime prison.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon on Monday repatriated a Tunisian detainee who was brought to the U.S. military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the day it opened, was never charged at the war court and was approved for transfer more than a decade ago.

headline: Migrants Accused of Killing Mexican Immigration Agent
abstract: Officials said the agent was attacked by a group of migrants at a checkpoint in the northern state of Chihuahua after asking to see their identification papers. At least two migrants were arrested.
lead_paragraph: A federal immigration agent in Mexico was killed on Monday afternoon by a group of migrants in the northern state of Chihuahua after asking to see their identification papers, the country’s migration agency said.

headline: Pentagon Appeals Court Upholds Plea Deals in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: The three-judge decision appeared, at least for now, to put plea proceedings for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and two others back on track to take place in early January at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: A Pentagon appeals panel on Monday upheld a military judge’s finding that the plea deals in the Sept. 11 case are valid, clearing the way at least for now for a guilty plea hearing next week with the accused mastermind of the attack, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed.

headline: Drugs, Scams and Sin: Myanmar’s War Has Made It the Global Crime Capital
abstract: The chaotic country is now a magnet for criminal syndicates, particularly from China, destabilizing law enforcement across much of Asia.
lead_paragraph: The flower fields stretch out from the mountain village along most every road — fluttering patchworks of white and pink and purple.

headline: Syrian Refugees in Germany Are Glad They Can Visit Home. But Just Visit.
abstract: The more than one million Syrians who fled to Germany have celebrated the end of war in their homeland, but some fear it could mean losing their refugee status.
