lead_paragraph: Upon learning that Syria’s dynastic dictatorship had fallen, Iman Mohammed, a Syrian refugee living in Germany, felt a surge of elation at the idea that she could return to her homeland.

headline: Quote of the Day: After a Presidency Ended, Carter Took On the World
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “No one looks at the post-presidency now as kind of a dead period where you don’t do anything.”

headline: Chinese Muslims, After Finding a Refuge in Queens, Now Fear Trump
abstract: At a shelter in the Flushing area of New York, Hui Muslims who fled oppression in China are concerned about the president-elect’s vows to tighten asylum policy.
lead_paragraph: They survived re-education camps in China’s western Xinjiang region. They were released from detention centers and psychiatric hospitals. They watched their loved ones disappear one by one and feared when it would be their turn.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Fighting in Northern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: After nearly three months of an intensified Israeli military campaign in northern Gaza to quell what Israel has said is a Hamas resurgence, fighting continued unabated yesterday, with each side claiming successes against the other’s fighters.

headline: A China-Taiwan War Would Start an Economic Crisis. America Isn’t Ready.
abstract: Congress must prepare a plan now to avoid global meltdown.
lead_paragraph: China’s military exercises in the waters around Taiwan this month — the largest in almost three decades — highlight the growing risk of a total breakdown in United States-China relations. A full-scale invasion of Taiwan is one eventuality; last year, the C.I.A. director, William Burns, noted that China’s president, Xi Jinping, has instructed his armed forces to be ready for an invasion by 2027.

headline: Food Tourism Is Dead. But Something More Interesting Is Emerging.
abstract: The world’s next great cuisine isn’t hidden in some undiscovered corner of the globe. It’s in the spaces among cultures, traditions and technologies.
lead_paragraph: I eagerly awaited my reservation last year at Rekondo in San Sebastián, Spain — another predictable, if excellent, stop on the well-worn food tourist circuit. At my table, I lost myself in a wine list thick as a phone book, each page heavy with forgotten Riojas, until the pristine hake kokotxas arrived.

headline: The Man Who Showed the World South Korea’s Deadly Plane Crash
abstract: In his own words, a restaurant owner described recording videos of the Jeju Air plane crash as it happened. “Every time I closed my eyes, I kept seeing afterimages of the blast.”
lead_paragraph: On the morning that the ill-fated Jeju Air flight was headed to its destination in southwestern South Korea, Lee Geun-young was near the airport, getting ready to open a restaurant serving mud-flat octopus, a local delicacy.

headline: Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt Reach Divorce Settlement
abstract: The settlement resolves a key part of the protracted end of their very public Hollywood romance.
lead_paragraph: Angelina Jolie and her ex-husband Brad Pitt have reached a divorce settlement, her lawyer said late Monday, resolving a key part of a separation saga that has stretched for eight years and drawn relentless media coverage.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: The Soviet Holiday Classic Even Kremlin Skeptics Can’t Stop Watching
abstract: “The Irony of Fate” is a turn-of-the-year TV tradition that endures even in households that are now wary of Russian culture.
lead_paragraph: When the film “The Irony of Fate, or Enjoy Your Bath!” premiered on millions of television sets in the Soviet Union on Jan. 1, 1976, Igor Rogovyi was 9 and living in Odesa, Ukraine.

headline: On E-Scooters and ATVs, Russian Forces Swarm Ukrainian Positions in the East
abstract: Stepped up attacks by Russia are heightening longstanding concerns over how Ukraine manages its military and countering assumptions that Moscow’s offensive would slow, soldiers and military analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Three Russian soldiers race down a cratered road on electric scooters, the video shows, while others speed across muddy fields on all-terrain vehicles.

headline: How ‘Trophy’ Videos Link Paramilitary Commanders to War Crimes in Sudan
abstract: Visual evidence collected and analyzed over months by The New York Times identifies the commanders leading an opaque paramilitary group, the Rapid Support Forces, as fighters under their watch commit atrocities across Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Visual evidence collected and analyzed over months by The New York Times identifies the commanders leading an opaque paramilitary group, the Rapid Support Forces, as fighters under their watch commit atrocities across Sudan.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Life, in 17 Objects
abstract: Items from his family, the military, his political career and long post-presidency — and two he made himself.
lead_paragraph: Lillian Gordy Carter, the president’s mother, lived life firmly on her own terms.

headline: The Backsplash Could Be the Star of Your Kitchen, if You Let It
abstract: There are countless colors, styles and materials to choose from. It comes down to the statement you’d like to make.
lead_paragraph: When designing a kitchen, it’s normal to obsess over appliances, cabinets and counters. But there’s another element that deserves just as much attention: the backsplash.

headline: For Those Who Don’t Trust Tap, There’s ‘Raw Water’
abstract: Untreated water enthusiasts swear by natural springs. Their movement has parallels with raw milk drinkers and vaccine skeptics.
lead_paragraph: The highway that winds along the coast of Marin County offers some of California’s most magnificent vistas, with the deep blue Pacific Ocean glittering through veils of fog. But for a handful of travelers, the views aren’t the prize.

headline: Your Top Health Questions of 2024
abstract: We researched chapped lips, pain relievers, hangnails and more. Here are the answers you need for a healthy new year.
lead_paragraph: You have burning health questions. We all do. But if you’ve spent any time scouring the internet for answers to them, you’ve probably stumbled upon some dubious information.

headline: First-Class Upgrades: How to Score a Sweeter Seat
abstract: Airlines are offering more ways than ever to get a taste of the champagne skies, but how do you get past the curtain, and when is it worth the cost? Here are some tips.
lead_paragraph: Visions of champagne and lie-flat seats danced in my head when Azores Airlines accepted my 500-euro bid to upgrade my husband and me to business class during our kid-free vacation this past August.

headline: Red-Light Hats and $2,700 Laser Kits: The Evolution of At-Home Beauty
abstract: As the science of skin care continues to expand, some of those advances have landed directly in consumers’ hands. Is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: For years, an at-home beauty device meant a hair dryer or maybe an electric toothbrush. Today, they have never been more omnipresent or more advanced, with heavily marketed products that range from $500 LED masks that promise to reduce fine lines, pigmentation and redness to laser wands that permanently (or so they claim) remove unwanted body hair.

headline: All I Want for Christmas Is My Broken Family
abstract: Rebecca Kauffman’s fifth novel, “I’ll Come to You,” is a “Corrections”-esque tale of one clan’s dysfunctions and joys in mid-90s America.
lead_paragraph: “And then there is using everything,” Gertrude Stein said of her approach to composition; for Rebecca Kauffman, there’s using everyone. The novelist is interested in congress: Friends reunite, families meet up, exes come together, and there’s something to be seen from each character’s vantage point. Her 2022 novel, “Chorus,” was told from nine points of view. Her narration never stays in the same place — or even the same brain — for too long.

headline: Goodbye to Small Yard, High Fence
abstract: The Biden administration’s approach to China has been full of contradictions.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 2, the United States announced a new round of export controls on advanced semiconductors to China, and more restrictions are expected soon. It was among the final pieces in an enduring legacy of the Biden administration: a significant expansion in the scale and scope of restricting China’s access to technology.

headline: The Hipster Grifter Tells All
abstract: In “You’ll Never Believe Me,” Kari Ferrell details going from internet notoriety to self-knowledge in a captivating, sharp and very funny memoir.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, The New York Observer published “The Hipster Grifter,” an article identifying a small-time scammer prowling the Brooklyn scene, extracting cash from unsuspecting men. Her name was Kari Ferrell, and she was 22 and immensely charming. She left a flurry of notes in her wake, cocktail napkins etched with sexually explicit jokes, sometimes signed “Korean Abdul-Jabbar.” It worked as long as her marks didn’t Google her name and find that she was wanted for felony fraud in Utah.

headline: Why You Should Relish Embarrassment
abstract: It’s only when we’re vulnerable that we allow ourselves to be truly known.
lead_paragraph: It started with a crush. We met at a book launch and drank martinis, our knees touching under the table in the corner of a dim bar. They were charming. “You’re charming,” I told them. They were also tall, with beautiful hair, eyes that seemed to collect everything and an impassive face that gave nothing away. This attitude of reserve made me crave their attention. I read their horoscope, jabbered about them to my friends and wrote bad, moony poetry. If I sound obsessed, I was.

headline: Why Directors Can’t Quit ‘Nosferatu’
abstract: Robert Eggers’s movie is the latest cinematic adaptation of the 1922 F.W. Murnau film, itself an unauthorized adaptation of Bram Stoker’s horror novel.
lead_paragraph: The funny thing is, we’re not even supposed to be able to see the original “Nosferatu.” When the director F.W. Murnau and the producer Albin Grau approached the estate of Bram Stoker, hoping to adapt his seminal horror novel “Dracula” into a feature film in 1921, the author’s widow turned them down flat. Unswayed, the filmmakers went ahead, pressing the screenwriter Henrik Galeen to make a handful of cosmetic changes to obscure their act of plagiarism. When “Nosferatu” was released the following year, the Stoker estate took them to court, kicking off a lengthy international legal battle; the final ruling ordered all copies of the film to be confiscated and destroyed.

headline: A Doping Feud Almost Cost Salt Lake City the Olympics. It Still Might.
abstract: A Justice Department investigation into whether antidoping authorities covered up positive tests for elite Chinese swimmers set off a power play to kill the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: In late June, federal agents working on a complex investigation were secretly positioned at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport, tracking a potentially key witness — a top international swimming official involved in the Olympics.

headline: How Will We Eat in 2025? 9 Predictions to Chew On.
abstract: Food forecasters see a year of offbeat choices: savory coffees, great convenience-store cuisine and sauces on everything.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand what’s going to be big in food next year, ignore the fridgescaping and hot-honey espresso martinis. Instead, peer into the nation’s psyche.

headline: Americans Love to Hate the State. But Do They Really Want This?
abstract: Eviscerating modern state institutions almost always clears a path for a different political order, built on loyalties and connections to the ruler.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump’s picks for many of the top cabinet positions in his upcoming administration are unorthodox, to say the least. In some cases, it would be hard to think of of people less qualified for their proposed jobs.

headline: A Mountain Lion Attacked My Nephews. What Could Have Stopped It?
abstract: As dangerous encounters in California continue to rise, local residents and wildlife experts are trying to figure out how humans and big cats can coexist.
lead_paragraph: On March 23, 2024, while walking down a forest service road outside Georgetown, Calif., my nephews Taylen and Wyatt Brooks were attacked by a mountain lion.

headline: Under a Highway in Rio, a Dance Style Charms a New Generation
abstract: On Rio de Janeiro’s fringes, partygoers have been dancing “charme” to the sounds of R&B for decades. Now, a new crop of dancers is reviving — and transforming — the scene.
lead_paragraph: Trucks, buses and cars rumbled overhead, drowning out Marcus Azevedo’s voice. In the distance, sirens blared and exhaust pipes backfired. From under a highway overpass, Mr. Azevedo, a dance teacher, shouted over the noise, “Five, six, seven, eight!”

headline: See Ya, 2024. Here’s What We Loved.
abstract: Where Times Opinion — and listeners — found joy this year.
lead_paragraph: As the year comes to an end, Times Opinion staff members — and our listeners — shared the things from 2024 they wanted to take with them into the new year. They range from impromptu hangs to weird A.I. TikToks. Take a listen.

headline: How Suicide Drones Transformed the Front Lines in Ukraine
abstract: Outnumbered and desperate, the nation began hacking cheap consumer UAVs with explosives — bringing a brutal new form of terror to 21st-century warfare.
lead_paragraph: The suicide drone beelined toward a strip of forest separating two agricultural fields. A remotely piloted quadcopter with a wingspan narrower than that of a duck, a camera in its nose and an antenna protruding from its tail, it crossed into Russian airspace unchallenged minutes before. An armor-piercing warhead hung from its underside. Now, about 18 miles south of Belgorod, it descended toward cropland with about five minutes of battery power remaining. It was time to hunt.

headline: For Comics, Honing Jokes Has Taken a Back Seat to Marketing. That’s Not Good.
abstract: Stand-ups need time and practice to get good. When they have to focus on promotion and their social media feeds, the art form suffers.
lead_paragraph: In November, the comic Isabel Hagen made a confession that you almost never hear an artist make publicly. In a provocative Substack essay headlined “Social Media Is Depriving Artists,” she wrote that while she once spent most of her time writing jokes, studying and refining them, her time and focus had shifted to promoting them.

headline: One Indelible Scene: Yearning and Loss in ‘All We Imagine as Light’
abstract: A mysterious rice cooker and a rainstorm combine to convey what a woman doesn’t speak of.
lead_paragraph: There’s a short scene in “All We Imagine as Light” in which a lonely woman cradles a rice cooker, and everything that has come before in this transcendent movie suddenly shifts, your perceptions included. In this one crystallizing moment, the woman’s yearning, desire that has been discreetly waiting in the background, rushes into view. In fewer than two minutes, she transforms from a character whom you have just begun to know into one who — by virtue of her longing and aching vulnerability — has immediately taken up residence in your heart.

headline: Alaska Knows Why Her Drag Show Resonates: ‘It’s About Family’
abstract: The performer discusses her Off Broadway musical about warring queens. “Everyone can connect to being a young person not feeling understood,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Alaska, the bigwig drag queen starring in “Drag: The Musical,” has a surname that’s unprintable here. But she has an adorbs alternative.

headline: Here’s Something We Agree On in America
abstract: Americans think of our society as so divided. Might there be some upside to starting the new year knowing we aren’t as polarized as we thought?
lead_paragraph: As we close out 2024, something important is unfolding in America that hasn’t happened in many years: We’re more united in our outlook about our country’s institutions. There is rising and perhaps unexpected alignment between Americans of different walks of life, from left to right. Granted, this alignment may at first glance seem like a problem, for what unites us, increasingly, is what we distrust. But consider this: We have thought of ourselves as so divided for so long, might there be some upside to starting the new year knowing we aren’t quite as polarized as we thought and that people with whom we assumed we had nothing in common also believe our institutions must do better?

headline: Chinese Companies Have Sidestepped Trump’s Tariffs. They Could Do It Again.
abstract: The companies have found plenty of new channels to the U.S. market — demonstrating the potential limits of the tariffs Donald Trump has promised to impose.
lead_paragraph: After President Donald J. Trump slapped tariffs on Chinese bicycles in 2018, Arnold Kamler, then the chief executive of the bike maker Kent International, saw a curious trend play out in the bicycle industry.

headline: Carter’s Mission to Build More Housing Became an Urgent National Issue
abstract: After Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter linked themselves to Habitat for Humanity, it grew and built homes for millions. Now, their cause is a national crisis.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter was set to attend a home-building event with Habitat for Humanity in Nashville in 2019 when he fell and hit his head at home in Georgia. He emerged from the hospital with a black eye and 14 stitches, but he refused to cancel his plans.

headline: The Year in Books
abstract: Our Book Review staff on the best of 2024.
lead_paragraph: As 2024 comes to a close, critics, reporters and editors at The New York Times are reflecting on the year in arts and culture, including books.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,292
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 1, 2025.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: China Hacks the Treasury Dept., and a Hydropower Crisis
abstract: Plus, what you might be eating in 2025.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 570
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 1, 2025.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Edinburgh’s Epic New Year’s Eve Street Party Is Canceled Because of Weather
abstract: The outdoor Hogmanay festivities were called off in Scotland’s capital as forecasters warned of rain, strong winds and snow across Britain.
lead_paragraph: The famed Hogmanay street party on New Year’s Eve in Edinburgh, the Scottish capital, has been canceled because of forecasts of rain, strong winds and snow.

headline: He Didn’t Know His Father Was on the Doomed Flight Until It Crashed
abstract: Oh Jaejin’s father, 64, had not told Mr. Oh he was flying, because he didn’t want his son to worry. They had been looking forward to his becoming a grandfather.
lead_paragraph: Days before setting off on a vacation from which he would never return, Oh Jaejin’s father had been overjoyed at the prospect of becoming a grandfather after Mr. Oh told him that his wife was pregnant.

headline: U.S. Strikes Militant Group in Yemen That Has Kept Up Attacks on Ships
abstract: The Houthis, who are backed by Iran, have targeted commercial ships in the Red Sea in solidarity with Hamas in Gaza. They launched a missile at Israel overnight.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military said on Tuesday that it had carried out a series of strikes on the Houthis, the Iranian-backed group in Yemen, as the group suggested it would continue attacking Israel and ships in the Red Sea if there was no cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Tracking War Crimes in Sudan
abstract: Inside a six-month Times investigation.
lead_paragraph: Sudan’s military and a powerful paramilitary — both armed by foreign powers — have spent almost two years at war, and their battle has laid waste to the country. Many tens of thousands of civilians have been killed. Close to 12 million people have been displaced. There is famine.

headline: The Atlantic Beefs Up Politics Coverage Under Trump
abstract: The magazine is recruiting from a crosstown rival, The Washington Post, to bolster its political staff.
lead_paragraph: As news organizations gear up to cover President-elect Donald J. Trump’s return to the White House, The Atlantic is going big to cover the story.

headline: Most of Puerto Rico Is Darkened by New Year’s Eve Blackout
abstract: Only a fraction of the island’s 1.4 million utility customers had power on Tuesday morning. The electricity provider said it would take 24 to 48 hours to restore power.
lead_paragraph: A sweeping blackout hit Puerto Rico early Tuesday morning, plunging nearly all of the island into darkness on New Year’s Eve.

headline: Wall Street Sees More Gains Ahead After Another Bumper Year for Stocks
abstract: The S&P 500 is set to post back-to-back annual gains of more than 20 percent for the first time since the late 1990s. Analysts expect stocks to continue rising in 2025.
lead_paragraph: Investors are heading into 2025 in an optimistic mood, believing that with the economy on a firm footing and the White House in their corner, the stock market will continue to climb.

headline: New Year’s 2025: Celebrations Around the World
abstract: See how people across the globe celebrated.
lead_paragraph: In plazas and parks and bars and homes across the globe, people gathered to commemorate the end of 2024 and welcome the New Year. Bold swimmers plunged into a frigid lake in Switzerland, joggers in Poland took one last whimsical run of the year and fireworks crackled in cities large and small.

headline: Give Chicken Breasts a Chance
abstract: And more cooking plans (with corresponding recipes) I have for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone! Mia here, filling in for Emily Weinstein today. (Ali Slagle will be with you next week!)

headline: From Grand Gestures to Intimate Moments: 10 Memorable Proposals
abstract: There was no shortage of creative engagements for couples who married in 2024. Here are some of the standouts that appeared in The New York Times’s Wedding section.
lead_paragraph: A “Sleeping Beauty” photo shoot. A photo book hidden in a bookstore. A proposal three minutes after a fight.

headline: Moviegoers Dealt Originality a Setback in 2024
abstract: Box office returns have started to stabilize. But nine of the top 10 box office hits this year were sequels. And the 10th was “Wicked.”
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Hollywood’s creative community was celebrating the apparent decline of corporate, paint-by-numbers sequels and remakes. Blockbuster ticket sales for movies like “Oppenheimer,” “Sound of Freedom” and “Barbie” had shown — or so it seemed — that audiences were finally hungry for fresh stories.

headline: $850 for a Table at Applebee’s? Welcome to Times Square on New Year’s Eve.
abstract: As revelers throng Midtown Manhattan, some chain restaurants are offering a respite, if a pricey one. Perks include bathroom access and unlimited breadsticks.
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, Times Square on New Year’s Eve brings to mind one word: Nope.

headline: Making a Cooking Resolution? These Recipes Will Get You Started.
abstract: If you’ve decided to get great at meal prep, waste less food or just eat breakfast, here are tips and dishes to set you up for success.
lead_paragraph: In 2025, there’s room for improvement. That room is the kitchen. Second only to our places of work, it hosts a good chunk of our waking hours — making it a natural focal point of annual resolution-making. Maybe last year you aspired to more baking, more meatless cooking, or simply more cooking, period. If you need ideas for the new year, below are a handful of goals, shared among members of the New York Times Cooking and Food staff, along with recipes to keep you on track for success.

headline: Pulling Back From the Nuclear Brink
abstract: Some ways to lessen the world’s most deadly risk. Also: The debate over work visas; unreliable polls; cruelty and Christianity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Victim of Coney Island Subway Immolation Is Identified by the Police
abstract: Debrina Kawam of Toms River, N.J., was burned alive on Dec. 22 in a videotaped killing that shocked New York.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have learned the name of a woman who was burned alive — and beyond recognizability — aboard a Brooklyn train last week.
